original: . Namo tassa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa.
analyzed: namaḥ tassa bhagavataḥ arahataḥ sammāsambuddhassa
translated: Homage to the Blessed One, the Arahant, the Perfectly Enlightened One.

original: Aṅguttaranikāye
analyzed: aṅguttara nikāye
translated: In the Numerical Collection

original: Dukanipāta-aṭṭhakathā🔽1. Paṭhamapaṇṇāsakaṃ
analyzed: duka nipāta aṭṭhakathā  paṭhama paṇṇāsakam
translated: Commentary on the Twos Collection🔽The First Fifty🔽The Chapter on Punishment

original: 1. Kammakāraṇavaggo🔽1. Vajjasuttavaṇṇanā🔽1. Dukanipātassa paṭhame vajjānīti dosā aparādhā. Diṭṭhadhammikanti diṭṭheva dhamme
analyzed: kamma kāraṇa vaggo  vajja sutta vaṇṇanā  duka nipātassa paṭhame vajjāni iti dosāḥ aparādhāḥ diṭṭhadhammikanti diṭṭhe iva dhamme
translated: The Discourse on Faults

original: imasmiṃyeva attabhāve uppannaphalaṃ. Samparāyikanti samparāye anāgate attabhāve uppannaphalaṃ.
analyzed: imasmin yeva atta bhāve uppanna phalam samparāyikam ti samparāye anāgate atta bhāve uppanna phalam
translated: In the first discourse in the Twos Collection, “faults” are hatreds, offenses. “In the here and now” means in this very life, in this very existence, the fruit that has arisen. “In the life to come” means the fruit that will arise in the future life.

original: Āgucārinti pāpakāriṃ aparādhakārakaṃ. Rājāno gahetvā vividhā kammakāraṇā kārenteti
analyzed: pāpa kārim aparādha kārakam rājānaḥ gahetvā vividhā kamma kāraṇā kārenta iti
translated: “The evildoer” is the evil-doer, the offender. “The king’s men, having seized him, inflict various punishments”

original: coraṃ gahetvā vividhā kammakāraṇā rājapurisā karonti, rājāno pana tā kārenti nāma.
analyzed: coram gahetvā vividhā kamma kāraṇā rāja purisā karonti rājāno pana tā kārenti nāma
translated: means that the king’s men, having seized the thief, inflict various punishments. But the kings are called those who cause them to be inflicted.

original: Taṃ coraṃ evaṃ kammakāraṇā kāriyamānaṃ esa passati. Tena vuttaṃ – “passati coraṃ
analyzed: tam coram evam kamma kāraṇā kāriyamānam esa passati tena vuttam passati coram
translated: He sees that thief being punished in this way. Therefore it is said: “He sees the evildoer

original: āgucāriṃ rājāno gahetvā vividhā kammakāraṇā kārente”ti. Addhadaṇḍakehīti muggarehi,
analyzed: āgucārim rājānaḥ gahetvā vividhā kamma kāraṇā kārentā iti addhadaṇḍakehi iti muggarehi
translated: the king’s men, having seized him, inflict various punishments.” “With half-measures” means with beans,

original: pahārasādhanatthaṃ vā catuhatthadaṇḍaṃ dvedhā chetvā gahitadaṇḍakehi. Bilaṅgathālikanti🔽kañjiyaukkhalikakammakāraṇaṃ. Taṃ karontā sīsakaṭāhaṃ uppāṭetvā tattaṃ ayoguḷaṃ saṇḍāsena
analyzed: pahāra sādhana ttham vā catuhattha daṇḍam dvedhā chetvā gahita daṇḍakehi  kañji yaukkhalika kamma kāraṇam tam karontā sīsa kaṭāham uppāṭetvā tat tam ayaḥ guḷam saṇḍāsena
translated: Or else, for the purpose of punishment, they cut a four-cubit stick in two and make them hold the sticks while they are being beaten. “The ‘bilva-fruit-eating’ punishment:🔽for the purpose of making them work at a smith’s forge. They make them remove the caul from their heads, take a red-hot ball of iron with their hands wrapped in cloth,

original: gahetvā tattha pakkhipanti, tena matthaluṅgaṃ pakkuthitvā uttarati. Saṅkhamuṇḍikanti
analyzed: gahetvā tattha pakkhipanti tena mattha luṅgam pakkuthitvā uttarati saṅkhamuṇḍikam ti
translated: and put it there. The brain boils and rises to the top. “The ‘conch-shell-head’ punishment:

original: saṅkhamuṇḍakammakāraṇaṃ. Taṃ karontā uttaroṭṭhaubhatokaṇṇacūḷikagalavāṭakaparicchedena
analyzed: saṅkha muṇḍa kamma kāraṇam tam karontāḥ uttara uṭṭhaubha tokaṇṇa cūḷika galavāṭaka paricchedena
translated: for the purpose of making them work as barbers. They make them cut the skin from their heads, leaving a strip of skin at the back of the neck,

original: cammaṃ chinditvā sabbakese ekato gaṇṭhiṃ katvā daṇḍakena veṭhetvā uppāṭenti, saha🔽kesehi cammaṃ uṭṭhahati. Tato sīsakaṭāhaṃ thūlasakkharāhi ghaṃsitvā dhovantā saṅkhavaṇṇaṃ🔽karonti. Rāhumukhanti rāhumukhakammakāraṇaṃ. Taṃ karontā saṅkunā mukhaṃ vivaritvā
analyzed: cammam chinditvā sabba kese ekatas gaṇṭhim katvā daṇḍakena veṭhetvā uppāṭenti saha  kesehi cammam uṭṭhahati tatas sīsa kaṭāham thūla sakkharāhi ghaṃsitvā dhovantā saṅkha vaṇṇam  karonti rāhumukham ti rāhumukha kamma kāraṇam tam karontā saṅkunā mukham vivaritvā
translated: and then they tie all the hair together, wrap it with a stick, and pull it out. The skin comes out together with the hair.🔽Then they pound the skull with a heavy pestle and wash it, making it white like a conch shell. “The ‘Rahu-mouth’ punishment:🔽for the purpose of making them work as barbers. They make them open their mouths with a pair of pincers,

original: antomukhe dīpaṃ jālenti, kaṇṇacūḷikāhi vā paṭṭhāya mukhaṃ nikhādanena khananti, lohitaṃ
analyzed: antar mukhe dīpam kaṇṇacūḷikāhi vā paṭṭhāya mukham nikhādanena khananti lohitam
translated: put a lamp inside their mouths, and dig out their mouths starting from the gums, until blood comes out.

original: paggharitvā mukhaṃ pūreti.🔽Jotimālikanti sakalasarīraṃ telapilotikāya veṭhetvā ālimpenti. Hatthapajjotikanti
analyzed: paggharitvā mukham pūra iti  joti mālikanti sakala sarīram tela pilotikāya veṭhetvā ālimpenti hattha pajjotikanti
translated: and it falls into his mouth.

original: hatthe telapilotikāya veṭhetvā dīpaṃ viya pajjālenti. Erakavattikanti erakavattakammakāraṇaṃ.🔽Taṃ karontā heṭṭhāgīvato paṭṭhāya cammavaṭṭe kantitvā gopphake ṭhapenti, atha naṃ
analyzed: hatthe tela pilotikāya veṭhetvā dīpam viya pajjālenti erakavattikam ti eraka vatta kamma kāraṇam  tam karontā heṭṭhāgīvataḥ paṭṭhāya camma vaṭṭe kantitvā gopphake ṭhapenti atha naṃ
translated: The ‘torch-bearer’ is one who wraps his whole body in a piece of cloth soaked in oil and sets it alight. The ‘hand- torch’ is one who, having wrapped his hand in a piece of cloth soaked in oil, lights it like a torch. The ‘razor-edged blade’ is one who makes a razor-edged blade.🔽Having had his skin flayed from his body starting from the throat, he is made to stand on his feet.

original: yottehi bandhitvā kaḍḍhanti. So attano cammavaṭṭe akkamitvā akkamitvā patati. Cīrakavāsikanti🔽cīrakavāsikakammakāraṇaṃ. Taṃ karontā tatheva cammavaṭṭe kantitvā kaṭiyaṃ ṭhapenti,🔽kaṭito paṭṭhāya kantitvā gopphakesu ṭhapenti, uparimehi heṭṭhimasarīraṃ cīrakanivāsananivatthaṃ
analyzed: yottehi bandhitvā kaḍḍhanti saḥ attano camma vaṭṭe akkamitvā akkamitvā patati cīrakavāsikanti  cīrakavāsika kamma kāraṇam tam karontā tathā iva camma vaṭṭe kantitvā kaṭiyam ṭhapenti  kaṭitaḥ paṭṭhāya kantitvā gopphakesu ṭhapenti uparimehi heṭṭhima sarīram cīraka nivāsana nivattham
translated: Then they bind him with ropes and pull him. He falls down, dragging his skin over his body. The ‘bark-robe’ is one who makes a bark-robe.🔽Having had his skin flayed from his body in the same way, he is made to stand on his hips.

original: viya hoti. Eṇeyyakanti eṇeyyakakammakāraṇaṃ. Taṃ karontā ubhosu kapparesu ca ubhosu
analyzed: viya hoti eṇeyyakanti eṇeyyaka kamma kāraṇam tam karontāḥ ubhosu kapparesu ca ubhosu
translated: Having had it flayed from his hips, he is made to stand on his ankles. The upper part of his body is like a piece of bark worn as a loin-cloth. The ‘antelope’ is one who makes an antelope. Having had his skin flayed from his body starting from both heels and both knees,

original: jāṇukesu ca ayavalayāni datvā ayasūlāni koṭṭenti. So catūhi ayasūlehi bhūmiyaṃ patiṭṭhahati.
analyzed: jāṇukesu ca aya valayāni datvā aya sūlāni koṭṭenti saḥ catūhi aya sūlehi bhūmiyam patiṭṭhahati
translated: and they put iron fetters on his legs and iron chains round his body and drive iron spikes through his sides. He falls to the ground on the four spikes.

original: Atha naṃ parivāretvā aggiṃ karonti. “Eṇeyyako jotipariggaho yathā”ti āgataṭṭhānepi
analyzed: atha nam parivāretvā aggim karonti eṇeyyakaḥ joti pariggahaḥ yathā ati āgata ṭṭhāne pi
translated: Then they surround him and make a fire, as in the passage beginning, “The fire-making by friction simile.”

original: idameva vuttaṃ. Taṃ kālena kālaṃ sūlāni apanetvā catūhi aṭṭhikoṭīhiyeva ṭhapenti.
analyzed: idam eva vuttam tam kālena kālam sūlāni apanetvā catūhi aṭṭhi koṭīhi yeva ṭhapenti
translated: At intervals they remove the spikes and leave him on the four buttocks.

original: Evarūpā kammakāraṇā nāma natthi.🔽Baḷisamaṃsikanti ubhatomukhehi baḷisehi paharitvā cammamaṃsanhārūni uppāṭenti. Kahāpaṇikanti🔽sakalasarīraṃ tiṇhāhi vāsīhi koṭito paṭṭhāya kahāpaṇamattaṃ, kahāpaṇamattaṃ pātentā
analyzed: evarūpā kamma kāraṇā nāma natthi  baḷisa maṃsikanti ubhatomukhehi baḷisehi paharitvā camma maṃsa nhārūni uppāṭenti kahāpaṇikanti  sakala sarīram tiṇhāhi vāsīhi koṭitaḥ paṭṭhāya kahāpaṇa mattam kahāpaṇa mattam pātentā
translated: There is no such thing as a punishment like this.🔽The saw-horses: they strike him with saws at both ends and tear off his skin, flesh and sinews. The coins:🔽they cut him up into coins’ worth, starting from the skin, and take away a coins’ worth, a coins’ worth.

original: koṭṭenti. Khārāpatacchikanti sarīraṃ tattha tattha āvudhehi paharitvā kocchehi khāraṃ
analyzed: sarīram tattha tattha āvudhehi paharitvā kocchehi khāram
translated: The lye-pot: they strike him here and there with weapons and pour lye into the wounds,

original: ghaṃsanti, cammamaṃsanhārūni paggharitvā aṭṭhikasaṅkhalikāva tiṭṭhati. Palighaparivattikanti
analyzed: ghaṃsanti camma maṃsa nhārūni paggharitvā aṭṭhika saṅkhalikā iva tiṭṭhati paligha parivattikam ti
translated: and the skin, flesh and sinews melt away and only the skeleton remains. The turning-joint:

original: ekena passena nipajjāpetvā kaṇṇacchiddena ayasūlaṃ koṭṭetvā pathaviyā ekābaddhaṃ🔽karonti. Atha naṃ pāde gahetvā āviñchanti. Palālapīṭhakanti cheko kāraṇiko chavicammaṃ
analyzed: ekena passena nipajjāpetvā kaṇṇa chiddena aya sūlam koṭṭetvā pathaviyā eka ābaddham  karonti atha nam pāde gahetvā āviñchanti palāla pīṭhakanti chekaḥ kāraṇiko chavi cammaṃ
translated: They make him lie on his side, and with a saw with iron teeth they cut off his ears.

original: acchinditvā nisadapotehi aṭṭhīni bhinditvā kesesu gahetvā ukkhipati, maṃsarāsiyeva
analyzed: a chinditvā nisada potehi aṭṭhīni bhinditvā kesesu gahetvā ukkhipati maṃsa rāsiyā iva
translated: Then they take him by the feet and turn him over. A bed of embers: a clever butcher cuts off the hide, breaks the bones with hatchets, and seizes the flesh with his hands.🔽It is like a piece of meat.

original: hoti. Atha naṃ keseheva pariyonandhitvā gaṇhanti, palālavaṭṭiṃ viya katvā puna veṭhenti.
analyzed: atha nam kesehi iva gaṇhanti palāla vaṭṭim katvā punar veṭhenti
translated: Then they seize it by the hair, wrap it up, and put it back again.

original: Sunakhehipīti katipayāni divasāni āhāraṃ adatvā chātakasunakhehi khādāpenti. Te muhuttena
analyzed: katipayāni divasāni āhāram a datvā chātaka sunakhehi khādāpenti te muhuttena
translated: Dogs: after not giving him any food for several days, they make him be devoured by famished dogs. They make a skeleton

original: aṭṭhikasaṅkhalikameva karonti. Sūle uttāsenteti sūle āropente.
analyzed: aṭṭhika saṅkhalikam eva karonti sūle uttāsenta iti sūle āropente
translated: in a moment. They impale him on the stake: they put him on the stake.

original: Na paresaṃ pābhataṃ vilumpanto caratīti paresaṃ santakaṃ bhaṇḍaṃ parammukhaṃ ābhataṃ
analyzed: na paresam pābhatam vilumpantaḥ carati iti paresam santakam bhaṇḍam parammukham ābhatam
translated: He does not go about plundering the property of others: he does not go about plundering the property of others, the property of others that has been stored away,

original: antamaso antaravīthiyaṃ patitaṃ sahassabhaṇḍikampi disvā “iminā jīvissāmī”ti vilumpanto
analyzed: antamasaḥ antara vīthiyam patitam sahassa bhaṇḍikam pi disvā iminā jīvissāmi iti vilumpantaḥ
translated: even if he sees a thousand coins fallen on the public road, thinking, “By this I will live.”

original: na vicarati, ko iminā atthoti piṭṭhipādena vā pavaṭṭetvā gacchati.
analyzed: na vicarati kaḥ iminā attho ti piṭṭhi pādena vā pavaṭṭetvā gacchati
translated: He does not move about, thinking, “Who needs this?” He goes about turning on his heels.

original: Pāpakoti lāmako. Dukkhoti aniṭṭho. Kiñca tanti kiṃ nāma taṃ kāraṇaṃ bhaveyya. Yāhanti🔽yena ahaṃ. Kāyaduccaritanti pāṇātipātādi tividhaṃ akusalaṃ kāyakammaṃ. Kāyasucaritanti
analyzed: pāpakoti lāmako dukkhoti aniṭṭho kiñca kim nāma tam kāraṇam bhaveyya yā aham ti  yena aham kāya duccaritanti pāṇa atipāta ādi tividham akusalam kāya kammam kāya su caritanti
translated: “Bad” means inferior. “Painful” means undesirable. “Why?” means “What is the reason?”

original: tassa paṭipakkhabhūtaṃ tividhaṃ kusalakammaṃ. Vacīduccaritanti musāvādādi catubbidhaṃ
analyzed: tassa paṭipakkha bhūtam tividham kusala kammam vacī duccaritan ti musāvāda ādi catubbidham
translated: “By which” means by which I. “Bad conduct by body” means the three kinds of unwholesome bodily action beginning with killing living beings. “Good conduct by body” means the three kinds of wholesome action that are the opposites of these.

original: akusalaṃ vacīkammaṃ. Vacīsucaritanti tassa paṭipakkhabhūtaṃ catubbidhaṃ kusalakammaṃ.🔽Manoduccaritanti abhijjhādi tividhaṃ akusalakammaṃ. Manosucaritanti tassa paṭipakkhabhūtaṃ
analyzed: akusalam vacī kammam vacī su caritanti tassa paṭipakkha bhūtam catubbidham kusala kammaṃ  manaḥ duccaritanti abhijjhā ādi tividham akusala kammam manaḥ su caritanti tassa paṭipakkha bhūtam
translated: “Bad conduct by speech” means the four kinds of unwholesome verbal action beginning with false speech. “Good conduct by speech” means the four kinds of wholesome action that are the opposites of these.🔽“Bad conduct by mind” means the three kinds of unwholesome mental action beginning with covetousness. “Good conduct by mind” means the three kinds of wholesome mental action that are the opposites of these.

original: tividhaṃ kusalakammaṃ. Suddhaṃ attānaṃ pariharatīti ettha duvidhā suddhi – pariyāyato
analyzed: tividham kusala kammam suddham attānam pariharati iti ettha duvidhā suddhi
translated: “Keeping himself pure”: here there are two kinds of purity,

original: ca nippariyāyato ca. Saraṇagamanena hi pariyāyena suddhaṃ attānaṃ pariharati nāma.
analyzed: ca ca saraṇa gamanena hi pariyāyena suddham attānam pariharati nāma
translated: by way of the proximate cause and by way of the ultimate goal. By going for refuge one keeps himself pure by way of the proximate cause.

original: Tathā pañcahi sīlehi, dasahi sīlehi – catupārisuddhisīlena, paṭhamajjhānena…pe… nevasaññānāsaññāyatanena,
analyzed: tathā pañcahi sīlehi dasahi sīlehi catu pārisuddhi sīlena paṭhama jhānena pe nevasaññānāsaññāyatanena
translated: Likewise, by means of the five precepts, the ten precepts, the precepts purified in four ways, the first jhāna, … the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception,

original: sotāpattimaggena, sotāpattiphalena…pe… arahattamaggena pariyāyena suddhaṃ attānaṃ
analyzed: sotāpatti maggena sotāpatti phalena pe arahatta maggena pariyāyena suddham attānam
translated: the path of stream-entry, the fruit of stream-entry, … the path of arahatship, he maintains himself in purity by way of a roundabout method.

original: pariharati nāma. Arahattaphale patiṭṭhito pana khīṇāsavo chinnamūlake pañcakkhandhe
analyzed: pariharati nāma arahatta phale patiṭṭhitaḥ pana khīṇa āsavaḥ chinna mūlake pañca kkhandhe
translated: But when he is established in the fruit of arahatship, then, as one whose cankers are destroyed, he maintains himself in purity, in immaculacy, by the direct method,

original: nhāpentopi khādāpentopi bhuñjāpentopi nisīdāpentopi nipajjāpentopi nippariyāyeneva🔽suddhaṃ nimmalaṃ attānaṃ pariharati paṭijaggatīti veditabbo.
analyzed: nhāpentaḥ upi khādāpentaḥ upi bhuñjāpentaḥ upi nisīdāpentaḥ upi nipajjāpentaḥ upi nippariyāyena iva  suddham nimmalam attānam pariharati paṭijaggati iti veditabbaḥ
translated: whether he bathes the five aggregates that are like a corpse, or feeds them, or makes them sit down, or makes them lie down.

original: Tasmāti yasmā imāni dve vajjāneva, no na vajjāni, tasmā. Vajjabhīrunoti vajjabhīrukā.
analyzed: tasmā iti yasmai imāni dve vajjānā iva naḥ na vajjāni tasmai vajja bhīrunā iti vajja bhīrukā
translated: Therefore, since these are only two kinds of sin, not non-sin, he is called “frightened of sin.”

original: Vajjabhayadassāvinoti vajjāni bhayato dassanasīlā. Etaṃ pāṭikaṅkhanti etaṃ icchitabbaṃ,
analyzed: vajja bhaya dassāvino ti vajjāni bhayataḥ dassana sīlāḥ etam pāṭikaṅkhanti etam icchitabbam
translated: He is “one who sees fear in what is fearful” because he has the habit of seeing sin as fearful. “This is to be expected” means “this is to be desired,”

original: etaṃ avassaṃbhāvīti attho. Yanti nipātamattaṃ, kāraṇavacanaṃ vā yena kāraṇena parimuccissati
analyzed: etam avassaṃbhāvi iti atthaḥ yanti nipāta mattam kāraṇa vacanam vā yena kāraṇena parimuccissati
translated: “this is to be hoped for.” The word y means “for what reason,” “for what cause” he will be liberated.

original: sabbavajjehi. Kena pana kāraṇena parimuccissatīti? Catutthamaggena ceva catutthaphalena🔽ca. Maggena hi parimuccati nāma, phalaṃ patto parimutto nāma hotīti. Kiṃ pana khīṇāsavassa🔽akusalaṃ na vipaccatīti? Vipaccati, taṃ pana khīṇāsavabhāvato pubbe kataṃ. Tañca
analyzed: sabbavajjehi kena pana kāraṇena parimuccissati iti catuttha maggena ca iva catuttha phalena  ca maggena hi parimuccati nāma phalam pattaḥ parimuttaḥ nāma hoti iti kim pana khīṇāsavassa  akusalam na vipaccati iti vipaccati tat pana khīṇāsava bhāvato pubbe katam tat ca
translated: By all kinds of blame. But by what means will he be delivered? By the fourth path and by the fourth fruit. For it is by means of the path that one is said to be delivered, and when he has reached the fruit he is said to be delivered. But does no unprofitable kamma ripen for one whose cankers are destroyed? It does ripen, but it is done before he becomes one whose cankers are destroyed.

original: kho imasmiṃyeva attabhāve, samparāye panassa kammaphalaṃ nāma natthīti. Paṭhamaṃ.
analyzed: kho imasmiṃ yeva atta bhāve samparāye panassa kamma phalam nāma natthi iti paṭhamam
translated: By all kinds of blame. But by what means will he be freed? By the fourth path and by the fourth fruit. For it is by means of the path that he is said to be freed, and when he has reached the fruit he is called “freed.” But will no unprofitable kamma of one whose cankers are destroyed ripen? It does ripen, but it is made by him before he becomes one whose cankers are destroyed. And that ripens in this present existence only; there is no ripening of kamma for him in the life to come. First.

original: 2. Padhānasuttavaṇṇanā🔽2. Dutiye padhānānīti vīriyāni. Vīriyañhi padahitabbato padhānabhāvakaraṇato vā padhānanti🔽vuccati. Durabhisambhavānīti dussahāni duppūriyāni, dukkarānīti attho. Agāraṃ ajjhāvasatanti
analyzed: padhāna sutta vaṇṇanā  dutiye padhānāni iti vīriyāni vīriyam hi padahitabbataḥ padhāna bhāva karaṇataḥ vā padhānanti  vuccati durabhisambhavāni iti dussahāni duppūriyāni dukkarāni iti attho agāram
translated: . The second section for recitation on energy

original: agāre vasantānaṃ. Cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānapaccayabhesajjaparikkhārānuppadānatthaṃ
analyzed: agāre vasantānam cīvara piṇḍapāta senāsana gilāna paccaya bhesajja parikkhāra an uppadāna attham
translated: In the second section, the “efforts” are the energies. For energy is called “effort” because it is to be exerted and because it causes the state of exertion to arise. “Hard to surmount”: hard to overcome, hard to fulfil; the meaning is, hard to do. “While living in a home”: for those who live in a home. “For the sake of the requisites of robes, alms food, resting place, and medicine for the sick”

original: padhānanti etesaṃ cīvarādīnaṃ catunnaṃ paccayānaṃ anuppadānatthāya padhānaṃ nāma🔽durabhisambhavanti dasseti. Caturatanikampi hi pilotikaṃ, pasatataṇḍulamattaṃ vā🔽bhattaṃ, caturatanikaṃ vā paṇṇasālaṃ, telasappinavanītādīsu vā appamattakampi bhesajjaṃ
analyzed: padhānam ti etesam cīvara ādīnam catunnam paccayānam an uppadāna atthāya padhānam nāma  durabhisambhavanti dasseti catur atanikam pi hi pilotikam pasata taṇḍula mattam vā  bhattam caturatanikam vā paṇṇa sālam tela sappi navanīta ādīsu vā appa mattakam pi bhesajjam
translated: Padhana : the striving for the non-arising of the four requisites of robes, etc.

original: paresaṃ dethāti vattumpi nīharitvā dātumpi dukkaraṃ ubhatobyūḷhasaṅgāmappavesanasadisaṃ. Tenāha bhagavā –
analyzed: paresam detha iti vattum pi nīharitvā dātum pi dukkaram ubhatas byūḍha saṅgāma pavesana sadisam tena āha bhagavā
translated: Durbhisambhava : it shows that it is difficult to attain. For it is difficult to give to others, even to the extent of a quarter or half of a meal of rice with curry, or a quarter or half of a leaf-hut, or even a little medicine such as oil, jaggery, or fresh butter, even to the extent of saying, “Give this.”🔽Therefore the Blessed One said:

original: “Dānañca yuddhañca samānamāhu,
analyzed: dānam ca yuddhañca samānam āhu
translated: “Giving and fighting are said to be the same;

original: Appāpi santā bahuke jinanti;
analyzed: appā api santā bahuke jinanti
translated: Even a few can conquer many;

original: Appampi ce saddahāno dadāti,
analyzed: appam ce saddahānaḥ dadāti
translated: If one has faith and gives a little,

original: Teneva so hoti sukhī paratthā”ti. ;🔽Agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajitānanti gehato nikkhamitvā agārassa gharāvāsassa hitāvahehi
analyzed: tena iva saḥ hoti sukhī parattha ati  agārasma anagāriyam gehataḥ nikkhamitvā agārassa ghara āvāsassa
translated: By that he becomes happy in the next world.”🔽Pabbajitānāgāriyaṃ : having gone forth from home to homelessness, having gone forth from the home life to homelessness.

original: kasigorakkhādīhi virahitaṃ anagāriyaṃ pabbajjaṃ upagatānaṃ. Sabbūpadhipaṭinissaggatthāya
analyzed: kasi gorakkha ādīhi virahitam anagāriyam pabbajjam upagatānam sabba upadhi paṭinissagga tthāya
translated: For the purpose of relinquishing all attachments,

original: padhānanti sabbesaṃ khandhūpadhikilesūpadhiabhisaṅkhārūpadhisaṅkhātānaṃ upadhīnaṃ
analyzed: padhānam ti sabbesam khandhu upadhi kilesu upadhi abhisaṅkhāra upadhi saṅkhātānam upadhīnam
translated: ‘Striving’: the striving of all the defilements, the striving of the cankers, the striving of the determinations, the striving of the determinations called ‘clinging’.🔽

original: paṭinissaggasaṅkhātassa nibbānassa atthāya vipassanāya ceva maggena ca sahajātavīriyaṃ.
analyzed: paṭinissagga saṅkhātassa nibbānassa atthāya vipassanāya ca iva maggena ca sahajāta vīriyam
translated: Striving: energy conascent with insight and the path, for the purpose of Nibbāna, which is called the “surrendering” of all the kinds of clinging called clinging to sense desires, clinging to views, clinging to rules and vows, and clinging to a doctrine of self .

original: Tasmāti yasmā imāni dve padhānāni durabhisambhavāni, tasmā. Dutiyaṃ.
analyzed: tasmāt ati yasmai imāni dve padhānāni durabhisambhavāni tasmai dutiyam
translated: Therefore: because these two kinds of striving are difficult to accomplish. The second tetrad is finished.

original: 3. Tapanīyasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: tapanīya sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . The exposition of the second tetrad

original: 3. Tatiye tapanīyāti idha ceva samparāye ca tapantīti tapanīyā. Tappatīti cittasantāpena
analyzed: tatiye tapanīyā ati idha ca iva samparāye ca tapanti iti tapanīyā tappati iti citta santāpena
translated: . In the third tetrad, tormenting here and in the afterlife are “torments” . He torments himself is he torments himself with the torment of consciousness,

original: tappati anusocati kāyaduccaritaṃ katvā nandayakkho viya nandamāṇavo viya nandagoghātako
analyzed: tappati anusocati kāya duccaritam katvā nanda yakkhaḥ viya nandamāṇavaḥ viya nanda go ghātako
translated: grieves, laments, and beating his breast he weeps, like the ghost Nandaka, like the young brāhmaṇa Nanda, like the cow-killer Nanda,

original: viya devadatto viya dvebhātikā viya ca. Te kira gāvaṃ vadhitvā maṃsaṃ dve koṭṭhāse
analyzed: viya devadattaḥ viya dvebhātikā viya ca te kira gāvam vadhitvā maṃsam dve koṭṭhāse
translated: like Devadatta, and like the two brothers. They killed a cow, it seems, and divided it into two parts.

original: akaṃsu. Tato kaniṭṭho jeṭṭhakaṃ āha – “mayhaṃ dārakā bahū, imāni me antāni dehī”ti.
analyzed: tatas kaniṭṭhaḥ jeṭṭhakam āha mayham dārakāḥ bahū imāni me antāni dehi iti
translated: Then the younger one said to the elder, “I have many children. Give me the choice bits.”

original: Atha naṃ so “sabbaṃ maṃsaṃ dvedhā vibhattaṃ, puna kiṃ maggasī”ti paharitvā jīvitakkhayaṃ
analyzed: atha nam saḥ sabbam maṃsam dvedhā vibhattam puna kim maggasi iti paharitvā jīvita khayam
translated: Then the elder said, “The whole of the meat has been divided into two parts. What more do you want?” and he struck him down and killed him.

original: pāpesi. Nivattitvā ca naṃ olokento mataṃ disvā “bhāriyaṃ me kammaṃ kata”nti cittaṃ🔽uppādesi. Athassa balavasoko uppajji. So ṭhitaṭṭhānepi nisinnaṭṭhānepi tadeva kammaṃ
analyzed: nivattitvā ca nam olokentaḥ matam disvā bhāriyam me kammam katanti cittam  uppādesi atha assa balava sokaḥ uppajji saḥ ṭhita ṭṭhāne pi nisinna ṭṭhāne pi tat eva kammaṃ
translated: and he killed him. Turning back, he saw that the man was dead. Then he thought, “I have done a terrible deed.”

original: āvajjeti, cittassādaṃ na labhati. Asitapītakhāyitasāyitampissa sarīre ojaṃ na pharati,
analyzed: āvajjeti citta ssādam na labhati sarīre ojam na pharati
translated: And he became very sorrowful. Wherever he stood or sat, he kept on thinking about the deed he had done. He could not get rid of his thoughts, and the food and drink he took did not agree with him.

original: aṭṭhicammamattameva ahosi. Atha naṃ eko thero disvā – “upāsaka, tvaṃ pahūtaannapāno,
analyzed: aṭṭhi camma mattam eva ahosi atha nam ekaḥ theraḥ disvā upāsaka tvam pahūta anna pāno
translated: His flesh and blood wasted away, and only his bones and sinews remained. A certain elder saw him and said, “Layman, you have plenty of food and drink.

original: aṭṭhicammamattameva te avasiṭṭhaṃ, atthi nu kho te kiñci tapanīyakamma”nti? So “āma,
analyzed: aṭṭhi camma mattam eva te avasiṭṭham atthi nu kho te kiñci tapanīya kammanti saḥ
translated: Why is it that only your bones and sinews remain? Have you done any reprehensible deed?” The layman replied, “Yes, I have.”

original: bhante”ti sabbaṃ ārocesi. Atha naṃ thero “bhāriyaṃ te upāsaka kammaṃ kataṃ, anaparādhaṭṭhāne
analyzed: bhante iti sabbam ārocesi atha nam theraḥ bhāriyam te upāsaka kammam katam anaparādha ṭṭhāne
translated: And he told the whole story. The elder said, “Layman, you have done a terrible deed. You have sinned where you ought not to have sinned.”🔽As a result of this deed, the layman was reborn in hell.

original: aparaddha”nti āha. So teneva kammena kālaṃ katvā niraye nibbatto. Vacīduccaritena
analyzed: aparaddham iti āha saḥ tena iva kammena kālam katvā niraye nibbattaḥ vacī duccaritena
translated: By his evil speech

original: suppabuddhasakkakokālikaciñcamāṇavikādayo viya tappati. Sesamettha catutthe ca uttānatthameva. Tatiyaṃ.
analyzed: suppabuddha sakka kokālika ciñca māṇavika ādayaḥ viya tappati sesam ettha catutthe ca uttāna attham eva tatiyam
translated: like the Sakyan Suppabuddha, the Kokālika, the student Cincā, and others. The rest of the text is self-evident in the fourth.

original: 5. Upaññātasuttavaṇṇanā🔽5. Pañcame dvinnāhanti dvinnaṃ ahaṃ. Upaññāsinti upagantvā guṇaṃ aññāsiṃ, jāniṃ paṭivijjhinti
analyzed: upaññāta sutta vaṇṇanā  pañcame dvinna aham ti dvinnam aham upaññāsinti upagantvā guṇam aññāsim jānim paṭivijjhinti
translated: . The Discourse on the Known.🔽. In the fifth, I had two: I had two, I went up to them and knew their virtue, I understood it.

original: attho. Idāni te dhamme dassento yā ca asantuṭṭhitātiādimāha. Imañhi dhammadvayaṃ🔽nissāya satthā sabbaññutaṃ patto, tasmā tassānubhāvaṃ dassento evamāha. Tattha asantuṭṭhitā
analyzed: atthaḥ idāni te dhamme dassentaḥ yā ca asantuṭṭhitā ati ādim āha iman hi dhamma dvayam  nissāya satthā sabbaññu tam patto tasmā tassa anubhāvam dassentaḥ evam āha tattha a santuṭṭhi tā
translated: The meaning is that I penetrated it. Now, showing those two ideas, he said, “And the discontent with what is well done,” and so on. For it was by depending on this

original: kusalesu dhammesūti iminā imaṃ dīpeti – “ahaṃ jhānamattakena vā obhāsanimittamattakena
analyzed: kusalesu dhammesu iti iminā imam dīpeti aham jhāna mattakena vā obhāsa nimitta mattakena
translated: pair of ideas that the Master reached omniscience. That is why he said this in order to show their influence. Herein, he illustrates the discontent with what is well done with the following. “ I was not satisfied with mere jhana or with mere object of insight as sign of resolution ,

original: vā asantuṭṭho hutvā arahattamaggameva uppādesiṃ. Yāva so na uppajji, na tāvāhaṃ santuṭṭho
analyzed: vā a santuṭṭhaḥ hutvā arahatta maggam eva uppādesim yāva saḥ na uppajji na tāva aham santuṭṭhaḥ
translated: and so I generated only the path of arahatship. As long as that did not arise I was not satisfied.

original: ahosiṃ. Padhānasmiṃ ca anukkaṇṭhito hutvā anosakkanāya ṭhatvāyeva padhānakiriyaṃ
analyzed: padhānasmin ca an ukkaṇṭhitaḥ hutvā anosakkanāya ṭhatvāya iva padhāna kiriyam
translated: And I was not disinclined to exert myself, but I stood exerting myself without disinclination.

original: akāsi”nti imamatthaṃ dassento yā ca appaṭivānitātiādimāha. Tattha appaṭivānitāti
analyzed: akāsin ti imam attham dassentaḥ yā ca appaṭivāni tā ati ādim āha tattha appaṭivāni tā ti
translated: He said this in order to show the meaning of the words, “And I did not turn back.”

original: appaṭikkamanā anosakkanā. Appaṭivānī sudāhaṃ, bhikkhave, padahāmīti ettha sudanti
analyzed: appaṭikkamanā anosakkanā appaṭivānī sudā aham bhikkhave padahāmi iti ettha sudanti
translated: Herein, he did not turn back means he did not turn away, he did not turn back. I did not turn back, monks, means I did not turn away, I did not turn back.

original: nipātamattaṃ. Ahaṃ, bhikkhave, anosakkanāyaṃ ṭhito bodhisattakāle sabbaññutaṃ patthento
analyzed: nipāta mattam aham bhikkhave anosakkanāyam ṭhitaḥ bodhisatta kāle sabbaññu tam patthentaḥ
translated: I stood firm, monks, in the past as a Bodhisatta, aspiring to full enlightenment,

original: padhānamakāsinti ayamettha attho.
analyzed: padhānam akāsin ti ayam ettha attho
translated: I made an effort. This is the meaning here.

original: Idāni yathā tena taṃ padhānaṃ kataṃ, taṃ dassento kāmaṃ taco cātiādimāha. Tattha
analyzed: idāni yathā tena tam padhānam katam tam dassentaḥ kāmam ca ati ādim āha tattha
translated: Now, showing how he made that effort, he said, “Though my skin, sinews, and bones,” etc. Herein,

original: pattabbanti iminā pattabbaṃ guṇajātaṃ dasseti. Purisathāmenātiādinā purisassa ñāṇathāmo
analyzed: pattabbam ti iminā pattabbam guṇa jātam dasseti purisa thāmena ati ādinā purisassa ñāṇa thāmaḥ
translated: what is to be attained means he shows the kind of qualities that are to be attained. By the man’s strength of mind, etc., the man’s heat of knowledge,

original: ñāṇavīriyaṃ ñāṇaparakkamo ca kathito. Saṇṭhānanti ṭhapanā appavattanā osakkanā, paṭippassaddhīti
analyzed: ñāṇa vīriyam ñāṇa parakkamo ca kathito saṇṭhānam ti ṭhapanā appavattanā osakkanā paṭippassaddhī iti
translated: his knowledge, energy, and knowledge-superiority are told. The frame of mind means the state of being set up, the state of not turning back, the state of not turning away; the meaning is, the state of being calmed down.

original: attho. Ettāvatā tena caturaṅgasamannāgataṃ vīriyādhiṭṭhānaṃ nāma kathitaṃ. Ettha
analyzed: ettāvatā tena catur aṅga samannāgatam vīriyādhiṭṭhānam nāma kathitam ettha
translated: So far he has told of the energy-resolution endowed with four factors. Herein,

original: hi kāmaṃ taco cāti ekaṃ aṅgaṃ, nhāru cāti ekaṃ, aṭṭhi cāti ekaṃ, maṃsalohitanti ekaṃ,🔽imāni cattāri aṅgāni. Purisathāmenātiādīni adhimattavīriyādhivacanāni. Iti purimehi🔽catūhi aṅgehi samannāgatena hutvā evaṃ adhiṭṭhitaṃ vīriyaṃ caturaṅgasamannāgataṃ
analyzed: hi kāmam taco ca ati ekam aṅgam nhāru ca ati ekam aṭṭhi ca ati ekam maṃsa lohitanti ekam  imāni cattāri aṅgāni adhimatta vīriya adhivacanāni iti purimehi  catūhi aṅgehi samannāgatena hutvā evam adhiṭṭhitam vīriyam catur aṅga samannāgatam
translated: The skin is one part, the sinews are one part, the bones are one part, and the flesh and blood are one part.🔽These are the four parts. The words “man’s effort” , etc., are terms for superior energy. Thus, having been endowed with the first four parts, the energy that is thus resolved upon is called “the footing for energy endowed with four parts.”

original: vīriyādhiṭṭhānaṃ nāmāti veditabbaṃ. Ettāvatā tena bodhipallaṅke attano āgamanīyapaṭipadā kathitā.
analyzed: vīriya adhiṭṭhānam nāma ati veditabbam ettāvatā tena bodhi pallaṅke attanaḥ āgamanīya paṭipadā kathitā
translated: So far he has described the way he had to come to the Bodhi throne.

original: Idāni tāya paṭipadāya paṭiladdhaguṇaṃ kathetuṃ tassa mayhaṃ, bhikkhavetiādimāha.
analyzed: idāni tāya paṭipadāya paṭiladdha guṇam kathetum tassa mayham bhikkhava iti ādim āha
translated: Now, in order to describe the special qualities he had attained by that way, he said, “Bhikkhus, that enlightenment of mine,” etc.

original: Tattha appamādādhigatāti satiavippavāsasaṅkhātena appamādena adhigatā, na suttappamattena
analyzed: tattha appamāda adhigatā ti sati a vippavāsa saṅkhātena appamādena adhigatā na sutta ppamattena
translated: Herein, attained by diligence means attained by diligence consisting in the absence of negligence, not attained by mere recitation.

original: laddhā. Sambodhīti catumaggañāṇañceva sabbaññutaññāṇañca. Na hi sakkā etaṃ suttappamattena
analyzed: laddhā sambodhī iti catu magga ñāṇañca iva sabbaññuta ññāṇañca na hi sakkā etam suttappa mattena
translated: Enlightenment is the four paths and the knowledge of omniscience. For this cannot be attained by mere recitation.

original: adhigantunti. Tenāha – “appamādādhigatā sambodhī”ti. Anuttaro yogakkhemoti na kevalaṃ
analyzed: adhigantum ti tena āha appamāda adhigatā sambodhī iti anuttaraḥ yogakkhemaḥ ti na kevalam
translated: Therefore he said, “The enlightenment attained by diligence.” Supreme security from bondage means not only

original: bodhiyeva, arahattaphalanibbānasaṅkhāto anuttaro yogakkhemopi appamādādhigatova.
analyzed: bodhiyā iva arahatta phala nibbāna saṅkhātaḥ anuttaraḥ yogakkhemaḥ api appamāda adhigataḥ va
translated: and the supreme security from bondage called Nibbāna, which is the fruition of Arahantship, is reached only by one who is diligent.

original: Idāni attanā paṭiladdhaguṇesu bhikkhusaṅghaṃ samādapento tumhe cepi bhikkhavetiādimāha.
analyzed: idāni attanā paṭiladdha guṇesu bhikkhu saṅgham samādapentaḥ tumhe ce pi bhikkhava iti ādim āha
translated: Now, exhorting the bhikkhus to the qualities he himself had reached, he said: “If you bhikkhus” .

original: Tattha yassatthāyāti yassa atthāya, yaṃ upasampajja viharitukāmā hutvāti attho. Tadanuttaranti
analyzed: tattha yassa atthāya ati yassa atthāya yam upasampajja viharitu kāmāḥ hutvā iti attho tat anuttaram ti
translated: Herein, for the sake of which means for the sake of what, the meaning is, for the sake of what, being desirous of entering upon and dwelling in. That supreme :

original: taṃ anuttaraṃ. Brahmacariyapariyosānanti maggabrahmacariyassa pariyosānabhūtaṃ ariyaphalaṃ.
analyzed: tam anuttaram brahmacariya pariyosānanti magga brahmacariyassa pariyosāna bhūtam ariya phalam
translated: that unsurpassed. The culmination of the spiritual life : the Noble Fruit, which is the culmination of the path-spiritual life.

original: Abhiññā sacchikatvāti abhiññāya uttamapaññāya paccakkhaṃ katvā. Upasampajja viharissathāti
analyzed: abhiññā sacchikatvā ati abhiññāya uttama paññāya paccakkham katvā upasampajja viharissatha ati
translated: Having directly known for oneself : having made it evident by means of the supreme knowledge called direct knowledge. You will enter upon and dwell in :

original: paṭilabhitvā pāpuṇitvā viharissatha. Tasmāti yasmā appaṭivānapadhānaṃ nāmetaṃ bahūpakāraṃ
analyzed: paṭilabhitvā pāpuṇitvā viharissatha tasmā ati yasmai appaṭivānapadhānam nāma etam bahu upakāram
translated: you will attain and reach and dwell in. Therefore : since this exertion is not without reward,

original: uttamatthasādhakaṃ, tasmā. Pañcamaṃ.🔽6. Saṃyojanasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: uttama ttha sādhakam  saṃyojana sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: since it is the fulfiller of the supreme good. The fifth .🔽The explanation of the Discourse on Fetters .

original: 6. Chaṭṭhe saṃyojaniyesu dhammesūti dasannaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ paccayabhūtesu tebhūmakadhammesu.
analyzed: chaṭṭhe saṃyojaniyesu dhammesu iti dasannam saṃyojanānam paccaya bhūtesu tebhūmaka dhammesu
translated: In the sixth , in ideas provocative of fetters : in the ideas of the three planes that are conditions for the ten fetters .

original: Assādānupassitāti assādato passitā passanabhāvoti attho. Nibbidānupassitāti nibbidāvasena
analyzed: assāda anupassitā ti assādataḥ passitā passana bhāvaḥ ti attho nibbida anupassitā ati nibbidā vasena
translated: “Contemplating as disappointment”: the state of seeing as disappointment. “Contemplating as a danger”: the state of seeing as a danger.

original: ukkaṇṭhanavasena passanabhāvo. Jātiyāti khandhanibbattito. Jarāyāti khandhaparipākato.
analyzed: ukkaṇṭhana vasena passana bhāvaḥ jātiyā ati khandha nibbattitaḥ jarāyā ati khandha paripākato
translated: “In birth”: in the production of the aggregates. “In aging”: in the maturing of the aggregates.

original: Maraṇenāti khandhabhedato. Sokehīti antonijjhāyanalakkhaṇehi sokehi. Paridevehīti
analyzed: maraṇena ati khandha bhedato sokehi iti antar nijjhāyana lakkhaṇehi sokehi paridevehi iti
translated: “In death”: in the dissolution of the aggregates. “In sorrow”: in the sorrows characterized by inward grief. “In lamentation”:

original: tannissitalālappitalakkhaṇehi paridevehi. Dukkhehīti kāyapaṭipīḷanadukkhehi. Domanassehīti
analyzed: tad nissita lālappita lakkhaṇehi paridevehi dukkhehi iti kāya paṭipīḷana dukkhehi domanassehi iti
translated: in the lamentations characterized by outward wailing. “In pain”: in the pains characterized by bodily suffering. “In grief”:

original: manovighātadomanassehi. Upāyāsehīti adhimattāyāsalakkhaṇaupāyāsehi. Dukkhasmāti sakalavaṭṭadukkhato.
analyzed: manaḥ vighāta domanassehi upāyāsehi iti adhimatta āyāsa lakkhaṇa upāyāsehi dukkhasma ati sakala vaṭṭa dukkhato
translated: in the griefs characterized by mental suffering. “In despair”: in the despairs characterized by excessive suffering. “In suffering”: in the suffering of the entire round.

original: Pajahatīti maggena pajahati. Pahāyāti ettha pana phalakkhaṇo kathito. Imasmiṃ sutte
analyzed: pajahati iti maggena pajahati pahāya ati ettha pana pha lakkhaṇaḥ kathito imasmim sutte
translated: “He abandons”: he abandons by means of the path. “Having abandoned”: here the fruit is stated. In this sutta

original: vaṭṭavivaṭṭaṃ kathitaṃ. Chaṭṭhaṃ.
analyzed: vaṭṭavivaṭṭam kathitam chaṭṭham
translated: the round of existence and the transcending of the round are stated. The sixth.

original: 7. Kaṇhasuttavaṇṇanā
