original: sukkhavipassakakhīṇāsavo. Kāyasakkhīti kāyena jhānaphassaṃ phusitvā pacchā nirodhaṃ🔽nibbānaṃ sacchikatvā ṭhito. Diṭṭhippattoti diṭṭhantaṃ patto. Ime dvepi chasu ṭhānesu🔽labbhanti. Saddhāvimuttoti saddahanto vimutto. Ayampi chasu ṭhānesu labbhati. Dhammaṃ🔽anussaratīti dhammānusārī. Saddhaṃ anussaratīti saddhānusārī. Ime dvepi paṭhamamaggasamaṅgino.
analyzed: sukkha vipassaka khīṇa āsavaḥ kāya sakkhī ti kāyena jhāna phassam phusitvā pacchā nirodham  nibbānam sacchikatvā ṭhitaḥ diṭṭhippatto ti diṭṭhantam patto ime dve pi chasu ṭhānesu  labbhanti saddhā vimuttaḥ ti saddahantaḥ vimuttaḥ ayam pi chasu ṭhānesu labbhati dhammaṃ  anussarati iti dhamma anusārī saddham anussarati iti saddhā anusārī ime dve pi paṭhama magga samaṅgino
translated: and the one who has reached the destruction of cankers by dry insight. The “body witness”: one who, having experienced the jhāna-touch, afterwards stands by realizing the cessation of the cankers.🔽The “one who has attained to view”: one who has attained to the seen. These two are found in the six directions.🔽The “one liberated by faith”: one who is liberated by having faith. This one is found in the six directions.🔽The “one who has faith as his guide”: one who has faith as his guide. These two are found in the first path.

original: Kalyāṇadhammoti sundaradhammo. Dussīlo pāpadhammoti nissīlo lāmakadhammo. Imaṃ kasmā🔽gaṇhanti? Sabbesu hi ekasadisesu jātesu sīlavantesu balavagāravaṃ na hoti, ekaccesu🔽pana dussīlesu sati sīlavantānaṃ upari balavagāravaṃ hotīti maññantā gaṇhanti. Te🔽tena lābhaṃ labhantīti te bhikkhū ekaccānaṃ vaṇṇaṃ ekaccānaṃ avaṇṇaṃ kathetvā cattāro
analyzed: kalyāṇa dhammo ti sundara dhammaḥ dussīlaḥ pāpa dhammaḥ ti nissīlaḥ lāmaka dhammaḥ imam kasmā 🔽gaṇhanti sabbesu hi eka sadisesu jātesu sīlavantesu balava gāravam na hoti ekaccesu 🔽pana dussīlesu sati sīlavantānam upari balava gāravam hoti iti maññantā gaṇhanti te 🔽tena lābham labhanti iti te bhikkhū ekaccānam vaṇṇam ekaccānam avaṇṇam kathetvā cattāraḥ
translated: and the one who has reached the destruction of taints by dry insight. The “body witness”: one who, after touching the jhāna-penetration with the body, afterwards realizes the cessation of the taints and is established in Nibbāna. The “one attained to vision”: one who has attained to the seen. These two are found in the six directions. The “one liberated by faith”: one who is liberated by faith. This one is found in the six directions. The “one who has faith as his support”: one who has faith as his support. These two are found in the one who possesses the first path. The “one of good conduct”: one of good conduct. The “one of bad conduct”: one of bad conduct. Why do they take these up? Because, when all are of the same kind, the virtuous are not greatly respected, but when some are of bad conduct, then the virtuous are greatly respected. Thinking thus, they take them up. By that they get gain. Those bhikkhus, after praising some and criticizing others, get gain.

original: paccaye labhanti. Gathitāti taṇhāya ganthitā. Mucchitāti taṇhāvaseneva mucchitā.
analyzed: paccaye labhanti gathitā ati taṇhāya ganthitā mucchitā ati taṇhā vasena iva mucchitā
translated: They get the conditions. They are bound: they are bound by craving. They are infatuated: they are infatuated by craving.

original: Ajjhopannāti ajjhosāya gilitvā pariniṭṭhapetvā ṭhitā. Anādīnavadassāvinoti apaccavekkhitaparibhoge
analyzed: ajjhopannā ati ajjhosāya gilitvā pariniṭṭhapetvā ṭhitā anādīnava dassāvino ti a paccavekkhita paribhoge
translated: They are swallowed up: they are swallowed up, swallowed down, swallowed right through, and remain having swallowed up.🔽They do not see the danger: they do not reflect on the danger in the enjoyment of the five strands of sense pleasure.

original: ādīnavaṃ apassantā. Anissaraṇapaññāti catūsu paccayesu chandarāgaapakaḍḍhanāya nissaraṇapaññāya
analyzed: ādīnavam a passantā a nissaraṇa paññā ati catūsu paccayesu chanda rāga apakaḍḍhanāya nissaraṇa paññāya
translated: They have no perception of escape: they are devoid of the perception of escape from the four conditions by the dragging out of will and lust.

original: virahitā idamatthaṃ etanti ajānantā. Paribhuñjantīti sacchandarāgā hutvā paribhuñjanti.
analyzed: virahitāḥ idam attham etat ti a jānantā paribhuñjanti iti sa chanda rāgāḥ hutvā paribhuñjanti
translated: They do not know the meaning of this: they do not know the meaning of this. They enjoy: they enjoy with will and lust.

original: Sukkapakkhe ubhatobhāgavimuttotiādīsu ayaṃ sattannampi ariyapuggalānaṃ saṅkhepapakāsanā
analyzed: sukka pakkhe ubhatobhāga vimuttaḥ ti ādīsu ayam sattannam api ariya puggalānam saṅkhepa pakāsanā
translated: In the bright fortnight, the “one both ways released” and so on are shown in brief for all seven noble persons.

original: – eko bhikkhu paññādhurena abhiniviṭṭho aṭṭha samāpattiyo nibbattetvā sotāpattimaggaṃ
analyzed: ekaḥ bhikkhu paññā dhurena abhiniviṭṭhaḥ aṭṭha samāpattiyaḥ nibbattetvā sotāpatti maggaṃ
translated: A bhikkhu who is intent on wisdom produces the eight attainments and reaches the stream-entry path.

original: pāpuṇāti. So tasmiṃ khaṇe dhammānusārī nāma hoti, sotāpattiphalādīsu chasu ṭhānesu
analyzed: pāpuṇāti so tasmin khaṇe dhamma anusārī nāma hoti sotāpatti phala ādīsu chasu ṭhānesu
translated: At that moment he is called a “Dhamma-follower” . In the six instances beginning with the fruit of stream-entry🔽he is called a “Dhamma-follower” and a “faith-follower” in the six instances beginning with the path of stream-entry.

original: kāyasakkhi nāma, arahattaphalakkhaṇe ubhatobhāgavimutto nāma. Samāpattīhi vikkhambhanavimuttiyā
analyzed: nāma arahatta phala kkhaṇe ubhatobhāgavimuttaḥ nāma samāpattīhi vikkhambhana vimuttiyā
translated: One who is a body witness is one liberated-in-both-ways at the moment of the fruition of Arahantship.

original: maggena samucchedavimuttiyāti dvikkhattuṃ vā dvīhi vā bhāgehi vimuttoti attho. Aparo
analyzed: maggena samuccheda vimuttiyā ti dvi kkhattum vā dvīhi vā bhāgehi vimuttaḥ ti atthaḥ aparaḥ
translated: The meaning is: liberated by the two kinds of deliverance, that is, by the deliverance of heart through surmounting the defilements by the attainment of jhāna and by the deliverance of wisdom through the exhaustion of the taints by means of the path. Another

original: paññādhurena abhiniviṭṭho samāpattiyo nibbattetuṃ asakkonto sukkhavipassakova hutvā🔽sotāpattimaggaṃ pāpuṇāti. So tasmiṃ khaṇe dhammānusārī nāma hoti, sotāpattiphalādīsu🔽chasu ṭhānesu diṭṭhippatto nāma, arahattaphalakkhaṇe paññāvimutto nāma. Aparo saddhādhurena🔽abhiniviṭṭho aṭṭha samāpattiyo nibbattetvā sotāpattimaggaṃ pāpuṇāti. So tasmiṃ khaṇe
analyzed: paññā dhurena abhiniviṭṭhaḥ samāpattiyaḥ nibbattetum a sakkontaḥ sukkha vipassakaḥ iva hutvā  sotāpatti maggam pāpuṇāti saḥ tasmin khaṇe dhamma anusārī nāma hoti sotāpatti phala ādīsu  chasu ṭhānesu diṭṭhippatto nāma arahatta phala kkhaṇe paññāvimutto nāma aparaḥ saddhā dhurena  abhiniviṭṭhaḥ aṭṭha samāpattiyaḥ nibbattetvā sotāpatti maggam pāpuṇāti saḥ tasmin khaṇe
translated: who is not able to produce the jhānas because he is devoted to the vehicle of understanding is a bare-insight worker.🔽He reaches the path of stream-entry. At that moment he is called a Dhamma-follower. In the six instances beginning with the fruition of stream-entry he is called one attained-to-view. At the moment of the fruition of Arahantship he is called one liberated-by-understanding. Another,

original: saddhānusārī nāma hoti, sotāpattiphalādīsu chasu ṭhānesu kāyasakkhi nāma, arahattaphalakkhaṇe
analyzed: saddhā anusārī nāma hoti sotāpatti phala ādīsu chasu ṭhānesu kāyasakkhi nāma arahatta phala kkhaṇe
translated: who is devoted to the vehicle of faith, produces the eight attainments and then reaches the path of stream-entry. At that moment he is called a faith-follower. In the six instances beginning with the fruition of stream-entry he is called one liberated-by-faith. At the moment of the fruition of Arahantship he is called one liberated-by-both-parts.

original: ubhatobhāgavimutto nāma. Aparo saddhādhurena abhiniviṭṭho samāpattiyo nibbattetuṃ🔽asakkonto sukkhavipassakova hutvā sotāpattimaggaṃ pāpuṇāti. So tasmiṃ khaṇe saddhānusārī
analyzed: ubhatobhāgavimuttaḥ nāma aparaḥ saddhā dhurena abhiniviṭṭhaḥ samāpattiyaḥ nibbattetum  a sakkontaḥ sukkha vipassakaḥ iva hutvā sotāpatti maggam pāpuṇāti saḥ tasmin khaṇe saddhā anusārī
translated: is called “one both-ways released.” Another, who has entered upon the way by faith, is unable to produce the attainments,🔽and so he becomes a bare-insight worker and reaches the path of stream-entry. At that moment he is a faith devotee.

original: nāma hoti, sotāpattiphalādīsu chasu ṭhānesu saddhāvimutto nāma, arahattaphalakkhaṇe paññāvimutto nāma.
analyzed: nāma hoti sotāpatti phala ādīsu chasu ṭhānesu saddhā vimuttaḥ nāma arahatta phala kkhaṇe paññā vimuttaḥ nāma
translated: One called “both-ways liberated” is one who, being a faith-follower, is unable to produce the attainments and so becomes a bare-insight worker and reaches the path of stream-entry. At that moment he is called a “faith-devotee” . He is called “faith-liberated” in the six instances beginning with the fruit of stream-entry, and he is called “understanding- liberated” at the moment of the fruit of arahantship.

original: 50. Aṭṭhame visamāti sapakkhalanaṭṭhena visamā. Samāti nipakkhalanaṭṭhena samā. Adhammakammānīti uddhammāni kammāni. Avinayakammānīti ubbinayāni kammāni.
analyzed: aṭṭhame visamā ati sa pakkhalana ṭṭhena visamā samā ati nipakkhalana ṭṭhena samā adhamma kammāni iti uddhammāni kammāni avinaya kammāni iti ubbinayāni kammāni
translated: In the eighth case, “uneven” is uneven in the sense of having holes. “Even” is even in the sense of being without holes. “Un-dhamma acts” are acts that are not dhamma. “Un-discipline acts” are acts that are not discipline.

original: 51. Navame adhammikāti niddhammā. Dhammikāti dhammayuttā.
analyzed: navame adhammikā ati niddhammā dhammikā ati dhamma yuttā
translated: In the ninth case, “un-dhamma” is not dhamma. “Dhamma” is associated with dhamma.

original: 52. Dasame adhikaraṇanti vivādādhikaraṇādicatubbidhaṃ adhikaraṇaṃ. Ādiyantīti gaṇhanti.
analyzed: dasame vivāda adhikaraṇa ādi catubbidham adhikaraṇam ādiyanti iti gaṇhanti
translated: In the tenth case, “legal issue” is a legal issue of one of the four kinds, that is to say, legal issues arising out of disputes, and so on. “Take up” means grasp.

original: Saññāpentīti jānāpenti. Na ca saññattiṃ upagacchantīti saññāpanatthaṃ na sannipatanti.
analyzed: saññāpenti iti jānāpenti na ca saññattim upagacchanti iti saññāpana attham na sannipatanti
translated: “Make them understand” means make them know. “Do not agree to the making of an agreement” means do not agree to a meeting for the purpose of making an agreement.

original: Na ca nijjhāpentīti na pekkhāpenti. Na ca nijjhattiṃ upagacchantīti aññamaññaṃ nijjhāpanatthāya
analyzed: na ca nijjhāpenti iti na pekkhāpenti na ca nijjhattim upagacchanti iti aññam aññam nijjhāpana tthāya
translated: Nor do they look on: they do not look on with the eye. Nor do they come to a decision: they do not come to a decision about each other for the purpose of looking on.

original: na sannipatanti. Asaññattibalāti asaññattiyeva balaṃ etesanti asaññattibalā. Appaṭinissaggamantinoti🔽yesaṃ hi evaṃ hoti – “sace amhehi gahitaṃ adhikaraṇaṃ dhammikaṃ bhavissati, gaṇhissāma.🔽Sace adhammikaṃ, vissajjessāmā”ti, te paṭinissaggamantino nāma honti. Ime pana na🔽tathā mantentīti appaṭinissaggamantino. Thāmasā parāmāsā abhinivissāti diṭṭhithāmena
analyzed: na sannipatanti a saññatti balā ati a saññattiyā iva balam etesanti a saññatti balāḥ a paṭinissagga mantino ti  yesam hi evam hoti sace amhehi gahitam adhikaraṇam dhammikam bhavissati gaṇhissāma  sace adhammikam vissajjessāma ati te paṭinissaggamantinaḥ nāma honti ime pana na  tathā mantenti iti appaṭinissagga mantinaḥ thāmasā parāmāsāḥ abhinivissāti diṭṭhi thāmena
translated: “They do not come to a decision” means they do not look into it. “They do not come to a settlement” means they do not gather together to settle it by means of a resolution face-to-face. “They do not have the strength to come to a settlement” means they do not have the strength of a resolution. “They do not have the strength to give up” means they do not think, “If the legal issue we have taken up turns out to be legitimate, we will take it up.

original: ca diṭṭhiparāmāsena ca abhinivisitvā. Idameva saccanti idaṃ amhākaṃ vacanameva saccaṃ.
analyzed: ca diṭṭhi parāmāsena ca abhinivisitvā idam eva saccanti idam amhākam vacanam eva saccam
translated: If it turns out to be illegitimate, we will give it up.” They do not think in this way. “They do not have the strength to give up” means they do not have the strength to give up. “They are obstinate, holding on tenaciously, and attached” means they are attached by means of view and by means of obstinacy. “This alone is the truth, other is worthless” means “This statement of ours alone is the truth.

original: Moghamaññanti avasesānaṃ vacanaṃ moghaṃ tucchaṃ. Sukkapakkho uttānatthoyevāti.🔽Parisavaggo pañcamo.
analyzed: mogham aññanti avasesānam vacanam mogham tuccham sukka pakkhaḥ uttāna tthaḥ yeva ati  parisavaggaḥ pañcamaḥ
translated: Other statements are worthless and void.” The bright side is straightforward in meaning.🔽The fifth sub-chapter on assemblies is finished.

original: Paṭhamapaṇṇāsakaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ.
analyzed: paṭhama paṇṇāsakam niṭṭhitam
translated: The first fifty is finished.

original: 2. Dutiyapaṇṇāsakaṃ
analyzed: dutiya paṇṇāsakam
translated: The second fifty

original: (6) 1. Puggalavaggavaṇṇanā
translated: 1. The first section of the second book of the Paṭisambhidāmagga

original: 53. Dutiyapaṇṇāsakassa paṭhame cakkavattinā saddhiṃ gahitattā “lokānukampāyā”ti na vuttaṃ. Ettha ca cakkavattino uppattiyā dve sampattiyo labhanti, buddhānaṃ uppattiyā tissopi.
analyzed: dutiya paṇṇāsakassa paṭhame cakkavattinā saddhim gahita ttā loka anukampāya iti na vuttam ettha ca cakkavattino uppattiyā dve sampattiyaḥ labhanti buddhānam uppattiyā tissaḥ api
translated: In the first of the second book, the phrase “out of compassion for the world” is not stated because the wheel-turning monarch is included together with the Buddha. And here, two kinds of prosperity are obtained with the appearance of a wheel-turning monarch, and three with the appearance of a Buddha.

original: 54. Dutiye acchariyamanussāti āciṇṇamanussā abbhutamanussā.🔽55. Tatiye bahuno janassa anutappā hotīti mahājanassa anutāpakārī hoti. Tattha cakkavattino
analyzed: dutiye acchariya manussā ati āciṇṇa manussā abbhuta manussā  tatiye bahuno janassa anutappā hoti iti mahā janassa anutāpa kārī hoti tattha cakkavattinaḥ
translated: In the second, “wonderful human beings” are human beings who are well-known, extraordinary human beings.

original: kālakiriyā ekacakkavāḷe devamanussānaṃ anutāpaṃ karoti, tathāgatassa kālakiriyā dasasu cakkavāḷasahassesu.
analyzed: kālakiriyā eka cakkavāḷe deva manussānam anutāpam karoti tathāgatassa kālakiriyā dasasu cakkavāḷa sahassesu
translated: In the third, “he is a source of sorrow to many people” means he is a source of great sorrow to the people. Here, the death of a wheel-turning monarch causes sorrow in one world-sphere, and the death of a Tathāgata causes sorrow in ten thousand world-spheres.

original: 56. Catutthe thūpārahāti thūpassa yuttā anucchavikā. Cakkavattino hi cetiyaṃ paṭijaggitvā dve sampattiyo labhanti, buddhānaṃ cetiyaṃ paṭijaggitvā tissopi.
analyzed: catutthe thūpārahā ti thūpassa yuttā anucchavikā cakkavattinaḥ hi cetiyam paṭijaggitvā dve sampattiyaḥ labhanti buddhānam cetiyam paṭijaggitvā tissaḥ api
translated: In the fourth, “worthy of a shrine” means suitable for a shrine. For two kinds of prosperity are obtained by those who look after the shrine of a wheel-turning monarch, and three by those who look after the shrine of a Buddha.

original: 57. Pañcame buddhāti attano ānubhāvena cattāri saccāni buddhā.
analyzed: pañcame buddhā ati attanaḥ ānubhāvena cattāri saccāni buddhā
translated: In the fifth, “Buddha” means one who has awakened to the four truths by his own power.

original: 58. Chaṭṭhe phalantiyāti saddaṃ karontiyā. Na santasantīti na bhāyanti. Tattha khīṇāsavo
analyzed: chaṭṭhe phalantiyā ati saddam karontiyā na santasanti iti na bhāyanti tattha khīṇa asavo
translated: In the sixth, “they make a sound” means they make a noise. “They are not afraid” means they are not terrified.

original: attano sakkāyadiṭṭhiyā pahīnattā na bhāyati, hatthājānīyo sakkāyadiṭṭhiyā balavattāti.
analyzed: attano sakkāya diṭṭhiyā pahīna ttā na bhāyati hatthājānīyo sakkāya diṭṭhiyā balavat tā ati
translated: In the sixth, the sound of the birds crying out is the sound of “they cry out” . The words “they are not afraid” mean that they are not terrified. Herein, one whose cankers are destroyed is not afraid because he has abandoned personality view, while the thoroughbred horse is terrified because of the strength of his personality view.

original: Sattamaṭṭhamesupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: sattama ṭṭhamesu pi esa iva nayaḥ
translated: The same method of explanation applies in the seventh and eighth cases.

original: 61. Navame kiṃpurisāti kinnarā. Mānusiṃ vācaṃ na bhāsantīti manussakathaṃ na kathenti.
analyzed: navame kiṃpurisāḥ ati kinnarāḥ mānusim vācam na bhāsanti iti manussa katham na kathenti
translated: In the ninth case, the “men” are the Kinnaras. The words “they do not speak the human speech” mean that they do not speak the language of men.

original: Dhammāsokassa kira ekaṃ kinnaraṃ ānetvā dassesuṃ. So “kathāpetha na”nti āha. Kinnaro
analyzed: dhammāsokassa kira ekam kinnaram ānetvā dassesuṃ saḥ āha kinnaro
translated: It seems that they brought a Kinnara to show to the Dhamma Sovereignty. He said, “Make him speak.” The Kinnara

original: kathetuṃ na icchati. Eko puriso “ahametaṃ kathāpessāmī”ti heṭṭhāpāsādaṃ otāretvā
analyzed: kathetum naḥ icchati ekaḥ purisaḥ aham etam kathāpessāmi iti heṭṭhā apāsādam otāretvā
translated: did not want to speak. A man said, “I will make him speak.” He took him down to the ground floor of the palace,

original: dve khāṇuke koṭṭetvā ukkhaliṃ āropesi. Sā ubhatopassehi patati. Taṃ disvā kinnaro
analyzed: dve khāṇuke koṭṭetvā ukkhalim āropesi sā ubhatopassehi patati tam disvā kinnaraḥ
translated: chipped two pieces of wood together, and set up a pot. It fell over on both sides. Seeing that, the Kinnara

original: “kiṃ aññaṃ ekaṃ khāṇukaṃ koṭṭetuṃ na vaṭṭatī”ti ettakameva āha. Puna aparabhāge dve
analyzed: kim aññam ekam khāṇukam koṭṭetum na vaṭṭati iti ettakam eva āha puna apara bhāge dve
translated: said, “Why is it not all right to chip just one piece of wood?” That was all he said. Later on, two

original: kinnare ānetvā dassesuṃ. Rājā “kathāpetha ne”ti āha. Te kathetuṃ na icchiṃsu. Eko
analyzed: kinnare ānetvā dassesum rājā kathāpetha na iti āha te kathetum na icchiṃsu ekaḥ
translated: and brought them to the king. The king said, “Make them speak.” They did not want to speak.

original: puriso “ahamete kathāpessāmī”ti te gahetvā antarāpaṇaṃ agamāsi. Tattheko ambapakkañca
analyzed: purisaḥ aham ete kathāpessāmi iti te gahetvā antarāpaṇam agamāsi tattha ekaḥ amba pakkam ca
translated: One man said, “I will make them speak.” He took them to a shop. There one saw a ripe mango and a fish,

original: macche ca addasa, eko kabiṭṭhaphalañca ambilikāphalañca. Tattha purimo “mahāvisaṃ
analyzed: macche ca addase ekaḥ kabiṭṭha phalam ca ambilikā phalam ca tattha purimaḥ mahāvisam
translated: and the other saw a jack-fruit and a lime. The first said, “People eat this very poisonous

original: manussā khādanti, kathaṃ te kilāsino na hontī”ti āha. Itaro “kathaṃ ime etaṃ nissāya
analyzed: manussā khādanti katham te kilāsinaḥ na honti iti āha itaro katham ime etam nissāya
translated: food. How is it that they do not get sick?” The other said, “How is it that they do not get leprosy

original: kuṭṭhino na hontī”ti āha. Evaṃ mānusiṃ vācaṃ kathetuṃ sakkontāpi dve atthe sampassamānā na kathentīti.
analyzed: kuṭṭhinaḥ na honti iti āha evam mānusim vācam kathetum sakkontā api dve atthe sampassamānā na kathenti iti
translated: by eating this?” Thus, although they were able to speak human speech, they did not speak because they saw two meanings .

original: 62. Dasame appaṭivānoti anukaṇṭhito apaccosakkito.
analyzed: dasame appaṭivānaḥ ti anukaṇṭhitaḥ a paccosakkitaḥ
translated: In the tenth case, “not to be rebuffed” means not to be turned away from.

original: 63. Ekādasame asantasannivāsanti asappurisānaṃ sannivāsaṃ. Na vadeyyāti ovādena vā
analyzed: ekādasame asappurisānam sannivāsam na vadeyyāti ovādena vā
translated: In the eleventh case, “living with the unvirtuous” means living with the unvirtuous. “I would not speak” means I would not speak with advice or

original: anusāsaniyā vā na vadeyya, mā vadatūti attho. Therampāhaṃ na vadeyyanti ahampi theraṃ
analyzed: anusāsaniyā vā na vadeyya mā vadatu uti attho theram pa aham na vadeyyanti aham pi theram
translated: instruction. The meaning is, “Let them not speak.” “I would not speak to the elder” means

original: bhikkhuṃ ovādānusāsanivasena na vadeyyaṃ. Ahitānukampīti ahitaṃ icchamāno. No hitānukampīti🔽hitaṃ anicchamāno. Noti naṃ vadeyyanti “ahaṃ tava vacanaṃ na karissa”nti naṃ vadeyyaṃ.
analyzed: bhikkhum ovāda anusāsani vasena na vadeyyam ahita anukampī iti ahitam icchamānaḥ no hita anukampī iti  hitam an icchamānaḥ no ti nam vadeyyanti aham tava vacanam na karissanti nam vadeyyam
translated: I would not speak to him in the way of instruction and counsel. I would not speak to him out of compassion for his welfare:🔽I would not speak to him out of compassion for his welfare. I would not speak to him: I would say to him, “I will not do what you say.”

original: Viheṭheyyanti vacanassa akaraṇena viheṭheyyaṃ. Passampissa nappaṭikareyyanti passantopi
analyzed: viheṭheyyanti vacanassa a karaṇena viheṭheyyam passam pissa na paṭikareyyanti passantaḥ api
translated: I would harm him: by not doing what he says I would harm him. I would not make amends even if I saw the fault: even if I saw

original: jānantopi ahaṃ tassa vacanaṃ na kareyyaṃ. Iminā upāyena sabbattha attho veditabbo.🔽Sukkapakkhe pana sādhūti naṃ vadeyyanti “sādhu bhaddakaṃ sukathitaṃ tayā”ti tassa
analyzed: jānantaḥ api aham tassa vacanam na kareyyam iminā upāyena sabbattha atthaḥ veditabbaḥ  sukka pakkhe pana sādhu uti nam vadeyyan ti sādhu bhaddakam su kathitam tayā ati tassa
translated: the fault and knew it, I would not make amends for it. The meaning should be understood in this way throughout.

original: kathaṃ abhinandanto naṃ vadeyyanti attho.🔽64. Dvādasame ubhato vacīsaṃsāroti dvīsupi pakkhesu aññamaññaṃ akkosanapaccakkosanavasena
analyzed: katham abhinandantaḥ nam vadeyyanti attho  dvādasame ubhatas vacī saṃsāro ti dvīsu pi pakkhesu aññamaññam akkosana paccakkosana vasena
translated: But if he said, “Good,” I would speak to him: the meaning is that, approving his speech, I would speak to him thus, “It is good, it is excellent, you have spoken well.”

original: saṃsaramānā vācā vacīsaṃsāro. Diṭṭhipaḷāsoti diṭṭhiṃ nissāya uppajjanako yugaggāhalakkhaṇo
analyzed: saṃsaramānā vācā vacīsaṃsāro diṭṭhipaḷāso ti diṭṭhim nissāya uppajjanakaḥ yuga ggāha lakkhaṇo
translated: In the twelfth case, verbal abuse on both sides: the verbal abuse of each on the other is the verbal abuse on both sides. The violence of views: the violence consisting in taking up a wrong position, which arises contingent upon a view, is the violence of views.

original: paḷāso diṭṭhipaḷāso nāma. Cetaso āghātoti kopo. So hi cittaṃ āghātento uppajjati.
analyzed: paḷāsaḥ diṭṭhi paḷāsaḥ nāma cetasaḥ āghāto ti kopo saḥ hi cittam āghātentaḥ uppajjati
translated: “Fear” is fear of views. “Mental anguish” is anger. It arises as that which torments the mind.

original: Appaccayoti atuṭṭhākāro, domanassanti attho. Anabhiraddhīti kopoyeva. So hi anabhirādhanavasena🔽anabhiraddhīti vuccati. Ajjhattaṃ avūpasantaṃ hotīti sabbampetaṃ niyakajjhattasaṅkhāte🔽attano citte ca saddhivihārikaantevāsikasaṅkhātāya attano parisāya ca avūpasantaṃ
analyzed: appaccayo ti atuṭṭha ākāraḥ domanassa nti attho an abhiraddhi iti saḥ hi an abhirādhana vasena  an abhiraddhi iti vuccati ajjhattam a vūpasantam hoti iti sabbam petam niyaka jjhatta saṅkhāte  attano citte ca saddhivihārika antevāsika saṅkhātāya attano parisāya ca a vūpasantam
translated: “Dissatisfaction” is the state of being discontented; the meaning is, displeasure. “Dissatisfaction” is anger itself. It is called “dissatisfaction” because it is the state of being dissatisfied.🔽“Is not calmed down internally” : all this is said of the teacher’s own mind, which is called “internal,” and of his own following, which is called “internal” in the sense of belonging to himself.

original: hoti. Tasmetanti tasmiṃ etaṃ. Sesaṃ vuttanayeneva veditabbanti.
analyzed: tasmin etam sesam vutta nayena iva veditabbam ti
translated: “Is not calmed down” means that it is not tranquil. “Because of that” : because of that. The rest should be understood in the way already stated.

original: Puggalavaggo paṭhamo.🔽(7) 2. Sukhavaggavaṇṇanā
analyzed: puggala vaggo paṭhamaḥ
translated: The first sub-chapter on persons is finished.🔽The second sub-chapter on happiness

original: 65. Dutiyassa paṭhame gihisukhanti gihīnaṃ sabbakāmanipphattimūlakaṃ sukhaṃ. Pabbajitasukhanti pabbajitānaṃ pabbajjāmūlakaṃ sukhaṃ.
analyzed: dutiyassa paṭhame gihi sukham ti gihīnam sabba kāma nipphatti mūlakam sukham pabbajita sukham ti pabbajitānam pabbajjā mūlakam sukham
translated: In the first of the second sub-chapter, “happiness of the household life” is the happiness of householders based on the fulfillment of all their desires. “Happiness of the life of renunciation” is the happiness of those gone forth based on the going forth itself.

original: 66. Dutiye kāmasukhanti kāme ārabbha uppajjanakasukhaṃ. Nekkhammasukhanti nekkhammaṃ vuccati pabbajjā, taṃ ārabbha uppajjanakasukhaṃ.
analyzed: dutiye kāma sukhanti kāme ārabbha uppajjanaka sukham nekkhamma sukhanti nekkhammam vuccati pabbajjā tam ārabbha uppajjanaka sukham
translated: In the second triad sensual pleasure is the pleasure arisen dependent on sense desires. The pleasure of renunciation is the pleasure arisen dependent on renunciation. Renunciation is a term for going forth; the pleasure arisen dependent on that is the pleasure of renunciation.

original: 67. Tatiye upadhisukhanti tebhūmakasukhaṃ. Nirupadhisukhanti lokuttarasukhaṃ.
analyzed: tatiye upadhi sukhanti tebhūmaka sukham nirupadhi sukhanti lokuttara sukham
translated: In the third triad the pleasure of being sought is the pleasure of the three planes. The pleasure of not being sought is the supramundane pleasure.

original: 68. Catutthe sāsavasukhanti āsavānaṃ paccayabhūtaṃ vaṭṭasukhaṃ. Anāsavasukhanti tesaṃ apaccayabhūtaṃ vivaṭṭasukhaṃ.
analyzed: catutthe sa āsava sukhanti āsavānam paccaya bhūtam vaṭṭa sukham anāsava sukhanti tesam apaccaya bhūtam vivaṭṭa sukham
translated: In the fourth triad the pleasure of taints is the pleasure of the round of rebirths that is a condition for the defilements. The pleasure of no taints is the pleasure of the cessation of the round that is no condition for them.

original: 69. Pañcame sāmisanti saṃkilesaṃ vaṭṭagāmisukhaṃ. Nirāmisanti nikkilesaṃ vivaṭṭagāmisukhaṃ.
analyzed: pañcame sa āmisanti saṃkilesam vaṭṭa gāmi sukham nirāmisanti nikkilesam vivaṭṭa gāmi sukham
translated: In the fifth triad the pleasure of what is corruptible is the pleasure that leads to corruption, to the round of rebirths. The pleasure of what is not corruptible is the pleasure that leads to what is not corruptible, to the cessation of the round.

original: 70. Chaṭṭhe ariyasukhanti aputhujjanasukhaṃ. Anariyasukhanti puthujjanasukhaṃ.
analyzed: chaṭṭhe ariya sukhanti a puthujjana sukham an ariya sukhanti puthujjana sukham
translated: In the sixth triad the pleasure of noble ones is the pleasure of those who are not ordinary men. The pleasure of what is ignoble is the pleasure of ordinary men.

original: 71. Sattame kāyikanti kāyaviññāṇasahajātaṃ. Cetasikanti manodvārikasukhaṃ. Taṃ lokiyalokuttaramissakaṃ kathitaṃ.
analyzed: sattame kāyikam ti kāya viññāṇa sahajātam cetasikam ti manaḥ dvārika sukham tam lokiya lokuttara missakam kathitam
translated: In the seventh triad bodily is that which is associated with body-consciousness. Mental is the pleasure of the mind door. That is said to be a mixture of mundane and supramundane.

original: 72. Aṭṭhame sappītikanti paṭhamadutiyajjhānasukhaṃ. Nippītikanti tatiyacatutthajjhānasukhaṃ.
analyzed: aṭṭhame sappītikanti paṭhama dutiya jhāna sukham nippītikanti tatiya catuttha jhāna sukham
translated: In the eighth triad the pleasure of fever is the pleasure of the first and second jhānas. The pleasure of no fever is the pleasure of the third and fourth jhānas.

original: Tattha lokiyasappītikato lokiyanippītikaṃ, lokuttarasappītikato ca lokuttaranippītikaṃ
analyzed: tattha lokiya sappītikataḥ lokiya nippītikam lokuttara sappītikataḥ ca lokuttara nippītikam
translated: Herein, the mundane is the mundane’s, and the supramundane is the supramundane’s.

original: agganti evaṃ bhummantaraṃ abhinditvā aggabhāvo veditabbo.
analyzed: aggan ti evam bhumma antaram a bhinditvā agga bhāvaḥ veditabbo
translated: The “foremost” should be understood as the foremost in each plane without distinguishing the kinds.

original: 73. Navame sātasukhanti tīsu jhānesu sukhaṃ. Upekkhāsukhanti catutthajjhānasukhaṃ.
analyzed: navame sāta sukhanti tīsu jhānesu sukham upekkhā sukhanti catuttha jhāna sukham
translated: In the ninth triad the pleasure in the three jhānas is pleasure of pleasure; the pleasure in the fourth jhāna is pleasure of equanimity.

original: 74. Dasame samādhisukhanti appanaṃ vā upacāraṃ vā pattasukhaṃ. Asamādhisukhanti tadubhayaṃ appattasukhaṃ.
analyzed: dasame samādhi sukhanti appanam vā upacāram vā patta sukham asamādhi sukhanti tat ubhayam appatta sukham
translated: In the tenth triad the pleasure that has reached absorption or access is pleasure of concentration; the pleasure that has not reached either is pleasure of non-concentration.

original: 75. Ekādasame sappītikārammaṇanti sappītikaṃ jhānadvayaṃ paccavekkhantassa uppannasukhaṃ. Nippītikārammaṇepi eseva nayo. Dvādasamepi imināva upāyena attho veditabbo.🔽77. Terasame rūpārammaṇanti rūpāvacaracatutthajjhānārammaṇaṃ, yaṃkiñci rūpaṃ ārabbha
analyzed: ekādasame sappītika ārammaṇam ti sappītikam jhāna dvayam paccavekkhantassa uppanna sukham nippītika ārammaṇe pi esa iva nayaḥ dvādasame pi iminā āva upāyena attho veditabbo  terasame rūpa ārammaṇam ti rūpa avacara catuttha jjhāna ārammaṇam yaṃ kiñci rūpam ārabbha
translated: In the eleventh the pleasure that arises in one who reviews the two jhānas with happiness is on a happy object; the pleasure that arises in one who reviews the fourth jhāna is on a neutral object. The meaning should be understood in each case in accordance with the actual state of affairs. In the twelfth the meaning should be understood in the same way.

original: uppajjanakaṃ vā. Arūpārammaṇanti arūpāvacarajjhānārammaṇaṃ, yaṃkiñci arūpaṃ ārabbha uppajjanakaṃ vāti.🔽Sukhavaggo dutiyo.
analyzed: uppajjanakam vā arūpa ārammaṇam ti arūpa avacara jhāna ārammaṇam yaṃ kiñci arūpam ārabbha uppajjanakam vā ati 🔽sukha vaggaḥ dutiyaḥ
translated: In the thirteenth the object of the fourth jhāna of the fine-material sphere is a material object; that of the immaterial jhānas is an immaterial object.

original: (8) 3. Sanimittavaggavaṇṇanā
translated: 8. 3. The Description of the Third Chapter

original: 78-79. Tatiyassa paṭhame sanimittāti sakāraṇā. Dutiyādīsupi eseva nayo. Nidānaṃ hetu saṅkhāro paccayo rūpanti sabbānipi hi etāni kāraṇavevacanāneva.
analyzed: tatiyassa paṭhame sa nimittā ati sa kāraṇā dutiya ādīsu pi esa iva nayaḥ nidānam hetu saṅkhāraḥ paccayaḥ rūpan ti sabbāni api hi etāni kāraṇa vevacanāni eva
translated: In the first of the third tetrad “with a cause” is with a reason. The same method applies in the second and third. “Source,” “cause,” “formation,” and “condition” are all synonyms for reason.

original: 84. Sattame savedanāti paccayabhūtāya sampayuttavedanāya satiyeva uppajjanti, nāsatīti attho. Aṭṭhamanavamesupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: sattame sa vedanā ti paccaya bhūtāya sampayutta vedanāya satiyā iva uppajjanti na asatī ti attho aṭṭhama navamesu pi esa eva nayo
translated: In the seventh “with feeling” means that they arise only when there is feeling associated with them that has become a condition for them, not when there is not. The same method applies in the eighth and ninth.

original: 87. Dasame saṅkhatārammaṇāti paccayanibbattaṃ saṅkhatadhammaṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvāva uppajjanti.
analyzed: dasame saṅkhata ārammaṇā ti paccaya nibbattam saṅkhata dhammam ārammaṇam katvā va uppajjanti
translated: In the tenth “with a formed object” means that they arise only with a formed state that is a condition as object.

original: No asaṅkhatārammaṇāti asaṅkhataṃ pana nibbānaṃ ārabbha na uppajjanti. Na hontīti🔽maggakkhaṇe na honti nāma, phale patte nāhesunti. Evametesu dasasupi ṭhānesu yāva
analyzed: no asaṅkhata ārammaṇā ati asaṅkhatam pana nibbānam ārabbha na uppajjanti na honti iti  magga kkhaṇe na honti nāma phale patte evam etesu dasasu pi ṭhānesu yāva
translated: “Not with an unformed object” means that they do not arise with the unformed element, Nibbāna. “Do not exist” means🔽that they do not exist at the moment of the path. When the fruit has been reached, they are not.

original: arahattā desanā desitāti.
analyzed: arahattā desanā desitā ati
translated: Thus the teaching is given in these ten instances up to arahantship.

original: Sanimittavaggo tatiyo.
analyzed: sa nimitta vaggaḥ tatiyaḥ
translated: The third chapter called “With a Cause” is finished.

original: (9) 4. Dhammavaggavaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Fourth Chapter

original: 88. Catutthassa paṭhame cetovimuttīti phalasamādhi. Paññāvimuttīti phalapaññā.
analyzed: catutthassa paṭhame cetaḥ vimutti iti phala samādhi paññā vimutti iti phala paññā
translated: In the first of the fourth group, “deliverance of mind” is fruition concentration, and “deliverance by wisdom” is fruition understanding.

original: 89. Dutiye paggāhoti vīriyaṃ. Avikkhepoti cittekaggatā.
analyzed: dutiye paggāho ti vīriyam avikkhepo ti citta ekagga tā
translated: In the second, “grasping” is energy, and “non-distraction” is unification of mind.

original: 90. Tatiye nāmanti cattāro arūpakkhandhā. Rūpanti rūpakkhandho. Iti imasmiṃ sutte dhammakoṭṭhāsaparicchedañāṇaṃ nāma kathitaṃ.
analyzed: tatiye nāmanti cattāro arūpa kkhandhāḥ rūpanti rūpa kkhandho iti imasmim sutte dhammakoṭṭhāsaparicchedañāṇam nāma kathitam
translated: In the third, “name” is the four immaterial aggregates, and “form” is the materiality aggregate. So in this sutta the knowledge of the analysis of the truths is taught.

original: 91. Catutthe vijjāti phalañāṇaṃ. Vimuttīti taṃsampayuttā sesadhammā.
analyzed: catutthe vijjā ati phala ñāṇam vimutti iti tad sampayuttā sesa dhammā
translated: In the fourth, “knowledge” is fruition knowledge, and “deliverance” is the remaining states associated with it.

original: 92. Pañcame bhavadiṭṭhīti sassatadiṭṭhi. Vibhavadiṭṭhīti ucchedadiṭṭhi. Chaṭṭhasattamāni uttānatthāneva.
analyzed: pañcame bhava diṭṭhi iti sassata diṭṭhi vibhava diṭṭhi iti uccheda diṭṭhi chaṭṭha sattamāni uttāna thānā eva
translated: In the fifth, “eternality view” is the eternalist view, and “annihilation view” is the annihilationist view. The sixth and seventh are self-evident.

original: 95. Aṭṭhame dovacassatāti dubbacabhāvo. Pāpamittatāti pāpamittasevanabhāvo. Navamaṃ vuttavipariyāyena veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: aṭṭhame dovacassatā ati dubbaca bhāvaḥ pāpa mitta tā ati pāpa mitta sevana bhāvaḥ navamam vutta vipariyāyena veditabbam
translated: In the eighth, “difficult to correct” is the state of being difficult to correct, and “evil friends” is the state of associating with evil friends. The ninth should be understood in the opposite sense to the eighth.

original: 97. Dasame dhātukusalatāti aṭṭhārasa dhātuyo dhātūti jānanaṃ. Manasikārakusalatāti tāsaṃyeva dhātūnaṃ aniccādivasena lakkhaṇattayaṃ āropetvā jānanaṃ.
analyzed: dasame dhātu kusala tā ati aṭṭhārasa dhātuyaḥ dhātu iti jānanam manasikāra kusala tā ati tāsam yeva dhātūnam anicca ādi vasena lakkhaṇa ttayam āropetvā jānanam
translated: In the tenth, “skill in elements” is the knowing of the eighteen elements as elements. “Skill in attending” is the knowing of the same elements by characterizing them according to the three characteristics, impermanence, etc.

original: 98. Ekādasame āpattikusalatāti pañcannañca sattannañca āpattikkhandhānaṃ jānanaṃ. Āpattivuṭṭhānakusalatāti desanāya vā kammavācāya vā āpattīhi vuṭṭhānajānananti.
analyzed: ekādasame āpatti kusala tā ati pañcannam ca sattannam ca āpatti kkhandhānam jānanaṃ āpatti vuṭṭhāna kusala tā ati desanāya vā kamma vācāya vā āpattīhi vuṭṭhāna jānananti
translated: “Skilled in offences” means knowing the five and the seven classes of offences. “Skilled in clearing offences” means knowing the clearing of offences by confession or by the performance of a ceremony.

original: Dhammavaggo catuttho.
analyzed: dhamma vaggaḥ catutthaḥ
translated: The fourth chapter on the True Idea is finished.

original: (10) 5. Bālavaggavaṇṇanā🔽99. Pañcamassa paṭhame anāgataṃ bhāraṃ vahatīti “sammajjanī padīpo ca, udakaṃ āsanena🔽ca, chandapārisuddhiutukkhānaṃ, bhikkhugaṇanā ca ovādo, pātimokkhaṃ therabhāroti🔽vuccatī”ti imaṃ dasavidhaṃ therabhāraṃ navako hutvā therena anajjhiṭṭho karonto anāgataṃ🔽bhāraṃ vahati nāma. Āgataṃ bhāraṃ na vahatīti thero samāno tameva dasavidhaṃ bhāraṃ
analyzed: pañcamassa paṭhame anāgatam bhāram vahati iti sammajjanī ca udakam āsanena  ca bhikkhu gaṇanā ca ovādaḥ pātimokkham thera bhāro ti  vuccati iti imam dasavidham thera bhāram navakaḥ hutvā therena anajjhiṭṭhaḥ karontaḥ anāgatam  bhāram vahati nāma āgatam bhāram na vahati iti theraḥ samānaḥ tam eva dasavidham bhāram
translated: The fool’s chapter

original: attanā vā akaronto paraṃ vā asamādapento āgataṃ bhāraṃ na vahati nāma. Dutiyasuttepi🔽imināva nayena attho veditabbo.
analyzed: attanā vā a karontaḥ param vā a samādapentaḥ āgatam bhāram na vahati nāma dutiya sutte pi 🔽iminā ava nayena atthaḥ veditabbo
translated: In the first of the five 1 the meaning is this. He carries a future burden: a new bhikkhu, not asked by an elder, does the ten kinds of burden of an elder, namely, the duties of the Community, the duties of a Community-representative, the duties of a Community-representative’s representative, the duties of a preceptor, the duties of a teacher, the duties of a co-resident, the duties of a pupil, the duties of a novice’s attendant, the duties of a worker, and the duties of a sick-nurse. He does not carry a present burden: an elder, not doing that same tenfold burden himself or not arranging for it to be done by others, does not carry a present burden. In the second sutta too the meaning should be understood in this way.

original: 101. Tatiye akappiye kappiyasaññīti akappiye sīhamaṃsādimhi “kappiyaṃ ida”nti evaṃsaññī.🔽Kappiye akappiyasaññīti kumbhīlamaṃsabiḷāramaṃsādimhi kappiye “akappiyaṃ ida”nti
analyzed: tatiye akappiye kappiya saññī iti akappiye sīha maṃsa ādimhi kappiyam idam ti evaṃsaññī  kappiye a kappiya saññī iti kumbhīla maṃsa biḷāra maṃsa ādimhi kappiye a kappiyam idam ti
translated: In the third, he perceives what is not allowable as allowable: he perceives as allowable what is not allowable, such as the flesh of wild animals, etc., thinking, “This is allowable.”

original: evaṃsaññī. Catutthaṃ vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ.🔽103. Pañcame anāpattiyā āpattisaññīti āpucchitvā bhaṇḍakaṃ dhovantassa, pattaṃ pacantassa,
analyzed: evaṃsaññī catuttham vutta nayena iva veditabbam  pañcame anāpattiyā āpatti saññī iti āpucchitvā bhaṇḍakam dhovantassa pattam pacantassa
translated: He perceives what is allowable as not allowable: he perceives as not allowable what is allowable, such as the flesh of pigs, dogs, and camels, etc., thinking, “This is not allowable.” The fourth should be understood in the way already stated.

original: kese chindantassa, gāmaṃ pavisantassātiādīsu anāpatti, tattha “āpatti aya”nti evaṃsaññī.
analyzed: kese chindantassa gāmam pavisantassa ati ādīsu anāpatti tattha āpatti ayanti evaṃsaññī
translated: In the fifth, he perceives what is not an offense as an offense: he perceives as an offense what is not an offense, such as washing a cloth belonging to oneself without asking for it, or cooking a bowl belonging to oneself, or cutting one’s own hair, or entering a village without informing anyone, thinking, “This is an offense.”

original: Āpattiyā anāpattisaññīti tesaññeva vatthūnaṃ anāpucchākaraṇe āpatti, tattha “anāpattī”ti
analyzed: āpattiyāḥ anāpatti saññī iti tesaññeva vatthūnam an āpucchā karaṇe āpatti tattha anāpatti iti
translated: He perceives what is an offense as not an offense: he perceives as not an offense what is an offense, such as doing these things without asking for permission, thinking, “This is not an offense.”

original: evaṃsaññī. Chaṭṭhepi vuttanayeneva attho veditabbo. Sattamādīni uttānatthāneva.
analyzed: evaṃsaññī chaṭṭhe pi vutta nayena iva atthaḥ veditabbo sattama ādīni uttāna tthānā eva
translated: The meaning of the sixth should be understood in the way already stated. The seventh, etc., are obvious.

original: 109. Ekādasame āsavāti kilesā. Na kukkuccāyitabbanti saṅghabhogassa apaṭṭhapanaṃ
analyzed: ekādasame kilesāḥ na saṅgha bhogassa apaṭṭhapanam
translated: In the eleventh, defilements: the defilements are called “remorse” because they are the cause of remorse. He should not be scrupulous: he should not be scrupulous about not using what belongs to the Community.

original: avicāraṇaṃ na kukkuccāyitabbaṃ nāma, taṃ kukkuccāyati. Kukkuccāyitabbanti tasseva
analyzed: a vicāraṇam na kukkuccāyitabbam nāma tam kukkuccāyati kukkuccāyitabbam ti tassa iva
translated: He is not anxious about what is not to be anxious about. He is anxious about what is to be anxious about. He is not anxious about what is to be anxious about.

original: paṭṭhapanaṃ vicāraṇaṃ, taṃ na kukkuccāyati. Dvādasamādīni heṭṭhā vuttanayeneva veditabbānīti.
analyzed: paṭṭhapanam vicāraṇam tam na kukkuccāyati dvādasama ādīni heṭṭhā vutta nayena iva veditabbāni iti
translated: He is anxious about what is not to be anxious about. The twelve are to be understood in the way already stated.

original: Bālavaggo pañcamo.
analyzed: bāla vaggo pañcamaḥ
translated: The fifth sub-chapter on fools is finished.

original: Dutiyapaṇṇāsakaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ.
analyzed: dutiya paṇṇāsakam niṭṭhitam

analyzed: tatiya paṇṇāsakam
translated: . The third fifties

original: (11) 1. Āsāduppajahavaggavaṇṇanā

analyzed: tatiyassa paṇṇāsakassa paṭhame āsāti taṇhā duppajahāti duccajā dunnīharā  sattā dasa pi vassāni vīsatipi saṭṭhipi vassāni ajja labhissāma
translated: In the first of the third fifties, hope is craving. It is difficult to give up, hard to get rid of. Hope for gain

translated: and they charge into battle with both sides drawn up, and they undertake the practice of the goat-path, the mouse-path, etc., and they go down to the great ocean in ships.

original: Jīvitāsāya duppajahattā sampatte maraṇakālepi vassasatajīviṃ attānaṃ maññanti. So
analyzed: jīvita āsāya duppajahattā sampatte maraṇa kāle pi vassa sata jīvim attānam maññanti so
translated: And because hope for life is difficult to give up, they think they will live a hundred years even when the time of death has arrived.

original: kammakammanimittādīni passantopi “dānaṃ dehi pūjaṃ, karohī”ti anukampakehi vuccamāno
analyzed: kamma kamma nimitta ādīni passantaḥ api dānam dehi pūjam karohi iti anukampakehi vuccamāno
translated: and he sees the work being done and the sign of the work being done, but when those who are compassionate say to him, “Give a gift, perform a rite of offering,”

original: “nāhaṃ marissāmi, jīvissāmi”cceva āsāya kassaci vacanaṃ na gaṇhāti.🔽120. Dutiye pubbakārīti paṭhamaṃ upakārassa kārako. Kataññūkatavedīti tena kataṃ
analyzed: na aham marissāmi jīvissāmi iccā iva āsāya kassaci vacanam na gaṇhāti  dutiye pubba kārī iti paṭhamam upakārassa kārako kataññūkatavedī iti tena katam
translated: he does not accept anyone’s word on the ground that “I shall not die, I shall live.”🔽In the second triad, the first helper is one who helps first. The one who repays what was done is one who helps later

translated: In the third triad, the satisfied and the satisfier: the one who is satisfied is the one who has destroyed the taints, either a paccekabuddha or a disciple of the Tathāgata. The satisfier is the Tathāgata, the Arahant, the Perfectly Enlightened One.

original: 122. Catutthe duttappayāti dāyakena duttappayā tappetuṃ na sukarā. Nikkhipatīti nidahati na paribhuñjati. Vissajjetīti paresaṃ deti.

translated: In the fourth triad, the difficult to satisfy: the giver finds it difficult to satisfy them by giving. He stores them away: he puts them aside and does not use them. He gives them away: he gives them to others.

analyzed: iti pi duppaṭipannā iti pi micchā paṭipannā ati avaṇṇam bhāsati vaṇṇa rahassa vaṇṇam  bhāsati iti su paṭipannānam sammāpaṭipannānam buddhānam buddha sāvakānam iti pi su paṭipannā

analyzed: sammāpaṭipannā ati vaṇṇam bhāsati
translated: he praises those who are well-practiced and correctly-practiced, saying: “They are well-practiced, they are correctly-practiced.”

original: 136. Chaṭṭhe appasādanīye ṭhāneti appasādakāraṇe. Pasādaṃ upadaṃsetīti duppaṭipadāya
analyzed: chaṭṭhe a pasādanīye ṭhāne iti appasāda kāraṇe pasādam upadaṃseti iti duppaṭipadāya

translated: He generates confidence in what inspires confidence, saying, “This is the right way, the straight way, the true way, the sound way, the way leading to Nibbāna,”

original: janetīti. Sesamettha uttānameva.

analyzed: āyācana vaggo dutiyaḥ  dāna vagga vaṇṇanā
translated: The second sub-chapter on begging is finished.🔽1. The sub-chapter on giving

original: 142. Tatiyassa paṭhame dānānīti diyyanakavasena dānāni, deyyadhammassetaṃ nāmaṃ.
analyzed: tatiyassa paṭhame dānāni iti diyyanaka vasena dānāni deyya dhammassa etam nāmam
translated: In the first of the third group, the kinds of giving are called “giving” in the sense of what is given, that is, in the sense of the thing given away.

original: Savatthukā vā cetanā dānaṃ, sampattipariccāgassetaṃ nāmaṃ. Āmisadānanti cattāro paccayā
analyzed: sa vatthukā vā cetanā dānam sampatti pariccāgassa etam nāmam āmisa dānanti cattāro paccayāḥ
translated: Or else, the volition that has a gift as its object is “giving,” which is called “the giving of an excellence” . The material giving is the four requisites

original: diyyanakavasena āmisadānaṃ nāma. Dhammadānanti idhekacco amatapattipaṭipadaṃ kathetvā
analyzed: diyyanaka vasena āmisa dānam nāma dhamma dānam ti idha ekaccaḥ amata patti paṭipadam kathetvā
translated: called “giving” in the sense of what is given. The giving of the Dhamma is when someone teaches the way to attain the deathless and then gives that.

original: deti, idaṃ dhammadānaṃ nāma.
analyzed: deti idam dhammadānam nāma
translated: This is called “giving of the Dhamma.”

original: 143. Dutiye cattāro paccayā yajanakavasena yāgo nāma dhammopi yajanakavasena yāgoti veditabbo.
analyzed: dutiye cattāro paccayāḥ yajanaka vasena yāgaḥ nāma dhammaḥ api yajanaka vasena yāgaḥ ti veditabbo
translated: In the second , the four requisites are called “sacrifice” in the sense of what is sacrificed. The Dhamma should be understood as “sacrifice” in the sense of what is sacrificed too.

original: 144. Tatiye āmisassa cajanaṃ āmisacāgo, dhammassa cajanaṃ dhammacāgo. Catutthe upasaggamattaṃ viseso.
analyzed: tatiye āmisassa cajanam āmisa cāgaḥ dhammassa cajanam dhamma cāgaḥ catutthe upasagga mattam visesaḥ
translated: In the third, giving of material things is giving of material things, giving of the Dhamma is giving of the Dhamma. In the fourth, the difference is only the addition of the prefix upa-.

original: 146. Pañcame catunnaṃ paccayānaṃ bhuñjanaṃ āmisabhogo, dhammassa bhuñjanaṃ dhammabhogo. Chaṭṭhe upasaggamattaṃ viseso.
analyzed: pañcame catunnam paccayānam bhuñjanam āmisa bhogaḥ dhammassa bhuñjanam dhamma bhogaḥ chaṭṭhe upasagga mattam visesaḥ
translated: In the fifth, enjoyment of the four kinds of requisites is enjoyment of material things, enjoyment of the Dhamma is enjoyment of the Dhamma. In the sixth, the difference is only the addition of the prefix upa-.

original: 148. Sattame catunnaṃ paccayānaṃ saṃvibhajanaṃ āmisasaṃvibhāgo, dhammassa saṃvibhajanaṃ dhammasaṃvibhāgo.
analyzed: sattame catunnam paccayānam saṃvibhajanam āmisa saṃvibhāgaḥ dhammassa saṃvibhajanam dhamma saṃvibhāgaḥ
translated: In the seventh, sharing out the four kinds of requisites is sharing out of material things, sharing out the Dhamma is sharing out of the Dhamma.

original: 149. Aṭṭhame catūhi paccayehi saṅgaho āmisasaṅgaho, dhammena saṅgaho dhammasaṅgaho.🔽150. Navame catūhi paccayehi anuggaṇhanaṃ āmisānuggaho, dhammena anuggaṇhanaṃ dhammānuggaho.
analyzed: aṭṭhame catūhi paccayehi saṅgahaḥ āmisa saṅgahaḥ dhammena saṅgahaḥ dhamma saṅgahaḥ  navame catūhi paccayehi anuggaṇhanam āmisa anuggahaḥ dhammena anuggaṇhanam dhamma anuggahaḥ
translated: In the eighth, collecting with the four kinds of requisites is collecting of material things, collecting by means of the Dhamma is collecting of the Dhamma.🔽In the ninth, helping with the four kinds of requisites is helping with material things, helping by means of the Dhamma is helping with the Dhamma.

original: 151. Dasame catūhi paccayehi anukampanaṃ āmisānukampā, dhammena anukampanaṃ dhammānukampāti.
analyzed: dasame catūhi paccayehi anukampanam āmisa anukampā dhammena anukampanam dhamma anukampā ati
translated: In the tenth, taking pity with the four kinds of requisites is taking pity with material things, taking pity by means of the Dhamma is taking pity with the Dhamma.

original: Dānavaggo tatiyo.
analyzed: dāna vaggo tatiyo
translated: The third chapter on giving is finished.

original: (14) 4. Santhāravaggavaṇṇanā
translated: The chapter on lodging

original: 152. Catutthassa paṭhame catūhi paccayehi attano ca parassa ca antarapaṭicchādanavasena
analyzed: catutthassa paṭhame catūhi paccayehi attano ca parassa ca antara paṭicchādana vasena
translated: In the first of the fourth triad, the “covering” is the covering of oneself and others by means of the four requisites.

original: santharaṇaṃ āmisasanthāro, dhammena santharaṇaṃ dhammasanthāro. Dutiye upasaggamattaṃ viseso.
analyzed: santharaṇam āmisa santhāraḥ dhammena santharaṇam dhamma santhāraḥ dutiye upasagga mattam visesaḥ
translated: The “material covering” is the covering of material things. The “Dhamma covering” is the covering of the Dhamma. In the second the only difference is the addition of the prefix upa-.

original: 154. Tatiye vuttappakārassa āmisassa esanā āmisesanā, dhammassa esanā dhammesanā. Catutthe upasaggamattameva viseso.
analyzed: tatiye vutta ppakārassa āmisassa esanā āmisa īsanā dhammassa esanā dhamma īsanā catutthe upasagga mattam eva visesaḥ
translated: In the third the “search for material things” is the search for material things of the kind already mentioned. The “search for the Dhamma” is the search for the Dhamma. In the fourth the only difference is the addition of the prefix upa-.

original: 156. Pañcame matthakappattā āmisapariyesanā āmisapariyeṭṭhi, matthakappattāva dhammapariyesanā dhammapariyeṭṭhīti vuttā.
analyzed: pañcame matthaka pattā āmisa pariyesanā āmisa pariyeṭṭhi matthaka ppattā ava dhamma pariyesanā dhamma pariyeṭṭhī iti vuttā
translated: In the fifth the “quest for material things” is the quest for material things that has reached the point of the head. The “quest for the Dhamma” is the quest for the Dhamma that has reached the point of the head.

original: 157. Chaṭṭhe āmisena pūjanaṃ āmisapūjā, dhammena pūjanaṃ dhammapūjā.
analyzed: chaṭṭhe āmisena pūjanam āmisa pūjā dhammena pūjanam dhamma pūjā
translated: In the sixth the “material honour” is the honouring with material things. The “Dhamma honour” is the honouring with the Dhamma.

original: 158. Sattame ātitheyyānīti āgantukadānāni. Atitheyyānītipi pāṭho.
analyzed: sattame ātitheyyāni iti āgantuka dānāni atitheyyāni iti pi
translated: In the seventh “hospitality” is the giving to visitors. The reading atitheyyaṃ is also allowable.

original: 159. Aṭṭhame āmisaṃ ijjhanakasamijjhanakavasena āmisiddhi, dhammopi ijjhanakasamijjhanakavasena dhammiddhi.
analyzed: aṭṭhame āmisam ijjhanaka samijjhanaka vasena āmisa iddhi dhammaḥ api ijjhanaka samijjhanaka vasena dhamma iddhi
translated: In the eighth the “success in material things” is the success in material things that is successful and well-faring. The “success in the Dhamma” is the success in the Dhamma that is successful and well-faring.

original: 160. Navame āmisena vaḍḍhanaṃ āmisavuddhi, dhammena vaḍḍhanaṃ dhammavuddhi.🔽161. Dasame ratikaraṇaṭṭhena āmisaṃ āmisaratanaṃ, dhammo dhammaratanaṃ.
analyzed: navame āmisena vaḍḍhanam āmisa vuddhi dhammena vaḍḍhanam dhamma vuddhi  dasame rati karaṇa ṭṭhena āmisam āmisa ratanam dhammaḥ dhamma ratanam
translated: 160.In the ninth, increase in material things is increase in material things; increase in the Dhamma is increase in the Dhamma.🔽In the tenth, material things are a material treasure because they bring pleasure; the Dhamma is a Dhamma treasure.

original: 162. Ekādasame āmisassa cinanaṃ vaḍḍhanaṃ āmisasannicayo, dhammassa cinanaṃ vaḍḍhanaṃ dhammasannicayo.
analyzed: ekādasame āmisassa cinanam vaḍḍhanam āmisa sannicayaḥ dhammassa cinanam vaḍḍhanam dhamma sannicayaḥ
translated: In the eleventh, accumulation of material things is the accumulation of material things; accumulation of the Dhamma is the accumulation of the Dhamma.

original: 163. Dvādasame āmisassa vipulabhāvo āmisavepullaṃ, dhammassa vipulabhāvo dhammavepullanti.
analyzed: dvādasame āmisassa vipula bhāvaḥ āmisa vepullam dhammassa vipula bhāvaḥ dhamma vepullam ti
translated: In the twelfth, abundance of material things is abundance of material things; abundance of the Dhamma is abundance of the Dhamma.

original: Santhāravaggo catuttho.
analyzed: santhāra vaggo catutthaḥ
translated: The fourth chapter on the requisites is finished.

original: (15) 5. Samāpattivaggavaṇṇanā🔽164. Pañcamassa paṭhame samāpattikusalatāti āhārasappāyaṃ utusappāyaṃ pariggaṇhitvā
analyzed: pañcamassa paṭhame samāpatti kusala tā ati āhāra sappāyam utu sappāyam pariggaṇhitvā
translated: 1. The chapter on attainment

original: samāpattisamāpajjane chekatā. Samāpattivuṭṭhānakusalatāti yathāparicchedena gate
analyzed: samāpatti samāpajjane cheka tā samāpatti vuṭṭhāna kusala tā ati yathā paricchedena gate
translated: In the first of the fifth chapter, skill in attainment is the ability to enter upon attainment by discerning what is suitable for the purpose of nutriment and what is suitable for the purpose of climate.

original: kāle viyatto hutvā uṭṭhahanto vuṭṭhānakusalo nāma hoti, evaṃ kusalatā.
analyzed: kāle viyattaḥ hutvā uṭṭhahantaḥ vuṭṭhāna kusalaḥ nāma hoti evam kusala tā
translated: Skill in emerging from attainment is the ability to emerge at the right time without over-doing it.

original: 165. Dutiye ajjavanti ujubhāvo. Maddavanti mudubhāvo.
analyzed: dutiye ajjavanti uju bhāvaḥ maddavanti mudu bhāvaḥ
translated: In the second, uprightness is straightforwardness; gentleness is mildness.

original: 166. Tatiye khantīti adhivāsanakhanti. Soraccanti susīlyabhāvena suratabhāvo.
analyzed: tatiye khanti iti adhivāsana khanti soraccanti susīlya bhāvena surata bhāvaḥ
translated: In the third, patience is patience in enduring. Gentleness is gentleness of disposition due to good breeding.

original: 167. Catutthe sākhalyanti saṇhavācāvasena sammodamānabhāvo. Paṭisanthāroti āmisena vā dhammena vā paṭisantharaṇaṃ.
analyzed: catutthe sākhalyanti saṇha vācā vasena sammodamāna bhāvo paṭisanthāro ti āmisena vā dhammena vā paṭisantharaṇam
translated: In the fourth, amiability is amiability of disposition due to speaking gently. Friendliness is the act of welcoming with material gifts or the Dhamma.

original: 168. Pañcame avihiṃsāti karuṇāpubbabhāgo. Soceyyanti sīlavasena sucibhāvo. Chaṭṭhasattamāni uttānatthāneva.
analyzed: pañcame a vihiṃsā ati karuṇā pubbabhāgaḥ soceyyanti sīla vasena suci bhāvo chaṭṭha sattamāni uttāna tthānā eva
translated: In the fifth, non-ill-will is the forerunner of compassion. Purity is purity of disposition due to virtue. The sixth and seventh are self-evident.

original: 171. Aṭṭhame paṭisaṅkhānabalanti paccavekkhaṇabalaṃ.
analyzed: aṭṭhame paṭisaṅkhāna balanti paccavekkhaṇa balaṃ
translated: In the eighth, the strength of reflection is the strength of reviewing.

original: 172. Navame muṭṭhassacce akampanena satiyeva satibalaṃ. Uddhacce akampanena samādhiyeva samādhibalaṃ.
analyzed: navame muṭṭhaḥ sacce akampanena satiyā iva sati balam uddhacce akampanena samādhiyā iva samādhi balam
translated: In the ninth, mindfulness is the strength of mindfulness since it is unshakable in respect of forgetfulness. Concentration is the strength of concentration since it is unshakable in respect of agitation.

original: 173. Dasame samathoti cittekaggatā. Vipassanāti saṅkhārapariggāhakaññāṇaṃ.
analyzed: dasame samatho ti citta ekagga tā vipassanā ati saṅkhāra pariggāhaka ññāṇam
translated: In the tenth, serenity is unification of mind. Insight is the knowledge that investigates formations.

original: 174. Ekādasame sīlavipattīti dussīlyaṃ. Diṭṭhivipattīti micchādiṭṭhi.
analyzed: ekādasame sīla vipatti iti dussīlyam diṭṭhi vipatti iti micchādiṭṭhi
translated: In the eleventh, failure in virtue is misconduct. Failure in view is wrong view.

original: 175. Dvādasame sīlasampadāti paripuṇṇasīlatā. Diṭṭhisampadāti sammādiṭṭhikabhāvo.
analyzed: dvādasame sīla sampadā ati paripuṇṇa sīla tā diṭṭhi sampadā ati sammādiṭṭhika bhāvo
translated: In the twelfth, virtue perfected is the state of one whose virtue is fulfilled. View perfected is the state of one who possesses right view.

original: Tena kammassakatasammādiṭṭhi, jhānasammādiṭṭhi, vipassanāsammādiṭṭhi, maggasammādiṭṭhi,
analyzed: tena kammassakata sammādiṭṭhi jhāna sammādiṭṭhi vipassanā sammādiṭṭhi magga sammādiṭṭhi
translated: Right view of action, right view of jhana, right view of insight, right view of the path,

original: phalasammādiṭṭhīti sabbāpi pañcavidhā sammādiṭṭhi saṅgahitā hoti.
analyzed: phala sammādiṭṭhī iti sabbā api pañcavidhā sammādiṭṭhi saṅgahitā hoti
translated: So all the five kinds of right view, namely, right view consisting in the fruit of once-return, right view consisting in the fruit of non-return, right view consisting in the fruit of arahantship, right view consisting in the path, and right view consisting in fruition, are included here.

original: 176. Terasame sīlavisuddhīti visuddhisampāpakaṃ sīlaṃ. Diṭṭhivisuddhīti visuddhisampāpikā catumaggasammādiṭṭhi, pañcavidhāpi vā sammādiṭṭhi.🔽177. Cuddasame diṭṭhivisuddhīti visuddhisampāpikā sammādiṭṭhiyeva. Yathādiṭṭhissa
analyzed: terasame sīla visuddhi iti visuddhi sampāpakam sīlam diṭṭhi visuddhi iti visuddhi sampāpikā catu magga sammādiṭṭhi pañcavidhā api vā sammādiṭṭhi  cuddasame diṭṭhi visuddhī iti visuddhi sampāpikā sammādiṭṭhiyā iva yathā diṭṭhissa
translated: In the thirteenth, “purity of virtue” is virtue that effects purification. “Purity of view” is right view belonging to the four paths and fruits or the five kinds of right view that effect purification.

original: ca padhānanti heṭṭhimamaggasampayuttaṃ vīriyaṃ. Tañhi tassā diṭṭhiyā anurūpattā “yathādiṭṭhissa🔽ca padhāna”nti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: ca padhānam ti heṭṭhima magga sampayuttam vīriyam tat hi tassā diṭṭhiyāḥ anurūpa ttā yathā diṭṭhissa  ca padhānam iti vuttam
translated: In the fourteenth, “purity of view” is right view that effects purification. “Striving in accordance with what is seen” is energy associated with the lower path. That is said to be “striving in accordance with what is seen” because it is suitable to that view.

original: 178. Pannarasame asantuṭṭhitā ca kusalesu dhammesūti aññatra arahattamaggā kusalesu dhammesu asantuṭṭhibhāvo.
analyzed: pannarasame asantuṭṭhi tā ca kusalesu dhammesu iti aññatra arahatta maggā kusalesu dhammesu asantuṭṭhi bhāvo
translated: In the fifteenth, “not being satisfied with the attainment of any degree of distinction in profitable things” is the dissatisfied state with regard to profitable things other than the path of arahantship.

original: 179. Soḷasame muṭṭhassaccanti muṭṭhassatibhāvo. Asampajaññanti aññāṇabhāvo.
analyzed: soḷasame muṭṭhassaccanti muṭṭhassati bhāvaḥ asampajaññanti aññāṇa bhāvaḥ
translated: In the sixteenth, “forgetfulness” is the state of forgetfulness. “Lack of full awareness” is the state of unknowing.

original: 180. Sattarasame apilāpanalakkhaṇā sati. Sammā pajānanalakkhaṇaṃ sampajaññanti.
analyzed: sattarasame apilāpana lakkhaṇā sati sammā pajānana lakkhaṇam sampajaññanti
translated: 180. Mindfulness has the characteristic of non-bewilderment in the seventeenth. Understanding has the characteristic of right knowing.

original: Samāpattivaggo pañcamo. Tatiyapaṇṇāsakaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ.
analyzed: samāpatti vaggo pañcamo tatiya paṇṇāsakam niṭṭhitam
translated: The fifth chapter on attainment is finished. The third decade is finished.

original: 1. Kodhapeyyālaṃ
analyzed: kodha peyyā alam
translated: . Grudge

original: 181. Ito paresu kujjhanalakkhaṇo kodho. Upanandhanalakkhaṇo upanāho. Sukatakaraṇamakkhanalakkhaṇo
analyzed: itas paresu kujjhana lakkhaṇaḥ kodhaḥ upanandhana lakkhaṇaḥ upanāhaḥ su kata karaṇa makkhana lakkhaṇo
translated: . From here on, the characteristic of anger is getting angry. The characteristic of resentment is bearing ill will. The characteristic of contempt is despising one who deserves to be corrected.

original: makkho. Yugaggāhalakkhaṇo palāso. Usūyanalakkhaṇā issā. Pañcamaccherabhāvo macchariyaṃ.
analyzed: makkhaḥ yuga ggāha lakkhaṇaḥ palāsaḥ usūyana lakkhaṇā issā pañca maccheḥ abhāvaḥ macchariyam
translated: The characteristic of obstinacy is taking up a side. The characteristic of envy is jealousy. The characteristic of avarice is the fifth state of avarice.

original: Taṃ sabbampi maccharāyanalakkhaṇaṃ. Katapaṭicchādanalakkhaṇā māyā. Kerāṭikalakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: tam sabbam pi mad charāyana lakkhaṇam kata paṭicchādana lakkhaṇā māyā kerāṭika lakkhaṇam
translated: All that has the characteristic of being avaricious. The characteristic of deceit is concealing what has been done. The characteristic of fraudulence is the way of a cheat.

original: sāṭheyyaṃ. Alajjanākāro ahirikaṃ. Upavādato abhāyanākāro anottappaṃ. Akkodhādayo
analyzed: sāṭheyyam a lajjana ākāraḥ ahirikam upavādataḥ a bhāyanā ākāraḥ anottappam akkodha ādayaḥ
translated: The characteristic of shamelessness is the way of not being ashamed. The characteristic of fearlessness of wrongdoing is the way of not being afraid of wrongdoing. The opposite of anger, etc.,

original: tesaṃ paṭipakkhavasena veditabbā.
analyzed: tesam paṭipakkha vasena veditabbā
translated: should be understood as the opposite of those.

original: 185. Sekkhassa bhikkhunoti sattavidhassāpi sekkhassa upariupariguṇehi parihānāya
analyzed: sekkhassa bhikkhuno ti sattavidhassa api sekkhassa upari upari guṇehi parihānāya
translated: . Of a trainee bhikkhu: they lead to the loss of the higher qualities of the seven kinds of trainee,🔽but they should be understood to lead to the loss of the ordinary man’s qualities sooner.

original: saṃvattanti, puthujjanassa pana paṭhamataraṃyeva parihānāya saṃvattantīti veditabbā.
analyzed: saṃvattanti puthujjanassa pana paṭhamataraṃ yeva parihānāya saṃvattanti iti veditabbā
translated: but for the ordinary man they lead to falling away first of all.

original: Aparihānāyāti upariupariguṇehi aparihānatthāya.
analyzed: a parihānāya ati upari upari guṇehi a parihāna atthāya
translated: For non-decline: for the purpose of non-decline in higher and higher qualities.

original: 187. Yathābhataṃ nikkhittoti yathā ānetvā nikkhitto, evaṃ niraye patiṭṭhito vāti veditabbo.
analyzed: yathābhatam nikkhitto ti yathā ānetvā nikkhittaḥ evam niraye patiṭṭhitaḥ vā ati veditabbo
translated: As he is placed: as he is brought and placed, so he should be understood to be placed in hell.

original: 190. Ekaccoti yassete kodhādayo atthi, so ekacco nāma.
analyzed: ekacco iti yassa ete kodha ādayaḥ atthi saḥ ekaccaḥ nāma
translated: One: one who has these things beginning with anger.

original: Kodhapeyyālaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ.
analyzed: kodhapeyyālam niṭṭhitam
translated: The sub-chapter on anger is finished.

original: 2. Akusalapeyyālaṃ🔽191-200. Sāvajjāti sadosā. Anavajjāti niddosā. Dukkhudrayāti dukkhavaḍḍhikā. Sukhudriyāti
analyzed: a kusala peyyā alam  sāvajjā ati sa dosā anavajjā ati niddosā dukkhudrayā ati dukkhavaḍḍhikā sukhudriyā ati
translated: The unprofitable

original: sukhavaḍḍhikā. Sabyābajjhāti sadukkhā. Abyābajjhāti niddukkhā. Ettāvatā vaṭṭavivaṭṭameva kathitaṃ.
analyzed: sukha vaḍḍhikā sa byābajjhā ati sa dukkhā a byābajjhā ati niddukkhā ettāvatā vaṭṭa vivaṭṭam eva kathitam
translated: Reproachable: with hate. Blameless: without hate. Painful: increasing pain. Pleasant: increasing pleasure. With conflict: with pain. Without conflict: without pain. So far, only the round and the transcending of the round have been stated.

original: Akusalapeyyālaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ.
analyzed: akusalapeyyālam niṭṭhitam
translated: The unprofitable permutation series is finished.

original: 3. Vinayapeyyālaṃ
analyzed: vinaya peyya alam
translated: The Monastic Code

original: 201. Dveme, bhikkhave, atthavase paṭiccāti, bhikkhave, dve atthe nissāya dve kāraṇāni🔽sandhāya. Sikkhāpadaṃ paññattanti sikkhākoṭṭhāso ṭhapito. Saṅghasuṭṭhutāyāti saṅghassa
analyzed: dve me bhikkhave attha vase paṭicca ati bhikkhave dve atthe nissāya dve kāraṇāni 🔽sandhāya sikkhāpadam paññattanti sikkhā koṭṭhāsaḥ ṭhapito saṅgha suṭṭhu tāya ati saṅghassa
translated: “Bhikkhus, for two reasons a training rule is laid down for disciples by me.🔽“For the well-faring of many people, for the happiness of many people, for the welfare, benefit, and happiness of devas and humans.”

original: suṭṭhubhāvāya, “suṭṭhu, bhante”ti vatvā sampaṭicchanatthāyāti attho. Saṅghaphāsutāyāti🔽saṅghassa phāsuvihāratthāya. Dummaṅkūnanti dussīlānaṃ. Pesalānanti pīyasīlānaṃ. Diṭṭhadhammikānaṃ
