analyzed: manoratha pūraṇiyā aṅguttara nikāya aṭṭhakathāya
translated: The commentary on the Anguttara Nikāya, which is called Manorathapūraṇī,

original: Dukanipātassa saṃvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: duka nipātassa saṃvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: is finished.

original: . Namo tassa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa.
analyzed: namaḥ tassa bhagavataḥ arahataḥ sammāsambuddhassa
translated: Homage to the Blessed One, the Arahant, the Perfectly Enlightened One.

original: Aṅguttaranikāye
analyzed: aṅguttara nikāye
translated: In the Anguttara Nikāya

original: Tikanipāta-aṭṭhakathā
analyzed: tika nipāta aṭṭhakathā
translated: The commentary on the Triads🔽The first fifty

original: 1. Paṭhamapaṇṇāsakaṃ🔽1. Bālavaggo
analyzed: paṭhama paṇṇāsakam  bāla vaggo
translated: The fool’s chapter

original: 1. Bhayasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: bhaya sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The exposition of the “Fear” sutta

original: 1. Tikanipātassa paṭhame bhayānītiādīsu bhayanti cittutrāso. Upaddavoti anekaggatākāro. Upasaggoti upasaṭṭhākāro tattha tattha lagganākāro.
analyzed: tika nipātassa paṭhame bhayāni iti ādīsu bhayanti cittu trāsaḥ upaddavaḥ ti anekaggatā ākāro upasaggo ti upasaṭṭhā ākāro tattha tattha laggana ākāro
translated: In the first of the three groups, in the case of the words beginning with “fear” , fear is mental terror.11 Danger is the state of being in many places.12 Peril is the state of being stuck here and there.

original: Tesaṃ evaṃ nānattaṃ veditabbaṃ – pabbatavisamanissitā corā janapadavāsīnaṃ pesenti
analyzed: tesam evam nānattam veditabbam pabbata visama nissitā corāḥ janapada vāsīnam pesenti
translated: The difference between them should be understood as follows. Bandits living in a mountain wilderness send word to the inhabitants of a village:

original: – “mayaṃ asukadivase nāma tumhākaṃ gāmaṃ paharissāmā”ti. Te taṃ pavattiṃ sutakālato
analyzed: mayam asukadivase nāma tumhākam gāmam paharissāma ati te tam pavattim suta kālataḥ
translated: “On such-and-such a day we shall attack your village.” From the time they hear this news

original: paṭṭhāya bhayaṃ santāsaṃ āpajjanti. Ayaṃ cittutrāso nāma. “Yathā no te corā kupitā
analyzed: paṭṭhāya bhayam santāsam āpajjanti ayam cittutrāsaḥ nāma yathā no te corā kupitā
translated: they are seized with fear and terror. This is called mental terror. “If those bandits get angry with us,

original: anatthampi āvaheyyu”nti hatthasāraṃ gahetvā dvipadacatuppadehi saddhiṃ araññaṃ pavisitvā
analyzed: anattham pi āvaheyyunti hattha sāram gahetvā dvipada catuppadehi saddhim araññam pavisitvā
translated: they might bring us to destruction,” they think, and taking their plough-oxen and their children, they go and live in the forest with two-footed and four-footed animals.

original: tattha tattha bhūmiyaṃ nipajjanti ḍaṃsamakasādīhi khajjamānā, gumbantarāni pavisantā
analyzed: tattha tattha bhūmiyam nipajjanti ḍaṃsama kasā ādīhi khajjamānāḥ gumbantarāni pavisantā
translated: There they lie down on the ground, and while they are being eaten by mosquitoes and sandflies, they enter the hollows of trees

original: khāṇukaṇṭake maddanti. Tesaṃ evaṃ vicarantānaṃ vikkhittabhāvo anekaggatākāro nāma.
analyzed: khāṇukaṇṭake maddanti tesam evam vicarantānam vikkhitta bhāvaḥ anekagga tā ākāraḥ nāma
translated: and crush themselves on stumps. The state of being scattered and distracted in this way is called the state of being in many places.

original: Tato coresu yathāvutte divase anāgacchantesu “tucchakasāsanaṃ bhavissati, gāmaṃ pavisissāmā”ti
analyzed: tatas coresu yathā vutte divase an āgacchantesu tucchaka sāsanam bhavissati gāmam pavisissāma ati
translated: Then, when the thieves did not come on the appointed day, they thought, “The doctrine of the ascetic Gotama is empty. We will enter the village.”

original: saparikkhārā gāmaṃ pavisanti. Atha tesaṃ paviṭṭhabhāvaṃ ñatvā gāmaṃ parivāretvā dvāre
analyzed: sa parikkhārāḥ gāmam pavisanti atha tesam paviṭṭha bhāvam ñatvā gāmam parivāretvā dvāre
translated: So they entered the village with their belongings. Then, having learned that they had entered the village, the thieves surrounded the village and set fire to the gate.

original: aggiṃ datvā manusse ghātetvā corā sabbaṃ vibhavaṃ vilumpitvā gacchanti. Tesu ghātitāvasesā
analyzed: aggim da tvā manusse ghātetvā corā sabbam vibhavam vilumpitvā gacchanti tesu ghātitā avasesā
translated: Having killed the people, the thieves robbed all their wealth and left. Those who survived the fire

original: aggiṃ nibbāpetvā koṭṭhakacchāyābhitticchāyādīsu tattha tattha laggitvā nisīdanti
analyzed: aggim nibbāpetvā koṭṭhaka chāyā bhitti chāyā ādīsu tattha tattha laggitvā nisīdanti
translated: put out the fire in the courtyards, on the walls, and so on, and sat here and there, clinging to the shadows.

original: naṭṭhaṃ anusocamānā. Ayaṃ upasaṭṭhākāro lagganākāro nāma.🔽Naḷāgārāti naḷehi channapaṭicchannaagārā. Sesasambhārā panettha rukkhamayā honti.🔽Tiṇāgārepi eseva nayo. Kūṭāgārānīti kūṭasaṅgahitāni agārāni. Ullittāvalittānīti anto
analyzed: naṭṭham anusocamānā ayam upasaṭṭhākāraḥ lagganākāraḥ nāma  naḷa āgārā ati naḷehi channa paṭicchanna agārā sesa sambhārā pana ittha rukkha mayāḥ honti  tiṇa āgāre pi esā iva nayo kūṭāgārāni iti kūṭa saṅgahitāni agārāni ullitta avalittāni iti antaḥ
translated: They sat there mourning their loss. This is called the mode of clinging.🔽“Huts thatched with reeds”: huts covered with reeds. The other requisites here are made of wood.🔽The same method applies to huts thatched with grass. “Huts with peaked roofs”: huts with peaked roofs. “With projecting roofs”: with roofs that project.

original: ca bahi ca littāni. Nivātānīti nivāritavātappavesāni. Phusitaggaḷānīti chekehi vaḍḍhakīhi
analyzed: ca bahi ca littāni nivātāni iti nivārita vāta ppavesāni phusita ggaḷāni iti chekehi vaḍḍhakīhi
translated: “With eaves”: with eaves. “With verandas”: with verandas. “With upper chambers”: with upper chambers. “With windows”: with windows. “With doors”: with doors.

original: katattā piṭṭhasaṅghāṭamhi suṭṭhu phusitakavāṭāni. Pihitavātapānānīti yuttavātapānāni.
analyzed: katattā piṭṭha saṅghāṭamhi suṭṭhu phusita kavāṭāni pihita vāta pānāni iti yutta vāta pānāni
translated: and the doors were well closed by being bolted on the inside. With the windows closed: with the windows fitted.

original: Iminā padadvayena kavāṭavātapānānaṃ niccapihitataṃ akathetvā sampattiyeva kathitā.
analyzed: iminā pada dvayena kavāṭa vāta pānānam a kathetvā sampattiyā iva kathitā
translated: By these two terms the fact that the doors and windows were well closed is stated, not the fact that they were not opened.

original: Icchiticchitakkhaṇe pana tāni pidhīyanti ca vivarīyanti ca.
analyzed: icchiticchita khaṇe pana tāni pidhīyanti ca ca
translated: But they were opened and closed at will.

original: Bālato uppajjantīti bālameva nissāya uppajjanti. Bālo hi apaṇḍitapuriso rajjaṃ vā
analyzed: bālataḥ uppajjanti iti bālam eva nissāya uppajjanti bālaḥ hi apaṇḍita purisaḥ rajjam vā
translated: Arising from fools: arising only in dependence on fools. For a fool, an unintelligent person,🔽seeking a kingship, a deputy kingship, or some other high position,

original: oparajjaṃ vā aññaṃ vā pana mahantaṃ ṭhānaṃ patthento katipaye attanā sadise vidhavaputte
analyzed: oparajjam vā aññam vā pana mahantam ṭhānam patthento katipaye attanā sadise vidhava putte
translated: takes with him a number of other fools like himself, sons of barren women,

original: mahādhutte gahetvā “etha ahaṃ tumhe issare karissāmī”ti pabbatagahanādīni nissāya🔽antamante gāme paharanto dāmarikabhāvaṃ jānāpetvā anupubbena nigamepi janapadepi
analyzed: mahādhutte gahetvā etha aham tumhe issare karissāmi iti pabbata gahana ādīni nissāya  antam ante gāme paharantaḥ dāmarika bhāvam jānāpetvā anupubbena nigame pi janapade pi
translated: and says, “Come, I will make you rulers.” And taking to the forest wilds,🔽he goes about plundering villages, making himself known as a bandit. Eventually he plunders in the market town and in the countryside.

original: paharati. Manussā gehāni chaḍḍetvā khemaṭṭhānaṃ patthayamānā pakkamanti. Te nissāya
analyzed: paharati manussāḥ gehāni chaḍḍetvā khemaṭṭhānam patthayamānāḥ pakkamanti te nissāya
translated: People abandon their homes and flee in search of a safe place.

original: vasantā bhikkhūpi bhikkhuniyopi attano attano vasanaṭṭhānāni pahāya pakkamanti. Gatagataṭṭhāne
analyzed: vasantā bhikkhū pi bhikkhuniyaḥ pi attanaḥ attanaḥ vasanaṭṭhānāni pahāya pakkamanti gata gata ṭṭhāne
translated: And the monks and nuns, too, left their own quarters and went away.

original: bhikkhāpi senāsanampi dullabhaṃ hoti. Evaṃ catunnampi parisānaṃ bhayaṃ āgatameva
analyzed: bhikkhā api senāsanam pi dullabham hoti evam catunnam pi parisānam bhayam āgatam eva
translated: And wherever they went, alms and lodging were hard to get. So fear came upon all four assemblies.

original: hoti. Pabbajjitesupi dve bālā bhikkhū aññamaññaṃ vivādaṃ paṭṭhapetvā codanaṃ ārabhanti.
analyzed: hoti pabbajjitesu pi dve bālā bhikkhū aññamaññam vivādam paṭṭhapetvā codanam ārabhanti
translated: And among the monks who had gone forth, two foolish monks started a dispute with each other and began to accuse each other.🔽So a great dispute arose among the Kosambī residents,

original: Iti kosambivāsikānaṃ viya mahākalaho uppajjati. Catunnaṃ parisānaṃ bhayaṃ āgatameva
analyzed: iti kosambi vāsikānam viya mahā kalahaḥ uppajjati catunnam parisānam bhayam āgatam eva
translated: and fear came upon all four assemblies.

original: hotīti evaṃ yāni kānici bhayāni uppajjanti, sabbāni tāni bālato uppajjantīti yathānusandhinā desanaṃ niṭṭhapesi.
analyzed: hoti iti evam yāni kānici bhayāni uppajjanti sabbāni tāni bālataḥ uppajjanti iti yathā anusandhinā desanam niṭṭhapesi
translated: So whatever fears arise, they all arise from a fool. This is how the Exalted One concluded the teaching with a reference to the original incident.

original: 2. Lakkhaṇasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: lakkhaṇa sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Commentary on the Lakkhaṇa Sutta

original: 2. Dutiye kāyadvārādipavattaṃ kammaṃ lakkhaṇaṃ sañjānanakāraṇaṃ assāti kammalakkhaṇo.
analyzed: dutiye kāya dvāra ādi pavattam kammam lakkhaṇam sañjānana kāraṇam assa ati kamma lakkhaṇaḥ
translated: In the second sutta, kamma that occurs through the door of the body, etc., is a lakkhaṇa, a cause of recognition, thus it is a kammalakkhaṇa.

original: Apadānasobhanī paññāti yā paññā nāma apadānena sobhati, bālā ca paṇḍitā ca attano
analyzed: apadāna sobhanī paññā ati yā paññā nāma apadānena sobhati bālā ca paṇḍitā ca attano
translated: The beauty of the feet is wisdom. The wisdom that is beautiful because of the feet is the wisdom of fools and the wisdom of the wise.

original: attano cariteneva pākaṭā hontīti attho. Bālena hi gatamaggo rukkhagacchagāmanigamādīni🔽jhāpetvā gacchantassa indaggino gatamaggo viya hoti, jhāmaṭṭhānamattameva aṅgāramasichārikāsamākulaṃ
analyzed: attano caritena iva pākaṭāḥ honti iti atthaḥ bālena hi gata maggaḥ rukkha gaccha gāma nigama ādīni  jhāpetvā gacchantassa indagginaḥ gata maggaḥ viya hoti jhāma ṭṭhāna mattam eva aṅgāram asi chārikā samākulam
translated: the meaning is that they become evident through their own conduct. For the path gone by a fool is like the path gone by a firebrand,🔽which burns up trees, creepers, villages, and towns, and when he has gone, only a place that is scorched is evident, as if strewn with embers.

original: paññāyati. Paṇḍitena gatamaggo kusobbhādayo pūretvā vividhasassasampadaṃ āvahamānena🔽catudīpikameghena gatamaggo viya hoti. Yathā tena gatamagge udakapūrāni ceva vividhasassaphalāphalāni
analyzed: paññāyati paṇḍitena gata maggo kusobbha ādayo pūretvā vividha sassa sampadam āvahamānena  catu dīpika meghena gata maggaḥ viya hoti yathā tena gata magge udaka pūrāni ca iva vividha sassa phala aphalāni
translated: The path gone by a wise man is like the path gone by a cloud that brings rain and causes the growth of various crops🔽with its fourfold radiance. Just as on the path gone by that cloud, the places are evident as being filled with water and as being endowed with various crops, fruits, and flowers,

original: ca tāni tāni ṭhānāni paññāyanti, evaṃ paṇḍitena gatamagge sampattiyova paññāyanti
analyzed: ca tāni tāni ṭhānāni paññāyanti evam paṇḍitena gata magge sampattiyaḥ uva paññāyanti
translated: so on the path gone by a wise man, only his prosperity is evident,

original: no vipattiyoti. Sesamettha uttānatthameva.
analyzed: no vipattiyaḥ ti sesam ettha uttānattham eva
translated: not his adversity. The rest here is self-evident.

original: 3. Cintīsuttavaṇṇanā
translated: . The exposition of the third verse.

original: 3. Tatiye bālalakkhaṇānīti “bālo aya”nti etehi lakkhīyati ñāyatīti bālalakkhaṇāni.
analyzed: tatiye bāla lakkhaṇāni iti bālaḥ ayanti etehi lakkhīyati ñāyati iti bāla lakkhaṇāni
translated: In the third , the characteristics of a fool : he is characterized, he is known, as “a fool” thus they are characteristics of a fool.

original: Tānevassa sañjānanakāraṇānīti bālanimittāni. Bālāpadānānīti bālassa apadānāni. Duccintitacintīti
analyzed: tāni eva assa sañjānana kāraṇāni iti bāla nimittāni bāla apadānāni iti bālassa apadānāni duccintita cintī iti
translated: They are the causes of his being recognized thus they are signs of a fool. The fool’s tracks : the tracks of a fool. He thinks evil thoughts :

original: cintayanto abhijjhābyāpādamicchādassanavasena duccintitameva cinteti. Dubbhāsitabhāsīti🔽bhāsamānopi musāvādādibhedaṃ dubbhāsitameva bhāsati. Dukkaṭakammakārīti karontopi
analyzed: cintayantaḥ abhijjhā byāpādam icchā dassana vasena duccintitam eva cintā iti dubbhāsita bhāsī iti  bhāsamānaḥ api musāvāda ādi bhedam dubbhāsitam eva bhāsati dukkaṭa kamma kārī iti karontaḥ api
translated: He thinks evil thoughts, thinking thoughts of sense-desire, ill-will, and cruelty. He speaks evil speech …🔽He does evil deeds …

original: pāṇātipātādivasena dukkaṭakammameva karoti. Paṇḍitalakkhaṇānītiādi vuttānusāreneva
analyzed: pāṇa atipāta ādi vasena dukkaṭa kammam eva karoti paṇḍita lakkhaṇāni itiādi vutta anusārena iva
translated: He has the characteristics of a fool.🔽He thinks good thoughts …🔽He speaks good speech …🔽He does good deeds …

original: veditabbaṃ. Sucintitacintītiādīni cettha manosucaritādīnaṃ vasena yojetabbāni.
analyzed: veditabbam su cintita cintī iti ādīni ca ittha manaḥ su carita ādīnam vasena yojetabbāni
translated: He has the characteristics of a wise man.

original: 4. Accayasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: accaya sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Recitation on Mistakes

original: 4. Catutthe accayaṃ accayato na passatīti attano aparādhaṃ aparādhato na passati.🔽Accayato disvā yathādhammaṃ nappaṭikarotīti “aparaddhaṃ mayā”ti ñatvāpi yo dhammo,🔽taṃ na karoti, daṇḍakammaṃ āharitvā accayaṃ na deseti nakkhamāpeti. Accayaṃ desentassa
analyzed: catutthe accayam accayataḥ na passati iti attanaḥ aparādham aparādhataḥ na passati  accayataḥ disvā yathādhammam na paṭikaroti iti aparaddham mayā ati ñatvā api yaḥ dhammo  tam na karoti daṇḍa kammam āharitvā accayam na deseti nakkhamāpeti accayam desentassa
translated: In the fourth, he does not see a mistake as a mistake: he does not see his own offense as an offense.🔽Having seen a mistake, he does not make amends for it in accordance with the rule: even though he knows, “I have offended,” he does not make amends in accordance with the rule, does not confess the offense.

original: yathādhammaṃ nappaṭiggaṇhātīti parassa “viraddhaṃ mayā”ti ñatvā daṇḍakammaṃ āharitvā
analyzed: yathādhammam na paṭiggaṇhāti iti parassa viraddham mayā ati ñatvā daṇḍa kammam āharitvā
translated: When someone confesses a mistake to him, he does not receive it in accordance with the rule: even though he knows, “I have offended,” he does not make amends in accordance with the rule, does not confess the offense.

original: khamāpentassa nakkhamati. Sukkapakkho vuttapaṭipakkhato veditabbo.
analyzed: khamāpentassa na khamati sukka pakkhaḥ vutta paṭipakkhataḥ veditabbaḥ
translated: He does not know how to forgive. The bright fortnight should be understood in the opposite sense to the dark fortnight.

original: 5. Ayonisosuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: ayoniso sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The exposition of the Sutta on Wrongness

original: 5. Pañcame ayoniso pañhaṃ kattā hotīti “kati nu kho, udāyi, anussatiṭṭhānānī”ti vutte
analyzed: pañcame ayonisaḥ pañham kattā hoti iti kati nu kho udāyi anussati ṭhānāni iti vutte
translated: In the fifth place, one who asks a question wrongly is one who asks a question without having first thought out a means of answering it. When the question “How many objects of recollection are there, Udayin? ” was asked,

original: “pubbenivāso anussatiṭṭhānaṃ bhavissatī”ti cintetvā lāḷudāyitthero viya anupāyacintāya
analyzed: pubbenivāsaḥ anussati ṭhānam bhavissati iti cintetvā lāḷudāyi ttheraḥ viya anupāya cintāya
translated: the Elder Laduda Udayin thought, “Recollection of past lives will be an object of recollection” , and he asked a question without having first thought out a means of answering it.

original: apañhameva pañhanti kattā hoti. Ayoniso pañhaṃ vissajjetā hotīti evaṃ cintitaṃ pana🔽pañhaṃ vissajjentopi “idha, bhante, bhikkhu anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati.
analyzed: apañham eva pañhanti kattā hoti ayonisaḥ pañham vissajjetā hoti iti evam cintitam pana  pañham vissajjentaḥ api idha bhante bhikkhu aneka vihitam pubbenivāsam anussarati
translated: One who answers a question wrongly is one who answers a question after thinking out an answer in this way.

original: Seyyathidaṃ, ekampi jāti”ntiādinā nayena soyeva thero viya ayoniso vissajjetā hoti,
analyzed: ekam pi jāti nti ādinā nayena saḥ yā iva theraḥ ayonisaḥ hoti
translated: When he answers the question thus, “Here, venerable sir, a bhikkhu recollects his manifold past lives … with their aspects and particulars” , he answers it wrongly, like the same elder.🔽One who asks a question wrongly is one who asks a question without having completed the words and the syllables.

original: apañhameva pañhanti katheti. Parimaṇḍalehi padabyañjanehīti ettha padameva atthassa
analyzed: apañham eva pañhanti kathā iti parimaṇḍalehi pada byañjanehi iti ettha padam eva atthassa
translated: Herein, the words are the meaning,

original: byañjanato padabyañjanaṃ. Taṃ akkharapāripūriṃ katvā dasavidhaṃ byañjanabuddhiṃ aparihāpetvā
analyzed: byañjanataḥ pada byañjanam tam akkhara pāripūrim katvā dasavidham byañjana buddhim a parihāpetvā
translated: and the syllables are the expression of the meaning. Having completed the syllables by filling out the letters, he asks a question without having failed in the ten kinds of skill in phrasing.

original: vuttaṃ parimaṇḍalaṃ nāma hoti, evarūpehi padabyañjanehīti attho. Siliṭṭhehīti padasiliṭṭhatāya🔽siliṭṭhehi. Upagatehīti atthañca kāraṇañca upagatehi. Nābbhanumoditāti evaṃ yoniso
analyzed: vuttam parimaṇḍalam nāma hoti evarūpehi pada byañjanehi iti attho siliṭṭhehi iti pada siliṭṭha tāya  siliṭṭhehi upagatehi iti attham ca kāraṇam ca upagatehi evam yoniso
translated: “The answer is given in a round about way” means: the answer is given by means of words and syllables that are round about. “By means of circumlocutions” means: by means of circumlocutions of words.

original: sabbaṃ kāraṇasampannaṃ katvāpi vissajjitaṃ parassa pañhaṃ nābhinumodati nābhinandati
analyzed: sabbam kāraṇa sampannam katvā api vissajjitam parassa pañham na abhinumodati na abhinandati
translated: “By means of approaches” means: by means of approaches to the meaning and to the reason. “He does not approve” means: he does not approve, he does not welcome, the answer given by another after having given all the reasons properly.

original: sāriputtattherassa pañhaṃ lāḷudāyitthero viya. Yathāha –
analyzed: sāriputta therassa pañham lāḷudāyi theraḥ viya yathā āha
translated: Like the Elder Ladudayi who did not approve the question of the Elder Sāriputta. As it is said:

original: “Aṭṭhānaṃ kho etaṃ, āvuso sāriputta, anavakāso, yaṃ so atikkammeva kabaḷīkārāhārabhakkhānaṃ🔽devānaṃ sahabyataṃ aññataraṃ manomayaṃ kāyaṃ upapanno saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ samāpajjeyyāpi
analyzed: aṭṭhānam kho etam āvuso sāriputta anavakāsaḥ yam saḥ atikkamma iva kabaḷīkāra āhāra bhakkhānam  devānam sahabyatam aññataram manaḥ mayam kāyam upapannaḥ saññā vedayita nirodham samāpajjeyya api
translated: “It is impossible, friend Sāriputta, it cannot happen that he, having transcended the plane of the Devas who feed on gross food,

original: vuṭṭhaheyyāpi, natthetaṃ ṭhāna”nti.
analyzed: vuṭṭhaheyya api nattha etam ṭhānanti
translated: would enter upon and abide in the cessation of perception and feeling, and that he would emerge from it. There is no such possibility.”

original: Yoniso pañhaṃ kattātiādīsu ānandatthero viya yonisova pañhaṃ cintetvā yoniso vissajjitā
analyzed: yoniso pañham kattā ati ādīsu ānanda theraḥ viya yoniso uva pañham cintetvā yoniso vissajjitā
translated: “He asks a question after proper reflection” and so forth: after having thought out a question properly, he answers it properly, like the Elder Ānanda.

original: hoti. Thero hi “kati nu kho, ānanda, anussatiṭṭhānānī”ti pucchito “ayaṃ pañho bhavissatī”ti
analyzed: hoti theraḥ hi kati nu kho ānanda anussati ṭṭhānāni iti pucchitaḥ ayam pañhaḥ bhavissati iti
translated: The elder replied, “This question will come up,”

original: yoniso cintetvā yoniso vissajjento āha – “idha, bhante, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi…pe…🔽catutthajjhānaṃ upasampajja viharati. Idaṃ, bhante, anussatiṭṭhānaṃ evaṃbhāvitaṃ
analyzed: yonisas cintetvā yonisas vissajjentaḥ āha idha bhante bhikkhu vivicca iva kāmehipe  catuttha jhānam upasampajja viharati idam bhante anussati ṭhānam evaṃbhāvitam
translated: and he thought it over carefully and gave the answer carefully: “Here, venerable sir, a bhikkhu, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unwholesome states,

original: evaṃbahulīkataṃ diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārāya saṃvattatī”ti. Abbhanumoditā hotīti tathāgato🔽viya yoniso abbhanumoditā hoti. Tathāgato hi ānandattherena pañhe vissajjite “sādhu
analyzed: evaṃbahulīkatam diṭṭhadhamma sukha vihārāya saṃvattati iti abbhanumoditā hoti iti tathāgataḥ  viya yonisaḥ abbhanumoditā hoti tathāgataḥ hi ānanda therena pañhe vissajjite sādhu
translated: enters and dwells in the first jhana, which is accompanied by thought and examination, with rapture and happiness born of seclusion. This, venerable sir, is a case of a meditation subject that, when developed and expanded, leads to a pleasant abiding in this very life. ”

original: sādhu, ānanda, tena hi tvaṃ, ānanda, imampi chaṭṭhaṃ anussatiṭṭhānaṃ dhārehi. Idhānanda,
analyzed: sādhu ānanda tena hi tvam ānanda imam pi chaṭṭham anussati ṭṭhānam dhārehi idha ānanda
translated: It is approved by the wise: it is approved by the wise as the elder’s answer. For the Exalted One said, “Good, good, Ananda! So you have learned this meditation subject well, Ananda. Therefore, Ananda, you should repeat this meditation subject to the bhikkhus, bhikkhunis, male lay followers, and female lay followers, and you should teach it, reveal it, explain it, and expound it.

original: bhikkhu satova abhikkamati satova paṭikkamatī”tiādimāha. Chaṭṭhādīni uttānatthāneva.
analyzed: bhikkhu sataḥ iva abhikkamati sataḥ iva paṭikkamati itiādim āha chaṭṭha ādīni uttāna tthāna eva
translated: When a bhikkhu develops and cultivates this meditation subject, he is capable of realizing and attaining the fruit of stream-entry. ”

original: 9. Khatasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: khata sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The sixth meditation subject and the rest are self-evident in meaning.

original: 9. Navame sukkapakkho pubbabhāge dasahipi kusalakammapathehi paricchinno, upari yāva arahattamaggā labbhati. Bahuñca puññaṃ pasavatīti ettha lokiyalokuttaramissakapuññaṃ kathitaṃ.
analyzed: navame sukka pakkho pubba bhāge dasahi api kusala kamma pathehi paricchinno upari yāva arahatta maggāḥ labbhati bahuñca puññam pasavati iti ettha lokiya lokuttara missaka puññam kathitam
translated: In the ninth, the bright fortnight, in the first part, it is delimited by the ten courses of kamma that are profitable, and in the second part it is delimited by the path of arahatship. And he generates much merit: here merit mixed with the mundane and supramundane is intended.

original: 10. Malasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: mala sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Explanation of the Ten Bad Ways

original: 10. Dasame dussīlabhāvo dussīlyaṃ, dussīlyameva malaṃ dussīlyamalaṃ. Kenaṭṭhena malanti?
analyzed: dasame dussīla bhāvaḥ dussīlyam dussīlyam eva malam dussīlya malam kenaṭṭhena malanti
translated: In the tenth, badness is corruption . Corruption is badness, thus it is corruption-badness . In what sense is it badness?

original: Anudahanaṭṭhena duggandhaṭṭhena kiliṭṭhakaraṇaṭṭhena ca. Tañhi nirayādīsu apāyesu
analyzed: anudahana ṭṭhena duggandha ṭṭhena kiliṭṭha karaṇa ṭṭhena ca tat hi niraya ādīsu apāyesu
translated: In the sense of smearing , in the sense of stinking , and in the sense of soiling . For it smears beings in the unhappy destinies beginning with hell,

original: anudahatīti anudahanaṭṭhenapi malaṃ. Tena samannāgato puggalo mātāpitūnampi santike
analyzed: anudahati iti anudahana ṭṭhena api malam tena samannāgataḥ puggalaḥ mātā pitūnam pi santike
translated: thus it is badness in the sense of smearing . One possessed of it is despised even by his parents

original: bhikkhusaṅghassāpi antare bodhicetiyaṭṭhānesupi jigucchanīyo hoti, sabbadisāsu cassa
analyzed: bhikkhu saṅghassa api antare bodhicetiya ṭṭhānesu pi jigucchanīyaḥ hoti sabba disāsu ca ssa
translated: and by the community of bhikkhus, and even in places where there are Enlightenment-tree shrines,

original: “evarūpaṃ kira tena pāpakammaṃ kata”nti avaṇṇagandho vāyatīti duggandhaṭṭhenapi malaṃ.
analyzed: evarūpam kira tena pāpa kammam katam ti avaṇṇa gandhaḥ vāyati iti malam
translated: and the smell of his infamy spreads in all directions, ‘Such and such a person has done this and that evil,’ thus it is badness in the sense of stinking .

original: Tena ca samannāgato puggalo gatagataṭṭhāne upatāpañceva labhati, kāyakammādīni cassa🔽asucīni honti apabhassarānīti kiliṭṭhakaraṇaṭṭhenapi malaṃ. Apica taṃ devamanussasampattiyo
analyzed: tena ca samannāgataḥ puggalaḥ gata gata ṭṭhāne upatāpam ca iva labhati kāya kamma ādīni ca ssa  asucīni honti apabhassarāni iti malam api ca tam deva manussa sampattiyaḥ
translated: And a person possessing it gets no help wherever he goes, and his bodily actions, etc.,

original: ceva nibbānasampattiñca milāpetīti milāpanaṭṭhenapi malanti veditabbaṃ. Issāmalamaccheramalesupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: ca iva nibbāna sampattiñca milāpeti iti milāpana ṭṭhena api malanti veditabbam issā mala macchera malesu pi esa eva nayaḥ
translated: are unclean and stinking. So it is defilement in the sense of soiling. Again, it withers the distinction of gods and men and the distinction of Nibbāna, so it is defilement in the sense of withering. The same method of explanation applies in the case of envy and avarice.

original: Bālavaggo paṭhamo.
analyzed: bāla vaggo paṭhamaḥ
translated: The first sub-chapter on the fool is finished

original: 2. Rathakāravaggo🔽1. Ñātasuttavaṇṇanā🔽11. Dutiyassa paṭhame ñātoti paññāto pākaṭo. Ananulomiketi sāsanassa na anulometīti
analyzed: rathakāra vaggo  ñāta sutta vaṇṇanā  dutiyassa paṭhame ñātoti paññātaḥ pākaṭaḥ ananulomikā iti sāsanassa na anulomā iti iti
translated: . The second sub-chapter on the chariot-maker🔽. The known

original: ananulomikaṃ, tasmiṃ ananulomike. Kāyakammeti pāṇātipātādimhi kāyaduccarite. Oḷārikaṃ
analyzed: ananulomikam tasmin ananulomike kāya kamme iti pāṇa atipāta ādimhi kāya duccarite oḷārikam
translated: In the first of the second sub-chapter: known: renowned, famous. Not in conformity: not in conformity with the Dispensation is not in conformity with the Dispensation. In that not in conformity with the Dispensation: in that which is not in conformity with the Dispensation. In bodily action: in bodily misconduct such as killing breathing things, etc. He encourages, he makes to take up, in that which is gross,

original: vā etaṃ, na evarūpe samādapetuṃ sakkoti. Disā namassituṃ vaṭṭati, bhūtabaliṃ kātuṃ
analyzed: vai etam naḥ evarūpe samādapetum sakkoti disā namassitum vaṭṭati bhūta balim kātum
translated: for he is not able to encourage in such as that. It is proper to pay homage to the directions, it is proper to make the oblation to the elements,

original: vaṭṭatīti evarūpe samādapeti gaṇhāpeti. Vacīkammepi musāvādādīni oḷārikāni, attano
analyzed: vaṭṭati iti evarūpe samādapeti gaṇhāpeti vacī kamme pi musāvāda ādīni oḷārikāni attano
translated: he encourages, he makes to take up, in such as that. In verbal action too, he encourages, he makes to take up, in such as gross lying, etc.,

original: santakaṃ parassa adātukāmena “natthī”ti ayaṃ vañcanamusāvādo nāma vattuṃ vaṭṭatīti
analyzed: santakam parassa a dātu kāmena natthi iti ayam vañcana musāvādaḥ nāma vattum vaṭṭati iti
translated: One who does not want to give another person’s property to him should tell a deliberate lie, saying, “There is none.”🔽This is called “cheating.”

original: evarūpe samādapeti. Manokammepi abhijjhādayo oḷārikā, kammaṭṭhānaṃ visaṃvādetvā kathento
analyzed: evarūpe samādapeti manaḥ kamme pi abhijjhā ādayaḥ oḷārikā kammaṭṭhānam visaṃvādetvā kathentaḥ
translated: In the case of mental action, covetousness, etc., are gross. But one who speaks after deceiving the meditation subject🔽is said to “advise” in things that are not conducive to the attainment of the goal.

original: pana ananulomikesu dhammesu samādapeti nāma dakkhiṇavihāravāsitthero viya. Taṃ kira🔽theraṃ eko upaṭṭhāko amaccaputto upasaṅkamitvā “mettāyantena paṭhamaṃ kīdise puggale
analyzed: pana ananulomikesu dhammesu samādapeti nāma dakkhiṇa vihāra vāsi ttheraḥ viya tam kira  theram ekaḥ upaṭṭhākaḥ amacca putto upasaṅkamitvā mettāyantena paṭhamam kīdise puggale
translated: This is like the Elder of Dakkhiṇagiri. It seems that a certain lay supporter, the son of a minister,🔽approached that elder and asked, “Venerable sir, to what kind of person should loving-kindness be practised first?”

original: mettāyitabba”nti pucchi. Thero sabhāgavisabhāgaṃ anācikkhitvā “piyapuggale”ti āha.
analyzed: pucchi theraḥ sabhāga visabhāgam an ācikkhitvā piya puggala iti āha
translated: The elder did not distinguish between a person of the same sex and one of a different sex. He said, “To a dear person.”

original: Tassa ca bhariyā piyā hoti manāpā, so taṃ ārabbha mettāyanto ummādaṃ pāpuṇi. Kathaṃ
analyzed: tassa ca bhariyā piyā hoti manāpā so tam ārabbha mettāyantaḥ ummādam pāpuṇi katham
translated: And that man’s wife was dear to him and pleasing to him. He practised loving-kindness towards her, and he went mad.🔽But how is he practising for the harm of many people? For his pupils, etc.,

original: panesa bahujanaahitāya paṭipanno hotīti? Evarūpassa hi saddhivihārikādayo ceva upaṭṭhākādayo
analyzed: pana esa bahu jana ahitāya paṭipanno hoti iti evarūpassa hi saddhivihārika ādayo ca iva upaṭṭhāka ādayo
translated: and his lay supporters,🔽and the deities who are their protectors, and so on, and the deities who are his friends,

original: ca tesaṃ ārakkhadevatā ādiṃ katvā tāsaṃ tāsaṃ mittabhūtā yāva brahmalokā sesadevatā
analyzed: ca tesam ārakkha devatā ādim katvā tāsam tāsam mitta bhūtā sesa devatā
translated: and the deities in the Brahma-world, and the rest, down to the earth gods,

original: ca “ayaṃ bhikkhu na ajānitvā karissatī”ti tena katameva karonti, evamesa bahujanaahitāya paṭipanno hoti.
analyzed: ca ayam bhikkhu na a jānitvā karissati iti tena katam eva karonti evam esa bahu jana ahitāya paṭipannaḥ hoti
translated: “This bhikkhu will not do it without knowing,” and they do it for him. Thus he is one who acts to the detriment of many people.

original: Sukkapakkhe pāṇātipātā veramaṇiādīnaṃyeva vasena kāyakammavacīkammāni veditabbāni.🔽Kammaṭṭhānaṃ pana avisaṃvādetvā kathento anulomikesu dhammesu samādapeti nāma koḷitavihāravāsī
analyzed: sukka pakkhe pāṇātipātāḥ veramaṇi ādīnam yeva vasena kāya kamma vacī kammāni veditabbāni  kammaṭṭhānam pana a visaṃvādetvā kathentaḥ anulomikesu dhammesu samādapeti nāma koḷita vihāra vāsī
translated: The bodily and verbal actions should be understood in the same way as the abstentions from killing living beings, etc., in the bright fortnight.🔽But one who teaches the meditation subject without deceiving is said to “advise” in the profitable things. The Elder Tissa of the Catunikāyika, resident at the Koḷivia Monastery,

original: catunikāyikatissatthero viya. Tassa kira jeṭṭhabhātā nandābhayatthero nāma potaliyavihāre
analyzed: catu nikāyika tissa theraḥ viya tassa kira jeṭṭha bhātā nandābhaya thero nāma potaliya vihāre
translated: was like this. His elder brother, the Elder Nandābhaya, resident at the Potaliya Monastery,

original: vasanto ekasmiṃ roge samuṭṭhite kaniṭṭhaṃ pakkosāpetvā āha – “āvuso, mayhaṃ sallahukaṃ🔽katvā ekaṃ kammaṭṭhānaṃ kathehī”ti. Kiṃ, bhante, aññena kammaṭṭhānena, kabaḷīkārāhāraṃ
analyzed: vasantaḥ ekasmin roge samuṭṭhite kaniṭṭham pakkosāpetvā āha āvuso mayham sat lahukam  katvā ekam kammaṭṭhānam kathehi iti kim bhante aññena kammaṭṭhānena kabaḷīkāra āhāram
translated: was afflicted with a certain disease. He sent for his younger brother and said, “Friend, teach me a meditation subject.”

original: pariggaṇhituṃ vaṭṭatīti? Kimatthiko esa, āvusoti? Bhante, kabaḷīkārāhāro upādārūpaṃ,
analyzed: pariggaṇhitum vaṭṭati iti kimatthikaḥ esaḥ āvuso ti bhante kabaḷīkāra āhāraḥ upādā rūpam
translated: “What, venerable sir, is the meditation subject for one who is to discern the material food?” “What is the purpose of that, friend?” “Venerable sir, the material food is a derived materiality,

original: ekasmiñca upādārūpe diṭṭhe tevīsati upādārūpāni pākaṭāni hontīti. So “vaṭṭissati,
analyzed: ekasmin ca upādārūpe diṭṭhe tevīsati upādārūpāni pākaṭāni honti iti so vaṭṭissati
translated: and when one derived materiality is seen, twenty-three kinds of derived materiality are evident.

original: āvuso, ettaka”nti taṃ uyyojetvā kabaḷīkārāhāraṃ pariggaṇhitvā upādārūpaṃ sallakkhetvā
analyzed: āvuso ettakan ti tam uyyojetvā kabaḷīkāra āhāram pariggaṇhitvā upādā rūpam sallakkhetvā
translated: So he sent him away, thinking, “That will do, friend,” and he himself took up the analysis of the physical body and the derived materiality,🔽and after reviewing and reversing the order he reached Arahantship.

original: vivaṭṭetvā arahattaṃ pāpuṇi. Atha naṃ theraṃ bahivihārā anikkhantameva pakkositvā,
analyzed: vivaṭṭetvā arahattam pāpuṇi atha nam theram bahi vihārā a nikkhantam eva pakkositvā
translated: Then they summoned the elder, who had not yet left the outer apartment,

original: “āvuso, mahāavassayosi mayhaṃ jāto”ti kaniṭṭhattherassa attanā paṭiladdhaguṇaṃ ārocesi.🔽Bahujanahitāyāti etassapi hi saddhivihārikādayo “ayaṃ na ajānitvā karissatī”ti tena
analyzed: āvuso mahā avassayaḥ asi mayham jātaḥ iti kaniṭṭha therassa attanā paṭiladdha guṇam ārocesi  bahu jana hitāya ati etassa api hi saddhivihārika ādayaḥ ayam na a jānitvā karissati iti tena
translated: and said, “Friend, you have been a great help to us.” And he told the junior elder of the special quality he had attained.🔽“For the benefit of many people”: for his pupils and so on do not do it because they know how to do it, but they do it because he does it.

original: katameva karontīti bahujanahitāya paṭipanno nāma hotīti.🔽2. Sāraṇīyasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: katame eva karonti iti bahu jana hitāya paṭipannaḥ nāma hoti iti
translated: So he is said to practice for the benefit of many people.🔽The explanation of the “helpful things”🔽In the second sutta, a “noble” is a noble by birth.

original: 12. Dutiye khattiyassāti jātiyā khattiyassa. Muddhāvasittassāti rājābhisekena muddhani
analyzed: dutiye khattiyassa ati jātiyā khattiyassa muddhāvasittassa ati rāja abhisekena muddhani
translated: “One anointed with royal consecration” is one anointed on the head with water in the royal consecration.🔽“They are helpful” : they are to be remembered, not to be forgotten.

original: abhisittassa. Sāraṇīyāni bhavantīti saritabbāni asammussanīyāni honti. Jātoti nibbatto.
analyzed: abhisittassa sāraṇīyāni bhavanti iti saritabbāni a sammussanīyāni honti jātaḥ iti nibbattaḥ
translated: “Born” : arisen.

original: Yāvajīvaṃ sāraṇīyanti daharakāle jānitumpi na sakkā, aparabhāge pana mātāpituādīhi🔽ñātakehi vā dāsādīhi vā “tvaṃ asukajanapade asukanagare asukadivase asukanakkhatte
analyzed: yāvajīvam dahara kāle jānitum pi na sakkāḥ aparabhāge pana mātā pitu ādīhi  ñātakehi vā dāsa ādīhi vā tvam asuka janapade asuka nagare asuka divase asuka nakkhatte
translated: “Be obliging as long as you live”: this cannot be known even in early life; but later on, by parents,🔽relatives, servants, etc., “You were born in such and such a country, in such and such a town, on such and such a day, under such and such a constellation,🔽

original: jāto”ti ācikkhite sutvā tato paṭṭhāya yāvajīvaṃ sarati na sammussati. Tena vuttaṃ
analyzed: jātaḥ ti ācikkhite sutvā tatas paṭṭhāya yāvajīvam sarati na sammussati tena vuttam
translated: As long as he lives he remembers the place of his birth: it is not possible to know this even in early life, but later on, when his parents or other relatives or his servants tell him, “You were born in such and such a country, in such and such a town, on such and such a day, under such and such a constellation,” then he remembers it and never forgets it. Hence it is said:

original: – “yāvajīvaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ hotī”ti.
analyzed: yāvajīvam sāraṇīyam hoti iti
translated: “As long as he lives he remembers the place of his birth.”

original: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, dutiyanti abhisekaṭṭhānaṃ nāma rañño balavatuṭṭhikaraṃ hoti, tenassa🔽taṃ yāvajīvaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ. Saṅgāmavijayaṭṭhānepi eseva nayo. Ettha pana saṅgāmanti🔽yuddhaṃ. Abhivijinitvāti jinitvā sattumaddanaṃ katvā. Tameva saṅgāmasīsanti tameva
analyzed: idam bhikkhave dutiyam ti abhiseka ṭṭhānam nāma raññaḥ balava tuṭṭhi karam hoti tena assa  tam yāvajīvam sāraṇīyam saṅgāma vijaya ṭṭhāne pi esā iva nayo ettha pana saṅgāmanti  yuddham abhivijinitvā ati jinitvā sattu maddanam katvā tam eva tam eva
translated: This is the second ground for the king’s joy, the place of his coronation.

original: saṅgāmaṭṭhānaṃ. Ajjhāvasatīti abhibhavitvā āvasati.
analyzed: saṅgāma ṭṭhānam ajjhāvasati iti abhibhavitvā āvasati
translated: The same method applies to the case of victory in battle. Here, however, “battle” means war. “Having conquered” means having won and having crushed the enemy. “The crest of that battle” means the place of that battle. “He dwells having overcome” means he dwells having conquered.

original: Idāni yasmā sammāsambuddhassa rañño jātiṭṭhānādīhi kattabbakiccaṃ natthi, imasmiṃ
analyzed: idāni yasmā sammāsambuddhassa raññaḥ jāti ṭṭhāna ādīhi kattabba kiccam na atthi imasmin
translated: Now, since the coronation of the king who is a Perfectly Enlightened One has nothing to do with the place of his birth, etc.,

original: pana sāsane tappaṭibhāge tayo puggale dassetuṃ idaṃ kāraṇaṃ ābhataṃ, tasmā te dassento
analyzed: pana sāsane tad paṭibhāge tayo puggale dassetum idam kāraṇam ābhatam tasmā te dassento
translated: But the reason for mentioning these three persons in the Dispensation in the place of the three kinds of persons mentioned in the world is this. The Blessed One has shown them in order to show that the three kinds of persons in the Dispensation are superior to the three kinds of persons in the world.🔽So too, bhikkhus, one gone forth …

analyzed: dukkha jīvike yattha vā āyāmena payogena jīvita vuttim sādhenti tathārūpā iti attho

original: ayañca na tādiso, tasmāssa sarīravipattimpi dassetuṃ so ca hoti dubbaṇṇotiādimāha.🔽Tattha dubbaṇṇoti paṃsupisācako viya jhāmakhāṇuvaṇṇo. Duddasikoti vijātamātuyāpi🔽amanāpadassano. translated: but this man is not like that. So the Exalted One says, “And he is ugly,” in order to show his bodily misfortune.

original: vā. Pakkhahatoti hatapakkho pīṭhasappī. Padīpeyyassāti vaṭṭitelakapallakādino padīpaupakaraṇassa.

translated: Herein, ugly means he is the colour of a soot-covered goblin. Unlovely to look at means he is unlovely to look at even to his mother at his birth. Hunchbacked means he is a hunchback. Lame means he is lame in one leg or lame in both legs. Paralysed means he is paralysed in one arm or paralysed in both arms. Blind in one eye means he is blind in one eye or blind in both eyes. Deformed means he is deformed in some such way as a hare-lip. He is not even considered for a lamp-attendant’s job, for a job as a sweeper or a wiper, or for any kind of work.

original: Tassa na evaṃ hotīti. Kasmā na hoti? Nīcakule jātattā.

translated: Why is it not so? Because he is born in a low family.

original: Jeṭṭhoti aññasmiṃ jeṭṭhe sati kaniṭṭho āsaṃ na karoti, tasmā jeṭṭhoti āha. Ābhisekoti

translated: The elder, too, who is worthy of consecration does not hope for it. Therefore he says, “not consecrated.” The one who is not consecrated is worthy of consecration.

original: mahantampi rajjaṃ vicāretuṃ samattho, tasmā “acalappatto”ti āha. Tassa evaṃ hotīti

original: Sadosāti sagaṇḍā uṇṇatoṇataṭṭhānayuttā. Sakasāvāti pūtisārena ceva pheggunā ca yuttā.

translated: are established, the bodily crookedness, etc., should be understood as abandoned in this way: killing living beings, taking what is not given,

original: micchācāro musāvādo pisuṇāvācā micchādiṭṭhīti ime tāva cha sotāpattimaggena pahīyanti,
analyzed: micchā ācāraḥ musāvādaḥ pisuṇa avācā micchā diṭṭhi iti ime tāva cha sa utāpatti maggena pahīyanti
translated: sexual misconduct, false speech, malicious speech, wrong view: these six are abandoned by the path of stream-entry.

original: pharusāvācā byāpādoti dve anāgāmimaggena, abhijjhā samphappalāpoti dve arahattamaggenāti.
analyzed: pharusa avācā byāpādo ti dve anāgāmi maggena abhijjhā samphappalāpo ti dve arahatta maggena ati
translated: Harsh speech and ill will are abandoned by the path of non-return, and covetousness and wrong and utter disregard are abandoned by the path of arahatship.

original: 6. Apaṇṇakasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: apaṇṇaka sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the sixth chapter is finished.

original: 16. Chaṭṭhe apaṇṇakapaṭipadanti aviraddhapaṭipadaṃ ekaṃsapaṭipadaṃ niyyānikapaṭipadaṃ
analyzed: chaṭṭhe apaṇṇaka paṭipadanti aviraddha paṭipadam ekaṃsa paṭipadam niyyānika paṭipadam
translated: In the sixth chapter, the “undistracted way” is the way that is not contradictory, the one-sided way, the way that leads out,

original: kāraṇapaṭipadaṃ sārapaṭipadaṃ maṇḍapaṭipadaṃ apaccanīkapaṭipadaṃ anulomapaṭipadaṃ
analyzed: kāraṇa paṭipadam sāra paṭipadam maṇḍa paṭipadam apaccanīka paṭipadam anuloma paṭipadam
translated: the way that is a reason, the way that is the heartwood, the way that is the crest, the way that is not adverse, the way that is in conformity,🔽the way that is in conformity with the Dhamma. He is one who has entered upon the way that is not by way of a reasoning faculty or a way of thinking.

original: dhammānudhammapaṭipadaṃ paṭipanno hoti, na takkaggāhena vā nayaggāhena vā. Evaṃ gahetvā
analyzed: dhamma anudhamma paṭipadam paṭipannaḥ hoti na takka ggāhena vā naya ggāhena vā evam gahetvā
translated: Having grasped it thus,

original: paṭipanno hi bhikkhu vā bhikkhunī vā upāsako vā upāsikā vā manussadevanibbānasampattīhi
analyzed: paṭipannaḥ hi bhikkhu vā bhikkhunī vā upāsakaḥ vā upāsikā vā manussa deva nibbāna sampattīhi
translated: For a bhikkhu or bhikkhunī or layman or laywoman who is practising the way is deprived of and falls away from the attainment of gods and men,

original: hāyati parihāyati, apaṇṇakapaṭipadaṃ paṭipanno pana tāhi sampattīhi na parihāyati.
analyzed: hāyati parihāyati apaṇṇaka paṭipadam paṭipannaḥ pana tāhi sampattīhi na parihāyati
translated: but one who is practising the way that is not subject to cankers does not fall away from that attainment.

original: Atīte kantāraddhānamaggaṃ paṭipannesu dvīsu satthavāhesu yakkhassa vacanaṃ gahetvā
analyzed: atīte kantāraddhāna maggam paṭipannesu dvīsu satthavāhesu yakkhassa vacanam gahetvā
translated: In the past, when two caravans were travelling along a desert path, the foolish caravan leader, after accepting the advice of a yakkha,

original: bālasatthavāho saddhiṃ satthena anayabyasanaṃ patto, yakkhassa vacanaṃ aggahetvā
analyzed: bāla sattha vāhaḥ saddhim satthena anaya byasanam pattaḥ yakkhassa vacanam aggahetvā
translated: came to destruction with his caravan. But the wise caravan leader, after rejecting the yakkha’s advice,

original: “udakadiṭṭhaṭṭhāne udakaṃ chaḍḍessāmā”ti satthake saññāpetvā maggaṃ paṭipanno paṇḍitasatthavāho
analyzed: udaka diṭṭha ṭṭhāne udakam chaḍḍessāma ati satthake saññāpetvā maggam paṭipannaḥ paṇḍita satthavāhaḥ
translated: and after instructing his caravan thus, “At the place where you see water, put down the drinking water and the water for washing” , went on his way.

original: viya. Yaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ –
analyzed: viya yam sandhāya vuttam
translated: And it was in reference to this that it was said:🔽“Some say the second is the sure way,

original: “Apaṇṇakaṃ ṭhānameke, dutiyaṃ āhu takkikā;
analyzed: apaṇṇakam ṭhānam eke dutiyam āhu takkikā
translated: The sophists say the second is the sure way;🔽The wise, perceiving this,

original: Etadaññāya medhāvī, taṃ gaṇhe yadapaṇṇaka”nti. ;
analyzed: etat aññāya medhāvī tam gaṇhe yat apaṇṇakam ti
translated: Should take the sure way, the second.”

original: Yoni cassa āraddhā hotīti ettha yonīti khandhakoṭṭhāsassapi kāraṇassapi passāvamaggassapi
analyzed: yoni ca ssa āraddhā hoti iti ettha yoni iti khandha koṭṭhāsassa api kāraṇassa api passa avamaggassa api
translated: As to the words “and his destination is reached” , here the word yoni is a collective term for the aggregates, a reason, and the urethra.

original: nāmaṃ. “Catasso kho imā, sāriputta, yoniyo”tiādīsu hi khandhakoṭṭhāso yoni nāma.🔽“Yoni hesā bhūmija phalassa adhigamāyā”tiādīsu kāraṇaṃ. “Na cāhaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ brūmi,🔽yonijaṃ mattisambhava”nti ca “tamenaṃ kammajavātā nivattitvā uddhaṃpādaṃ adhosiraṃ
analyzed: nāmam catasso kho imā sāriputta yoniyo ti ādīsu hi khandha koṭṭhāsaḥ yoni nāma  kāraṇam na ca aham brāhmaṇam brūmi  yoni jam matti sambhavanti ca tam enam kamma ja vātāḥ nivattitvā uddhaṃpādam
translated: In such passages as “There are these four kinds of generation” , the aggregate-base is called “generation” .🔽In such passages as “This is the source, the origin, the birth, the production, the arising, the production of the fruit” , it is a cause. In such passages as “I do not say, brahmin, that one is a brahmin by birth” ,

original: samparivattetvā mātu yonimukhe sampaṭipādentī”ti ca ādīsu passāvamaggo. Idha pana
analyzed: samparivattetvā mātu yoni mukhe sampaṭipādenti iti ca ādīsu passa avamaggaḥ idha pana
translated: and “By the winds generated by his kamma he is turned over and dropped out of the womb, head downward, feet up” , it is the birth passage. Here it is🔽a cause that is intended.

original: kāraṇaṃ adhippetaṃ. Āraddhāti paggahitā paripuṇṇā.🔽Āsavānaṃ khayāyāti ettha āsavantīti āsavā, cakkhutopi…pe… manatopi sandanti pavattantīti🔽vuttaṃ hoti. Dhammato yāva gotrabhu, okāsato yāva bhavaggā savantīti vā āsavā, ete
analyzed: kāraṇam adhippetam āraddhā ati paggahitā paripuṇṇā  āsavānam khayāya ati ettha āsavanti iti āsavā cakkhutaḥ pi pe manataḥ pi sandanti pavattanti iti  vuttam hoti dhammataḥ yāva gotrabhu okāsataḥ yāva bhavaggā savanti iti vai āsavāḥ ete
translated: “Set going” : undertaken, accomplished.🔽“For the destruction of cankers” : they flow , thus they are cankers . What is meant is that they flow from the eye, etc., and they flow in the eye, etc.🔽Or alternatively, they flow by way of the eye, etc., and they flow in the eye, etc., thus they are cankers. The meaning is that they flow having included both the states and the physical basis.

original: dhamme etañca okāsaṃ antokaritvā pavattantīti attho. Antokaraṇattho hi ayaṃ ākāro.
analyzed: dhamme etañca okāsam antokaritvā pavattanti iti atthaḥ antokaraṇa atthaḥ hi ayam ākāro
translated: For the prefix anu has the sense of inclusion.

original: Cirapārivāsiyaṭṭhena madirādayo āsavā, āsavā viyātipi āsavā. Lokasmimpi hi cirapārivāsikā
analyzed: cirapārivāsiya ṭṭhena madirā ādayaḥ āsavāḥ āsavāḥ āsavāḥ hi cirapārivāsikā
translated: And as for the words “they are called effluents because they flow out” , they flow out in the sense of flowing out for a long time, like the words “effluents” , “wines” , etc.,

original: madirādayo āsavāti vuccanti, yadi ca cirapārivāsiyaṭṭhena āsavā, eteyeva bhavitumarahanti.
analyzed: madirā ādayaḥ āsavā ti vuccanti yadi ca cira pārivāsiya ṭṭhena āsavāḥ bhavitum arahanti
translated: and they are called “effluents” in the world in the sense of flowing out for a long time, like wines, etc., and if they are effluents in the sense of flowing out for a long time, then only these can be so.

original: Vuttañhetaṃ – “purimā, bhikkhave, koṭi na paññāyati avijjāya, ito pubbe avijjā nāhosī”tiādi.
analyzed: vuttam ha etam purimā bhikkhave koṭi na paññāyati avijjāya itas pubbe avijjā na ahosi itiādi
translated: For this is said: “Bhikkhus, there is no describing in terms of a beginning for the round of rebirths. Before the eyes of you who are now seeing, bhikkhus, only this is the case, that beings, hindered by ignorance, bound by craving, run and wander on, going from this world to the other world, from the other world to this world, experiencing the manifoldness of suffering” .

original: Āyataṃ vā saṃsāradukkhaṃ savanti pasavantītipi āsavā. Purimāni cettha nibbacanāni
analyzed: āyatam vā saṃsāra dukkham savanti pasavanti itipi āsavā purimāni ca ittha nibbacanāni
translated: And they flow out and cause to flow out the suffering of the round of rebirths, which is long in the sense of being long to cross, thus they are effluents .🔽And the first two explanations here

original: yattha kilesā āsavāti āgacchanti, tattha yujjanti, pacchimaṃ kammepi. Na kevalañca
analyzed: yattha kilesāḥ āgacchanti tattha yujjanti pacchimam kamme pi na kevalam ca
translated: apply where defilements are called “effluents” , while the last applies to kamma also.🔽And not only defilements and kamma,

original: kammakilesāyeva āsavā, apica kho nānappakārā upaddavāpi. Suttesu hi “nāhaṃ, cunda,
analyzed: kamma kilesāya iva āsavāḥ apica kho nānappakārāḥ upaddavāḥ api suttesu hi na aham cunda
translated: but also various kinds of misfortune are called “effluents” . For in the texts, in the passage:

original: diṭṭhadhammikānaṃyeva āsavānaṃ saṃvarāya dhammaṃ desemī”ti ettha vivādamūlabhūtā
analyzed: diṭṭhadhammikānam yeva āsavānam saṃvarāya dhammam desemi iti ettha vivāda mūla bhūtā
translated: “Cunda, I do not teach the Dhamma only for the restraint of effluents visible here and now” ,

original: kilesā āsavāti āgatā.
analyzed: kilesā āsavāti āgatā
translated: the defilements that are the roots of disputes are called “effluents” .🔽“By which one is reborn as a god,

original: “Yena devūpapatyassa, gandhabbo vā vihaṅgamo;
analyzed: yena deva upapatyassa gandhabbaḥ vā vihaṅgamaḥ
translated: Or an gandhabb or a bird,

original: Yakkhattaṃ yena gaccheyyaṃ, manussattañca abbaje;
analyzed: yakkhattam yena gaccheyyam manussattam ca abbaje
translated: And I would fall to the state of a human.🔽But for me, those taints are destroyed,

original: Te mayhaṃ āsavā khīṇā, viddhastā vinaḷīkatā”ti. –
analyzed: te mayham āsavā khīṇāḥ vid hastāḥ vinaḷīka tā ati
translated: Crushed, and brought to an end.”

original: Ettha tebhūmakaṃ ca kammaṃ avasesā ca akusalā dhammā. “Diṭṭhadhammikānaṃ āsavānaṃ🔽saṃvarāya samparāyikānaṃ āsavānaṃ paṭighātāyā”ti ettha parūpavādavippaṭisāravadhabandhādayo
analyzed: ettha tebhūmakam ca kammam avasesā ca akusalāḥ dhammāḥ diṭṭhadhammikānam āsavānam  saṃvarāya samparāyikānam āsavānam paṭighātāya ati ettha parūpavāda vippaṭisāra vadha bandha ādayaḥ
translated: Herein, the kamma of the three planes and the remaining unprofitable dhammas are the taints of the here and now.

original: ceva apāyadukkhabhūtā ca nānappakārā upaddavā.
analyzed: ca iva apāya dukkha bhūtā ca nānappakārā upaddavā
translated: The various kinds of misfortune, such as slander by others, remorse, killing, binding, and so on, and the manifold kinds of suffering in the states of loss, are the taints of the life to come.

original: Te panete āsavā yattha yathā āgatā, tattha tathā veditabbā. Ete hi vinaye tāva “diṭṭhadhammikānaṃ
analyzed: te pana ete āsavāḥ yattha yathā āgatā tattha tathā veditabbāḥ ete hi vinaye tāva diṭṭhadhammikānam
translated: But these taints should be understood in each case according to the context in which they are found. For in the Vinaya they are found in two ways:

original: āsavānaṃ saṃvarāya, samparāyikānaṃ āsavānaṃ paṭighātāyā”ti dvedhā āgatā. Saḷāyatane
analyzed: āsavānam saṃvarāya āsavānam paṭighātāya ati dvedhā āgatā saṭāyatane
translated: “for the restraint of taints of the here and now and for the restraint of taints of the life to come” .🔽In the sixfold base they are found in three ways:

original: “tayo me, āvuso, āsavā kāmāsavo bhavāsavo avijjāsavo”ti tidhā āgatā. Aññesu ca suttantesu
analyzed: tayaḥ me āvuso āsavā kāma āsavaḥ bhava āsavaḥ avijja āsavaḥ ti tidhā āgatā aññesu ca suttantesu
translated: “Friends, there are these three taints: the taint of sensuality, the taint of becoming, and the taint of ignorance” .

original: abhidhamme ca teyeva diṭṭhāsavena saha catudhā āgatā. Nibbedhikapariyāyena “atthi,
analyzed: abhidhamme ca teyeva diṭṭhāsavena saha catudhā āgatā nibbedhika pariyāyena atthi
translated: And in other suttas and in the Abhidhamma they are found in four ways with the addition of the taint of views.🔽In the analysis of the penetration of the four noble truths they are found in five ways: “There is the case, friends, where a monk remains focused on arising & passing away with regard to the five aggregates: ‘Such is form, such its origination, such its disappearance. Such is feeling … Such is perception … Such are fabrications … Such is consciousness, such its origination, such its disappearance.’

original: bhikkhave, āsavā nirayagāminiyā, atthi āsavā tiracchānayonigāminiyā, atthi āsavā
analyzed: bhikkhave āsavā niraya gāminiyā atthi āsavā tiracchāna yoni gāminiyā atthi āsavā
translated: There are, monks, corruptions that lead to hell, there are corruptions that lead to the animal realm,

original: pettivisayagāminiyā, atthi āsavā manussalokagāminiyā, atthi āsavā devalokagāminiyā”ti🔽pañcadhā āgatā. Kammameva cettha āsavāti vuttaṃ. Chakkanipāte “atthi, bhikkhave,
analyzed: petti visaya gāminiyā atthi āsavā manussa loka gāminiyā atthi āsavā deva loka gāminiyā ti  pañcadhā āgatā kammam eva ca ittha āsavā ti vuttam chakkanipāte atthi bhikkhave
translated: There are effluents leading to hell, leading to the animal realm, leading to the realm of afflicted spirits, leading to the human world, leading to the heavenly worlds.”🔽They are called effluents because they flow out in the six directions.

original: āsavā saṃvarāpahātabbā”tiādinā nayena chadhā āgatā. Sabbāsavapariyāye teyeva dassanena
analyzed: āsavā saṃvara apahātabbā ati ādinā nayena chadhā āgatā sabba āsava pariyāye teyā iva dassanena
translated: In the Chakkanipata they are called effluents because they flow out in the six directions: “There are effluents, bhikkhus, that are to be abandoned by guarding, that are to be abandoned by using, that are to be abandoned by tolerating, that are to be abandoned by avoiding, that are to be abandoned by dispelling, and that are to be abandoned by developing.🔽In the Sabbāsava-sutta they are called effluents because they flow out in the seven directions: “There are effluents, bhikkhus, that are to be abandoned by seeing, that are to be abandoned by guarding, that are to be abandoned by using, that are to be abandoned by tolerating, that are to be abandoned by avoiding, that are to be abandoned by dispelling, and that are to be abandoned by developing.”

original: pahātabbehi saddhiṃ sattadhā āgatā. Idha pana abhidhammanayena cattāro āsavā adhippetāti veditabbā.
analyzed: pahātabbehi saddhim sattadhā āgatāḥ idha pana abhidhamma nayena cattāraḥ āsavāḥ adhippetā ati veditabbā
translated: Here, however, the four effluents should be understood as intended in the sense of the method of the Abhidhamma.

original: Khayāyāti ettha pana āsavānaṃ sarasabhedopi khīṇākāropi maggaphalanibbānānipi “āsavakkhayo”ti
analyzed: khayāya āti ettha pana āsavānam sa rasa bhedaḥ api khīṇa ākāraḥ api magga phala nibbānāni pi āsava kkhayaḥ ti
translated: As to “for their destruction”: the destruction of the effluents is said to be their complete dissolution, their vanishing without remainder. The path and fruition, and Nibbāna, are also called “the destruction of the effluents.”

original: vuccati. “Yo āsavānaṃ khayo vayo bhedo paribhedo aniccatā antaradhāna”nti ettha hi
analyzed: vuccati yaḥ āsavānam khayaḥ vayaḥ bhedo paribhedaḥ anicca tā ettha hi
translated: For in the passage, “The destruction of the effluents, their fading away, cessation, giving up, relinquishment, release, and letting go,”🔽the complete dissolution of the effluents is called “the destruction of the effluents.”

original: āsavānaṃ sarasabhedo “āsavakkhayo”ti vutto. “Jānato ahaṃ, bhikkhave, passato āsavānaṃ
analyzed: āsavānam sa rasa bhedaḥ āsava kkhayaḥ ti vuttaḥ jānataḥ aham bhikkhave passataḥ āsavānam
translated: In the passage, “When he knows and sees thus, bhikkhus, the effluents are abandoned in him” ,

original: khayaṃ vadāmī”ti ettha āsavappahānaṃ āsavānaṃ accantakkhayo asamuppādo khīṇākāro
analyzed: khayam vadāmi iti ettha āsava ppahānam āsavānam accanta khayaḥ asamuppādaḥ khīṇa ākāraḥ
translated: I declare the destruction of cankers. ” Herein, the abandoning of cankers is the utter destruction of cankers, their non-arising, their state of being abolished.

original: natthibhāvo “āsavakkhayo”ti vutto.
analyzed: natthi bhāvaḥ āsava kkhayaḥ ti vutto
translated: “I declare the destruction of lust, hatred, and delusion” , the abandoning of cankers is the utter destruction of cankers, their non-arising again, their state of having been destroyed, their state of non-existence, which is called “the destruction of cankers” .🔽“For one in training who is practicing,

original: “Sekhassa sikkhamānassa, ujumaggānusārino;
analyzed: sekhassa sikkhamānassa uju magga anusārino
translated: Who is following the straight path,🔽First knowledge is in regard to destruction,

original: Khayasmiṃ paṭhamaṃ ñāṇaṃ, tato aññā anantarā”ti. –
analyzed: khayasmim paṭhamam ñāṇam tatas aññā anantarā ti
translated: Then immediately after that, knowledge of the others” .

original: Ettha maggo “āsavakkhayo”ti vutto. “Āsavānaṃ khayā samaṇo hotī”ti ettha phalaṃ.
analyzed: ettha maggaḥ āsava khayo ti vuttaḥ āsavānam khayā samaṇaḥ hoti iti ettha phalam
translated: Herein, the path is called “the destruction of cankers” . “By the destruction of cankers one becomes an ascetic” , here the fruit is so called.🔽“For one who is always looking for faults in others,

original: “Paravajjānupassissa, niccaṃ ujjhānasaññino;
analyzed: paravajja anupassissa niccam ujjhāna saññinaḥ
translated: Who is always on the watch for others’ faults,

original: Āsavā tassa vaḍḍhanti, ārā so āsavakkhayā”ti. –
analyzed: āsavā tassa vaḍḍhanti ārā saḥ āsava kkhayāti
translated: His cankers increase; he is far from the destruction of cankers” .

original: Ettha nibbānaṃ. Imasmiṃ pana sutte phalaṃ sandhāya “āsavānaṃ khayāyā”ti āha, arahattaphalatthāyāti attho.
analyzed: ettha nibbānam imasmin pana sutte phalam sandhāya āsavānam khayāya iti āha arahatta phala atthāya ati atthaḥ
translated: Herein, Nibbāna is so called. But in this sutta the fruit is intended by the words “by the destruction of cankers” , the meaning being “for the purpose of the fruit of arahatship.”

original: Indriyesu guttadvāroti manacchaṭṭhesu indriyesu pihitadvāro. Bhojane mattaññūti bhojanasmiṃ
analyzed: indriyesu gutta dvāraḥ ti mana chaṭṭhesu indriyesu pihita dvāraḥ bhojane bhojanasmin
translated: “Guarded in the doors of the sense faculties”: closed in the six doors beginning with the eye. “Moderate in eating”:

original: pamāṇaññū, paṭiggahaṇaparibhogapaccavekkhaṇamattaṃ jānāti pajānātīti attho. Jāgariyaṃ
analyzed: pamāṇaññū paṭiggahaṇa paribhoga paccavekkhaṇa mattam jānāti pajānāti iti atthaḥ jāgariyam
translated: knowing the measure in eating. The meaning is that he knows, he understands, the measure in regard to receiving and consuming. “Devoted to wakefulness”:

original: anuyuttoti rattindivaṃ cha koṭṭhāse katvā pañcasu koṭṭhāsesu jāgaraṇabhāvaṃ anuyutto,
analyzed: anuyuttaḥ ti rattindivam cha koṭṭhāse katvā pañcasu koṭṭhāsesu jāgaraṇa bhāvam anuyuttaḥ
translated: He is devoted to wakefulness: he is devoted to wakefulness by making the six periods of the day and night his rule.

original: jāgaraṇeyeva yuttappayuttoti attho.🔽Evaṃ mātikaṃ ṭhapetvā idāni tameva ṭhapitapaṭipāṭiyā vibhajanto kathañca, bhikkhave,
analyzed: jāgaraṇeya iva yutta ppayuttaḥ ti attho  evam mātikam ṭhapetvā idāni tam eva ṭhapita paṭipāṭiyā vibhajanto katham ca bhikkhave
translated: The meaning is: he is devoted to wakefulness itself, he is intent on wakefulness itself.

original: bhikkhūtiādimāha. Tattha cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvātiādīnaṃ attho visuddhimagge vitthārito,
analyzed: bhikkhu iti ādim āha tattha cakkhunā rūpam disvā ati ādīnam atthaḥ visuddhi magge vitthāritaḥ
translated: Having thus defined the schedule, he now divides it up into the order in which it is given, beginning with “And how, bhikkhus, is a bhikkhu devoted to wakefulness?” Herein, on seeing a visible object with the eye, etc., is given in detail in the Path of Purification.

original: tathā paṭisaṅkhā yoniso āhāraṃ āhāreti neva davāyātiādīnaṃ. Āvaraṇīyehi dhammehīti

translated: So too with “After reviewing the danger in sensual pleasures he is one who avoids a settled view of sensual pleasures” , etc.🔽With the states that are impediments: with the states that are hindrances.

original: pañcahi nīvaraṇehi dhammehi. Nīvaraṇāni hi cittaṃ āvaritvā tiṭṭhanti, tasmā āvaraṇīyā🔽dhammāti vuccanti. Sīhaseyyaṃ kappetīti sīho viya seyyaṃ kappeti. Pāde pādaṃ accādhāyāti
analyzed: pañcahi nīvaraṇehi dhammehi nīvaraṇāni hi cittam āvaritvā tiṭṭhanti tasmai āvaraṇīyā  dhammā ti vuccanti sīha seyyam kappeti iti sīhaḥ viya seyyam kappeti pāde pādam accādhāya ati
translated: For the hindrances stand in the way of the mind, thus they are called impediments .🔽He lies down in the lion’s posture: he lies down in the posture of the lion.🔽Having placed one foot on the other: having placed the left foot on the right one.

original: vāmapādaṃ dakkhiṇapāde atiādhāya. Samaṃ ṭhapite hi pāde jāṇukena jāṇukaṃ gopphakena
analyzed: vāma pādam dakkhiṇa pāde atiādhāya samam ṭhapite hi pāde jāṇukena jāṇukam gopphakena
translated: For when the feet are placed evenly, the knees touch.

original: ca gopphakaṃ ghaṭīyati, tato vedanā uṭṭhahanti. Tasmā tassa dosassa parivajjanatthaṃ
analyzed: ca gopphakam ghaṭīyati tatas vedanāḥ uṭṭhahanti tasmā tassa dosassa parivajjana ttham

original: thokaṃ atikkamitvā esa pādaṃ ṭhapeti. Tena vuttaṃ – “pāde pādaṃ accādhāyā”ti.
analyzed: thokam atikkamitvā esa pādam ṭhapeti tena vuttam pāde pādam accādhāya ati

analyzed: sataḥ sampajānaḥ nāma hoti iti purima ppavatti vasena ayam hi caṅkame caṅkamantaḥ niddāya  okkamana bhāvam ñatvā pavattamānam kammaṭṭhānam ṭhapetvā mañce vā phalake vā nipannaḥ
translated: By virtue of his previous practice. For this meditator, while walking up and down,🔽knows that sleepiness is coming upon him, and he sets aside his meditation subject and lies down on his right side on a bed or a bench,

original: niddaṃ upagantvā puna pabujjhamāno kammaṭṭhānaṃ ṭhitaṭṭhāne gaṇhantoyeva pabujjhati.🔽Tasmā niddāyantopi sato sampajāno nāma hoti. Ayaṃ tāva mūlakammaṭṭhāne nayova. Pariggahakammaṭṭhānavasenāpi
analyzed: niddam upagantvā puna pabujjhamāno kammaṭṭhānam ṭhita ṭhāne gaṇhantaḥ yeva pabujjhati  tasmā niddāyantaḥ api sataḥ sampajānaḥ nāma hoti ayam tāva mūla kammaṭṭhāne pariggaha kammaṭṭhāna vasena api
translated: thinking, “I will lie down for a little while.” He goes to sleep and wakes up. When he wakes up, he takes up the meditation subject where he left it.🔽Therefore he is called “mindful and fully aware” even when he is falling asleep. This is according to the basic meditation subject.

original: panesa sato sampajāno nāma hoti. Kathaṃ? Ayaṃ hi caṅkamanto niddāya okkamanabhāvaṃ

translated: he is said to be “mindful and fully aware.”🔽Having given attention to the perception of light: having given attention to the perception that defines the time for rising, thinking, “I shall rise when the moon or the stars are at such and such a point in the heavens,”
