translated: In the first of the fourth chapter, he entered his own house: he entered his own home. They are worshipped: they are looked after with whatever is in the house.

original: paṭijaggitā gopitā honti. Iti mātāpitupūjakāni kulāni mātāpitūhi sabrahmakānīti pakāsetvā
analyzed: paṭijaggitāḥ gopitāḥ honti iti mātā pitu pūjakāni kulāni sabrahmakāni iti pakāsetvā
translated: Thus, after showing that families who worship their mother and father are families with Brahmā,

original: idāni nesaṃ sapubbācariyakādibhāvaṃ pakāsento sapubbācariyakānītiādimāha. Tattha
analyzed: idāni na isam sa pubba ācariyaka ādi bhāvam pakāsentaḥ sa pubba ācariyakāni iti ādim āha tattha
translated: he now said “with the previous teachers” in order to show their state of having previous teachers, etc. Herein,

original: brahmātiādīni tesaṃ brahmādibhāvasādhanatthaṃ vuttāni. Bahukārāti puttānaṃ bahūpakārā.🔽Āpādakāti jīvitassa āpādakā. Puttakānaṃ hi mātāpitūhi jīvitaṃ āpāditaṃ pālitaṃ ghaṭitaṃ
analyzed: brahma ati ādīni tesam brahma ādi bhāva sādhana ttham vuttāni bahu kārā ati puttānam bahu upakārā  āpādakā ati jīvitassa āpādakā puttakānam hi mātā pitūhi jīvitam āpāditam pālitam ghaṭitam
translated: Brahmā, etc., are said in order to prove their state of being Brahmā, etc. They are benefactors: they are a great help to their children.🔽They are nurturers: they are the nurturers of life. For the life of children is nurtured, protected, and sustained

original: anuppabandhena pavattitaṃ. Posakāti hatthapāde vaḍḍhetvā hadayalohitaṃ pāyetvā posetāro.
analyzed: an uppabandhena pavattitam posakā ti hattha pāde vaḍḍhetvā hadaya lohitam pāyetvā posetāro
translated: by their mother and father, who keep it going without interruption. They are nourishers: they are the ones who nourish by making their hands and feet grow and by giving them the blood of their hearts.

original: Imassa lokassa dassetāroti puttānaṃ hi imasmiṃ loke iṭṭhāniṭṭhārammaṇassa dassanaṃ
analyzed: imassa lokassa dassetāraḥ ti puttānam hi imasmin loke iṭṭha aniṭṭha ārammaṇassa dassanam
translated: ‘Showers the world with gifts’: parents are ‘showers of gifts’ in the world to their children, since they show them what is desirable and undesirable.

original: nāma mātāpitaro nissāya jātanti imassa lokassa dassetāro nāma.🔽Brahmāti mātāpitaroti seṭṭhādhivacanaṃ. Yathā brahmuno catasso bhāvanā avijahitā
analyzed: nāma mātā pitaraḥ nissāya jātanti imassa lokassa dassetāraḥ nāma  brahmā ati mātā pitaro ti seṭṭha adhivacanam yathā catassaḥ bhāvanāḥ a vijahitā
translated: ‘Showers the world with gifts’: parents are ‘showers of gifts’ in the world to their children, since they show them what is desirable and undesirable.🔽‘Brahma’: this is a term for the most excellent. Just as the four divine abodes of Brahma are never abandoned by Brahma, namely, loving-kindness, compassion, gladness, and equanimity,

original: honti mettā karuṇā muditā upekkhāti, evameva mātāpitūnaṃ puttakesu catasso bhāvanā🔽avijahitā honti. Tā tasmiṃ tasmiṃ kāle veditabbā – kucchigatasmiṃ hi dārake “kadā
analyzed: honti mettā karuṇā muditā upekkhāti evam eva mātā pitūnam puttakesu catasso bhāvanā  a vijahitāḥ honti tā tasmin tasmin kāle veditabbā kucchi gatasmin hi dārake kadā
translated: so too the four divine abodes of parents are never abandoned by them with regard to their children.

original: nu kho puttakaṃ arogaṃ paripuṇṇaṅgapaccaṅgaṃ passissāmā”ti mātāpitūnaṃ mettacittaṃ
analyzed: nu kho puttakam arogam paripuṇṇaṅga paccaṅgam passissāma ati mātā pitūnam metta cittam
translated: These should be understood in each case: When the child is in the womb, the parents have loving-kindness for it, thinking, ‘When shall we see our child, healthy and sound, after it is born?’

original: uppajjati. Yadā panesa mando uttānaseyyako ūkāhi vā maṅkulādīhi pāṇakehi daṭṭho dukkhaseyyāya
analyzed: uppajjati yadā pana esa mandaḥ uttānaseyyakaḥ ūkāhi vā maṅkula ādīhi pāṇakehi daṭṭho dukkha seyyāya
translated: When the child is lying prone, unable to crawl or walk, and is bitten by flies or hurt by worms, or when it is suffering from the discomfort of its own excrement, and it cries and wails,

original: vā pana pīḷito parodati viravati, tadāssa saddaṃ sutvā mātāpitūnaṃ kāruññaṃ uppajjati,
analyzed: vā pana pīḍitaḥ parodati viravati tadā assa saddam sutvā mātā pitūnam kāruññam uppajjati
translated: then the parents have compassion for it, thinking, ‘Poor child!’

original: ādhāvitvā vidhāvitvā kīḷanakāle pana lobhanīyavayasmiṃ vā ṭhitakāle dārakaṃ oloketvā
analyzed: ādhāvitvā vidhāvitvā kīḷana kāle pana lobhanīya vayasmin vā ṭhita kāle dārakam oloketvā
translated: But when he is running about and playing or standing in a lovely youth’s prime of life,

original: mātāpitūnaṃ cittaṃ sappimaṇḍe pakkhittasatavihatakappāsapicupaṭalaṃ viya mudukaṃ
analyzed: mātā pitūnam cittam sappi maṇḍe pakkhitta sata vihata kappāsa picu paṭalam viya mudukam
translated: then his parents’ minds become soft and tender like cotton-wool soaked in oil,

original: hoti āmoditaṃ pamoditaṃ, tadā tesaṃ muditā labbhati. Yadā panesa putto dārābharaṇaṃ
analyzed: hoti āmoditam pamoditam tadā tesam muditā labbhati yadā pana isa putto dāra ābharaṇam
translated: and they are gladdened and thrilled. Then they get loving-kindness.

original: paccupaṭṭhāpetvā pāṭiyekkaṃ agāraṃ ajjhāvasati, tadā mātāpitūnaṃ “sakkoti dāni no
analyzed: paccupaṭṭhāpetvā pāṭiyekkam agāram ajjhāvasati tadā mātā pitūnam sakkoti dāni no
translated: But when he has taken a wife and set up a separate household,

original: puttako attano dhammatāya yāpetu”nti majjhattabhāvo uppajjati, tasmiṃ kāle upekkhā
analyzed: puttakaḥ attanaḥ dhamma tāya yāpetunti majjhatta bhāvaḥ uppajjati tasmin kāle upekkhā
translated: then his parents’ minds become indifferent to him, thinking “Now our son can manage by himself.” Then they get equanimity.

original: labbhatīti iminā kāraṇena “brahmāti mātāpitaro”ti vuttaṃ.🔽Pubbācariyāti vuccareti mātāpitaro hi jātakālato paṭṭhāya “evaṃ nisīda, evaṃ tiṭṭha,
analyzed: labbhati iti iminā kāraṇena brahmā ati mātā pitaraḥ iti vuttam  pubba ācariyā ti vuccara iti mātā pitaro hi jāta kālataḥ paṭṭhāya evam nisīda evam tiṭṭha
translated: That is why it is said that parents are a “divine state” .

original: evaṃ gaccha, evaṃ saya, evaṃ khāda, evaṃ bhuñja, ayaṃ te, tātāti vattabbo, ayaṃ bhātikāti,
analyzed: evam gaccha evam sayaḥ evam khāda evam bhuñja ayam te tāta ati vattabbaḥ ayam bhātikā ati
translated: “They are called ‘former teachers’ ”: parents are called “former teachers” because from the time of a child’s birth they teach it, saying “Sit like this, stand like this, walk like this, lie down like this, speak like this, this is your father, this your mother, this your brother, this your sister, this your wife, this your child, this your friend, this your kinsman, this your companion, this your master, this your servant, this is gain, this is loss, this is blame, this is praise, this is happiness, this is suffering, this is the desirable, this the undesirable, this is the beautiful, this the ugly, this is the agreeable, this the disagreeable, this is the pleasant, this the unpleasant, this is the profitable, this the unprofitable, this is the blameless, this the blameable, this is the dark, this the bright, this is the gross, this the subtle, this is the far, this the near, this is the past, this the future, this the present, this is the internal, this the external, this is the conditioned, this the unconditioned, this is the conditioned and the unconditioned, this is the conditioned and the unconditioned together, this is the conditioned and the unconditioned together” .

original: ayaṃ bhaginīti, idaṃ nāma kātuṃ vaṭṭati, idaṃ na vaṭṭati, asukaṃ nāma upasaṅkamituṃ
analyzed: ayam bhagini iti idam nāma kātum vaṭṭati idam na vaṭṭati asukam nāma upasaṅkamitum
translated: “This is your sister. This is proper for you to do, this is not proper. It is proper for you to visit such and such a place,

original: vaṭṭati, asukaṃ na vaṭṭatī”ti gāhāpenti sikkhāpenti. Athāparabhāge aññe ācariyā hatthisippaassasipparathasippadhanusippatharusippamuddāgaṇanādīni
analyzed: vaṭṭati asukam na vaṭṭati iti gāhāpenti sikkhāpenti atha apara bhāge aññe ācariyāḥ hatthi sippa assa sippa ratha sippa dhanu sippa tharu sippa muddā gaṇanā ādīni
translated: it is not proper to visit such and such a place.” They taught them and trained them. Later other teachers taught elephant craft, horse craft, chariot craft, archery, mathematics,

original: sikkhāpenti. Añño saraṇāni deti, añño sīlesu patiṭṭhāpeti, añño pabbājeti, añño buddhavacanaṃ
analyzed: sikkhāpenti aññaḥ saraṇāni deti aññaḥ sīlesu patiṭṭhāpeti aññaḥ pabbājeti aññaḥ buddha vacanam
translated: etc. Another gave them the Refuges, another established them in the moral precepts, another gave them the going forth, another taught them the Buddha’s word,

original: uggaṇhāpeti, añño upasampādeti, añño sotāpattimaggādīni pāpeti. Iti sabbepi te pacchācariyā
analyzed: uggaṇhāpeti aññaḥ upasampādeti aññaḥ sotāpatti magga ādīni pāpeti iti sabbe pi te pacchā cariyāḥ
translated: another gave them the full admission, another led them to the fruit of stream-entry, etc. Thus all these were later teachers,

original: nāma honti, mātāpitaro pana sabbapaṭhamā, tenāha – “pubbācariyāti vuccare”ti. Tattha
analyzed: nāma honti mātā pitaraḥ pana sabba paṭhamā tena āha pubba ācariyā ati tattha
translated: but the parents were the first, hence it is said: “They are called the first teachers.” Herein

original: vuccareti vuccanti kathiyanti. Āhuneyyā ca puttānanti puttānaṃ āhutaṃ pāhutaṃ abhisaṅkhataṃ
analyzed: vuccarā iti vuccanti kathiyanti āhuneyyā ca puttānam ti puttānam āhutam pāhutam abhisaṅkhatam
translated: “They are called” : they are said, they are spoken of. And worthy of offerings from their children: they are worthy of the offerings, the invitations, the preparations made by their children,

original: annapānādiṃ arahanti, anucchavikā taṃ paṭiggahetuṃ. Tasmā “āhuneyyā ca puttāna”nti
analyzed: anna pāna ādim arahanti anucchavikā tam paṭiggahetum tasmai āhuneyyā ca puttānam ti
translated: of food, drink, etc. They are fit to receive them. Therefore it is said: “And worthy of offerings from their children.”

original: vuttaṃ. Pajāya anukampakāti paresaṃ pāṇe acchinditvāpi attano pajaṃ paṭijagganti
analyzed: vuttam pajāya anukampakāḥ ati paresam pāṇe a chinditvā api attanaḥ pajam paṭijagganti
translated: He has compassion on his people. He does not take life, and he looks after his people,

original: gopāyanti. Tasmā “pajāya anukampakā”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: gopāyanti tasmā pajāya anukampakā iti vuttam
translated: he protects them. Therefore it is said, “He has compassion on his people.”

original: Namasseyyāti namo kareyya. Sakkareyyāti sakkārena paṭimāneyya. Idāni taṃ sakkāraṃ🔽dassento “annenā”tiādimāha. Tattha annenāti yāgubhattakhādanīyena. Pānenāti aṭṭhavidhapānena.
analyzed: namasseyya iti namaḥ kareyya sakkareyya ati sakkārena paṭimāneyya idāni tam sakkāram  dassentaḥ annena atiādim āha tattha annena āti yāgu bhatta khādanīyena pānena ati aṭṭhavidha pānena
translated: He should honour: he should pay homage. He should respect: he should respect him with respect. Now, showing that respect,🔽he says “with food,” etc. Herein, with food: with rice gruel, meals, and fresh food. With drink: with the eight kinds of drink.

original: Vatthenāti nivāsanapārupanakena vatthena. Sayanenāti mañcapīṭhānuppadānena. Ucchādanenāti🔽duggandhaṃ paṭivinodetvā sugandhakaraṇucchādanena. Nhāpanenāti sīte uṇhodakena, uṇhe🔽sītodakena gattāni parisiñcitvā nhāpanena. Pādānaṃ dhovanenāti uṇhodakasītodakehi
analyzed: vatthena ati nivāsana pārupanakena vatthena sayanena ati mañca pīṭha an uppadānena ucchādanena ati  duggandham paṭivinodetvā sugandha karaṇa ucchādanena nhāpanena ati sīte uṇha udakena uṇhe  sīta udakena gattāni parisiñcitvā nhāpanena pādānam dhovanena ati uṇha udaka sīta udakehi
translated: With clothes: with lower and upper robes. With a bed: with a bedstead and a mattress. With a chair:🔽with a chair and a mattress. With bathing: with hot water for bathing when it is cold and with cold water for bathing when it is hot.

original: pādadhovanena ceva telamakkhanena ca. Peccāti paralokaṃ gantvā. Sagge pamodatīti
analyzed: pāda dhovanena ca iva tela makkhanena ca pecca ati para lokam gantvā sagge pamodati iti
translated: With washing the feet: with hot water and cold water for washing the feet and with oil for massaging the feet. He rejoices in heaven:

original: idha tāva mātāpitūsu pāricariyaṃ disvā pāricariyakāraṇā taṃ paṇḍitamanussā idheva
analyzed: idha tāva mātā pitūsu pāricariyam disvā pāricariya kāraṇā tam paṇḍita manussāḥ idha iva
translated: Here, first, having seen the service to mother and father, the wise people, because of the service, here and now🔽

original: pasaṃsanti, paralokaṃ pana gantvā sagge ṭhito so mātāpituupaṭṭhāko dibbasampattīhi āmodati pamodatīti.
analyzed: pasaṃsanti para lokam pana gantvā sagge ṭhitaḥ saḥ mātā pitu upaṭṭhākaḥ dibba sampattīhi āmodati pamodati iti
translated: Here, first, having seen the service rendered to mother and father, the wise praise the one who renders service for that reason right here in this very world. But having gone to the other world, the one who attends on mother and father, standing in heaven, delights and rejoices in the divine attainments.

original: 2. Ānandasuttavaṇṇanā🔽32. Dutiye tathārūpoti tathājātiko. Samādhipaṭilābhoti cittekaggatālābho. Imasmiṃ
analyzed: ānanda sutta vaṇṇanā  dutiye tathārūpaḥ iti tathājātiko samādhi paṭilābho ti citta ekagga tā lābho imasmin
translated: . Commentary to the Ānandasutta

original: ca saviññāṇaketi ettha attano ca parassa cāti ubhayesampi kāyo saviññāṇakaṭṭhena🔽ekato katvā imasminti vutto. Ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānānusayāti ahaṅkāradiṭṭhi ca mamaṅkārataṇhā🔽ca mānānusayo cāti attano ca parassa ca kilesā. Nāssūti na bhaveyyuṃ. Bahiddhā ca
analyzed: ca sa viññāṇaka iti ettha attanaḥ ca parassa ca ati ubhayesam pi kāyo sa viññāṇaka ṭṭhena  ekatas katvā imasmin ti vuttaḥ ahaṅkāra mamaṅkāra māna anusayā ati ahaṅkāra diṭṭhi ca mamaṅkāra taṇhā  ca māna anusayo ca ati attano ca parassa ca kilesā na assu iti na bhaveyyum bahiddhā ca
translated: . In the second sutta, “of such a kind” means of such a birth. “Attainment of concentration” means the attainment of one-pointedness of mind. And here in this “percipient” body, in this place, both one’s own and another’s body are made one by the state of being percipient.

original: sabbanimittesūti rūpanimittaṃ, saddanimittaṃ, gandhanimittaṃ, rasanimittaṃ, phoṭṭhabbanimittaṃ,
analyzed: sabba nimittesu iti rūpa nimittam sadda nimittam gandha nimittam rasa nimittam phoṭṭhabba nimittam
translated: “I-making, mine-making, and the underlying tendency to conceit” means the view of self, the craving for “mine,” and the underlying tendency to conceit. Thus the defilements of oneself and others. “Would not be” means would not exist. And “in regard to all external signs” means the sign of visible form, the sign of sound, the sign of odour, the sign of flavour, the sign of tangible data,

original: sassatādinimittaṃ, puggalanimittaṃ dhammanimittanti evarūpesu ca bahiddhā sabbanimittesu.
analyzed: sassata ādi nimittam puggala nimittam dhamma nimittam ti evarūpesu ca bahiddhā sabba nimittesu
translated: and the sign of the self-theory, and the sign of the person-theory, and the sign of the soul-theory, and so on.

original: Cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttinti phalasamādhiñceva phalañāṇañca. Siyāti bhaveyya.
analyzed: cetaḥ vimuttim paññā vimuttim ti phala samādhim ca iva phala ñāṇam ca siyā ati bhaveyya
translated: Liberation of mind and liberation by wisdom: the concentration and the knowledge that are the fruit of those paths.

original: Idhānanda, bhikkhunoti, ānanda, imasmiṃ sāsane bhikkhuno. Etaṃ santaṃ etaṃ paṇītanti
analyzed: idha ānanda bhikkhuno ti ānanda imasmim sāsane bhikkhuno etam santam etam paṇītam ti
translated: Here, Ananda, a bhikkhu: in this Dispensation, Ananda, a bhikkhu. This is peace, this is exquisite:

original: nibbānaṃ dassento āha. Nibbānaṃ hi kilesānaṃ santatāya santaṃ nāma, nibbānaṃ santanti
analyzed: nibbānam dassentaḥ āha nibbānam hi kilesānam santatāya santam nāma nibbānam santanti
translated: he said this showing Nibbana. For Nibbana is called peace because of the stilling of defilements. Nibbana is peace

original: samāpattiṃ appetvāva divasampi nisinnassa cittuppādo santanteva pavattatītipi santaṃ.🔽Paṇītanti samāpattiṃ appetvā nisinnassāpi cittuppādo paṇītanteva pavattatīti nibbānaṃ
analyzed: samāpattim appetvā ava divasam pi nisinnassa cittuppādo santantā iva pavattati iti pi santam  paṇītanti samāpattim appetvā nisinnassa api cittuppādaḥ paṇītantā iva pavattati iti nibbānam
translated: because the arising of cognizance in one who has entered into it continues in a state of peace even for a whole day without his emerging from it.🔽It is called exquisite because the arising of cognizance in one who has entered into it continues in a state of exquisiteness even for a whole day without his emerging from it.🔽Nibbana is called exquisite. The synonyms for it beginning with “the stilling of all formations” are given in the passage:

original: paṇītaṃ nāma. Sabbasaṅkhārasamathotiādīnipi tasseva vevacanāni. “Sabbasaṅkhārasamatho”ti
analyzed: paṇītam nāma tassa iva vevacanāni sabba saṅkhāra samatha uti
translated: “‘The stilling of all formations’: this is a designation for Nibbana” .

original: samāpattiṃ appetvā nisinnassa hi divasabhāgampi cittuppādo sabbasaṅkhārasamathoteva
analyzed: samāpattim appetvā nisinnassa hi divasa bhāgam pi cittuppādaḥ
translated: For the arising of cognizance in one who has entered into it continues in a state of the stilling of all formations even for a whole day without his emerging from it.

original: pavattati…pe… tathā tīsu bhavesu vānasaṅkhātāya taṇhāya abhāvena nibbānanti laddhanāme🔽tasmiṃ samāpattiṃ appetvā nisinnassa cittuppādo nibbānaṃ nibbānanteva pavattatīti
analyzed: tathā tīsu bhavesu vāna saṅkhātāya taṇhāya abhāvena laddha nāme  tasmin samāpattim appetvā nisinnassa cittuppādaḥ nibbānam nibbānantā iva pavattati iti

analyzed: dosa moha māna diṭṭhi kilesa duccarita iñjitanti imāni satta iñjitāni calitāni phanditāni
translated: and so on as in § 10 up to …🔽and so on as in § 10 up to …🔽and so on as in § 10 up to …🔽and so on as in § 10 up to …🔽and so on as in § 10 up to …

original: Natthi kuhiñcīti katthaci ekārammaṇepi natthi. Santoti paccanīkakilesānaṃ santatāya
analyzed: natthi kuhiñci iti katthaci eka ārammaṇe pi natthi santo ti paccanīka kilesānam santatāya
translated: and so on as

original: santo. Vidhūmoti kāyaduccaritādidhūmavirahito. Anīghoti rāgādiīghavirahito. Nirāsoti
analyzed: santaḥ vidhūmaḥ iti kāya duccarita ādi dhūma virahitaḥ anīghaḥ iti rāga ādi īgha virahitaḥ
translated: Peaceful: tranquil. Smoke-free: free from the smoke of bodily misconduct, etc. Burden-free: free from the burden of lust, etc. Hope-free:

original: nittaṇho. Atārīti tiṇṇo uttiṇṇo samatikkanto. Soti so arahaṃ khīṇāsavo. Jātijaranti
analyzed: nittaṇhaḥ atāri iti tiṇṇaḥ uttiṇṇaḥ samatikkanto saḥ ti saḥ araham khīṇa asavaḥ jāti jaranti
translated: free from craving. Crossed over: gone beyond, come out from, overcome. He: the arahat whose cankers are destroyed. Birth and aging:

original: ettha jātijarāgahaṇeneva byādhimaraṇampi gahitamevāti veditabbaṃ. Iti suttantepi
analyzed: ettha jāti jarā gahaṇena iva byādhi maraṇam pi gahitam evā ti veditabbam iti suttante pi
translated: here it should be understood that by the words “birth” and “aging” disease and death are included. Thus in the suttas

original: gāthāyapi arahattaphalasamāpattiyeva kathitāti.
analyzed: kathitā ati
translated: and in the verse, only the attainment of the fruit of arahatship is spoken of.

original: 3. Sāriputtasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: sāriputta sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . Commentary on the Sāriputta Sutta

original: 33. Tatiye saṃkhittenāti mātikāṭhapanena. Vitthārenāti ṭhapitamātikāvibhajanena.
analyzed: tatiye saṃkhittena ati mātikā ṭhapanena vitthārena ati ṭhapita mātikā vibhajanena
translated: In the third sutta, briefly: by the setting up of the mātikā. In detail: by the analysis of the mātikā that has been set up.

original: Saṃkhittavitthārenāti kāle saṃkhittena kāle vitthārena. Aññātāro ca dullabhāti paṭivijjhanakapuggalā
analyzed: saṃkhitta vitthārena ati kāle saṃkhittena kāle vitthārena aññātāraḥ ca dullabhā ati paṭivijjhanaka puggalā
translated: Briefly and in detail: briefly at one time, in detail at another time. And those who understand are hard to find: but those who penetrate

original: pana dullabhā. Idaṃ bhagavā “sāriputtattherassa ñāṇaṃ ghaṭṭemī”ti adhippāyena kathesi.
analyzed: pana dullabhā idam bhagavā sāriputta therassa ñāṇam ghaṭṭemi iti adhippāyena kathesi
translated: are hard to find. This the Exalted One spoke with the intention: “I will stimulate the knowledge of the Elder Sāriputta.”

original: Taṃ sutvā thero kiñcāpi “ahaṃ, bhante, ājānissāmī”ti na vadati, adhippāyena pana
analyzed: tam sutvā theraḥ kiñcā api aham bhante ājānissāmi iti na vadati adhippāyena pana
translated: Having heard this, the Elder did not say: “I will understand, venerable sir.” But with the intention:

original: “vissatthā tumhe, bhante, desetha, ahaṃ tumhehi desitaṃ dhammaṃ nayasatena nayasahassena
analyzed: vissatthā tumhe bhante desetha aham tumhehi desitam dhammam naya satena naya sahassena
translated: “You may be confident, venerable sir, in teaching me the Dhamma. I will penetrate with my mind what you teach me, and that will be my responsibility.”

original: paṭivijjhissāmi, mamesa bhāro hotū”ti satthāraṃ desanāya ussāhento etassa bhagavā kālotiādimāha.
analyzed: paṭivijjhissāmi mama esa bhāraḥ hotu uti satthāram desanāya ussāhentaḥ etassa bhagavā kālaḥ iti ādim āha
translated: And in urging the Teacher to teach, he said: “Now is the time for this, Blessed One, now is the time for this, Fortunate One.”

original: Athassa satthā tasmātihāti desanaṃ ārabhi. Tattha imasmiñca saviññāṇaketiādi vuttanayameva.
analyzed: atha assa satthā tasmā atihā ti desanam ārabhi tattha imasmin ca sa viññāṇaka iti ādi vutta nayam eva
translated: Then the Teacher began his teaching with the words “Therefore, Sariputta.” Herein, this is the method of explaining the passage beginning with “in this fathom-long carcase”:🔽“He has cut off craving”: he has cut off craving with the sword of the knowledge of the path.

original: Acchecchi taṇhanti maggañāṇasatthena taṇhaṃ chindi. Vivattayi saṃyojananti dasavidhampi🔽saṃyojanaṃ samūlakaṃ ubbattetvā chaḍḍesi. Sammā mānābhisamayā antamakāsi dukkhassāti
analyzed: taṇhanti magga ñāṇa satthena taṇham chindi vivattayi saṃyojananti dasavidham pi  saṃyojanam sa mūlakam ubbattetvā chaḍḍesi sammā māna abhisamayā antam akāsi dukkhassa ati
translated: “He has untied the fetters”: he has uprooted the ten fetters and cast them away.

original: sammā upāyena sammā paṭipattiyā navavidhassa mānassa pahānābhisamayena vaṭṭadukkhassa
analyzed: sammā upāyena sammā paṭipattiyā navavidhassa mānassa pahāna abhisamayena vaṭṭa dukkhassa
translated: “By the full understanding of conceit he has made an end of suffering”: by the full understanding of conceit through the right means, through the right practice, he has made an end of the suffering of the round.

original: antamakāsi. Idañca pana metaṃ, sāriputta, sandhāya bhāsitanti, sāriputta, mayā pārāyane
analyzed: antam akāsi idam ca pana mā etam sāriputta sandhāya bhāsitan ti sāriputta mayā pārāyane
translated: “This, Sariputta, is the meaning of what I said in the Parayana in ‘The Questions of Udaya’:🔽‘In the fathom-long carcase lies the world, with its divine and mortal beings. Having known this world as it really is, the sage, here and now, makes an end of suffering.’“

original: udayapañhe idaṃ phalasamāpattimeva sandhāya etaṃ bhāsitaṃ.
analyzed: udaya pañhe idam phala samāpattim eva sandhāya etam bhāsitam
translated: “This, Sariputta, is the meaning of what I said in the Parayana in ‘The Questions of Udaya’: ‘In the fathom-long carcase lies the world, with its divine and mortal beings. Having known this world as it really is, the sage, here and now, makes an end of suffering.’“

original: Idāni yaṃ taṃ bhagavatā bhāsitaṃ, taṃ dassento pahānaṃ kāmasaññānantiādi āraddhaṃ.
analyzed: idāni yam tam bhagavatā bhāsitam tam dassento pahānam kāma saññā na ti ādi āraddham
translated: Now, showing what was said by the Blessed One, he began with the words “The abandoning of sensual perceptions” .

original: Udayapañhe ca etaṃ padaṃ “pahānaṃ kāmacchandāna”nti āgataṃ, idha pana aṅguttarabhāṇakehi
analyzed: udaya pañhe ca etam padam āgatam idha pana aṅguttara bhāṇakehi
translated: And in the Questions of Udaya this phrase occurs as “The abandoning of sensual desire” , but here in the Anguttara Nikāya it has been added by the reciters as “sensual perceptions” .

original: “kāmasaññāna”nti āropitaṃ. Tattha byañjanameva nānaṃ, attho pana ekoyeva. Kāmasaññānanti
analyzed: kāma saññānan ti āropitam tattha byañjanam eva nānam atthaḥ pana kāma saññānan ti
translated: Herein, the wording is different, but the meaning is the same. Sensual perceptions :

original: kāme ārabbha uppannasaññānaṃ, aṭṭhahi vā lobhasahagatacittehi sahajātasaññānaṃ. Domanassāna
analyzed: kāme ārabbha uppanna saññānam aṭṭhahi vā lobha sahagata cittehi sahajāta saññānam domanassānaṃ
translated: perceptions arisen with regard to sensual desires, or perceptions conascent with the eight consciousnesses associated with greed.🔽And grief :

original: cūbhayanti etāsañca kāmasaññānaṃ cetasikadomanassānañcāti ubhinnampi pahānaṃ paṭippassaddhipahānasaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: etāsam ca kāma saññānam cetasika domanassānam ca ati ubhinnam pi pahānam paṭippassaddhi pahāna saṅkhātam
translated: both these sensual perceptions and mental grief. The abandoning of both is the state of further-men called “the abandoning of what is to be abandoned by seeing” .

original: arahattaphalaṃ aññāvimokkhaṃ pabrūmīti attho. Niddese pana “kāmacchandassa ca domanassassa
analyzed: arahatta phalam aññāvimokkham pabrūmi iti atthaḥ niddese pana kāmacchandassa ca domanassassa
translated: The meaning is that I proclaim the final emancipation of the Arahant fruit. But in the Niddesa it is said:

original: ca ubhinnaṃ pahānaṃ vūpasamaṃ paṭinissaggaṃ paṭippassaddhiṃ amataṃ nibbāna”nti vuttaṃ,
analyzed: ca ubhinnam pahānam vūpasamam paṭinissaggam paṭippassaddhim amatam nibbānam ti vuttam
translated: “The abandoning, the allaying, the uprooting, the abolition, the destruction, the non-recurrence of both sensual desire and grief” .

original: taṃ atthuddhāravasena vuttaṃ. Pahānanti hi khīṇākārasaṅkhāto vūpasamopi vuccati,🔽kilese paṭinissajjanto maggopi, kilesapaṭippassaddhisaṅkhātaṃ phalampi, yaṃ āgamma🔽kilesā pahīyanti, taṃ amataṃ nibbānampi. Tasmā tattha tāni padāni āgatāni. “Aññāvimokkhaṃ
analyzed: tat attha uddhāra vasena vuttam pahānam ti hi khīṇa ākāra saṅkhātaḥ vūpasamaḥ api vuccati  kilese paṭinissajjantaḥ maggaḥ api kilesa paṭippassaddhi saṅkhātam phalam pi yam āgamma  kilesā pahīyanti tam amatam nibbānam pi tasmā tattha tāni padāni āgatāni aññā vimokkham
translated: This is said by way of the meaning of the expression. For the abandoning is also called the stilling of the defilements in the sense of the destruction of their mode of being.🔽The path is also called the abandoning of the defilements in the sense of the relinquishing of the defilements. The fruit is also called the abandoning of the defilements in the sense of the stilling of the defilements. The deathless Nibbāna is also called the abandoning of the defilements in the sense of the abandoning of the defilements by means of which the defilements are abandoned.

original: pabrūmī”ti vacanato pana arahattaphalameva adhippetaṃ. Thinassa ca panūdanantipi
analyzed: pabrūmi iti vacanato pana arahatta phalam eva adhippetam thinassa ca
translated: Therefore, those terms are included here. But by the words “I declare the liberation by knowledge” , only the fruit of arahatship is intended.🔽“The dispelling of torpor” is also said.

original: thinassa ca panūdanante uppannattā arahattaphalameva adhippetaṃ. Kukkuccānaṃ nivāraṇanti
analyzed: thinassa ca pana udanante uppanna ttā arahatta phalam eva adhippetam
translated: By the words “the dispelling of torpor” , only the fruit of arahatship is intended, because it arises after the arising of the dispelling of torpor.🔽“The warding off of doubt” is also said.

original: kukkuccanivāraṇassa maggassa anantaraṃ uppannattā phalameva adhippetaṃ.
analyzed: kukkucca nivāraṇassa maggassa anantaram uppanna ttā phalam eva adhippetaṃ
translated: By the words “the warding off of doubt” , only the fruit is intended, because it arises immediately after the path which wards off doubt.🔽“The purity of mindfulness and equanimity” is also said.

original: Upekkhāsatisaṃsuddhanti catutthajjhānike phale uppannāya upekkhāya ca satiyā ca saṃsuddhaṃ.
analyzed: upekkhā sati saṃsuddham ti catuttha jhānike phale uppannāya upekkhāya ca satiyā ca saṃsuddham
translated: By the words “the purity of mindfulness and equanimity” , only the fruit arisen in the fourth jhāna is intended.

original: Dhammatakkapurejavanti dhammatakko vuccati sammāsaṅkappo, so ādito hoti, purato hoti,
analyzed: dhamma takka purejavanti dhamma takko vuccati sammāsaṅkappo saḥ āditas hoti puratas hoti
translated: “The right view that precedes” is also said.

original: pubbaṅgamo hoti aññāvimokkhassāti dhammatakkapurejavo. Taṃ dhammatakkapurejavaṃ.
analyzed: pubbaṅgamaḥ hoti aññāvimokkhassa ati dhamma takka purejavaḥ tam dhamma takka purejavam
translated: He is the forerunner in the liberation by understanding: he is the forerunner in the penetration of ideas. He is the forerunner in the penetration of ideas.

original: Aññāvimokkhanti aññindriyapariyosāne uppannaṃ vimokkhaṃ, aññāya vā vimokkhaṃ aññāvimokkhaṃ,
analyzed: aññāvimokkhanti aññindriya pariyosāne uppannam vimokkham aññāya vā vimokkham aññāvimokkham
translated: Liberation by understanding: the liberation that arises at the end of the sixth kind of direct- knowledge, or the liberation by understanding is liberation by understanding,🔽the meaning being ‘liberation by understanding’.

original: paññāvimuttanti attho. Avijjāya pabhedananti avijjāya pabhedanante uppannattā, avijjāya
analyzed: paññā vimuttanti atthaḥ avijjāya pabhedananti avijjāya pabhedanante uppanna ttā avijjāya
translated: The breaking-up of ignorance: because it arises with the breaking-up of ignorance,🔽or because it arises with reference to extinction called the ‘breaking-up of ignorance’,

original: pabhedanasaṅkhātaṃ vā nibbānaṃ ārabbha uppannattā evaṃladdhanāmaṃ arahattaphalameva.
analyzed: pabhedana saṅkhātam vā nibbānam ārabbha uppannattā evaṃladdha nāmam arahatta phalam eva
translated: it is the Arahant path that is so called.

original: Iti sabbehipi imehi pahānantiādīhi padehi arahattaphalameva pakāsitanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: iti sabbehi pi imehi pahāna nti ādīhi padehi arahatta phalam eva pakāsitanti veditabbam
translated: So it should be understood that all these terms beginning with ‘giving up’ refer to the Arahant path.

original: 4. Nidānasuttavaṇṇanā🔽34. Catutthe nidānānīti kāraṇāni. Kammānanti vaṭṭagāmikammānaṃ. Lobho nidānaṃ kammānaṃ
analyzed: nidāna sutta vaṇṇanā  catutthe nidānāni iti kāraṇāni kammānan ti vaṭṭa gāmi kammānam lobhaḥ nidānam kammānam
translated: The Nidana Sutta🔽In the fourth sutta, ‘causes’ are ‘origins’ . ‘Kamma’ is the kamma that generates the round of rebirths. ‘Greed’ is the greed that is the cause of kamma,

original: samudayāyāti lubbhanapalubbhanasabhāvo lobho vaṭṭagāmikammānaṃ samudayāya piṇḍakaraṇatthāya
analyzed: samudayāya ati lubbhana palubbhana sabhāvaḥ lobhaḥ vaṭṭa gāmi kammānam samudayāya piṇḍa karaṇa tthāya
translated: the cause of the origin of kamma that generates the round of rebirths, the cause of the accumulation of kamma.

original: nidānaṃ kāraṇaṃ paccayoti attho. Dosoti dussanapadussanasabhāvo doso. Mohoti muyhanapamuyhanasabhāvo moho.
analyzed: nidānam kāraṇam paccayaḥ ti attho doso ti dussana padussana sabhāvaḥ dosaḥ mohaḥ iti muyhana pamuyhana sabhāvaḥ mohaḥ
translated: The meaning is: source, cause, condition. “Hate” is hate having the nature of hating and being hateful. “Delusion” is delusion having the nature of deluding and being deluded.

original: Lobhapakatanti lobhena pakataṃ, lobhābhibhūtena luddhena hutvā katakammanti attho.🔽Lobhato jātanti lobhajaṃ. Lobho nidānamassāti lobhanidānaṃ. Lobho samudayo assāti
analyzed: lobha pakatam ti lobhena pakatam lobha abhibhūtena luddhena hutvā kata kamman ti attho  lobhataḥ jātanti lobha jam lobhaḥ nidānam assa ati lobha nidānam lobho samudayaḥ assa ati
translated: “Rooted in greed” : done by one who is greedy, by one who is overcome by greed, by one who is a slave of greed, is the meaning.🔽“Born of greed” : born of greed. “Greed is its source” : greed is its source. “Greed is its origin” :

original: lobhasamudayaṃ. Samudayoti paccayo, lobhapaccayanti attho. Yatthassa attabhāvo nibbattatīti
analyzed: lobha samudayam samudayaḥ uti paccayaḥ lobha paccayanti atthaḥ yatthassa atta bhāvaḥ nibbattati iti
translated: greed is its origin. “Origin” means condition; the meaning is: greed is the condition. “Where his being is generated” :

original: yasmiṃ ṭhāne assa lobhajakammavato puggalassa attabhāvo nibbattati, khandhā pātubhavanti.
analyzed: yasmin ṭhāne assa lobha ja kammavataḥ puggalassa atta bhāvaḥ nibbattati khandhāḥ pātubhavanti
translated: in whatever place the being of the person who has done the action rooted in greed is generated, the aggregates become manifest.

original: Tattha taṃ kammaṃ vipaccatīti tesu khandhesu taṃ kammaṃ vipaccati. Diṭṭhe vā dhammetiādi
analyzed: tattha tam kammam vipaccati iti tesu khandhesu tam kammam vipaccati diṭṭhe vā dhamma itiādi
translated: “There that action ripens” : in those aggregates that action ripens. “Either here and now” :

original: yasmā taṃ kammaṃ diṭṭhadhammavedanīyaṃ vā hoti upapajjavedanīyaṃ vā aparapariyāyavedanīyaṃ
analyzed: yasmai tam kammam diṭṭhadhamma vedanīyam vā hoti upapajja vedanīyam vā apara pariyāya vedanīyam
translated: since that action may be to be experienced here and now, or to be experienced on rebirth, or to be experienced in some subsequent becoming,

original: vā, tasmā taṃ pabhedaṃ dassetuṃ vuttaṃ. Sesadvayepi eseva nayo.
analyzed: vā tasmā tam pabhedam dassetum vuttam sesa dvaye pi esā iva nayo
translated: in order to show that classification it is said: “Either here and now, etc.” The same method applies to the other two kinds of action.

original: Akhaṇḍānīti abhinnāni. Apūtīnīti pūtibhāvena abījattaṃ appattāni. Avātātapahatānīti🔽na vātena na ca ātapena hatāni. Sārādānīti gahitasārāni sāravantāni na nissārāni.
analyzed: akhaṇḍāni iti abhinnāni apūtīni iti pūti bhāvena abījattam appattāni a vāta atapahatāni iti  na vātena na ca ātapena hatāni sāra ādāni iti gahita sārāni sāravantāni na nissārāni
translated: Unbroken: not split. Unbroken up: not become seedless through rotting. Not exposed to the wind and sun:🔽not damaged by wind and sun. Of good growth: of good growth in the sense of being well grown, of good growth in the sense of having heartwood.

original: Sukhasayitānīti sannicayabhāvena sukhaṃ sayitāni. Sukhetteti maṇḍakhette. Suparikammakatāya
analyzed: sukha sayitāni iti sannicaya bhāvena sukham sayitāni su khette iti maṇḍa khette su parikammaka tāya
translated: Well-spread: well-spread in the sense of being well-stored. In good soil: in a good field.

original: bhūmiyāti naṅgalakasanena ceva aṭṭhadantakena ca suṭṭhu parikammakatāya khettabhūmiyā.🔽Nikkhittānīti ṭhapitāni ropitāni. Anuppaveccheyyāti anuppaveseyya. Vuddhintiādīsu
analyzed: bhūmiyā ti naṅgala kasanena ca iva aṭṭhadantakena ca suṭṭhu parikammaka tāya khetta bhūmiyā  nikkhittāni iti ṭhapitāni ropitāni anuppaveccheyya ati anuppaveseyya vuddhi nti ādīsu
translated: Well-prepared ground: well-prepared ground in the sense of being well-ploughed with the ploughshare of right view and well-harrowed with the harrow of right thought.

original: uddhaggamanena vuddhiṃ, heṭṭhā mūlappatiṭṭhānena virūḷhiṃ, samantā vitthārikabhāvena vepullaṃ.🔽Yaṃ panettha diṭṭhe vā dhammetiādi vuttaṃ, tattha asammohatthaṃ imasmiṃ ṭhāne kammavibhatti
analyzed: uddhak gamanena vuddhim heṭṭhā mūla ppatiṭṭhānena virūḷhim samantā vitthārika bhāvena vepullam  yam pana ittha diṭṭhe vā dhamma iti ādi vuttam tattha asammoha attham imasmin ṭhāne kamma vibhatti
translated: Sown: sown, planted. Would grow up: would grow. Growth: growth by rising upwards. Increase: increase by being firmly established below. Abundance: abundance by spreading all round.

original: nāma kathetabbā. Suttantikapariyāyena hi ekādasa kammāni vibhattāni. Seyyathidaṃ
analyzed: nāma kathetabbā suttantika pariyāyena hi ekādasa kammāni vibhattāni seyyathidam
translated: As to what is said here about “in this very life” and so on, the analysis of action should be told here in order to avoid confusion. For eleven kinds of action are analysed in the Suttanta method, that is to say:

original: – diṭṭhadhammavedanīyaṃ upapajjavedanīyaṃ aparapariyāyavedanīyaṃ, yaggarukaṃ yabbahulaṃ
analyzed: diṭṭhadhamma vedanīyam upapajja vedanīyam apara pariyāya vedanīyam yaggarukam yaggarukam
translated: to be experienced in this very life, to be experienced after rebirth, to be experienced in some future life, what is weighty, what is habitual,

original: yadāsannaṃ kaṭattā vā pana kammaṃ, janakaṃ upatthambhakaṃ upapīḷakaṃ upaghātakanti.
analyzed: yat āsannam kaṭattā vā pana kammam janakam upatthambhakam upapīḷakam upaghātakam ti
translated: to be experienced here and now, to be experienced on rebirth, and to be experienced in some subsequent becoming.  It is the most outstanding, the most usual, the nearest, or it is the first to be produced.  It is productive, supportive, obstructive, or suppressive.

original: Tattha ekajavanavīthiyaṃ sattasu cittesu kusalā vā akusalā vā paṭhamajavanacetanā
analyzed: tattha eka javana vīthiyam sattasu cittesu kusalā vā akusalā vā paṭhama javana cetanā
translated: Herein, the volition of the first impulsion in a single impulsion process, whether it is profitable or unprofitable,

original: diṭṭhadhammavedanīyakammaṃ nāma. Taṃ imasmiṃyeva attabhāve vipākaṃ deti kākavaḷiyapuṇṇaseṭṭhīnaṃ
analyzed: diṭṭhadhamma vedanīya kammam nāma tam imasmin yeva atta bhāve vipākam deti kākavaḷiya puṇṇa seṭṭhīnam
translated: is called kamma to be experienced here and now. It gives its result in this present existence. It is profitable like that of the treasurer Kakudha and Puṇṇaka the money-lender,

original: viya kusalaṃ, nandayakkhanandamāṇavakanandagoghātakakokāliyasuppabuddhadevadattaciñcamāṇavikānaṃ
