analyzed: mahācetiyassa dakkhiṇa passe nipannassa pañca nikāya vasena bhikkhu saṅghe sajjhāyam
translated: As he lay on his right side at the southern side of the Great Shrine, the Community of Bhikkhus was reciting the Scriptures by the five Collections.

original: karonte chahi devalokehi cha rathā āgantvā purato ākāse aṭṭhaṃsu. Rājā “puññapotthakaṃ
analyzed: karonte chahi deva lokehi cha rathāḥ āgantvā puratas ākāse aṭṭhaṃsu rājā puñña potthakam
translated: Six chariots came from the six divine worlds and stood in the air in front of the king. The king said, “Bring the Book of Merits.”

original: āharathā”ti ādito paṭṭhāya puññapotthakaṃ vācāpesi. Atha naṃ kiñci kammaṃ na paritosesi.🔽So “parato vācethā”ti āha. Potthakavācako “cūḷaṅgaṇiyayuddhe parājitena te deva aṭaviṃ
analyzed: āharatha ati āditas paṭṭhāya puñña potthakam vācā apesi atha nam kiñci kammam na paritosesi  saḥ paratas vācetha iti āha potthaka vācakaḥ cūḷaṅgaṇiya yuddhe parājitena te deva aṭavim
translated: From the beginning he had the Book of Merits recited. Then he found no fault with any deed.

original: pavisitvā nisinnena ekaṃ sarakabhattaṃ cattāro koṭṭhāse kāretvā bodhimātumahātissattherassa🔽bhikkhā dinnā”ti āha. Rājā “ṭhapehī”ti vatvā bhikkhusaṅghaṃ pucchi, “bhante, kataro
analyzed: pavisitvā nisinnena ekam saraka bhattam cattāraḥ koṭṭhāse kāretvā bodhimātu mahā tissa therassa  bhikkhā dinnā iti āha rājā ṭhapehi iti vatvā bhikkhu saṅgham pucchi bhante kataro
translated: He said, “Recite from the end.” The reciter of the Book of Merits said, “Your majesty, when you were defeated in the battle of Cūḷaṅgīra and you were sitting in the forest, you divided a dish of rice and curry into four parts and gave alms to the Elder Mahā Tissa, the mother of the Bodhisatta.”

original: devaloko ramaṇīyo”ti? Sabbabodhisattānaṃ vasanaṭṭhānaṃ tusitabhavanaṃ mahārājāti.
analyzed: deva lokaḥ ramaṇīyaḥ ti sabba bodhisattānam vasana ṭṭhānam tusita bhavanam mahā rāja ati
translated: The king said, “Stop,” and he asked the Community of Bhikkhus, “Venerable sirs, which divine world is delightful?” —“The Tusita world, great king, where all Bodhisattas dwell.”

original: Rājā kālaṃ katvā tusitabhavanato āgataratheva patiṭṭhāya tusitabhavanaṃ agamāsi.
analyzed: rājā kālam katvā tusitabhavanataḥ āgata rathā iva patiṭṭhāya tusitabhavanam agamāsi
translated: When the king died, he was established in the very chariot that had come from the Tusita world and he went to the Tusita world.

original: Idaṃ balavakammassa vipākadāne vatthu.
analyzed: idam balava kammassa vipāka dāne vatthu
translated: This is the instance of the giving of the result of strong kamma.

original: Yaṃ pana kusalākusalesu āsannamaraṇe anussarituṃ sakkoti, taṃ yadāsannaṃ nāma. Tadetaṃ
analyzed: yam pana kusala akusalesu āsanna maraṇe anussaritum sakkoti tam yat āsannam nāma tat etam
translated: But that which can be remembered as near to the profitable or unprofitable at the time of death is called near.

original: yathā nāma gogaṇaparipuṇṇassa vajassa dvāre vivaṭe parabhāge dammagavabalavagavesu
analyzed: yathā nāma go gaṇa paripuṇṇassa vajassa dvāre vivaṭe parabhāge dammagava balavagavesu
translated: This is like the case of a cowpen full of cows with the gate open. Although there are strong bulls and strong oxen in the other part,

original: santesupi yo vajadvārassa āsanno hoti antamaso dubbalajaraggavopi, so eva paṭhamataraṃ
analyzed: yaḥ vaja dvārassa āsannaḥ hoti antamasaḥ saḥ eva paṭhamataram
translated: the one that is near the gate of the cowpen, even if it is a weak calf,

original: nikkhamati, evameva aññesu kusalākusalesu santesupi maraṇakālassa āsannattā vipākaṃ deti.
analyzed: nikkhamati evam eva aññesu kusala akusalesu santesu pi maraṇa kālassa āsanna ttā vipākam deti
translated: goes out first. So too, although there are other profitable and unprofitable kinds of kamma, this gives its result because it is near to the time of death.

original: Tatrimāni vatthūni – madhuaṅgaṇagāme kira eko damiḷadovāriko pātova baḷisaṃ ādāya
analyzed: tatra imāni vatthūni madhuaṅgaṇa gāme kiraḥ ekaḥ damiḷa dovārikaḥ baḷisam ādāya
translated: Here are the instances. In the village of Madhuanganagara, it seems, a certain Tamil watchman went out in the morning, taking his net,

original: gantvā macche vadhitvā tayo koṭṭhāse katvā ekena taṇḍulaṃ gaṇhāti, ekena dadhiṃ,
analyzed: gantvā macche vadhitvā tayoḥ koṭṭhāse katvā ekena taṇḍulam gaṇhāti ekena dadhim
translated: and after catching fish he divided them into three parts. With one part he bought rice, with another he bought curd,

original: ekaṃ pacati. Iminā nīhārena paññāsa vassāni pāṇātipātakammaṃ katvā aparabhāge mahallako
analyzed: ekam pacati iminā nīhārena paññāsa vassāni pāṇātipāta kammam katvā aparabhāge mahallakaḥ
translated: and he cooked the third part. By this means he went on for fifty years killing living beings. Later on he became an old man

original: anuṭṭhānaseyyaṃ upagacchati. Tasmiṃ khaṇe girivihāravāsī cūḷapiṇḍapātikatissatthero
analyzed: anuṭṭhāna seyyam upagacchati tasmin khaṇe giri vihāra vāsī cūḷapiṇḍapātika tissa theraḥ
translated: He went to bed and lay down. At that moment the Elder Tissa, the Lesser Almsman, who lived in the Gabled Hall,

original: “mā ayaṃ satto mayi passante nassatū”ti gantvā tassa gehadvāre aṭṭhāsi. Athassa bhariyā,
analyzed: mā ayam satto mayi passante nassatu uti gantvā tassa geha dvāre aṭṭhāsi athassa bhariyā
translated: thought, “Let not this being perish while looking at me.” So he went and stood at the door of his house. Then his wife,

original: “sāmi, thero āgato”ti ārocesi. Ahaṃ paññāsa vassāni therassa santikaṃ na gatapubbo,
analyzed: sāmi theraḥ āgataḥ ti ārocesi aham paññāsa vassāni therassa santikam na gata pubbo
translated: saying, “Husband, the Elder is here,” told him. “I have not been near the Elder for fifty years,

original: katarena me guṇena thero āgamissati, gacchāti naṃ vadathāti. Sā “aticchatha, bhante”ti
analyzed: katarena me guṇena theraḥ āgamissati gaccha ati nam vadatha ati sā aticchatha bhante iti
translated: what good quality of mine has the Elder come to see? Go and tell him to be off.” She said, “Husband, be not angry.”

original: āha. Thero “upāsakassa kā sarīrappavattī”ti pucchi. Dubbalo, bhanteti. Thero gharaṃ🔽pavisitvā satiṃ uppādetvā “sīlaṃ gaṇhissasī”ti āha. Āma, bhante, dethāti. Thero tīṇi🔽saraṇāni datvā pañca sīlāni dātuṃ ārabhi. Tassa pañca sīlānīti vacanakāleyeva jivhā
analyzed: āha theraḥ upāsakassa kā sarīra ppavatti iti pucchi dubbalaḥ bhante ti theraḥ gharaṃ  pavisitvā satim uppādetvā sīlam gaṇhissasi iti āha āma bhante detha ati theraḥ tīṇi  saraṇāni da tvā pañca sīlāni dātum ārabhi tassa pañca sīlāni iti vacana kāleyā iva jivhā
translated: The Elder asked, “What is the matter with the body of the lay disciple?” “He is weak, Reverend Sir.” The Elder entered the house,🔽aroused his mindfulness, and said, “Will you take the Refuges?” “Yes, Reverend Sir, give them to me.” The Elder gave him the Three Refuges and began to give him the Five Precepts.🔽As soon as he heard the words “the Five Precepts,” his tongue fell out. The Elder thought, “This will do,” and he went away.

original: papati. Thero “vaṭṭissati ettaka”nti nikkhamitvā gato. Sopi kālaṃ katvā cātumahārājikabhavane
analyzed: papati theraḥ vaṭṭissati ettakam ti nikkhamitvā gataḥ saḥ api kālam katvā cātumahārājika bhavane
translated: The lay disciple died and was reborn in the World of the Four Great Kings.

original: nibbatti. Nibbattakkhaṇeyeva ca “kiṃ nu kho kammaṃ katvā mayā idaṃ laddha”nti āvajjento
analyzed: nibbatti ca kim nu kho kammam katvā mayā idam laddhanti āvajjento
translated: As soon as he was reborn, he considered thus: “What deed did I do by which I have obtained this?”

original: theraṃ nissāya laddhabhāvaṃ ñatvā devalokato āgantvā theraṃ vanditvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi.
analyzed: theram nissāya laddha bhāvam ñatvā deva lokataḥ āgantvā theram vanditvā ekamantam aṭṭhāsi
translated: He came to know that he had obtained it by means of the Elder, and so he came down from the world of the gods, paid homage to the Elder, and stood at one side.

original: “Ko eso”ti ca vutte “ahaṃ, bhante, damiḷadovāriko”ti āha. Kuhiṃ nibbattosīti? Cātumahārājikesu,🔽bhante, sace me ayyo pañca sīlāni adassa, upari devaloke nibbatto assaṃ. Ahaṃ kiṃ
analyzed: kaḥ esaḥ iti ca vutte aham bhante damiḷadovārikaḥ iti āha kuhim nibbatto asi iti cātumahārājikesu  bhante sace me ayyo pañca sīlāni adassaḥ upari deva loke nibbatto assam aham kim
translated: When asked, “Who are you?” he replied, “Venerable sir, I am the Tamil gatekeeper.” “Where were you reborn?” “In the world of the Four Great Kings, venerable sir.

original: karissāmi, tvaṃ gaṇhituṃ nāsakkhi, puttakāti. So theraṃ vanditvā devalokameva gato.
analyzed: karissāmi tvam gaṇhitum na asakkhi puttaka iti saḥ theram vanditvā deva lokam eva gataḥ
translated: If you had given me the five precepts, venerable sir, I should have been reborn in a higher world of the gods. What can I do? You could not take them. I am your son.” He paid homage to the Elder and went off to the world of the gods.

original: Idaṃ tāva kusalakamme vatthu.
analyzed: idam tāva kusala kamme vatthu
translated: This is the story of a profitable action.

original: Antaragaṅgāya pana mahāvācakālaupāsako nāma ahosi. So tiṃsa vassāni sotāpattimaggatthāya
analyzed: antaragaṅgāya pana mahāvāca kālaupāsakaḥ nāma ahosi saḥ tiṃsa vassāni sotāpatti magga tthāya
translated: But the lay devotee Mahāvāca of Antarācalā was one who had recited the thirty-two aspects of the way to the fruit of stream-entry for thirty years,

original: dvattiṃsākāraṃ sajjhāyitvā “ahaṃ evaṃ dvattiṃsākāraṃ sajjhāyanto obhāsamattampi nibbattetuṃ
analyzed: dvattiṃsa ākāram sajjhāyitvā aham evam dvattiṃsa ākāram sajjhāyantaḥ obhāsa mattam pi nibbattetum
translated: saying, “While I am reciting the thirty-two aspects of the way, let a sign arise.”

original: nāsakkhiṃ, buddhasāsanaṃ aniyyānikaṃ bhavissatī”ti diṭṭhivipallāsaṃ patvā kālakiriyaṃ
analyzed: na asakkhim buddha sāsanam aniyyānikam bhavissati iti diṭṭhi vipallāsam patvā kālakiriyam
translated: and he died with a wrong view.

original: katvā mahāgaṅgāya navausabhiko susumārapeto hutvā nibbatti. Ekaṃ samayaṃ kacchakatitthena
analyzed: katvā mahāgaṅgāya nava ausabhikaḥ susumāra petaḥ hutvā nibbatti ekam samayam kacchakatitthena
translated: He was reborn as a crocodile in the great Ganges, nine fathoms long, with a head like a ploughshare.

original: saṭṭhi pāsāṇatthambhasakaṭāni agamaṃsu. So sabbepi te goṇe ca pāsāṇe ca khādi. Idaṃ
analyzed: saṭṭhi pāsāṇa tthambha sakaṭāni agamaṃsu saḥ sabbe pi te goṇe ca pāsāṇe ca khādi idam
translated: Once, when sixty carts with stone pillars were going along the bank of the Ganges, he ate all the oxen and the pillars.

original: akusalakamme vatthu.
analyzed: akusala kamme vatthu
translated: This was the occasion for his unwholesome action.

original: Etehi pana tīhi muttaṃ aññāṇavasena kataṃ kaṭattā vā pana kammaṃ nāma. Taṃ yathā🔽nāma ummattakena khittadaṇḍaṃ yattha vā tattha vā gacchati, evameva tesaṃ abhāve
analyzed: etehi pana tīhi muttam aññāṇa vasena katam kaṭattā vā pana kammam nāma tam yathā  nāma ummattakena khitta daṇḍam yattha vā tattha vā gacchati evam eva tesam abhāve
translated: But that which is excluded from these three kinds of action is called “action that is done by unknowing” or “action that is done by mere volition.”

original: yattha katthaci vipākaṃ deti.🔽Janakaṃ nāma ekaṃ paṭisandhiṃ janetvā pavattiṃ na janeti, pavatte aññaṃ kammaṃ vipākaṃ
analyzed: yattha katthacid vipākam deti  janakam nāma ekam paṭisandhim janetvā pavattim na janeti pavatte aññam kammam vipākam
translated: That, like a stick thrown down at random, gives its fruit anywhere at all, since there is no specific condition for it.

original: nibbatteti. Yathā hi mātā janetiyeva, dhātiyeva pana jaggati; evamevaṃ mātā viya
analyzed: nibbattā iti yathā hi mātā janetiyā iva dhātiyā iva pana jaggati evam evam mātā viya
translated: “Action that produces only the rebirth-linking” is that which produces only the rebirth-linking and does not produce the course of action following on the rebirth-linking. It is like a mother who only gives birth but does not bring up her child.

original: paṭisandhinibbattakaṃ janakakammaṃ, dhāti viya pavatte sampattakammaṃ. Upatthambhakaṃ
analyzed: paṭisandhi nibbattakam janaka kammam dhāti viya pavatte sampatta kammam upatthambhakam
translated: Generating kamma is kamma that generates rebirth-linking; supporting kamma is kamma that supports the continuity of aggregates already obtained, like a wet-nurse.

original: nāma kusalepi labbhati akusalepi. Ekacco hi kusalaṃ katvā sugatibhave nibbattati.
analyzed: nāma kusale api labbhati akusale api ekaccaḥ hi kusalam katvā sugati bhave nibbattati
translated: Supporting kamma is found in the profitable and in the unprofitable. For one who has done profitable kamma is reborn in a happy destiny.

original: So tattha ṭhito punappunaṃ kusalaṃ katvā taṃ kammaṃ upatthambhetvā anekāni vassasatasahassāni🔽sugatibhavasmiṃyeva vicarati. Ekacco akusalaṃ katvā duggatibhave nibbattati. So tattha
analyzed: saḥ tattha ṭhitaḥ punappunam kusalam katvā tam kammam upatthambhetvā anekāni vassa sata sahassāni  sugati bhavasmiṃ yeva vicarati ekaccaḥ akusalam katvā duggati bhave nibbattati saḥ tattha
translated: While he remains there he does profitable kamma again and again, and he supports that kamma by remaining there. He goes on living in a happy destiny for many hundreds of thousands of years.

original: ṭhito punappunaṃ akusalaṃ katvā taṃ kammaṃ upatthambhetvā bahūni vassasatasahassāni🔽duggatibhavasmiṃyeva vicarati.🔽Aparo nayo – janakaṃ nāma kusalampi hoti akusalampi. Taṃ paṭisandhiyampi pavattepi
analyzed: ṭhitaḥ punappunam akusalam katvā tam kammam upatthambhetvā bahūni vassa sata sahassāni  vicarati  aparaḥ nayaḥ janakam nāma kusalam pi hoti akusalam pi tam paṭisandhiyam pi pavatte pi
translated: One who has done unprofitable kamma is reborn in an unhappy destiny. While he remains there he does unprofitable kamma again and again, and he supports that kamma by remaining there. He goes on living in an unhappy destiny for many hundreds of thousands of years.🔽Another method: Generating kamma is both profitable and unprofitable. It generates the aggregates subject to ripening, whether in the rebirth-linking or in the course of an existence.

original: rūpārūpavipākakkhandhe janeti. Upatthambhakaṃ pana vipākaṃ janetuṃ na sakkoti, aññena
analyzed: rūpa arūpa vipāka khandhe janeti upatthambhakam pana vipākam janetum na sakkoti aññena
translated: But supporting kamma is incapable of generating ripening. It supports the aggregates subject to ripening that have already been generated by other kamma.

original: kammena dinnāya paṭisandhiyā janite vipāke uppajjanakasukhadukkhaṃ upatthambheti,🔽addhānaṃ pavatteti. Upapīḷakaṃ nāma aññena kammena dinnāya paṭisandhiyā janite vipāke
analyzed: kammena dinnāya paṭisandhiyā janite vipāke uppajjanaka sukha dukkham upatthambheti  addhānam pavatteti upapīḷakam nāma aññena kammena dinnāya paṭisandhiyā janite vipāke
translated: It supports the pleasure and pain that arise in the ripening produced by the rebirth-linking that is given by kamma.

original: uppajjanakasukhadukkhaṃ pīḷeti bādheti, addhānaṃ pavattituṃ na deti. Tatrāyaṃ nayo
analyzed: uppajjanaka sukha dukkham pīḷeti bādheti addhānam pavattitum na deti tatra ayam nayaḥ
translated: It causes the life-continuum to occur. Oppressing is that which oppresses, which obstructs, the pleasure and pain that arise in the ripening produced by the rebirth-linking given by another kamma, and which does not allow the life-continuum to occur.🔽Here is the method.

original: – kusalakamme vipaccamāne akusalakammaṃ upapīḷakaṃ hutvā tassa vipaccituṃ na deti.
analyzed: kusala kamme vipaccamāne akusala kammam upapīḍakam hutvā tassa vipaccitum na deti
translated: When profitable kamma is ripening, unprofitable kamma becomes oppressive and does not allow it to ripen.

original: Akusalakamme vipaccamāne kusalakammaṃ upapīḷakaṃ hutvā tassa vipaccituṃ na deti.
analyzed: akusala kamme vipaccamāne kusala kammam upapīḍakam hutvā tassa vipaccitum na deti
translated: When unprofitable kamma is ripening, profitable kamma becomes oppressive and does not allow it to ripen.

original: Yathā vaḍḍhamānakaṃ rukkhaṃ vā gacchaṃ vā lataṃ vā kocideva daṇḍena vā satthena vā
analyzed: yathā vaḍḍhamānakam rukkham vā gaccham vā latam vā kocid eva daṇḍena vā satthena vā
translated: Just as if someone were to pierce or cut a growing tree or creeper or vine with a knife or an axe,

original: bhindeyya vā chindeyya vā, atha so rukkho vā gaccho vā latā vā vaḍḍhituṃ na sakkuṇeyya;
analyzed: bhindeyya vā chindeyya vā atha saḥ rukkhaḥ vā gacchaḥ vā latā vā vaḍḍhitum na sakkuṇeyya
translated: then that tree or creeper or vine would not be able to grow;🔽so too, when profitable kamma is ripening, it is oppressed by the unprofitable,

original: evamevaṃ kusalaṃ vipaccamānaṃ akusalena upapīḷitaṃ, akusalaṃ vā pana vipaccamānaṃ
analyzed: evam evam kusalam vipaccamānam akusalena upapīḷitam akusalam vā pana vipaccamānam
translated: and when unprofitable kamma is ripening, it is oppressed by the profitable,

original: kusalena upapīḷitaṃ vipaccituṃ na sakkoti. Tattha sunakkhattassa akusalakammaṃ kusalaṃ
analyzed: kusalena upapīḷitam vipaccitum na sakkoti tattha sunakkhattassa akusala kammam kusalam
translated: and the unprofitable cannot ripen when pressed by the profitable. Herein, Sunakkhatta’s unprofitable action was pressed by his profitable action,

original: upapīḷesi, coraghātakassa kusalakammaṃ akusalaṃ upapīḷesi.
analyzed: upapīḷesi cora ghātakassa kusala kammam akusalam upapīḷesi
translated: and the robber’s profitable action was pressed by his unprofitable action.

original: Rājagahe kira vātakāḷako paññāsa vassāni coraghātakammaṃ akāsi. Atha naṃ rañño ārocesuṃ
analyzed: rājagahe kira vātakāḷako paññāsa vassāni cora ghāta kammam akāsi atha nam raññaḥ ārocesuṃ
translated: In Rājagaha, it seems, a certain Vātakāḷaka had been a robber for fifty years. Then they told the king

original: – “deva, vātakāḷako mahallako core ghātetuṃ na sakkotī”ti. “Apanetha naṃ tasmā ṭhānantarāti.
analyzed: deva vātakāḷakaḥ mahallakaḥ core ghātetum na sakkoti iti apanetha nam tasmai
translated: “Sire, Vātakāḷaka is too old to kill robbers any more.” “Then remove him from that post.”

original: Amaccā naṃ apanetvā aññaṃ tasmiṃ ṭhāne ṭhapayiṃsu. Vātakāḷakopi yāva taṃ kammaṃ akāsi,🔽tāva ahatavatthāni vā acchādituṃ surabhipupphāni vā piḷandhituṃ pāyāsaṃ vā bhuñjituṃ
analyzed: amaccā nam apanetvā aññam tasmiṃ ṭhāne ṭhapayiṃsu yāva tam kammam akāsi  tāva ahata vatthāni vā a chāditum surabhi pupphāni vā piḷandhitum pāyāsam vā bhuñjitum
translated: The ministers removed him and gave the post to someone else. But Vātakāḷaka,

original: ucchādananhāpanaṃ vā paccanubhotuṃ nālattha. So “dīgharattaṃ me kiliṭṭhavesena carita”nti
analyzed: ucchādana nhāpanam vā paccanubhotum na alattha saḥ dīgharattam me kiliṭṭha vesena
translated: as long as he was doing that work, did not get to wear unworn clothes, or to anoint himself with perfumes, or to eat milk-rice, or to enjoy a massage, a bath, or a rubbing with oil. He thought “I have been going about dirty for a long time,”

original: “pāyāsaṃ me pacāhī”ti bhariyaṃ āṇāpetvā nhānīyasambhārāni gāhāpetvā nhānatitthaṃ
analyzed: pāyāsam me pacāhi iti bhariyam āṇāpetvā nhānīya sambhārāni gāhāpetvā nhāna tittham
translated: and he told his wife to cook milk-rice for him, and he had the requisites for bathing brought and went to a bathing place.

original: gantvā sīsaṃ nhatvā ahatavatthāni acchādetvā gandhe vilimpitvā pupphāni piḷandhitvā
analyzed: gantvā sīsam nhatvā ahata vatthāni acchādetvā gandhe vilimpitvā pupphāni piḷandhitvā
translated: and after bathing his head, he put on new clothes, anointed himself with perfume, and wreathed himself with flowers.

original: gharaṃ āgacchanto sāriputtattheraṃ disvā “saṃkiliṭṭhakammato camhi apagato, ayyo🔽ca me diṭṭho”ti tuṭṭhamānaso theraṃ gharaṃ netvā navasappisakkaracuṇṇābhisaṅkhatena🔽pāyāsena parivisi. Thero tassa anumodanamakāsi. So anumodanaṃ sutvā anulomikakhantiṃ
analyzed: gharam āgacchanto sāriputta theram disvā saṃkiliṭṭha kammataḥ camhi apagataḥ ayyo  ca me diṭṭhā iti tuṭṭha mānasaḥ theram gharam netvā nava sappi sakkara cuṇṇa abhisaṅkhatena  pāyāsena parivisi theraḥ tassa anumodanam akāsi saḥ anumodanam sutvā anulomika khantim
translated: On his way back home he saw the Elder Sāriputta. He thought to himself, “I have come away from a dirty deed, and now I have seen the Elder.🔽I am indeed fortunate.” With a glad heart he took the Elder to his house and served him with milk-rice mixed with fresh ginger and sugar. The Elder pronounced the words of thanksgiving.🔽After hearing the words of thanksgiving, the thief attained the first stage of cleansing.

original: paṭilabhitvā theraṃ anugantvā nivattamāno antarāmagge taruṇavacchāya gāviyā madditvā🔽jīvitakkhayaṃ pāpito gantvā tāvatiṃsabhavane nibbatti. Bhikkhū tathāgataṃ pucchiṃsu🔽– “bhante, coraghātako ajjeva kiliṭṭhakammato apanīto, ajjeva kālaṅkato, kahaṃ nu
analyzed: paṭilabhitvā theram anugantvā nivattamānaḥ antara āmagge taruṇa vacchāya gāviyā madditvā  jīvita kkhayam pāpitaḥ gantvā tāvatiṃsa bhavane nibbatti bhikkhū tathāgatam pucchiṃsu  bhante cora ghātakaḥ ajja iva kiliṭṭha kammataḥ apanītaḥ ajja iva kālaṅkato kaham nu
translated: Following the Elder, he turned back on the road and was gored to death by a young bull.🔽The monks asked the Teacher, “Reverend Sir, the murderer of the thief has just now come away from a dirty deed, and now he is dead. Where has he been reborn?”🔽“Monks, he has been reborn in the World of the Thirty-three.”

original: kho nibbatto”ti? Tāvatiṃsabhavane, bhikkhaveti. Bhante, coraghātako dīgharattaṃ purise
analyzed: kho nibbattaḥ ti tāvatiṃsa bhavane bhikkhave ti bhante cora ghātakaḥ dīgharattam purise
translated: “Reverend Sir, the murderer of the thief has for a long time been a murderer of men.

original: ghātesi, tumhe ca evaṃ vadetha, natthi nu kho pāpakammassa phalanti. Mā, bhikkhave,
analyzed: ghātesi tumhe ca evam vadetha natthi nu kho pāpa kammassa phalanti mā bhikkhave
translated: and you say that there is no fruit of evil action. Do not say so,🔽bhikkhus. Having obtained the support of a powerful good friend,

original: evaṃ avacuttha, balavakalyāṇamittūpanissayaṃ labhitvā dhammasenāpatissa piṇḍapātaṃ
analyzed: evam avacuttha balava kalyāṇa mittu upanissayam labhitvā dhammasenāpatissa piṇḍapātam
translated: having given almsfood to the General of the Dhamma,

original: datvā anumodanaṃ sutvā anulomikakhantiṃ paṭilabhitvā so tattha nibbattoti.
analyzed: datvā anumodanam sutvā anulomika khantim paṭilabhitvā so tattha nibbatto ti
translated: and having heard the expression of appreciation, he obtained acquiescence in conformity and was reborn there.🔽Having heard the well-spoken words,

original: “Subhāsitaṃ suṇitvāna, nāgariyo coraghātako;
analyzed: su bhāsitam nāgariyaḥ cora ghātakaḥ
translated: the bandit, slayer of men,

original: Anulomakhantiṃ laddhāna, modatī tidivaṃ gato”ti.
analyzed: anuloma khantim modatī tidivam gatā iti
translated: having obtained acquiescence in conformity, rejoices, gone to the realm of the gods.

original: Upaghātakaṃ pana sayaṃ kusalampi akusalampi samānaṃ aññaṃ dubbalakammaṃ ghātetvā
analyzed: upaghātakam pana sayam kusalam pi akusalam pi samānam aññam dubbala kammam ghātetvā
translated: But the act of suppression, whether it is wholesome or unwholesome, suppresses another weak action,

original: tassa vipākaṃ paṭibāhitvā attano vipākassa okāsaṃ karoti. Evaṃ pana kammena kate
analyzed: tassa vipākam paṭibāhitvā attanaḥ vipākassa okāsam karoti evam pana kammena kate
translated: and having blocked off its result, it makes an opportunity for its own result. But when the opportunity has been made in this way by the action,

original: okāse taṃ vipākaṃ uppannaṃ nāma vuccati. Upacchedakantipi etasseva nāmaṃ. Tatrāyaṃ
analyzed: okāse tam vipākam uppannam nāma vuccati etassa iva nāmam tatra ayam
translated: that result is called “arisen.” This is also a name for the act of cutting off. Here is the method.

original: nayo – kusalakammassa vipaccanakāle ekaṃ akusalakammaṃ uṭṭhāya taṃ kammaṃ chinditvā
analyzed: nayaḥ kusala kammassa vipaccana kāle ekam akusala kammaṃ uṭṭhāya tam kammam chinditvā
translated: At the time of the ripening of a wholesome action, a single unwholesome action arises and cuts off that action,🔽and having blocked off its result,

original: pāteti. Akusalakammassapi vipaccanakāle ekaṃ kusalakammaṃ uṭṭhāya taṃ kammaṃ chinditvā
analyzed: pāteti akusala kammassa api vipaccana kāle ekam kusala kammam uṭṭhāya tam kammam chinditvā
translated: and when the time comes for the result of the unprofitable action to be experienced, then a single profitable action arises and cuts off that action and sends it away.

original: pāteti. Idaṃ upacchedakaṃ nāma. Tattha ajātasattuno kammaṃ kusalacchedakaṃ ahosi,
analyzed: pāta iti idam upacchedakam nāma tattha ajāta sattuno kammam kusala chedakam ahosi
translated: This is called “cutting off.” Herein, the action of Ajātasattu was cutting off of the profitable,

original: aṅgulimālattherassa akusalacchedakanti. Evaṃ suttantikapariyāyena ekādasa kammāni vibhattāni.
analyzed: aṅgulimāla therassa akusala chedakanti evam suttantika pariyāyena ekādasa kammāni vibhattāni
translated: and that of the Elder Aṅgulimāla was cutting off of the unprofitable. So they are distributed in eleven ways according to the Suttas.

original: Abhidhammapariyāyena pana soḷasa kammāni vibhattāni, seyyathidaṃ – “atthekaccāni🔽pāpakāni kammasamādānāni gatisampattipaṭibāḷhāni na vipaccanti, atthekaccāni pāpakāni
analyzed: abhidhamma pariyāyena pana soḷasa kammāni vibhattāni seyyathidam attha ekaccāni  pāpakāni kamma samādānāni gati sampatti paṭibāḷhāni na vipaccanti attha ekaccāni pāpakāni
translated: But according to the Abhidhamma they are distributed in sixteen ways, as follows:🔽“There are some bad actions undertaken that are not effective in producing an unhappy destination;🔽there are some bad actions undertaken that are not effective in producing an unhappy destination;🔽there are some bad actions undertaken that are not effective in producing an unhappy destination;

original: kammasamādānāni upadhisampattipaṭibāḷhāni na vipaccanti, atthekaccāni pāpakāni kammasamādānāni🔽kālasampattipaṭibāḷhāni na vipaccanti, atthekaccāni pāpakāni kammasamādānāni payogasampattipaṭibāḷhāni
analyzed: kamma samādānāni upadhi sampatti paṭibāḷhāni na vipaccanti attha ekaccāni pāpakāni kamma samādānāni 🔽kāla sampatti paṭibāḷhāni na vipaccanti attha ekaccāni pāpakāni kamma samādānāni payoga sampatti paṭibāḷhāni
translated: there are some bad actions undertaken that are not effective in producing an unhappy destination;

original: na vipaccanti. Atthekaccāni pāpakāni kammasamādānāni gativipattiṃ āgamma vipaccanti,
analyzed: na vipaccanti attha ekaccāni pāpakāni kamma samādānāni gati vipattim āgamma vipaccanti
translated: and do not ripen. Some evil deeds, when they have been done and stored up, ripen in an unhappy destination.

original: upadhivipattiṃ, kālavipattiṃ, payogavipattiṃ āgamma vipaccanti. Atthekaccāni kalyāṇāni🔽kammasamādānāni gativipattipaṭibāḷhāni na vipaccanti, upadhivipatti, kālavipatti,
analyzed: upadhi vipattim kāla vipattim payoga vipattim āgamma vipaccanti attha ekaccāni kalyāṇāni  kamma samādānāni gati vipatti paṭibāḷhāni na vipaccanti upadhi vipatti kāla vipatti
translated: Some good deeds, when they have been done and stored up, do not ripen in a happy destination.

original: payogavipattipaṭibāḷhāni na vipaccanti. Atthekaccāni kalyāṇāni kammasamādānāni gatisampattiṃ
analyzed: payoga vipatti paṭibāḷhāni na vipaccanti atthekaccāni kalyāṇāni kamma samādānāni gati sampattim
translated: Some good deeds, when they have been done and stored up, do not ripen in a happy destination because of the weakness of the conditions for ripening.🔽Some good deeds, when they have been done and stored up, ripen in a happy destination.

original: āgamma vipaccanti, upadhisampattiṃ, kālasampattiṃ, payogasampattiṃ āgamma vipaccantī”ti.🔽Tattha pāpakānīti lāmakāni. Kammasamādānānīti kammaggahaṇāni. Gahitasamādinnānaṃ🔽kammānametaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Gatisampattipaṭibāḷhāni na vipaccantītiādīsu aniṭṭhārammaṇānubhavanārahe
analyzed: āgamma vipaccanti upadhi sampattim kāla sampattim payoga sampattim āgamma vipaccanti iti  tattha pāpakāni iti lāmakāni kamma samādānāni iti kamma gahaṇāni gahita samādinnānam  kammānam etam adhivacanam gati sampatti paṭibāḷhāni na vipaccanti itiādīsu aniṭṭha ārammaṇa anubhavana arahe
translated: Some good deeds, when they have been done and stored up, ripen in a happy destination because of the strength of the conditions for ripening. ”

original: kamme vijjamāneyeva sugatibhave nibbattassa taṃ kammaṃ gatisampattipaṭibāḷhaṃ na
analyzed: kamme vijjamāne iya iva sugati bhave nibbattassa tam kammam gati sampatti paṭibāḷham na
translated: Herein, evil means blameworthy. Deeds done and stored up means deeds done and laid up. This is a term for deeds that have been done and stored up. Do not ripen in a happy destination because of the strength of the conditions for ripening, etc., means that although the deed is there, which is fit to be experienced as an undesirable object, it does not ripen in one who is reborn in a happy destination.

original: vipaccati nāma. Gatisampattiyā patibāhitaṃ hutvā na vipaccatīti attho. Yo pana pāpakammena
analyzed: vipaccati nāma gati sampattiyā patibāhitam hutvā na vipaccati iti atthaḥ yaḥ pana pāpa kammena
translated: Ripens means: it does not ripen, having been obstructed by the attainment of a good destiny. But if, by means of a bad kamma,🔽

original: dāsiyā vā kammakāriyā vā kucchiyaṃ nibbattitvā upadhisampanno hoti, attabhāvasamiddhiyaṃ
analyzed: dāsiyāḥ vā kammakāriyāḥ vā kucchiyam nibbattitvā upadhi sampannaḥ hoti atta bhāva samiddhiyam
translated: “It does not come to fruition” means that it is prevented from doing so by the excellence of his destiny. But if he is reborn in the womb of a slave woman or of a worker woman, and he is endowed with the material support of a life of leisure, he remains in the excellence of his physical form.

original: tiṭṭhati. Athassa sāmikā tassa rūpasampattiṃ disvā “nāyaṃ kiliṭṭhakammassānucchaviko”ti🔽cittaṃ uppādetvā attano jātaputtaṃ viya bhaṇḍāgārikādiṭṭhānesu ṭhapetvā sampattiṃ
analyzed: tiṭṭhati atha assa sāmikā tassa rūpa sampattim disvā na ayam kiliṭṭha kammassa ānucchavikā ti  cittam uppādetvā attanaḥ jāta puttam viya bhaṇḍāgārika ādi ṭhānesu ṭhapetvā sampattim
translated: Then his masters, seeing his excellence of form, think, “This does not befit one of lowly deeds,” and they raise him to the status of a son, and they provide him with all the requisites and look after him.

original: yojetvā pariharanti. Evarūpassa kammaṃ upadhisampattipaṭibāḷhaṃ na vipaccati nāma.🔽Yo pana paṭhamakappikakālasadise sulabhasampannarasabhojane subhikkhakāle nibbattati,
analyzed: yojetvā pariharanti evarūpassa kammam upadhi sampatti paṭibāḷham na vipaccati nāma  yaḥ pana paṭhama kappika kāla sadise sulabha sampanna rasa bhojane subhikkha kāle nibbattati
translated: Thus his kamma is prevented from coming to fruition by the excellence of his material support.🔽But if he is reborn at a time when food is plentiful and easily obtained, as in the first period of the Buddha’s dispensation, then his evil kamma is prevented from coming to fruition by the excellence of the time.

original: tassa vijjamānampi pāpakammaṃ kālasampattipaṭibāḷhaṃ na vipaccati nāma. Yo pana sammāpayogaṃ
analyzed: tassa vijjamānam api pāpa kammam kāla sampatti paṭibāḷham na vipaccati nāma yaḥ pana sammā apayogam
translated: But if he is reborn at a time when food is scarce and difficult to obtain, as in the time of the famine of the “Thrice Cooked Rice,” then his evil kamma comes to fruition.

original: nissāya jīvati, upasaṅkamitabbayuttakāle upasaṅkamati, paṭikkamitabbayuttakāle paṭikkamati,🔽palāyitabbayuttakāle palāyati. Lañjadānayuttakāle lañjaṃ deti, corikayuttakāle corikaṃ
analyzed: nissāya jīvati upasaṅkamitabba yutta kāle upasaṅkamati paṭikkamitabba yutta kāle paṭikkamati  palāyitabba yutta kāle palāyati lañja dāna yutta kāle lañjam deti corika yutta kāle corikam
translated: He lives in dependence on him. When it is time to go to him, he goes to him. When it is time to go back from him, he goes back from him.

original: karoti, evarūpassa pāpakammaṃ payogasampattipaṭibāḷhaṃ na vipaccati nāma.
analyzed: karoti evarūpassa pāpa kammam payoga sampatti paṭibāḷham na vipaccati nāma
translated: When it is time to run away, he runs away. When it is time to give a signal, he gives a signal. When it is time to steal, he steals. Such evil action is called “not ripening because of the success of the means.”

original: Duggatibhave nibbattassa pana pāpakammaṃ gativipattiṃ āgamma vipaccati nāma. Yo pana🔽dāsiyā vā kammakāriyā vā kucchismiṃ nibbatto dubbaṇṇo hoti dussaṇṭhāno, “yakkho nu🔽kho manusso nu kho”ti vimatiṃ uppādeti. So sace puriso hoti, atha naṃ “nāyaṃ aññassa
analyzed: duggati bhave nibbattassa pana pāpa kammam gati vipattim āgamma vipaccati nāma yaḥ pana  dāsiyāḥ vā kammakāriyāḥ vā kucchismiṃ nibbattaḥ dubbaṇṇaḥ hoti dussaṇṭhānaḥ yakkhaḥ nu  kho manussaḥ nu khoti vimatim uppādeti so sace purisaḥ hoti atha nam na ayam aññassa
translated: But when it is produced in an existence in an unhappy destination, it is called “ripening because of the failure of the destination.”🔽But one who is born in the womb of a slave woman or of a worker is ugly and ill-formed, and he arouses doubt as to whether he is a yakkha or a human being.

original: kammassa anucchaviko”ti hatthiṃ vā rakkhāpenti assaṃ vā goṇe vā, tiṇakaṭṭhādīni vā
analyzed: kammassa anucchavikaḥ ti hatthim vā rakkhāpenti assam vā goṇe vā tiṇa kaṭṭha ādīni vā
translated: If he is a male, they say, “This is not suitable for anyone else’s work,” and they make him look after the elephants, horses, and cattle, or they make him fetch grass, wood, and water, or they make him take charge of the rubbish heap.

original: āharāpenti, kheḷasarakaṃ vā gaṇhāpenti. Sace itthī hoti, atha naṃ hatthiassādīnaṃ
analyzed: āharāpenti kheḷasarakam vā gaṇhāpenti sace itthī hoti atha nam hatthi assa ādīnam
translated: If he is a female, they make her look after the elephants, horses, and cattle,

original: bhattamāsādīni vā pacāpenti, kacavaraṃ vā chaḍḍāpenti, aññaṃ vā pana jigucchanīyakammaṃ
analyzed: bhatta māsa ādīni vā pacāpenti kaca varam vā chaḍḍāpenti aññam vā pana jigucchanīya kammaṃ
translated: or they have them cook rice or other food, or they have them throw away scraps, or they make them do some other kind of contemptible work,

original: kārenti. Evarūpassa pāpakammaṃ upadhivipattiṃ āgamma vipaccati nāma. Yo pana dubbhikkhakāle
analyzed: kārenti evarūpassa pāpa kammam upadhi vipattim āgamma vipaccati nāma yaḥ pana dubbhikkha kāle
translated: or they make them cook rice and curry, or they make them throw away scraps, or they make them do some other kind of disgusting work. Such a person’s evil actions are said to ripen through misfortune in respect of requisites.🔽But when someone is reborn at a time of famine,

original: vā parihīnasampattikāle vā antarakappe vā nibbattati, tassa pāpakammaṃ kālavipattiṃ🔽āgamma vipaccati nāma. Yo pana payogaṃ sampādetuṃ na jānāti, upasaṅkamitabbayuttakāle
analyzed: vā parihīna sampatti kāle vā antara kappe vā nibbattati tassa pāpa kammam kāla vipattim  āgamma vipaccati nāma yaḥ pana payogam sampādetum na jānāti upasaṅkamitabba yutta kāle
translated: or at a time of decline in the dispensation, or in an intermediate period between Buddhas, his evil actions are said to ripen through misfortune in respect of time.

original: upasaṅkamituṃ na jānāti…pe… corikayuttakāle corikaṃ kātuṃ na jānāti, tassa pāpakammaṃ🔽payogavipattiṃ āgamma vipaccati nāma.
analyzed: upasaṅkamitum na jānāti pe corika yutta kāle corikam kātum na jānāti tassa pāpa kammam  payoga vipattim āgamma vipaccati nāma
translated: But when someone does not know how to make an effort, does not know how to approach at a time when one should approach, … does not know how to steal at a time when one should steal, his evil actions are said to ripen through misfortune in respect of means.

original: Yo pana iṭṭhārammaṇānubhavanārahe kamme vijjamāneyeva gantvā duggatibhave nibbattati,
analyzed: yaḥ pana iṭṭha ārammaṇa anubhavana arahe kamme vijjamāne iya iva gantvā duggati bhave nibbattati
translated: But when someone, though he has done profitable deeds that deserve a happy rebirth, is reborn in an unhappy destination,

original: tassa taṃ kammaṃ gativipattipaṭibāḷhaṃ na vipaccati nāma. Yo pana puññānubhāvena
analyzed: tassa tam kammam gati vipatti paṭibāḷham na vipaccati nāma yaḥ pana puñña anubhāvena
translated: his actions are said not to ripen because they are thwarted by a more serious action.

original: rājarājamahāmattādīnaṃ gehe nibbattitvā kāṇo vā hoti kuṇī vā khañjo vā pakkhahato
analyzed: rāja rāja mahāmatta ādīnam gehe nibbattitvā kāṇaḥ vā hoti kuṇī vā khañjaḥ vā pakkha hataḥ
translated: or he is born in the house of a king, a king’s minister, and so on, but he is blind, or lame, or crippled, or paralysed on one side,

original: vā, tassa oparajjasenāpatibhaṇḍāgārikaṭṭhānādīni na anucchavikānīti na denti. Iccassa🔽taṃ puññaṃ upadhivipattipaṭibāḷhaṃ na vipaccati nāma. Yo pana dubbhikkhakāle vā parihīnasampattikāle
analyzed: vā tassa oparajja senāpati bhaṇḍāgārika ṭṭhāna ādīni na anucchavikāni iti na denti iccassa  tam puññam upadhi vipatti paṭibāḷham na vipaccati nāma yaḥ pana dubbhikkha kāle vā parihīna sampatti kāle
translated: or he is deformed, and they do not give him the rank of a viceroy, a general, a minister, and so on, because it is not suitable for him. So his🔽merit is said not to have ripened because it has been thwarted by failure in requisites. But when someone is born among human beings at a time of famine or at a time of failure of the fruits of the tree of life,

original: vā antarakappe vā manussesu nibbattati, tassa taṃ kalyāṇakammaṃ kālavipattipaṭibāḷhaṃ
analyzed: vā antara kappe vā manussesu nibbattati tassa tam kalyāṇa kammam kāla vipatti paṭibāḷham
translated: or in the interval between the two Buddhas Vipassī and Sikhī, his good kamma is said not to have ripened because it has been thwarted by failure of time.

original: na vipaccati nāma. Yo heṭṭhā vuttanayeneva payogaṃ sampādetuṃ na jānāti, tassa kalyāṇakammaṃ🔽payogavipattipaṭibāḷhaṃ na vipaccati nāma.
analyzed: na vipaccati nāma yaḥ heṭṭhā vutta nayena iva payogam sampādetum na jānāti tassa kalyāṇa kammam  payoga vipatti paṭibāḷham na vipaccati nāma
translated: But when someone does not know how to make the requisite effort in the way described above, his good kamma is said not to have ripened because it has been thwarted by failure in effort.

original: Kalyāṇakammena pana sugatibhave nibbattassa taṃ kammaṃ gatisampattiṃ āgamma vipaccati
analyzed: kalyāṇa kammena pana sugati bhave nibbattassa tat kammam gati sampattim āgamma vipaccati
translated: But when someone is reborn in a happy destiny through good kamma, that kamma is said to have ripened because of the excellence of his destiny.

original: nāma. Rājarājamahāmattādīnaṃ kule nibbattitvā upadhisampattiṃ pattassa attabhāvasamiddhiyaṃ
analyzed: nāma rāja rāja mahāmatta ādīnam kule nibbattitvā upadhi sampattim pattassa atta bhāva samiddhiyam
translated: When someone is born in the family of a king, a king’s minister, and so on, and he obtains the excellence of requisites, then his kamma is said to have ripened because of the excellence of his physical support.

original: ṭhitassa devanagare samussitaratanatoraṇasadisaṃ attabhāvaṃ disvā “imassa oparajjasenāpatibhaṇḍāgārikaṭṭhānādīni
analyzed: ṭhitassa devanagare samussita ratana toraṇa sadisam atta bhāvam disvā imassa oparajja senāpati bhaṇḍāgārika ṭṭhāna ādīni
translated: and as he stood there, he saw his own body like a jeweled gateway in the city of the gods.🔽

original: anucchavikānī”ti daharasseva sato tāni ṭhānantarāni denti, evarūpassa kalyāṇakammaṃ🔽upadhisampattiṃ āgamma vipaccati nāma. Yo paṭhamakappikesu vā sulabhannapānakāle
analyzed: anucchavikāni iti daharassa iva sataḥ tāni denti evarūpassa kalyāṇa kammaṃ  upadhi sampattim āgamma vipaccati nāma yaḥ paṭhamakappikesu vā
translated: and when he saw his own body like a city of the gods with a triumphal arch of the seven precious stones, he gave him the offices of viceroy, treasurer, general, and so on, which were suitable to him, while he was still young. So his good kamma ripens through the excellence of the object.🔽One who is reborn in the first period of the aeon or in the time of plenty when food and drink are easy to get, his good kamma ripens through the excellence of the time.

original: vā nibbattati, tassa kalyāṇakammaṃ kālasampattiṃ āgamma vipaccati nāma. Yo vuttanayeneva🔽payogaṃ sampādetuṃ jānāti, tassa kammaṃ payogasampattiṃ āgamma vipaccati nāma. Evaṃ🔽abhidhammapariyāyena soḷasa kammāni vibhattāni.
analyzed: vā nibbattati tassa kalyāṇa kammam kāla sampattim āgamma vipaccati nāma yaḥ vutta nayena iva  payogam sampādetum jānāti tassa kammam payoga sampattim āgamma vipaccati nāma evam  abhidhamma pariyāyena soḷasa kammāni vibhattāni
translated: One who knows how to make use of the opportunity in the way already described, his kamma ripens through the excellence of the opportunity.🔽So these are the sixteen kinds of kamma classed according to the three kinds of roots, etc.,🔽in the way stated in the Abhidhamma.

original: Aparānipi paṭisambhidāmaggapariyāyena dvādasa kammāni vibhattāni. Seyyathidaṃ – “ahosi
analyzed: aparāni pi paṭisambhidā magga pariyāyena dvādasa kammāni vibhattāni seyyathidam
translated: There are also twelve kinds of kamma classed according to the method of the Paṭisambhidā. They are as follows: there is kamma that has been done and has kamma-result; there is kamma that has been done but has not kamma-result; there is kamma that has had kamma-result and has had kamma-result;

original: kammaṃ ahosi kammavipāko, ahosi kammaṃ nāhosi kammavipāko, ahosi kammaṃ atthi kammavipāko,
analyzed: kammam ahosi kamma vipāko ahosi kammam na ahosi kamma vipāko ahosi kammam atthi kamma vipāko
translated: there is kamma that has had kamma-result and has not had kamma-result; there is kamma that has not had kamma-result and has not had kamma-result;

original: ahosi kammaṃ natthi kammavipāko, ahosi kammaṃ bhavissati kammavipāko, ahosi kammaṃ🔽na bhavissati kammavipāko, atthi kammaṃ atthi kammavipāko, atthi kammaṃ natthi kammavipāko,
analyzed: ahosi kammam natthi kamma vipāko ahosi kammam bhavissati kamma vipāko ahosi kammam  na bhavissati kamma vipākaḥ atthi kammam atthi kamma vipāko atthi kammam na tthi kamma vipāko
translated: There was action, there was no result of action; there was action, there will be result of action; there was action,🔽there was no result of action; there is action, there is result of action; there is action, there is no result of action;

original: atthi kammaṃ bhavissati kammavipāko, atthi kammaṃ na bhavissati kammavipāko, bhavissati
analyzed: atthi kammam bhavissati kamma vipākaḥ atthi kammam na bhavissati kamma vipākaḥ bhavissati
translated: there is action, there will be result of action; there is action, there will be no result of action; there will be

original: kammaṃ bhavissati kammavipāko, bhavissati kammaṃ na bhavissati kammavipāko”ti.
analyzed: kammam bhavissati kamma vipākaḥ bhavissati kammam na bhavissati kamma vipāko ti
translated: action, there will be result of action; there will be action, there will be no result of action.”

original: Tattha yaṃ kammaṃ atīte āyūhitaṃ atīteyeva vipākavāraṃ labhi, paṭisandhijanakaṃ paṭisandhiṃ
analyzed: tattha yam kammam atīte āyūhitam atīta iya iva vipāka vāram paṭisandhi janakam paṭisandhim
translated: Herein, action that was performed in the past and obtained a ripening in the past only, that produced rebirth-linking if it was productive of rebirth-linking,

original: janesi, rūpajanakaṃ rūpaṃ, taṃ ahosi kammaṃ ahosi kammavipākoti vuttaṃ. Yaṃ pana🔽vipākavāraṃ na labhi, paṭisandhijanakaṃ paṭisandhiṃ rūpajanakaṃ vā rūpaṃ janetuṃ
analyzed: janesi rūpa janakam rūpam tam ahosi kammam ahosi kamma vipāko ti vuttam yam pana  vipāka vāram na labhi paṭisandhi janakam paṭisandhim rūpa janakam vā rūpam janetum
translated: and that produced materiality if it was productive of materiality, is called “there was action, there was result of action.” But that which

original: nāsakkhi, taṃ ahosi kammaṃ nāhosi kammavipākoti vuttaṃ. Yaṃ pana atīte āyūhitaṃ etarahi
analyzed: na asakkhi tat ahosi kammam na ahosi kamma vipāko ti vuttam yam pana atīte āyūhitam etarahi
translated: did not obtain a ripening in the past, and that which was not able to produce rebirth-linking if it was productive of rebirth-linking, or to produce materiality if it was productive of materiality, is called “there was action, there was no result of action.” But that which was performed in the past and

original: laddhavipākavāraṃ paṭisandhijanakaṃ paṭisandhiṃ janetvā rūpajanakaṃ rūpaṃ janetvā
analyzed: laddha vipāka vāram paṭisandhi janakam paṭisandhim janetvā rūpa janakam rūpam janetvā
translated: The kind that has obtained a chance for fruition generates rebirth-linking, having generated rebirth-linking it generates materiality.

original: ṭhitaṃ, taṃ ahosi kammaṃ atthi kammavipākoti vuttaṃ. Yaṃ aladdhavipākavāraṃ paṭisandhijanakaṃ
analyzed: ṭhitam tam ahosi kammam atthi kamma vipāko ti vuttam yam aladdha vipāka vāram paṭisandhi janakam
translated: It is said that “there is kamma that has been and there is kamma-result that has been.” The kind that has not obtained a chance for fruition

original: vā paṭisandhiṃ rūpajanakaṃ vā rūpaṃ janetuṃ nāsakkhi, taṃ ahosi kammaṃ natthi kammavipākoti🔽vuttaṃ. Yaṃ pana atīte āyūhitaṃ anāgate vipākavāraṃ labhissati, paṭisandhijanakaṃ
analyzed: vā paṭisandhim rūpa janakam vā rūpam janetum na asakkhi tat ahosi kammam natthi kamma vipāko ti  vuttam yam pana atīte āyūhitam anāgate vipāka vāram labhissati paṭisandhi janakam
translated: is said to be “there is kamma that has been but there is no kamma-result that has been” if it has not been able to generate rebirth-linking that generates rebirth-linking or materiality that generates materiality.

original: paṭisandhiṃ rūpajanakaṃ rūpaṃ janetuṃ sakkhissati, taṃ ahosi kammaṃ bhavissati kammavipākoti🔽vuttaṃ. Yaṃ anāgate vipākavāraṃ na labhissati, paṭisandhijanakaṃ paṭisandhiṃ rūpajanakaṃ
analyzed: paṭisandhim rūpa janakam rūpam janetum sakkhissati tat ahosi kammam bhavissati kamma vipāko ti  vuttam yam anāgate vipāka vāram na labhissati paṭisandhi janakam paṭisandhim rūpa janakam
translated: But that which was stored up in the past and will obtain a chance for fruition in the future and will be able to generate rebirth-linking that generates rebirth-linking and materiality that generates materiality is said to be “there is kamma that has been and there will be kamma-result that has been.”

original: vā rūpaṃ janetuṃ na sakkhissati, taṃ ahosi kammaṃ na bhavissati kammavipākoti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: vā rūpam janetum na sakkhissati tat ahosi kammam na bhavissati kamma vipāko ti vuttam
translated: That which will not obtain a chance for fruition in the future and will not be able to generate rebirth-linking that generates rebirth-linking or materiality that generates materiality is said to be “there is kamma that has been but there will be no kamma-result that has been.”

original: Yaṃ pana etarahi āyūhitaṃ etarahiyeva vipākavāraṃ labhati, taṃ atthi kammaṃ atthi
analyzed: yam pana etarahi āyūhitam vipāka vāram labhati tam atthi kammam atthi
translated: But that which is stored up in the present and obtains a chance for fruition in the present is said to be “there is kamma that is and there is kamma-result that is.”

original: kammavipākoti vuttaṃ. Yaṃ pana etarahi vipākavāraṃ na labhati, taṃ atthi kammaṃ natthi🔽kammavipākoti vuttaṃ. Yaṃ pana etarahi āyūhitaṃ anāgate vipākavāraṃ labhissati, paṭisandhijanakaṃ
analyzed: kamma vipākaḥ ti vuttam yam pana etarahi vipāka vāram na labhati tam atthi kammam natthi  kamma vipākaḥ ti vuttam yam pana etarahi āyūhitam anāgate vipāka vāram labhissati paṭisandhi janakam
translated: is called “there is kamma, there is kamma-result.” But that which does not get a chance to produce its result in the present existence is called “there is kamma, there is no kamma-result.”

original: paṭisandhiṃ rūpajanakaṃ rūpaṃ janetuṃ sakkhissati, taṃ atthi kammaṃ bhavissati kammavipākoti🔽vuttaṃ. Yaṃ pana vipākavāraṃ na labhissati, paṭisandhijanakaṃ paṭisandhiṃ rūpajanakaṃ
analyzed: paṭisandhim rūpa janakam rūpam janetum sakkhissati tat atthi kammam bhavissati kamma vipāko ti  vuttam yam pana vipāka vāram na labhissati paṭisandhi janakam paṭisandhim rūpa janakam
translated: But that which is stored up now and will get a chance to produce its result in the future, which will produce rebirth-linking and will be able to produce materiality that has rebirth-linking as its material cause, is called “there will be kamma, there will be kamma-result.”

original: vā rūpaṃ janetuṃ sakkhissati, taṃ atthi kammaṃ na bhavissati kammavipākoti vuttaṃ.🔽Yaṃ panānāgate āyūhissati, anāgateyeva vipākavāraṃ labhissati, paṭisandhijanakaṃ
analyzed: vā rūpam janetum sakkhissati tat atthi kammam na bhavissati kamma vipāko ti vuttam  yam pana anāgate āyūhissati anāgate iya iva vipāka vāram labhissati paṭisandhi janakam
translated: But that which will not get a chance to produce its result in the future, which will not produce rebirth-linking or be able to produce materiality that has rebirth-linking as its material cause, is called “there will be kamma, there will be no kamma-result.”

original: paṭisandhiṃ rūpajanakaṃ vā rūpaṃ janessati, taṃ bhavissati kammaṃ bhavissati kammavipākoti
analyzed: paṭisandhim rūpa janakam vā rūpam janessati tat bhavissati kammam bhavissati kamma vipāko ti
translated: But that which will be stored up in the future and will get a chance to produce its result in the future, which will produce rebirth-linking and be able to produce materiality that has rebirth-linking as its material cause, is called “there will be kamma, there will be kamma-result.”

original: vuttaṃ. Yaṃ pana vipākavāraṃ na labhissati, paṭisandhijanakaṃ paṭisandhiṃ rūpajanakaṃ
analyzed: vuttam yam pana vipāka vāram na labhissati paṭisandhi janakam paṭisandhim rūpa janakam
translated: But what does not get a chance to do so in the case of the resultant period is to generate rebirth-linking and materiality.

original: vā rūpaṃ janetuṃ na sakkhissati, taṃ bhavissati kammaṃ na bhavissati kammavipākoti
analyzed: vā rūpam janetum na sakkhissati tat bhavissati kammam na bhavissati kamma vipāko ti
translated: and so on. But that which will not get a turn to produce result in the next becoming is said to be kamma that will be, not kamma result.

original: vuttaṃ. Evaṃ paṭisambhidāmaggapariyāyena dvādasa kammāni vibhattāni.🔽Iti imāni ceva dvādasa abhidhammapariyāyena vibhattāni ca soḷasa kammāni attano ṭhānā
analyzed: vuttam evam paṭisambhidā magga pariyāyena dvādasa kammāni vibhattāni  iti imāni ca iva dvādasa abhidhamma pariyāyena vibhattāni ca soḷasa kammāni attanaḥ ṭhānā
translated: So they are analysed into twelve kinds by the method of the Paṭisambhidā.

original: osakkitvā suttantikapariyāyena vuttāni ekādasa kammāniyeva bhavanti. Tānipi tato
analyzed: osakkitvā suttantika pariyāyena vuttāni ekādasa bhavanti tāni pi tatas
translated: So these twelve kinds analysed by the method of the Abhidhamma and the sixteen kinds analysed by the method of the Paṭisambhidā come to eleven kinds when they are condensed by the method of the Suttas and reduced to the place of their primary meaning.

original: osakkitvā tīṇiyeva kammāni honti diṭṭhadhammavedanīyaṃ, upapajjavedanīyaṃ, aparapariyāyavedanīyanti.🔽Tesaṃ saṅkamanaṃ natthi, yathāṭhāneyeva tiṭṭhanti. Yadi hi diṭṭhadhammavedanīyaṃ
analyzed: osakkitvā tīṇi yeva kammāni honti diṭṭhadhamma vedanīyam upapajja vedanīyam apara pariyāya vedanīyanti  tesam saṅkamanam natthi yathāṭhāneya iva tiṭṭhanti yadi hi diṭṭha dhamma vedanīyam
translated: And these eleven kinds come to three kinds when they are condensed by the method of the Abhidhamma and reduced to the place of their primary meaning. They are kamma to be experienced here and now, kamma to be experienced after rebirth, and kamma to be experienced in some subsequent becoming.

original: kammaṃ upapajjavedanīyaṃ vā aparapariyāyavedanīyaṃ vā bhaveyya, “diṭṭhe vā dhamme”ti
analyzed: kammam upapajja vedanīyam vā apara pariyāya vedanīyam vā bhaveyya diṭṭhe vā dhamme ti
translated: They do not migrate. They remain in their own place. For if kamma to be experienced here and now were to become kamma to be experienced after rebirth or kamma to be experienced in some subsequent becoming, then the words “here and now” in the passage “kamma to be experienced here and now” would be contradicted.

original: satthā na vadeyya. Sacepi upapajjavedanīyaṃ diṭṭhadhammavedanīyaṃ vā aparapariyāyavedanīyaṃ🔽vā bhaveyya, “upapajja vā”ti satthā na vadeyya. Athāpi aparapariyāyavedanīyaṃ diṭṭhadhammavedanīyaṃ
analyzed: satthā na vadeyya sace pi upapajja vedanīyam diṭṭhadhamma vedanīyam vā apara pariyāya vedanīyam  vā bhaveyya upapajja vā ati satthā na vadeyya atha api apara pariyāya vedanīyam diṭṭhadhamma vedanīyam
translated: the Teacher would not have said “reborn”. If it were to be experienced in the next existence or in some subsequent existence, the Teacher would not have said “reborn”. If it were to be experienced in the next existence or in some subsequent existence, the Teacher would not have said “in this very life”.🔽

original: vā upapajjavedanīyaṃ vā bhaveyya, “apare vā pariyāye”ti satthā na vadeyya.
analyzed: vā upapajja vedanīyam vā bhaveyya apare vā pariyāya iti satthā na vadeyya
translated: The Teacher would not have said “if it were to ripen in the next rebirth.” If it were to ripen in the present life or in some future rebirth, the Teacher would not have said “if it were to ripen in the next rebirth.” If it were to ripen in some future rebirth, in the present life, or in the next rebirth, the Teacher would not have said “in some future rebirth.”

original: Sukkapakkhepi imināva nayena attho veditabbo. Ettha pana lobhe vigateti lobhe apagate
analyzed: sukkapakkhe pi iminā ava nayena atthaḥ veditabbo ettha pana lobhe vigate iti lobhe apagate
translated: The meaning should be understood in the same way in the case of the bright side. Herein, with the disappearance of greed means with the disappearance of greed, with its cessation, with its not being there.

original: niruddhe. Tālavatthukatanti tālavatthu viya kataṃ, matthakacchinnatālo viya puna
analyzed: niruddhe tāla vatthu katanti tāla vatthu viya katam matthaka chinna tālaḥ viya punar
translated: Made like a palm stump means made like a palm stump whose crown has been cut off, made incapable of sprouting again.

original: aviruḷhisabhāvaṃ katanti attho. Anabhāvaṃ katanti anuabhāvaṃ kataṃ, yathā puna nuppajjati,🔽evaṃ katanti attho. Evassūti evaṃ bhaveyyuṃ. Evameva khoti ettha bījāni viya kusalākusalaṃ
analyzed: a viruḷhi sabhāvam katanti atthaḥ anabhāvam katanti anu abhāvam katam yathā puna nuppajjati  evam katanti attho evassu ti evam bhaveyyuṃ evam eva kho ti ettha bījāni viya kusala akusalam
translated: Made non-existent means made non-existent, made incapable of arising again.🔽So would it be means it would be just so.

original: kammaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ, tāni agginā ḍahanapuriso viya yogāvacaro, aggi viya maggañāṇaṃ,
analyzed: kammam daṭṭhabbam tāni agginā ḍahana puriso viya yogāvacaraḥ aggi viya magga ñāṇam
translated: Just as means here the profitable and unprofitable should be regarded as the seeds, the meditator as the man who burns them with fire, the path knowledge as the fire,

original: aggiṃ datvā bījānaṃ ḍahanakālo viya maggañāṇena kilesānaṃ daḍḍhakālo, masikatakālo
analyzed: aggim da tvā bījānam ḍahana kālaḥ viya magga ñāṇena kilesānam daḍḍha kālaḥ masikata kālo
translated: The time of the burning of the defilements by the path is like the time of burning the seeds by the fire.

original: viya pañcannaṃ khandhānaṃ chinnamūlake katvā ṭhapitakālo, mahāvāte opunitvā nadiyā🔽vā pavāhetvā appavattikatakālo viya upādinnakasantānassa nirodhena chinnamūlakānaṃ
analyzed: viya pañcannam khandhānam chinna mūlake katvā ṭhapita kālaḥ mahā vāte opunitvā nadiyā  vā pavāhetvā appavatti kata kālaḥ viya upādinnaka santānassa nirodhena chinna mūlakānam
translated: The time of the placing of the five aggregates with their roots cut off is like the time of the cow’s horn.🔽The time of the non-occurrence of the five aggregates with their roots cut off by the cessation of the continuity of the aggregates that have been clung to, is like the time of the non-occurrence of the cow’s horn after it has been cut off and thrown into a river.

original: pañcannaṃ khandhānaṃ appaṭisandhikabhāvena nirujjhitvā puna bhavasmiṃ paṭisandhiṃ🔽aggahitakālo veditabbo.
analyzed: pañcannam khandhānam appaṭisandhika bhāvena nirujjhitvā puna bhavasmin paṭisandhim  aggahita kālaḥ veditabbaḥ
translated: The time of the non-grasping of rebirth-linking in a new becoming is like the time of the non-occurrence of the cow’s horn after it has been cut off and thrown into a river.

original: Mohajañcāpaviddasūti mohajañcāpi aviddasu. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – yaṃ so avidū andhabālo
analyzed: moha jam ca apaviddasu iti moha jam ca api aviddasu idam vuttam hoti yam saḥ avidū andha bālo
translated: “And of the deed born of delusion, too, he has no store”: of the deed born of delusion, too, he has no store. This is the meaning: Whatever deed the fool, blind with delusion,

original: lobhajañca dosajañca mohajañcāti kammaṃ karoti, evaṃ karontena yaṃ tena pakataṃ kammaṃ
analyzed: lobha jañca dosa jañca moha jañca ati kammam karoti evam karontena yam tena pakatam kammam
translated: does born of greed, born of hate, born of delusion, whatever deed he does, whether it is small or great,

original: appaṃ vā yadi vā bahuṃ. Idheva taṃ vedaniyanti taṃ kammaṃ tena bālena idha sake attabhāveyeva
analyzed: appam vā yadi vā bahum idhā iva tam tam kammam tena bālena sake
translated: here itself he experiences the result of that deed.

original: vedanīyaṃ, tasseva taṃ attabhāve vipaccatīti attho. Vatthuṃ aññaṃ na vijjatīti tassa
analyzed: vedanīyam tassa iva tam atta bhāve vipaccati iti atthaḥ vatthum aññam na vijjati iti tassa
translated: what is to be felt, it ripens in that same individual existence, is the meaning. There is no other basis: there is no other individual existence.

original: kammassa vipaccanatthāya aññaṃ vatthu natthi. Na hi aññena kataṃ kammaṃ aññassa attabhāve
analyzed: kammassa vipaccana tthāya aññam vatthu natthi na hi aññena katam kammam aññassa atta bhāve
translated: and it is that same selfhood in which it ripens. The meaning is that it ripens in that same selfhood. “No other basis is found”: there is no other basis for the ripening of that kamma. For kamma done by one person does not ripen in the selfhood of another.

original: vipaccati. Tasmā lobhañca dosañca, mohajañcāpi viddasūti tasmā yo vidū medhāvī paṇḍito
analyzed: vipaccati tasmai lobhañca dosañca moha jañca api tasmai yaḥ medhāvī paṇḍitaḥ
translated: Therefore, “He who has understood what springs from greed, from hate, and from delusion too,🔽He who is wise, the man of vision, does not do such kamma.

original: taṃ lobhajādibhedaṃ kammaṃ na karoti, so vijjaṃ uppādayaṃ bhikkhu, sabbā duggatiyo🔽jahe, arahattamaggavijjaṃ uppādetvā taṃ vā pana vijjaṃ uppādento sabbā duggatiyo
analyzed: tam lobha ja ādi bhedam kammam na karoti saḥ vijjam uppādayan bhikkhu sabbāḥ duggatiyaḥ  jahe arahatta magga vijjam uppādetvā tam vā pana vijjam uppādento sabbāḥ duggatiyaḥ
translated: The monk who generates the knowledge of the path to arahatship abandons all bad destinations.

original: jahati. Desanāsīsamevetaṃ, sugatiyopi pana so khīṇāsavo jahatiyeva. Yampi cetaṃ “tasmā
analyzed: jahati pana saḥ khīṇa āsavaḥ yam pi tasmai
translated: Or, generating that knowledge, he abandons all bad destinations. This is the climax of the teaching. Even though he is still subject to rebirth in good destinations, the one whose cankers are destroyed abandons all bad destinations.

original: lobhañca dosañcā”ti vuttaṃ, etthāpi lobhadosasīsena lobhajañca dosajañca kammameva
analyzed: lobham ca dosam ca ati vuttam ettha api lobha dosa sīsena lobha jañca dosa jañca kammam eva
translated: And although it is said here, “Therefore, greed and hate,” it should be understood that what is meant by “greed” and “hate” is kamma born of greed and hate.

original: niddiṭṭhanti veditabbaṃ. Evaṃ suttantesupi gāthāyapi vaṭṭavivaṭṭameva kathitanti.
analyzed: niddiṭṭhanti veditabbam evam suttantesu pi vaṭṭa vivaṭṭam eva kathitan ti
translated: Thus in the suttas and in the stanzas, only the round and the transcending of the round are taught.

original: 5. Hatthakasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: hatthaka sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: 5. The explanation of the “Discourse with Hatthaka”

analyzed: sayam patita paṇṇa santhare atha ati evam gunnam gamana maggam ujum mahāpatham nissāya

analyzed: siṃsa pāvane sayam patita paṇṇāni saṅkaḍḍhitvā kata santhare sugata mahā cīvaram pattharitvā

original: avoca. Kasmā pana sammāsambuddho taṃ ṭhānaṃ gantvā nisinno, kasmā rājakumāro tattha🔽gatoti? Sammāsambuddho tāva aṭṭhuppattikāya dhammadesanāya samuṭṭhānaṃ disvā tattha
analyzed: avoca kasmā pana sammāsambuddhaḥ tam ṭhānam gantvā nisinnaḥ kasmā rāja kumāraḥ tattha  gataḥ ti sammāsambuddho tāva aṭṭhuppattikāya dhamma desanāya samuṭṭhānam disvā tattha
translated: But why did the Perfectly Awakened One go to that place and sit down? Why did the prince go there?🔽The Perfectly Awakened One, having seen the origin of the teaching of the eight causes, sat down there. The prince, having gotten up early in the morning, surrounded by five hundred lay followers, went to the Buddha’s dwelling place

original: nisinno, rājakumāropi pātova uṭṭhāya pañcahi upāsakasatehi parivuto buddhupaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: nisinnaḥ rāja kumāraḥ api pātova uṭṭhāya pañcahi upāsaka satehi parivutaḥ buddha upaṭṭhānam
