original: gacchanto mahāmaggā okkamma gopathaṃ gahetvā “buddhānaṃ pūjanatthāya missakamālaṃ
analyzed: gacchantaḥ mahā maggāḥ okkamma gopatham gahetvā buddhānam pūjana tthāya missaka mālam
translated: Going, he left the main road, took a cow-path, and said: “For the purpose of worshipping the Buddhas I have brought a garland of mixed flowers

original: ocinissāmī”ti gacchanto satthāraṃ disvā upasaṅkamitvā vanditvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi,
analyzed: ocinissāmi iti gacchantaḥ satthāram disvā upasaṅkamitvā vanditvā ekamantam nisīdi
translated: As he was going, he left the main road and took a by-road, thinking, “I will pick up a handful of flowers from the roadside and offer them to the Buddhas.” As he was going along, he saw the Teacher, approached him, paid obeisance to him, sat down,

original: evaṃ so tattha gatoti. Sukhamasayitthāti sukhaṃ sayittha.🔽Antaraṭṭhakoti māghaphagguṇānaṃ antare aṭṭhadivasaparimāṇo kālo. Māghassa hi avasāne
analyzed: evam saḥ tattha gataḥ iti sukham asayittha ati sukham sayittha  antaraṭṭhakaḥ ti māgha phagguṇānaṃ antare aṭṭha divasa parimāṇaḥ kālaḥ māghassa hi avasāne
translated: and went there for that purpose. He slept in comfort: he slept happily.

original: cattāro divasā, phagguṇassa ādimhi cattāroti ayaṃ “antaraṭṭhako”ti vuccati. Himapātasamayoti
analyzed: cattāraḥ divasā phagguṇassa ādimhi cattāro ti ayam antaraṭṭhakaḥ ti vuccati himapāta samayaḥ ti
translated: The interval: the period of eight days between Māgha and Phālguna. For the last four days of Māgha and the first four days of Phālguna are called “the interval.” The time of the fall of frost:

original: himassa patanasamayo. Kharāti pharusā kakkhaḷā vā. Gokaṇṭakahatāti navavuṭṭhe deve
analyzed: himassa patana samayaḥ kharāti pharusā kakkhaḷā vā gokaṇṭaka hatā ati navavuṭṭhe deve
translated: the time when frost falls. Rough: hard, or harsh. Trampled by the hoofs of cattle: when it rains in the early rains,

original: gāvīnaṃ akkantakkantaṭṭhāne khurantarehi kaddamo uggantvā tiṭṭhati, so vātātapena
analyzed: gāvīnam akkanta kkanta ṭṭhāne khura antarehi kaddamaḥ uggantvā tiṭṭhati saḥ vāta ātapena
translated: the mud that rises between the hooves of cattle when they walk about is left lying on the ground. When it dries in the wind and sun,

original: sukkho kakacadantasadiso hoti dukkhasamphasso. Taṃ sandhāyāha – “gokaṇṭakahatā bhūmī”ti.
analyzed: sukkhaḥ ka kaca danta sadisaḥ hoti dukkha samphassaḥ tam sandhāya āha gokaṇṭaka hatā bhūmi iti
translated: it becomes as hard as the edge of a ploughshare and is unpleasant to the touch. Referring to this, it is said, “the ground trampled by the hoofs of cattle.”

original: Gunnaṃ khurantarehi chinnātipi attho. Verambho vāto vāyatīti catūhi disāhi vāyanto
analyzed: gunnam khura antarehi attho verambhaḥ vātaḥ vāyati iti catūhi disāhi
translated: The wind blows, the wind blows from the four directions.

original: vāto vāyati. Ekāya disāya vā dvīhi vā disāhi tīhi vā disāhi vāyanto vāto verambhoti na vuccati.
analyzed: vātaḥ vāyati ekāya disāya vā dvīhi vā disāhi tīhi vā disāhi vāyantaḥ vātaḥ verambhā iti na vuccati
translated: The wind blowing from one direction or two directions or three directions is not called “verambha.”

original: Tena hi rājakumārāti idaṃ satthā “ayaṃ rājakumāro lokasmiṃ neva sukhavāsino, na dukkhavāsino
analyzed: tena hi rāja kumārā ati idam satthā ayam rāja kumāraḥ lokasmiṃ na iva sukha vāsinaḥ na dukkha vāsinaḥ
translated: “Then, Prince,” the Teacher said, “this prince does not know who in the world lives happily and who lives unhappily.🔽I will make him know.” So saying, he extended the teaching.

original: jānāti, jānāpessāmi na”nti upari desanaṃ vaḍḍhento āha. Tattha yathā te khameyyāti
analyzed: jānāti jānāpessāmi nanti upari desanam vaḍḍhentaḥ āha tattha yathā te khameyya iti
translated: Herein, as to “as it may please you”:

original: yathā tuyhaṃ rucceyya. Idhassāti imasmiṃ loke assa. Gonakatthatoti caturaṅgulādhikalomena🔽kāḷakojavena atthato. Paṭikatthatoti uṇṇāmayena setattharaṇena atthato. Paṭalikatthatoti
analyzed: yathā tuyham rucceyya idhassa ati imasmin loke catur aṅgula adhika lomena  kāḷakojavena atthataḥ paṭikatthato ti uṇṇa āmayena setattharaṇena atthataḥ paṭalikatthato ti
translated: as it may be agreeable to you. As to “in this world”: in this world. As to “in the cowpen”:🔽in the cowpen with a black bull. As to “in the bed”: in the bed with a white spread. As to “in the bedspread”:

original: ghanapupphena uṇṇāmayaattharaṇena atthato. Kadalimigapavarapaccattharaṇoti kadalimigacammamayena
analyzed: ghana pupphena uṇṇā maya attharaṇena atthatas kadali miga pavara paccattharaṇā ti kadali miga camma mayena
translated: in the bed with a thick-flowered white spread. As to “in the bedspread of choice antelope hide”:🔽in the bed with a bedspread of choice antelope hide.

original: uttamapaccattharaṇena atthato. Taṃ kira paccattharaṇaṃ setavatthassa upari kadalimigacammaṃ🔽attharitvā sibbitvā karonti. Sauttaracchadoti saha uttaracchadena, upari baddhena
analyzed: uttama paccattharaṇena atthataḥ tam kira paccattharaṇam seta vatthassa upari kadali miga cammam  attharitvā sibbitvā karonti sauttaracchadā iti saha uttaracchadena upari baddhena
translated: With the best spread means with the best spread of all. It seems that this spread was made by spreading out a cloth of white cloth, then a cloth of kadali-deer hide,🔽and then a cloth of antelope hide on top of that. With a canopy means with a canopy on top.

original: rattavitānena saddhinti attho. Ubhatolohitakūpadhānoti sīsūpadhānañca pādūpadhānañcāti🔽pallaṅkassa ubhato ṭhapitalohitakūpadhāno. Pajāpatiyoti bhariyāyo. Manāpena paccupaṭṭhitā
analyzed: ratta vitānena saddhinti attho sīsu upadhānam ca pādu upadhānam ca ati  pallaṅkassa ubhatas ṭhapita lohita kūpa dhāno bhariyāyaḥ manāpena paccupaṭṭhitā
translated: The meaning is: together with a red canopy on top. With red cushions on both sides means with red cushions placed on both sides of the couch.

original: assūti manāpena upaṭṭhānavidhānena paccupaṭṭhitā bhaveyyuṃ.🔽Kāyikāti pañcadvārakāyaṃ khobhayamānā. Cetasikāti manodvāraṃ khobhayamānā. So rāgo
analyzed: manāpena upaṭṭhāna vidhānena paccupaṭṭhitāḥ bhaveyyuṃ  kāyikā ati pañca dvāra kāyam khobhayamānā cetasikā ati manaḥ dvāram khobhayamānā saḥ rāgaḥ
translated: Pajāpati means wives. Would serve me with the best means would serve me with the best service.

original: tathāgatassa pahīnoti tathārūpo rāgo tathāgatassa pahīnoti attho. Yo pana tassa rāgo,
analyzed: tathāgatassa pahīnoti tathārūpaḥ rāgo tathāgatassa pahīnaḥ ti atthaḥ yaḥ pana tassa rāgo
translated: With their own hands means with their own hands. With physical means with physical agitation in the five doors. With mental means with mental agitation in the mind door. That lust … has been abandoned by the Tathāgata means that such lust has been abandoned by the Tathāgata.

original: na so tathāgatassa pahīno nāma. Dosamohesupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: na saḥ tathāgatassa pahīnaḥ nāma dosa mohesu pi esā iva nayo
translated: But the lust that is in him has not been abandoned by the Tathāgata. The same method applies to hatred and delusion.

original: Brāhmaṇoti bāhitapāpo khīṇāsavabrāhmaṇo. Parinibbutoti kilesaparinibbānena parinibbuto.
analyzed: brāhmaṇaḥ iti bāhita pāpaḥ khīṇāsava brāhmaṇaḥ parinibbuto ti kilesa parinibbānena parinibbutaḥ
translated: “A brahmin”: a brahmin who has expelled evil, who is one whose cankers are destroyed. “Extinguished”: extinguished by the extinction of defilements.

original: Na limpati kāmesūti vatthukāmesu ca kilesakāmesu ca taṇhādiṭṭhilepehi na limpati.
analyzed: na limpati kāmesu iti vatthu kāmesu ca kilesa kāmesu ca taṇhā diṭṭhi lepehi na limpati
translated: “Does not stick in sensual desires”: he does not stick in sensual desires as objects or in sensual desires as defilements through the sticking of craving and views.

original: Sītibhūtoti abbhantare tāpanakilesānaṃ abhāvena sītibhūto. Nirūpadhīti kilesūpadhīnaṃ🔽abhāvena nirūpadhi. Sabbā āsattiyo chetvāti āsattiyo vuccanti taṇhāyo, tā sabbāpi
analyzed: sīti bhūtaḥ iti abbhantare tāpana kilesānam abhāvena sīti bhūtaḥ kilesa upadhīnam  abhāvena nirūpadhi sabbāḥ āsattiyaḥ chetvā ati āsattiyaḥ vuccanti taṇhāyaḥ tā sabbā api
translated: “Is cooled”: he is cooled by the absence of the burning defilements within. “Without grasping”: without grasping due to the absence of the grasping of defilements.

original: rūpādīsu ārammaṇesu āsattavisattā āsattiyo chinditvā. Vineyya hadaye daranti hadayanissitaṃ
analyzed: rūpa ādīsu ārammaṇesu āsatta visattāḥ āsattiyaḥ chinditvā vineyya hadaye daranti hadaya nissitam
translated: “Having cut off all bonds”: the bonds are called cravings; all of them are bonds because of their attachment and clinging to objects such as form, etc.🔽Having cut them off, having destroyed the fever that is based on the heart,🔽having brought it to rest,

original: darathaṃ vinayitvā vūpasametvā. Santiṃ pappuyya cetasoti cittassa kilesanibbānaṃ🔽pāpuṇitvā. Karaṇavacanaṃ vā etaṃ “sabbacetaso samannāharitvā”tiādīsu viya, cetasā
analyzed: daratham vinayitvā vūpasametvā santim pappuyya cetasaḥ ti cittassa kilesa nibbānam  pāpuṇitvā karaṇa vacanam vai etam sabba cetasaḥ samannāharitvā ati ādīsu viya cetasā
translated: having attained the peace of mind,

original: nibbānaṃ pāpuṇitvāti attho.
analyzed: nibbānam pāpuṇitvā ti atthaḥ
translated: the extinction of defilements in the mind. Or this is a gerundive expression, like “having collected the mind in every way” , etc.; the meaning is: having attained the extinction of the mind.

original: 6. Devadūtasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: deva dūta sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Discourse on the Divine Messengers

original: 36. Chaṭṭhe devadūtānīti devadūtā. Ayaṃ panettha vacanattho – devoti maccu, tassa
analyzed: chaṭṭhe deva dūtāni iti deva dūtāḥ ayam pana ittha vacana atthaḥ devaḥ ti maccu tassa
translated: In the sixth, “divine messengers”: divine messengers . The word-meaning here is this: “God” is death,

original: dūtāti devadūtā. Jiṇṇabyādhimatā hi saṃvegajananaṭṭhena “idāni te maccusamīpaṃ gantabba”nti
analyzed: dūta ati deva dūtāḥ jiṇṇa byādhimatā hi saṃvega janana ṭṭhena idāni te maccu samīpam gantabbanti
translated: his “messengers” are divine messengers . For the aged and the sick, by arousing urgency, as if they were to say, “Now you must go into the presence of death,”

original: codenti viya, tasmā devadūtāti vuccanti. Devā viya dūtātipi devadūtā. Yathā hi alaṅkatapaṭiyattāya
analyzed: codenti tasmā deva dūtā ati vuccanti devāḥ deva dūtāḥ yathā hi alaṅkata paṭiyattāya
translated: they admonish. Therefore they are called “divine messengers.” They are also called “divine messengers” because they are messengers like gods. For just as when a god, adorned and attired,

original: devatāya ākāse ṭhatvā “tvaṃ asukadivase marissasī”ti vutte tassā vacanaṃ saddhātabbaṃ🔽hoti; evamevaṃ jiṇṇabyādhimatāpi dissamānā “tvampi evaṃdhammo”ti codenti viya, tesañca🔽taṃ vacanaṃ anaññathābhāvitāya devatāya byākaraṇasadisameva hotīti devā viya dūtāti
analyzed: devatāya ākāse ṭhatvā tvam asuka divase marissasi iti vutte tassāḥ vacanam saddhātabbam  hoti evam evam jiṇṇa byādhimatā api dissamānā tvam pi evaṃdhammā ti codenti viya tesam ca  tam vacanam anaññathābhāvitāya devatāya byākaraṇa sadisam eva hoti iti devāḥ viya dūtāti
translated: stands in the sky and says, “On such and such a day you will die,” then her word must be believed,

original: devadūtā. Visuddhidevānaṃ dūtātipi devadūtā. Sabbabodhisattā hi jiṇṇabyādhimatapabbajite
analyzed: deva dūtāḥ visuddhi devānam deva dūtā sabba bodhisattāḥ hi jiṇṇa byādhi mata pabbajite
translated: so too, the aged and the sick, when seen, admonish as if they were to say, “You are just the same.” And because their word is not otherwise, it is just like the god’s declaration. Therefore they are called “divine messengers” because they are messengers like gods. They are also called “divine messengers” because they are messengers of the gods of purity. For all bodhisattas, when they see the aged, the sick, and those gone forth,

original: disvāva saṃvegaṃ āpajjitvā nikkhamma pabbajiṃsu. Evaṃ visuddhidevānaṃ dūtātipi devadūtā.
analyzed: disvā ava saṃvegam āpajjitvā nikkhamma pabbajiṃsu evam visuddhi devānam dūtā atipi deva dūtā
translated: and after seeing them they were filled with remorse and went forth from home into homelessness. So they are messengers of the gods in the sense that they are gods who have become purified.

original: Idha pana liṅgavipallāsena “devadūtānī”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: idha pana liṅga vipallāsena deva dūtāni iti vuttam
translated: But here the word is used in the sense of “female messengers of the gods” with a change of gender.

original: Kāyena duccaritantiādi kasmā āraddhaṃ? Devadūtānuyuñjanaṭṭhānupakkamakammadassanatthaṃ.
analyzed: kāyena duccarita nti ādi kasmai āraddham deva dūta anuyuñjana ṭṭhānu pakkama kamma dassana attham
translated: Why is it begun with “Misconduct in deed”? In order to show the kind of action that is the cause for the messengers of the gods to be sent.

original: Iminā hi kammena ayaṃ satto niraye nibbattati, atha naṃ tattha yamo rājā devadūte
analyzed: iminā hi kammena ayam satto niraye nibbattati atha nam tattha yamaḥ rājā deva dūte
translated: For by this kind of action a being is reborn in hell, and then King Yama questions him through the messengers of the gods.

original: samanuyuñjati. Tattha kāyena duccaritaṃ caratīti kāyadvārena tividhaṃ duccaritaṃ🔽carati. Vācāyāti vacīdvārena catubbidhaṃ duccaritaṃ carati. Manasāti manodvārena
analyzed: samanuyuñjati kāyena duccaritam carati iti kāya dvārena tividham duccaritam  carati vācāya ati vacī dvārena catubbidham duccaritam carati manasā ati manaḥ dvārena
translated: Herein, “Misconduct in deed” is the doing of the three kinds of misconduct by body through the door of the body.🔽“Misconduct in speech” is the doing of the four kinds of misconduct by speech through the door of speech.

original: tividhaṃ duccaritaṃ carati.🔽Tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, nirayapālāti ettha ekacce therā “nirayapālā nāma natthi, yantarūpaṃ
analyzed: tividham duccaritam carati  tam enam bhikkhave niraya pālā ati ettha ekacce therāḥ niraya pālāḥ nāma natthi
translated: “Misconduct in mind” is the doing of the three kinds of misconduct by mind through the door of the mind.🔽Herein, “Then, bhikkhus, the wardens of hell” : some elders say that there are no wardens of hell, that it is only kamma that acts as the cause like a substitute for them.

original: viya kammameva kāraṇaṃ kāretī”ti vadanti. Taṃ “atthi niraye nirayapālāti, āmantā.
analyzed: viya kammam eva kāraṇam kāreti iti vadanti tam atthi niraye niraya pālā ati āmantā
translated: But it is said, “There are wardens of hell, Ānanda.

original: Atthi ca kāraṇikā”tiādinā nayena abhidhamme paṭisedhitameva. Yathā hi manussaloke
analyzed: atthi ca kāraṇikā ati ādinā nayena abhidhamme paṭisedhitam eva yathā hi manussa loke
translated: and the Abhidhamma rejects this view in the way beginning, “But there are those who are not makers” .🔽Just as in the human world there are craftsmen and makers, so too in hell there are the warders of hell.

original: kammakāraṇakārakā atthi, evameva niraye nirayapālā atthīti. Yamassa raññoti yamarājā🔽nāma vemānikapetarājā. Ekasmiṃ kāle dibbavimāne dibbakapparukkhadibbauyyānadibbanāṭakādisabbasampattiṃ
analyzed: kamma kāraṇa kārakā atthi evam eva niraye niraya pālā atthi iti yamassa rañño ti yama rājā  nāma vemānika peta rājā ekasmin kāle dibba vimāne dibba kappa rukkha dibba oyyāna dibba nāṭaka ādi sabba sampattim
translated: King Yama: Yama the king of the ghosts is called “Yama the king” .

original: anubhavati, ekasmiṃ kāle kammavipākaṃ, dhammiko rājā, na cesa ekova hoti, catūsu🔽pana dvāresu cattāro janā honti. Amatteyyoti mātu hito matteyyo, mātari sammā paṭipannoti
analyzed: anubhavati ekasmim kāle kamma vipākam dhammikaḥ rājā na ca isaḥ ekaḥ iva hoti catūsu  pana dvāresu cattāro janāḥ honti amatteyyaḥ ti mātu hitaḥ matteyyaḥ mātari sammā paṭipanno ti
translated: At one time he experiences all the excellence of the divine palace, the divine food and clothes, the divine dancing, singing and music, etc., and at another time the result of kamma. He is a righteous king. But he is not alone. There are four of him at the four doors.🔽“One who is dear to his mother” is one who conducts himself rightly towards his mother.

original: attho. Na matteyyoti amatteyyo, mātari micchā paṭipannoti attho. Sesapadesupi eseva
analyzed: attho na matteyyo ti a matteyyaḥ mātari micchā paṭipanno ti attho sesa padesu pi esā eva
translated: “One who is not dear to his mother” is one who conducts himself wrongly towards his mother. The same method applies in the other cases.

original: nayo. Abrahmaññoti ettha ca khīṇāsavā brāhmaṇā nāma, tesu micchā paṭipanno abrahmañño nāma.
analyzed: nayo abrahmañño ti ettha ca khīṇa āsavāḥ brāhmaṇāḥ nāma tesu micchā paṭipanno abrahmaññaḥ nāma
translated: “One who is not a brahmin” : those who are called brahmins are those who are free from cankers. One who conducts himself wrongly towards them is “one who is not a brahmin.”

original: Samanuyuñjatīti anuyogavattaṃ āropento pucchati, laddhiṃ patiṭṭhāpento pana samanuggāhati🔽nāma, kāraṇaṃ pucchanto samanubhāsati nāma. Nāddasanti attano santike pahitassa kassaci🔽devadūtassa abhāvaṃ sandhāya evaṃ vadati.
analyzed: samanuyuñjati iti anuyogavattam āropento pucchati laddhim patiṭṭhāpento pana samanuggāhati  nāma kāraṇam pucchantaḥ samanubhāsati nāma na addasanti attanaḥ santike pahitassa kassaci  deva dūtassa abhāvam sandhāya evam vadati
translated: He questions, imposing the method of cross-questioning, but he exhorts when he establishes a point.🔽He asks the reason when he asks for the cause. He says “They do not admit” because there is no divine messenger sent to him.

original: Atha naṃ yamo “nāyaṃ bhāsitassa atthaṃ sallakkhetī”ti ñatvā atthaṃ sallakkhāpetukāmo
analyzed: atha nam yamaḥ na ayam bhāsitassa attham sallakkheti iti ñatvā attham sallakkhāpetu kāmo
translated: Then Yama, thinking “He does not consider the meaning of what is said,”🔽and wishing to make him consider the meaning, said: “Friend, you are old, bent like a roof-beam,🔽broken, with a stick to support you,🔽shaky, sick, with broken teeth, grey-haired, bald, wrinkled,

original: ambhotiādimāha. Tattha jiṇṇanti jarājiṇṇaṃ. Gopānasivaṅkanti gopānasī viya vaṅkaṃ.
analyzed: ambhaḥ ti ādim āha tattha jiṇṇam ti jarā jiṇṇam gopānasi vaṅkam ti gopānasī viya vaṅkam
translated: with blotchy skin.” Herein, old means worn out by old age. Bent like a roof-beam means bent like a roof-beam.

original: Bhogganti bhaggaṃ. Imināpissa vaṅkabhāvameva dīpeti. Daṇḍaparāyaṇanti daṇḍapaṭisaraṇaṃ🔽daṇḍadutiyaṃ. Pavedhamānanti kampamānaṃ. Āturanti jarāturaṃ. Khaṇḍadantanti jarānubhāvena
analyzed: bhoggam ti bhaggam iminā api sa vaṅka bhāvam eva dīpeti daṇḍa parāyaṇam ti daṇḍa paṭisaraṇam  kampamānam āturanti jarā āturam jarā anubhāvena
translated: Broken means broken up. By this he also shows his bentness. With a stick to support you means with a stick as a support,🔽with a stick as a second self. Shaky means trembling. Sick means sick with old age. With broken teeth means🔽with teeth broken up through the influence of old age. Grey-haired means with white hair. Bald means with hair that is as though plucked out and taken away, that is, with a bald scalp.

original: khaṇḍitadantaṃ. Palitakesanti paṇḍarakesaṃ. Vilūnanti luñcitvā gahitakesaṃ viya khallāṭaṃ.
analyzed: khaṇḍita dantam palita kesanti paṇḍara kesam vilūnanti luñcitvā khallāṭam
translated: Wrinkled means with skin that is wrinkled. Blotchy means with skin that is blotchy.

original: Khalitasiranti mahākhallāṭasīsaṃ. Valitanti sañjātavaliṃ. Tilakāhatagattanti setatilakakāḷatilakehi
analyzed: mahā khallāṭa sīsam valitanti sañjāta valim tilaka āhata gattanti seta tilaka kāḷa tilakehi
translated: Khalitasirā means with a large bald head. Valitā means with wrinkles. Tilakāhatagattā means with white and black wrinkles.

original: vikiṇṇasarīraṃ. Jarādhammoti jarāsabhāvo, aparimutto jarāya, jarā nāma mayhaṃ abbhantareyeva
analyzed: vikiṇṇa sarīram jarā dhammo ti jarā sabhāvaḥ a parimuttaḥ jarāya jarā nāma mayham
translated: Khalitasiranti mahākhallāṭasīsaṃ: his head was like a big pestle. Valitanti sañjātavaliṃ: he had wrinkles. Tilakāhatagattanti setatilakakāḷatilakehi viṭabhiṇṇasarīraṃ: his body was covered with white and black moles. Jarādhammoti jarāsabhāvo: he was subject to old age. Aparimutto jarāya: he was not free from old age. Jarā nāma mayhaṃ abbhantareyeva pavattatīti: he thought, “Old age is taking place in me.”

original: pavattatīti. Parato byādhidhammo maraṇadhammoti padadvayepi eseva nayo.
analyzed: pavattati iti paratas byādhi dhammo maraṇa dhammo ti pada dvaye pi esa iva nayo
translated: Parato byādhidhammo maraṇadhammo: the same method of explanation applies to the other two terms.

original: Paṭhamaṃ devadūtaṃ samanuyuñjitvāti ettha jarājiṇṇasatto atthato evaṃ vadati nāma
analyzed: paṭhamam deva dūtam samanuyuñjitvā ati ettha jarā jiṇṇa satto atthataḥ evam vadati nāma
translated: Paṭhamaṃ devadūtaṃ samanuyuñjitvā: having reflected on the first divine messenger. The old and decrepit creature, in effect, said this:

original: – “passatha, bho, ahampi tumhe viya taruṇo ahosiṃ ūrubalī bāhubalī javasampanno,🔽tassa me tā balajavasampattiyo antarahitā, vijjamānāpi me hatthapādā hatthapādakiccaṃ
analyzed: passatha bho aham pi tumhe viya taruṇaḥ ahosim ūru balī bāhu balī java sampanno  tassa me tāḥ bala java sampattiyaḥ antarahitāḥ vijjamānāḥ api me hattha pādāḥ hattha pāda kiccam
translated: “Look, friends, I was once as young as you are. I had strong thighs and strong arms and was endowed with speed.🔽But my strength and speed have disappeared. Although they are still present, my hands and feet do not perform their functions.

original: na karonti, jarāyamhi aparimuttatāya ediso jāto. Na kho panāhameva, tumhepi jarāya
analyzed: na karonti jarāyamhi a parimutta tāya edisaḥ jātaḥ na kho pana aham eva tumhe pi jarāya
translated: I have become like this because I am not free from old age. But I am not the only one. You too are not free from old age.

original: aparimuttāva. Yatheva hi mayhaṃ, evaṃ tumhākampi jarā āgamissati. Iti tassā pure
analyzed: a parimuttā ava yathā iva hi mayham evam tumhākam pi jarā āgamissati iti tassā pure
translated: Just as it has come upon me, so it will come upon you. Thus, in the past,

original: āgamanāva kalyāṇaṃ karothā”ti. Tenevesa devadūto nāma jāto. Ābādhikanti bādhikaṃ.
analyzed: kalyāṇam karotha ati tena iva isa deva dūtaḥ nāma jātaḥ bādhikam
translated: and that is why he is called a divine messenger.🔽Afflicted: afflicted with affliction.

original: Dukkhitanti dukkhappattaṃ. Bāḷhagilānanti adhimattagilānaṃ.
analyzed: dukkhitam ti dukkha ppattam bāḷha gilānam ti adhimatta gilānam
translated: Very ill: with extreme illness.

original: Dutiyaṃ devadūtanti etthapi gilānasatto atthato evaṃ vadati nāma – “passatha, bho,
analyzed: dutiyam deva dūtam ti ettha api gilāna satto atthataḥ evam vadati nāma passatha bho
translated: Second divine messenger: here the sick person speaks as if he were saying: “Look, friends,

original: ahampi tumhe viya nirogo ahosiṃ, somhi etarahi byādhinā abhihato, sake muttakarīse
analyzed: aham pi tumhe viya nirogaḥ ahosim somhi etarahi byādhinā abhihato sake mutta karīse
translated: I was once as healthy as you are now. But now I am struck down by illness. I am🔽covered with my own urine and excrement. I cannot even get up. Though my

original: palipanno, uṭṭhātumpi na sakkomi. Vijjamānāpi me hatthapādā hatthapādakiccaṃ na karonti,
analyzed: palipannaḥ uṭṭhātum pi na sakkomi vijjamānā api me hattha pādāḥ hattha pāda kiccam na karonti
translated: hands and feet are here, they will not do the work of hands and feet.🔽I am ill because I am not free from the possibility of illness. But you are not

original: byādhitomhi aparimuttatāya ediso jāto. Na kho panāhameva, tumhepi byādhito aparimuttāva.
analyzed: byādhitaḥ amhi a parimutta tāya edisaḥ jātaḥ na kho pana aham eva tumhe pi byādhitaḥ
translated: free from the possibility of illness either.

original: Yatheva hi mayhaṃ, evaṃ tumhākampi byādhi āgamissati. Iti tassa pure āgamanāva kalyāṇaṃ
analyzed: yathā iva hi mayham evam tumhākam pi byādhi āgamissati iti tassa pure kalyāṇam
translated: Just as it has happened to me, so it will happen to you. Therefore it is good

original: karothā”ti. Tenevesa devadūto nāma jāto.
analyzed: karotha ati tena iva isa deva dūtaḥ nāma jātaḥ
translated: for you to do good.” And that is why he is called a divine messenger.

original: Ekāhamatantiādīsu ekāhaṃ matassa assāti ekāhamato, taṃ ekāhamataṃ. Parato padadvayepi
analyzed: ekāha mata nti ādīsu ekāham matassa assa ati ekāha mataḥ tam ekāha matam paratas pada dvaye pi
translated: In the case of the words ekāhamataṃ, etc., the meaning is: he is one who has died one day ago, thus he is ekāhamataṃ;🔽the same method of explanation applies in the case of the other two words.

original: eseva nayo. Bhastā viya vāyunā uddhaṃ jīvitapariyādānā yathākkamaṃ samuggatena sūnabhāvena🔽uddhumātattā uddhumātakaṃ. Vinīlo vuccati viparibhinnavaṇṇo, vinīlova vinīlako, taṃ
analyzed: esā iva nayaḥ bhastā viya vāyunā uddham jīvita pariyādānā yathākkamam samuggatena sūna bhāvena  uddhumātattā uddhumātakam vinīlaḥ vuccati viparibhinna vaṇṇaḥ vinīlaḥ iva vinīlakaḥ tam
translated: It is bloated because it is swollen with the wind that has arisen in the corpse and has no outlet, like a bellows blown with air.🔽It is livid because it has changed colour, thus it is vinīlakaṃ. Or alternatively, it is livid because it is discoloured, thus it is vinīlakaṃ.

original: vinīlakaṃ. Paṭikūlattā vā kucchitaṃ vinīlanti vinīlakaṃ. Vipubbakanti vissandamānapubbakaṃ,
analyzed: vinīlakam paṭikūla ttā vā kucchitam vinīlanti vinīlakam vipubbakam ti vissandamāna pubbakam
translated: It is festering because it is oozing from the various openings of the body.

original: paribhinnaṭṭhāne hi paggharitena pubbena palimakkhitanti attho.
analyzed: paribhinna ṭṭhāne hi paggharitena pubbena pali makkhitanti atthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is smeared with the pus that has come out from the places where it is festering.

original: Tatiyaṃ devadūtanti ettha matakasatto atthato evaṃ vadati nāma – “passatha, bho,
analyzed: tatiyam deva dūtam ti ettha mataka satto atthataḥ evam vadati nāma passatha bho
translated: The third divine messenger: here the dead body itself seems to say this: “Look, friends,

original: maṃ āmakasusāne chaḍḍitaṃ uddhumātakādibhāvappattaṃ, maraṇatomhi aparimuttatāya ediso
analyzed: āmaka susāne chaḍḍitam uddhumātaka ādi bhāva ppattam maraṇataḥ mhi a parimutta tāya ediso
translated: I have been thrown into the charnel ground and have reached the state of a bloated corpse, etc., because I was not free from death.🔽But you are not free from death either. Just as I am,

original: jāto. Na kho panāhameva, tumhepi maraṇato aparimuttā. Yatheva hi mayhaṃ, evaṃ tumhākampi
analyzed: jātaḥ na kho pana aham eva tumhe pi maraṇataḥ a parimuttā yathā iva hi mayham evam tumhākam pi
translated: so you will be too.

original: maraṇaṃ āgamissati. Iti tassa pure āgamanāva kalyāṇaṃ karothā”ti. Tenevassa devadūto nāma jāto.
analyzed: maraṇam āgamissati iti tassa pure kalyāṇam karotha ati tena iva assa deva dūtaḥ nāma jātaḥ
translated: and death will come to him. So do good to him before he comes.” That is how he came to be called the “messenger of the gods.”

original: Imaṃ pana devadūtānuyogaṃ ko labhati, ko na labhati? Yena tāva bahuṃ pāpaṃ kataṃ,
analyzed: imam pana deva dūta anuyogam kaḥ labhati kaḥ na labhati yena tāva bahum pāpam katam
translated: Now, who is it that gets this “messenger of the gods” and who does not? In the first place, he who has committed much evil

original: so gantvā niraye nibbattatiyeva. Yena pana parittaṃ pāpaṃ kataṃ, so labhati. Yathā
analyzed: saḥ gantvā niraye yena pana parittam pāpam katam saḥ labhati yathā
translated: goes and is reborn in hell. But he who has committed little evil gets it.

original: hi sabhaṇḍaṃ coraṃ gahetvā kattabbameva karonti na vinicchinanti. Anuvijjitvā gahitaṃ🔽pana vinicchayaṭṭhānaṃ nayanti, so vinicchayaṃ labhati. Evaṃsampadametaṃ. Parittapāpakammā
analyzed: hi sa bhaṇḍam coram gahetvā kattabbam eva karonti na vinicchinanti anuvijjitvā gahitam  pana vinicchaya ṭṭhānam nayanti saḥ vinicchayam labhati evaṃsampadam etam paritta pāpa kammā
translated: For just as when they catch a thief with stolen goods they do what is proper and do not investigate him,🔽but when he is caught without his goods they investigate him and he gets a judgment, so too, in this case.

original: hi attano dhammatāyapi saranti, sārīyamānāpi saranti.🔽Tattha dīghajayantadamiḷo nāma attano dhammatāya sari. So kira damiḷo sumanagirimahāvihāre
analyzed: hi attanaḥ saranti sārīyamānā api saranti  tattha dīghajayantadamiḷaḥ nāma dhammatāya sari saḥ kira damiḷaḥ sumanagiri mahā vihāre
translated: For those who have committed little evil go by their own nature and go when pressed.🔽Herein, Dīghāyus the Damiḷa went by his own nature.🔽It seems that this Damiḷa worshipped the Cloth-tree Shrine in the Great Monastery at Sumanakūṭa with a red cloth.

original: ākāsacetiyaṃ rattapaṭena pūjesi, atha niraye ussadasāmante nibbatto aggijālasaddaṃ
analyzed: ākāsa cetiyam ratta paṭena pūjesi atha niraye ussada sāmante nibbattaḥ aggi jāla saddam
translated: Then he was reborn in hell in the neighbourhood of the Great Hell. He heard the sound of the flames of the Great Hell

original: sutvāva attanā pūjitapaṭaṃ anussari, so gantvā sagge nibbatto. Aparopi puttassa daharabhikkhuno🔽khalisāṭakaṃ dento pādamūle ṭhapesi, maraṇakālamhi paṭapaṭāti sadde nimittaṃ gaṇhi,🔽sopi ussadasāmante nibbatto jālasaddena taṃ sāṭakaṃ anussaritvā sagge nibbatto. Evaṃ
analyzed: sutvā ava attanā pūjita paṭam anussari so gantvā sagge nibbattaḥ aparaḥ api puttassa dahara bhikkhuno  khali sāṭakam dento pāda mūle ṭhapesi maraṇa kālamhi sadde nimittam gaṇhi  saḥ api ussada sāmante nibbattaḥ jāla saddena tam sāṭakam anussaritvā sagge nibbattaḥ evam
translated: and as soon as he heard it he remembered the robe he had offered. He was reborn in a happy destiny. Another man gave a coarse cloth to his son, a young bhikkhu,🔽and placed it at his feet. At the time of his death he took the sound of the robe as a sign, saying “Cloth, cloth.”🔽He too was reborn in a happy destiny in the vicinity of the gods of the heaven of the Vehapphala devas. Remembering the cloth because of the sound of the net, he was reborn in a happy destiny.🔽

original: tāva attano dhammatāya kusalaṃ kammaṃ saritvā sagge nibbattatīti.
analyzed: tāva attanaḥ dhamma tāya kusalam kammam saritvā sagge nibbattati iti
translated: and as soon as he heard it he remembered the robe he had offered himself. He went and was reborn in a happy destiny. Another man gave a coarse cloth to his son, a young bhikkhu, and placed it at his feet. At the time of his death he took the sound of the cloth as a sign. He too was reborn in a happy destiny in the neighbourhood of the gods of the heaven of the Thirty-three. Remembering the cloth by the sound of the net, he was reborn in a happy destiny. This is how it is said that he is reborn in a happy destiny by remembering a profitable action of his own accord.

original: Attano dhammatāya asarante pana tayo devadūte pucchati. Tattha koci paṭhamena devadūtena
analyzed: attanaḥ dhamma tāya a sarante pana tayo deva dūte pucchati tattha koci paṭhamena deva dūtena
translated: But if he does not remember by his own accord, then he is questioned by three messengers of the gods. Herein, some remember by the first messenger,

original: sarati, koci dutiyatatiyehi, koci tīhipi nassarati. Taṃ yamo rājā disvā sayaṃ sāreti.🔽Eko kira amacco sumanapupphakumbhena mahācetiyaṃ pūjetvā yamassa pattiṃ adāsi, taṃ
analyzed: sarati koci dutiya tatiyehi koci tīhi pi naḥ sarati tam yamaḥ rājā disvā sayam sāreti  ekaḥ kira amaccaḥ sumana puppha kumbhena mahā cetiyam pūjetvā yamassa pattim adāsi tam
translated: some by the second and third, and some do not remember by even three. Then King Yama himself questions them.🔽It seems that a certain minister worshipped the Great Relic Shrine with a basket of jasmine flowers and gave the merit to Yama. He was reborn in hell because of unprofitable action and was led into the presence of Yama.

original: akusalakammena niraye nibbattaṃ yamassa santikaṃ nayiṃsu. Tasmiṃ tīhipi devadūtehi
analyzed: akusala kammena niraye nibbattam yamassa santikam nayiṃsu tasmin tīhi pi deva dūtehi
translated: He did not remember by even three messengers of the gods.

original: kusalaṃ asarante yamo sayaṃ olokento disvā – “nanu tvaṃ mahācetiyaṃ sumanapupphakumbhena🔽pūjetvā mayhaṃ pattiṃ adāsī”ti sāresi, so tasmiṃ kāle saritvā devalokaṃ gato. Yamo
analyzed: kusalam a sarante yamaḥ sayam olokentaḥ disvā nanu tvam mahā cetiyam sumana puppha kumbhena  pūjetvā mayham pattim adāsi iti sāresi saḥ tasmin kāle saritvā deva lokam gataḥ yamaḥ
translated: Yama, not seeing any good deeds, looked himself and seeing him, said: “Did you not worship the Great Shrine with a basket of Sumana flowers and give me the merit?” He remembered that at that time and went to the heavenly world.

original: pana sayaṃ oloketvāpi apassanto – “mahādukkhaṃ nāma anubhavissati ayaṃ satto”ti tuṇhī ahosi.🔽Tattaṃ ayokhilanti tigāvutaṃ attabhāvaṃ sampajjalitāya lohapathaviyā uttānakaṃ nipajjāpetvā🔽dakkhiṇahatthe tālappamāṇaṃ ayasūlaṃ pavesenti, tathā vāmahatthādīsu. Yathā ca taṃ
analyzed: pana sayam oloketvā api a passantaḥ mahādukkham nāma anubhavissati ayam satto ti tuṇhī ahosi  tat tam tigāvutam atta bhāvam sampajjalitāya loha pathaviyāḥ uttānakam  dakkhiṇa hatthe tāla ppamāṇam aya sūlam pavesenti tathā vāma hattha ādīsu yathā ca tam
translated: Yama himself, not finding any good kamma, looked and saw him. Seeing him, he said: “Did you not worship the Great Shrine with a basket of Sumana flowers and give me the merit?” He remembered that at that time and went to the heavenly world. But Yama, not seeing him even though he looked, was silent, thinking: “This being will experience great suffering.”

original: uttānakaṃ nipajjāpetvā, evaṃ urenapi vāmapassenapi dakkhiṇapassenapi nipajjāpetvā
analyzed: uttānakam nipajjāpetvā evam urena api vāma passena api dakkhiṇa passena api nipajjāpetvā
translated: A red-hot iron stake: they make him lie down on an iron surface that is burning, blazing and glowing, and they drive in an iron stake the size of a palm tree into his right hand, and in the same way into his left hand and so on. And just as they make him lie down on his back, so also on his chest, left side, and right side.

original: te taṃ kammakāraṇaṃ karontiyeva. Saṃvesetvāti jalitāya lohapathaviyā tigāvutaṃ attabhāvaṃ
analyzed: te tam kamma kāraṇam karontiyā iva saṃvesetvā ati jalitāya loha pathaviyā tigāvutam atta bhāvam
translated: They do this to him as the reason for his kamma. They make him lie down: they make him lie down on an iron surface that is burning, blazing and glowing, his body the size of three gavutas.

original: nipajjāpetvā. Kuṭhārīhīti mahatīhi gehassa ekapakkhacchadanamattāhi kuṭhārīhi tacchanti,
analyzed: nipajjāpetvā kuṭhārīhi iti mahatīhi gehassa eka pakkha chadana mattāhi kuṭhārīhi tacchanti
translated: and make them lie down. With saws means with great saws the size of a house wall.

original: lohitaṃ nadī hutvā sandati, lohapathavito jālā uṭṭhahitvā tacchitaṭṭhānaṃ gaṇhāti,
analyzed: lohitam nadī hutvā sandati loha pathavitaḥ jālā uṭṭhahitvā tad chita ṭṭhānam gaṇhāti
translated: Blood flows like a river. A net of iron spikes rises up and covers the place where they are being sawn.

original: mahādukkhaṃ uppajjati. Tacchantā pana suttāhataṃ karitvā dāruṃ viya aṭṭhaṃsampi chaḷaṃsampi🔽karonti. Vāsīhīti mahāsuppappamāṇāhi vāsīhi. Rathe yojetvāti saddhiṃ yugayottapakkharathacakkakubbarapājanehi
analyzed: mahā dukkham uppajjati tacchantā pana sutta ahatam karitvā dārum viya aṭṭhaṃsam pi chaḷaṃsam pi  karonti vāsīhi iti mahā suppappamāṇāhi vāsīhi rathe yojetvā ati saddhim
translated: Great pain arises. But when they are sawing, they make the wood like a bed of needles or a bed of spikes.🔽With axes means with great axes the size of a good-sized palm tree. Having yoked them to a chariot means having yoked them to a burning chariot together with the yoke, the pole, the axle, the wheels, the shaft, and the flagstaff.

original: sabbato pajjalite rathe yojetvā. Mahantanti mahākūṭāgārappamāṇaṃ. Āropentīti sampajjalitehi
analyzed: sabbatas pajjalite rathe yojetvā mahantanti mahā kūṭāgāra ppamāṇam āropenti iti sampajjalitehi
translated: Great means the size of a great gabled building. They make them climb means they make them climb while striking them with burning hammers.

original: ayamuggarehi pothentā āropenti. Sakimpi uddhanti supakkuthitāya ukkhaliyā pakkhittataṇḍulā
analyzed: pothentāḥ āropenti su pakkuthitāya ukkhaliyā pakkhitta taṇḍulā
translated: They lift them up once means they lift them up and down like rice grains put into a boiling cauldron.

original: viya uddhamadhotiriyañca gacchati. Mahānirayeti avīcimahānirayamhi.
analyzed: viyaḥ uddham adhotiriyam ca gacchati mahāniraya iti avīci mahānirayamhi
translated: In the Great Hell means in the Great Avīci Hell.

original: Bhāgaso mitoti bhāge ṭhapetvā vibhatto. Pariyantoti parikkhitto. Ayasāti upari ayapaṭṭena🔽chādito. Samantā yojanasataṃ, pharitvā tiṭṭhatīti evaṃ pharitvā tiṭṭhati, yathā taṃ
analyzed: bhāgasaḥ mitaḥ ti bhāge ṭhapetvā vibhattaḥ pariyantaḥ ti parikkhittaḥ ayasā āti upari  samantā yojana satam pharitvā tiṭṭhati iti evam pharitvā tiṭṭhati yathā tam
translated: “Measured out in parts” means divided by being measured out in parts. “Surrounded” means enclosed. “Covered above with a network of gold” means covered above with a network of gold.

original: samantā yojanasate ṭhatvā olokentassa akkhīni yamakagoḷakā viya nikkhamanti.🔽Hīnakāyūpagāti hīnaṃ kāyaṃ upagatā hutvā. Upādāneti taṇhādiṭṭhiggahaṇe. Jātimaraṇasambhaveti🔽jātiyā ca maraṇassa ca kāraṇabhūte. Anupādāti catūhi upādānehi anupādiyitvā. Jātimaraṇasaṅkhayeti
analyzed: samantā yojana sate ṭhatvā olokentassa akkhīni yamaka goḷakā viya nikkhamanti  hīna kāya upagā iti hīnam kāyam upagatā hutvā upādāne iti taṇhā diṭṭhi ggahaṇe jāti maraṇa sambhavā iti  jātiyā ca maraṇassa ca kāraṇa bhūte catūhi upādānehi an upādiyitvā jāti maraṇa saṅkhayā iti
translated: “Extending a hundred leagues in all directions” means extending in this way. It is as if one were to stand in the four directions a hundred leagues away and look at it; one’s eyes would be dazzled, as if one were looking at twin suns.🔽“Having gone to a low birth” means having gone to a low form of existence. “Clinging” means clinging through craving and views. “The origin of birth and death” means the cause of birth and death.

original: jātimaraṇasaṅkhayasaṅkhāte nibbāne vimuccanti. Diṭṭhadhammābhinibbutāti diṭṭhadhamme
analyzed: jāti maraṇa saṅkhaya saṅkhāte nibbāne vimuccanti diṭṭhadhamma abhinibbutā ati diṭṭhadhamme
translated: “Not clinging” means not clinging through the four kinds of clinging. “The destruction of birth and death” means Nibbāna, which is called the destruction of birth and death. “They are liberated” means they are liberated in Nibbāna. “They are extinguished in this very life” means they are extinguished in this very life,

original: imasmiṃyeva attabhāve sabbakilesanibbānena nibbutā. Sabbadukkhaṃ upaccagunti sakalavaṭṭadukkhaṃ atikkantā.
analyzed: imasmin yeva atta bhāve sabba kilesa nibbānena nibbutā sabba dukkham upaccagunti sakala vaṭṭa dukkham atikkantā
translated: in this very individuality, through the extinguishing of all defilements. “They have crossed over attachment to all suffering” means they have crossed over all suffering in the three planes of existence.

original: 7. Catumahārājasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: catu mahārāja sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Discourse on the Four Great Kings

original: 37. Sattame amaccā pārisajjāti paricārikadevatā. Imaṃ lokaṃ anuvicarantīti aṭṭhamīdivase
analyzed: sattame amaccā pārisajjāti paricārika devatāḥ imam lokam anuvicaranti iti aṭṭhamī divase
translated: 7. In the seventh line, the “ministers and counsellors” are the deities who attend upon the king. “Wandering through the world” means that on the eighth day of the lunar half-month,

original: kira sakko devarājā cattāro mahārājāno āṇāpeti – “tātā, ajja aṭṭhamīdivase manussalokaṃ🔽anuvicaritvā puññāni karontānaṃ nāmagottaṃ uggaṇhitvā āgacchathā”ti. Te gantvā attano
analyzed: kira sakkaḥ deva rājā cattāraḥ mahā rājānaḥ āṇāpeti tātā ajja aṭṭhamī divase manussa lokaṃ  anuvicaritvā puññāni karontānam nāma gottam uggaṇhitvā āgacchatha ati te gantvā attanaḥ
translated: it is said, Sakka, king of the gods, commands the Four Great Kings: “Gentlemen, today, on the eighth day of the lunar half-month,

original: paricārake pesenti – “gacchatha, tātā, manussalokaṃ vicaritvā puññakārakānaṃ nāmagottāni
analyzed: paricārake pesenti gacchatha tātāḥ manussa lokam vicaritvā puñña kārakānam nāma gottāni
translated: wander through the human world and find out who is making merit. Then return and tell me their names and clans.” The Four Great Kings go and send their own attendants, saying: “Go, gentlemen, wander through the human world and find out who is making merit.

original: suvaṇṇapaṭṭe likhitvā ānethā”ti. Te tathā karonti. Tena vuttaṃ – “imaṃ lokaṃ anuvicarantī”ti.
analyzed: suvaṇṇa paṭṭe likhitvā ānetha iti te tathā karonti tena vuttam imam lokam anuvicaranti iti
translated: Then write down their names and clans on golden plates and bring them back to me.” They do so. Therefore it is said: “wandering through the world.”

original: Kacci bahūtiādi tesaṃ upaparikkhākāradassanatthaṃ vuttaṃ. Evaṃ upaparikkhantā hi
analyzed: kacci bahu itiādi tesam upaparikkhā ākāra dassana attham vuttam evam upaparikkhantāḥ hi
translated: “Are many” and so forth are said to show the way they investigate. For they investigate

original: te anuvicaranti. Tattha uposathaṃ upavasantīti māsassa aṭṭhavāre uposathaṅgāni adhiṭṭhahanti.
analyzed: te anuvicaranti tattha uposatham upavasanti iti māsassa aṭṭhavāre uposathaṅgāni adhiṭṭhahanti
translated: in this way. “Observing the uposatha”: on the eight days of the lunar half-month, they undertake the uposatha observances.

original: Paṭijāgarontīti paṭijāgarauposathakammaṃ nāma karonti. Taṃ karontā ekasmiṃ addhamāse
analyzed: paṭijāgaronti iti paṭijāgara uposatha kammam nāma karonti tam karontāḥ ekasmin addha māse
translated: “They observe” means they perform the observance-day ceremony. Doing that, they

original: catunnaṃ uposathadivasānaṃ paccuggamanānuggamanavasena karonti. Pañcamīuposathaṃ
analyzed: catunnam uposatha divasānam paccuggamana anuggamana vasena karonti pañcamī uposatham
translated: They are ‘keeping awake’ when they are doing what is called the Uposatha rite of ‘keeping awake.’ When they do this they do it by way of the coming and going of the four Uposatha days in the half-month.🔽They are ‘coming back’ on the fifth Uposatha day

original: paccuggacchantā catutthiyaṃ uposathikā honti, anugacchantā chaṭṭhiyaṃ. Aṭṭhamīuposathaṃ
analyzed: paccuggacchantā catutthiyam uposathikāḥ honti anugacchantā chaṭṭhiyam aṭṭhamī uposathaṃ
translated: when they are Uposatha-day observers on the fourth, and they are ‘going on’ when they are Uposatha-day observers on the sixth. They are ‘coming back’ on the eighth Uposatha day

original: paccuggacchantā sattamiyaṃ, anugacchantā navamiyaṃ. Cātuddasiṃ paccuggacchantā terasiyaṃ,
analyzed: paccuggacchantā sattamiyam anugacchantā navamiyam cātuddasim paccuggacchantā terasiyam
translated: when they are Uposatha-day observers on the seventh, and they are ‘going on’ when they are Uposatha-day observers on the ninth. They are ‘coming back’ on the fourteenth

original: pannarasīuposathaṃ anugacchantā pāṭipade uposathikā honti. Puññāni karontīti saraṇagamananiccasīlapupphapūjādhammassavanapadīpasahassaāropanavihārakaraṇādīni
analyzed: pannarasī uposatham anugacchantā pāṭipade uposathikāḥ honti puññāni karonti iti saraṇa gamana nicca sīla puppha pūjā dhamma ssavana padīpa sahassa āropana vihāra karaṇa ādīni
translated: when they are Uposatha-day observers on the thirteenth, and they are ‘going on’ when they are Uposatha-day observers on the fifteenth. They are ‘doing merit’ when they are doing various kinds of merit such as going for refuge, observing the eight precepts, making flower offerings, listening to the True Idea, lighting a thousand oil-lamps, and building a monastery.

original: nānappakārāni puññāni karonti. Te evaṃ anuvicaritvā puññakammakārakānaṃ nāmagottāni
analyzed: nānappakārāni puññāni karonti te evam anuvicaritvā puñña kamma kārakānam nāma gottāni
translated: After they have thus roamed about, they write down the names and clans of those who have done meritorious deeds

original: sovaṇṇamaye paṭṭe likhitvā āharitvā catunnaṃ mahārājānaṃ denti. Puttā imaṃ lokaṃ
analyzed: sovaṇṇa maye paṭṭe likhitvā āharitvā catunnam mahā rājānam denti puttāḥ imam lokaṃ
translated: on golden tablets and bring them and give them to the Four Great Kings. ‘Sons, this world

analyzed: anuvicaranti iti catūhi mahārājehi purima nayena iva anuvicaranti
translated: “They will go around” means that, because the four Great Kings have sent out their ministers and messengers as described above, they will go around. “On that day” means

original: taṃdivasaṃ. Uposatheti uposathadivase.
analyzed: taṃ divasam uposatha iti uposatha divase
translated: on the Uposatha day.

original: Sace, bhikkhave, appakā hontīti catunnaṃ mahārājānaṃ amaccā pārisajjā tā tā gāmanigamarājadhāniyo
analyzed: sace bhikkhave appakāḥ honti iti catunnam mahārājānam amaccā pārisajjā tā tā gāma nigama rājadhāniyaḥ
translated: “If, bhikkhus, there are few” means that if the ministers and messengers of the four Great Kings have gone to the villages, towns, and capital cities,

original: upasaṅkamanti, tato taṃ upanissāya adhivatthā devatā “mahārājānaṃ amaccā āgatā”ti🔽paṇṇākāraṃ gahetvā tesaṃ santikaṃ gacchanti. Te paṇṇākāraṃ gahetvā “kacci nu kho
analyzed: upasaṅkamanti tatas tam upanissāya adhivatthā devatā mahā rājānam amaccā āgatā ati  paṇṇa ākāram gahetvā tesam santikam gacchanti te paṇṇa ākāram gahetvā kacci nu kho
translated: then the deities who live in dependence on them will take a written message and go to them, thinking, “The ministers and messengers of the Great Kings have come.”

original: mārisā bahū manussā matteyyā”ti vuttanayena manussānaṃ puññapaṭipattiṃ pucchitvā
analyzed: mārisā bahū manussāḥ matteyya ati vutta nayena manussānam puñña paṭipattim pucchitvā
translated: They will take the written message and ask the people, “Perhaps, sirs, there are many people who are respectful?”🔽In the way described above, they will ask about the people’s practice of merit.

original: “āma, mārisa, imasmiṃ gāme asuko ca asuko ca puññāni karontī”ti vutte tesaṃ nāmagottaṃ
analyzed: āma mārisa imasmin gāme asuko ca asuko ca puññāni karonti iti vutte tesam nāma gottam
translated: “Yes, sirs, in this village so-and-so and so-and-so are making merit.” When they have been told this,

original: likhitvā aññattha gacchanti. Atha cātuddasiyaṃ catunnaṃ mahārājānaṃ puttāpi tameva
analyzed: likhitvā aññattha gacchanti atha cātuddasiyam catunnam mahā rājānam puttāḥ api tam eva
translated: they will write down their names and family names and go elsewhere. Then on the fourteenth, the sons of the four Great Kings

original: suvaṇṇapaṭṭaṃ gahetvā teneva nayena anuvicarantā nāmagottāni likhanti. Tadahuposathe🔽pannarase cattāropi mahārājāno teneva nayena tasmiṃyeva suvaṇṇapaṭṭe nāmagottāni
analyzed: suvaṇṇa paṭṭam gahetvā tena iva nayena anuvicarantāḥ nāma gottāni likhanti tad ah uposathe  pannarase cattāro api mahā rājāno tena iva nayena tasmin yeva suvaṇṇa paṭṭe nāma gottāni
translated: They take a gold tablet and, in the same way, they write down the names and clans. On the Uposatha day of the fifteenth,

original: likhanti. Te suvaṇṇapaṭṭaparimāṇeneva – “imasmiṃ kāle manussā appakā, imasmiṃ kāle
analyzed: likhanti te suvaṇṇa paṭṭa parimāṇena iva imasmin kāle manussāḥ appakāḥ imasmin kāle
translated: all four Great Kings, in the same way, write down the names and clans on the same gold tablet. They know by the size of the gold tablet whether at that time people are few or many.

original: bahukā”ti jānanti. Taṃ sandhāya “sace, bhikkhave, appakā honti manussā”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: bahukā iti jānanti tam sandhāya sace bhikkhave appakāḥ honti manussā tiādi vuttam
translated: With reference to that it is said: “If, bhikkhus, there are few people” and so on.

original: Devānaṃ tāvatiṃsānanti paṭhamaṃ abhinibbatte tettiṃsa devaputte upādāya evaṃladdhanāmānaṃ.🔽Tesaṃ pana uppattikathā dīghanikāye sakkapañhasuttavaṇṇanāya vitthāritā. Tenāti tena
analyzed: devānam tāvatiṃsānam ti paṭhamam abhinibbatte tettiṃsa deva putte upādāya evaṃladdha nāmānam  tesam pana uppatti kathā dīgha nikāye sakka pañha sutta vaṇṇanāya vitthāritā tena ati tena
translated: The Thirty-three Gods: the Thirty-three Gods who were first reborn there.

original: ārocanena, tena vā puññakārakānaṃ appakabhāvena. Dibbā vata, bho, kāyā parihāyissantīti
analyzed: ārocanena tena vā puñña kārakānam appaka bhāvena dibbāḥ vata bho kāyā parihāyissanti iti
translated: The story of their rebirth is told in detail in the commentary to the Sakkapañhasutta of the Digha Nikaya. By that: by that announcement, or by the fact that there are few who make merit.

original: navanavānaṃ devaputtānaṃ apātubhāvena devakāyā parihāyissanti, ramaṇīyaṃ dasayojanasahassaṃ
analyzed: nava navānam deva puttānam a pātubhāvena deva kāyā parihāyissanti ramaṇīyam dasa yojana sahassam
translated: The divine hosts will dwindle: because the new gods will not appear, the divine hosts will dwindle. Delightful: delightful for ten thousand leagues.

original: devanagaraṃ suññaṃ bhavissati. Paripūrissanti asurakāyāti cattāro apāyā paripūrissanti.
analyzed: deva nagaram suññam bhavissati paripūrissanti asura kāyā ati cattāro apāyā paripūrissanti
translated: the city of the gods will be empty. The four lower worlds will be filled up.

original: Iminā “mayaṃ paripuṇṇe devanagare devasaṅghamajjhe nakkhattaṃ kīḷituṃ na labhissāmā”ti
analyzed: iminā mayam paripuṇṇe devanagare deva saṅgha majjhe nakkhattam kīḷitum na labhissāma ati
translated: They are displeased because they will not be able to play the nakkhatta game in the full city of the gods in the midst of the assembly of gods.

original: anattamanā honti. Sukkapakkhepi imināva upāyena attho veditabbo.
analyzed: anattamanāḥ honti sukkapakkhe pi iminā ava upāyena atthaḥ veditabbaḥ
translated: The meaning should be understood in the same way in the bright fortnight.

original: Bhūtapubbaṃ, bhikkhave, sakko devānamindoti attano sakkadevarājakālaṃ sandhāya katheti.
analyzed: bhūta pubbam bhikkhave sakkaḥ devānamindo ti attanaḥ sakka devarāja kālam sandhāya kathā iti
translated: Once, bhikkhus, Sakka, lord of the gods,🔽either he speaks taking the intention of one Sakka or he speaks taking the intention of all Sakkas.

original: Ekassa vā sakkassa ajjhāsayaṃ gahetvā kathetīti vuttaṃ. Anunayamānoti anubodhayamāno.
analyzed: ekassa vā sakkassa ajjhāsayam gahetvā katheti iti vuttam anunayamānaḥ ti anubodhayamānaḥ
translated: He exhorts: he instructs.

original: Tāyaṃ velāyanti tasmiṃ kāle.
analyzed: tāyam velāyanti tasmin kāle
translated: At that time: at that occasion.

original: Pāṭihāriyapakkhañcāti ettha pāṭihāriyapakkho nāma antovasse temāsaṃ nibaddhuposatho,
analyzed: pāṭihāriya pakkham ca ati ettha pāṭihāriya pakkhaḥ nāma antovasse temāsam nibaddha uposathaḥ
translated: The fortnight of miracles: here the fortnight of miracles is the regular observance day within the three months of the rainy season.

original: taṃ asakkontassa dvinnaṃ pavāraṇānaṃ antare ekamāsaṃ nibaddhuposatho, tampi asakkontassa
analyzed: tam a sakkontassa dvinnam pavāraṇānam antare eka māsam nibaddha uposathaḥ tam pi a sakkontassa
translated: If one is unable to do that, the regular observance day for one month between the two Invitation days. If one is unable to do that,

original: paṭhamapavāraṇato paṭṭhāya eko addhamāso pāṭihāriyapakkhoyeva nāma. Aṭṭhaṅgasusamāgatanti
analyzed: paṭhama pavāraṇataḥ paṭṭhāya ekaḥ addha māso nāma aṭṭhaṅga su samāgatam ti
translated: The first fortnight beginning with the new-moon day is called the “fortnight of miracles.”🔽Endowed with eight factors: endowed with eight good qualities.

original: aṭṭhahi guṇaṅgehi samannāgataṃ. Yopissa mādiso naroti yopi satto mādiso bhaveyya.
analyzed: aṭṭhahi guṇaṅgehi samannāgatam yo pi sattaḥ mādisaḥ bhaveyya
translated: If a man were like me: if a being were like me.

original: Sakkopi kira vuttappakārassa uposathakammassa guṇaṃ jānitvā dve devalokasampattiyo🔽pahāya māsassa aṭṭha vāre uposathaṃ upavasati. Tasmā evamāha. Aparo nayo – yopissa
analyzed: sakkaḥ api kira vutta ppakārassa uposatha kammassa guṇam jānitvā dve deva loka sampattiyaḥ  pahāya māsassa aṭṭha vāre uposatham upavasati tasmai evam āha aparaḥ nayaḥ
translated: Sakka, it seems, knowing the good quality of the observance-day rite described,🔽abandoned the two kinds of success in the divine world and observed the observance day on the fourteenth, fifteenth, and eighth of the fortnight. That is why he said “If a man were like me.”

original: mādiso naroti yopi satto mādiso assa, mayā pattaṃ sampattiṃ pāpuṇituṃ iccheyyāti
analyzed: mādisaḥ naraḥ iti yaḥ api sattaḥ mādisaḥ assa mayā pattam sampattim pāpuṇitum iccheyya ati
translated: Another method: if a being were like me, would wish to attain the success that I have attained.

original: attho. Sakkā hi evarūpena uposathakammena sakkasampattiṃ pāpuṇitunti ayamettha adhippāyo.
analyzed: attho sakkā hi evarūpena uposatha kammena sakka sampattim pāpuṇitum ti ayam ettha adhippāyaḥ
translated: For it is possible to attain the success of Sakka by means of such an observance-day rite. This is the meaning here.🔽Who has lived the holy life: who has completed the holy life.

original: Vusitavāti vutthavāso. Katakaraṇīyoti catūhi maggehi kattabbakiccaṃ katvā ṭhito.
analyzed: vusitavā ati vuttha vāsaḥ kata karaṇīyaḥ iti catūhi maggehi kattabba kiccam katvā ṭhitaḥ
translated: Who has done his task: who has stood firm after doing the task that should be done by means of the four paths.

original: Ohitabhāroti khandhabhārakilesabhāraabhisaṅkhārabhāre otāretvā ṭhito. Anuppattasadatthoti
analyzed: ohita bhāraḥ ti khandha bhāra kilesa bhāra abhisaṅkhāra bhāre otāretvā ṭhitaḥ anuppatta sadattho ti
translated: Who has cast off the burden: who has stood firm after casting off the burden of the aggregates, the burden of defilements, and the burden of the formations. Who has attained his own goal:

original: sadattho vuccati arahattaṃ, taṃ anuppatto. Parikkhīṇabhavasaṃyojanoti yena saṃyojanena🔽baddho bhavesu ākaḍḍhīyati, tassa khīṇattā parikkhīṇabhavasaṃyojano. Sammadaññā vimuttoti
analyzed: sat atthaḥ vuccati arahattam tam an uppatto parikkhīṇa bhava saṃyojanaḥ ti yena saṃyojanena  baddhaḥ bhavesu ākaḍḍhīyati tassa khīṇa ttā parikkhīṇa bhava saṃyojano sammad aññā vimutto ti
translated: The meaning of “well-gone” is Arahantship, and he has reached that. He has “cut off the round of births and deaths” : by the cutting off of the fetter by which he was bound and dragged around in the round of births and deaths, he has cut off the round of births and deaths. “He has attained to perfect knowledge and is liberated” :🔽

original: hetunā nayena kāraṇena jānitvā vimutto. Kallaṃ vacanāyāti yuttaṃ vattuṃ.
analyzed: hetunā nayena kāraṇena jānitvā vimuttaḥ kallam vacanāya ati yuttam vattum
translated: The meaning of “well-gone” is arahatship, and he has reached that. He has “cut off the round of rebirths” : by the cutting off of the fetter by which he was bound and dragged around in the round of rebirths, he has cut off the round of rebirths. “He is liberated by right understanding” : he is liberated by knowing the cause, the method, the reason. “He is worthy of offerings” : it is proper to make offerings to him.

original: Yopissa mādiso naroti yopi mādiso khīṇāsavo assa, sopi evarūpaṃ uposathaṃ upavaseyyāti🔽uposathakammassa guṇaṃ jānanto evaṃ vadeyya. Aparo nayo yopissa mādiso naroti yopi🔽satto mādiso assa, mayā pattaṃ sampattiṃ pāpuṇituṃ iccheyyāti attho. Sakkā hi evarūpena
analyzed: yaḥ pi sa mādisaḥ naraḥ ati yaḥ pi mādisaḥ khīṇa āsavaḥ assa saḥ api evarūpam uposatham upavaseyya ati  uposatha kammassa guṇam jānantaḥ evam vadeyya aparaḥ nayaḥ yopissa mādisaḥ yopi  sattaḥ mādisaḥ assa mayā pattam sampattim pāpuṇitum iccheyya ati attho sakkā hi evarūpena
translated: “If a man like me” : if a person like me, a cankerless saint, were to observe such a uposatha,

original: uposathakammena khīṇāsavasampattiṃ pāpuṇitunti ayamettha adhippāyo. Aṭṭhamaṃ uttānatthameva.🔽9. Sukhumālasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: uposatha kammena khīṇāsava sampattim pāpuṇitum ti ayam ettha adhippāyaḥ aṭṭhamam uttānattham eva 🔽sukhumāla sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: knowing the virtues of the uposatha rite, he would speak thus. Another interpretation: “If a being like me” : if a being were to desire to attain the excellence attained by me. For it is possible to attain the excellence of a cankerless saint by means of such a uposatha rite. This is the intended meaning. The eighth sutta is straightforward in meaning.

original: 39. Navame sukhumāloti niddukkho. Paramasukhumāloti paramaniddukkho. Accantasukhumāloti
analyzed: navame sukhumālo ti niddukkho parama sukhumālo ti parama niddukkho accanta sukhumālo ti
translated: 9. The ninth stanza, “The delicate,” etc., refers to the absence of suffering. The tenth stanza, “The most delicate,” etc., refers to the absence of the highest suffering. The eleventh stanza, “The very delicate,” etc., refers to the absence of constant suffering.

original: satataniddukkho. Imaṃ bhagavā kapilapure nibbattakālato paṭṭhāya niddukkhabhāvaṃ🔽gahetvā āha, cariyakāle pana tena anubhūtadukkhassa anto natthīti. Ekatthāti ekissā🔽pokkharaṇiyā. Uppalaṃ vappatīti uppalaṃ ropeti. Sā nīluppalavanasañchannā hoti. Padumanti
analyzed: satata niddukkhaḥ imam bhagavā kapilapure nibbatta kālataḥ paṭṭhāya niddukkha bhāvam  gahetvā āha cariya kāle pana tena anubhūta dukkhassa antaḥ natthi iti ekattha ati ekissā  pokkharaṇiyā uppalam vappati iti uppalam ropeti sā nīla uppala vana sañchannā hoti padumanti
translated: The Blessed One spoke these stanzas, taking the absence of suffering from the time of his birth in Kapilavatthu,

original: paṇḍarapadumaṃ. Puṇḍarīkanti rattapadumaṃ. Evaṃ itarāpi dve padumapuṇḍarīkavanehi🔽sañchannā honti. Bodhisattassa kira sattaṭṭhavassikakāle rājā amacce pucchi – “taruṇadārakā🔽katarakīḷikaṃ piyāyantī”ti? Udakakīḷikaṃ devāti. Tato rājā kuddālakammakārake sannipātetvā
analyzed: rattapadumam evam itarā api dve  sañchannāḥ honti bodhisattassa kira satta ṭṭhavassika kāle rājā amacce pucchi taruṇa dārakā  katara kīḷikam piyāyanti iti udaka kīḷikam deva ati tatas rājā kuddāla kamma kārake sannipātetvā
translated: but there is no end to the suffering he experienced during his life as a Bodhisatta. “In one place” means in one lotus tank. “He planted the blue lotus” means he planted the blue lotus. It was covered with blue lotuses. “The red lotus” means the white lotus. “The white lotus” means the red lotus. Thus the other two were covered with forests of lotuses and white lotuses.🔽When the Bodhisatta was seven or eight years old, the king asked his ministers, “What games do young boys like?”

original: pokkharaṇiṭṭhānāni gaṇhāpesi. Atha sakko devarājā āvajjento taṃ pavattiṃ ñatvā –
analyzed: pokkharaṇi ṭṭhānāni gaṇhāpesi atha sakkaḥ devarājā āvajjentaḥ tam pavattim ñatvā
translated: “Water games, your majesty.” Then the king assembled the workers and had them select the sites for the lotus tanks. Then Sakka, king of the gods, who was observing this, understood what was happening and thought,🔽“

original: “na yutto mahāsattassa mānusakaparibhogo, dibbaparibhogo yutto”ti vissakammaṃ āmantetvā
analyzed: na yuttaḥ mahāsattassa mānusaka paribhogaḥ dibba paribhogaḥ yuttaḥ iti vissa kammam āmantetvā
translated: “It is not fitting for a Great Being to use human enjoyments; celestial enjoyments are fitting for him.” He then addressed Vissakamma,

original: – “gaccha, tāta, mahāsattassa kīḷābhūmiyaṃ pokkharaṇiyo māpehī”ti āha. Kīdisā hontu,🔽devāti? Apagatakalalakaddamā hontu vippakiṇṇamaṇimuttapavāḷikā sattaratanamayapākāraparikkhittā
analyzed: gaccha tāta mahāsattassa kīḷā bhūmiyam pokkharaṇiyaḥ mā apehi iti āha kīdisāḥ hontu  devā ati apagata kalala kaddamāḥ hontu vippakiṇṇa maṇi mutta pavāḷikā satta ratana maya pākāra parikkhittā
translated: saying: “Go, my dear, and have lotus-pools made in the playground of the Great Being.” “What sort of pools shall they be,🔽Lord?” “They shall be free from mud and slime, and shall be strewn with precious gems and pearls. They shall be surrounded by sevenfold walls of the seven precious substances,

original: pavāḷamayauṇhīsehi maṇimayasopānabāhukehi suvaṇṇarajatamaṇimayaphalakehi sopānehi🔽samannāgatā. Suvaṇṇarajatamaṇipavāḷamayā cettha nāvā hontu, suvaṇṇanāvāya rajatapallaṅko
analyzed: pavāḷa maya oṇhīsehi maṇi maya sopāna bāhukehi suvaṇṇa rajata maṇi maya phalakehi sopānehi  samannāgatā suvaṇṇa rajata maṇi pavāḷa mayā ca ittha nāvāḥ hontu suvaṇṇa nāvāya rajata pallaṅko
translated: and shall be provided with flights of steps made of three precious substances, gold, silver and gems.🔽The boats shall be made of gold, silver, gems and pearls. In the golden boat there shall be a silver couch,

original: hotu, rajatanāvāya suvaṇṇapallaṅko, maṇināvāya pavāḷapallaṅko, pavāḷanāvāya maṇipallaṅko,
analyzed: hotu rajata nāvāya suvaṇṇa pallaṅkaḥ maṇi nāvāya pavāḷa pallaṅkaḥ pavāḷa nāvāya maṇi pallaṅkaḥ
translated: in the silver boat a golden couch, in the gem boat a pearl couch, and in the pearl boat a gem couch.

original: suvaṇṇarajatamaṇipavāḷamayāva udakasecananāḷikā hontu, pañcavaṇṇehi ca padumehi sañchannā
analyzed: udakasecana nāḷikāḥ hontu pañcavaṇṇehi ca padumehi sañchannā
translated: The water-scoops shall be made of gold, silver, gems and pearls, and the pools shall be covered with lotuses of five colours,

original: hontūti. “Sādhu, devā”ti vissakammadevaputto sakkassa paṭissutvā rattibhāge otaritvā
analyzed: hontu uti sādhu devā ti vissakammadeva putto sakkassa paṭissutvā ratti bhāge otaritvā
translated: “Very well, your majesty,” and Vissakamma, having agreed, descended during the night

original: rañño gāhāpitapokkharaṇiṭṭhānesuyeva teneva niyāmena pokkharaṇiyo māpesi.🔽Nanu cetā apagatakalalakaddamā, kathamettha padumāni pupphiṃsūti? So kira tāsu pokkharaṇīsu
analyzed: raññaḥ gāhāpita pokkharaṇi ṭṭhānesu yeva tena iva niyāmena pokkharaṇiyaḥ māpesi  nanu ca itā apagata kalala kaddamā katham ettha padumāni so kira tāsu pokkharaṇīsu
translated: and had the lotus-ponds made in the very places where the king had had his ponds.

original: tattha tattha suvaṇṇarajatamaṇipavāḷamayā khuddakanāvāyo māpetvā “etā kalalakaddamapūritā
analyzed: tattha tattha suvaṇṇa rajata maṇi pavāḷa mayā khuddaka nāvāyaḥ māpetvā etā kalala kaddama pūritā
translated: But how could the lotuses have blossomed there when the mud had not been removed? It is said that he had small boats made of gold, silver, gems and coral

original: ca hontu, pañcavaṇṇāni cettha padumāni pupphantū”ti adhiṭṭhāsi. Evaṃ pañcavaṇṇāni
analyzed: ca hontu pañcavaṇṇāni ca ittha padumāni pupphantu iti adhiṭṭhāsi evam pañcavaṇṇāni
translated: and had them filled with mud and had it resolved that “let the lotuses blossom there in five colours.” So the lotuses blossomed in five colours,

original: padumāni pupphiṃsu, reṇuvaṭṭiyo uggantvā udakapiṭṭhaṃ ajjhottharitvā vicaranti. Pañcavidhā
analyzed: padumāni reṇu vaṭṭiyaḥ uggantvā udaka piṭṭham ajjhottharitvā vicaranti pañcavidhā
translated: and the bees flew up and covered the surface of the water and moved about. The bees moved about humming in five colours.

original: bhamaragaṇā upakūjantā vicaranti. Evaṃ tā māpetvā vissakammo devapurameva gato. Tato
analyzed: bhamara gaṇāḥ upakūjantāḥ vicaranti evam tāḥ māpetvā vissa kammaḥ deva puram eva gataḥ tatas
translated: Having had them made in this way, Vissakamma went to the city of the gods. Then,

original: vibhātāya rattiyā mahājano disvā “mahāpurissassa māpitā bhavissantī”ti gantvā rañño
analyzed: vibhātāya rattiyā mahā janaḥ disvā mahāpurissassa māpitāḥ bhavissanti iti gantvā rañño
translated: when the night had passed, the people saw and went and said, “They will be made by a great man.”

original: ārocesi. Rājā mahājanaparivāro gantvā pokkharaṇiyo disvā “mama puttassa puññiddhiyā
analyzed: ārocesi rājā mahā jana parivāraḥ gantvā pokkharaṇiyaḥ disvā mama puttassa puññiddhiyā
translated: and he reported it. The king went with a great crowd of people, and when he saw the lotus-ponds, he was pleased, thinking: “They must have been made by the spirits through the merit of my son.”

original: devatāhi māpitā bhavissantī”ti attamano ahosi. Tato paṭṭhāya mahāpuriso udakakīḷikaṃ agamāsi.
analyzed: devatāhi māpitāḥ bhavissanti iti atta manaḥ ahosi tatas paṭṭhāya mahā puriso udakakīḷikam agamāsi
translated: From that time on the Great Man went to play in the water.

original: Yāvadeva mamatthāyāti ettha yāvadevāti payojanāvadhiniyāmavacanaṃ, yāva mameva atthāya,
analyzed: yāvat eva mamatthāya ati ettha yāvat eva ati payojana avadhi niyāma vacanam mama eva atthāya
translated: As for me: the word yāvadeva in the passage, “As for me, I have no use for them” is a term for limiting the purpose, meaning “as far as I am concerned.”

original: natthettha aññaṃ kāraṇanti attho. Na kho panassāhanti na kho panassa ahaṃ. Akāsikaṃ🔽candananti asaṇhaṃ candanaṃ. Kāsikaṃ, bhikkhave, su me taṃ veṭhananti, bhikkhave,
analyzed: nattha ittha aññam kāraṇanti attho na kho pana assa aham ti na kho pana assa aham a kāsikam  candanam ti asaṇham candanam kāsikam bhikkhave su me tam veṭhanan ti bhikkhave
translated: The meaning is: “There is no other reason for them.” Na kho panassāhaṃ means “I am not his.”🔽As for me, I have no use for them: asaṅkhaṃ candanaṃ means “unrefined sandalwood.” Kāsikaṃ, bhikkhave, su me taṃ veṭhananti means “Bhikkhus, as for me, I have even a Kāsi garment for a turban.”

original: veṭhanampi me kāsikaṃ hoti. Ettha hi suiti ca tanti ca nipātamattaṃ, meti sāmivacanaṃ.
analyzed: veṭhanam pi me kāsikam hoti ettha hi ca ca nipāta mattam mā iti sāmi vacanam
translated: Here su is a mere particle, and me is a possessive form.

original: Veṭhanampi me saṇhameva hotīti dasseti. Kāsikā kañcukāti pārupanakañcukopi saṇhakañcukova.
analyzed: veṭhanam pi me saṇham eva hoti iti dassa iti kāsikā kañcukā ati pārupana kañcukaḥ api saṇha kañcukaḥ uva
translated: Veṭhanampi me saṇhameva hotīti means “Even a turban for me is soft.” Kāsikā kañcukāti means “even a Kāsi garment for a cloak is soft.”

original: Setacchattaṃ dhārīyatīti mānusakasetacchattampi dibbasetacchattampi uparidhāritameva
analyzed: setacchattam dhārīyati iti mānusaka setacchattam pi dibba setacchattam pi upari dhāritam eva
translated: Setacchattaṃ dhārīyati means “a white parasol is held over me.”

original: hoti. Mā naṃ phusi sītaṃ vāti mā etaṃ bodhisattaṃ sītaṃ vā uṇhādīsu vā aññataraṃ phusatūti attho.🔽Tayo pāsādā ahesunti bodhisatte kira soḷasavassuddesike jāte suddhodanamahārājā “puttassa🔽vasanakapāsāde kāressāmī”ti vaḍḍhakino sannipātāpetvā bhaddakena nakkhattamuhuttena
analyzed: hoti mā nam phusi sītam vā ati mā etam bodhisattam sītam vā uṇha ādīsu vā aññataram phusatu iti attho  tayo pāsādāḥ ahesunti bodhisatte kira soḷasa vassuddesike jāte suddhodana mahā rājā puttassa  vasanaka pāsāde kāressāmi iti vaḍḍhakino sannipāta apetvā bhaddakena nakkhatta muhuttena
translated: Let not cold touch him: let not cold or heat or any of the rest touch this Bodhisatta.

original: navabhūmikataparikammaṃ kāretvā tayo pāsāde kārāpesi. Te sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ. Hemantikotiādīsu
analyzed: nava bhūmi kata parikammam kāretvā tayo pāsāde kārāpesi te sandhāya itam vuttam hemantika uti ādīsu
translated: There were three palaces: when the Bodhisatta was sixteen years old, it seems, King Suddhodana had the thought: “I shall have a palace built for my son to live in.” So he assembled master-builders, and on an auspicious day and at an auspicious moment he had them clear the ground for the nine-storied palace and have three palaces built. This is what is referred to here. The winter one, etc.:

original: yattha sukhaṃ hemante vasituṃ, ayaṃ hemantiko. Itaresupi eseva nayo. Ayaṃ panettha
analyzed: yattha sukham hemante vasitum ayam hemantikaḥ itaresu pi eṣa iva nayaḥ ayam pana ittha
translated: where it is pleasant to live in winter, that is the winter one. The same method applies in the other two cases.

original: vacanattho – hemante vāso hemantaṃ, hemantaṃ arahatīti hemantiko. Itaresupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: vacana atthaḥ hemante vāsaḥ hemantam hemantam arahati iti hemantikaḥ itaresu pi esa eva nayaḥ
translated: But the word-meaning here is as follows. The winter is the living in winter; the winter one is he who deserves the winter. The same method applies in the other two cases.

original: Tattha hemantiko pāsādo navabhūmako ahosi, bhūmiyo panassa uṇhautuggāhāpanatthāya
analyzed: tattha hemantikaḥ pāsādaḥ nava bhūmakaḥ ahosi bhūmiyaḥ panassa
translated: There the winter palace was nine stories high, and the floors were made

original: nīcā ahesuṃ. Tattha dvāravātapānāni suphusitakavāṭāni ahesuṃ nibbivarāni. Cittakammampi🔽karontā tattha tattha pajjalite aggikkhandheyeva akaṃsu. Bhūmattharaṇaṃ panettha🔽kambalamayaṃ, tathā sāṇivitānanivāsanapārupanaveṭhanāni. Vātapānāni uṇhaggāhāpanatthaṃ
analyzed: nīcāḥ ahesum tattha dvāra vāta pānāni su phusita kavāṭāni ahesum nibbivarāni citta kammam pi  karontā tattha tattha pajjalite aggi kkhandheya iva akaṃsu bhūmattharaṇam pana ittha  kambala mayam tathā sāṇi vitāna nivāsana pārupana veṭhanāni vātapānāni
translated: and the windows and doors were well-fitting and closed tightly. And when they were making the decorations, they did them in the places where the flames of the fire had been. But the floor-covering here🔽was made of blankets, and so were the bedspreads, the curtains, the bed linen, and the cushions. And the windows were made🔽for the purpose of letting in the heat.

original: divā vivaṭāni rattiṃ pihitāni honti.
analyzed: divā vivaṭāni rattim pihitāni honti
translated: and the doors and windows were well closed and well fastened. And in making the decorations they made only flames of fire here and there. But the floor covering here was made of blankets, and so were the bedspreads, the rugs, the sheets, the blankets, and the pillows. And the windows were opened by day and closed at night in order to keep out the heat.

original: Gimhiko pana pañcabhūmako ahosi. Sītautuggāhāpanatthaṃ panettha bhūmiyo uccā asambādhā🔽ahesuṃ. Dvāravātapānāni nātiphusitāni savivarāni sajālāni ahesuṃ. Cittakamme uppalāni
analyzed: gimhikaḥ pana pañca bhūmakaḥ ahosi sītautuggāhāpana attham pana ittha bhūmiyaḥ uccāḥ asambādhā  ahesum dvāra vāta pānāni na ati phusitāni sa vivarāni sa jālāni ahesum citta kamme uppalāni
translated: But the winter palace was five stories high. And the floors here were high and spacious

original: padumāni puṇḍarīkāniyeva akaṃsu. Bhūmattharaṇaṃ panettha dukūlamayaṃ, tathā sāṇivitānanivāsanapārupanaveṭhanāni.
analyzed: bhūmattharaṇam dukūla mayam tathā sāṇi vitāna nivāsana pārupana veṭhanāni
translated: and the doors and windows were not too tightly closed, but were left slightly open, and had lattice-work. And in making the decorations they made only lotuses here and there. But the floor covering here was made of fine silk, and so were the bedspreads, the rugs, the sheets, the blankets, and the pillows.

original: Vātapānasamīpesu cettha nava cāṭiyo ṭhapetvā udakassa pūretvā nīluppalādīhi sañchādenti.
analyzed: vāta pāna samīpesu ca ittha nava cāṭiyaḥ ṭhapetvā udakassa pūretvā nīluppala ādīhi sañchādenti
translated: And near the windows they placed nine fans and filled them with water, covering them with blue and red and white lotuses.

original: Tesu tesu padesesu udakayantāni karonti, yehi deve vassante viya udakadhārā nikkhamanti.
analyzed: tesu tesu padesesu udaka yantāni karonti yehi deve vassante viya udaka dhārāḥ nikkhamanti
translated: In various places they made water-spouts, from which water flowed out as if from rain-clouds.

original: Antopāsāde tattha tattha kalalapūrā doṇiyo ṭhapetvā pañcavaṇṇāni padumāni ropayiṃsu.🔽Pāsādamatthake sukkhamahiṃsacammaṃ bandhitvā yantaṃ parivattetvā yāva chadanapiṭṭhiyā
analyzed: antopāsāde tattha tattha kalalapūrāḥ doṇiyaḥ ṭhapetvā pañca vaṇṇāni padumāni ropayiṃsu  pāsāda matthake sukkham ahiṃsa cammam bandhitvā yantam parivattetvā yāva chadana piṭṭhiyā
translated: In the inner quadrangle they set out pots filled with mud and planted five-coloured lotus-flowers.

original: pāsāṇe āropetvā tasmiṃ vissajjenti. Tesaṃ camme pavaṭṭantānaṃ saddo meghagajjitaṃ
analyzed: pāsāṇe āropetvā tasmin vissajjenti tesam camme pavaṭṭantānam saddaḥ megha gajjitam
translated: On the top of the palace they fastened a dry elephant-hide to a machine, and by working the machine they made the hide flap about,

original: viya hoti. Dvāravātapānāni panettha divā pihitāni honti rattiṃ vivaṭāni.
analyzed: viya hoti dvāra vāta pānāni pana ittha divā pihitāni honti rattim vivaṭāni
translated: and the sound it made resembled the roar of thunder. The windows and doors were closed by day and opened at night.

original: Vassiko sattabhūmako ahosi. Bhūmiyo panettha dvinnampi utūnaṃ gāhāpanatthāya nātiuccā
analyzed: vassikaḥ satta bhūmakaḥ ahosi bhūmiyaḥ pana ittha dvinnam pi utūnam gāhāpana atthāya na ati uccā
translated: The palace had seven storeys, but the floors were not very high,

original: nātinīcā akaṃsu. Ekaccāni dvāravātapānāni suphusitāni, ekaccāni savivarāni. Tattha
analyzed: na ati nīcāḥ akaṃsu ekaccāni dvāra vāta pānāni su phusitāni ekaccāni sa vivarāni tattha
translated: so that they might be suitable for both seasons. Some of the windows and doors were closed, and some were open.

original: cittakammampi kesuci ṭhānesu pajjalitaaggikkhandhavasena, kesuci jātassaravasena
analyzed: citta kammam pi kesuci ṭhānesu pajjalita aggi kkhandha vasena kesuci jāta ssara vasena
translated: In some places the decorative work was like a mass of blazing fire, in some like a stream of water.

original: kataṃ. Bhūmattharaṇādīni panettha kambaladukūlavasena ubhayamissakāni. Ekacce dvāravātapānā
analyzed: katam bhūmattharaṇa ādīni pana ittha kambala dukūla vasena ubhaya missakāni ekacce dvāra vāta pānā
translated: But here the floor-coverings, etc., are a mixture of both, being made of blankets and woven wool. Some doors and windows are made of woven wool.

original: rattiṃ vivaṭā divā pihitā, ekacce divā vivaṭā rattiṃ pihitā. Tayopi pāsādā ubbedhena
analyzed: rattim vivaṭā divā pihitā ekacce divā vivaṭā rattim pihitā pāsādāḥ ubbedhena
translated: The floor-coverings were of both blankets and fine cloth. Some of the windows and doors were open at night and closed during the day, and some were open during the day and closed at night. All three palaces were the same in height.

original: samappamāṇā. Bhūmikāsu pana nānattaṃ ahosi.
analyzed: bhūmikāsu pana nānattam ahosi
translated: But there was a difference in the floors.

original: Evaṃ niṭṭhitesu pāsādesu rājā cintesi – “putto me vayappatto, chattamassa ussāpetvā
analyzed: evam niṭṭhitesu pāsādesu rājā cintesi putto me vaya pattaḥ chattamassa ussāpetvā
translated: When the palaces were finished, the king thought, “My son has now reached the age when he should be married. I shall have the royal parasol raised over him and

original: rajjasiriṃ passissāmī”ti. So sākiyānaṃ paṇṇāni pahiṇi – “putto me vayappatto, rajje
analyzed: rajja sirim passissāmi iti saḥ sākiyānam paṇṇāni pahiṇi putto me vaya pattaḥ rajje
translated: show him the glory of kingship.” He sent word to the Sakyans, “My son has now reached the age when he should be married. I shall install him in the kingship.

original: naṃ patiṭṭhāpessāmi, sabbe attano attano gehesu vayappattā, dārikā imaṃ gehaṃ pesentū”ti.
analyzed: nam patiṭṭhāpessāmi sabbe attanaḥ attanaḥ gehesu vaya pattāḥ dārikāḥ imam geham pesentu uti
translated: All of you should send your marriageable daughters to my house.”

original: Te sāsanaṃ sutvā – “kumāro kevalaṃ dassanakkhamo rūpasampanno, na kiñci sippaṃ jānāti,
analyzed: te sāsanam sutvā kumāraḥ kevalam dassana khamaḥ rūpa sampannaḥ na kiñci sippam jānāti
translated: When they heard the message, they said, “The prince is merely fit to be seen, endowed with beauty, but he does not know any craft.

translated: but I have passed over myself.” “Subject to old age” means having the nature of old age.

translated: “Living like this”: living by disdaining others in this way, or living by this kind of reflection.

analyzed: viharantaḥ ñatvā dhammam nirūpadhinti sabba upadhi virahitam nibbāna dhammam ñatvā sabbe

analyzed: made abhibhosmi iti sabbe tayo api made abhibhavim samatikkamim nekkhamme daṭṭhu
translated: Having seen the safety in renunciation:

analyzed: nibbāne khema bhāvam disvā nekkhammam daṭṭhu khemataḥ ti pi pāṭhaḥ nibbānam khemataḥ  disvā ati attho tassa me ahu ussāhaḥ iti tassa mayham tam nekkhamma saṅkhātam nibbānam
translated: having seen the state of safety in Nibbāna. There is also the reading “having seen the safety in renunciation,” the meaning of which is: having seen Nibbāna as a safe haven.

original: abhipassantassa ussāho ahu, vāyāmo ahosīti attho. Nāhaṃ bhabbo etarahi, kāmāni paṭisevitunti
analyzed: abhipassantassa ussāhaḥ ahu vā āyāmaḥ ahosi iti attho na aham bhabbaḥ etarahi kāmāni paṭisevitunti
translated: There was exertion for me: there was exertion for me who was looking forward to that Nibbāna called renunciation. The meaning is: there was effort. I am now unable to enjoy sensual pleasures:

original: ahaṃ dāni duvidhepi kāme paṭisevituṃ abhabbo. Anivatti bhavissāmīti pabbajjato ca
analyzed: aham dāni duvidhe api kāme paṭisevitum abhabbaḥ anivatti bhavissāmi iti pabbajjataḥ ca
translated: I am now unable to enjoy the two kinds of sensual pleasures. I will not turn back:

original: sabbaññutaññāṇato ca na nivattissāmi, anivattako bhavissāmi. Brahmacariyaparāyaṇoti🔽maggabrahmacariyaparāyaṇo jātosmīti attho. Iti imāhi gāthāhi mahābodhipallaṅke attano🔽āgamanīyavīriyaṃ kathesi.
analyzed: sabbaññu taññāṇataḥ ca na nivattissāmi a nivattakaḥ bhavissāmi brahmacariya parāyaṇaḥ ti  magga brahmacariya parāyaṇaḥ jātaḥ asmi iti iti imāhi gāthāhi mahā bodhi pallaṅke  āgamanīya vīriyam kathesi
translated: I will not turn back from going forth or from the knowledge of omniscience. I will not turn back, I will go forward.

original: 10. Ādhipateyyasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: ādhipateyya sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: I have become one who has gone forth to the spiritual life: the meaning is, I have become one who has gone forth to the path of spiritual life. Thus with these verses he spoke of his exertion in coming to the Great Bodhi Seat.

analyzed: dasame ādhipateyyāni iti jeṭṭhaka kāraṇataḥ nibbattāni atta ādhipateyya ntiādīsu attānam  jeṭṭhakam katvā nibbattitam guṇa jātam atta ādhipateyyam lokam jeṭṭhakam katvā nibbattitam

In the case of “predominance of self” and so on, the aggregate of states produced by making self the chief is “predominance of self.” That produced by making the world the chief is “predominance of the world.”🔽
