analyzed: loka ādhipateyyam navavidham lokuttara dhammam jeṭṭhakam katvā nibbattitam dhamma ādhipateyyam  na iti bhava abhava hetū iti iti bhavo iti bhavo iti evam āyatim na tassa tassa sampatti bhavassa  hetu otiṇṇaḥ ti anupaviṭṭhaḥ yassa hi jāti anta upaviṭṭhā saḥ jātiyā otiṇṇaḥ nāma jarā ādīsu pi  esa iva nayaḥ kevalassa dukkha kkhandhassa ati sakalassa vaṭṭa dukkha rāsissa anta kiriyā

In the case of “self-mastery” and so on, the self is made chief and the qualities produced are self-mastery. The world is made chief and the qualities produced are world-mastery. The nine-factored supramundane Dhamma is made chief and the qualities produced are Dhamma-mastery.

original: Upaṭṭhitāti catusatipaṭṭhānavasena upaṭṭhitā. Upaṭṭhitattāva asammuṭṭhā. Passaddho
analyzed: upaṭṭhitā ti catusati paṭṭhāna vasena upaṭṭhitā upaṭṭhita ttā āva asammuṭṭhā passaddhaḥ
translated: “Established”: established by means of the four foundations of mindfulness. Because of being established, they are “unconfused.”

original: kāyoti nāmakāyo ca karajakāyo ca passaddho vūpasantadaratho. Passaddhattāva asāraddho.
analyzed: nāma kāyo ca karaja kāyo ca passaddhaḥ asāraddho
translated: “Calm” : the mental body and the material body are calm, with the fever of passion subsided. Because of being calm, they are “unagitated.”

original: Samāhitaṃ cittanti ārammaṇe cittaṃ sammā āhitaṃ suṭṭhu ṭhapitaṃ. Sammā āhitattāva🔽ekaggaṃ. Adhipatiṃ karitvāti jeṭṭhakaṃ katvā. Suddhaṃ attānaṃ pariharatīti suddhaṃ🔽nimmalaṃ katvā attānaṃ pariharati paṭijaggati, gopāyatīti attho. Ayañca yāva arahattamaggā
analyzed: samāhitam cittanti ārammaṇe cittam sammā āhitam suṭṭhu ṭhapitam sammā āhita ttā avasesa  ekaggam adhipatim karitvā iti jeṭṭhakam katvā suddham attānam pariharati iti suddham  nimmalam katvā attānam pariharati paṭijaggati gopāyati iti atthaḥ ayam ca yāva arahatta maggā
translated: “Concentrated”: the mind is well concentrated on the object, well placed. Because of being well concentrated, it is🔽“one-pointed.”🔽“Having made it the overlord”: having made it the chief.

original: pariyāyena suddhamattānaṃ pariharati nāma, phalappattova pana nippariyāyena suddhamattānaṃ pariharati.
analyzed: pariyāyena suddha mattānam pariharati nāma phala ppattaḥ uva pana nippariyāyena suddha mattānam pariharati
translated: “Maintaining themselves in purity”: maintaining themselves in purity, in stainlessness. The meaning is that they look after themselves, they guard themselves. And this is called “maintaining themselves in purity” by way of the path up to the path of arahantship. But one who has reached the fruition maintains himself in purity in the ultimate sense.🔽“Well proclaimed” and so forth are explained in detail in the Visuddhimagga.

original: Svākkhātotiādīni visuddhimagge vitthāritāni. Jānaṃ passaṃ viharantīti taṃ dhammaṃ
analyzed: svākkhāta uti ādīni visuddhi magge vitthāritāni jānam passam viharanti iti tam dhammam
translated: “Knowing and seeing, they live”: they live knowing and seeing that Dhamma.

original: jānantā passantā viharanti. Imāni kho, bhikkhave, tīṇi ādhipateyyānīti ettāvatā tīṇi
analyzed: jānantā passantā viharanti imāni kho bhikkhave tīṇi ādhipateyyāni iti ettāvatā tīṇi
translated: “These, bhikkhus, are the three dominants”: up to this point the three dominants are explained.

original: ādhipateyyāni lokiyalokuttaramissakāni kathitāni.🔽Pakubbatoti karontassa. Attā te purisa jānāti, saccaṃ vā yadi vā musāti yaṃ tvaṃ
analyzed: ādhipateyyāni lokiya lokuttara missakāni kathitāni  pakubbataḥ ti karontassa attā te purisa jānāti saccam vā yadi vā musā ati yam tvam
translated: The ‘lordships’ are said to be mundane and supramundane mixed together.

original: karosi, taṃ yadi vā yathāsabhāvaṃ yadi vā no yathāsabhāvanti tava attāva jānāti.
analyzed: karosi tam yadi vā yathāsabhāvam yadi vā no tava attā ava jānāti
translated: ‘Of one who does’: of one who is doing. ‘Your self knows, man, whether it is true or not’: your self knows whether what you are doing is in accordance with its true nature or not.

original: Iminā ca kāraṇena veditabbaṃ “pāpakammaṃ karontassa loke paṭicchannaṭṭhānaṃ nāma🔽natthī”ti. Kalyāṇanti sundaraṃ. Atimaññasīti atikkamitvā maññasi. Attānaṃ parigūhasīti
analyzed: iminā ca kāraṇena veditabbam pāpa kammam karontassa loke paṭicchanna ṭṭhānam nāma  na atthi iti kalyāṇam ti sundaram atimaññasi iti atikkamitvā maññasi attānam parigūhasi iti
translated: And for this reason it should be understood that there is no place in the world that is hidden from one who does evil.

original: yathā me attāpi na jānāti, evaṃ naṃ parigūhāmīti vāyamasi. Attādhipateyyakoti attajeṭṭhako.
analyzed: yathā me attā api na jānāti evam nam parigūhāmi iti vā ayam asi attā ādhipateyyakaḥ iti atta jeṭṭhakaḥ
translated: ‘Good’: beautiful. ‘You overrate yourself’: you overestimate yourself. ‘You conceal yourself’: you make an effort to conceal yourself as though your self did not know. ‘Your self is your lord’: your self is the chief.

original: Lokādhipoti lokajeṭṭhako. Nipakoti paññavā. Jhāyīti jhāyanto. Dhammādhipoti dhammajeṭṭhako.
analyzed: loka adhipo ti loka jeṭṭhakaḥ nipakaḥ ti paññavā jhāyī iti jhāyantaḥ dhamma adhipo ti dhamma jeṭṭhakaḥ
translated: ‘The world’s lord’: the world’s chief. ‘The wise’: the wise one. ‘The meditator’: the one who is meditating. ‘The Dhamma’s lord’: the Dhamma’s chief.

original: Saccaparakkamoti thiraparakkamo bhūtaparakkamo. Pasayha māranti māraṃ pasahitvā.
analyzed: sacca parakkamo ti thira parakkamaḥ bhūta parakkamaḥ pasayha māranti māram pasahitvā
translated: ‘Steadfast effort’: steadfast effort, true effort. ‘Having overcome Mara’: having overcome Mara.

original: Abhibhuyya antakanti idaṃ tasseva vevacanaṃ. Yo ca phusī jātikkhayaṃ padhānavāti
analyzed: abhibhuyya antakam ti idam tassa iva vevacanam yaḥ ca phusī jāti khayam padhāna vāti
translated: ‘Having overcome the End-maker’ is a synonym for that. ‘Who has touched the destruction of birth through striving’

original: yo jhāyī padhānavā māraṃ abhibhavitvā jātikkhayaṃ arahattaṃ phusi. So tādisoti so
analyzed: yaḥ jhāyī padhānavā māram abhibhavitvā jāti khayam arahattam so tādisaḥ iti so
translated: is the meditator who, through striving, has overcome Mara and touched the destruction of birth, that is, Arahantship. ‘Such a one’

original: tathāvidho tathāsaṇṭhito. Lokavidūti tayo loke vidite pākaṭe katvā ṭhito. Sumedhoti
analyzed: tathāvidhaḥ tathā saṇṭhitaḥ loka vidū ti tayaḥ loke vidite pākaṭe katvā ṭhitaḥ sumedhā iti
translated: is one of that kind, of that sort. ‘The world’s knower’ is one who, having made the three worlds known and evident, stands. ‘The wise one’

original: supañño. Sabbesu dhammesu atammayo munīti sabbe tebhūmakadhamme taṇhāsaṅkhātāya tammayatāya
analyzed: su paññaḥ sabbesu dhammesu a tammayaḥ muni iti sabbe tebhūmaka dhamme taṇhā saṅkhātāya tammaya tāya
translated: is the one with good understanding. ‘The sage who has no attachment to any state’ is the sage who has destroyed the taints, who has no attachment to any state in the three planes of becoming, because of the absence of any attachment called craving.

original: abhāvena atammayo khīṇāsavamuni kadāci katthaci na hīyati na parihīyatīti vuttaṃ hotīti.
analyzed: abhāvena atammayaḥ khīṇa āsava muni kadāci katthaci na hīyati na parihīyati iti vuttam hoti iti
translated: It is said that he does not decline, does not fall away, at any time, anywhere.

original: Devadūtavaggo catuttho.
analyzed: deva dūta vaggo catutthaḥ
translated: The fourth sub-chapter on the divine messengers is finished.

original: 5. Cūḷavaggo
analyzed: cūḷa vaggo
translated: The Minor Chapter

original: 1. Sammukhībhāvasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: sammukhībhāva sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Discourse on Presence

original: 41. Pañcamassa paṭhame sammukhībhāvāti sammukhībhāvena, vijjamānatāyāti attho. Pasavatīti
analyzed: pañcamassa paṭhame sammukhībhāva āti sammukhībhāvena vijjamāna tāya ati atthaḥ pasavati iti
translated: In the first of the fifth , ‘presence’ means presence in the sense of existing. ‘Possesses’ means🔽obtains. ‘Through the presence of faith’ : if there were no faith, there would be no

original: paṭilabhati. Saddhāya sammukhībhāvāti yadi hi saddhā na bhaveyya, deyyadhammo na
analyzed: paṭilabhati saddhāya sammukhībhāvā ati yadi hi saddhā na bhaveyya deyya dhammaḥ na
translated: giving.

original: bhaveyya, dakkhiṇeyyasaṅkhātā paṭiggāhakapuggalā na bhaveyyuṃ, kathaṃ puññakammaṃ
analyzed: bhaveyya dakkhiṇeyya saṅkhātā paṭiggāhaka puggalāḥ na bhaveyyum katham puñña kammam
translated: If there were no persons worthy of offerings, who are called “fields of merit,”🔽how could there be merit?

original: kareyya. Tesaṃ pana sammukhībhāvena sakkā kātunti tasmā “saddhāya sammukhībhāvā”tiādimāha.
analyzed: kareyya tesam pana sammukhībhāvena sakkā kātun ti tasmai saddhāya sammukhībhāva ati ādim āha
translated: If there were no persons to receive gifts, who would be worthy of gifts, then how could one make merit by giving? But it is possible to make merit by giving when they are present. Therefore he said “because of the presence of faith” and so on.

original: Ettha ca dve dhammā sulabhā deyyadhammā ceva dakkhiṇeyyā ca, saddhā pana dullabhā.
analyzed: ettha ca dve dhammā sulabhā deyya dhammā ca iva dakkhiṇeyyā ca saddhā pana dullabhā
translated: And here the two things that are easy to get are the things to be given and the worthy recipients, but faith is difficult to get.

original: Puthujjanassa hi saddhā athāvarā padavārena nānā hoti, teneva mahāmoggallānasadisopi
analyzed: puthujjanassa hi saddhā atha avarā padavārena nānā hoti tena iva mahā moggallāna sadisaḥ api
translated: For the faith of an ordinary man is low and varied, as it were, by turns. For this very reason, even a chief disciple like the Venerable Mahā Moggallāna,

analyzed: aggasāvakaḥ pāṭibhogaḥ bhavitum a sakkontaḥ āha dvinnam kho te aham āvuso dhammānam  pāṭibhogaḥ bhogānaṃ ca jīvitassa ca saddhāya pana tvaṃyeva pāṭibhogaḥ ti
translated: unable to be a guarantor, said: “I, friend, am a guarantor for two things, for wealth and for life, but you alone are a guarantor for faith” .

original: 2. Tiṭhānasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: tiṭhāna sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Exposition of the Second Jhana

original: 42. Dutiye vigatamalamaccherenāti vigatamacchariyamalena. Muttacāgoti vissaṭṭhacāgo.
analyzed: dutiye mutta cāgo ti vissaṭṭha cāgo
translated: In the second, “free from the hindrance of ill will” means free from the stain of ill will. “Free from the hindrance of cruelty” means free from the stain of cruelty.

analyzed: payata pāṇi iti dhota hatthaḥ assaddhaḥ hi satakkhattum hatthe dhovitvā api malina hatthaḥ uva
translated: “Hands and feet well-poised” : his hands and feet are well-poised, well-placed, because he has no need to stretch out or draw in his limbs.🔽For one without faith is as if his hands and feet were cut off, even though he may wash them a hundred times.

original: hoti, saddho pana dānābhiratattā malinahatthopi dhotahatthova. Vossaggaratoti vossaggasaṅkhāte
analyzed: hoti saddhaḥ pana dāna abhirata ttā malina hatthaḥ api dhota hatthaḥ uva vossagga rataḥ ti vossagga saṅkhāte
translated: But one who is faithful and delights in giving is one who gives even with dirty hands.🔽One who delights in relinquishing is one who delights in giving, which is called “relinquishing.”

original: dāne rato. Yācayogoti yācituṃ yutto, yācakehi vā yogo assātipi yācayogo. Dānasaṃvibhāgaratoti
analyzed: dāne rataḥ yāca yogo ti yācitum yuttaḥ yācakehi vā yogaḥ yāca yogaḥ dāna saṃvibhāga rataḥ ti
translated: One who is worthy of gifts is one who is fit to receive gifts or one who is connected with those who ask for gifts.

original: dānaṃ dadanto saṃvibhāgañca karonto dānasaṃvibhāgarato nāma hoti.🔽Dassanakāmo sīlavatanti dasapi yojanāni vīsampi tiṃsampi yojanasatampi gantvā sīlasampanne
analyzed: dānam dadantaḥ saṃvibhāgam ca karontaḥ dāna saṃvibhāga rataḥ nāma hoti  dassana kāmaḥ dasa pi yojanāni vīsampi tiṃsampi yojana satampi gantvā sīla sampanne
translated: One who delights in giving and sharing is one who delights in giving and in sharing what he has given.

original: daṭṭhukāmo hoti pāṭaliputtakabrāhmaṇo viya saddhātissamahārājā viya ca. Pāṭaliputtassa
analyzed: daṭṭhu kāmaḥ hoti pāṭaliputtaka brāhmaṇaḥ viya saddhātissa mahā rājā viya ca pāṭaliputtassa
translated: One who is eager to see virtuous persons is one who is eager to see those endowed with virtue, even if he has to go ten, twenty, or thirty leagues to see them, like the brahmin of Pāṭaliputta and King Mahāsudassana.

analyzed: kira nagara dvāre sālāya nisinnā dve brāhmaṇā kāḷavalli maṇḍapa vāsi mahā nāga ttherassa

translated: Hearing a talk on the qualities of the Elder Mahā-Tissa, who lived in the Kāḷavellināga Grove, they said, “We must go and see that bhikkhu.” And the two of them set out.

analyzed: ekaḥ antara āmagge kālam akāsi ekaḥ samudda tīram patvā nāvāya mahā tittha paṭṭane oruyha
translated: But one of them died on the way. The other reached the sea coast, and after going on board a ship at Mahātittha, he landed at

analyzed: anurādha puram āgantvā kāḷavalli maṇḍapaḥ kuhinti pucchi rohaṇa janapada iti saḥ anupubbena
translated: and asked, “Where is the Black Rock Pavilion?” “In the Rohaṇa country.” He went there

analyzed: therassa vasanaṭṭhānam patvā cūḷa nagara gāme dhura ghare nivāsam gahetvā therassa āhāram  sampādetvā pātova vuṭṭhāya therassa vasanaṭṭhānam pucchitvā gantvā jana pariyante

analyzed: ṭhitaḥ theram dūratas vā āgacchantam disvā sakim tattha iva ṭhitaḥ vanditvā punar upasaṅkamitvā

analyzed: adhivāsana tthāya sahana tthāya khamana tthāya
translated: for the sake of endurance, for the sake of patience, for the sake of forgiveness.

original: Ettake ṭhāne satthā āṇāpetvā āṇattiṃ pavattetvā idāni samādapento yato kho, bhikkhavetiādimāha.
analyzed: ettake ṭhāne satthā āṇāpetvā āṇattim pavattetvā idāni samādapentaḥ yatas kho bhikkhave ti ādim āha
translated: Having instructed and given the instruction up to this point, the Teacher now encourages them, saying “Bhikkhus, when a bhikkhu understands as they really are the origin and the passing away of the six bases of contact, … the life-taking as they really are, then he is called a bhikkhu who has comprehended the meaning and the Dhamma, who follows the Dhamma and is not without foundation in the Dhamma, who has crossed over doubt, gotten rid of bewilderment, attained to confidence, and become independent of others in the Teacher’s teaching.”

original: Tattha yatoti yadā. Ātāpīti vīriyavā. Nipakoti sappañño. Satoti satiyā samannāgato.
analyzed: tattha yatas ti yadā ātāpī iti vīriyavā nipakaḥ ti sappañño satoti satiyā samannāgato
translated: Herein, from the time when : whenever. He is ardent : he is energetic. He is wise : he is possessed of understanding. He is mindful : he is possessed of mindfulness.

original: Dukkhassa antakiriyāyāti vaṭṭadukkhassa paricchedaparivaṭumakiriyāya. Ime ca pana
analyzed: dukkhassa anta kiriyāya ati vaṭṭa dukkhassa pariccheda parivaṭuma kiriyāya ime ca pana
translated: For the ending of suffering : for the delimitation, the circumscribing, of the suffering of the round of rebirths.

original: ātāpādayo tayopi lokiyalokuttaramissakā kathitā.
analyzed: ātāpa ādayaḥ kathitā
translated: And these three, namely, ardour, wisdom, and mindfulness, are called “ mundane and supramundane” .

original: 11. Mahācorasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: mahā cora sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Great Thief Sutta

original: 51. Ekādasame mahācoroti mahanto balavacoro. Sandhinti gharasandhiṃ. Nillopanti mahāvilopaṃ.
analyzed: ekādasame mahā coraḥ iti mahantaḥ balavat coraḥ sandhim mahā vilopam
translated: In the eleventh sutta the great thief is a powerful thief. A junction is a house junction. A great plunder is a great robbery.

original: Ekāgārikanti ekameva gehaṃ parivāretvā vilumpanaṃ. Paripanthepi tiṭṭhatīti panthadūhanakammaṃ🔽karoti. Nadīvidugganti nadīnaṃ duggamaṭṭhānaṃ antaradīpakaṃ, yattha sakkā hoti dvīhipi
analyzed: ekāgārikam ti ekam eva geham parivāretvā vilumpanam paripanthe pi tiṭṭhati iti panthadūhana kammaṃ  karoti nadī vidugganti nadīnam duggama ṭṭhānam antara dīpakam yattha sakkā hoti
translated: A single house is a house surrounded and robbed. He stands in the open road is one who does the work of road-blocking.

original: tīhipi jaṅghasahassehi saddhiṃ nilīyituṃ. Pabbatavisamanti pabbatānaṃ visamaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: tīhi pi jaṅgha sahassehi saddhim nilīyitum pabbata visamanti pabbatānam visama ṭṭhānam
translated: A river ford is a difficult place in a river, an island in the middle of a river, where it is possible to lie hidden with two or three thousand men. A mountain fastness is a difficult place in mountains,

original: pabbatantaraṃ, yattha sakkā hoti sattahi vā aṭṭhahi vā jaṅghasahassehi saddhiṃ nilīyituṃ.
analyzed: pabbata antaram yattha sakkā hoti sattahi vā aṭṭhahi vā jaṅgha sahassehi saddhim nilīyitum
translated: a mountain fastness, where it is possible to lie hidden with seven or eight thousand men.

original: Tiṇagahananti tiṇena vaḍḍhitvā sañchannaṃ dvattiyojanaṭṭhānaṃ. Rodhanti ghanaṃ aññamaññaṃ
analyzed: tiṇa gahanam tiṇena vaḍḍhitvā sañchannam dvatti yojana ṭṭhānam rodhanti ghanam aññam aññam
translated: The grass-clump is the place two hundred yojanas in extent covered with grass. The obstruction is the mass of grass.

original: saṃsaṭṭhasākhaṃ ekābaddhaṃ mahāvanasaṇḍaṃ. Pariyodhāya atthaṃ bhaṇissantīti pariyodahitvā🔽taṃ taṃ kāraṇaṃ pakkhipitvā atthaṃ kathayissanti. Tyāssāti te assa. Pariyodhāya atthaṃ🔽bhaṇantīti kismiñci kiñci vattuṃ āraddheyeva “mā evaṃ avacuttha, mayaṃ etaṃ kulaparamparāya
analyzed: saṃsaṭṭha sākham eka ābaddham mahā vana saṇḍam pariyodhāya attham bhaṇissanti iti pariyodahitvā  tam tam kāraṇam pakkhipitvā attham kathayissanti te assa pariyodhāya attham  bhaṇanti iti kismiñci kiñci vattum āraddhā iya iva mā evam avacuttha mayam etam kula paramparāya
translated: “A thicket of reeds”: a place two yojanas wide overgrown with reeds. “A forest”: a great forest with its trees’ branches and foliage all entangled together. “They will explain the meaning by way of a roundabout way”: having prevaricated,

original: jānāma, na esa evarūpaṃ karissatī”ti taṃ taṃ kāraṇaṃ pakkhipitvā mahantampi dosaṃ🔽harantā atthaṃ bhaṇanti. Atha vā pariyodhāyāti paṭicchādetvātipi attho. Te hi tassapi🔽dosaṃ paṭicchādetvā atthaṃ bhaṇanti. Khataṃ upahatanti guṇakhananena khataṃ, guṇupaghātena
analyzed: jānāma naḥ esaḥ evarūpam karissati iti tam tam kāraṇam pakkhipitvā mahantam pi dosam  harantāḥ attham bhaṇanti atha vā pariyodhāya ati paṭicchādetvā atipi atthaḥ te hi tassa pi  dosam paṭicchādetvā attham bhaṇanti khatam guṇa khananena khatam guṇa upaghātena
translated: having introduced this or that reason, they will tell the meaning. “They will be”: they will be like that. “They will explain the meaning by way of a roundabout way”: when someone begins to say something, they will say, “Don’t say that. We know this by family tradition. He wouldn’t do such a thing.” Having introduced this or that reason, they will explain the meaning,

original: upahataṃ. Visamena kāyakammenāti sampakkhalanaṭṭhena visamena kāyadvārikakammena.
analyzed: upahatam visamena kāya kammena ati sampakkhalana ṭṭhena visamena kāya dvārika kammena
translated: removing even a great offense. Or else, “by way of a roundabout way” means “by way of concealment.” For they will explain the meaning by concealing even that offense. “Broken, damaged”: broken by the breaking of his virtues, damaged by the damaging of his virtues. “By means of distorted bodily action”: by means of bodily action that is distorted in the sense of being crooked.

original: Vacīmanokammesupi eseva nayo. Antaggāhikāyāti dasavatthukāya antaṃ gahetvā ṭhitadiṭṭhiyā.
analyzed: vacī manaḥ kammesu pi esa iva nayaḥ antaggāhikāya ati dasa vatthukāya antam gahetvā ṭhita diṭṭhiyā
translated: The same method applies to verbal and mental action. “To the view that grasps an extreme”: to the view that stands at the extreme of the ten speculative views.

original: Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānatthamevāti.🔽Cūḷavaggo pañcamo.
analyzed: sesam sabbattha uttāna attham eva ati  cūḷa vaggo pañcamaḥ
translated: The rest is clear throughout.🔽The fifth sub-chapter on the lesser men is finished.

original: Paṭhamapaṇṇāsakaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ.
analyzed: paṭhama paṇṇāsakam niṭṭhitam
translated: The first fifty is finished.

original: 2. Dutiyapaṇṇāsakaṃ
analyzed: dutiya paṇṇāsakam
translated: . The second fifty

original: (6) 1. Brāhmaṇavaggo🔽1. Paṭhamadvebrāhmaṇasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: brāhmaṇa vaggaḥ
translated: . The Brahmins’ Group🔽. The first on two Brahmins

original: 52. Brāhmaṇavaggassa paṭhame jiṇṇāti jarājiṇṇā. Vuddhāti vayovuddhā. Mahallakāti
analyzed: brāhmaṇa vaggassa paṭhame jiṇṇā ati jarā jiṇṇā vuddhā ati vayaḥ vuddhā mahallakā ati
translated: . In the first sutta of the Brahmins’ Group, “old” means worn out by old age. “Aged” means passed the age of youth. “Advanced in life” means

original: jātimahallakā. Addhagatāti tayo addhe atikkantā. Vayoanuppattāti tatiyaṃ vayaṃ anuppattā.🔽Yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsūti puttadāre attano vacanaṃ akaronte disvā “samaṇassa
analyzed: jāti mahallakāḥ addha gatā ati tayaḥ addhe atikkantāḥ vayaḥ anuppattā ati tatiyam vayam anuppattā  yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkamiṃsu iti putta dāre attanaḥ vacanam a karonte disvā samaṇassa
translated: advanced in birth. “Having reached the last stage of life” means having reached the third stage of life.

original: gotamassa santikaṃ gantvā niyyānikamaggaṃ gavesissāmā”ti cintetvā upasaṅkamiṃsu.
analyzed: gotamassa santikam gantvā niyyānika maggam gavesissāma iti cintetvā upasaṅkamiṃsu
translated: They approached the Blessed One: having seen that their sons and wives did not follow their advice, they thought, “We will go to the ascetic Gotama and seek a way of escape,” and they approached him.

original: Mayamassu, bho gotama, brāhmaṇāti; bho gotama, mayaṃ brāhmaṇā na khattiyā nāmaccā
analyzed: bho gotama brāhmaṇa ati bho gotama mayam brāhmaṇāḥ na khattiyāḥ nāmaccāḥ
translated: “We are Brahmins, Master Gotama”: Master Gotama, we are Brahmins, not Khattiyas, not Vessas, not Suddas,

original: na gahapatikāti brāhmaṇabhāvaṃ jānāpetvā jiṇṇātiādimāhaṃsu. Akatabhīruttāṇāti akatabhayaparittāṇā.
analyzed: na gahapatikā ati brāhmaṇa bhāvam jānāpetvā akata bhīru ttāṇā ati akata bhaya parittāṇā
translated: “Not a householder”: they said this, making him known as a brahmin. “No protection from fear”: no protection from fear made.

original: Avassayabhūtaṃ patiṭṭhākammaṃ amhehi na katanti dassenti. Tagghāti ekaṃsatthe nipāto,
analyzed: avassaya bhūtam patiṭṭhā kammam amhehi na katanti dassenti ekaṃsa tthe nipātaḥ
translated: “Not a householder” : they said this in order to make him understand that he was a brahmin. “No protection from fear” : they show that they have not done the work of protection from fear. “Taggha” : this is a particle in the sense of “ekanta” .🔽Or it is in the sense of “sampaṭicchana” .

original: sampaṭicchanatthe vā. Ekantena tumhe evarūpā, ahampi kho etaṃ sampaṭicchāmīti ca
analyzed: sampaṭicchana atthe vā ekantena tumhe evarūpāḥ aham pi kho etam sampaṭicchāmi iti ca
translated: They show that “you are just so, and I too agree to this.”

original: dasseti. Upanīyatīti upasaṃharīyati. Ayaṃ hi jātiyā jaraṃ upanīyati, jarāya byādhiṃ,
analyzed: dassā iti upanīyati iti ayam hi jātiyā jaram upanīyati jarāya byādhim
translated: “Is led on” : is brought near. For this one is led on to old age by birth, to disease by old age,

original: byādhinā maraṇaṃ, maraṇena puna jātiṃ. Tena vuttaṃ – “upanīyatī”ti.
analyzed: byādhinā maraṇam maraṇena puna jātim tena vuttam upanīyati iti
translated: to death by disease, and to rebirth by death. Therefore it was said, “is led on.”

original: Idāni yasmā te brāhmaṇā mahallakattā pabbajitvāpi vattaṃ pūretuṃ na sakkhissanti,
analyzed: idāni yasmā te brāhmaṇāḥ mahallakattā pabbajitvā api vattam pūretum na sakkhissanti
translated: Now, since those brahmins, because of their old age, will not be able to fulfill the duties even after going forth,

original: tasmā ne pañcasu sīlesu patiṭṭhāpento bhagavā yodha kāyena saṃyamotiādimāha. Tattha
analyzed: tasmā ne pañcasu sīlesu patiṭṭhāpentaḥ bhagavā kāyena saṃyamaḥ ti ādim āha tattha
translated: the Blessed One, in order to establish them in the five precepts, said, “If one is restrained in body” , etc. Herein,

original: kāyena saṃyamoti kāyadvārena saṃvaro. Sesesupi eseva nayo. Taṃ tassa petassāti taṃ
analyzed: kāyena saṃyamaḥ ti kāya dvārena saṃvaro sesesu pi esa iva nayo tam tassa petassa ati tam
translated: “Restraint in body” : restraint by way of the door of body. The same method applies to the rest. “That is his protection” :

original: puññaṃ tassa paralokaṃ gatassa tāyanaṭṭhena tāṇaṃ, nilīyanaṭṭhena leṇaṃ, patiṭṭhānaṭṭhena
analyzed: puññam tassa para lokaṃ gatassa tāyana ṭṭhena tāṇam nilīyana ṭṭhena leṇam patiṭṭhāna ṭṭhena
translated: Merit is a refuge for him who has gone to the other world in the sense of a protection, in the sense of a shelter, in the sense of a support,

original: dīpo, avassayanaṭṭhena saraṇaṃ, uttamagativasena parāyaṇañca hotīti dasseti. Gāthā
analyzed: dīpaḥ avassayana ṭṭhena saraṇam uttama gati vasena parāyaṇam ca hoti iti dassā iti gāthā
translated: and merit is a refuge for him who has gone to the other world in the sense of protection, a shelter in the sense of lying down, an island in the sense of a firm footing, a haven in the sense of a place to lie down, and a final support in the sense of a supreme resort. The verses

original: uttānatthāyeva. Evaṃ te brāhmaṇā tathāgatena pañcasu sīlesu samādapitā yāvajīvaṃ
analyzed: uttāna tthāya iva evam te brāhmaṇā tathāgatena pañcasu sīlesu samādapitāḥ yāvajīvam
translated: are self-evident in meaning. So the brahmins, having been exhorted by the Exalted One to the five precepts,

original: pañca sīlāni rakkhitvā sagge nibbattiṃsu.
analyzed: pañca sīlāni rakkhitvā sagge nibbattiṃsu
translated: kept the five precepts as long as they lived, and were reborn in heaven.

original: 2. Dutiyadvebrāhmaṇasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dutiya dve brāhmaṇa sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . Commentary to the Second Discourse to the Two Brahmins

original: 53. Dutiye bhājananti yaṃkiñci bhaṇḍakaṃ. Sesaṃ paṭhame vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: dutiye bhājanam ti yaṃkiñci bhaṇḍakam sesam paṭhame vutta nayena iva veditabbam
translated: . In the second discourse, a vessel is any kind of container. The rest should be understood in the way already stated in the first discourse.

original: 3. Aññatarabrāhmaṇasuttavaṇṇanā🔽54. Tatiye sammodanīyanti sammodajananiṃ. Sāraṇīyanti saritabbayuttakaṃ. Vītisāretvāti🔽pariyosāpetvā. Kittāvatāti kittakena. Sandiṭṭhiko dhammo hotīti sāmaṃ passitabbo
analyzed: aññatara brāhmaṇa sutta vaṇṇanā  tatiye sammodanīyanti sammoda jananim sāraṇīyanti saritabba yuttakam vītisāretvā ati  pariyosāpetvā kittāvatā ati kittakena sandiṭṭhikaḥ dhammo hoti iti sāmam passitabbo
translated: . Commentary to the Discourse to a Certain Brahmin

original: hoti. Akālikoti na kālantare phaladāyako. Ehipassikoti “ehi passā”ti evaṃ dassetuṃ
analyzed: hoti akāliko ti na kāla antare phala dāyakaḥ ehipassiko ti ehi passa ati evam dassetum
translated: . In the third discourse, a matter for rejoicing is that which causes rejoicing. A matter for consolation is that which is suitable to be consoled. Having consoled him means having brought him to the end. How much means how many. A matter to be seen here and now is that which can be seen by oneself. Not subject to time means not giving its fruit at a later time. Inviting one to come and see means that which can be shown by saying “Come and see.”

original: sakkāti āgamanīyapaṭipadaṃ pucchati. Opaneyyikoti attano cittaṃ upanetabbo. Paccattaṃ🔽veditabboti sāmaṃyeva jānitabbo. Viññūhīti paṇḍitehi. Pariyādinnacittoti ādinnagahitaparāmaṭṭhacitto🔽hutvā. Cetetīti cinteti. Sesamettha uttānameva. Imasmiṃ pana sutte brāhmaṇena lokuttaramaggo
analyzed: sakkā iti āgamanīya paṭipadam pucchati opaneyyiko ti attanaḥ cittam upanetabbo paccattam  veditabbaḥ ti sāmaṃyā iva jānitabbaḥ viññūhi iti paṇḍitehi pariyādinna citto ti ādinna gahita parāmaṭṭha citto  hutvā ceta iti iti cintā iti sesam ettha uttānam eva imasmim pana sutte brāhmaṇena lokuttara maggo
translated: “Can be approached” : he asks about the way that leads to the attainment of the goal. “To be led to” : he should be led to the state of his own mind. “To be known personally” : he should be known by himself alone. “By the wise” : by the wise ones. “With a mind that has gone beyond” : with a mind that has gone beyond, that has taken up, that has grasped, that has adhered to. “He plans” : he thinks. The rest is clear.

original: pucchito, satthārāpi soyeva kathito. So hi sāmaṃ passitabbattā sandiṭṭhiko nāmāti.
analyzed: pucchitaḥ satthārā api saḥ yā iva kathitaḥ saḥ hi sāmam passitabbattā sandiṭṭhikaḥ nāma ati
translated: “Can be realized” : he asks about the way that leads to the attainment of the goal. “Can be directly known” : it can be known by oneself. “By the wise” : by the wise men. “Having made his mind pliable” : having made his mind pliable, having taken it up, having grasped it, having made it his own. “He reflects” : he thinks. The rest is clear. But in this sutta the brahmin asked about the supramundane path, and the Master also explained that alone. For that is called “to be seen here and now” because it is to be seen by oneself.

original: 4. Paribbājakasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: paribbājaka sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . The explanation of the Sutta on Wanderers.

original: 55. Catutthe brāhmaṇaparibbājakoti brāhmaṇajātiko paribbājako, na khattiyādijātiko. Attatthampīti diṭṭhadhammikasamparāyikaṃ lokiyalokuttaramissakaṃ attano atthaṃ.
analyzed: catutthe brāhmaṇa paribbājako ti brāhmaṇa jātikaḥ paribbājakaḥ na khattiya ādi jātikaḥ atta attham pi iti diṭṭhadhammika samparāyikam lokiya lokuttara missakam attanaḥ attham
translated: . In the fourth sutta, a brahmin wanderer is a wanderer of brahmin birth, not of khattiya or other birth. “For his own benefit” : for his own welfare in this life, in the life to come, and in both, mundane and supramundane.

original: 5. Nibbutasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: nibbuta sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . The explanation of the Sutta on the State of Peace.

original: 56. Pañcame akālikanti na kālantare pattabbaṃ. Opaneyyikanti paṭipattiyā upagantabbaṃ.
analyzed: pañcame akālikam ti na kāla antare pattabbam opaneyyikam ti paṭipattiyā upagantabbam
translated: . In the fifth sutta, “not to be attained by a future life” : not to be attained in a future life. “Can be directly known” : can be reached by practice.

original: 6. Palokasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: paloka sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . The explanation of the Sutta on Decay.

original: 57. Chaṭṭhe ācariyapācariyānanti ācariyānañceva ācariyācariyānañca. Avīci maññe phuṭo
analyzed: chaṭṭhe ācariya pācariya ananti ācariya ananti ca iva ācariya ācariya ananti avīci maññe phuṭaḥ
translated: In the sixth, “teachers’ teachers” means teachers’ teachers as well as teachers.

original: ahosīti yathā avīci mahānirayo nirantaraphuṭo nerayikasattehi paripuṇṇo, manussehi🔽evaṃ paripuṇṇo hoti. Kukkuṭasaṃpātikāti ekagāmassa chadanapiṭṭhito uppatitvā itaragāmassa🔽chadanapiṭṭhe patanasaṅkhāto kukkuṭasaṃpāto etāsu atthīti kukkuṭasaṃpātikā. Kukkuṭasaṃpādikātipi🔽pāṭho, gāmantarato gāmantaraṃ kukkuṭānaṃ padasā gamanasaṅkhāto kukkuṭasaṃpādo etāsu
analyzed: ahosi iti yathā avīci mahānirayaḥ nirantara phuṭaḥ nerayika sattehi paripuṇṇaḥ manussehi  evam paripuṇṇaḥ hoti kukkuṭa saṃpātikā ati eka gāmassa chadana piṭṭhitaḥ uppatitvā itara gāmassa  chadana piṭṭhe patana saṅkhāto kukkuṭa saṃpāto etāsu atthi iti kukkuṭa saṃpātikā kukkuṭa saṃpādikā atipi  pāṭhaḥ gām antarataḥ gām antaram kukkuṭānam gamana saṅkhātaḥ kukkuṭa saṃpādaḥ etāsu
translated: “As if filled with Avīci” : just as the great Avīci hell is filled without interstice by hell-beings, so it is filled with human beings.

original: atthīti attho. Ubhayampetaṃ ghananivāsataṃyeva dīpeti. Adhammarāgarattāti rāgo nāma
analyzed: atthi iti ghana nivāsa taṃyā iva dīpeti adhamma rāga rattā ati rāgaḥ nāma
translated: “Crow-stepping” : the meaning is that there is crow-stepping in these villages, that is, the jumping of crows from the roof of a house in one village to the roof of a house in another village which is within crow-flight. The reading kukkuṭasaṃpādikā is also allowable, the meaning being that there is crow-walking in these villages, that is, the walking of crows on foot from one village to another. Both terms indicate a thickly settled country.

original: ekanteneva adhammo, attano parikkhāresu pana uppajjamāno na adhammarāgoti adhippeto,
analyzed: ekantena iva adhammaḥ attanaḥ parikkhāresu pana uppajjamānaḥ na adhamma rāgaḥ ti adhippeto
translated: “Lust for unallowable lusts” : lust is entirely unallowable. But when it arises for one’s own requisites, it is not called “lust for unallowable lusts” ;

original: paraparikkhāresu uppajjamānova adhammarāgoti. Visamalobhābhibhūtāti lobhassa samakālo
analyzed: para parikkhāresu uppajjamānaḥ iva adhamma rāgaḥ ti visama lobha abhibhūtā ati lobhassa sama kālo
translated: it is called “lust for allowable lusts.” It is only when it arises for the requisites of others that it is called “lust for unallowable lusts.”🔽“Overcome by unjust greed” : greed is not just.

original: nāma natthi, ekantaṃ visamova esa. Attanā pariggahitavatthumhi pana uppajjamāno samalobho
analyzed: nāma natthi ekantam visamaḥ uva esa attanā pariggahita vatthumhi pana uppajjamānaḥ sama lobho
translated: There is no such thing as a ‘mixed’ greed. It is only a ‘wrong’ greed. But when it arises in regard to an object that one has appropriated, it is called ‘mixed greed’;

original: nāma, parapariggahitavatthumhi uppajjamānova visamoti adhippeto. Micchādhammaparetāti🔽avatthupaṭisevanasaṅkhātena micchādhammena samannāgatā. Devo na sammā dhāraṃ anuppavecchatīti
analyzed: nāma para pariggahita vatthumhi uppajjamānaḥ iva visamaḥ ti adhippeto micchādhamma paretā ti  avatthu paṭisevana saṅkhātena micchādhammena samannāgatā devaḥ na sammā dhāram anuppavecchati iti
translated: and when it arises in regard to an object appropriated by another, it is called ‘wrong greed.’🔽They are not in accord with the Dhamma: they are not in accord with the Dhamma called “the practice of the object.”🔽The god does not send down rain: at the time when it should rain, it does not rain.

original: vassitabbayutte kāle vassaṃ na vassati. Dubbhikkhanti dullabhabhikkhaṃ. Dussassanti🔽vividhasassānaṃ asampajjanena dussassaṃ. Setaṭṭhikanti sasse sampajjamāne pāṇakā
analyzed: vassitabba yutte kāle vassam na vassati dubbhikkhanti dullabha bhikkham dussassanti  vividha sassānam a sampajjanena dussassam setaṭṭhikanti sasse sampajjamāne pāṇakā
translated: There is famine: almsfood is difficult to obtain.🔽There is crop failure: crops fail in various ways.

original: patanti, tehi daṭṭhattā nikkhantanikkhantāni sālisīsāni setavaṇṇāni honti nissārāni.
analyzed: patanti tehi daṭṭha ttā nikkhanta nikkhantāni sāli sīsāni seta vaṇṇāni honti nissārāni
translated: There is white- eared corn: when the crops are growing, worms fall and eat the corn.

original: Taṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ “setaṭṭhika”nti. Salākāvuttanti vapitaṃ vapitaṃ sassaṃ salākāmattameva
analyzed: tam sandhāya vuttam setaṭṭhikanti salākāvuttanti vapitam vapitam sassam salākā mattam eva
translated: Therefore it is said, “white-eared corn.”🔽There is famine due to famine: the corn that is planted grows only to the height of a finger and does not bear fruit.

original: sampajjati, phalaṃ na detīti attho. Yakkhāti yakkhādhipatino. Vāḷe amanusse ossajjantīti
analyzed: sampajjati phalam na deti iti atthaḥ yakkha ati yakkha adhipatino vāḷe amanusse ossajjanti iti
translated: The meaning is that it does not give a harvest.🔽The yakkhas: the lords of the yakkhas.🔽They let loose wild spirits: they let loose wild spirits.

original: caṇḍayakkhe manussapathe vissajjenti, te laddhokāsā mahājanaṃ jīvitakkhayaṃ pāpenti.
analyzed: caṇḍayakkhe manussa pathe vissajjenti te laddha okāsāḥ mahājanam jīvita kkhayam pāpenti
translated: and they let loose the fierce yakkhas on the human path, and they, having got their chance, destroy the great multitude.

original: 7. Vacchagottasuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the Sutta on Vacchagotta.

original: 58. Sattame mahapphalanti mahāvipākaṃ. Dhammassa cānudhammaṃ byākarontīti ettha dhammo🔽nāma kathitakathā, anudhammo nāma kathitassa paṭikathanaṃ. Sahadhammikoti sakāraṇo🔽sahetuko. Vādānupātoti vādassa anupāto, anupatanaṃ pavattīti attho. Gārayhaṃ ṭhānanti
analyzed: sattame mahapphalanti mahā vipākam dhammassa ca anudhammam byākaronti iti ettha dhammo  nāma kathita kathā anudhammaḥ nāma kathitassa paṭikathanam sahadhammikaḥ ti sa kāraṇaḥ  sa hetukaḥ vāda anupāto ti vādassa anupātaḥ anupatanam pavatti iti atthaḥ gārayham ṭhānam ti
translated: In the seventh, “great fruit” means great result. In the phrase “expounding in conformity with the Dhamma,” the Dhamma is🔽what has been said; conformity with the Dhamma is the reply to what has been said. “In accordance with the Dhamma” means with reason,

original: garahitabbayuttaṃ kāraṇaṃ. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – bhotā gotamena vuttā sakāraṇā vādappavatti
analyzed: garahitabba yuttam kāraṇam idam vuttam hoti bhotā gotamena vuttā sa kāraṇā vāda ppavatti
translated: with cause. “The approach of a reply” is the approach, the occurrence, of a reply. “A ground for censure” is a reason for blame. This is what is said: “The approach of a reply with reason that has been made by Master Gotama

original: kiñcipi gārayhaṃ kāraṇaṃ na āgacchatīti. Atha vā tehi parehi vuttā sakāraṇā vādappavatti
analyzed: kiñcipi gārayham kāraṇam na āgacchati iti atha vā tehi parehi vuttā sa kāraṇā vāda ppavatti
translated: does not come to have any ground for censure.” Or else, he asks: “The approach of a reply with reason that has been made by the others

original: kiñci gārayhaṃ kāraṇaṃ na āgacchatīti pucchati.
analyzed: kiñci gārayham kāraṇam naḥ āgacchati iti pucchati
translated: does not come to have any ground for censure.”

original: Antarāyakaro hotīti antarāyaṃ vināsaṃ kicchalābhakaṃ vilomakaṃ karoti. Pāripanthikoti panthadūhanacoro. Khato ca hotīti guṇakhananena khato hoti. Upahatoti guṇupaghāteneva upahato.
analyzed: antarāya karaḥ hoti iti antarāyam vināsam kiccha lābhakam vilomakam karoti pāripanthikaḥ iti panthadūhana coraḥ khataḥ ca hoti iti guṇa khananena khataḥ hoti upahataḥ iti guṇa upaghātena iva upahataḥ
translated: He is an obstructor: he is an obstruction, a destruction, a misfortune, a hindrance. A highwayman: a thief who spoils a road. He is a slanderer: he is a slanderer by the slander of his qualities. He is a reviler: he is a reviler by the reviling of his qualities.

original: Candanikāyāti asucikalalakūpe. Oligalleti niddhamanakalale. So cāti so sīlavāti vuttakhīṇāsavo.🔽Sīlakkhandhenāti sīlarāsinā. Sesapadesupi eseva nayo. Ettha ca vimuttiñāṇadassanaṃ
analyzed: candanikāya ati asuci kalala kūpe oligallā iti niddhamana kalale saḥ ca ati saḥ sīlavā ati vutta khīṇa āsavaḥ  sīla kkhandhena ati sīla rāsinā sesa padesu pi esa iva nayaḥ ettha ca vimutti ñāṇa dassanam
translated: In a cesspit: in a cesspit of impure filth. In a drain: in a drain for carrying off urine. He is: he is the one called “virtuous” who is a canker-free perfected being.🔽By the aggregate of virtue: by the mass of virtue. The same method of explanation applies in the other cases. And here the knowledge of reviewing is called “knowledge of deliverance”

original: vuccati paccavekkhaṇañāṇaṃ, taṃ asekkhassa pavattattā asekkhanti vuttaṃ. Itarāni
analyzed: vuccati paccavekkhaṇa ñāṇam tam asekkhassa pavattattā asekkhanti vuttam itarāni
translated: because it occurs in the Arahant who is “delivered” from defilements. The other three are called “knowledge of the Asekha” because they are reached at the end of training.

original: sikkhāpariyosānappattatāya sayampi asekkhāneva. Tāni ca pana lokuttarāni, paccavekkhaṇañāṇaṃ lokiyaṃ.
analyzed: sikkhā pariyosāna patta tāya sayam pi tāni ca pana lokuttarāni paccavekkhaṇa ñāṇam lokiyam
translated: But they are themselves the Asekha because they are reached at the end of training. And they are supramundane, while the knowledge of reviewing is mundane.

original: Rohiṇīsūti rattavaṇṇāsu. Sarūpāsūti attano vacchakehi samānarūpāsu. Pārevatāsūti
analyzed: rohiṇīsu iti ratta vaṇṇāsu sarūpāsu iti attanaḥ vacchakehi samāna rūpāsu pārevatāsu iti
translated: Red cows: red-coloured cows. Like his own calves: like his own calves in appearance. The Parivara cows:

original: kapotavaṇṇāsu. Dantoti nibbisevano. Puṅgavoti usabho. Dhorayhoti dhuravāho. Kalyāṇajavanikkamoti
analyzed: kapota vaṇṇāsu danto ti nibbisevano puṅgavo ti usabhaḥ dhorayho iti dhura vāho kalyāṇa java nikkamo ti
translated: In the dove-colored ones. Tamed: free from passion. Bull: a bull. Strong: a draught animal. With good speed and gait:

original: kalyāṇena ujunā javena gantā. Nāssa vaṇṇaṃ parikkhareti assa goṇassa sarīravaṇṇaṃ
analyzed: kalyāṇena ujunā javena gantā na assa vaṇṇam parikkhareti assa goṇassa sarīra vaṇṇam
translated: he goes with good, straight speed. His color: his body color.

original: na upaparikkhanti, dhuravahanakammameva pana upaparikkhanti. Yasmiṃ kasmiñci jātiyeti
analyzed: na upaparikkhanti dhura vahana kammam eva pana upaparikkhanti yasmin kasmiñci jātiyā iti
translated: They do not examine, but they examine only his work of bearing the load. In whatever:

original: yattha katthaci kulajāte. Yāsu kāsuci etāsūti etāsu khattiyādippabhedāsu yāsu kāsuci jātīsu.
analyzed: yattha katthaci kula jāte yāsu kāsuci etāsu iti etāsu khattiya ādi ppabhedāsu yāsu kāsuci jātīsu
translated: in whatever family. In whatever: in whatever of these, in whatever of these divided into nobles, etc.

original: Brahmacariyassa kevalīti brahmacariyassa kevalena samannāgato, paripuṇṇabhāvena yuttoti
analyzed: brahmacariyassa kevalī iti brahmacariyassa kevalena samannāgato paripuṇṇa bhāvena yutto ti
translated: Complete in the holy life: endowed with the complete holy life, endowed with the fulfilled state, is the meaning.

original: attho. Khīṇāsavo hi sakalabrahmacārī nāma hoti. Tenetaṃ vuttaṃ. Pannabhāroti oropitabhāro,
analyzed: attho khīṇāsavaḥ hi sakala brahmacārī nāma hoti tena itam vuttam panna bhāraḥ ti oropita bhāro
translated: For one whose cankers are destroyed is called one who has fulfilled the holy life. Therefore this was said. Having put down the burden: having put down the burden,

original: khandhabhāraṃ kilesabhāraṃ kāmaguṇabhārañca oropetvā ṭhitoti attho. Katakiccoti catūhi
analyzed: khandha bhāram kilesa bhāram kāmaguṇa bhārañca oropetvā ṭhitaḥ ti attho kata kiccaḥ ti catūhi
translated: having stood after putting down the burden of the aggregates, the burden of defilements, and the burden of the strands of sensual pleasure, is the meaning. Having done what was to be done: having done the four

original: maggehi kiccaṃ katvā ṭhito. Pāragū sabbadhammānanti sabbadhammā vuccanti pañcakkhandhā
analyzed: maggehi kiccam katvā ṭhitaḥ pāragū sabba dhammānam ti sabba dhammāḥ vuccanti pañca kkhandhāḥ
translated: The words “he has gone to the further shore of all things” mean that the five aggregates are called “all things,”🔽and the twelve bases and the eighteen elements are called “all things.” He has gone to the further shore of all things in six ways:

original: dvādasāyatanāni aṭṭhārasa dhātuyo, tesaṃ sabbadhammānaṃ abhiññāpāraṃ, pariññāpāraṃ,🔽pahānapāraṃ, bhāvanāpāraṃ, sacchikiriyāpāraṃ, samāpattipārañcāti chabbidhaṃ pāraṃ
analyzed: dvādasa āyatanāni aṭṭhārasa dhātuyaḥ tesam sabba dhammānam abhiññāpāram pariññāpāram  pahāna pāram bhāvanā pāram sacchikiriyā pāram samāpatti pāram ca ati chabbidham pāram
translated: the further shore of direct knowledge, the further shore of full understanding,🔽the further shore of abandoning, the further shore of developing, the further shore of realizing, and the further shore of attainment.

original: gatattā pāragū. Anupādāyāti aggahetvā. Nibbutoti kilesasantāparahito. Virajeti rāgadosamoharajarahite.
analyzed: gata ttā pāragū an upādāya ati aggahetvā nibbutaḥ ti kilesa santāpa rahitaḥ viraja iti rāga dosa moha raja rahite
translated: He has gone to the further shore of all things because he has gone to the further shore in these six ways. “Without grasping” : without taking up. “He is extinguished” : he is free from the burning of defilements. “He is free from passion” : he is free from passion, hatred, and delusion.

original: Avijānantāti khettaṃ ajānantā. Dummedhāti nippaññā. Assutāvinoti khettavinicchayasavanena🔽rahitā. Bahiddhāti imamhā sāsanā bahiddhā. Na hi sante upāsareti buddhapaccekabuddhakhīṇāsave
analyzed: a vijānantā ati khettam a jānantā dummedhā ati nippaññāḥ a sutāvinaḥ iti khetta vinicchaya savanena  rahitāḥ bahiddhā ati imamhā sāsanā bahiddhā na hi sante upāsareti buddha paccekabuddha khīṇāsave
translated: “Not knowing the field” : not knowing the field. “Foolish” : unskillful. “Unlearned” : devoid of the learning🔽of the investigation of the field. “Outside” : outside this Dispensation. “They do not attend on the peaceful ones” : they do not approach the supreme men, the Buddhas, Paccekabuddhas, and those who have exhausted the taints.

original: uttamapurise na upasaṅkamanti. Dhīrasammateti paṇḍitehi sammate sambhāvite. Mūlajātā
analyzed: uttama purise na upasaṅkamanti dhīra sammata iti paṇḍitehi sammate sambhāvite mūla jātā
translated: “Honored by the wise” : honored and respected by the wise.

original: patiṭṭhitāti iminā sotāpannassa saddhaṃ dasseti. Kule vā idha jāyareti idha vā manussaloke🔽khattiyabrāhmaṇavessakule jāyanti. Ayameva hi tividhā kulasampatti nāma. Anupubbena
analyzed: patiṭṭhitā ati iminā sotāpannassa saddham dasseti kule vā idha idha vā manussa loke  khattiya brāhmaṇa vessa kule jāyanti ayam eva hi tividhā kula sampatti nāma anupubbena
translated: “They are born in a family here” means that they are born in a family in this human world.🔽For this is the threefold excellence of family:🔽

original: nibbānaṃ, adhigacchantīti sīlasamādhipaññāti ime guṇe pūretvā anukkamena nibbānaṃ adhigacchantīti.
analyzed: nibbānam adhigacchanti iti sīla samādhi paññā ati ime guṇe pūretvā anukkamena nibbānam adhigacchanti iti
translated: “Established” shows the faith of the stream-enterer. “Are born in a family here” means that they are born in a family of nobles, brahmins, or householders in this human world. For this is the threefold excellence of family. “Gradually” means in due order. “They reach Nibbāna” means that they reach Nibbāna by fulfilling the qualities of virtue, concentration, and wisdom.

original: 8. Tikaṇṇasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: tikaṇṇa sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Commentary on the Three-Ear Discourse

original: 59. Aṭṭhame tikaṇṇoti tassa nāmaṃ. Upasaṅkamīti “samaṇo kira gotamo paṇḍito, gacchissāmi🔽tassa santika”nti cintetvā bhuttapātarāso mahājanaparivuto upasaṅkami. Bhagavato
analyzed: aṭṭhame tikaṇṇo ti tassa nāmam upasaṅkamīti samaṇaḥ kira gotamaḥ paṇḍitaḥ gacchissāmi  tassa santikam ti cintetvā bhutta pāta rāsaḥ mahā jana parivutaḥ upasaṅkami bhagavataḥ
translated: In the eighth discourse, “Three-Ear” is his name. “Approached” means that he thought, “The ascetic Gotama is said to be wise. I will go

original: sammukhāti dasabalassa purato nisīditvā. Vaṇṇaṃ bhāsatīti kasmā bhāsati? So kira
analyzed: sammukhā ati dasabalassa puratas nisīditvā vaṇṇam bhāsati iti kasmai bhāsati saḥ kira
translated: to his presence,” and after his morning meal, surrounded by a large crowd, he approached. “In the presence of the Blessed One” means that he sat down in front of the One of Ten Powers. “Praised his appearance” means why did he praise? It seems that

original: ito pubbe tathāgatassa santikaṃ agatapubbo. Athassa etadahosi – “buddhā nāma durāsadā,
analyzed: itas pubbe tathāgatassa santikam a gata pubbaḥ atha assa etat ahosi buddhāḥ nāma durāsadā
translated: previously he had never gone into the presence of the Tathāgata. Then he thought, “Buddhas are difficult to approach,

original: mayi paṭhamataraṃ akathente katheyya vā na vā. Sace na kathessati, atha maṃ samāgamaṭṭhāne
analyzed: mayi paṭhamataram a kathente katheyya vā na vā sace na kathessati atha mama samāgama ṭṭhāne
translated: If I do not speak first, he may or may not speak. If he does not speak, then when I am speaking at the meeting,

original: kathentaṃ evaṃ vakkhanti ‘tvaṃ idha kasmā kathesi, yena te samaṇassa gotamassa santikaṃ
analyzed: kathentam evam vakkhanti tvam idha kasmā kathesi yena te samaṇassa gotamassa santikam
translated: they will say: ‘Why do you speak here? You went to the recluse Gotama

original: gantvā vacanamattampi na laddha’nti. Tasmā ‘evaṃ me ayaṃ garahā muccissatī”’ti maññamāno
analyzed: gantvā vacana mattam pi na laddhanti tasmai evam me ayam garahā muccissati iti maññamāno
translated: and did not even get a chance to speak to him.’ Therefore, thinking ‘In this way I will be freed from blame,’

original: bhāsati. Kiñcāpi brāhmaṇānaṃ vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, tathāgatassa pana ñāṇaṃ ghaṭṭessāmīti
analyzed: bhāsati kiñcā api brāhmaṇānam vaṇṇam bhāsati tathāgatassa pana ñāṇam ghaṭṭessāmi iti
translated: he speaks. Although he speaks in praise of the brahmins, his intention is to test the Tathāgata’s knowledge.

original: adhippāyeneva bhāsati. Evampi tevijjā brāhmaṇāti tevijjakabrāhmaṇā evaṃpaṇḍitā evaṃdhīrā🔽evaṃbyattā evaṃbahussutā evaṃvādino, evaṃsammatāti attho. Itipīti iminā tesaṃ paṇḍitādiākāraparicchedaṃ
analyzed: adhippāyena iva bhāsati evam pi tevijjāḥ brāhmaṇāḥ ti tevijjaka brāhmaṇāḥ evaṃpaṇḍitāḥ evaṃdhīrā  evaṃbyattāḥ evaṃbahu ssutāḥ evaṃvādinaḥ evaṃsammatāḥ ati atthaḥ iti pi iti iminā tesam paṇḍita ādi ākāra paricchedam
translated: Thus, the brahmins of the three Vedas are wise, prudent,🔽clever, learned, and renowned in the three Vedas. The meaning is that they are regarded as such. The words thus, too, show that they are distinguished by the characteristics of wisdom, etc.

original: dasseti. Ettakena kāraṇena paṇḍitā…pe… ettakena kāraṇena sammatāti ayañhi ettha attho.
analyzed: dasseti ettakena kāraṇena ettakena kāraṇena sammatā ati ayaṃ hi ettha atthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that they are regarded as such because of these reasons.

original: Yathā kathaṃ pana brāhmaṇāti ettha yathāti kāraṇavacanaṃ, kathaṃ panāti pucchāvacanaṃ.🔽Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – kathaṃ pana, brāhmaṇa, brāhmaṇā tevijjaṃ paññāpenti. Yathā evaṃ🔽sakkā hoti jānituṃ, taṃ kāraṇaṃ vadehīti. Taṃ sutvā brāhmaṇo “jānanaṭṭhāneyeva maṃ
analyzed: yathā katham pana brāhmaṇa ati ettha yathā iti kāraṇa vacanam katham pana ati pucchā vacanam  idam vuttam hoti katham pana brāhmaṇa brāhmaṇā tevijjam paññāpenti yathā evam  sakkā hoti jānitum tam kāraṇam vadehi iti tam sutvā brāhmaṇaḥ jānana ṭṭhānā iya iva mama
translated: How then, brahmin? ” Herein, how is a term of cause, how then? is a term of question.

original: sammāsambuddho pucchi, no ajānanaṭṭhāne”ti attamano hutvā idha, bho gotamātiādimāha.
analyzed: sammāsambuddhaḥ pucchi naḥ a jānana ṭhāne iti atta manaḥ hutvā idha bho gotama ati ādim āha
translated: This is what is said: “How then, brahmin, do brahmins describe one possessed of the three knowledges? Tell the reason why it is possible to know thus. ” On hearing this, the brahmin thought “The Fully Enlightened One is questioning me on a matter that can be known, not on a matter that cannot be known” and so he was pleased and said “Here, Master Gotama” .

original: Tattha ubhatoti dvīhipi pakkhehi. Mātito ca pitito cāti yassa mātā brāhmaṇī, mātu🔽mātā brāhmaṇī, tassāpi mātā brāhmaṇī. Pitā brāhmaṇo, pitu pitā brāhmaṇo, tassāpi🔽pitā brāhmaṇo, so ubhato sujāto mātito ca pitito ca. Saṃsuddhagahaṇikoti yassa saṃsuddhā
analyzed: tattha ubhatas ti dvīhi pi pakkhehi mātitaḥ ca pititaḥ ca ati yassa mātā brāhmaṇī mātu  mātā brāhmaṇī tassa api mātā brāhmaṇī pitā brāhmaṇaḥ pitu pitā brāhmaṇaḥ tassa api  pitā brāhmaṇo saḥ ubhatas su jātaḥ mātitaḥ ca pititaḥ ca yassa saṃsuddhā
translated: Herein, on both sides means on both sides, that is, on the mother’s side and on the father’s side. His mother is a brahmin,

original: mātu gahaṇī, kucchīti attho. “Samavepākiniyā gahaṇiyā”ti pana ettha kammajatejodhātu gahaṇīti vuccati.
analyzed: mātu gahaṇī kucchī iti attho sama vepākiniyā gahaṇiyā ati pana ettha kamma ja tejaḥ dhātu gahaṇī iti vuccati
translated: his mother’s mother is a brahmin, and his mother’s mother’s mother is a brahmin. His father is a brahmin, his father’s father is a brahmin, and his father’s father’s father is a brahmin. He is thus well-born on both sides, that is, on his mother’s side and on his father’s side. Of pure descent for seven generations means that for him there is no slur on the family for seven generations back on either the mother’s side or the father’s side. His mother’s womb was pure, that is, his mother’s womb was clean. “By a pure womb” is said here, but in the text of the Abhidhamma it is said “by a womb that is a field” .

original: Yāva sattamā pitāmahayugāti ettha pitu pitā pitāmaho, pitāmahassa yugaṃ pitāmahayugaṃ.
analyzed: yāva sattamā pitāmaha yugā ti ettha pitu pitā pitāmahaḥ pitāmahassa yugam pitāmaha yugam
translated: “As far back as he can trace his ancestry for seven generations of his father’s line” : the father’s father is the grandfather, and the grandfather’s pair is the grandfather’s pair.

original: Yuganti āyuppamāṇaṃ vuccati. Abhilāpamattameva cetaṃ, atthato pana pitāmahoyeva pitāmahayugaṃ.
analyzed: yugam ti āyu ppamāṇam vuccati abhilāpa mattam eva atthato pana pitāmaha uyā iva pitāmaha yugam
translated: “Pair” is said to be a measure of life-span. But this is merely a figure of speech; in fact, the grandfather’s pair is the grandfather himself.

original: Tato uddhaṃ sabbepi pubbapurisā pitāmahaggahaṇeneva gahitā. Evaṃ yāva sattamo puriso,
analyzed: tatas uddham sabbe pi pubba purisāḥ pitāmaha ggahaṇena iva gahitāḥ evam yāva sattamaḥ puriso
translated: All the ancestors before him are included by the mention of the grandfather. Thus as far back as the seventh person,

original: tāva saṃsuddhagahaṇiko, atha vā akkhitto anupakkuṭṭho jātivādenāti dasseti. Akkhittoti🔽“apanetha etaṃ, kiṃ iminā”ti evaṃ akkhitto anavakkhitto. Anupakkuṭṭhoti na upakkuṭṭho,
analyzed: tāva saṃsuddha gahaṇikaḥ atha vā akkhittaḥ an upakkuṭṭhaḥ jāti vādena ati dasseti akkhittaḥ ti  apanetha etam kim iminā ati evam akkhittaḥ an avakkhittaḥ an upakkuṭṭhaḥ ti na upakkuṭṭhaḥ
translated: he is of pure descent, or else he is not accused, not charged with, the offense of having an impure ancestry. “Not accused” means🔽not charged with the offense of having an impure ancestry by the words “Remove him, what is he doing here?” “Not charged” means not charged,

original: na akkosaṃ vā nindaṃ vā pattapubbo. Kena kāraṇenāti? Jātivādena. “Itipi hīnajātiko
analyzed: na akkosam vā nindam vā patta pubbaḥ kena kāraṇena ati jāti vādena hīna jātiko
translated: not reproached. For what reason? For the reason of ancestry. “Thus he is of low ancestry”

original: eso”ti evarūpena vacanenāti attho.
analyzed: eso ti evarūpena vacanena ati attho
translated: is the meaning of such a statement.

original: Ajjhāyakoti idaṃ “na dānime jhāyanti, na dānime jhāyantīti kho, vāseṭṭha, ajjhāyakā
analyzed: ajjhāyaka uti idam na dāni ime jhāyanti na dāni ime jhāyanti iti kho vāseṭṭha ajjhāyakā
translated: “A teacher of the Vedas” : “They do not meditate, they do not meditate” , thus, Vasettha, the teachers of the Vedas

original: ajjhāyakāteva tatiyaṃ akkharaṃ upanibbatta”nti evaṃ paṭhamakappikakāle jhānavirahitānaṃ
analyzed: ajjhāyakātā iva tatiyam akkharam upanibbattanti evam paṭhama kappika kāle jhāna virahitānam
translated: and the third syllable was produced by the mere recitation of the text.”

original: brāhmaṇānaṃ garahavacanaṃ uppannaṃ. Idāni pana taṃ ajjhāyatīti ajjhāyako, mante parivattetīti
analyzed: brāhmaṇānam garaha vacanam uppannam idāni pana tam ajjhāyati iti ajjhāyakaḥ mante parivatteti iti
translated: This is the censure of the brahmans who were devoid of jhāna in the first period of the dispensation. But now they praise them by calling them “reciters” in the sense of “one who recites the texts,” and “one who bears the texts” in the sense of “one who bears the texts in mind.”🔽“The three Vedas”: the Rg Veda, the Yajur Veda, and the Sāma Veda.🔽“One who has gone to the end by the method of the O and the U”:

original: iminā atthena pasaṃsāvacanaṃ katvā voharanti. Mante dhāretīti mantadharo.🔽Tiṇṇaṃ vedānanti irubbedayajubbedasāmabbedānaṃ. Oṭṭhapahatakaraṇavasena pāraṃ gatoti🔽pāragū. Saha nighaṇḍunā ca keṭubhena ca sanighaṇḍukeṭubhānaṃ. Nighaṇḍūti nāmanighaṇḍurukkhādīnaṃ🔽vevacanapakāsakasatthaṃ. Keṭubhanti kiriyākappavikappo kavīnaṃ upakārāya satthaṃ.
analyzed: iminā atthena pasaṃsā vacanam katvā voharanti mante dhārā iti iti mantadharo  tiṇṇam vedānan ti irup beda yajup beda sāmap bedānam oṭṭha apahata karaṇa vasena pāram gataḥ ti  pāragū saha nighaṇḍunā ca keṭubhena ca sa nighaṇḍu keṭubhānam nighaṇḍu uti nāma nighaṇḍu rukkha ādīnam  vevacana pakāsaka sattham keṭubhanti kiriyā kappa vikappaḥ kavīnam upakārāya sattham
translated: “O” is the vowel o, and “U” is the vowel u. “By the method of the O and the U” means by the method of the O and the U. “One who has gone to the end” means one who has gone to the end of the three Vedas by the method of the O and the U.🔽“Together with the Nighaṇṭu and the Keṭu”: the Nighaṇṭu is a book of synonyms for trees, etc.,🔽and the Keṭu is a book of synonyms for verbs and nouns.
