translated: And of these, a stream-enterer enters upon the attainment of the fruit of stream-entry …

original: arahā arahattaphalasamāpattiṃ samāpajjati. Uparimo heṭṭhimaṃ na samāpajjati. Tesañhi
analyzed: arahā arahatta phala samāpattim samāpajjati uparimaḥ heṭṭhimam na samāpajjati tesam hi
translated: The Arahant enters upon the fruition attainment of Arahantship. The higher does not enter upon the lower.🔽For the lower attainment is only a means of access for them.

original: heṭṭhimā heṭṭhimā samāpatti tatravattiyeva hoti. Tatheva taṃ hotīti etaṃ ekaṃsena
analyzed: heṭṭhimā heṭṭhimā samāpatti tatravattiyā iva hoti tathā iva tam hoti iti etam ekaṃsena
translated: It is just as it is: this is invariable.

original: tatheva hoti. Cetopariyañāṇavasena ñātañhi aññathābhāvi nāma natthi.🔽Evaṃ vitakkethāti evaṃ nekkhammavitakkādayo pavattentā vitakketha. Mā evaṃ vitakkayitthāti
analyzed: tathā iva hoti cetaḥ pariya ñāṇa vasena ñātam hi aññathābhāvi nāma natthi  evam vitakketha ati evam nekkhamma vitakka ādayaḥ pavattentāḥ vitakketha mā evam vitakkayittha ati
translated: For what is known by means of the knowledge of penetration of minds has no other state than that.

original: evaṃ kāmavitakkādayo pavattentā mā vitakkayittha. Evaṃ manasi karothāti evaṃ aniccasaññameva,
analyzed: evam kāma vitakka ādayaḥ pavattentāḥ mā vitakkayittha evam manasi karotha ati evam anicca saññam eva
translated: Thus let them reflect: thus let them reflect by giving attention to the kinds of reflection beginning with that on renunciation. Let them not reflect thus: let them not reflect by giving attention to the kinds of reflection beginning with that on sense desires.

original: dukkhasaññādīsu vā aññataraṃ manasi karotha. Mā evanti niccantiādinā nayena mā manasā🔽karittha. Idanti idaṃ pañcakāmaguṇarāgaṃ pajahatha. Idañca upasampajjāti idaṃ catumaggaphalappabhedaṃ
analyzed: dukkha saññā ādīsu vā aññataram manasi karotha mā evanti niccanti ādinā nayena mā manasā  karittha idam ti idam pañca kāmaguṇa rāgam pajahatha idam ca upasampajjāti idam catu magga phala ppabhedam
translated: Thus let them give attention: thus let them give attention only to the perception of impermanence, or to one among the perceptions of pain, etc., beginning with that. Let them not give attention thus: let them not give attention by way of the perception of permanence, etc., beginning with that.🔽Let them abandon: let them abandon this lust for the five strands of sense pleasure.

original: lokuttaradhammameva upasampajja pāpuṇitvā nipphādetvā viharatha.
analyzed: lokuttara dhammam eva upasampajja pāpuṇitvā nipphādetvā viharatha
translated: And let them enter upon and abide in: let them enter upon and attain and reach and realize only the supramundane Dhamma classed as the four paths and their fruits.

original: Māyāsahadhammarūpaṃ viya khāyatīti māyāya samānakāraṇajātikaṃ viya hutvā upaṭṭhāti.
analyzed: māyā sahadhamma rūpam viya khāyati iti māyāya samāna kāraṇa jātikam viya hutvā upaṭṭhāti
translated: It appears as though it were a thing of the same nature as the illusion, thus it appears as though it were a thing of the same nature as the illusion.

original: Māyākāropi hi udakaṃ gahetvā telaṃ karoti, telaṃ gahetvā udakanti evaṃ anekarūpaṃ
analyzed: māyākāraḥ api hi udakam gahetvā telam karoti telam gahetvā evam aneka rūpam
translated: For the magician, having taken water, makes it oil, and having taken oil, makes it water, and so he shows various illusions.🔽This miracle is of the same kind.

original: māyaṃ dasseti. Idampi pāṭihāriyaṃ tathārūpamevāti. Idampi me, bho gotama, pāṭihāriyaṃ
analyzed: mā ayam dassa iti idam pi pāṭihāriyam tathārūpam eva ati idam pi me bho gotama pāṭihāriyam
translated: This miracle of yours, Master Gotama, appears as though it were a thing of the same nature as the illusion.

original: māyāsahadhammarūpaṃ viya khāyatīti cintāmaṇikavijjāsarikkhakataṃ sandhāya evaṃ āha.
analyzed: māyā sahadhamma rūpam viya khāyati iti sandhāya evam āha
translated: He said this with reference to the knowledge of the wish-fulfilling gem.

original: Cintāmaṇikavijjaṃ jānantāpi hi āgacchantameva disvā “ayaṃ idaṃ nāma vitakkento āgacchatī”ti🔽jānanti. Tathā “idaṃ nāma vitakkento ṭhito, idaṃ nāma vitakkento nisinno, idaṃ nāma
analyzed: cintāmaṇika vijjam jānantā api hi āgacchantam eva disvā ayam idam nāma vitakkentaḥ āgacchati iti  jānanti tathā idam nāma vitakkentaḥ ṭhitaḥ idam nāma vitakkentaḥ nisinnaḥ idam nāma
translated: For those who know the knowledge of the wish-fulfilling gem know that “he is coming after thinking of such and such a thing.”

original: vitakkento nipanno”ti jānanti.
analyzed: vitakkentaḥ nipannaḥ iti jānanti
translated: In the same way they know that “he is standing after thinking of such and such a thing, he is sitting after thinking of such and such a thing, he is lying down after thinking of such and such a thing.”

original: Abhikkantataranti sundarataraṃ. Paṇītataranti uttamataraṃ. Bhavañhi gotamo avitakkaṃ
analyzed: abhikkantataranti sundarataram paṇītataranti uttamataram bhavan hi gotamaḥ a vitakkam
translated: More excellent: more beautiful. More sublime: more exalted.

original: avicāranti idha brāhmaṇo avasesaṃ ādesanāpāṭihāriyaṃ bāhirakanti na gaṇhi. Idañca
analyzed: brāhmaṇaḥ avasesam ādesanā pāṭihāriyam na idam ca
translated: ‘Without hesitation’: here the brahmin did not take the rest of the miracle of instruction as being that of an outsider.

original: pana sabbaṃ so brāhmaṇo tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ kathentoyeva āha. Addhā kho tyāyanti🔽ekaṃseneva tayā ayaṃ. Āsajja upanīya vācā bhāsitāti mama guṇe ghaṭṭetvā mameva guṇānaṃ
analyzed: pana sabbam saḥ brāhmaṇaḥ tathāgatassa vaṇṇam āha addhā kho tyāyanti  ekaṃsena iva tayā ayam āsajjaḥ upanīya vācā bhāsitā ati mama guṇe ghaṭṭetvā mama iva
translated: But all this the brahmin said as though praising the Tathāgata.🔽‘Surely you will not be able to conceal it from me’: you will not be able to conceal it from me by any means.

original: santikaṃ upanītā vācā bhāsitā. Apica tyāhaṃ byākarissāmīti apica te ahameva kathessāmīti.
analyzed: santikam upanītā vācā bhāsitā apica tyā aham byākarissāmi iti apica te aham eva kathessāmi iti
translated: ‘Having brought it up, you speak’: having brought up my special qualities, you speak with words that are near to my special qualities. Moreover, ‘I will explain it to you’ means ‘I will tell it to you myself.’

original: Sesaṃ uttānatthamevāti.
analyzed: sesam uttānattham eva ati
translated: The rest is clear in meaning.

original: Brāhmaṇavaggo paṭhamo.
analyzed: brāhmaṇa vaggo paṭhamaḥ
translated: The first vagga is concluded.

original: (7) 2. Mahāvaggo
analyzed: mahāvaggaḥ
translated: The Great Chapter

original: 1. Titthāyatanasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: titthāyatana sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Discussion of the Bases of Disputes

original: 62. Dutiyassa paṭhame titthāyatanānīti titthabhūtāni āyatanāni, titthiyānaṃ vā āyatanāni.
analyzed: dutiyassa paṭhame tittha āyatanāni iti tittha bhūtāni āyatanāni titthiyānam vā āyatanāni
translated: In the first sutta of the second vagga, ‘bases of disputes’ means bases that are disputed, or bases of those who dispute.

original: Tattha titthaṃ jānitabbaṃ, titthakarā jānitabbā, titthiyā jānitabbā, titthiyasāvakā
analyzed: tattha tittham jānitabbam titthakarāḥ jānitabbā titthiyāḥ jānitabbā titthiya sāvakā
translated: Herein, the dispute should be known, the originators of the dispute should be known, the disputants should be known,

original: jānitabbā. Titthaṃ nāma dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhiyo. Titthikarā nāma tāsaṃ diṭṭhīnaṃ uppādakā.
analyzed: jānitabbā tittham nāma dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhiyaḥ titthikarāḥ nāma tāsam diṭṭhīnam uppādakā
translated: the disciples of the disputants should be known. The dispute is the sixty-two views. The originators of the dispute are those who give rise to those views.

original: Titthiyā nāma yesaṃ tā diṭṭhiyo ruccanti khamanti. Titthiyasāvakā nāma tesaṃ paccayadāyakā.
analyzed: titthiyāḥ nāma yesam tāḥ diṭṭhiyaḥ ruccanti khamanti titthiya sāvakāḥ nāma tesam paccaya dāyakā
translated: “Heretics” are those who approve of and acquiesce in those views. “Heretics’ pupils” are those who give them the requisites.

original: Āyatananti “kambojo assānaṃ āyatanaṃ, gunnaṃ dakkhiṇāpatho āyatana”nti ettha sañjātiṭṭhānaṃ āyatanaṃ nāma.
analyzed: āyatananti kambojaḥ assānam āyatanam gunnam dakkhiṇāpathaḥ āyatananti ettha sañjā atiṭṭhānam āyatanam nāma
translated: “The place of origin” is the place of birth. “The place of horses is Kamboja, the place of cattle is the South Country” .

original: “Manorame āyatane, sevanti naṃ vihaṅgamā;
analyzed: manorame āyatane sevanti nam vihaṅgamā
translated: “In a delightful place the birds enjoy it,

original: Chāyaṃ chāyatthino yanti, phalatthaṃ phalabhojino”ti. –
analyzed: chāyam chāyatthinaḥ yanti phalattham phala bhojinaḥ uti
translated: Those that need shade go to the shade, those that want fruit to the fruit” .

original: Ettha samosaraṇaṭṭhānaṃ. “Pañcimāni, bhikkhave, vimuttāyatanānī”ti ettha kāraṇaṃ.
analyzed: ettha samosaraṇa ṭṭhānam pañcimāni bhikkhave vimutta āyatanāni iti ettha kāraṇam
translated: Here it is the place of resort. “Bhikkhus, there are these five places of resort” .

original: Taṃ idha sabbampi labbhati. Sabbepi hi diṭṭhigatikā sañjāyamānā imesuyeva tīsu ṭhānesu🔽sañjāyanti, samosaraṇamānāpi etesuyeva tīsu ṭhānesu samosaranti sannipatanti, diṭṭhigatikabhāve
analyzed: tat idha sabbam api labbhati sabbe api hi diṭṭhi gatikā sañjāyamānāḥ imesu yeva tīsu ṭhānesu  sañjāyanti etesu yeva tīsu ṭhānesu samosaranti sannipatanti diṭṭhigatika bhāve
translated: Here all these are applicable. For all those who hold views are born in these three places,🔽and when they resort together they resort together in these three places, and these three are the reasons for their being those who hold views.

original: ca nesaṃ etāneva tīṇi kāraṇānīti titthabhūtāni sañjātiādinā atthena āyatanānītipi
analyzed: ca etān eva tīṇi kāraṇāni iti tittha bhūtāni sañjāti ādinā atthena āyatanāni iti pi
translated: So they are “places of origin” and so on in the sense of being the source, etc., of those who hold views.

original: titthāyatanāni. Tenevatthena titthiyānaṃ āyatanānītipi titthāyatanāni. Samanuyuñjiyamānānīti🔽kā nāmetā diṭṭhiyoti evaṃ pucchiyamānāni. Samanugāhiyamānānīti kiṃkāraṇā etā diṭṭhiyo
analyzed: titthāyatanāni tenevatthena titthiyānam āyatanāni itipi titthāyatanāni samanuyuñjiyamānāni iti  kā nāma etāḥ diṭṭhiyaḥ ti evam pucchiyamānāni samanugāhiyamānāni iti kiṃkāraṇāḥ etāḥ diṭṭhiyaḥ
translated: Are being cross-examined:🔽are being asked, “What is this view? ”🔽Are being cross-questioned:🔽are being properly questioned, “What is the reason why these views have arisen? ”

original: uppannāti evaṃ sammā anuggāhiyamānāni. Samanubhāsiyamānānīti paṭinissajjetha etāni
analyzed: uppannā ati evam sammā anuggāhiyamānāni samanubhāsiyamānāni iti paṭinissajjetha etāni
translated: Are being pressed:🔽are being properly advised, “Give up these evil false views. ”

original: pāpakāni diṭṭhigatānīti evaṃ sammā anusāsiyamānāni. Apica tīṇipi etāni anuyogapucchāvevacanāneva.🔽Tena vuttaṃ aṭṭhakathāyaṃ – “samanuyuñjatīti vā samanuggāhatīti vā samanubhāsatīti
analyzed: pāpakāni diṭṭhi gatāni iti evam sammā anusāsiyamānāni apica etāni  tena vuttam aṭṭhakathāyam samanuyuñjati iti vā samanuggāhati iti vā samanubhāsati iti
translated: Moreover, all three terms are simply synonyms for “cross-examination.”

original: vā esese ekaṭṭhe same samabhāge tajjāte taññevā”ti.
analyzed: vā esese ekaṭṭhe same sama bhāge tad jāte tat na eva ati
translated: Hence it is said in the commentary: “He cross-examines, he cross-questions, he presses—these are synonyms, having the same meaning, being of the same connotation and derivation” .

original: Parampi gantvāti ācariyaparamparā laddhiparamparā attabhāvaparamparāti etesu yaṃkiñci
analyzed: gantvā ati ācariya paramparā laddhi paramparā attabhāva paramparā ti etesu yaṃkiñci
translated: Having gone to the end: having gone to the end of the teacher’s succession, the succession of the doctrine, the succession of the person.

original: paramparaṃ gantvāpi. Akiriyāya saṇṭhahantīti akiriyamatte saṃtiṭṭhanti. “Amhākaṃ
analyzed: paramparam gantvā api akiriyāya saṇṭhahanti iti akiriya matte saṃtiṭṭhanti amhākam
translated: They settle down to inaction: they settle down to mere inaction.

original: ācariyo pubbekatavādī, amhākaṃ pācariyo pubbekatavādī, amhākaṃ ācariyapācariyo pubbekatavādī.🔽Amhākaṃ ācariyo issaranimmānavādī, amhākaṃ pācariyo issaranimmānavādī, amhākaṃ ācariyapācariyo
analyzed: ācariyaḥ pubbekata vādī amhākam pācariyaḥ pubbekata vādī amhākam ācariya pācariyaḥ pubbekata vādī  amhākam ācariyaḥ issara nimmāna vādī amhākam pācariyaḥ issara nimmāna vādī amhākam ācariya pācariyaḥ
translated: Our teacher was a former-&-later theorist, our teacher’s teacher was a former-&-later theorist, our teacher’s teacher’s teacher was a former-&-later theorist.🔽Our teacher was an act-of-will theorist, our teacher’s teacher was an act-of-will theorist, our teacher’s teacher’s teacher was an act-of-will theorist.

original: issaranimmānavādī. Amhākaṃ ācariyo ahetuapaccayavādī, amhākaṃ pācariyo ahetuapaccayavādī,
analyzed: issara nimmāna vādī amhākam ācariyaḥ ahetu apaccaya vādī amhākam pācariyaḥ ahetu apaccaya vādī
translated: Our teacher was a no-cause-no-condition theorist, our teacher’s teacher was a no-cause-no-condition theorist, our teacher’s teacher’s teacher was a no-cause-no-condition theorist.”

original: amhākaṃ ācariyapācariyo ahetuapaccayavādī”ti evaṃ gacchantāni hi etāni ācariyaparamparaṃ
analyzed: amhākam ācariya pācariyaḥ ahetu apaccaya vādī iti evam gacchantāni hi etāni ācariya paramparam
translated: These are called “going by way of the teacher’s lineage.”

original: gacchanti nāma. “Amhākaṃ ācariyo pubbekataladdhiko, amhākaṃ pācariyo…pe… amhākaṃ
analyzed: gacchanti nāma amhākam ācariyaḥ pubbekata laddhikaḥ amhākam pācariya upe amhākam
translated: “Our teacher was a former-&-later theorist, our teacher’s teacher was a former-&-later theorist, our teacher’s teacher’s teacher was a former-&-later theorist.🔽Our teacher was a no-cause-no-condition theorist, our teacher’s teacher was a no-cause-no-condition theorist, our teacher’s teacher’s teacher was a no-cause-no-condition theorist.”

original: ācariyapācariyo ahetuapaccayaladdhiko”ti evaṃ gacchantāni laddhiparamparaṃ gacchanti
analyzed: ācariya pācariyaḥ ahetu apaccaya laddhiko ti evam gacchantāni laddhi paramparam gacchanti
translated: These are called “going by way of the theory’s lineage.”

original: nāma. “Amhākaṃ ācariyassa attabhāvo pubbekatahetu, amhākaṃ pācariyassa…pe… amhākaṃ
analyzed: nāma amhākam ācariyassa atta bhāvo pubbekata hetu amhākam amhākam
translated: “Our teacher’s self was a result of former-&-later kamma, our teacher’s teacher’s self was a result of former-&-later kamma, our teacher’s teacher’s teacher’s self was a result of former-&-later kamma.🔽Our teacher’s self was a result of an act of will, our teacher’s teacher’s self was a result of an act of will, our teacher’s teacher’s teacher’s self was a result of an act of will.

original: ācariyapācariyassa attabhāvo ahetu apaccayo”ti evaṃ gacchantāni attabhāvaparamparaṃ🔽gacchanti nāma. Evaṃ pana suvidūrampi gacchantāni akiriyamatteyeva saṇṭhahanti, ekopi
analyzed: ācariya pācariyassa atta bhāvaḥ ahetu apaccayo ti evam gacchantāni atta bhāva paramparam  gacchanti nāma evam pana su vidūram pi gacchantāni saṇṭhahanti ekaḥ api
translated: “The self of the teacher’s teacher had no cause or condition.”🔽Thus they go on to a succession of selves.

original: etesaṃ diṭṭhigatikānaṃ kattā vā kāretā vā na paññāyati.
analyzed: etesam diṭṭhigatikānam kattā vā kāretā vā na paññāyati
translated: But though they go on thus to a very great distance, they come to rest in mere non-action. For no one of these theorists is found to be the doer or the instigator of what is done.

original: Purisapuggaloti satto. Kāmañca purisotipi vutte puggalotipi vutte sattoyeva vutto
analyzed: purisa puggalo ti satto kāmañca purisaḥ iti pi vutte puggalaḥ iti pi vutte sattaḥ yeva vuttaḥ
translated: “A person” is a being. And when “man” is said, and “individual” is said,

original: hoti, ayaṃ pana sammutikathā nāma yo yathā jānāti, tassa tathā vuccati. Paṭisaṃvedetīti
analyzed: hoti ayam pana sammuti kathā nāma yaḥ yathā jānāti tassa tathā vuccati paṭisaṃvedeti iti
translated: a being is what is said. But this is a matter of conventional discourse. One can say of a being what one knows of it.

original: attano santāne uppannaṃ jānāti paṭisaṃviditaṃ karoti, anubhavati vā. Pubbekatahetūti🔽pubbekatakāraṇā, pubbekatakammapaccayeneva paṭisaṃvedetīti attho. Iminā kammavedanañca
analyzed: attano santāne uppannam jānāti paṭisaṃviditam karoti anubhavati vā pubbekata hetū ti  pubbekata kāraṇā pubbekata kamma paccayena iva paṭisaṃvedeti iti atthaḥ iminā kamma vedanam ca
translated: “He experiences” : he knows, he makes known to himself, he feels what has arisen in his own continuity.

original: kiriyavedanañca paṭikkhipitvā ekaṃ vipākavedanameva sampaṭicchanti. Ye vā ime pittasamuṭṭhānā
analyzed: kiriya vedanam ca paṭikkhipitvā ekam vipāka vedanam eva sampaṭicchanti ye vā ime pitta samuṭṭhānāḥ
translated: “Because of what was done in the past” : because of a cause in the past. The meaning is: he experiences because of a condition consisting in kamma done in the past. By this they assert only a single result-experience, rejecting kamma-born feeling and functional feeling.🔽Or alternatively, “because of what was done in the past” is said in order to refute the doctrine of the Andhakas that the kamma that is the cause of the first javana in an existence is the cause of all the javanas in that existence.

original: ābādhā semhasamuṭṭhānā vātasamuṭṭhānā sannipātikā utupariṇāmajā visamaparihārajā
analyzed: ābādhā semha samuṭṭhānā vāta samuṭṭhānā sannipātikā utu pariṇāma jā visama parihāra jā
translated: The eight kinds of sickness mentioned are sickness due to wind, bile, phlegm, the three combined, change of climate, excessive demands,🔽untimely eating, and kamma-result. Of these, they admit only the last,

original: opakkamikā ābādhā kammavipākajā ābādhāti aṭṭha rogā vuttā, tesu satta paṭikkhipitvā🔽ekaṃ vipākavedanaṃyeva sampaṭicchanti. Yepime diṭṭhadhammavedanīyaṃ upapajjavedanīyaṃ🔽aparapariyāyavedanīyanti tayo kammarāsayo vuttā, tesupi dve paṭibāhitvā ekaṃ aparapariyāyakammaṃyeva🔽sampaṭicchanti. Yepime diṭṭhadhammavedanīyo vipāko upapajjavedanīyo aparapariyāyavedanīyoti
analyzed: opakkamikā ābādhā kamma vipāka jā ābādhā ati aṭṭha rogāḥ vuttā tesu satta paṭikkhipitvā  ekam vipāka vedanaṃ yā iva sampaṭicchanti ye pi me diṭṭhadhamma vedanīyam upapajja vedanīyam  apara pariyāya vedanīyanti tayo kamma rāsayaḥ vuttā tesu pi dve paṭibāhitvā ekam apara pariyāya kammaṃya eva  sampaṭicchanti ye pi ime diṭṭhadhamma vedanīyaḥ vipākaḥ upapajja vedanīyaḥ apara pariyāya vedanīyaḥ ti
translated: rejecting the other seven. The three kinds of kamma mentioned are kamma resulting in rebirth in the next moment, kamma resulting in rebirth in a later life,🔽and kamma resulting in rebirth at some unspecified future time. Of these, they admit only the last, rejecting the other two.

original: tayo vipākarāsayo vuttā, tesupi dve paṭibāhitvā ekaṃ aparapariyāyavipākameva sampaṭicchanti.🔽Yepime kusalacetanā akusalacetanā vipākacetanā kiriyacetanāti cattāro cetanārāsayo
analyzed: tayaḥ vipāka rāsayaḥ vuttā tesu pi dve paṭibāhitvā ekam apara pariyāya vipākam eva sampaṭicchanti  ye pi me kusala cetanā akusala cetanā vipāka cetanā kiriya cetanā ati cattāro cetanā rāsayo
translated: The three kinds of kamma-result mentioned are kamma-result experienced here and now, kamma-result experienced in the next life, and kamma-result experienced in some unspecified future life. Of these, they admit only the last, rejecting the other two.

original: vuttā, tesupi tayo paṭibāhitvā ekaṃ vipākacetanaṃyeva sampaṭicchanti.
analyzed: vuttā tesu pi tayo paṭibāhitvā ekam vipāka cetanaṃyā iva sampaṭicchanti
translated: The four kinds of volition mentioned are wholesome volition, unwholesome volition, resultant volition, and functional volition. Of these, they admit only the last, rejecting the other three.

original: Issaranimmānahetūti issaranimmānakāraṇā, issarena nimmitattā paṭisaṃvedetīti attho.🔽Ayaṃ hi tesaṃ adhippāyo – imā tisso vedanā paccuppanne attanā katamūlakena vā āṇattimūlakena
analyzed: issara nimmāna hetū ti issara nimmāna kāraṇā issarena nimmita ttā paṭisaṃvedeti iti attho  ayam hi tesam adhippāyaḥ imāḥ tissaḥ vedanāḥ paccuppanne attanā kata mūlakena vā āṇatti mūlakena
translated: ‘By the act of a creating God’: by the act of a creating God, by being created by a God, is what is meant.

original: vā pubbekatena vā ahetuapaccayā vā paṭisaṃvedituṃ nāma na sakkā, issaranimmānakāraṇāyeva🔽pana imā paṭisaṃvedetīti. Evaṃvādino panete heṭṭhā vuttesu aṭṭhasu rogesu ekampi
analyzed: vā pubbekatena vā ahetu apaccayāḥ vā paṭisaṃveditum nāma na sakkā issara nimmāna kāraṇāya iva  pana imā paṭisaṃvedeti iti evaṃvādinaḥ pana ete heṭṭhā vuttesu aṭṭhasu rogesu ekam pi
translated: For this is their intention: ‘These three kinds of feeling cannot be felt without a root of one’s own making or a root of one’s own commanding or a root made by another or a root commanded by another or a root made by a creating God or a root commanded by a creating God.🔽But they are felt only by the act of a creating God.’

original: asampaṭicchitvā sabbe paṭibāhanti, heṭṭhā vuttesu ca tīsu kammarāsīsu tīsu vipākarāsīsu
analyzed: a sampaṭicchitvā sabbe paṭibāhanti heṭṭhā vuttesu ca tīsu kamma rāsīsu tīsu vipāka rāsīsu
translated: But these people, denying all the eight diseases stated above, deny all the three kinds of roots of kamma stated above, the three kinds of ripening,

original: catūsu cetanārāsīsu ekampi asampaṭicchitvā sabbepi paṭibāhanti.
analyzed: catūsu cetanā rāsīsu ekam pi a sampaṭicchitvā sabbe pi paṭibāhanti
translated: and the four kinds of volition.

original: Ahetuapaccayāti hetuñca paccayañca vinā, akāraṇeneva paṭisaṃvedetīti attho. Ayañhi
analyzed: ahetu apaccayā ti hetuñca paccayañca vinā akāraṇena iva paṭisaṃvedeti iti atthaḥ ayam hi
translated: ‘Without cause or condition’: without cause and without condition, without reason, is what is meant.

original: nesaṃ adhippāyo – imā tisso vedanā paccuppanne attanā katamūlakena vā āṇattimūlakena
analyzed: na īsam adhippāyaḥ imāḥ tissaḥ vedanāḥ paccuppanne attanā kata mūlakena vā āṇatti mūlakena
translated: For this is their intention: ‘These three kinds of feeling cannot be felt without a root of one’s own making or a root of one’s own commanding or a root made by another or a root commanded by another or a root made by a creating God or a root commanded by a creating God.

original: vā pubbekatena vā issaranimmānahetunā vā paṭisaṃvedituṃ nāma na sakkā, ahetuapaccayāyeva
analyzed: vā pubbekatena vā issara nimmāna hetunā vā paṭisaṃveditum nāma na sakkā a hetu a paccayāya iva
translated: It is impossible to experience them as due to a former self, or due to a creator God, or without cause or condition.🔽But they experience them just because of this.

original: pana imā paṭisaṃvedetīti. Evaṃvādino panete heṭṭhā vuttesu rogādīsu ekampi asampaṭicchitvā sabbaṃ paṭibāhanti.
analyzed: pana imā paṭisaṃvedeti iti evaṃvādinaḥ pana ete heṭṭhā vuttesu roga ādīsu ekam pi a sampaṭicchitvā sabbam paṭibāhanti
translated: But they deny all the above-mentioned diseases, etc., and they deny everything.

original: Evaṃ satthā mātikaṃ nikkhipitvā idāni taṃ vibhajitvā dassetuṃ tatra, bhikkhavetiādimāha.
analyzed: evam satthā mātikam nikkhipitvā idāni tam vibhajitvā dassetum tatra bhikkhave ti ādim āha
translated: Having thus set out the schedule, the Master now divides it up and shows it to be untenable, saying, “Here, bhikkhus.”

original: Tattha evaṃ vadāmīti laddhipatiṭṭhāpanatthaṃ evaṃ vadāmīti dasseti. Laddhiñhi appatiṭṭhāpetvā🔽niggayhamānā laddhito laddhiṃ saṅkamanti, bho gotama, na mayaṃ pubbekatavādaṃ vadāmātiādīni
analyzed: tattha evam vadāmi iti laddhi patiṭṭhāpana attham evam vadāmi iti dasseti laddhim hi a patiṭṭhāpetvā  niggayhamānāḥ laddhitaḥ laddhim saṅkamanti bho gotama na mayam pubbekata vādam vadāma ati ādīni
translated: Here, bhikkhus, I say thus: he shows that he says thus in order to establish his doctrine. For if he does not establish his doctrine,🔽then when he is pressed for argument, he will say, “We do not say that there is a former self,” etc.,

original: vadanti. Laddhiyā pana patiṭṭhāpitāya saṅkamituṃ alabhantā suniggahitā honti, iti
analyzed: vadanti laddhiyā pana patiṭṭhāpitāya saṅkamitum a labhantā su niggahitāḥ honti iti
translated: But when his doctrine is established, he cannot escape, and so he is well pressed. Therefore he says, “Here, bhikkhus, I say thus.”

original: nesaṃ laddhipatiṭṭhāpanatthaṃ evaṃ vadāmīti āha. Tenahāyasmantoti tena hi āyasmanto.
analyzed: na īsam laddhi patiṭṭhāpana attham evam vadāmi iti āha tena hi āyasmanto ti tena hi āyasmanto
translated: “Therefore, venerable sirs”: therefore, venerable sirs.

original: Kiṃ vuttaṃ hoti – yadi etaṃ saccaṃ, evaṃ sante tena tumhākaṃ vādena. Pāṇātipātino
analyzed: kim vuttam hoti yadi etam saccam evam sante tena tumhākam vādena pāṇa atipātino
translated: What is meant? If this is true, then, according to your doctrine,

original: bhavissanti pubbekatahetūti ye keci loke pāṇaṃ atipātenti, sabbe te pubbekatahetu🔽pāṇātipātino bhavissanti. Kiṃkāraṇā? Na hi pāṇātipātakammaṃ attanā katamūlakena na
analyzed: bhavissanti pubbekata hetū ti ye keci loke pāṇam atipātenti sabbe te pubbekata hetu  pāṇa atipātinaḥ bhavissanti kiṃkāraṇā na hi pāṇa atipāta kammaṃ attanā kata mūlakena na
translated: all those in the world who kill living beings are killers of living beings because of kamma done in the past.🔽Why? For it is not possible to experience the result of killing living beings without a root cause,

original: āṇattimūlakena na issaranimmānahetunā na ahetuapaccayā sakkā paṭisaṃvedetuṃ, pubbekatahetuyeva🔽paṭisaṃvedetīti ayaṃ vo laddhi. Yathā ca pāṇātipātino, evaṃ pāṇātipātā viramantāpi
analyzed: āṇatti mūlakena na issara nimmāna hetunā na ahetua paccayā sakkā paṭisaṃvedetum pubbekata hetuyā iva  paṭisaṃvedeti iti ayam vaḥ laddhi yathā ca pāṇātipātinaḥ evam pāṇātipātāḥ viramanta api
translated: without a cause consisting of a prior volition, without a cause consisting of a creator god, without a cause consisting of a primal essence, without a cause consisting of chance, without a cause consisting of past kamma.🔽You hold that it is experienced only because of kamma done in the past.🔽And just as those who kill living beings do so because of kamma done in the past, so too those who abstain from killing living beings do so because of kamma done in the past.

original: pubbekatahetuyeva viramissantīti. Iti bhagavā tesaṃyeva laddhiṃ gahetvā tesaṃ niggahaṃ
analyzed: pubbekata hetuyā iva viramissanti iti iti bhagavā tesam yeva laddhim gahetvā tesam niggaham
translated: Thus the Exalted One, taking their very doctrine as a basis,

original: āropeti. Iminā nayena adinnādāyinotiādīsupi yojanā veditabbā.
analyzed: āropa iti iminā nayena yojanā veditabbā
translated: confutes them. And the explanation should be understood in this way in the case of the other terms beginning with “taking what is not given.”

original: Sārato paccāgacchatanti sārabhāvena gaṇhantānaṃ. Chandoti kattukamyatāchando. Idaṃ
analyzed: sārataḥ sāra bhāvena chandaḥ iti kattu kamyatā chandaḥ idam
translated: “Those who take what is not given because of a belief in a real self”: those who take what is not given because they apprehend a real self and what belongs to a self.

original: vā karaṇīyaṃ idaṃ vā akaraṇīyanti ettha ayaṃ adhippāyo – idaṃ vā karaṇīyanti kattabbassa
analyzed: vā karaṇīyam idam vā a karaṇīyanti ettha ayam adhippāyaḥ idam vā karaṇīyanti kattabbassa
translated: Herein, the purport of the words “in what should be done and in what should not be done” is this. In what should be done is for the purpose of doing what should be done,

original: karaṇatthāya, idaṃ vā akaraṇīyanti akattabbassa akaraṇatthāya kattukamyatā vā paccattapurisakāro
analyzed: karaṇa atthāya idam vā a karaṇīyanti a kattabbassa a karaṇa atthāya kattu kamya tā vā paccatta purisakāro
translated: and in what should not be done is for the purpose of not doing what should not be done. Or alternatively, in what should be done is for the purpose of the desire to do what should be done, and in what should not be done is for the purpose of the effort not to do what should not be done.

original: vā na hoti. Chandavāyāmesu vā asantesu “idaṃ kattabba”ntipi “idaṃ na kattabba”ntipi
analyzed: vā na hoti chanda vāyāmesu vā asantesu idam kattabbanti ipi idam na kattabbanti ipi
translated: And when there is no desire and no effort, there is no “this should be done” or “this should not be done.”

original: na hoti. Iti karaṇīyākaraṇīye kho pana saccato thetato anupalabbhiyamāneti evaṃ kattabbe🔽ca akattabbe ca bhūtato thirato apaññāyamāne alabbhamāne. Yadi hi kattabbaṃ kātuṃ
analyzed: na hoti iti karaṇīya akaraṇīye kho pana saccataḥ thetataḥ evam kattabbe  ca a kattabbe ca bhūtataḥ thirataḥ a paññāyamāne a labbhamāne yadi hi kattabbam kātum
translated: So when what should be done and what should not be done are not apprehended as real and true,

original: akattabbato ca viramituṃ labheyya, karaṇīyākaraṇīyaṃ saccato thetato upalabbheyya.
analyzed: a kattabbataḥ ca viramitum labheyya karaṇīya a karaṇīyam saccataḥ thetataḥ upalabbheyya
translated: if it were possible to do what should be done and to refrain from what should not be done, then what should be done and what should not be done would be apprehended as real and true.

original: Yasmā pana ubhayampi taṃ esa nupalabbhati, tasmā taṃ saccato thetato na upalabbhati,
analyzed: yasmā pana ubhayam pi tam na upalabbhati tasmā tam saccatas na upalabbhati
translated: But since he does not apprehend either of them, therefore he does not apprehend them as real and true,

original: evaṃ tasmiṃ ca anupalabbhiyamāneti attho. Muṭṭhassatīnanti naṭṭhassatīnaṃ vissaṭṭhassatīnaṃ.
analyzed: evam tasmin ca anupalabbhiyamāna iti atthaḥ muṭṭha ssatīnam ti naṭṭha ssatīnam vissaṭṭha ssatīnam
translated: With their mindfulness unestablished: with their mindfulness lost, with their mindfulness scattered.🔽Dwelling without protection: dwelling without protection in the six sense doors.🔽There is no individual

original: Anārakkhānaṃ viharatanti chasu dvāresu nirārakkhānaṃ viharantānaṃ. Na hoti paccattaṃ🔽sahadhammiko samaṇavādoti evaṃ bhūtānaṃ tumhākaṃ vā aññesaṃ vā mayaṃ samaṇāti paccattaṃ
analyzed: chasu dvāresu nirārakkhānam viharantānam na hoti paccattam  sahadhammikaḥ samaṇa vādo ti evam bhūtānam tumhākam vā aññesam vā mayam samaṇa ati paccattam
translated: reason for the designation “ascetic.”

original: sakāraṇo samaṇavādo na hoti na ijjhati. Samaṇāpi hi pubbekatakāraṇāyeva honti, assamaṇāpi
analyzed: sa kāraṇaḥ samaṇa vādaḥ na hoti na ijjhati samaṇāḥ api hi pubbekata kāraṇāya iva honti assamaṇāḥ api
translated: Thus, when you are such or others are such, there is no individual reason, no ground, for the designation “ascetic” for us or for anyone else. For ascetics were so called in the past for a specific reason, and non-ascetics were so called in the past for a specific reason.🔽“Individual reason” means “reason” .🔽“There is a designation” means “I designate” .

original: pubbekatakāraṇāyevāti. Sahadhammikoti sakāraṇo. Niggaho hotīti mama niggaho hoti,🔽te pana niggahitā hontīti.
analyzed: pubbekata kāraṇāya iva ati sahadhammikaḥ iti sa kāraṇaḥ niggahaḥ hoti iti mama niggahaḥ hoti  te pana niggahitāḥ honti iti
translated: “They are designated” means “they are designated by me.”

original: Evaṃ pubbekatavādino niggahetvā idāni issaranimmānavādino niggahetuṃ tatra, bhikkhavetiādimāha. Tassattho pubbekatavāde vuttanayeneva veditabbo, tathā ahetukavādepi.
analyzed: evam pubbekata vādinaḥ niggahetvā idāni issara nimmāna vādinaḥ niggahetum tatra bhikkhave ti ādim āha tassa atthaḥ pubbekata vāde vutta nayena iva veditabbaḥ tathā ahetuka vāde pi
translated: Having thus refuted the doctrine of the origination of beings through a single cause, the Exalted One now said, “Bhikkhus, in this case,” in order to refute the doctrine of the origination of beings through the creative act of God. The meaning should be understood in the way already stated in the case of the doctrine of a single cause, and also in the case of the doctrine of causeless origination.

original: Evaṃ imesaṃ titthāyatanānaṃ parampi gantvā akiriyāya saṇṭhahanabhāvena tucchabhāvaṃ
analyzed: evam imesam titthāyatanānam parampi gantvā a kiriyāya saṇṭhahana bhāvena tuccha bhāvam
translated: In this way, after going beyond the other sects, he shows the emptiness of their doctrines by their ending in inaction,

original: aniyyānikabhāvaṃ, asārabhāvena thusakoṭṭanasadisataṃ āpajjanabhāvena aggisaññāya🔽dhamamānakhajjupanakasarikkhataṃ taṃdiṭṭhikānaṃ purimassapi majjhimassapi pacchimassapi
analyzed: aniyyānika bhāvam asāra bhāvena thusa koṭṭana sadisa tam āpajjana bhāvena aggi saññāya  taṃdiṭṭhikānam purimassa api majjhimassa api pacchimassa api
translated: their unfruitfulness by their being like a heap of chaff, their pithlessness by their being like a burning grass-fire,🔽and their being like a blind alley for those who hold those views, whether they are of the first, middle, or last generation, by their lack of any teaching of the meaning.

original: atthadassanatāya abhāvena andhaveṇūpamataṃ saddamatteneva tāni gahetvā sāradiṭṭhikānaṃ
analyzed: attha dassana tāya abhāvena andha veṇu upama tam sadda mattena iva tāni gahetvā sāra diṭṭhikānam
translated: He shows the similarity of those who hold such views to those who grasp at mere sound,

original: pathaviyaṃ patitassa beluvapakkassa daddabhāyitasaddaṃ sutvā “pathavī saṃvaṭṭamānā🔽āgacchatī”ti saññāya palāyantena sasakena sarikkhabhāvañca dassetvā idāni attanā
analyzed: pathaviyam patitassa beluva pakkassa daddabhāyita saddam sutvā pathavī saṃvaṭṭamānā  āgacchati iti saññāya palāyantena sasakena sarikkha bhāvañca dassetvā idāni attanā
translated: and to the hare who, hearing the sound of a bel fruit falling on a leaf in the forest, thinks: “The earth is breaking up and coming together again,” and flees in terror.

original: desitassa dhammassa sārabhāvañceva niyyānikabhāvañca dassetuṃ ayaṃ kho pana, bhikkhavetiādimāha.
analyzed: desitassa dhammassa sāra bhāvañca iva niyyānika bhāvañca dassetuṃ ayam kho pana bhikkhave tiādim āha
translated: Now, in order to show the fruitfulness and the unfruitfulness of his own doctrine, he says: “Monks, this is the only path for the purification of beings, for the surmounting of sorrow and lamentation, for the disappearance of dukkha and depression, for the attainment of the true way, for the realization of Nibbāna, that is to say, the four foundations of mindfulness.”

original: Tattha aniggahitoti aññehi aniggahito niggahetuṃ asakkuṇeyyo. Asaṃkiliṭṭhoti nikkileso
analyzed: tattha aniggahitoti aññehi aniggahitaḥ niggahetum asakkuṇeyyaḥ a saṃkiliṭṭhaḥ ti nikkilesaḥ
translated: Herein, unfettered means not fettered by others, not to be fettered by others. Unpolluted means free from defilements.

original: parisuddho, “saṃkiliṭṭhaṃ naṃ karissāmā”ti pavattehipi tathā kātuṃ asakkuṇeyyo. Anupavajjoti
analyzed: parisuddhaḥ saṃkiliṭṭham nam karissāma ati pavattehi pi tathā kātum a sakkuṇeyyaḥ
translated: He is pure, and they cannot make him impure.🔽He is free from blame: he is free from the blame of the world and of the Dhamma.

original: upavādavinimutto. Appaṭikuṭṭhoti “kiṃ iminā haratha na”nti evaṃ appaṭibāhito, anupakkuṭṭho
analyzed: upavāda vinimuttaḥ appaṭikuṭṭhaḥ ti kim iminā haratha evam a paṭibāhitaḥ an upakkuṭṭhaḥ
translated: He is not despised: he is not despised by the wise, who do not say: “What is the use of him? Throw him away!”

original: vā. Viññūhīti paṇḍitehi. Apaṇḍitānañhi ajānitvā kathentānaṃ vacanaṃ appamāṇaṃ. Tasmā viññūhīti āha.🔽Idāni tassa dhammassa dassanatthaṃ “katamo ca, bhikkhave”ti pañhaṃ pucchitvā “imā
analyzed: vā viññūhi iti paṇḍitehi apaṇḍitānam hi a jānitvā kathentānam vacanam appamāṇam tasmai viññūhi iti āha  idāni tassa dhammassa dassana attham katamaḥ ca bhikkhave ti pañham pucchitvā imā
translated: By the wise: by the wise ones, the learned ones. For the words of the ignorant who do not know are not authoritative. Therefore he says “by the wise.”

original: cha dhātuyo”tiādinā nayena mātikaṃ nikkhipitvā yathāpaṭipāṭiyā vibhajitvā dassento🔽puna imā cha dhātuyotiādimāha. Tattha dhātuyoti sabhāvā. Nijjīvanissattabhāvappakāsako
analyzed: cha dhātuyo ti ādinā nayena mātikam nikkhipitvā yathā paṭipāṭiyā vibhajitvā dassento  punar imā cha dhātuyo ti ādim āha tattha sabhāvā
translated: Now, in order to show that Dhamma, he asks the question, “And what, bhikkhus, is that Dhamma?” and he sets forth the mātikā beginning with “The six elements” . Then, in the order of the mātikā, he shows it with the words “The six elements” , etc.🔽Herein, elements means individual essences.🔽For the meaning of “element” is the meaning of “individual essence,” which is the manifestation of the individual nature of the living being.

original: hi sabhāvaṭṭho dhātvaṭṭho nāma. Phassāyatanānīti vipākaphassānaṃ ākaraṭṭhena āyatanāni.
analyzed: hi sabhāvaṭṭhaḥ dhātu aṭṭhaḥ nāma phassa āyatanāni iti vipāka phassānam ākaraṭṭhena āyatanāni
translated: The bases for contact: the six bases for the ripening of contact, in the sense of being its source.

original: Manopavicārāti vitakkavicārapādehi aṭṭhārasasu ṭhānesu manassa upavicārā.
analyzed: mana upavicārā ati vitakka vicāra pādehi aṭṭhārasasu ṭhānesu manassa upavicārā
translated: The mind’s determinations: the mind’s determinations in the eighteen grounds, which are the bases for the mind’s determinations in the form of applied and sustained thought.

original: Pathavīdhātūti patiṭṭhādhātu. Āpodhātūti ābandhanadhātu. Tejodhātūti paripācanadhātu.
analyzed: pathavī dhātu uti patiṭṭhā dhātu āpaḥ dhātu uti ābandhana dhātu tejaḥ dhātu uti paripācana dhātu
translated: The earth element is the element of support. The water element is the element of cohesion. The fire element is the element of maturing.

original: Vāyodhātūti vitthambhanadhātu. Ākāsadhātūti asamphuṭṭhadhātu. Viññāṇadhātūti vijānanadhātu.🔽Evamidaṃ dhātukammaṭṭhānaṃ āgataṃ. Taṃ kho panetaṃ saṅkhepato āgataṭṭhāne saṅkhepatopi
analyzed: vāyo dhātu uti vitthambhana dhātu ākāsa dhātu uti a samphuṭṭha dhātu viññāṇa dhātu uti vijānana dhātu  evam idam dhātu kammaṭṭhānam āgatam tam kho pana itam saṅkhepataḥ āgata ṭhāne saṅkhepataḥ pi
translated: The air element is the element of distension. The space element is the element of non- obstruction. The consciousness element is the element of cognizing.🔽So this meditation subject comes into the Abhidhamma.🔽But although it comes into the Abhidhamma in brief, it can be expounded in brief and in detail in the place where it comes into the Abhidhamma.

original: vitthāratopi kathetuṃ vaṭṭati. Vitthārato āgataṭṭhāne saṅkhepato kathetuṃ na vaṭṭati,🔽vitthāratova vaṭṭati. Imasmiṃ pana titthāyatanasutte idaṃ saṅkhepato chadhātuvasena
analyzed: vitthārataḥ api kathetum vaṭṭati vitthārataḥ āgata ṭṭhāne saṅkhepato kathetum na vaṭṭati  vitthārataḥ iva vaṭṭati imasmim pana tittha āyatana sutte idam saṅkhepato cha dhātu vasena
translated: In the place where it comes into the Abhidhamma in detail, it cannot be expounded in brief;🔽it can only be expounded in detail. But in this Sutta of the Unanswered Questions the meditation subject comes in brief,

original: kammaṭṭhānaṃ āgataṃ. Taṃ ubhayathāpi kathetuṃ vaṭṭati.
analyzed: kammaṭṭhānam āgatam tam ubhayathā api kathetum vaṭṭati
translated: in terms of the six elements. It can be expounded in both ways.

original: Saṅkhepato chadhātuvasena kammaṭṭhānaṃ pariggaṇhantopi evaṃ pariggaṇhāti – pathavīdhātu
analyzed: saṅkhepataḥ cha dhātu vasena kammaṭṭhānam pariggaṇhantaḥ api evam pariggaṇhāti pathavī dhātu
translated: When he is discerning the meditation subject in the six elements in brief, he discerns it thus: the earth element,

original: āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātūti imāni cattāri mahābhūtāni, ākāsadhātu upādārūpaṃ.
analyzed: āpaḥ dhātu tejaḥ dhātu vāyaḥ dhātu uti imāni cattāri mahābhūtāni ākāsa dhātu upādā rūpam
translated: the water element, the fire element, the air element, the space element, the consciousness element.

original: Ekasmiṃ ca upādārūpe diṭṭhe sesāni tevīsati diṭṭhānevāti sallakkhetabbāni. Viññāṇadhātūti
analyzed: ekasmim ca upādā rūpe diṭṭhe sesāni tevīsati diṭṭhāneva ati sallakkhetabbāni viññāṇa dhātū ti
translated: and when one derived materiality is seen, the remaining twenty-three are seen too. The consciousness element is

original: cittaṃ viññāṇakkhandho hoti, tena sahajātā vedanā vedanākkhandho, saññā saññākkhandho,🔽phasso ca cetanā ca saṅkhārakkhandhoti ime cattāro arūpakkhandhā nāma. Cattāri pana🔽mahābhūtāni catunnañca mahābhūtānaṃ upādārūpaṃ rūpakkhandho nāma. Tattha cattāro
analyzed: cittam viññāṇa kkhandhaḥ hoti tena sahajātā vedanā vedanā kkhandho saññā saññā kkhandho  phasso ca cetanā ca saṅkhāra kkhandho ti ime cattāro arūpa kkhandhāḥ nāma cattāri pana  mahābhūtāni catunnam ca mahābhūtānam upādā rūpam rūpakkhandho nāma tattha cattāro
translated: the mind, which is the consciousness aggregate. The feeling associated with it is the feeling aggregate. Perception is the perception aggregate.

original: arūpakkhandhā nāmaṃ, rūpakkhandho rūpanti nāmañca rūpañcāti dveyeva dhammā honti,🔽tato uddhaṃ satto vā jīvo vā natthīti evaṃ ekassa bhikkhuno saṅkhepato chadhātuvasena
analyzed: arūpa khandhāḥ nāmam rūpa kkhandhaḥ rūpanti nāman ca rūpan ca ati dveyeva dhammāḥ honti  tatas uddham sattaḥ vā jīvaḥ vā natthi iti evam ekassa bhikkhuno saṅkhepataḥ cha dhātu vasena
translated: Contact and volition are the formations aggregate. These four immaterial aggregates are called “name.” The four great primaries and the derived materiality of the four great primaries are the materiality aggregate. Herein, the four immaterial aggregates are “name,” and the materiality aggregate is “form.” So there are only two things,

original: arahattasampāpakaṃ kammaṭṭhānaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: arahatta sampāpakam kammaṭṭhānam veditabbam
translated: name and form. Beyond that there is no being or soul. This is how a bhikkhu should understand the meditation subject that leads to the destruction of suffering in brief by way of the six elements.

original: Vitthārato pariggaṇhanto pana cattāri mahābhūtāni pariggaṇhitvā ākāsadhātupariggahānusārena
analyzed: vitthārataḥ pariggaṇhantaḥ pana cattāri mahābhūtāni pariggaṇhitvā ākāsa dhātu pariggaha anusārena
translated: But one who wants to comprehend it in detail should do so by way of the four great primaries, following the exposition of the space element in the Paṭisambhidā:

original: tevīsati upādārūpāni pariggaṇhāti. Atha nesaṃ paccayaṃ upaparikkhanto puna cattāreva🔽mahābhūtāni disvā tesu pathavīdhātu vīsatikoṭṭhāsā, āpodhātu dvādasa, tejodhātu cattāro,
analyzed: tevīsati upādā rūpāni pariggaṇhāti atha nesam paccayam upaparikkhanto puna cattāri eva  mahābhūtāni disvā tesu pathavī dhātu vīsati koṭṭhāsāḥ āpodhātu dvādasa tejodhātu cattāro
translated: He discerns the twenty-three kinds of derived materiality. Then, as he investigates their conditions, he sees the four great primaries.🔽The earth element has twenty parts, the water element twelve, the fire element four,

original: vāyodhātu chakoṭṭhāsāti koṭṭhāsavasena samodhānetvā dvācattālīsa mahābhūtāni ca vavatthapetvā
analyzed: vāyodhātu koṭṭhāsa vasena samodhānetvā dvācattālīsa mahābhūtāni ca vavatthapetvā
translated: and the air element six parts. Thus he defines the forty-two great primaries.

original: tesu tevīsati upādārūpāni pakkhipitvā pañcasaṭṭhi rūpāni vavatthapeti. Tāni ca vatthurūpena
analyzed: tesu tevīsati upādā rūpāni pakkhipitvā pañcasaṭṭhi rūpāni vavatthapeti tāni ca vatthu rūpena
translated: Then he includes the twenty-three kinds of derived materiality in them and defines the sixty-five kinds of materiality.🔽Together with the materiality of the physical basis, they make sixty-six.

original: saddhiṃ chasaṭṭhi hontīti chasaṭṭhi rūpāni passati. Viññāṇadhātu pana lokiyacittavasena🔽ekāsīti cittāni. Tāni sabbānipi viññāṇakkhandho nāma hoti. Tehi sahajātā vedanādayopi
analyzed: saddhim cha saṭṭhi honti iti cha saṭṭhi rūpāni passati viññāṇa dhātu pana lokiya citta vasena  cittāni tāni sabbāni pi viññāṇa kkhandho nāma hoti tehi sahajātāḥ vedanā ādayaḥ api
translated: He sees sixty-six kinds of materiality. The consciousness element is eighty-one kinds of mundane consciousness.🔽All these are called the consciousness aggregate. The feeling, perception, and formations associated with them

original: tattakāyevāti ekāsīti vedanā vedanākkhandho, ekāsīti saññā saññākkhandho, ekāsīti
analyzed: tattakāya iva ati ekā asi iti vedanā vedanā khandho ekā asi iti saññā saññā khandho ekā asi iti
translated: are also of the same number. Thus there are eighty-one kinds of feeling, which are the feeling aggregate, eighty-one kinds of perception, which are the perception aggregate, and eighty-one kinds of formations, which are the formations aggregate.

original: cetanā saṅkhārakkhandhoti ime cattāro arūpakkhandhā tebhūmakavasena gayhamānā catuvīsādhikāni🔽tīṇi dhammasatāni hontīti iti ime ca arūpadhammā chasaṭṭhi ca rūpadhammāti sabbepi
analyzed: cetanā saṅkhāra kkhandho ti ime cattāraḥ arūpa kkhandhā tebhūmaka vasena gayhamānā catuvīsa adhikāni  tīṇi dhamma satāni honti iti iti ime ca arūpa dhammā chasaṭṭhi ca rūpa dhammā ati sabbe pi
translated: The volition is the formations aggregate. These four immaterial aggregates, when taken with the three planes, amount to three hundred and twenty-two kinds of states.🔽So these immaterial states and the sixty kinds of material states make

original: samodhānetvā nāmañca rūpañcāti dveva dhammā honti, tato uddhaṃ satto vā jīvo vā natthīti🔽nāmarūpavasena pañcakkhandhe vavatthapetvā tesaṃ paccayaṃ pariyesanto avijjāpaccayā
analyzed: samodhānetvā nāman ca rūpam ca ati dve iva dhammāḥ honti tatas uddham satto vā jīvo vā natthi iti  nāma rūpa vasena pañca kkhandhe vavatthapetvā tesam paccayam pariyesantaḥ avijjā paccayā
translated: a total of two hundred and eighty-two kinds of states. But when all these are condensed, there are only two kinds of states, namely, mentality and materiality. Beyond that there is no being or soul.

original: taṇhāpaccayā kammapaccayā āhārapaccayāti evaṃ paccayaṃ disvā “atītepi imehi paccayehi🔽idaṃ vaṭṭaṃ pavattittha, anāgatepi etehi paccayehi pavattissati, etarahipi etehiyeva
analyzed: taṇhā paccayā kamma paccayā āhāra paccayā ti evam paccayam disvā atīte pi imehi paccayehi  idam vaṭṭam anāgate pi etehi paccayehi pavattissati etarahi pi etehi yeva
translated: So when he has defined the five aggregates by means of mentality-materiality, and when he has sought out their condition, seeing that ignorance is their condition, craving is their condition, kamma is their condition, and nutriment is their condition, he sees that this round goes on occurring in the three divisions of time thus:🔽“In the past too this round occurred in this way with these conditions, and in the future too this round will occur in this way with these conditions,” and he dispels doubt in regard to the three periods of time.

original: pavattatī”ti tīsu kālesu kaṅkhaṃ vitaritvā anukkamena paṭipajjamāno arahattaṃ pāpuṇāti.
analyzed: pavattati iti tīsu kālesu kaṅkham vitaritvā anukkamena paṭipajjamānaḥ arahattam pāpuṇāti
translated: And as he continues to tread the path in due course he reaches Arahantship.

original: Evaṃ vitthāratopi chadhātuvasena arahattasampāpakaṃ kammaṭṭhānaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: evam vitthārataḥ api cha dhātu vasena arahatta sampāpakam kammaṭṭhānam veditabbam
translated: This is how the meditation subject that leads to Arahantship should be known as “developed” in detail.

original: Cakkhu phassāyatananti suvaṇṇādīnaṃ suvaṇṇādiākaro viya dve cakkhuviññāṇāni dve sampaṭicchanāni🔽tīṇi santīraṇānīti imehi sattahi viññāṇehi sahajātānaṃ sattannaṃ phassānaṃ samuṭṭhānaṭṭhena🔽ākaroti āyatanaṃ. Sotaṃ phassāyatanantiādīsupi eseva nayo. Mano phassāyatananti ettha
analyzed: cakkhu phassa āyatananti suvaṇṇa ādīnam suvaṇṇa ādi ākaraḥ viya dve cakkhu viññāṇāni dve sampaṭicchanāni  tīṇi santīraṇāni iti imehi sattahi viññāṇehi sahajātānam sattannam phassānam samuṭṭhāna aṭṭhena  ākaroti āyatanam sotam phassa āyatanan ti ādīsu pi esa iva nayaḥ mano phassa āyatanan ti ettha
translated: The eye base for contact: the eye is the source in the sense of being the origin of the seven kinds of contact associated with the two eye- consciousnesses and the two kinds of adverting.

original: pana dvāvīsati vipākaphassā yojetabbā. Iti hidaṃ chaphassāyatanānaṃ vasena kammaṭṭhānaṃ🔽āgataṃ. Taṃ saṅkhepatopi vitthāratopi kathetabbaṃ. Saṅkhepato tāva – ettha hi purimāni
analyzed: pana dvāvīsati vipāka phassāḥ yojetabbāḥ iti hi idam cha phassa āyatanānam vasena kammaṭṭhānam  āgatam tam saṅkhepataḥ api vitthārataḥ api kathetabbam saṅkhepataḥ tāva ettha hi purimāni
translated: The ear base for contact, etc., should be understood in the same way. The mind base for contact: here the twenty-two kinds of resultant contact should be understood. Thus the meditation subject comes to be stated in terms of the six bases for contact.

original: pañca āyatanāni upādārūpaṃ, tesu diṭṭhesu avasesaṃ upādārūpaṃ diṭṭhameva hoti. Chaṭṭhaṃ
analyzed: pañca āyatanāni upādā rūpam tesu diṭṭhesu avasesam upādā rūpam diṭṭham eva hoti chaṭṭham
translated: That should be expounded both in brief and in detail. In brief, firstly, the first five bases are the formed derived materiality. When they are seen, the rest of the formed derived materiality is also seen.

original: āyatanaṃ cittaṃ, taṃ viññāṇakkhandho hoti, tena sahajātā vedanādayo sesā tayo arūpakkhandhāti
analyzed: āyatanam cittam tam viññāṇa kkhandho hoti tena sahajātāḥ vedanā ādayo sesā tayo arūpa kkhandhā ti
translated: The sixth base is consciousness, which is the consciousness aggregate. The feeling, etc., associated with it are the remaining three immaterial aggregates.

original: heṭṭhā vuttanayeneva saṅkhepato ca vitthārato ca arahattasampāpakaṃ kammaṭṭhānaṃ veditabbaṃ.🔽Cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvāti cakkhuviññāṇena rūpaṃ passitvā. Somanassaṭṭhāniyanti somanassassa🔽kāraṇabhūtaṃ. Upavicaratīti tattha manaṃ cārento upavicarati. Sesapadesupi eseva🔽nayo. Ettha ca iṭṭhaṃ vā hotu aniṭṭhaṃ vā, yaṃ rūpaṃ disvā somanassaṃ uppajjati,
analyzed: heṭṭhā vutta nayena iva saṅkhepataḥ ca vitthārataḥ ca arahatta sampāpakam kammaṭṭhānam veditabbam  cakkhunā rūpam disvā ati cakkhu viññāṇena rūpam passitvā somanassa ṭṭhāniyanti somanassassa  kāraṇa bhūtam upavicarati iti tattha manam cārentaḥ upavicarati sesa padesu pi esā iva  nayo ettha ca iṭṭham vā hotu aniṭṭham vā yam rūpam disvā somanassam uppajjati
translated: The meditation subject that brings about the realization of Arahantship should be understood in brief and detail in the way already described.

original: taṃ somanassaṭṭhāniyaṃ nāma. Yaṃ disvā domanassaṃ uppajjati, taṃ domanassaṭṭhāniyaṃ🔽nāma. Yaṃ disvā upekkhā uppajjati, taṃ upekkhāṭṭhāniyaṃ nāmāti veditabbaṃ. Saddādīsupi
analyzed: tam somanassaṭṭhāniyam nāma yam disvā domanassam uppajjati tam domanassaṭṭhāniyam  nāma yam disvā upekkhā uppajjati tat upekkhāṭṭhāniyam nāma ati veditabbam sadda ādīsu pi
translated: On seeing a form with the eye: on seeing a visible form with eye-consciousness. A source of joy: a cause of joy. He pursues it: he pursues it with the mind. The same method of explanation applies in the case of the other phrases. Herein, whether a visible form is a source of joy or a source of grief or a source of equanimity should be understood in this way: when a man looks at a visible form and gladness arises in him, that visible form is a source of joy for him;🔽when resentment arises, it is a source of grief;

original: eseva nayo. Iti idaṃ saṅkhepato kammaṭṭhānaṃ āgataṃ. Taṃ kho panetaṃ saṅkhepato āgataṭṭhāne
analyzed: esa iva nayo iti idam saṅkhepataḥ kammaṭṭhānam āgatam tam kho pana itam saṅkhepataḥ āgata ṭṭhāne
translated: when on looking at it equanimity arises in him, it is a source of equanimity. The same method applies in the case of sounds cognizable by the ear, and so on. So this meditation subject comes into the brief treatment here.🔽But in the place where it is given in brief it is allowable to give it in detail,

original: saṅkhepatopi vitthāratopi kathetuṃ vaṭṭati. Vitthārato āgataṭṭhāne saṅkhepato kathetuṃ
analyzed: saṅkhepataḥ api vitthārataḥ api kathetum vaṭṭati vitthārataḥ āgata ṭṭhāne saṅkhepato kathetum
translated: and in the place where it is given in detail it is allowable to give it in brief.

original: na vaṭṭati. Imasmiṃ pana titthāyatanasutte idaṃ saṅkhepato aṭṭhārasamanopavicāravasena
analyzed: na vaṭṭati imasmin pana titthāyatana sutte idam saṅkhepataḥ aṭṭhārasa mana upavicāra vasena
translated: It is not allowable. But in this Thread of the Sectarians’ Creeds, this is the meaning in brief by way of the eighteen kinds of applied-thought pervasion:

original: kammaṭṭhānaṃ āgataṃ. Taṃ saṅkhepatopi vitthāratopi kathetuṃ vaṭṭati.🔽Tattha saṅkhepato tāva – cakkhu sotaṃ ghānaṃ jivhā kāyo, rūpaṃ saddo gandho rasoti
analyzed: kammaṭṭhānam āgatam tam saṅkhepataḥ api vitthārataḥ api kathetum vaṭṭati  tattha saṅkhepato tāva cakkhu sotam ghānam jivhā kāyaḥ rūpam saddaḥ gandho raso ti
translated: It is not allowable. But in this Thread of the Sectarians’ Views the meditation subject comes down to the eighteen kinds of exercise of applied-thought, and that is allowable to expound both in brief and in detail.🔽Herein, in brief, firstly, the nine kinds of derived materiality, namely, eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, visible data, sound, odour, and flavour,

original: imāni nava upādārūpāni, tesu diṭṭhesu sesaṃ upādārūpaṃ diṭṭhameva hoti. Phoṭṭhabbaṃ
analyzed: imāni nava upādārūpāni tesu diṭṭhesu sesam upādārūpam diṭṭham eva hoti phoṭṭhabbam
translated: are seen when the materiality of the eye, etc., is seen. The remaining derived materiality is seen too. Tangible data

original: tīṇi mahābhūtāni, tehi diṭṭhehi catutthaṃ diṭṭhameva hoti. Mano viññāṇakkhandho,🔽tena sahajātā vedanādayo tayo arūpakkhandhāti heṭṭhā vuttanayeneva saṅkhepato ca
analyzed: tīṇi mahābhūtāni tehi diṭṭhehi catuttham diṭṭham eva hoti manaḥ viññāṇa kkhandho  tena sahajātāḥ vedanā ādayo tayo arūpa kkhandhā ti heṭṭhā vutta nayena iva saṅkhepato ca
translated: are the three elements. When these are seen, the fourth, the earth element, is seen too. The mind is the consciousness aggregate.

original: vitthārato ca arahattasampāpakaṃ kammaṭṭhānaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: vitthārato ca arahatta sampāpakam kammaṭṭhānam veditabbam
translated: The three immaterial aggregates, namely, feeling, perception, and formations, are conascent with that. So the meditation subject that effects the realization of Arahantship should be understood in brief and in detail in the way already stated.

original: Ariyasaccānīti ariyabhāvakarāni, ariyapaṭividdhāni vā saccāni. Ayamettha saṅkhepo,
analyzed: ariya saccāni iti ariya bhāva karāni ariya paṭividdhāni vā saccāni ayam ettha saṅkhepaḥ
translated: The Noble Truths are either truths penetrated by Noble Ones or truths that cause the state of Noble One to arise. This is the brief

original: vitthārato panetaṃ padaṃ visuddhimagge pakāsitaṃ. Channaṃ, bhikkhave, dhātūnanti🔽idaṃ kimatthaṃ āraddhaṃ? Sukhāvabodhanatthaṃ. Yassa hi tathāgato dvādasapadaṃ paccayāvaṭṭaṃ🔽kathetukāmo hoti, tassa gabbhāvakkanti vaṭṭaṃ dasseti. Gabbhāvakkanti vaṭṭasmiṃ hi
analyzed: vitthārato pana itam padam visuddhi magge pakāsitam channam bhikkhave dhātūnam ti  idam kimattham āraddham sukha avabodhana attham yassa hi tathāgataḥ dvādasa padam paccaya avaṭṭam  kathetu kāmo hoti tassa gabbha avakkanti vaṭṭam dasseti gabbha avakkanti vaṭṭasmim hi
translated: But this term is explained in detail in the Visuddhimagga. “Bhikkhus, with the six elements as condition, there is the sphere of contact” .🔽Why was this stated? For the sake of easy understanding. For when the Tathāgata wishes to teach the twelve-fold dependent origination, he shows the round of existence with the descent into the womb as its starting point.

original: dassite kathetumpi sukhaṃ hoti paraṃ avabodhe utumpīti sukhāvabodhanatthaṃ idamāraddhanti🔽veditabbaṃ. Tattha channaṃ dhātūnanti heṭṭhā vuttānaṃyeva pathavīdhātuādīnaṃ. Upādāyāti
analyzed: dassite sukham hoti param avabodhe sukha avabodhana attham idam āraddham ti  veditabbam tattha channam dhātūnam ti heṭṭhā vuttānam yeva pathavī dhātu ādīnam upādāya ati
translated: For when the descent into the womb is shown, it is easy to understand and to enter upon the teaching. Thus this was stated for the sake of easy understanding.

original: paṭicca. Etena paccayamattaṃ dasseti. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti “chadhātupaccayā gabbhassāvakkanti
analyzed: paṭicca etena paccaya mattam dasseti idam vuttam hoti cha dhātu paccayāḥ
translated: Herein, “the six elements” are the earth element, etc., mentioned above. “With the six elements as condition” means “with the six elements as its support.” This shows only the condition. What is meant is: “With the six elements as condition, there is descent into the womb.”

original: hotī”ti. Kassa channaṃ dhātūnaṃ paccayena, kiṃ mātu, udāhu pitūti? Na mātu na pitu,
analyzed: hoti iti kassa channam dhātūnam paccayena kim mātu udāhu pitu uti na mātu na pitu
translated: Whose six elements? What, the mother’s or the father’s? Not the mother’s or the father’s,

original: paṭisandhiggaṇhanakasattasseva pana channaṃ dhātūnaṃ paccayena gabbhassāvakkanti
analyzed: paṭisandhi ggaṇhanaka sattassa iva pana channam dhātūnam paccayena
translated: but with the six elements of the being who takes rebirth-linking, there is descent into the womb.

original: nāma hoti. Gabbho ca nāmesa nirayagabbho tiracchānayonigabbho pettivisayagabbho manussagabbho
analyzed: nāma hoti gabbhaḥ ca nāma isa niraya gabbho tiracchāna yoni gabbho pettivisaya gabbho manussa gabbho
translated: and the womb is of various kinds: a womb of hell, a womb of animals, a womb of ghosts, a womb of human beings,

original: devagabbhoti nānappakāro hoti. Imasmiṃ pana ṭhāne manussagabbho adhippeto. Avakkanti
analyzed: devagabbhaḥ ti nānappakāraḥ hoti imasmin pana ṭhāne manussa gabbhaḥ adhippeto
translated: a womb of gods. But here the human womb is intended. The descent

original: hotīti okkanti nibbatti pātubhāvo hoti, kathaṃ hotīti? Tiṇṇaṃ sannipātena. Vuttañhetaṃ –
analyzed: hoti iti okkanti nibbatti pātubhāvaḥ hoti katham hoti iti tiṇṇam sannipātena vuttam ha etam
translated: means the descent, the rebirth, the manifestation. How is it? By the coming together of three things. For this is said:

original: “Tiṇṇaṃ kho pana, bhikkhave, sannipātā gabbhassāvakkanti hoti. Katamesaṃ tiṇṇaṃ?🔽Idha mātāpitaro ca sannipatitā honti, mātā ca na utunī hoti, gandhabbo ca na paccupaṭṭhito
analyzed: tiṇṇam kho pana bhikkhave sannipātā gabbhassa avakkanti hoti katamesam tiṇṇam  idha mātā pitaro ca sannipatitāḥ honti mātā ca na utunī hoti gandhabbaḥ ca na paccupaṭṭhito
translated: “Bhikkhus, there is the descent of the embryo by the coming together of three things. What three?

original: hoti. Neva tāva gabbhassāvakkanti hoti. Idha mātāpitaro ca sannipatitā honti, mātā
analyzed: hoti na iva tāva gabbhassa avakkanti hoti idha mātā pitaro ca sannipatitāḥ honti mātā
translated: Here the parents have come together, but the mother is not in season, and the gandhabba is not present. There is no descent of the embryo. Here the parents have come together and the mother is in season,

original: ca utunī hoti, gandhabbo ca na paccupaṭṭhito hoti, neva tāva gabbhassāvakkanti hoti.
analyzed: ca utunī hoti gandhabbaḥ ca na paccupaṭṭhitaḥ hoti na iva tāva gabbhassa avakkanti hoti
translated: but the gandhabba is not present. There is no descent of the embryo.

original: Yato ca kho, bhikkhave, mātāpitaro ca sannipatitā honti, mātā ca utunī hoti, gandhabbo
analyzed: yatas ca kho bhikkhave mātā pitaro ca sannipatitāḥ honti mātā ca utunī hoti gandhabbaḥ
translated: But when the parents have come together and the mother is in season, and the gandhabba is present,

original: ca paccupaṭṭhito hoti. Evaṃ tiṇṇaṃ sannipātā gabbhassāvakkanti hotī”ti.🔽Okkantiyā sati nāmarūpanti “viññāṇapaccayā nāmarūpa”nti vuttaṭṭhāne vatthudasakaṃ
analyzed: ca paccupaṭṭhito hoti evam tiṇṇam sannipātā gabbhassa avakkanti hoti iti  okkantiyā sati nāma rūpanti viññāṇa paccayā nāma rūpanti vutta ṭṭhāne vatthu dasakam
translated: and the mother is in season, then the entry of the consciousness is effected by the concurrence of these three. ”

original: kāyadasakaṃ bhāvadasakaṃ tayo arūpino khandhāti tettiṃsa dhammā gahitā, imasmiṃ pana🔽“okkantiyā sati nāmarūpa”nti vuttaṭṭhāne viññāṇakkhandhampi pakkhipitvā gabbhaseyyakānaṃ
analyzed: kāya dasakam bhāva dasakam tayo arūpino khandhā ati tettiṃsa dhammāḥ gahitāḥ imasmin pana  okkantiyā sati nāma rūpam ti vutta ṭṭhāne viññāṇa kkhandham pi pakkhipitvā gabbhaseyyakānam
translated: When there is entry, there is manifestation of mentality-materiality: in the place where it is said, “With consciousness as condition, mentality-materiality” , thirty-three states are included, namely, the ten physical bases, the ten kinds of materiality of the physical bases, and the three immaterial aggregates.🔽But in the place where it is said, “When there is entry, there is manifestation of mentality-materiality” , the consciousness aggregate should be included as well, and then forty-four states should be understood as included in the case of those who are born in the womb.

original: paṭisandhikkhaṇe catuttiṃsa dhammā gahitāti veditabbā. Nāmarūpapaccayā saḷāyatanantiādīhi
analyzed: paṭisandhi kkhaṇe catuttiṃsa dhammā gahitā ati veditabbā nāma rūpa paccayā saḷāyatana nti ādīhi
translated: With mentality-materiality as condition, the sixfold base, and so on:

original: yatheva okkantiyā sati nāmarūpapātubhāvo dassito, evaṃ nāmarūpe sati saḷāyatanapātubhāvo,🔽saḷāyatane sati phassapātubhāvo, phasse sati vedanāpātubhāvo dassito.
analyzed: yathā iva okkantiyā sati nāma rūpa pātubhāvaḥ dassito evam nāma rūpe sati saḷāyatana pātubhāvaḥ  saḷāyatane sati phassa pātubhāvo phasse sati vedanā pātubhāvaḥ dassito
translated: just as the manifestation of mentality-materiality is shown with the words “When there is entry” , so the manifestation of the sixfold base is shown with the words “With mentality-materiality as condition” ,🔽the manifestation of contact with the words “With the sixfold base as condition,” and the manifestation of feeling with the words “With contact as condition.”

original: Vediyamānassāti ettha vedanaṃ anubhavantopi vediyamānoti vuccati jānantopi. “Vediyāmahaṃ,
analyzed: vediyamānassa ati ettha vedanam anubhavantaḥ api vediyamānaḥ ti vuccati jānantaḥ api
translated: “Feeling”: one who feels and also one who knows are called “one who feels” .

original: bhante, vediyatīti maṃ saṅgho dhāretū”ti ettha hi anubhavanto vediyamāno nāma, “sukhaṃ🔽vedanaṃ vediyamāno sukhaṃ vedanaṃ vediyāmīti pajānātī”ti ettha jānanto. Idhāpi jānantova🔽adhippeto. Idaṃ dukkhanti paññapemīti evaṃ jānantassa sattassa “idaṃ dukkhaṃ ettakaṃ
analyzed: bhante vediyatī iti mam saṅghaḥ dhāretu uti ettha hi anubhavantaḥ nāma sukham  vedanam vediyamānaḥ sukham vedanam vediyāmi iti pajānāti iti ettha jānantaḥ idha api jānantaḥ uva  adhippetaḥ idam dukkhanti paññapemi iti evam jānantassa sattassa idam dukkham ettakam
translated: “Venerable sir, let the Order remember me as one who has confessed.” Herein, one who is experiencing is called “one who is sensing.” “He understands: ‘I am sensing a pleasant feeling.’ ” Herein, one who knows is intended. Here too it is one who knows that is intended. “I am describing this as pain” : in one who knows thus, there is this thought: “This is pain, this much

original: dukkhaṃ, natthi ito uddhaṃ dukkha”nti paññapemi bodhemi jānāpemi. Ayaṃ dukkhasamudayotiādīsupi eseva nayo.🔽Tattha dukkhādīsu ayaṃ sanniṭṭhānakathā – ṭhapetvā hi taṇhaṃ tebhūmakā pañcakkhandhā
analyzed: dukkham natthi itas uddham dukkhanti paññapemi bodhemi jānāpemi ayam dukkha samudayaḥ ti ādīsu pi esa eva nayo  tattha dukkha ādīsu ayam sanniṭṭhāna kathā ṭhapetvā hi taṇham tebhūmakā pañca kkhandhā
translated: “Venerable sir, let the Order remember me as one who has declared his purity.” Herein, one who is experiencing is called “one who is purifying.” “When he is experiencing a pleasant feeling he understands: ‘I am experiencing a pleasant feeling’; when he is experiencing a painful feeling he understands: ‘I am experiencing a painful feeling’; when he is experiencing a neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling he understands: ‘I am experiencing a neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling’” . Here too it is one who understands that is intended. “I make it plain that this is suffering” : I make it plain, I teach, I reveal to the being who understands in this way that “This is suffering, this much is suffering, there is no suffering beyond this.” “I make it plain that this is the origin of suffering” , and so on. The method is the same in each case.

original: dukkhaṃ nāma, tasseva pabhāvikā pubbataṇhā dukkhasamudayo nāma, tesaṃ dvinnampi saccānaṃ
analyzed: dukkham nāma tassa iva pabhāvikā pubba taṇhā dukkha samudayaḥ nāma tesam dvinnam pi saccānam
translated: Herein, this is the explanation of the meaning of the words in the case of each of the four truths. For the five aggregates as objects of clinging in the three planes, except craving, are called “suffering” . The former craving is called “the origin of suffering” . The two truths, namely, cessation and path, are called “the cessation of suffering” .

original: anuppattinirodho dukkhanirodho nāma, ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā
analyzed: anuppatti nirodho dukkha nirodho nāma ariyaḥ aṭṭhaṅgikaḥ maggo dukkha nirodha gāminī paṭipadā
translated: The noble eightfold path is called “the way leading to the cessation of suffering” .

original: nāma. Iti bhagavā okkantiyā sati nāmarūpanti kathentopi vediyamānassa jānamānasseva
analyzed: nāma iti bhagavā okkantiyā sati nāma rūpam ti kathentaḥ api vediyamānassa jānamānassa iva
translated: “When there is descent into the womb, there is name-and-form” , the Exalted One spoke of name-and-form only in reference to one who is conscious of being reborn.

original: kathesi, nāmarūpapaccayā saḷāyatananti kathentopi, saḷāyatanapaccayā phassoti kathentopi,
analyzed: kathesi nāma rūpa paccayā saḷāyatananti kathentaḥ api saḷāyatana paccayā phasso ti kathentaḥ api
translated: “With name-and-form as condition, the six sense bases” , “With the six sense bases as condition, contact” ,

original: phassapaccayā vedanāti kathentopi, vediyamānassa kho panāhaṃ, bhikkhave, idaṃ dukkhanti🔽paññapemīti kathentopi, ayaṃ dukkhasamudayoti, ayaṃ dukkhanirodhoti, ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī
analyzed: phassa paccayā vedanā ti kathento api vediyamānassa kho pana aham bhikkhave idam dukkhanti  paññapemi iti kathento pi ayam dukkha samudayo ti ayam dukkha nirodho ti ayam dukkha nirodha gāminī
translated: “With contact as condition, feeling” , and “When there is feeling, bhikkhus, then I declare that there is the possibility of the occurrence of craving” ,

original: paṭipadāti paññapemīti kathentopi vediyamānassa jānamānasseva kathesi.
analyzed: paṭipadā ati paññapemi iti kathentaḥ api vediyamānassa jānamānassa iva kathesi
translated: “I declare that there is the possibility of the occurrence of the origination of suffering, the possibility of the occurrence of the cessation of suffering, and the possibility of the occurrence of the way leading to the cessation of suffering” , the Exalted One spoke of these things only in reference to one who is conscious of being reborn.

original: Idāni tāni paṭipāṭiyā ṭhapitāni saccāni vitthārento katamañca, bhikkhavetiādimāha.
analyzed: idāni tāni paṭipāṭiyā ṭhapitāni saccāni vitthārentaḥ katamat ca bhikkhave ti ādim āha
translated: Now, in order to explain the truths which he has set forth in sequence, the Exalted One says, “And what, bhikkhus, is the noble truth of suffering? Birth is suffering, aging is suffering, death is suffering, sorrow, lamentation, pain, grief, and despair are suffering;🔽not to obtain what one wants is suffering; in brief, the five aggregates subject to clinging are suffering” .

original: Taṃ sabbaṃ sabbākārena visuddhimagge vitthāritameva. Tattha vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: tat sabbam sabba ākārena visuddhi magge vitthāritam eva tattha vutta nayena iva veditabbam
translated: All this has been explained in detail in the Visuddhimagga. It should be understood in the way given there.

original: Ayaṃ pana viseso – tattha “dukkhasamudayaṃ ariyasaccaṃ yāyaṃ taṇhā ponobbhavikā”ti
analyzed: ayam pana visesaḥ tattha dukkha samudayam ariya saccam yā ayam taṇhā ponobbhavikā ti
translated: But there is this difference. There, the passage reads: “The noble truth of the origin of suffering is the craving which leads to continuation in existence, which is accompanied by delight and lust, and delights in this and that” .

original: imāya tantiyā āgataṃ, idha “avijjāpaccayā saṅkhārā”ti paccayākāravasena. Tattha ca
analyzed: imāya tantiyā āgatam idha avijjā paccayā saṅkhārā ti paccaya ākāra vasena tattha ca
translated: and it is given in this Thread here in the way of conditions thus ‘With ignorance as condition there are formations’ .🔽Herein,

analyzed: dukkha nirodham ariya saccam yaḥ tassāya iva taṇhāya asesa virāga nirodhaḥ ti imāya tantiyā  āgatam idha avid jāyatu eva asesa virāga nirodhā ti paccaya ākāra nirodha vasena
translated: This is the Thread’s meaning. Herein, the noble truth of the cessation of suffering is stated in the Thread thus ‘ With the remainderless fading away and cessation of that same craving ’ . This is stated here in the Thread by way of the cessation of conditionality, namely, ‘ With the remainderless fading away and cessation of ignorance ’ .

original: Tattha asesavirāganirodhāti asesavirāgena ca asesanirodhena ca. Ubhayampetaṃ aññamaññavevacanameva.
analyzed: tattha asesa virāga nirodhā ati asesa virāgena ca asesa nirodhena ca ubhayam petam aññamañña vevacanam eva
translated: Herein, with the remainderless fading away and cessation is with the remainderless fading away and with the remainderless cessation. Both are merely synonyms.

original: Saṅkhāranirodhoti saṅkhārānaṃ anuppattinirodho hoti. Sesapadesupi eseva nayo. Imehi
analyzed: saṅkhāra nirodhaḥ ti saṅkhārānaṃ anuppatti nirodhaḥ hoti sesa padesu pi esa iva nayaḥ imehi
translated: With the cessation of determinations is the non-arising cessation of determinations. The same method of explanation applies in the rest of the passage.

original: pana padehi yaṃ āgamma avijjādayo nirujjhanti, atthato taṃ nibbānaṃ dīpitaṃ hoti.
analyzed: pana padehi yam āgamma avijjā ādayaḥ nirujjhanti atthataḥ tam nibbānam dīpitam hoti
translated: But by means of these terms the extinction called “ cessation “ of the states beginning with ignorance is demonstrated in the sense of their non-arising.

original: Nibbānañhi avijjānirodhotipi saṅkhāranirodhotipi evaṃ tesaṃ tesaṃ dhammānaṃ nirodhanāmena
analyzed: nibbānam hi avijjā nirodhaḥ tipi saṅkhāra nirodhaḥ tipi evam tesam tesam dhammānam nirodha nāmena
translated: For extinction is called “ cessation of ignorance “ and “ cessation of determinations “ and so on, in the sense of the cessation of these states.

original: kathīyati. Kevalassāti sakalassa. Dukkhakkhandhassāti vaṭṭadukkharāsissa. Nirodho
analyzed: kathīyati kevalassa ati sakalassa dukkha kkhandhassa ati vaṭṭa dukkha rāsissa nirodho
translated: Entirely is wholly. Mass of suffering is the suffering of the round. Cessation is

analyzed: hoti iti appavatti hoti tattha yasmai avijjā ādīnam nirodho nāma khīṇa ākāraḥ api vuccati  arahattam pi nibbānam pi tasmai idha khīṇa ākāra dassana vasena dvādasasu ṭhānesu arahattam
translated: Herein, since the cessation of ignorance, etc., is called “the destruction of the process,”🔽and also “Arahantship” and “Nibbana,” therefore it should be understood that in these twelve instances Arahantship is stated and in the same twelve instances Nibbana is stated.

original: dvādasasuyeva nibbānaṃ kathitanti veditabbaṃ. Idaṃ vuccatīti ettha nibbānameva sandhāya
analyzed: dvādasasuyā iva nibbānam kathitanti veditabbam idam vuccati iti ettha nibbānam eva sandhāya
translated: “This is called” : here only Nibbana is intended by the word “this.”

original: idanti vuttaṃ. Aṭṭhaṅgikoti na aṭṭhahi aṅgehi vinimutto añño maggo nāma atthi. Yathā
analyzed: idam ti vuttam aṭṭhaṅgikaḥ ti na aṭṭhahi aṅgehi vinimuttaḥ aññaḥ maggaḥ nāma atthi yathā
translated: “The Noble Eightfold Path” : there is no other path devoid of these eight factors.

original: pana pañcaṅgikaṃ tūriyanti vutte pañcaṅgamattameva tūriyanti vuttaṃ hoti, evamidhāpi
analyzed: pana pañcaṅgikam tūriyanti vutte pañcaṅga mattam eva tūriyanti vuttam hoti evam idha api
translated: But just as when it is said “a five-part musical instrument,” it is understood that only the five parts are the musical instrument, so here too

original: aṭṭhaṅgikamattameva maggo hotīti veditabbo. Aniggahitoti na niggahito. Niggaṇhanto
analyzed: aṭṭhaṅgika mattam eva maggaḥ hoti iti veditabbaḥ a niggahitaḥ ti na niggahitaḥ niggaṇhantaḥ
translated: it should be understood that only the eight factors are the path.🔽“Unhampered” : not hampered. For one who hampers would show it by subtracting or adding or by changing it.

original: hi hāpetvā vā dasseti vaḍḍhetvā vā taṃ parivattetvā vā. Tattha yasmā cattāri ariyasaccāni
analyzed: hi hāpetvā vā dasseti vaḍḍhetvā vā tam parivattetvā vā tattha yasmā cattāri ariya saccāni
translated: Herein, since the four Noble Truths🔽are not four or two or three, he shows it by subtracting thus:

original: “na imāni cattāri, dve vā tīṇi vā”ti evaṃ hāpetvāpi “pañca vā cha vā”ti evaṃ vaḍḍhetvāpi
analyzed: na imāni cattāri dve vā tīṇi vā ati evam hāpetvā api pañca vā cha vā ati evam vaḍḍhetvā api
translated: “They are four only”; and he shows it by adding thus: “They are five or six”;

analyzed: na imāni cattāri ariya saccāni aññānā iva cattāri ariya saccāni iti dassetum na sakkā
translated: “It is not possible to show that these four noble truths are not the four noble truths.”

original: Tasmā ayaṃ dhammo aniggahito nāma. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānamevāti.
analyzed: tasmai ayam dhammaḥ a niggahitaḥ nāma sesam sabbattha uttānam eva ati
translated: Therefore this Dhamma is called “unobstructed.” The rest is clear in all instances.

original: 2. Bhayasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: bhaya sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Explanation of the Second Miracle

original: 63. Dutiye amātāputtikānīti mātā ca putto ca mātāputtaṃ, parittātuṃ samatthabhāvena🔽natthi ettha mātāputtanti amātāputtikāni. Yanti yasmiṃ samaye. Tattha mātāpi puttaṃ🔽nappaṭilabhatīti tasmiṃ aggibhaye uppanne mātāpi puttaṃ passituṃ na labhati, puttopi
analyzed: dutiye a mātāputtikāni iti mātā ca putto ca mātāputtam samattha bhāvena  na atthi ettha mātā puttanti a mātā puttikāni yanti yasmin samaye tattha mātā api puttam  na paṭilabhati iti tasmin aggi bhaye uppanne mātā api puttam passitum na labhati puttaḥ api
translated: In the second miracle, there are no mothers and children: a mother and a child are a mother and child.🔽Because they are not able to protect each other, there are no mothers and children.

original: mātaraṃ passituṃ na labhatīti attho. Bhayaṃ hotīti cittutrāsabhayaṃ hoti. Aṭavisaṅkopoti🔽aṭaviyā saṅkopo. Aṭavīti cettha aṭavivāsino corā veditabbā. Yadā hi te aṭavito janapadaṃ
analyzed: mātaram passitum na labhati iti attho bhayam hoti iti cittu trāsa bhayam hoti aṭavi saṅkopaḥ ti  aṭaviyā saṅkopaḥ aṭavī iti ca ittha aṭavi vāsinaḥ corāḥ veditabbāḥ yadā hi te aṭavitaḥ janapadam
translated: In that case, a mother does not find her child: when that danger from fire arises, a mother does not find her child, does not get to see her child. The meaning is that a child does not get to see its mother. There is danger: there is danger of fear in the mind.🔽There is a panic in the forest:🔽Herein, the forest should be understood as the bandits who live in the forest. For when they come down from the forest into the countryside,

original: otaritvā gāmanigamarājadhāniyo paharitvā vilumpanti, tadā aṭavisaṅkopo nāma hoti,
analyzed: otaritvā gāma nigama rājadhāniyā upaharitvā vilumpanti tadā aṭavisaṅkopaḥ nāma hoti
translated: attacking villages, towns, and royal cities and plundering them, then there is a panic in the forest.

original: taṃ sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ. Cakkasamārūḷhāti ettha iriyāpathacakkampi vaṭṭati yānacakkampi.
analyzed: tam sandhāya itam vuttam cakka samārūḍhā ti ettha iriyāpatha cakkam pi vaṭṭati yāna cakkam pi
translated: This is what is meant. ‘ Mounted on a vehicle ’: here, the vehicle of deportment is also allowable, as well as a conveyance.

original: Bhayasmiṃ hi sampatte yesaṃ yānakāni atthi, te attano parikkhārabhaṇḍaṃ tesu āropetvā
analyzed: bhayasmim hi sampatte yesam yānakāni atthi te attanaḥ parikkhāra bhaṇḍam tesu āropetvā
translated: For when danger arises, those who have conveyances load their belongings on them

original: palāyanti. Yesaṃ natthi, te kājena vā ādāya sīsena vā ukkhipitvā palāyantiyeva. Te🔽cakkasamārūḷhā nāma honti. Pariyāyantīti ito cito ca gacchanti. Kadācīti kismiñcideva
analyzed: palāyanti yesam na atthi te kājena vā ādāya sīsena vā ukkhipitvā palāyantiyā iva te  cakka samārūḍhāḥ nāma honti pariyāyanti iti itas citas ca gacchanti kadācid iti kismiñcid eva
translated: and flee. Those who have none carry them on their heads or shoulders and flee.

original: kāle. Karahacīti tasseva vevacanaṃ. Mātāpi puttaṃ paṭilabhatīti āgacchantaṃ vā gacchantaṃ🔽vā ekasmiṃ ṭhāne nilīnaṃ vā passituṃ labhati. Udakavāhakoti nadīpūro. Mātāpi puttaṃ
analyzed: kāle karahacī iti tassa iva vevacanam mātā api puttam paṭilabhati iti āgacchantam vā gacchantam  vā ekasmim ṭhāne nilīnam vā passitum labhati udaka vāhakaḥ ti nadī pūraḥ mātā api puttam
translated: They are called ‘ mounted on a vehicle ’. ‘ They go here and there ’: they go from here to there. ‘ At some time ’: at some occasion. ‘ A water-carrying basket ’: this is a synonym for the same thing. ‘ A mother finds her son ’: she finds him coming, or going,

original: paṭilabhatīti kulle vā uḷumpe vā mattikābhājane vā dārukkhaṇḍe vā laggaṃ vuyhamānaṃ
analyzed: paṭilabhati iti kulle vā uḷumpe vā mattikā bhājane vā dāru khaṇḍe vā laggam vuyhamānam
