original: paṭicca hitvāpi anuttaraṃ vivekasukhaṃ dhammaṃ deseti. Tañca kho appaṃ vā bahuṃ vā🔽desento ādikalyāṇādippakārameva deseti, ādimhipi kalyāṇaṃ bhaddakaṃ anavajjameva
analyzed: paṭicca hitvā api anuttaram viveka sukham dhammam deseti tat ca kho appam vā bahum vā  desentaḥ ādi kalyāṇa ādi ppakāram eva deseti ādimhi pi kalyāṇam bhaddakam anavajjam eva
translated: and he teaches the Dhamma that is the unsurpassed deliverance of the mind, whether he teaches much or little.

original: katvā deseti, majjhepi, pariyosānepi kalyāṇaṃ bhaddakaṃ anavajjameva katvā desetīti vuttaṃ hoti.🔽Tattha atthi desanāya ādimajjhapariyosānaṃ, atthi sāsanassa. Desanāya tāva catuppadikāyapi
analyzed: katvā deseti majjhe pi pariyosāne pi kalyāṇam bhaddakam anavajjam eva katvā deseti iti vuttam hoti  tattha atthi desanāya ādi majjha pariyosānaṃ atthi sāsanassa desanāya tāva
translated: And when he teaches, he teaches what is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, with the right meaning and phrasing, and he reveals a holy life that is utterly perfect and pure.🔽Herein, there is a beginning, middle, and end of a teaching, and there is a beginning, middle, and end of the Dispensation.

original: gāthāya paṭhamapādo ādi nāma, tato dve majjhaṃ nāma, ante eko pariyosānaṃ nāma. Ekānusandhikassa
analyzed: gāthāya paṭhama pādaḥ ādi nāma tatas dve majjham nāma ante ekaḥ pariyosānam nāma eka anusandhikassa
translated: As regards a teaching, firstly, in a stanza of four lines, the first line is called the beginning, the next two lines are the middle, and the last line is the end.

original: suttassa nidānaṃ ādi, idamavocāti pariyosānaṃ, ubhinnaṃ antarā majjhaṃ. Anekānusandhikassa
analyzed: suttassa nidānam ādi idam avoca ati pariyosānam ubhinnam antarā majjham aneka anusandhikassa
translated: In a sutta with a single sequence, the introduction is the beginning, the words “Thus spoke the Exalted One” are the end, and what is in between is the middle.

original: suttassa paṭhamānusandhi ādi, ante anusandhi pariyosānaṃ, majjhe eko vā dve vā bahū vā majjhameva.
analyzed: suttassa paṭhama anusandhi ādi ante anusandhi pariyosānam majjhe ekaḥ vā dve vā bahū vā majjham eva
translated: In a sutta with several sequences, the first sequence is the beginning, the last sequence is the end, and what is in between, whether one, two, or many, is the middle.

original: Sāsanassa sīlasamādhivipassanā ādi nāma. Vuttampi cetaṃ – “ko cādi kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ,🔽sīlañca suvisuddhaṃ diṭṭhi ca ujukā”ti. “Atthi, bhikkhave, majjhimā paṭipadā tathāgatena
analyzed: sāsanassa sīla samādhi vipassanā ādi nāma vuttam pi ca itaṃ kaḥ ca ādi kusalānam dhammānam  sīlam ca su visuddham diṭṭhi ca ujukā ati atthi bhikkhave majjhimā paṭipadā tathāgatena
translated: The training in virtue, concentration, and understanding is the beginning of the Dispensation. And this is said: “What is the beginning of profitable things?

original: abhisambuddhā”ti evaṃ vutto pana ariyamaggo majjhaṃ nāma. Phalañceva nibbānañca pariyosānaṃ🔽nāma. “Tasmātiha tvaṃ, brāhmaṇa, brahmacariyaṃ etaṃpāraṃ etaṃpariyosāna”nti ettha🔽phalaṃ pariyosananti vuttaṃ. “Nibbānogadhañhi, āvuso visākha, brahmacariyaṃ vussati🔽nibbānaparāyaṇaṃ nibbānapariyosāna”nti ettha nibbānaṃ pariyosānanti vuttaṃ. Idha🔽pana desanāya ādimajjhapariyosānaṃ adhippetaṃ. Bhagavā hi dhammaṃ desento ādimhi
analyzed: abhisambuddhā iti evam vuttaḥ pana ariya maggo majjham nāma phalam ca iva nibbānam ca pariyosānam  nāma tasmāt ati ha tvam brāhmaṇa brahmacariyam etaṃpāram etaṃpariyosānam ti ettha  phalam pariyosananti vuttam nibbāna ugadham hi āvuso visākha brahmacariyam vussati  nibbāna parāyaṇam nibbāna pariyosānanti ettha nibbānam pariyosānanti vuttam idha  pana desanāya ādi majjha pariyosānam adhippetam bhagavā hi dhammam desentaḥ ādimhi
translated: Virtue purified and right view” . And the noble path is called the middle, as in the passage: “Bhikkhus, there is a middle way of practice, awakened to by the Tathagata, which produces vision, knowledge, peace, direct knowledge, enlightenment, and nibbana” . The fruition attainment and nibbana are called the end,

original: sīlaṃ dassetvā majjhe maggaṃ pariyosāne nibbānaṃ dasseti. Tena vuttaṃ – “so dhammaṃ
analyzed: sīlam dassetvā majjhe maggam pariyosāne nibbānam dasseti tena vuttam so dhammaṃ
translated: as in the passage: “Therefore, brahmin, this spiritual life is lived with that as its ground, that as its destination, that as its final goal” , where the fruition attainment is called the end. And in the passage: “Friend Visakha, the spiritual life is lived with nibbana as its ground, with nibbana as its destination, with nibbana as its final goal” , nibbana is called the end. Here, however, the beginning, middle, and end of the teaching are intended. For when the Blessed One teaches the Dhamma, he teaches virtue at the beginning, the path in the middle, and nibbana at the end. Hence it was said above: “He shows virtue at the beginning, the path in the middle, and nibbana at the end” .

original: deseti ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇa”nti. Tasmā aññopi dhammakathiko dhammaṃ kathento –
analyzed: deseti ādi kalyāṇam majjhe kalyāṇam pariyosāna kalyāṇam ti tasmai aññaḥ api dhamma kathikaḥ dhammam kathentaḥ
translated: Therefore, when any other preacher of the Dhamma preaches the Dhamma,🔽he should show virtue at the beginning,

original: “Ādimhi sīlaṃ dasseyya, majjhe maggaṃ vibhāvaye;
analyzed: ādimhi sīlam dasseyya majjhe maggam vibhāvaye
translated: make the path clear in the middle,

original: Pariyosānamhi nibbānaṃ, esā kathikasaṇṭhitī”ti.
analyzed: pariyosānamhi nibbānam esā kathika saṇṭhitī iti
translated: and show Nibbāna at the end. This is the method of preaching.

original: Sātthaṃ sabyañjananti yassa hi yāgubhattaitthipurisādivaṇṇanānissitā desanā hoti,
analyzed: sa attham sa byañjananti yassa hi yāgu bhatta aitthi purisa ādi vaṇṇanā nissitā desanā hoti
translated: Meaningful and well phrased: if a man’s preaching is concerned with such things as rice gruel, rice, women, men, etc.,

original: na so sātthaṃ deseti. Bhagavā pana tathārūpaṃ desanaṃ pahāya catusatipaṭṭhānādinissitaṃ
analyzed: na saḥ sa attham deseti bhagavā pana tathārūpam desanam pahāya catusati paṭṭhāna ādi nissitam
translated: then he does not preach the Dhamma that is meaningful. But the Exalted One, having abandoned such preaching,

original: desanaṃ deseti. Tasmā “sātthaṃ desetī”ti vuccati. Yassa pana desanā ekabyañjanādiyuttā
analyzed: desanam deseti tasmā sa attham deseti iti vuccati yassa pana desanā eka byañjana ādi yuttā
translated: preaches the Dhamma that is meaningful, concerned with the four foundations of mindfulness, etc. Therefore it is said that he preaches the Dhamma that is meaningful.🔽If a man’s preaching is connected with a single syllable,

original: vā sabbaniroṭṭhabyañjanā vā sabbavissaṭṭhabyañjanā vā sabbaniggahitabyañjanā vā,🔽tassa damiḷakirātayavanādimilakkhānaṃ bhāsā viya byañjanapāripūriyā abhāvato abyañjanā
analyzed: vā sabba niroṭṭha byañjanā vā sabba vissaṭṭha byañjanā vā sabba niggahita byañjanā vā  tassa bhāsā viya byañjana pāripūriyāḥ abhāvataḥ abyañjanā
translated: or if it is devoid of all the vowels, or if it is devoid of all consonants, or if it is devoid of all the words,

original: nāma desanā hoti. Bhagavā pana –
analyzed: nāma desanā hoti bhagavā pana
translated: then his preaching is called devoid of phrasing, like the speech of the Damilas, the Kiratas, the Yavanas, etc. Because it lacks the perfection of phrasing. But the Exalted One’s preaching🔽is not devoid of phrasing.

original: “Sithilaṃ dhanitañca dīgharassaṃ, lahukaṃ garukañca niggahītaṃ;
analyzed: sithilam dhanitam ca dīgharassam lahukam garukam ca niggahītam
translated: “Loose and tight, long and short, light and heavy, and held in check,

original: Sambandhaṃ vavatthitaṃ vimuttaṃ, dasadhā byañjanabuddhiyā pabhedo”ti. –
analyzed: sambandham vavatthitam vimuttam dasadhā
translated: Connected, defined, and released: the analysis of the letter-meaning is tenfold.”

original: Evaṃ vuttaṃ dasavidhaṃ byañjanaṃ amakkhetvā paripuṇṇabyañjanameva katvā dhammaṃ deseti.🔽Tasmā “sabyañjanaṃ katvā desetī”ti vuccati. Kevalaparipuṇṇanti ettha kevalanti sakalādhivacanaṃ.
analyzed: evam vuttam dasavidham byañjanam a makkhetvā paripuṇṇa byañjanam eva katvā dhammam deseti  sa byañjanam katvā deseti iti vuccati ettha sakala adhivacanam
translated: Having thus analyzed the tenfold letter-meaning, he teaches the Dhamma with the letter-meaning complete.🔽Therefore it is said that he teaches “with the letter-meaning complete.” As to “complete in its entirety”: here “complete” is a word for the whole,

original: Paripuṇṇanti anūnādhikavacanaṃ. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – sakalaparipuṇṇameva deseti, ekadesanāpi
analyzed: paripuṇṇam ti anūna adhika vacanam idam vuttam hoti sakala paripuṇṇam eva deseti eka desanā api
translated: “in its entirety” is a word for what is not deficient. This is what is meant: he teaches what is complete in its entirety,🔽there is no teaching of a mere part.

original: aparipuṇṇā natthīti. Parisuddhanti nirupakkilesaṃ. Yo hi “imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ nissāya
analyzed: a paripuṇṇā na atthi iti parisuddham nti nirupakkilesam yaḥ hi imam dhamma desanam nissāya
translated: “Pure” means free from defilements. For the teaching of one who teaches the Dhamma thinking “By this teaching of the Dhamma

original: lābhaṃ vā sakkāraṃ vā labhissāmī”ti deseti, tassa aparisuddhā desanā nāma hoti. Bhagavā
analyzed: lābham vā sakkāram vā labhissāmi iti deseti tassa aparisuddhā desanā nāma hoti bhagavā
translated: I will obtain gain and honor” is called impure. But the Exalted One,

original: pana lokāmisanirapekkho hitapharaṇeneva mettābhāvanāya muduhadayo ullumpanasabhāvasaṇṭhitena
analyzed: pana loka āmisa nirapekkhaḥ hita pharaṇena iva mettā bhāvanāya ullumpana sabhāva saṇṭhitena
translated: who is indifferent to worldly gain, who is tender-hearted through the cultivation of loving-kindness, who is endowed with the nature of uplifting,

original: cittena deseti. Tasmā parisuddhaṃ desetīti vuccati. Brahmacariyaṃ pakāsetīti ettha🔽brahmacariyanti sikkhattayasaṅgahitaṃ sakalaṃ sāsanaṃ. Tasmā brahmacariyaṃ pakāsetīti🔽so dhammaṃ deseti ādikalyāṇaṃ…pe… parisuddhaṃ, evaṃ desento ca sikkhattayasaṅgahitaṃ
analyzed: cittena deseti tasmā parisuddham deseti iti vuccati brahmacariyam pakāseti iti ettha  brahmacariyanti sikkhattaya saṅgahitam sakalam sāsanam tasmai brahmacariyam pakāseti iti  so dhammam deseti parisuddham evam desento ca sikkhattaya saṅgahitam
translated: He teaches with his mind. Therefore it is said that he teaches pure . He reveals the holy life :🔽herein,🔽the holy life is the entire dispensation consisting of the three trainings. Therefore it is said that he reveals the holy life consisting of the three trainings.

original: sakalasāsanabrahmacariyaṃ pakāsetīti evamettha attho daṭṭhabbo. Brahmacariyanti seṭṭhaṭṭhena
analyzed: sakala sāsana brahmacariyam pakāseti iti evam ettha atthaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ brahmacariyam ti seṭṭha ṭṭhena
translated: Thus, teaching in this way, he reveals the holy life consisting of the three trainings and the entire dispensation. This is the meaning here. The holy life is the practice of the holy ones ;

original: brahmabhūtaṃ cariyaṃ, brahmabhūtānaṃ vā buddhādīnaṃ cariyanti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: brahma bhūtam cariyam brahma bhūtānam vā buddha ādīnam cariyanti vuttam hoti
translated: or it is the practice of those who have become holy ones, the Buddhas, etc.

original: Sādhu kho panāti sundaraṃ kho pana, atthāvahaṃ sukhāvahanti vuttaṃ hoti. Tathārūpānaṃ🔽arahatanti yathārūpo so bhavaṃ gotamo, evarūpānaṃ anekehipi kappakoṭisatasahassehi
analyzed: sādhu kho pana ati sundaram kho pana attha āvaham sukha āvahanti vuttam hoti tathārūpānam  yathārūpaḥ saḥ bhavam gotamaḥ anekehi pi kappa koṭi sata sahassehi
translated: It is good : it is beautiful, it is profitable, it is blissful.🔽Such as he is : such as he is, the venerable Gotama,🔽such as he is, the Blessed One, who is difficult to see

original: dullabhadassanānaṃ byāmappabhāparikkhittehi asītianubyañjanapaṭimaṇḍitehi dvattiṃsamahāpurisalakkhaṇavarehi
analyzed: dullabha dassanānam byāma ppabhā parikkhittehi asīti anubyañjana paṭimaṇḍitehi dvattiṃsa mahāpurisa lakkhaṇa varehi
translated: even for many hundreds of thousands of koṭis of eons, who is surrounded by a halo of light extending a fathom, who is adorned with the thirty-two marks of a great man,

original: samākiṇṇamanoramasarīrānaṃ anappakadassanānaṃ atimadhuradhammanigghosānaṃ yathābhūtaguṇādhigamena
analyzed: samākiṇṇa manorama sarīrānam anappaka dassanānam ati madhura dhamma nigghosānam yathā bhūta guṇa adhigamena
translated: who have attained to the most excellent and delightful bodies, who are not to be seen by just anyone, whose voice is most sweet, who have attained to the most excellent qualities as they really are,

original: loke arahantoti laddhasaddānaṃ arahataṃ. Dassanaṃ hotīti pasādasommāni akkhīni ummīletvā
analyzed: loke arahantaḥ ti laddha saddānam arahatam dassanam hoti iti pasāda sommāni akkhīni ummīletvā
translated: who are called “Worthy Ones” in the world, it would be good if we could see them. If we could hear even one phrase

original: dassanamattampi sādhu hoti. Sace pana aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgatena brahmassarena dhammaṃ
analyzed: dassana mattam pi sādhu hoti sace pana aṭṭhaṅga samannāgatena brahmassarena dhammaṃ
translated: of the Dhamma being taught with the Brahma-like voice endowed with the eight factors,

original: desentassa ekapadampi sotuṃ labhissāma, sādhutaraṃyeva bhavissatīti evaṃ ajjhāsayaṃ
analyzed: desentassa eka padam pi sotum labhissāma sādhutaram yeva bhavissati iti evam ajjhāsayam
translated: that would be even better.” Having made this aspiration,

original: katvā. Yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsūti sabbakiccāni pahāya tuṭṭhamānasā agamaṃsu.
analyzed: katvā yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkamiṃsu iti sabba kiccāni pahāya tuṭṭha mānasāḥ agamaṃsu
translated: they approached the Blessed One. They went with joyful minds, having given up all their duties.

original: Añjaliṃ paṇāmetvāti ete ubhatopakkhikā, te evaṃ cintesuṃ – “sace no micchādiṭṭhikā🔽codessanti ‘kasmā tumhe samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ vanditthā’ti, tesaṃ ‘kiṃ añjalikaraṇamattenāpi
analyzed: añjalim paṇāmetvā iti ete ubhatopakkhikā te evam cintesum sace no micchādiṭṭhikā  codessanti kasmā tumhe samaṇam gotamam vandittha ati tesam kim añjali karaṇam attena api
translated: They raised their joined palms: those on both sides thought thus: “If those who have wrong views🔽rebuke us, saying, ‘Why did you pay homage to the ascetic Gotama?’ we will say, ‘Is it not homage to pay reverence with the hands raised in salutation?’ If those who have right views rebuke us, saying, ‘Why did you not pay homage

original: vanditaṃ hotī’ti vakkhāma. Sace no sammādiṭṭhikā codessanti ‘kasmā bhagavantaṃ na
analyzed: vanditam hoti iti vakkhāma sace no sammādiṭṭhikā codessanti kasmai bhagavantam na
translated: to the Blessed One, who is worthy of homage?’ we will say, ‘Is it not homage to pay reverence with the hands raised in salutation?’”

original: vanditthā’ti, ‘kiṃ sīsena bhūmiṃ paharanteneva vanditaṃ hoti. Nanu añjalikammampi
analyzed: vandittha ati kim sīsena bhūmim paharantena iva vanditam hoti nanu añjali kammam pi
translated: “They have paid homage”: “Is homage paid only by striking the ground with the head? Is not paying homage with joined palms homage too?

original: vandanā evā’ti vakkhāmā”ti.
analyzed: vandanāḥ eva ati vakkhāma ati
translated: I shall say that this is so.”

original: Nāmagottanti, “bho gotama, ahaṃ asukassa putto datto nāma mitto nāma idhāgato”ti
analyzed: nāma gottam ti bho gotama aham asukassa putto dattaḥ nāma mittaḥ nāma idha āgataḥ ti
translated: Name and clan: “Venerable sir, I am the son of so-and-so, called so-and-so, a friend, come here.”

original: vadantā nāmaṃ sāventi nāma. “Bho gotama, ahaṃ vāseṭṭho nāma kaccāno nāma idhāgato”ti🔽vadantā gottaṃ sāventi nāma. Ete kira daliddā jiṇṇakulaputtā “parisamajjhe nāmagottavasena
analyzed: vadantā nāmam sāventi nāma bho gotama aham vāseṭṭhaḥ nāma kaccānaḥ nāma idha āgataḥ ti  vadantā gottam sāventi nāma ete kira daliddāḥ jiṇṇa kula puttā parisamajjhe nāma gotta vasena
translated: In this way they announced their names. “Venerable sir, I am called Vasettha, a Kaccana, come here.”🔽In this way they announced their clans. It seems that these poor men, sons of poor families, did this thinking, “We shall become well known in the assembly by our names and clans.”

original: pākaṭā bhavissāmā”ti evaṃ akaṃsu. Ye pana tuṇhībhūtā nisīdiṃsu, te kerāṭikā ceva
analyzed: pākaṭāḥ bhavissāma ati evam akaṃsu ye pana tuṇhībhūtāḥ nisīdiṃsu te kerāṭikā ca iva
translated: But those who sat there in silence were called “the silent ones”

original: andhabālā ca. Tattha kerāṭikā “ekaṃ dve kathāsallāpe karonte vissāsiko hoti, atha
analyzed: andha bālā ca tattha kerāṭikā ekam dve kathā sallāpe karonte vissāsikaḥ hoti atha
translated: and “the blind fools.” Herein, the “silent ones” thought, “When two or three are conversing together, one becomes confident.

original: vissāse sati ekaṃ dve bhikkhā adātuṃ na yutta”nti tato attānaṃ mocentā tuṇhībhūtā
analyzed: vissāse sati ekam dve bhikkhāḥ a dātum na yuttanti tatas attānam mocentā tuṇhībhūtā
translated: Then, when there is confidence, it is not proper to refuse to give one or two alms.” So, in order to deceive them, they sat there in silence.

original: nisīdanti. Andhabālā aññāṇatāyeva avakkhittamattikāpiṇḍā viya yattha katthaci tuṇhībhūtā nisīdanti.
analyzed: nisīdanti andha bālāḥ aññāṇa tāya iva avakkhitta mattikā piṇḍāḥ viya yattha katthaci tuṇhībhūtāḥ nisīdanti
translated: and sat down. The blind fools, through sheer ignorance, sat down silently anywhere at all, like lumps of clay.🔽The man from Vebhārāma

original: Venāgapurikoti venāgapuravāsī. Etadavocāti pādantato paṭṭhāya yāva kesaggā tathāgatassa
analyzed: venāgapurikā iti venāgapura vāsī etat avoca ati pādantataḥ paṭṭhāya yāva kesaggā tathāgatassa
translated: saw the Tatḥagata’s body from head to foot,

original: sarīraṃ olokento asītianubyañjanasamujjalehi dvattiṃsamahāpurisalakkhaṇehi paṭimaṇḍitaṃ
analyzed: sarīram olokentaḥ asīti anubyañjana samujjalehi dvattiṃsa mahāpurisa lakkhaṇehi paṭimaṇḍitam
translated: adorned with the thirty-two marks of a Great Man, each of which was radiant with the eighty minor characteristics,

original: sarīrā nikkhamitvā samantato asītihatthappadesaṃ ajjhottharitvā ṭhitāhi chabbaṇṇāhi🔽ghanabuddharaṃsīhi samparivāritaṃ tathāgatassa sarīraṃ disvā sañjātavimhayo vaṇṇaṃ
analyzed: sarīrā nikkhamitvā samantataḥ asīti hattha ppadesam ajjhottharitvā ṭhitāhi chabbaṇṇāhi  ghana buddha raṃsīhi samparivāritam tathāgatassa sarīram disvā sañjāta vimhayaḥ vaṇṇam
translated: and surrounded by the six-coloured rays of light that issued from his body and spread out to a distance of eighty cubits all around.

original: bhaṇanto etaṃ “acchariyaṃ, bho gotamā”tiādivacanaṃ avoca.🔽Tattha yāvañcidanti adhimattappamāṇaparicchedavacanametaṃ. Tassa vippasannapadena
analyzed: bhaṇantaḥ etam acchariyam bho gotama ati ādi vacanam avoca  tattha adhimatta ppamāṇa pariccheda vacanam etam tassa vippasanna padena
translated: Overcome with wonder, he spoke these words beginning with “It is wonderful, Master Gotama!” in order to express his admiration.🔽Herein, yāvañcidaṃ means this much, that is, an expression for the highest measure. It is connected with the word vippasannāni,

original: saddhiṃ sambandho. Yāvañca vippasannāni adhimattavippasannānīti attho. Indriyānīti
analyzed: saddhim sambandhaḥ yāvat ca vippasannāni adhimatta vippasannāni iti attho indriyāni iti
translated: which means very clear. Indriyānīti means faculties.

original: cakkhādīni cha indriyāni. Tassa hi pañcannaṃ indriyānaṃ patiṭṭhitokāsassa vippasannataṃ🔽disvā tesaṃ vippasannatā pākaṭā ahosi. Yasmā pana sā mane vippasanneyeva hoti, avippasannacittānañhi
analyzed: cakkha ādīni cha indriyāni tassa hi pañcannam indriyānam patiṭṭhita ukāsassa vippasanna taṃ  disvā tesam vippasanna tā pākaṭā ahosi yasmā pana sā mane vippasannā iya iva hoti a vippasanna cittānam hi
translated: The six faculties are the eye, etc. For when he saw the clarity of the location of the five faculties,🔽their clarity became evident to him. But since that clarity is in the mind,

analyzed: indriya pasādaḥ nāma natthi tasmā assa manindriya ppasādaḥ api pākaṭaḥ ahosi tam esa vippasanna tam
translated: for those whose minds are unclear there is no clarity of the faculties. Therefore the clarity of the mind faculty was also evident to him. Taking that clarity,

original: gahetvā “vippasannāni indriyānī”ti āha. Parisuddhoti nimmalo. Pariyodātoti pabhassaro.🔽Sāradaṃ badarapaṇḍunti saradakāle jātaṃ nātisuparipakkaṃ badaraṃ. Tañhi parisuddhañceva
analyzed: gahetvā vippasannāni indriyāni iti āha parisuddhaḥ ti nimmalo pariyodātaḥ ti pabhassaro  sāradam badara paṇḍunti sarada kāle jātam na ati su paripakkam badaram tat hi parisuddham ca iva
translated: he said, “The faculties are clear.” Pure: stainless. Bright: shining.

original: hoti pariyodātañca. Tālapakkanti suparipakkatālaphalaṃ. Sampati bandhanā pamuttanti
analyzed: hoti pariyodātam ca tāla pakkanti su paripakka tāla phalam bandhanā
translated: A ripe jujube fruit: a jujube fruit that is not too ripe in the autumn. For that is pure and bright. A ripe palm fruit: a palm fruit that is very ripe. Released from its bondage:

original: taṃkhaṇaññeva bandhanā pamuttaṃ. Tassa hi bandhanamūlaṃ apanetvā paramukhaṃ katvā
analyzed: bandhanā pamuttam tassa hi bandhana mūlam apanetvā para mukham katvā
translated: released from its bondage at that very moment. For after the root of its bondage is removed, it is turned upside down.

original: phalake ṭhapitassa caturaṅgulamattaṃ ṭhānaṃ olokentānaṃ parisuddhaṃ pariyodātaṃ hutvā
analyzed: phalake ṭhapitassa catur aṅgula mattam ṭhānam olokentānam parisuddham pariyodātam hutvā
translated: When it is placed on a slab of stone, it shines forth, pure and clear, even in a space of four inches square.

original: khāyati. Taṃ sandhāyevamāha. Nekkhaṃ jambonadanti surattavaṇṇassa jambonadasuvaṇṇassa🔽ghaṭikā. Dakkhakammāraputtasuparikammakatanti dakkhena suvaṇṇakāraputtena suṭṭhu🔽kataparikammaṃ. translated: It is of this that he speaks. ‘A golden jar’: a golden jar of the colour of the Jambu River gold.🔽‘Well-worked’: well-worked by a skilled goldsmith. ‘Well-polished’: well-polished by a skilled goldsmith by rubbing it with a woollen pad. The meaning is: well-polished.

original: Paṇḍukambale nikkhittanti agginā pacitvā dīpidāṭhāya ghaṃsitvā gerukaparikammaṃ katvā🔽rattakambale ṭhapitaṃ. Bhāsateti sañjātaobhāsatāya bhāsate. Tapateti andhakāraviddhaṃsanatāya
analyzed: paṇḍu kambale nikkhittanti agginā pacitvā dīpi dāṭhāya ghaṃsitvā geruka parikammam katvā  ratta kambale ṭhapitam bhāsata iti bhāsate tapata iti andhakāra viddhaṃsanatāya
translated: ‘Placed on a white cloth’: placed on a red cloth after it has been heated by fire, polished with a red woollen pad, and treated with a fine polish.🔽‘It shines forth’: it shines forth with its natural radiance. ‘It glows’: it glows by dispelling darkness.

original: tapate. Virocatīti vijjotamānaṃ hutvā virocati, sobhatīti attho.
analyzed: tapate virocati iti vijjotamānam hutvā virocati sobhati iti attho
translated: ‘It radiates’: it radiates by becoming a mass of light. The meaning is: it shines.

original: Uccāsayanamahāsayanānīti ettha atikkantappamāṇaṃ uccāsayanaṃ nāma, āyatavitthataṃ
analyzed: uccāsayana mahāsayanāni iti ettha atikkanta ppamāṇam uccāsayanam nāma āyata vitthatam
translated: High couches and luxurious couches: what is called a high couch is one that exceeds the right size; what is called a luxurious couch is one that is long and wide. Now, in order to show them, he said “such as a couch, a chair” .

original: akappiyabhaṇḍaṃ mahāsayanaṃ nāma. Idāni tāni dassento seyyathidaṃ, āsandītiādimāha.🔽Tattha āsandīti atikkantappamāṇaṃ āsanaṃ. Pallaṅkoti pādesu vāḷarūpāni ṭhapetvā kato.
analyzed: akappiyabhaṇḍam mahāsayanam nāma idāni tāni dassentaḥ seyyathā idam āsandī iti ādim āha  tattha āsandī iti atikkanta ppamāṇam āsanam pallaṅko ti pādesu vāḷa rūpāni ṭhapetvā kataḥ
translated: Herein, a couch is a seat that exceeds the right size. A chair is one made with legs and a framework.

translated: A sofa is one with long hair-like fringes. Its hairs are four fingerbreadths long, it is said. A rug is a spread made of wool. A spread is a spread made of cotton. A tiger skin is a spread made of tiger skin. A leopard skin is a spread made of leopard skin. A panther skin is a spread made of panther skin. A deer skin is a spread made of deer skin. A cloth is a spread made of cloth.

analyzed: uṇṇāmayattharako yaḥ āmalakapaṭṭaḥ tipi vuccati tūlikā ti tiṇṇam tūlānam aññatara puṇṇā  tūlikā vikatikā ati sīha byaggha ādi rūpa vicitraḥ uṇṇāmayattharakaḥ uddalomī iti
translated: A cotton-down quilt is one filled with cotton down. A silk quilt is one filled with silk floss. A wool quilt is one filled with wool. A silk quilt is one filled with silk. A wool-cotton quilt is one filled with wool and cotton. A silk-cotton quilt is one filled with silk and cotton. A silk-wool quilt is one filled with silk and wool. A silk-cotton-wool quilt is one filled with silk and cotton and wool.

A couch with a decoration on the edge is a couch with a decoration on the edge. A couch with a decoration on the edge and in the middle is a couch with a decoration on the edge and in the middle. A couch with a decoration on the

translated: Some say that it is a flower growing on both sides.🔽Kaṭṭissa means a bedstead made of the finest cloth.

analyzed: paccattharaṇam koseyyanti ratana parisibbitam eva kosiya sutta mayam paccattharaṇam
translated: Some say that the flowers are those that grow on both trees. “Carpets” : carpets made of Koseyya wool, woven with gold thread. “Koseyya” : carpets made of Koseyya wool, woven with silver thread.

original: Kuttakanti soḷasannaṃ nāṭakitthīnaṃ ṭhatvā naccanayoggaṃ uṇṇāmayattharaṇaṃ. Hatthattharādayo🔽hatthipiṭṭhādīsu attharaṇakaattharakā ceva hatthirūpādīni dassetvā kataattharakā
analyzed: nāṭakitthīnam ṭhatvā uṇṇa amayattharaṇam hatthatthara ādayaḥ  hatthi piṭṭha ādīsu attharaṇaka attharakā ca iva hatthi rūpa ādīni dassetvā kata attharakā
translated: “Coverlets” : coverlets made of cotton, spread out for the sixteen kinds of dancing-girls to dance upon. “Blankets” : blankets made of wool, spread out on the backs of elephants, etc.

original: ca. Ajinappaveṇīti ajinacammehi mañcappamāṇena sibbitvā katappaveṇī. Sesaṃ heṭṭhā vuttatthameva.
analyzed: ca ajina ppaveṇī iti ajina cammehi mañca ppamāṇena sibbitvā kata ppaveṇī sesam heṭṭhā vutta ttham eva
translated: “Spreads” : spreads made of wool, spread out on the backs of elephants, etc. “Coverings” : coverings made of wool, spread out on the backs of elephants, etc. “Ajina covers” : covers made of ajina deer-hide, spread out on the backs of elephants, etc. The rest is as already stated.

original: Nikāmalābhīti atikāmalābhī icchiticchitalābhī. Akicchalābhīti adukkhalābhī. Akasiralābhīti
analyzed: nikāma lābhī iti atikāma lābhī icchiticchitalābhī akiccha lābhī iti adukkha lābhī akasira lābhī iti
translated: “At will” : at one’s will, as one wishes. “Without trouble” : without difficulty. “Without confusion” :

original: vipulalābhī mahantalābhī, uḷāruḷārāneva labhati maññeti sandhāya vadati. Ayaṃ kira
analyzed: vipula lābhī mahanta lābhī uḷāra uḷārān eva labhati maññā iti sandhāya vadati ayam kira

original: brāhmaṇo sayanagaruko, so bhagavato vippasannindriyāditaṃ disvā “addhā esa evarūpesu🔽uccāsayanamahāsayanesu nisīdati ceva nipajjati ca. Tenassa vippasannāni indriyāni,
analyzed: brāhmaṇaḥ sayana garukaḥ saḥ bhagavataḥ vippasan indriya āditam disvā addhā esaḥ evarūpesu  uccāsayana mahāsayanesu nisīdati ca iva nipajjati ca tena assa vippasannāni indriyāni
translated: The brahmin was a bed-lounger, and seeing the Blessed One’s faculties clear, etc., he thought: “Surely this one sits and lies down on such high couches and beds. That is why his faculties are clear,

original: parisuddho chavivaṇṇo pariyodāto”ti maññamāno imaṃ senāsanavaṇṇaṃ kathesi.
analyzed: parisuddhaḥ chavi vaṇṇo pariyodāto ti maññamāno imam senāsana vaṇṇam kathesi
translated: The brahmin was a bed-lover. Seeing the Blessed One’s faculties clear, etc., he thought, “Surely he must lie down and sit on such high couches and beds. That is why his faculties are clear, his complexion is pure and bright.” So he spoke this praise of the bed.

original: Laddhā ca pana na kappantīti ettha kiñci kiñci kappati. Suddhakoseyyañhi mañcepi
analyzed: laddhā ca pana na kappanti iti ettha kiñci kiñci kappati
translated: But when it is said that “having obtained them, they are not allowable,” some are allowable. For a pure silk sheet is allowable to spread on a couch,

original: attharituṃ vaṭṭati, gonakādayo ca bhūmattharaṇaparibhogena, āsandiyā pāde chinditvā,🔽pallaṅkassa vāḷe bhinditvā, tūlikaṃ vijaṭetvā “bimbohanañca kātu”nti vacanato imānipi
analyzed: attharitum vaṭṭati gonaka ādayo ca bhūma ttharaṇa paribhogena āsandiyā pāde chinditvā  pallaṅkassa vāḷe bhinditvā tūlikam vijaṭetvā bimbohanam ca kātunti vacanato imāni pi
translated: and the hide of a cow, etc., are allowable as a ground-covering by the usage of elders. The legs of a couch may be cut off and a couch made into a settee.

original: ekena vidhānena kappanti. Akappiyaṃ pana upādāya sabbāneva na kappantīti vuttāni.
analyzed: ekena vidhānena kappanti akappiyam pana upādāya sabbān eva na kappanti iti vuttāni
translated: The frame of a sofa may be broken and the cotton wool pulled out. And the expression “and make a bimbohana” is a term for all these things. So these are allowable by one method. But all are said to be not allowable when taken as what is not allowable.

original: Vanantaññeva pavisāmīti araññaṃyeva pavisāmi. Yadevāti yāniyeva. Pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvāti
analyzed: vanantaññā iva pavisāmi iti araññaṃyā iva pavisāmi yat eva ati yāniyā iva pallaṅkam ābhujitvā ati
translated: I enter only the forest: I enter only the forest grove. Whatever: which. Having folded the legs of the couch under it:

original: samantato ūrubaddhāsanaṃ bandhitvā. Ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāyāti aṭṭhārasa piṭṭhikaṇṭake
analyzed: samantataḥ ūru baddha āsanam bandhitvā ujum kāyam paṇidhāya ati aṭṭhārasa piṭṭhikaṇṭake
translated: and he should bind it on all round with a bandage. Straightened the body:🔽he should straighten the body by placing one rib on the other.

original: koṭiyā koṭiṃ paṭipādento ujuṃ kāyaṃ ṭhapetvā. Parimukhaṃ satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvāti kammaṭṭhānābhimukhaṃ
analyzed: koṭiyā koṭim paṭipādento ujum kāyam ṭhapetvā parimukham satim upaṭṭhapetvā ati kammaṭṭhāna abhimukham
translated: Established mindfulness in front: he should establish mindfulness facing the meditation subject,

original: satiṃ ṭhapetvā, pariggahitaniyyānaṃ vā katvāti attho. Vuttañhetaṃ – “parīti pariggahaṭṭho.
analyzed: satim ṭhapetvā pariggahita niyyānam vā katvā iti atthaḥ vuttam ha etam pari iti pariggahaṭṭhaḥ
translated: or he should take up the outlet. For this is said: “Pari is the syllable of taking up;

original: Mukhanti niyyānaṭṭho. Satīti upaṭṭhānaṭṭho. Tena vuccati parimukhaṃ satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvā”ti.
analyzed: mukham ti niyyāna aṭṭho satī iti upaṭṭhāna aṭṭho tena vuccati parimukham satim upaṭṭhapetvā ati
translated: mukha is the syllable of outlet; sati is the syllable of establishment. Hence ‘having established mindfulness in front’ is said” .🔽I enter upon and abide in: I obtain and actualize.

original: Upasampajja viharāmīti paṭilabhitvā paccakkhaṃ katvā viharāmi. Evaṃbhūtoti evaṃ paṭhamajjhānādīsu🔽aññatarasamaṅgī hutvā. Dibbo me eso tasmiṃ samaye caṅkamo hotīti cattāri hi rūpajjhānāni
analyzed: upasampajja viharāmi iti paṭilabhitvā paccakkham katvā viharāmi evaṃbhūtaḥ ti evam paṭhama jhāna ādīsu  aññatara samaṅgī hutvā dibbaḥ me eso tasmin samaye caṅkamaḥ hoti iti cattāri hi rūpa jjhānāni
translated: Possessed of such a body: possessed of one of the kinds of jhāna beginning with the first.

original: samāpajjitvā caṅkamantassa caṅkamo dibbacaṅkamo nāma hoti, samāpattito vuṭṭhāya caṅkamantassāpi
analyzed: samāpajjitvā caṅkamantassa caṅkamaḥ dibbacaṅkamaḥ nāma hoti samāpattitaḥ vuṭṭhāya caṅkamantassa api
translated: My walk at that time is divine: when he enters upon and abides in any one of the four jhānas of the fine-material sphere and walks up and down, then his walk is called “divine walk.” And also when he walks up and down after emerging from the jhāna,🔽his walk is still called “divine walk.”

original: caṅkamo dibbacaṅkamoyeva. Ṭhānādīsupi eseva nayo. Tathā itaresu dvīsu vihāresu.
analyzed: caṅkamaḥ ṭhāna ādīsu pi esa iva nayo tathā itaresu dvīsu vihāresu
translated: and the walking place is divine. The same method applies to the standing place, etc., and to the other two dwellings.🔽I understand thus: “Destroyed is birth, the holy life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no more for this state of being” .

original: So evaṃ pajānāmi “rāgo me pahīno”ti mahābodhipallaṅke arahattamaggena pahīnarāgameva
analyzed: evam pajānāmi rāgaḥ me pahīnaḥ iti mahā bodhi pallaṅke arahatta maggena pahīna rāgam eva
translated: He shows that he had already abandoned lust by the path of Arahantship on the Great Jhāna Seat.

original: dassento “so evaṃ pajānāmi rāgo me pahīno”ti āha. Sesapadesupi eseva nayo. Iminā
analyzed: dassentaḥ saḥ evam pajānāmi rāgaḥ me pahīnaḥ ti āha sesa padesu pi esa iva nayaḥ iminā
translated: “I understand thus: ‘Lust is abandoned by me’” . The same method applies to the other cases.

original: pana kiṃ kathitaṃ hotīti? Paccavekkhaṇā kathitā, paccavekkhaṇāya phalasamāpatti kathitā.
analyzed: pana kim kathitam hoti iti paccavekkhaṇā kathitā paccavekkhaṇāya phala samāpatti kathitā
translated: But what is stated here? The reviewing is stated. The fruition attainment is stated.

original: Phalasamāpattiñhi samāpannassapi samāpattito vuṭṭhitassāpi caṅkamādayo ariyacaṅkamādayo
analyzed: phala samāpattim hi samāpannassa api samāpattitaḥ vuṭṭhitassa api caṅkama ādayaḥ ariya caṅkama ādayaḥ
translated: For even when one has emerged from fruition attainment, the walking place, etc., are still the Noble Ones’ walking place, etc.

original: honti. Sesamettha uttānatthamevāti.
analyzed: honti sesam ettha uttānattham eva ati
translated: The rest is clear in meaning.

analyzed: kūṭāni gijjhāḥ vā tassa kūṭesu vasanti iti gijjhakūṭaḥ tasmin gijjhakūṭe pabbate etena assa

translated: a dwelling was built for the Tathāgata, and it was called the Vulture Peak Monastery. There he🔽lived at that time.

analyzed: samaye viharati iti sarabhaḥ nāma paribbājakaḥ acira pakkanto hoti iti sarabhaḥ iti evaṃnāmako  paribbājakaḥ imasmin sāsane pabbajitvā nacirassa iva pakkantaḥ hoti adhunā vibbhantaḥ ti  attho sammāsambuddhe hi loke uppanne titthiyāḥ naṭṭha lābha sakkārāḥ ahesum tiṇṇam
translated: The wanderer named Sarabha had recently left the Dispensation: the wanderer named Sarabha,

translated: does not lead out, does not lead beyond, does not accomplish that purpose. The one who practises: the person who fulfils that practice. Or else: for the one for whose sake the Dhamma was taught. Thus: for the sake of whom the Dhamma was taught. For example: the meditation subject of foulness for the sake of greed and aversion, the development of loving-kindness for the sake of ill will, the five aggregates for the sake of the conceit “I am,” the four noble truths for the sake of ignorance, mindfulness of breathing for the sake of cutting off applied thoughts. translated: does not lead out, does not lead forth, does not accomplish that aim. The one who practises: the person who fulfils that practice. To the complete destruction of suffering: by means of the cause, the method, the reason, for the destruction of all suffering in the round of rebirths. Or else: for the sake of which you taught the Dhamma. For the sake of which you taught the Dhamma: for the sake of which you taught the Dhamma, such as the meditation subject of foulness for the sake of overcoming lust, the development of loving-kindness for the sake of overcoming ill will, the five aggregates for the sake of overcoming delusion, mindfulness of breathing for the sake of cutting off applied thoughts. It does not lead out: that Dhamma does not lead out, does not lead forth, by means of the cause, the method, the reason, for the destruction of the suffering in the round of rebirths of the one who practises it in the way taught. original: Tattha hoteva kaṅkhāti hotiyeva kaṅkhā. Vicikicchāti tasseva vevacanaṃ. Alanti yuttaṃ.🔽Mā anussavenāti anussavakathāyapi mā gaṇhittha. Mā paramparāyāti paramparakathāyapi
analyzed: tattha hotā iva kaṅkhāti hotiyā iva kaṅkhā vicikicchāti tassa iva vevacanam alanti yuttam  mā anussavena ati anussava kathāyapi mā gaṇhittha mā paramparāya ati parampara kathāyapi
translated: “There is doubt for him” means there is doubt for him. “Scepticism” is a synonym for that. “Not” is connected.

original: mā gaṇhittha. Mā itikirāyāti evaṃ kira etanti mā gaṇhittha. Mā piṭakasampadānenāti🔽amhākaṃ piṭakatantiyā saddhiṃ sametīti mā gaṇhittha. Mā takkahetūti takkaggāhenapi🔽mā gaṇhittha. Mā nayahetūti nayaggāhenapi mā gaṇhittha. Mā ākāraparivitakkenāti sundaramidaṃ🔽kāraṇanti evaṃ kāraṇaparivitakkenapi mā gaṇhittha. Mā diṭṭhinijjhānakkhantiyāti amhākaṃ
analyzed: mā gaṇhittha mā itikirāya ati evam kira etat ti mā gaṇhittha mā piṭaka sampadānena ati  amhākam piṭaka tantiyā saddhim sameti iti mā gaṇhittha mā takka hetu uti takka ggāhena api  mā gaṇhittha mā naya hetū ti naya ggāhena api mā gaṇhittha mā ākāra parivitakkena ati sundaram idam  kāraṇam ti evam kāraṇa parivitakkena api mā gaṇhittha mā diṭṭhi nijjhāna kkhantiyā ati amhākam
translated: “Do not take it on the strength of oral tradition” means do not take it on the strength of the statement of oral tradition. “Do not take it on the strength of what has been handed down” means do not take it on the strength of the statement of what has been handed down.🔽“Do not take it on the strength of what is contained in books” means do not take it on the strength of the statement of what is contained in books. “Do not take it on the strength of logical reasoning” means do not take it on the strength of the statement of logical reasoning.🔽“Do not take it on the strength of the approval of the thoughtful” means do not take it on the strength of the statement of the approval of the thoughtful. “Do not take it on the strength of the appearance of what is factually possible” means do not take it on the strength of the statement of the appearance of what is factually possible.

original: nijjhāyitvā khamitvā gahitadiṭṭhiyā saddhiṃ sametītipi mā gaṇhittha. Mā bhabbarūpatāyāti🔽ayaṃ bhikkhu bhabbarūpo, imassa kathaṃ gahetuṃ yuttantipi mā gaṇhittha. Mā samaṇo
analyzed: nijjhāyitvā khamitvā gahita diṭṭhiyā saddhim sameti iti pi mā gaṇhittha mā bhabba rūpa tāya ati 🔽ayam bhikkhu bhabba rūpaḥ imassa katham gahetum mā gaṇhittha mā samaṇaḥ
translated: “Do not take it on the strength of the fact that the teacher is worthy of confidence” means do not take it on the strength of the statement of the fact that the teacher is worthy of confidence. “Do not take it on the strength of the fact that the teacher is competent” means do not take it on the strength of the statement of the fact that the teacher is competent.

original: no garūti ayaṃ samaṇo amhākaṃ garu, imassa kathaṃ gahetuṃ yuttantipi mā gaṇhittha.
analyzed: no ayam samaṇaḥ amhākam garu imassa katham gahetum mā
translated: No, he is not my superior: do not think that this ascetic is my superior and that it is proper for me to take his side.

original: Samattāti paripuṇṇā. Samādinnāti gahitā parāmaṭṭhā. Yaṃsa hotīti yaṃ kāraṇaṃ tassa
analyzed: sa mattā ati paripuṇṇā samādinnā ati gahitā parāmaṭṭhā hoti iti yam kāraṇam tassa
translated: Complete: fulfilled. Taken up: grasped and adhered to. Whatever is the reason: whatever is the reason for that person’s

original: puggalassa hoti. Alobhādayo lobhādipaṭipakkhavasena veditabbā. Vigatābhijjhotiādīhi
analyzed: puggalassa hoti alobha ādayaḥ lobha ādi paṭipakkha vasena veditabbā vigata abhijjhoti ādīhi
translated: being so. Non-greed, etc., should be understood as the opposites of greed, etc. Free from covetousness: the preliminary stage of loving-kindness is stated by the words

original: mettāya pubbabhāgo kathito.
analyzed: mettāya pubbabhāgaḥ kathitaḥ
translated: “free from covetousness.”

original: Idāni mettādikaṃ kammaṭṭhānaṃ kathento mettāsahagatenātiādimāha. Tattha kammaṭṭhānakathāya
analyzed: idāni mettā ādikam kammaṭṭhānam kathentaḥ mettā sahagatena ati ādim āha tattha kammaṭṭhāna kathāya
translated: Now, in order to explain the meditation subject beginning with loving- kindness, he said, “With his mind filled with loving-kindness, etc.” Herein,

original: vā bhāvanānaye vā pāḷivaṇṇanāya vā yaṃ vattabbaṃ siyā, taṃ sabbaṃ visuddhimagge vuttameva.🔽Evaṃ averacittoti evaṃ akusalaverassa ca puggalaverino ca natthitāya averacitto.
analyzed: vā bhāvanā naye vā pāḷi vaṇṇanāya vā yam vattabbam siyā tat sabbam visuddhi magge vuttam eva  evam avera citto ti evam akusala verassa ca puggala verino ca natthitāya avera citto
translated: whatever should be said about the meditation subject, or about the method of development, or about the text of the discourses, all that has been said in the Visuddhimagga.🔽Thus with a mind free from hate: thus with a mind free from both the unprofitable root hate and the personal malice called “bearing ill will.”

original: Abyābajjhacittoti kodhacittassa abhāvena niddukkhacitto. Asaṃkiliṭṭhacittoti kilesassa
analyzed: abyābajjha citto ti kodha cittassa abhāvena niddukkha citto asaṃkiliṭṭha cittoti kilesassa
translated: With a mind free from ill will: with a mind free from the state of anger called “ill will.” With a mind unaffected by hate: with a mind free from the defilement

original: natthitāya asaṃkiliṭṭhacitto. Visuddhacittoti kilesamalābhāvena visuddhacitto hotīti
analyzed: natthitāya asaṃkiliṭṭha cittaḥ visuddha citto ti kilesa mala abhāvena visuddha cittaḥ hoti iti
translated: He is one whose mind is uncontaminated by non-existence. He is one whose mind is purified by being free from the stain of defilements.🔽This is the meaning. He: of such a noble disciple.

original: attho. Tassāti tassa evarūpassa ariyasāvakassa. Assāsāti avassayā patiṭṭhā. Sace
analyzed: attho tassa ati tassa evarūpassa ariya sāvakassa assāsā ati avassayā patiṭṭhā sace
translated: Assurance: a refuge.

original: kho pana atthi paro lokoti yadi imamhā lokā paraloko nāma atthi. Athāhaṃ kāyassa
analyzed: kho pana atthi paraḥ loko ti yadi imamhā lokā para lokaḥ nāma atthi atha aham kāyassa
translated: If there is another world: if there is what is called another world beyond this world,

original: bhedā parammaraṇā…pe… upapajjissāmīti atthetaṃ kāraṇaṃ, yenāhaṃ kāyassa bhedā parammaraṇā
analyzed: bhedā parammaraṇā pe upapajjissāmi iti attha etam kāraṇam yena aham kāyassa bhedā parammaraṇā
translated: then I shall be reborn after the break-up of the body, after death …

original: sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjissāmīti evaṃ sabbattha nayo veditabbo. Anīghanti niddukkhaṃ.
analyzed: sugatim saggam lokam upapajjissāmi iti evam sabbattha nayaḥ veditabbaḥ anīgham ti niddukkham
translated: I shall be reborn in a happy state, in a heavenly world. This is the reason why I shall be reborn in a happy state, in a heavenly world, after the break-up of the body, after death. The method should be understood in this way in each instance.🔽Free from distress: free from suffering.🔽Happy: happy.

original: Sukhinti sukhitaṃ. Ubhayeneva visuddhaṃ attānaṃ samanupassāmīti yañca pāpaṃ na karomi,
analyzed: sukhinti sukhitam ubhayena iva visuddham attānam samanupassāmi iti yat ca pāpam na karomi
translated: I see myself as purified in both ways: I see myself as purified in both ways, in that I do not do evil

original: yañca karotopi na karīyati, iminā ubhayenāpi visuddhaṃ attānaṃ samanupassāmi. Sesaṃ🔽sabbattha uttānatthamevāti.🔽6. Sāḷhasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: yat ca na iminā ubhayena api visuddham attānam samanupassāmi sesam 🔽sabbattha uttāna attham eva ti 🔽sāḷha sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: and in that I do not do what is done to me. The rest is self-evident.

original: 67. Chaṭṭhe migāranattāti migāraseṭṭhino nattā. Sekhuniyanattāti sekhuniyaseṭṭhino
analyzed: chaṭṭhe migāra nattā ati migāra seṭṭhinaḥ nattā sekhu niya nattā ati sekhu niya seṭṭhinaḥ
translated: 67.In the sixth, the king of deer’s son is the son of the chief of the deer. The son of the female weaver is the son of the chief weaver.

original: nattā. Upasaṅkamiṃsūti bhuttapātarāsā dāsakammakaraparivutā upasaṅkamiṃsu. Tesaṃ🔽kira purebhatte pubbaṇhasamayeyeva gehe eko pañho samuṭṭhito, taṃ pana kathetuṃ okāso
analyzed: nattāḥ upasaṅkamiṃsu iti bhutta pāta rāsāḥ dāsa kammakara parivutāḥ upasaṅkamiṃsu tesam  kira purebhatte pubbaṇha samayeya iva gehe ekaḥ pañhaḥ samuṭṭhito tam pana kathetum okāsaḥ
translated: In the sixth, the chief of the deer’s attendants: the chief of the deer’s attendants. The chief of the weavers’ attendants: the chief of the weavers’ attendants. They approached: after eating breakfast, surrounded by slaves and workmen, they approached. It is said that

original: nāhosi. Te “taṃ pañhaṃ sossāmā”ti therassa santikaṃ gantvā vanditvā tuṇhī nisīdiṃsu.🔽Thero “gāme taṃ samuṭṭhitaṃ pañhaṃ sotuṃ āgatā bhavissantī”ti tesaṃ manaṃ ñatvā tameva🔽pañhaṃ ārabhanto etha tumhe sāḷhātiādimāha. Tattha atthi lobhoti lubbhanasabhāvo🔽lobho nāma atthīti pucchati. Abhijjhāti kho ahaṃ sāḷhā etamatthaṃ vadāmīti etaṃ lobhasaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: na ahosi te tam pañham sossāma ati therassa santikam gantvā vanditvā tuṇhī nisīdiṃsu  theraḥ gāme tam samuṭṭhitam pañham sotum āgatāḥ bhavissanti iti tesam manam ñatvā tam eva  pañham ārabhantaḥ tumhe sāḷhā iti ādim āha tattha atthi lobho ti lubbhana sabhāvaḥ  lobhaḥ nāma atthi iti pucchati kho aham sāḷhā etam attham vadāmi iti etam lobha saṅkhātam
translated: before breakfast, in the early morning, a question arose in the house, but there was no opportunity to discuss it. They thought, “We will listen to that question,” and went to the Elder’s presence, paid homage, and sat down silently.

original: atthaṃ ahaṃ “abhijjhā”ti vadāmi, “taṇhā”ti vadāmīti samuṭṭhitapañhassa atthaṃ dīpento
analyzed: attham aham abhijjhā iti vadāmi taṇhā iti vadāmi iti samuṭṭhita pañhassa attham dīpento
translated: The Elder thought, “They have come to hear the question that arose in the village,” and knowing their minds, he began with that very question, saying, “Come, Sāḷha.” Herein, is there greed? He asks whether there is a thing called greed, the nature of which is to be greedy. I speak of this, Sāḷha, as covetousness: I speak of this meaning, which is called greed, as “covetousness,” as “craving,” he said, illuminating the meaning of the question that arose.

original: āha. Evaṃ sabbavāresu nayo netabbo.
analyzed: āha evam sabba vāresu nayaḥ netabbo
translated: He said. The method should be understood in this way in all the cases.

original: So evaṃ pajānātīti so cattāro brahmavihāre bhāvetvā ṭhito ariyasāvako samāpattito
analyzed: saḥ evam pajānāti iti saḥ cattāraḥ brahmavihāre bhāvetvā ṭhitaḥ ariyasāvako samāpattitaḥ
translated: He understands thus: the noble disciple who has thus developed the four divine abodes, on emerging from that attainment,

original: vuṭṭhāya vipassanaṃ ārabhanto evaṃ pajānāti. Atthi idanti atthi dukkhasaccasaṅkhātaṃ🔽khandhapañcakaṃ nāmarūpavasena paricchinditvā pajānanto esa “evaṃ pajānāti atthi
analyzed: vuṭṭhāya vipassanam ārabhantaḥ evam pajānāti atthi idam ti atthi dukkha sacca saṅkhātam  khandha pañcakam nāma rūpa vasena paricchinditvā pajānantaḥ esaḥ evam pajānāti atthi
translated: understands thus: “There is this, there is what is worse than this, there is what is better than this, and there is an escape beyond both the good and the bad.”🔽He understands thus: he understands thus by discerning the five aggregates as objects of clinging as “There is this” and by discerning the origin of the aggregates as “There is what is worse than this” and by discerning the cessation of the aggregates as “There is what is better than this” and by discerning the path as “There is an escape beyond both the good and the bad.”🔽He understands thus: “There is this”: he is said to “understand thus” because he understands by discerning the five aggregates as objects of clinging as “There is this.”

original: ida”nti vutto. Hīnanti samudayasaccaṃ. Paṇītanti maggasaccaṃ. Imassa saññāgatassa🔽uttari nissaraṇanti imassa vipassanāsaññāsaṅkhātassa saññāgatassa uttari nissaraṇaṃ
analyzed: idam ti vuttaḥ hīna nti samudaya saccam paṇīta nti magga saccam imassa saññāgatassa  uttari nissaraṇanti imassa vipassanā saññā saṅkhātassa saññāgatassa uttari nissaraṇaṃ
translated: What is worse than this: the truth of the origin. What is better than this: the truth of the path. Beyond both the good and the bad: the escape from this state of consciousness called insight.🔽There is an escape: he shows the truth of cessation by this.

original: nāma nibbānaṃ, tamatthīti iminā nirodhasaccaṃ dasseti. Vimuttasmiṃ vimuttamiti ñāṇanti
analyzed: nāma nibbānam tam atthi iti iminā nirodha saccam dasseti vimuttasmin vimuttam iti ñāṇam ti
translated: When it is liberated, he understands: he understands by the nineteen kinds of knowledge of reviewing.

original: ekūnavīsatividhaṃ paccavekkhaṇañāṇaṃ kathitaṃ. Ahu pubbe lobhoti pubbe me lobho ahosi.
analyzed: ekūnavīsatividham paccavekkhaṇa ñāṇam kathitam ahu pubbe lobho ti pubbe me lobho ahosi
translated: There was greed in the past: there was greed in me in the past.

original: Tadahu akusalanti taṃ akusalaṃ nāma ahosi, tadā vā akusalaṃ nāma ahosi. Iccetaṃ kusalanti
analyzed: tat ahu tam akusalam nāma ahosi tadā vā akusalam nāma ahosi icca itam kusalanti
translated: “It was called unwholesome then”: it was called unwholesome at that time.

original: iti etaṃ kusalaṃ, tasseva akusalassa natthibhāvaṃ kusalaṃ khemanti sandhāya vadati.
analyzed: iti etam kusalam tassa iva akusalassa natthi bhāvam kusalam khemanti sandhāya vadati
translated: “Thus it is called wholesome”: thus it is called wholesome. He says this with reference to the non-existence of that unwholesome state, to its being wholesome and safe.

original: Nicchātoti nittaṇho. Nibbutoti abbhantare santāpakarānaṃ kilesānaṃ abhāvena nibbuto.
analyzed: nicchāto ti nittaṇhaḥ nibbutaḥ ti abbhantare santāpa karānam kilesānam abhāvena nibbutaḥ
translated: “Satisfied”: free from craving. “Quenched”: quenched by the absence of the defilements that burn within.

original: Sītibhūtoti sītalībhūto. Sukhappaṭisaṃvedīti kāyikacetasikassa sukhassa paṭisaṃveditā.
analyzed: sīti bhūtaḥ ti sītalībhūtaḥ sukha ppaṭisaṃvedī iti kāyika cetasikassa sukhassa paṭisaṃveditā
translated: “Cooled off”: become cool. “Experiencing bliss”: experiencing bodily and mental bliss.

original: Brahmabhūtenāti seṭṭhabhūtena. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānatthamevāti.🔽7. Kathāvatthusuttavaṇṇanā🔽68. Sattame kathāvatthūnīti kathākāraṇāni, kathāya bhūmiyo patiṭṭhāyoti attho. Atītaṃ🔽vā, bhikkhave, addhānanti atītamaddhānaṃ nāma kālopi vaṭṭati khandhāpi. Anāgatapaccuppannesupi
analyzed: brahma bhūtena ati seṭṭha bhūtena sesam sabbattha uttāna attham eva ati 🔽       🔽sattame kathā vatthūni iti kathā kāraṇāni kathāya bhūmiyaḥ patiṭṭhāya uti attho atītam 🔽vā bhikkhave addhānanti atītam addhānam nāma kālaḥ api vaṭṭati khandhā api anāgata paccuppannesu pi
translated: “With a mind that is free from enmity”: with a mind that is free from hatred. The rest is clear.

original: eseva nayo. Tattha atīte kassapo nāma sammāsambuddho ahosi, tassa kikī nāma kāsikarājā
analyzed: esa iva nayaḥ tattha atīte kassapaḥ nāma sammāsambuddhaḥ ahosi tassa kikī nāma kāsika rājā
translated: and so on. Herein, in the past there was a Supremely Enlightened One named Kassapa. His royal chief attendant was a king of Kāsi named Kiki.

original: aggupaṭṭhāko ahosi, vīsati vassasahassāni āyu ahosīti iminā nayena kathento atītaṃ🔽ārabbha kathaṃ katheti nāma. Anāgate metteyyo nāma buddho bhavissati, tassa saṅkho🔽nāma rājā aggupaṭṭhāko bhavissati, asīti vassasahassāni āyu bhavissatīti iminā nayena
analyzed: aggupaṭṭhākaḥ ahosi vīsati vassa sahassāni āyu ahosi iti iminā nayena kathentaḥ atītam  ārabbha katham kathā iti nāma anāgate metteyyaḥ nāma buddhaḥ bhavissati tassa saṅkhaḥ  nāma rājā aggupaṭṭhākaḥ bhavissati asīti vassa sahassāni āyu bhavissati iti iminā nayena
translated: So too with the rest. Herein, one who tells stories about the past, saying, “In the past there was a Perfect Buddha named Kassapa, whose chief attendant was a king of Kāsī named Kiki, whose life-span was twenty thousand years,” is telling stories about the past.🔽One who tells stories about the future, saying, “In the future there will be a Buddha named Metteyya, whose chief attendant will be a king named Saṅkha, whose life-span will be eighty thousand years,” is telling stories about the future.

original: kathento anāgataṃ ārabbha kathaṃ katheti nāma. Etarahi asuko nāma rājā dhammikoti🔽iminā nayena kathento paccuppannaṃ ārabbha kathaṃ katheti nāma.
analyzed: kathentaḥ anāgatam ārabbha katham kathā iti nāma etarahi asukaḥ nāma rājā dhammikā ti  iminā nayena kathentaḥ paccuppannam ārabbha katham kathā iti nāma
translated: One who tells stories about the present, saying, “At present this king is righteous,” is telling stories about the present.🔽By the means of a story: by the means of a meeting of stories.

original: Kathāsampayogenāti kathāsamāgamena. Kacchoti kathetuṃ yutto. Akacchoti kathetuṃ na
analyzed: kathā sampayogena ati kathā samāgamena kaccho iti kathetum yuttaḥ a kaccho iti kathetum na
translated: Worthy of being told: fit to be told. Unworthy of being told: unfit to be told.

original: yutto. Ekaṃsabyākaraṇīyaṃ pañhantiādīsu, “cakkhu, anicca”nti puṭṭhena, “āma, anicca”nti
analyzed: ekaṃsa byākaraṇīyam pañha nti ādīsu cakkhu aniccanti puṭṭhena āma aniccanti
translated: In the case of the question “Is the eye permanent?” if one is asked, “Is the eye permanent?” and one answers, “Yes, it is permanent,”

original: ekaṃseneva byākātabbaṃ. Eseva nayo sotādīsu. Ayaṃ ekaṃsabyākaraṇīyo pañho. “Aniccaṃ
analyzed: ekaṃsena iva byākātabbam esa iva nayaḥ sota ādīsu ayam ekaṃsa byākaraṇīyaḥ pañhaḥ aniccam
translated: and it should be answered categorically. So too with the ear, and so on. This is a question to be answered categorically.

original: nāma cakkhū”ti puṭṭhena pana “na cakkhumeva, sotampi aniccaṃ, ghānampi anicca”nti
analyzed: nāma cakkhu iti puṭṭhena pana na cakkhum eva sotam pi aniccam ghānam pi aniccanti
translated: But when he is asked, “Is the eye impermanent?” he should answer by analyzing it thus: “Not only the eye but also the ear is impermanent, and the nose is impermanent too.”

original: evaṃ vibhajitvā byākātabbaṃ. Ayaṃ vibhajjabyākaraṇīyo pañho. “Yathā cakkhu, tathā
analyzed: evam vibhajitvā byākātabbam ayam vibhajja byākaraṇīyaḥ pañhaḥ yathā cakkhu tathā
translated: This is a question to be answered by analyzing it.

original: sotaṃ. Yathā sotaṃ, tathā cakkhū”ti puṭṭhena “kenaṭṭhena pucchasī”ti paṭipucchitvā
analyzed: sotam yathā sotam tathā cakkhu iti puṭṭhena kenaṭṭhena pucchasi iti paṭipucchitvā
translated: When he is asked, “Is the ear as it is the eye, or is the eye as it is the ear?” he should counter-question thus: “In what sense do you ask?”🔽If the questioner replies, “I ask in the sense of seeing,” the answer should be “No.”

original: “dassanaṭṭhena pucchāmī”ti vutte “na hī”ti byākātabbaṃ. “Aniccaṭṭhena pucchāmī”ti🔽vutte, “āmā”ti byākātabbaṃ. Ayaṃ paṭipucchābyākaraṇīyo pañho. “Taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīra”ntiādīni
analyzed: dassana ṭṭhena pucchāmi iti vutte na hi iti byākātabbam anicca ṭṭhena pucchāmi iti  vutte āma ati byākātabbam ayam paṭipucchā byākaraṇīyaḥ pañho tam jīvam tam sarīram ti ādīni
translated: If he replies, “I ask in the sense of impermanence,” the answer should be “Yes.”🔽This is a question to be answered by a counter-question.

original: puṭṭhena pana “abyākatametaṃ bhagavatā”ti ṭhapetabbo, esa pañho na byākātabbo. Ayaṃ ṭhapanīyo pañho.
analyzed: puṭṭhena pana a byākatam etam bhagavatā ati ṭhapetabbaḥ esa pañhaḥ na byākātabbaḥ ayam ṭhapanīyaḥ pañho
translated: When he is asked, “Is the soul the same as the body? ” he should set the question aside as one that should not be answered, saying, “This has not been declared by the Blessed One.” This is a question to be set aside.

original: Ṭhānāṭhāne na saṇṭhātīti kāraṇākāraṇe na saṇṭhāti. Tatrāyaṃ nayo – sassatavādī yuttena
analyzed: ṭhāna aṭhāne na saṇṭhāti iti kāraṇa akāraṇe na saṇṭhāti tatra ayam nayaḥ sassata vādī yuttena
translated: He does not stick to the reason and the non-reason: he does not stick to the cause and the non-cause. Here is the explanation. A theorist of eternalism,

original: kāraṇena pahoti ucchedavādiṃ niggahetuṃ, ucchedavādī tena niggayhamāno “kiṃ panāhaṃ
analyzed: kāraṇena uccheda vādim niggahetum uccheda vādī tena niggayhamānaḥ kim pana aham
translated: he is able to refute the annihilationist, and the annihilationist, being refuted, thinks: “What is this?

original: ucchedaṃ vadāmī”ti sassatavādibhāvameva dīpeti, attano vāde patiṭṭhātuṃ na sakkoti.🔽Evaṃ ucchedavādimhi pahonte sassatavādī, puggalavādimhi pahonte suññatavādī, suññatavādimhi
analyzed: ucchedam vadāmi iti sassata vādi bhāvam eva dīpeti attanaḥ vāde patiṭṭhātum na sakkoti  evam uccheda vādimhi pahonte sassata vādī puggala vādimhi pahonte suññata vādī suññata vādimhi
translated: He is able to refute the annihilationist by reason. When the annihilationist is refuted, he shows that he himself is not an annihilationist, but a theorist of eternalism. He is unable to establish his own view.

original: pahonte puggalavādīti evaṃ ṭhānāṭhāne na saṇṭhāti nāma.
analyzed: puggala vādī iti evam ṭhāna aṭhāne na saṇṭhāti nāma
translated: Thus when the annihilationist is refuted, the eternalist is refuted. When the theorist of the person is refuted, the theorist of emptiness is refuted. When the theorist of emptiness is refuted, the theorist of the person is refuted. Thus he does not stand firm in the right or wrong place.

original: Parikappe na saṇṭhātīti idaṃ pañhapucchanepi pañhakathanepi labbhati. Kathaṃ? Ekacco🔽hi “pañhaṃ pucchissāmī”ti kaṇṭhaṃ sodheti, so itarena “idaṃ nāma tvaṃ pucchissasī”ti🔽vutto ñātabhāvaṃ ñatvā “na etaṃ, aññaṃ pucchissāmī”ti vadati. Pañhaṃ puṭṭhopi “pañhaṃ
analyzed: parikappe na saṇṭhāti iti idam pañha pucchane pi pañha kathane pi labbhati katham ekacco  hi pañham pucchissāmi iti kaṇṭham sodheti saḥ itarena idam nāma tvam pucchissasi iti  vuttaḥ ñāta bhāvam ñatvā na etam aññam pucchissāmi iti vadati pañham puṭṭhaḥ api pañham
translated: He does not stand firm in the discussion. This applies to the asking of the question and to the answering of the question. How?🔽For one who says, “I will ask a question,” clears his throat. The other says to him, “You will ask this.”🔽Understanding that he is found out, he says, “No, I will ask another.”

original: kathessāmī”ti hanuṃ saṃsodheti, so itarena “idaṃ nāma kathessasī”ti vutto ñātabhāvaṃ
analyzed: kathessāmi iti hanum saṃsodheti saḥ itarena idam nāma kathessasi iti vuttaḥ ñāta bhāvam
translated: When asked a question, he cleans his throat, saying, “I will answer the question.” The other says to him, “You will answer this.” Understanding that he is found out,

original: ñatvā “na etaṃ, aññaṃ kathessāmī”ti vadati. Evaṃ parikappe na saṇṭhāti nāma.
analyzed: ñatvā na etam aññam kathessāmi iti vadati evam parikappe na saṇṭhāti nāma
translated: He knows that it is not so, but he says, “I will tell you something else.” This is called “not settling down in the discussion.”

original: Aññātavāde na saṇṭhātīti aññātavāde jānitavāde na saṇṭhāti. Kathaṃ? Ekacco pañhaṃ
analyzed: aññāta vāde na saṇṭhāti iti aññāta vāde jānita vāde na saṇṭhāti katham ekacco pañham
translated: “He does not settle down in the statement of what is known”: he does not settle down in the statement of what is known, in the statement of what is seen. How? Someone

original: pucchati, taṃ itaro “manāpo tayā pañho pucchito, kahaṃ te esa uggahito”ti vadati.
analyzed: pucchati tam itaraḥ manāpaḥ tayā pañhaḥ pucchito kaham te esaḥ uggahito ti vadati
translated: asks a question. The other says, “The question you have asked is pleasing. Where did you learn it?”

original: Itaro pucchitabbaniyāmeneva pañhaṃ pucchitvāpi tassa kathāya “apañhaṃ nu kho pucchita”nti🔽vimatiṃ karoti. Aparo pañhaṃ puṭṭho katheti, tamañño “suṭṭhu te pañho kathito, kattha
analyzed: itaro pucchitabba niyāmena iva pañham pucchitvā api tassa kathāya apañham nu kho pucchitanti  vimatim karoti aparaḥ pañham puṭṭhaḥ katheti tamañño suṭṭhu te pañhaḥ kathitaḥ kattha
translated: The first, though he has asked the question according to the rules for asking it, becomes doubtful about it through the other’s statement: “Have I asked a question or not?”

original: te uggahito, pañhaṃ kathentena nāma evaṃ kathetabbo”ti vadati. Itaro kathetabbaniyāmeneva
analyzed: te uggahito pañham kathentena nāma evam kathetabbaḥ iti vadati itaro kathetabba niyāmena iva
translated: Another answers a question. The other says, “The question you have answered is well answered. Where did you learn it? When answering a question, one should answer it like this.”

original: pañhaṃ kathetvāpi tassa kathāya “apañho nu kho mayā kathito”ti vimatiṃ karoti.
analyzed: pañham kathetvā api tassa kathāya a pañhaḥ nu kho mayā kathitaḥ iti vimatim karoti
translated: The first, though he has answered the question according to the rules for answering it, becomes doubtful about it through the other’s statement: “Have I answered the question or not?”

original: Paṭipadāya na saṇṭhātīti paṭipattiyaṃ na tiṭṭhati, vattaṃ ajānitvā apucchitabbaṭṭhāne
analyzed: paṭipadāya na saṇṭhāti iti paṭipattiyam na tiṭṭhati vattam a jānitvā a pucchitabba ṭṭhāne
translated: “He does not settle down in the practice”: he does not stand firm in the practice. Without knowing the proper conduct, without asking, he does not do what should be done.

original: pucchatīti attho. Ayaṃ pañho nāma cetiyaṅgaṇe pucchitena na kathetabbo, tathā bhikkhācāramagge
analyzed: pucchati iti atthaḥ ayam pañho nāma cetiyaṅgaṇe pucchitena na kathetabbo tathā bhikkhācāra magge

analyzed: gāmam piṇḍāya caraṇa kāle āsana sālāya nisinna kāle yāgum vā bhattam vā gahetvā nisinna kāle
translated: nor while sitting and eating,🔽nor while going to the place for the day’s abiding,

analyzed: paribhuñjitvā nisinna kāle divāvihāra ṭṭhāna gamana kāle api divāṭṭhāne nisinna kāle pana

analyzed: okāsam kāretvā ava pucchantassa kathetabbo a kāretvā pucchantassa na kathetabbo idam  vattam a jānitvā pucchantaḥ paṭipadāya na saṇṭhāti nāma evam santā ayam bhikkhave
translated: But if he asks after making an opportunity, it may be discussed with him; if he asks without making an opportunity, it may not be discussed with him.🔽If he asks without knowing this rule, he is said not to be established in the way.🔽“If there is this reason, bhikkhus,

analyzed: ṭhāna aṭhāne saṇṭhāti iti sassata vādī yuttena kāraṇena pahoti uccheda vādim niggahetum
translated: “He is established in the right place” : the eternalist can refute the annihilationist with a proper reason,

analyzed: uccheda vādī tena niggayhamānaḥ api aham tayā satakkhattum niggayhamānaḥ api uccheda vādīyā iva ati
translated: and when he is being charged with the view of annihilation, he says, “I am being charged with the view of annihilation for the tenth time,”

analyzed: vadati iminā nayena sassata puggala suññata vāda ādīsu pi nayaḥ netabbaḥ evam ṭhāna aṭhāne
translated: and so on. The method should be extended in this way to the case of the person who holds the view of the eternity of self, to the case of the view of emptiness of the self, and so on. This is how he “keeps to the proper course in regard to the proper and the improper.”

original: saṇṭhāti nāma. Parikappe saṇṭhātīti “pañhaṃ pucchissāmī”ti kaṇṭhaṃ sodhento “tvaṃ🔽imaṃ nāma pucchissasī”ti vutte, “āma, etaṃyeva pucchissāmī”ti vadati. Pañhaṃ kathessāmīti
analyzed: saṇṭhāti nāma parikappe saṇṭhāti iti pañham pucchissāmi iti kaṇṭham sodhento tvam  imam nāma pucchissasi iti vutte āma etaṃyeva pucchissāmi iti vadati pañham kathessāmi iti
translated: “He keeps to the proper course in regard to the subject under discussion”: when he is asked, “I shall ask you a question,” he clears his throat and says, “Ask me.”🔽When he is told, “You will be asked this,” he says, “I shall answer.” When he is asked, “I shall answer you a question,”

analyzed: hanum saṃsodhentaḥ api tvam imam nāma kathessasi iti vutte āma etam yeva kathessāmi iti
translated: he clears his throat and says, “Ask me.” When he is told, “You will be asked this,” he says, “I shall answer.”

original: vadati. Evaṃ parikappe saṇṭhāti nāma.🔽Aññātavāde saṇṭhātīti imaṃ pañhaṃ pucchitvā “suṭṭhu te pañho pucchito, pucchantena
analyzed: vadati evam parikappe saṇṭhāti nāma  aññāta vāde saṇṭhāti iti imam pañham pucchitvā suṭṭhu te pañho pucchito pucchantena
translated: This is how he “keeps to the proper course in regard to the subject under discussion.”🔽“He keeps to the proper course in regard to the statement of the case”: when he is asked a question, he approves of the question, “Your question is well asked,” and he does not give rise to doubt. When he is asked, “I shall answer you a question,”

analyzed: nāma evam pucchitabban ti vutte sampaṭicchati vimatim na uppādeti pañham kathetvā api
translated: he clears his throat and says, “Ask me.” When he is told, “You will be asked this,” he says, “I shall answer.” When he is asked, “I shall answer you a question,”🔽he clears his throat and says, “Ask me.” When he is told, “You will be asked this,” he says, “I shall answer.”

analyzed: suṭṭhu te pañhaḥ kathitaḥ kathentena nāma evam kathetabbam ti vutte sampaṭicchati
translated: “Your question has been well answered. When one answers a question, one should answer it in this way,” he agrees,

translated: he sits down and asks his question while the meal is being served. He is well-disposed to the medicine:🔽he takes ghee, etc.,

analyzed: aṭṭhavidhāni pānakāni vattha chādana mālā gandha ādīni vā ādāya vihāram gantvā tāni da tvā
translated: the eight kinds of fermented rice grain, and the various kinds of cloth, garlands, perfumes, etc., to the monastery, gives them to the bhikkhus,

analyzed: divāṭṭhānam pavisitvā okāsam kāretvā pañham pucchati evam hi vattam ñatvā pucchantaḥ
translated: enters the day-quarters, asks for an opportunity , and asks his question. One who asks in this way

analyzed: paṭipadāya saṇṭhāti nāma tassa pañham kathetum vaṭṭati  aññena aññam paṭicarati iti aññena vacanena aññam paṭicchādeti aññam vā pucchitaḥ aññam
translated: is said to be well-disposed to the practice. It is proper to answer his question.🔽He evades the question by another: he covers up one thing by another, or when asked about one thing,

analyzed: kathā iti bahiddhā katham apanāmeti iti āgantuka katham purima katham bahiddhā
translated: he talks about something else. He diverts the discussion to an irrelevant subject: he introduces a different topic.

original: apanāmeti. Tatridaṃ vatthu – bhikkhū kira sannipatitvā ekaṃ daharaṃ, “āvuso, tvaṃ🔽imañcimañca āpattiṃ āpanno”ti āhaṃsu. So āha – “bhante, nāgadīpaṃ gatomhī”ti. Āvuso,🔽na mayaṃ tava nāgadīpagamanena atthikā, āpattiṃ pana āpannoti pucchāmāti. Bhante,🔽nāgadīpaṃ gantvā macche khādinti. Āvuso, tava macchakhādanena kammaṃ natthi, āpattiṃ
analyzed: apanāma iti tatra idam vatthu bhikkhū kira sannipatitvā ekam daharam āvuso tvam  āpattim āpannaḥ iti āhaṃsu saḥ āha bhante nāgadīpam gataḥ asmi iti āvuso  na mayam tava nāgadīpa gamanena atthikāḥ āpattim pana āpanno ti pucchāma ati bhante  nāga dīpam gantvā macche khādinti āvuso tava maccha khādanena kammam natthi āpattim
translated: He explains it thus: It seems that monks assembled and said to a certain young man, “Friend, you have fallen into such-and-such an offence.” He said, “Venerable sirs, I have been to the island of the nāgas.” They said, “Friend, we are not interested in your going to the island of the nāgas, but we ask whether you have fallen into an offence.” He said, “Venerable sirs, having gone to the island of the nāgas, I ate fish.” They said, “Friend, we are not interested in your eating fish, but we ask whether you have fallen into an offence.”

original: kirasi āpannoti. So “nātisupakko maccho mayhaṃ aphāsukamakāsi, bhante”ti. Āvuso,🔽tuyhaṃ phāsukena vā aphāsukena vā kammaṃ natthi, āpattiṃ āpannosīti. Bhante, yāva🔽tattha vasiṃ, tāva me aphāsukameva jātanti. Evaṃ āgantukakathāvasena bahiddhā kathaṃ🔽apanāmetīti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: kirasi āpannaḥ ti saḥ na ati su pakkaḥ macchaḥ mayham bhante iti āvuso  tuyham phāsukena vā a phāsukena vā kammam natthi āpattim āpanno si iti bhante yāva  tattha vasim tāva me a phāsukam eva evam āgantuka kathā vasena bahiddhā katham  apanāma iti iti veditabbam
translated: He diverts the talk is this. It seems that monks had met together and said to a certain young bhikkhu: “Friend, you have fallen into this and that offence.” He said: “Venerable sirs, I went to the Island of the Nāgas.” — “Friend, we are not concerned with your going to the Island of the Nāgas, but we ask whether you have fallen into an offence.” — “Venerable sirs, having gone to the Island of the Nāgas I ate fish.” — “Friend, we are not concerned with your eating fish, but we ask whether you have fallen into an offence.” — “The fish was not very good, venerable sirs, and it made me ill.” — “Friend, we are not concerned with whether you were comfortable or not, but we ask whether you have fallen into an offence.” — “Venerable sirs, as long as I stayed there I was ill all the time.” So he diverted the talk by talking about what happened on his travels. This is how he diverted the talk.

original: Abhiharatīti ito cito ca suttaṃ āharitvā avattharati. Tepiṭakatissatthero viya. Pubbe
analyzed: abhiharati iti itas citas ca suttam āharitvā avattharati tepiṭaka tissa theraḥ viya pubbe
