analyzed: maddati an upajagghati iti parena pañhe pucchite api kathite api pāṇim paharitvā mahāhasitam  hasati yena parassa a pucchitabbam nu kho pucchim a kathetabbam nu kho kathesinti  vimati uppajjati khalitam gaṇhāti iti appamattakam mukha dosa mattam gaṇhāti akkhare
translated: and harassing. He “did not follow” by slapping his hand and laughing loudly🔽when another asked a question or gave an answer, so that the other became unsure whether he should ask or not ask, whether he should answer or not answer. He “seized on what was irrelevant” by seizing on a mere fault in speech, and he went around grumbling, “This is not the way to say it,”

original: vā pade vā byañjane vā durutte “evaṃ nāmetaṃ vattabba”nti ujjhāyamāno vicarati. Saupanisoti
analyzed: vā pade vā byañjane vā durutte evam nāma etat vattabbanti ujjhāyamānaḥ vicarati sa aupanisaḥ ti
translated: if the other made a mistake in a syllable, a word, or a grammatical form. He “had a companion”

original: saupanissayo sapaccayo.
analyzed: sa upanissayaḥ sa paccayaḥ
translated: in the sense of having a supporter, having a reason.

original: Ohitasototi ṭhapitasoto. Abhijānāti ekaṃ dhammanti ekaṃ kusaladhammaṃ abhijānāti
analyzed: ohita soto ti ṭhapita soto abhijānāti ekam dhammam ti ekam kusala dhammam abhijānāti
translated: “With ear intent”: with ear applied. “He knows one idea”: he knows one profitable idea.

original: ariyamaggaṃ. Parijānāti ekaṃ dhammanti ekaṃ dukkhasaccadhammaṃ tīraṇapariññāya parijānāti.🔽Pajahati ekaṃ dhammanti ekaṃ sabbākusaladhammaṃ pajahati vinodeti byantīkaroti. Sacchikaroti
analyzed: ariya maggam parijānāti ekam dhammam ti ekam dukkha sacca dhammam tīraṇa pariññāya parijānāti  pajahati ekam dhammam ti ekam sabba akusala dhammam pajahati vinodeti byantīkaroti sacchikaroti
translated: “With ear-element given attention”: with ear-consciousness given attention. “He knows one idea”: he knows one profitable idea, namely, the Noble Path. “He comprehends one idea”: he comprehends one idea of the truth of suffering by the comprehending of seeing.

original: ekaṃ dhammanti ekaṃ arahattaphaladhammaṃ nirodhameva vā paccakkhaṃ karoti. Sammāvimuttiṃ
analyzed: ekam dhammam ti ekam arahatta phala dhammam nirodham eva vā paccakkham karoti sammāvimuttim
translated: “He abandons one idea”: he abandons one idea of all unprofitable ideas, he removes it, makes it no more. “He realizes one idea”: he realizes one idea of the fruit of arahantship or of cessation.

original: phusatīti sammā hetunā nayena kāraṇena arahattaphalavimokkhaṃ ñāṇaphassena phusati.
analyzed: phusati iti sammā hetunā nayena kāraṇena arahatta phala vimokkham ñāṇa phassena phusati
translated: “He contacts one idea with his body”: he contacts with the contact of the knowledge of the fruit of arahantship the deliverance of the fruit of arahantship.

original: Etadatthā, bhikkhave, kathāti, bhikkhave, yā esā kathāsampayogenāti kathā dassitā,
analyzed: etad atthā bhikkhave kathā ati bhikkhave yā esā kathā sampayogena ati kathā dassitā
translated: “This is the meaning of the talk on development”: the talk on development shown in the passage beginning, “Bhikkhus, there are four kinds of talk on development” ,

original: sā etadatthā, ayaṃ tassā kathāya bhūmi patiṭṭhā. Idaṃ vatthu yadidaṃ anupādā cittassa🔽vimokkhoti evaṃ sabbapadesu yojanā veditabbā. Etadatthā mantanāti yā ayaṃ kacchākacchesu
analyzed: sā etad atthā ayam tassā kathāya bhūmi idam vatthu yat idam anupādā cittassa 🔽vimokkho ti evam sabba padesu yojanā veditabbā etad atthā yā ayam kacchā kacchesu
translated: has this as its meaning, this is the plane, the footing, the province of that talk on development. The province of that talk on development is this: the deliverance of the mind by nonclinging.🔽“This is the meaning of the talk on questioning”: the talk on questioning shown in the passage beginning, “Bhikkhus, there are four kinds of talk on questioning” ,

original: puggalesu kacchena saddhiṃ mantanā, sāpi etadatthāyeva. Etadatthā upanisāti ohitasoto
analyzed: puggalesu kacchena saddhim mantanā sā api etad atthāya iva etad atthā ohita soto
translated: In the case of persons, the discussion with Kaccana is for the same purpose. The ‘means’ are stated in the phrase ‘with ear intent’

original: saupanisoti evaṃ vuttā upanisāpi etadatthāyeva. Etadatthaṃ sotāvadhānanti tassā upanisāya🔽sotāvadhānaṃ, tampi etadatthameva. Anupādāti catūhi upādānehi aggahetvā. Cittassa
analyzed: sa aupanisaḥ ti evam vuttā upanisā api etad atthāya iva etad attham sotāvadhānam ti tassāḥ upanisāya  sotāvadhānam tat pi etad attham eva catūhi upādānehi aggahetvā cittassa
translated: and the ‘means’ are for the same purpose. The ‘ear intent’🔽is for the same purpose. The ‘unclung-to’ is the liberation of mind

original: vimokkhoti arahattaphalavimokkho. Arahattaphalatthāya hi sabbametanti suttantaṃ vinivattetvā
analyzed: vimokkho ti arahatta phala vimokkhaḥ arahatta phala atthāya hi sabbam etat ti suttantam vinivattetvā
translated: by not grasping the four clingings. The ‘liberation of mind’ is the liberation of mind of the fruit of arahantship. For the purpose of the fruit of arahantship, the whole sutta is turned round

original: upari gāthāhi kūṭaṃ gaṇhanto ye viruddhātiādimāha.
analyzed: upari gāthāhi kūṭam gaṇhantaḥ ye viruddha ati ādim āha
translated: and the verse is taken as the peak. Taking the verse as the peak, he says ‘those who are opposed’ and so on.

original: Tattha viruddhāti virodhasaṅkhātena kopena viruddhā. Sallapantīti sallāpaṃ karonti.
analyzed: tattha viruddhā ati virodha saṅkhātena kopena viruddhā sallapanti iti sallāpam karonti
translated: Herein, ‘opposed’ means opposed by the anger called opposition. ‘They talk’ means they carry on a conversation.

original: Viniviṭṭhāti abhiniviṭṭhā hutvā. Samussitāti mānussayena suṭṭhu ussitā. Anariyaguṇamāsajjāti
analyzed: viniviṭṭhā ati abhiniviṭṭhā hutvā samussitā ati mā anussayena suṭṭhu ussitā anariya guṇam āsajja
translated: ‘Entrenched’ means entrenched in their views. ‘Exaltedly’ means exalted by conceit. ‘Clinging to the virtue and practices’

original: anariyaguṇakathaṃ guṇamāsajja kathenti. Guṇaṃ ghaṭṭetvā kathā hi anariyakathā nāma,
analyzed: an ariya guṇa katham guṇam āsajja kathenti guṇam ghaṭṭetvā kathā hi an ariya kathā nāma
translated: means they talk about the virtue and practices of the noble ones. Talk that is based on the noble ones’ virtues is called talk of the noble ones.

original: na ariyakathā, taṃ kathentīti attho. Aññoññavivaresinoti aññamaññassa chiddaṃ aparādhaṃ🔽gavesamānā. Dubbhāsitanti dukkathitaṃ. Vikkhalitanti appamattakaṃ mukhadosakhalitaṃ.
analyzed: na ariya kathā tam kathenti iti attho aññoñña vivaresino ti aññamaññassa chiddam aparādham  gavesamānāḥ dubbhāsitanti dukkathitam vikkhalitanti appamattakam mukha dosa khalitam
translated: “Not talk that is in conformity with the Dhamma”: the meaning is that he does not talk talk that is in conformity with the Dhamma.🔽“Seeking the faults of others”: seeking the other’s weakness, his transgression.🔽“Badly spoken”: badly said. “Slip of the tongue”: a slight verbal fault.

original: Sampamohaṃ parājayanti aññamaññassa appamattena mukhadosena sampamohañca parājayañca.
analyzed: sampamoham parājayanti aññamaññassa appamattena mukha dosena sampamoham ca parājayañca
translated: “Confusion and defeat”: confusion and defeat of the other through a slight verbal fault.

original: Abhinandantīti tussanti. Nācareti na carati na katheti. Dhammaṭṭhapaṭisaṃyuttāti
analyzed: abhinandanti iti tussanti na ācareti na carati na kathā iti dhamma ṭṭha paṭisaṃyuttā ati
translated: “Rejoicing”: being pleased. “Does not engage in”: does not engage in, does not talk. “In talk connected with the Dhamma”:

original: yā ca dhamme ṭhitena kathitakathā, sā dhammaṭṭhā ceva hoti tena ca dhammena paṭisaṃyuttāti
analyzed: yā ca dhamme ṭhitena kathita kathā sā dhammaṭṭhā ca iva hoti tena ca dhammena paṭisaṃyuttā ati
translated: talk that is spoken by one who is established in the Dhamma is connected with the Dhamma.🔽“With a mind that is not exalted”: with a mind that is not excited. “Without contempt”:

original: dhammaṭṭhapaṭisaṃyuttā. Anunnatena manasāti anuddhatena cetasā. Apaḷāsoti yugaggāhapaḷāsavasena
analyzed: dhamma aṭṭha paṭisaṃyuttā an unnatena manasā ati an uddhatena cetasā a paḷāsaḥ ti yugaggāha paḷāsa vasena
translated: without contempt through the contempt of taking sides.

original: apaḷāso hutvā. Asāhasoti rāgadosamohasāhasānaṃ vasena asāhaso hutvā.
analyzed: apaḷāsaḥ hutvā asāhasaḥ iti rāga dosa moha sāhasānam vasena asāhasaḥ hutvā
translated: “Without violence”: without violence through the violence of lust, hatred, and delusion.

original: Anusūyāyamānoti na usūyamāno. Dubbhaṭṭhe nāpasādayeti dukkathitasmiṃ na apasādeyya.
analyzed: anusūyāyamānaḥ iti na usūyamānaḥ dubbhaṭṭhe na apasādaya iti dukkathitasmin na apasādeyya
translated: “Without envy”: not being envious. “Does not dishearten one who speaks badly”: does not dishearten one who speaks badly.

original: Upārambhaṃ na sikkheyyāti kāraṇuttariyalakkhaṇaṃ upārambhaṃ na sikkheyya. Khalitañca
analyzed: upārambham na sikkheyya ati kāraṇa uttariya lakkhaṇam upārambham na sikkheyya khalitam ca
translated: He should not train in a quibble: he should not train in a quibble as a quibble, that is, he should not train in a quibble that has the characteristic of a quibble.

original: na gāhayeti appamattakaṃ mukhakhalitaṃ “ayaṃ te doso”ti na gāhayeyya. Nābhihareti🔽nāvatthareyya. Nābhimaddeti ekaṃ kāraṇaṃ āharitvā na maddeyya. Na vācaṃ payutaṃ bhaṇeti
analyzed: na gāhaya iti appamattakam mukha khalitam ayam te dosaḥ iti na gāhayeyya na abhihara iti  na avatthareyya na abhimaddeti ekam kāraṇam āharitvā na maddeyya na vācam payutam bhaṇa iti
translated: Nor should he seize on a slip of the tongue: he should not seize on a mere slip of the tongue, saying, “This is your fault.”🔽Nor should he overstep: he should not overstep a single reason.🔽Nor should he over-press: he should not over-press after he has brought up a single reason.🔽Nor should he speak with a hidden meaning: he should not speak with a meaning that is connected with a riddle.

original: saccālikapaṭisaṃyuttaṃ vācaṃ na bhaṇeyya. Aññātatthanti jānanatthaṃ. Pasādatthanti
analyzed: sacca alika paṭisaṃyuttam vācam na bhaṇeyya aññātattham ti jānanattham pasādattham ti
translated: For the sake of knowing: for the sake of knowing the meaning.🔽For the sake of confidence: for the sake of arousing confidence.

original: pasādajananatthaṃ. Na samusseyya mantayeti na mānussayena samussito bhaveyya. Na
analyzed: pasāda janana attham na samusseyya mantaya iti na mā anussayena samussitaḥ bhaveyya na
translated: He should not be over-haughty: he should not be over-haughty with conceit.

original: hi mānussitā hutvā paṇḍitā kathayanti, mānena pana anussitova hutvā mantaye katheyya bhāseyyāti.🔽8. Aññatitthiyasuttavaṇṇanā🔽69. Aṭṭhame bhagavaṃmūlakāti bhagavā mūlaṃ etesanti bhagavaṃmūlakā. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti
analyzed: hi mā anussitāḥ hutvā paṇḍitā kathayanti mānena pana anussitaḥ uva hutvā mantaye katheyya bhāseyya ati 🔽añña titthiya sutta vaṇṇanā 🔽aṭṭhame bhagavaṃmūlakā ati bhagavā mūlam etesan ti bhagavaṃmūlakā idam vuttam hoti
translated: For the wise do not speak when they are over-haughty with conceit. But he should speak when he is over-haughty with conceit after he has been over-haughty with conceit.

original: – ime, bhante, amhākaṃ dhammā pubbe kassapasammāsambuddhena uppāditā, tasmiṃ parinibbute
analyzed: ime bhante amhākam dhammā pubbe kassapa sammāsambuddhena uppāditā tasmin parinibbute
translated: “These ideas, venerable Sir, were formerly produced by the Perfect Sambuddha Kassapa, when he had attained Final Emancipation

original: ekaṃ buddhantaraṃ añño samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā ime dhamme uppādetuṃ samattho nāma nāhosi,🔽bhagavato pana no ime dhammā uppāditā. Bhagavantañhi nissāya mayaṃ ime dhamme ājānāma
analyzed: ekam buddha antaram añño samaṇaḥ vā brāhmaṇaḥ vā ime dhamme uppādetum samatthaḥ nāma na ahosi  bhagavataḥ pana no ime dhammāḥ uppāditāḥ bhagavantam hi nissāya mayam ime dhamme ājānāma
translated: for one period between two Buddhas there was no ascetic or Brahmin who was able to produce these ideas,🔽but these ideas have been produced by the Fortunate One. For we have understood these ideas, venerable Sir,🔽we have penetrated them, depending on the Fortunate One.

original: paṭivijjhāmāti evaṃ bhagavaṃmūlakā no, bhante, dhammāti. Bhagavaṃnettikāti bhagavā🔽dhammānaṃ netā vinetā anunetā yathāsabhāvato pāṭiyekkaṃ pāṭiyekkaṃ nāmaṃ gahetvāva
analyzed: paṭivijjhāma iti evam bhagavaṃmūlakāḥ no bhante dhammā ati bhagavaṃnettikā ati bhagavā  dhammānam netā vinetā anunetā yathā sabhāvataḥ pāṭiyekkam pāṭiyekkam nāmam gahetvā ava
translated: Thus, venerable Sir, these ideas have the Fortunate One as their root, the Fortunate One as their origin, the Fortunate One as their guide to the explanation. The Fortunate One is the forerunner of Dhamma,

original: dassetāti dhammā bhagavaṃnettikā nāma honti. Bhagavaṃpaṭisaraṇāti catubhūmakadhammā🔽sabbaññutaññāṇassa āpāthaṃ āgacchamānā bhagavati paṭisaranti nāmāti bhagavaṃpaṭisaraṇā.🔽Paṭisarantīti osaranti samosaranti. Apica mahābodhimaṇḍe nisinnassa bhagavato paṭivedhavasena
analyzed: dhammā bhagavaṃnettikāḥ nāma honti bhagavaṃpaṭisaraṇāḥ ati catu bhūmaka dhammāḥ 🔽sabbaññu ta ññāṇassa āpātham āgacchamānāḥ bhagavati paṭisaranti nāma ati bhagavaṃpaṭisaraṇā 🔽paṭisaranti iti osaranti samosaranti apica mahā bodhimaṇḍe nisinnassa bhagavato paṭivedha vasena
translated: the Fortunate One is the leader of Dhamma, the Fortunate One is the proclaimer of Dhamma, the Fortunate One is the expounder of Dhamma, the Fortunate One is the knower of Dhamma, the Fortunate One is the seer of Dhamma, the Fortunate One is the cleanser of Dhamma, the Fortunate One is the speaker about Dhamma, the Fortunate One is the one skilled in Dhamma, the Fortunate One is the one perfected in Dhamma, the Fortunate One is the one who has attained to Dhamma, the Fortunate One is the one who has confidence in Dhamma, the Fortunate One is the one who has delight in Dhamma, the Fortunate One is the one who has faith in Dhamma, the Fortunate One is the one who has love for Dhamma, the Fortunate One is the one who has devotion to Dhamma, the Fortunate One is the one who has reverence for Dhamma, the Fortunate One is the one who has respect for Dhamma, the Fortunate One is the one who has veneration for Dhamma, the Fortunate One is the one who has fear of Dhamma, the Fortunate One is the one who has trembling at Dhamma, the Fortunate One is the one who has respect for Dhamma, the Fortunate One is the one who has fear of Dhamma, the Fortunate One is the one who has trembling at Dhamma, the Fortunate One is the one who has respect for Dhamma, the Fortunate One is the one who has fear of Dhamma, the Fortunate One is the one who has trembling at Dhamma, the Fortunate One is the one who has respect for Dhamma, the Fortunate One is the one who has fear of Dhamma, the Fortunate One is the one who has trembling

original: phasso āgacchati – “ahaṃ bhagavā kinnāmo”ti. Tvaṃ phusanaṭṭhena phasso nāma. Vedanā,
analyzed: phassaḥ āgacchati aham bhagavā kinnāma uti tvam phusana ṭṭhena phassaḥ nāma vedanā
translated: Contact comes to him, “What is my name, Lord?” You are called “contact” in the sense of touching. Feeling,

original: saññā, saṅkhārā, viññāṇaṃ āgacchati – “ahaṃ bhagavā kinnāma”nti. Tvaṃ vijānanaṭṭhena
analyzed: saññā saṅkhārāḥ viññāṇam āgacchati aham bhagavā kinnāman ti tvam vijānana ṭṭhena
translated: perception, mental formations, and consciousness come to him, “What is my name, Lord?” You are called “consciousness” in the sense of cognizing.

original: viññāṇaṃ nāmāti. Evaṃ catubhūmakadhammānaṃ yathāsabhāvato pāṭiyekkaṃ pāṭiyekkaṃ nāmaṃ🔽gaṇhanto bhagavā dhamme paṭisaratīti bhagavaṃpaṭisaraṇā. Bhagavantaṃyeva paṭibhātūti
analyzed: viññāṇam nāma ati evam catu bhūmaka dhammānam yathā sabhāvataḥ pāṭiyekkam pāṭiyekkam nāmam  gaṇhantaḥ bhagavā dhamme paṭisarati iti bhagavaṃpaṭisaraṇā bhagavantam yā iva paṭibhātu uti
translated: Thus the Exalted One reflects on the dhammas by taking the individual names of the dhammas of the four planes in accordance with their individual natures.🔽Let the Exalted One explain it himself.

original: bhagavatova etassa bhāsitassa attho upaṭṭhātu, tumheyeva no kathetvā dethāti attho.🔽Rāgo khoti rajjanavasena pavattarāgo. Appasāvajjoti lokavajjavasenapi vipākavajjavasenapīti
analyzed: bhagavato va etassa bhāsitassa atthaḥ upaṭṭhātu no kathetvā detha ati attho  rāgaḥ khoti rajjana vasena pavatta rāgaḥ appasā vajjaḥ ti loka vajja vasena api vipāka vajja vasena api iti
translated: The meaning is: Let the meaning of what he has said occur to you yourselves, and then give it to me after you have discussed it among yourselves.🔽Lust is called “blameworthy” in the sense of defiling.

original: dvīhipi vajjehi appasāvajjo, appadosoti attho. Kathaṃ? Mātāpitaro hi bhātibhaginiādayo
analyzed: dvīhi pi vajjehi appasāvajjaḥ appa doso ti katham mātā pitaraḥ hi bhāti bhagini ādayaḥ
translated: Blameworthy in two ways: blameworthy in the world and blameworthy in the ripening. The meaning is: of little blame, of little fault. How? For parents and brothers and sisters

original: ca puttabhātikānaṃ āvāhavivāhamaṅgalaṃ nāma kārenti. Evaṃ tāveso lokavajjavasena
analyzed: ca putta bhātikānam āvāha vivāha maṅgalam nāma kārenti evam tāvesaḥ lokavat ja vasena
translated: make the auspicious ceremony of marriage for their sons and brothers. Thus they are blameworthy in the world.

original: appasāvajjo. Sadārasantosamūlikā pana apāye paṭisandhi nāma na hotīti evaṃ vipākavajjavasena
analyzed: pana apāye paṭisandhi nāma na hoti iti evam vipāka vat ja vasena
translated: and it is less blameworthy. But when it is rooted in the delight in a woman, it is not called rebirth-linking in the unhappy destinies. So it is less blameworthy in this way too.

original: appasāvajjo. Dandhavirāgīti virajjamāno panesa saṇikaṃ virajjati, na sīghaṃ muccati.
analyzed: appasāvajjaḥ dandha virāgī iti virajjamānaḥ pana esa saṇikam virajjati na sīgham muccati
translated: The “slow-to-deteriorate type” is one who, in the process of his deterioration, does so slowly, not quickly, and he is not easily released.

original: Telamasirāgo viya ciraṃ anubandhati, dve tīṇi bhavantarāni gantvāpi nāpagacchatīti dandhavirāgī.
analyzed: ciram anubandhati dve tīṇi bhavantarāni gantvā api na apagacchati iti dandha virāgī
translated: He is like a drop of oil on water, which spreads slowly and does not quickly disappear. He goes on for two or three existences, and so he is called “slow-to-deteriorate.”

original: Tatridaṃ vatthu – eko kira puriso bhātu jāyāya micchācāraṃ carati. Tassāpi itthiyā🔽attano sāmikato soyeva piyataro ahosi. Sā tamāha – “imasmiṃ kāraṇe pākaṭe jāte mahatī
analyzed: tatra idam vatthu ekaḥ kira purisaḥ bhātu jāyāya micchā ācāram carati tassa api itthiyā  attanaḥ sāmikato soyā iva piyataraḥ ahosi sā tam āha imasmin kāraṇe pākaṭe jāte mahatī
translated: Here is an illustration. A certain man had intercourse with his brother’s wife. The woman

original: garahā bhavissati, tava bhātikaṃ ghātehī”ti. So “nassa, vasali, mā evaṃ puna avacā”ti
analyzed: garahā bhavissati tava bhātikam ghātehi iti saḥ nassa vasali mā evam puna avacāti
translated: came to love him more than her own husband. She said to him, “If this matter becomes known, there will be a great scandal. You must kill your brother.” He said, “Good woman, do not speak so again.”

original: apasādesi. Sā tuṇhī hutvā katipāhaccayena puna kathesi, tassa cittaṃ dvajjhabhāvaṃ
analyzed: apasādesi sā tuṇhī hutvā kati pāhaccayena puna kathesi tassa cittam dvajjha bhāvam
translated: He reassured her. But after a few days she spoke again, and his mind became infected with hate.

original: agamāsi. Tato tatiyavāraṃ kathito “kinti katvā okāsaṃ labhissāmī”ti āha. Athassa
analyzed: agamāsi tatas tatiya vāram kathito kinti katvā okāsam labhissāmi iti āha athassa
translated: Then when she spoke a third time, he said, “What can I do to get an opportunity?”

original: sā upāyaṃ kathentī “tvaṃ mayā vuttameva karohi, asukaṭṭhāne mahākakudhasamīpe titthaṃ
analyzed: sā upāyam kathentī tvam mayā vuttam eva karohi asuka ṭṭhāne mahākakudha samīpe tittham
translated: She told him a trick, saying, “Do just as I tell you. Near such and such a place is a ford in the river.

original: atthi, tattha tikhiṇaṃ daṇḍakavāsiṃ gahetvā tiṭṭhāhī”ti. So tathā akāsi. Jeṭṭhabhātāpissa🔽araññe kammaṃ katvā gharaṃ āgato. Sā tasmiṃ muducittā viya hutvā “ehi sāmi, sīse
analyzed: atthi tattha tikhiṇam daṇḍaka vāsim gahetvā tiṭṭhāhi iti so tathā akāsi jeṭṭha bhātā apissa  araññe kammam katvā gharam āgataḥ sā tasmin mudu cittā viya hutvā ehi sāmi sīse
translated: Take a sharp knife and stand there.” He did as she told him. His elder brother🔽also had gone to the forest to work. She pretended to be very kind to him, saying, “Come, dear, I will anoint your head.”

original: te olikhissāmī”ti olikhantī “upakkiliṭṭhaṃ te sīsa”nti āmalakapiṇḍaṃ datvā “gaccha
analyzed: te olikhissāmi iti olikhantī upakkiliṭṭham te āmalaka piṇḍam da tvā gaccha
translated: As she anointed his head, she said, “Your head is dirty.” She gave him a lump of sour gruel and said, “Go and wash your head

original: asukaṭṭhāne sīsaṃ dhovitvā āgacchāhī”ti pesesi. So tāya vuttatitthameva gantvā āmalakakakkena
analyzed: asuka ṭṭhāne sīsam dhovitvā āgacchāhi iti pesesi saḥ tāya vutta tittham eva gantvā āmalaka kakkena
translated: at such and such a place and come back.” He went to the ford she had told him of, anointed his head with the sour gruel,

original: sīsaṃ makkhetvā udakaṃ oruyha onamitvā sīsaṃ dhovi. Atha naṃ itaro rukkhantarato🔽nikkhamitvā khandhaṭṭhike paharitvā jīvitā voropetvā gehaṃ agamāsi.
analyzed: sīsam makkhetvā udakam oruyha onamitvā sīsam dhovi atha nam itaraḥ rukkhantarataḥ  nikkhamitvā khandhaṭṭhike paharitvā jīvitā voropetvā geham agamāsi
translated: and went into the water to wash his head. As he bent over, his younger brother🔽came out from behind a tree, struck him on the back of the neck, and killed him. Then he went home.

original: Itaro bhariyāya sinehaṃ pariccajitumasakkonto tasmiṃyeva gehe mahādhammani hutvā
analyzed: itaraḥ bhariyāya sineham pariccajitum a sakkontaḥ tasmin yeva gehe mahā dhammani hutvā
translated: The elder brother was unable to give up his affection for his wife. He remained in the house and died of a broken heart.

original: nibbatti. So tassā ṭhitāyapi nisinnāyapi gantvā sarīre patati. Atha naṃ sā “soyeva
analyzed: nibbatti saḥ tassā ṭhitāya api nisinnāya api gantvā sarīre patati atha nam sā soyā iva
translated: and it fell on her body whether she was standing, sitting, or walking. Then she said,

original: ayaṃ bhavissatī”ti ghātāpesi. So puna tassā sinehena tasmiṃyeva gehe kukkuro hutvā🔽nibbatti. So padasā gamanakālato paṭṭhāya tassā pacchato pacchato carati. Araññaṃ
analyzed: ayam bhavissati iti ghātāpesi saḥ puna tassā sinehena tasmiṃ yeva gehe kukkuraḥ hutvā  nibbatti so padasā gamana kālataḥ paṭṭhāya tassā pacchatas pacchatas carati araññam
translated: and he was born as her son. Whether she stood or sat, he went and fell on her body. She thought, “This must be the same one,” and had him killed. Out of love for her, he was again born as her dog in the same house.

original: gacchantiyāpi saddhiṃyeva gacchati. Taṃ disvā manussā “nikkhanto sunakhaluddako,
analyzed: gacchantiyā api saddhiṃyā iva gacchati tam disvā manussāḥ nikkhantaḥ su nakha luddakaḥ
translated: From the time he could walk, he followed her about. When she went to the forest, he went with her. Seeing him, people teased her, saying, “The dog-hunter has come out.

original: kataraṭṭhānaṃ gamissatī”ti uppaṇḍenti. Sā puna taṃ ghātāpesi.🔽Sopi puna tasmiṃyeva gehe vacchako hutvā nibbatti. Tatheva tassā pacchato pacchato
analyzed: katara ṭṭhānam gamissati iti uppaṇḍenti sā puna tam ghātāpesi  saḥ api puna tasmiṃyeva gehe vacchakaḥ hutvā nibbatti tathā iva tassā pacchatas pacchatas
translated: Where will he go?” She had him killed again.

original: carati. Tadāpi naṃ manussā disvā “nikkhanto gopālako, kattha gāviyo carissantī”ti
analyzed: carati tadā api nam manussāḥ disvā nikkhantaḥ gopālako kattha gāviyaḥ carissanti iti
translated: He was again born as her calf in the same house. He followed her about as before. People saw him and teased her as before.🔽She had him killed in the same place.

original: uppaṇḍenti. Sā tasmimpi ṭhāne taṃ ghātāpesi. So tadāpi tassā upari sinehaṃ chindituṃ
analyzed: uppaṇḍenti sā tasmim pi ṭhāne tam saḥ tadā api tassāḥ upari sineham chinditum
translated: He was again born as her son in the same house. She loved him dearly. He was a very handsome boy.

original: asakkonto catutthe vāre tassāyeva kucchiyaṃ jātissaro hutvā nibbatti. So paṭipāṭiyā
analyzed: a sakkonto catutthe vāre tassāya eva kucchiyam jātissaraḥ hutvā nibbatti so paṭipāṭiyā
translated: Unable to do so, he was reborn in his mother’s womb in the fourth month, as a result of his own kamma. He was reborn in the same way in four successive months.

original: catūsu attabhāvesu tāya ghātitabhāvaṃ disvā “evarūpāya nāma paccatthikāya kucchismiṃ
analyzed: catūsu attabhāvesu tāya ghātita bhāvam disvā evarūpāya nāma paccatthikāya kucchismiṃ
translated: Seeing that he was to be killed by her in each of these four existences, he thought, “I have been reborn in the womb of such a deadly enemy.”

original: nibbattosmī”ti tato paṭṭhāya tassā hatthena attānaṃ phusituṃ na deti. Sace naṃ sā
analyzed: nibbattaḥ asmi iti tatas paṭṭhāya tassāḥ hatthena attānam phusitum na deti sace nam sā
translated: From that time on he would not let her touch him with her hand. If she did touch him,

original: phusati, kandati rodati. Atha naṃ ayyakova paṭijaggati. Taṃ aparabhāge vuddhippattaṃ
analyzed: phusati kandati rodati atha nam ayyakā uva paṭijaggati tam aparabhāge vuddhi ppattam
translated: he would cry and weep. Then his uncle would take care of him. Later, when he had grown up,

original: ayyako āha – “tāta, kasmā tvaṃ mātu hatthena attānaṃ phusituṃ na desi. Sacepi taṃ
analyzed: ayyakaḥ āha tāta kasmā tvam mātu hatthena attānam phusitum na desi sace pi tam
translated: his uncle said to him, “Dear, why won’t you let your mother touch you? If she does touch you,

original: phusati, mahāsaddena rodasi kandasī”ti. Ayyakena puṭṭho “na esā mayhaṃ mātā, paccāmittā🔽esā”ti taṃ pavattiṃ sabbaṃ ārocesi. So taṃ āliṅgitvā roditvā “ehi, tāta, kiṃ amhākaṃ
analyzed: phusati mahā saddena rodasi kandasi iti ayyakena puṭṭhaḥ na esā mayham mātā pacca amittā  esā ati tam pavattim sabbam ārocesi saḥ tam āliṅgitvā roditvā ehi tāta kim amhākam
translated: you cry and weep with a loud voice.” When asked by his uncle, he told him the whole story, “She is not my mother, she is my deadly enemy.”

original: īdise ṭhāne nivāsakicca”nti taṃ ādāya nikkhamitvā ekaṃ vihāraṃ gantvā pabbajitvā
analyzed: īdise ṭhāne nivāsa kiccanti tam ādāya nikkhamitvā ekam vihāram gantvā pabbajitvā
translated: He embraced him, wept, and said, “Come, dear, what is the use of our living in such a place?” Taking him with him, he left and went to a monastery, where he became a monk.

original: ubhopi tattha vasantā arahattaṃ pāpuṇiṃsu.
analyzed: ubho api tattha vasantā arahattam pāpuṇiṃsu
translated: and they both reached Arahantship while living there.

original: Mahāsāvajjoti lokavajjavasenapi vipākavajjavasenapīti dvīhipi kāraṇehi mahāsāvajjo.
analyzed: mahā sāvajjaḥ iti vipāka vat ja vasena api iti dvīhi pi kāraṇehi
translated: It is a grave offence in two ways, that is to say, as a worldly offence and as an offence entailing an unpleasant result.

original: Kathaṃ? Dosena hi duṭṭho hutvā mātaripi aparajjhati, pitaripi bhātibhaginiādīsupi
analyzed: katham dosena hi duṭṭhaḥ hutvā mātaripi aparajjhati pitaripi bhāti bhagini ādīsu pi
translated: How so? For when a man is corrupted by hate he transgresses against his mother and father, and against his brother and sister and the rest,

original: pabbajitesupi. So gatagataṭṭhānesu “ayaṃ puggalo mātāpitūsupi aparajjhati, bhātibhaginiādīsupi,
analyzed: pabbajitesu pi saḥ gata gata ṭṭhānesu ayam puggalaḥ mātā pitūsu pi aparajjhati bhāti bhagini ādīsu pi
translated: and against those gone forth into homelessness. And wherever he goes he gets a bad reputation: ‘This person transgresses against his mother and father and against his brother and sister and the rest,

original: pabbajitesupī”ti mahatiṃ garahaṃ labhati. Evaṃ tāva lokavajjavasena mahāsāvajjo.🔽Dosavasena pana katena ānantariyakammena kappaṃ niraye paccati. Evaṃ vipākavajjavasena
analyzed: pabbajitesu pi iti mahatim garaham labhati evam tāva lokavajja vasena mahāsāvajjaḥ  dosa vasena pana katena ānantariya kammena kappam niraye paccati evam vipāka vajja vasena
translated: and against those gone forth into homelessness.’ So it is a grave offence in the worldly sense.🔽And as a result of the action of killing one’s mother, which is done out of hate, one is tormented in hell for an aeon. So it is a grave offence in the sense of the unpleasantness of its result.

original: mahāsāvajjo. Khippavirāgīti khippaṃ virajjati. Dosena hi duṭṭho mātāpitūsupi cetiyepi
analyzed: mahāsā vajjaḥ khippa virāgī iti khippam virajjati dosena hi duṭṭhaḥ cetiye pi
translated: It is a quick-ripener: it ripens quickly. For when a man is corrupted by hate he transgresses against his mother and father, and against the shrine and the Bodhi Tree,

original: bodhimhipi pabbajitesupi aparajjhitvā “mayhaṃ khamathā”ti. Accayaṃ deseti. Tassa
analyzed: bodhimhi pi pabbajitesu pi aparajjhitvā mayham khamatha ati accayam deseti tassa
translated: and against those gone forth into homelessness. And he confesses the transgression, saying, ‘Forgive me.’

original: saha khamāpanena taṃ kammaṃ pākatikameva hoti.
analyzed: saha khamāpanena tam kammam pākatikam eva hoti
translated: And with the forgiveness

original: Mohopi dvīheva kāraṇehi mahāsāvajjo. Mohena hi mūḷho hutvā mātāpitūsupi cetiyepi
analyzed: mohaḥ api dvīhā iva kāraṇehi mahāsaḥ avajjaḥ mohena hi mūḍhaḥ hutvā cetiye pi
translated: Delusion is also very blamable for two reasons. For when a man is deluded by delusion, he kills even his mother and father and even a shrine,

original: bodhimhipi pabbajitesupi aparajjhitvā gatagataṭṭhāne garahaṃ labhati. Evaṃ tāva lokavajjavasena
analyzed: bodhimhi pi pabbajitesu pi aparajjhitvā gata gata ṭṭhāne garaham labhati evam tāva lokavat ja vasena
translated: Delusion is also very blamable for two reasons. For when a person is deluded by delusion, he is not afraid of his parents, of shrines, of the Enlightened One, of the True Idea, of the Community, of recluses, or of brahmans, and he goes about doing harm wherever he goes. So it is very blamable in this way too, that is,🔽as a breach of the world’s conventions.

original: mahāsāvajjo. Mohavasena pana katena ānantariyakammena kappaṃ niraye paccati. Evaṃ🔽vipākavajjavasenapi mahāsāvajjo. Dandhavirāgīti saṇikaṃ virajjati. Mohena mūḷhena🔽hi katakammaṃ saṇikaṃ muccati. Yathā hi acchacammaṃ satakkhattumpi dhoviyamānaṃ na
analyzed: mahā sāvajjaḥ moha vasena pana katena ānantariya kammena kappam niraye paccati evam  vipāka vat javasena api dandha virāgī iti saṇikam virajjati mohena mūḍhena  hi kata kammam saṇikam muccati yathā hi accha cammam sata kkhattum pi dhoviyamānam na
translated: But also, when a person has done a heinous kamma through delusion, he is reborn in hell for an aeon. So it is very blamable🔽as a breach of ripening.

original: paṇḍaraṃ hoti, evameva mohena mūḷhena katakammaṃ sīghaṃ na muccati, saṇikameva muccatīti.
analyzed: paṇḍaram hoti evam eva mohena mūḷhena kata kammam sīgham na muccati saṇikam eva muccati iti
translated: He is a slow-to-change type of faith-liberated person: he changes slowly. For kamma done by a person deluded by delusion is slow to be cleared away. Just as a white cloth is slow to be dyed when it is thick, so too kamma done by a person deluded by delusion is slow to be cleared away; it is only slowly that it is cleared away.

original: Sesamettha uttānamevāti.🔽9. Akusalamūlasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: sesam ettha uttānam eva ati  akusala mūla sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The rest here is self-explanatory.🔽The explanation of the Triad of the Roots of Unprofitable Action is ended.

original: 70. Navame akusalamūlānīti akusalānaṃ mūlāni, akusalāni ca tāni mūlāni cāti vā akusalamūlāni.
analyzed: navame akusala mūlāni iti mūlāni akusalāni ca tāni mūlāni ca ati vā akusala mūlāni
translated: In the ninth, the roots of unprofit are the roots of the unprofitable, or they are the unprofitable and roots.

original: Yadapi, bhikkhave, lobhoti yopi, bhikkhave, lobho. Tadapi akusalamūlanti sopi akusalamūlaṃ.
analyzed: yat api bhikkhave lobho ti yaḥ api bhikkhave lobho tat api akusala mūlan ti saḥ api akusala mūlam
translated: “Whatever is a root of unprofit” : whatever is greed, etc., is a root of unprofit.🔽Or the meaning of “that” can be taken as referring to the root of unprofit.

original: Akusalamūlaṃ vā sandhāya idha tampīti attho vaṭṭatiyeva. Etenupāyena sabbattha nayo🔽netabbo. Abhisaṅkharotīti āyūhati sampiṇḍeti rāsiṃ karoti. Asatā dukkhaṃ uppādayatīti
analyzed: akusala mūlam vā sandhāya idha tam pi iti atthaḥ vaṭṭatiyā iva etena upāyena sabbattha nayaḥ  netabbaḥ abhisaṅkharoti iti āyūhati sampiṇḍeti rāsim karoti asatā dukkham uppādayati iti
translated: The method should be understood in this way in all instances.🔽“He instigates” : he makes an effort, he combines, he makes a heap.

original: abhūtena avijjamānena yaṃkiñci tassa abhūtaṃ dosaṃ vatvā dukkhaṃ uppādeti. Vadhena
analyzed: abhūtena a vijjamānena yaṃkiñci tassa abhūtam dosam vatvā dukkham uppādeti vadhena
translated: “He causes suffering to arise in the innocent” : having stated some non-existent, unreal fault of his, he causes suffering to arise in him.🔽“By killing” , etc., is said to show the way in which he causes suffering to arise.

original: vātiādi yenākārena dukkhaṃ uppādeti, taṃ dassetuṃ vuttaṃ. Tattha jāniyāti dhanajāniyā.
analyzed: vā ti ādi yena ākārena dukkham uppādeti tam dassetum vuttam tattha jāniyā ti dhana jāniyā
translated: “By a fine” : by a fine of a monetary penalty.

original: Pabbājanāyāti gāmato vā raṭṭhato vā pabbājanīyakammena. Balavamhīti ahamasmi balavā.
analyzed: pabbājanāya ati gāmataḥ vā raṭṭhataḥ vā pabbājanīya kammena balavamhi iti aham asmi balavā
translated: “By banishment” : by the act of banishing him from the village or the country.

original: Balattho itipīti balena me attho itipi, bale vā ṭhitomhītipi vadati.
analyzed: balatthaḥ itipi iti balena me atthaḥ itipi bale vā ṭhitaḥ asmi itipi vadati
translated: “I am powerful” : he says “I have need of power” or “I stand on power” .🔽“He speaks at the wrong time” : he does not speak at the right time, he speaks at the wrong time.

original: Akālavādīti kālasmiṃ na vadati, akālasmiṃ vadati nāma. Abhūtavādīti bhūtaṃ na vadati,
analyzed: akāla vādī iti kālasmin na vadati akālasmin vadati nāma abhūta vādī iti bhūtam na vadati
translated: “He speaks what is not fact” : he does not speak what is fact,

original: abhūtaṃ vadati nāma. Anatthavādīti atthaṃ na vadati, anatthaṃ vadati nāma. Adhammavādīti
analyzed: abhūtam vadati nāma anattha vādī iti attham na vadati anattham vadati nāma adhamma vādī iti
translated: He speaks what is not fact: he does not speak fact, he speaks what is not fact. He speaks what is not beneficial: he does not speak what is beneficial, he speaks what is not beneficial. He speaks what is not Dhamma:

original: dhammaṃ na vadati, adhammaṃ vadati nāma. Avinayavādīti vinayaṃ na vadati, avinayaṃ vadati nāma.🔽Tathā hāyanti tathā hi ayaṃ. Na ātappaṃ karoti tassa nibbeṭhanāyāti tassa abhūtassa
analyzed: dhammam na vadati adhammam vadati nāma avinaya vādī iti vinayam na vadati avinayam vadati nāma  tathā ha āyanti tathā hi ayam na ātappam karoti tassa nibbeṭhanāya ati tassa abhūtassa
translated: he does not speak Dhamma, he speaks what is not Dhamma. He speaks what is not Discipline: he does not speak Discipline, he speaks what is not Discipline.🔽Thus they are lost: thus this is lost. He does not make an effort to free himself: he does not make an effort to free himself from what is not fact.

original: nibbeṭhanatthāya vīriyaṃ na karoti. Itipetaṃ atacchanti imināpi kāraṇena etaṃ atacchaṃ.
analyzed: nibbeṭhana tthāya vīriyam na karoti iti petam atacchanti iminā api kāraṇena etam ataccham
translated: Thus it is unture: for this reason it is unture.

original: Itaraṃ tasseva vevacanaṃ.
analyzed: itaram vevacanam
translated: The other is a synonym for that.

original: Duggati pāṭikaṅkhāti nirayādikā duggati icchitabbā, sā assa avassabhāvinī, tatthānena
analyzed: duggati pāṭikaṅkhā ati niraya ādikā duggati icchitabbā sā assa avassa bhāvinī tattha anena
translated: He can expect a bad destination: he can expect a bad destination such as hell, etc., it is certain that he will be reborn there.

original: nibbattitabbanti attho. Uddhastoti upari dhaṃsito. Pariyonaddhoti samantā onaddho.
analyzed: nibbattitabbanti attho uddhastaḥ ti upari dhaṃsito pariyonaddhaḥ ti samantā onaddhaḥ
translated: He is agitated: he is struck down above. He is overwhelmed: he is overwhelmed all round.

original: Anayaṃ āpajjatīti avuḍḍhiṃ āpajjati. Byasanaṃ āpajjatīti vināsaṃ āpajjati. Gimhakālasmiñhi
analyzed: anayam āpajjati iti avuḍḍhim āpajjati byasanam āpajjati iti vināsam āpajjati gimha kālasmin hi
translated: He falls into misfortune: he falls into non-prosperity. He falls into destruction: he falls into ruin. For in the hot season

original: māluvāsipāṭikāya phalitāya bījāni uppatitvā vaṭarukkhādīnaṃ mūle patanti. Tattha🔽yassa rukkhassa mūle tīsu disāsu tīṇi bījāni patitāni honti, tasmiṃ rukkhe pāvussakena
analyzed: māluvāsi pāṭikāya phalitāya bījāni uppatitvā vaṭa rukkha ādīnam mūle patanti tattha  yassa rukkhassa mūle tīsu disāsu tīṇi bījāni patitāni honti tasmin rukkhe pāvussakena
translated: When the creeper has fruited, the seeds fall to the ground at the foot of the trees.🔽Then, when the rains come, the three seeds that have fallen at the foot of a tree

original: meghena abhivaṭṭhe tīhi bījehi tayo aṅkurā uṭṭhahitvā taṃ rukkhaṃ allīyanti. Tato
analyzed: meghena abhivaṭṭhe tīhi bījehi tayo aṅkurāḥ uṭṭhahitvā tam rukkham allīyanti tatas
translated: sprout and twine around the tree.

original: paṭṭhāya rukkhadevatāyo sakabhāvena saṇṭhātuṃ na sakkonti. Tepi aṅkurā vaḍḍhamānā🔽latābhāvaṃ āpajjitvā taṃ rukkhaṃ abhiruhitvā sabbaviṭapasākhāpasākhā saṃsibbitvā
analyzed: paṭṭhāya rukkha devatāyo saka bhāvena saṇṭhātum na sakkonti te pi aṅkurāḥ vaḍḍhamānā  latā bhāvam āpajjitvā tam rukkham abhiruhitvā sabba viṭa pasākhā pasākhā saṃsibbitvā
translated: From then on the tree-deities are unable to live there in their former state.🔽As the creeper grows, it becomes a vine, and it climbs the tree,🔽enveloping it with its tendrils and creepers.

original: taṃ rukkhaṃ upari pariyonandhanti. So māluvālatāhi saṃsibbito ghanehi mahantehi māluvāpattehi
analyzed: tam rukkham upari pariyonandhanti saḥ māluvā latāhi saṃsibbitaḥ ghanehi mahantehi māluvā pattehi
translated: Covered with the creeper, with its thick, large leaves,

original: sañchanno deve vā vassante vāte vā vāyante tattha tattha palujjitvā khāṇumattameva
analyzed: sañchannaḥ deve vā vassante vāte vā vāyante tattha tattha palujjitvā khāṇu mattam eva
translated: when it rains or the wind blows, the tree is damaged here and there, and only the stump

original: avasissati. Taṃ sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ.
analyzed: avasissati tam sandhāya itam vuttam
translated: remains. This is what is meant.

original: Evameva khoti ettha pana idaṃ opammasaṃsandanaṃ – sālādīsu aññatararukkho viya hi
analyzed: evam eva kho ti ettha pana idam opamma saṃsandanam sāla ādīsu aññatara rukkhaḥ viya hi
translated: So too, the being should be regarded as any one of the trees, sāla, etc.,

original: ayaṃ satto daṭṭhabbo, tisso māluvālatā viya tīṇi akusalamūlāni, yāva rukkhasākhā🔽asampattā, tāva tāsaṃ latānaṃ ujukaṃ rukkhārohanaṃ viya lobhādīnaṃ dvāraṃ asampattakālo,
analyzed: ayam satto daṭṭhabbo tissaḥ māluvāla tāḥ viya tīṇi akusala mūlāni yāva rukkha sākhā  a sampattā tāva tāsam latānam ujukam rukkha ārohanam viya lobha ādīnam dvāram a sampatta kālo
translated: The three roots of unprofit as the three māluva creepers.🔽The time before the creepers reach the tree-top is like the time before the greed, etc., reach the doors.

original: sākhānusārena gamanakālo viya dvāravasena gamanakālo, pariyonaddhakālo viya lobhādīhi🔽pariyuṭṭhitakālo, khuddakasākhānaṃ palujjanakālo viya dvārappattānaṃ kilesānaṃ vasena
analyzed: sākhā anusārena gamana kālaḥ dvāra vasena gamana kālaḥ pariyonaddha kālaḥ  pariyuṭṭhita kālaḥ khuddaka sākhānam palujjana kālaḥ viya dvāra ppattānam kilesānam vasena
translated: The time when they go along following the branches is like the time when they go along by way of the doors.🔽The time when they envelop is like the time when they are surrounded by greed, etc.🔽The time when the small branches break is like the time when the minor and very minor offences are committed by way of the defilements that have reached the doors.

original: khuddānukhuddakā āpattiyo āpannakālo, mahāsākhānaṃ palujjanakālo viya garukāpattiṃ🔽āpannakālo, latānusārena otiṇṇena udakena mūlesu tintesu rukkhassa bhūmiyaṃ patanakālo
analyzed: khuddānukhuddakāḥ āpattiyaḥ āpanna kālaḥ mahā sākhānam palujjana kālaḥ viya garuka āpattim  āpanna kālaḥ latā anusārena otiṇṇena udakena mūlesu tintesu rukkhassa bhūmiyam patana kālaḥ
translated: The time when the big branches break is like the time when a grave offence is committed.

original: viya kamena cattāri pārājikāni āpajjitvā catūsu apāyesu nibbattanakālo daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: viya kamena cattāri pārājikāni āpajjitvā catūsu apāyesu nibbattana kālaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: The time when the tree falls to the ground with the water soaking the roots and following the creepers is like the time when, after committing the four offences entailing expulsion in due course, the being is reborn in the four states of deprivation.

original: Sukkapakkho vuttavipallāsena veditabbo. Evameva khoti ettha pana idaṃ opammasaṃsandanaṃ
analyzed: sukka pakkhaḥ vutta vipallāsena veditabbaḥ evam eva kho ti ettha pana idam opamma saṃsandanam
translated: Here is the correspondence of the similes:

original: – sālādīsu aññatararukkho viya ayaṃ satto daṭṭhabbo, tisso māluvālatā viya tīṇi akusalamūlāni,
analyzed: sāla ādīsu aññatara rukkhaḥ viya ayam satto daṭṭhabbo tissaḥ māluvāla tāḥ viya tīṇi akusala mūlāni
translated: This being should be regarded as a tree such as a sala; the three roots of unprofit as the three creepers;

original: tāsaṃ appavattiṃ kātuṃ āgatapuriso viya yogāvacaro, kuddālo viya paññā, kuddālapiṭakaṃ🔽viya saddhāpiṭakaṃ, palikhananakhaṇitti viya vipassanāpaññā, khaṇittiyā mūlacchedanaṃ
analyzed: tāsam appavattim kātum āgata puriso viya yogāvacaraḥ kuddālaḥ viya paññā kuddāla piṭakam  viya saddhā piṭakam palikhanana khaṇitti viya vipassanā paññā khaṇittiyā mūla chedanam
translated: the meditator who has come to stop their growth as the man; wisdom as the spade;🔽the basket of faith as the basket;🔽insight as the digging; the time of cutting the root of ignorance with the knowledge of insight as the time of cutting the creeper’s root with the spade;

original: viya vipassanāñāṇena avijjāmūlassa chindanakālo, khaṇḍākhaṇḍikaṃ chindanakālo viya
analyzed: viya vipassanā ñāṇena avijjā mūlassa chindana kālo khaṇḍākhaṇḍikam chindana kālaḥ viya
translated: the time of seeing the aggregates as the time of cutting it up into pieces;🔽the time of uprooting defilements with path knowledge as the time of splitting it up;

original: khandhavasena diṭṭhakālo, phālanakālo viya maggañāṇena kilesānaṃ samugghātitakālo,
analyzed: khandha vasena diṭṭha kālo phālana kālo viya magga ñāṇena kilesānam samugghātita kālo
translated: the time of the five aggregates still persisting as the time of making a heap of the pieces;

original: masikaraṇakālo viya dharamānakapañcakkhandhakālo, mahāvāte opuṇitvā appavattanakālo
analyzed: masi karaṇa kālaḥ viya dharamānaka pañcakkhandha kālaḥ mahāvāte opuṇitvā appavattana kālaḥ
translated: the time of their non-occurrence after being winnowed by the great wind as the time of the pieces being carried off by the water.

original: viya upādinnakakkhandhānaṃ appaṭisandhikanirodhena nirujjhitvā punabbhave paṭisandhiaggahaṇakālo
analyzed: viya upādinnaka khandhānam appaṭisandhika nirodhena nirujjhitvā punabbhave paṭisandhi aggahaṇa kālaḥ
translated: as the cessation of the aggregates that have been taken up, and the time of the arising of the rebirth-linking consciousness in the next existence should be seen as the arising of the aggregates that have not been taken up.

original: daṭṭhabboti. Imasmiṃ sutte vaṭṭavivaṭṭaṃ kathitaṃ.
analyzed: daṭṭhabbā iti imasmim sutte vaṭṭa vivaṭṭam kathitam
translated: In this sutta the round and the reversal of the round are taught.

original: 10. Uposathasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: uposatha sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . The explanation of the tenth sutta

original: 71. Dasame tadahuposatheti tasmiṃ ahu uposathe taṃ divasaṃ uposathe, pannarasikauposathadivaseti
analyzed: dasame tad ahu uposatha iti tasmin ahu uposathe tam divasam uposathe pannarasika auposatha divasa iti
translated: On that Observance day: on that Observance day, on that day of Observance, on the Observance day of the fifteenth.

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Upasaṅkamīti uposathaṅgāni adhiṭṭhāya gandhamālādihatthā upasaṅkami.
analyzed: vuttam hoti upasaṅkami iti uposathaṅgāni adhiṭṭhāya gandha mālā ādi hatthā upasaṅkami
translated: He approached: having resolved on the Observance factors, he approached with his hands filled with perfumes, garlands, etc.🔽Hand: the indeclinable hand is in the sense of “I give myself up.”

original: Handāti vavassaggatthe nipāto. Divā divassāti divasassa divā nāma majjhanho, imasmiṃ
analyzed: handa iti vavassagga atthe nipātaḥ divā divassā ati divasassa divā nāma majjhanhaḥ imasmin
translated: Day by day: the day of the day is midday; the meaning is, “in this standing, at midday.”

original: ṭhite majjhanhike kāleti attho. Kuto nu tvaṃ āgacchasīti kiṃ karontī vicarasīti pucchati.🔽Gopālakuposathoti gopālakehi saddhiṃ upavasanauposatho. Nigaṇṭhuposathoti nigaṇṭhānaṃ
analyzed: ṭhite majjhanhike kāleti attho kutas nu tvam āgacchasi iti kim karontī vicarasi iti pucchati  gopālaka uposathaḥ iti gopālakehi saddhim upavasana uposathaḥ nigaṇṭha uposathaḥ iti nigaṇṭhānam
translated: Where do you come from? he asks, “What are you doing?”🔽The cowherds’ Observance: the Observance kept together with the cowherds. The Observance of the Nigaṇṭhas: the Observance kept by the Nigaṇṭhas.

original: upavasanauposatho. Ariyuposathoti ariyānaṃ upavasanauposatho. Seyyathāpi visākheti
analyzed: upavasana auposathaḥ ariyuposathaḥ iti ariyānam upavasana auposathaḥ sā iyyathā api visākhā iti
translated: The Noble Ones’ Observance: the Observance kept by the Noble Ones. Just as, Visākhā:

original: yathā nāma, visākhe. Sāyanhasamaye sāmikānaṃ gāvo niyyātetvāti gopālakā hi devasikavetanena
analyzed: yathā nāma visākhe sāyanha samaye gāvaḥ gopālakāḥ hi devasika vetanena
translated: For cowherds take the cows in charge for a day’s wage,

original: vā pañcāhadasāhaaddhamāsamāsachamāsasaṃvaccharaparicchedena vā gāvo gahetvā rakkhanti.
analyzed: vā pañca aha dasa aha addha māsa māsa cha māsa saṃvacchara paricchedena vā gāvaḥ gahetvā rakkhanti
translated: or for five days, or for a fortnight, or for a month, or for a year.

original: Idha pana devasikavetanena rakkhantaṃ sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ – niyyātetvāti paṭicchāpetvā
analyzed: idha pana devasika vetanena rakkhantam sandhāya itam vuttam niyyātetvā ati paṭicchāpetvā
translated: But here it is said with reference to one who looks after them for a day’s wage: ‘after having sent out’ means after having handed over,

original: “etā vo gāvo”ti datvā. Iti paṭisañcikkhatīti attano gehaṃ gantvā bhuñjitvā mañce🔽nipanno evaṃ paccavekkhati. Abhijjhāsahagatenāti taṇhāya sampayuttena. Evaṃ kho,
analyzed: etāḥ vaḥ gāvaḥ iti da tvā iti paṭisañcikkhati iti attanaḥ geham gantvā bhuñjitvā mañce  nipannaḥ evam paccavekkhati abhijjhā sahagatena ati taṇhāya sampayuttena evam kho
translated: saying: ‘These are your cows.’ ‘Thus he reflects’ means: after going to his own house and eating, he lies down on his bed

original: visākhe, gopālakuposatho hotīti ariyuposathova ayaṃ, aparisuddhavitakkatāya pana🔽gopālakauposathaṭṭhāne ṭhito. Na mahapphaloti vipākaphalena na mahapphalo. Na mahānisaṃsoti
analyzed: visākhe gopālaka uposathaḥ hoti iti ariya uposathaḥ uva ayam a parisuddha vitakka tāya pana  gopālaka oposatha ṭṭhāne ṭhitaḥ na mahapphalo ti vipāka phalena na mahapphalaḥ na mahā nisaṃso ti
translated: and reflects thus. ‘With thoughts accompanied by covetousness’ means: with thoughts connected with craving. ‘Thus, Visakha, is the cowherds’ observance day’ means: this is the Noble One’s observance day, but it is placed in the position of the cowherds’ observance day because of the impure thoughts.

original: vipākānisaṃsena na mahānisaṃso. Na mahājutikoti vipākobhāsena na mahāobhāso. Na mahāvipphāroti
analyzed: vipāka anisaṃsena na mahānisaṃsaḥ na mahājutiko ti vipāka ubhāsena na mahāobhāsaḥ na mahā vipphāro ti
translated: ‘It is not fruitful’ means: it is not fruitful with the fruit of ripening. ‘It is not greatly beneficial’ means: it is not greatly beneficial with the benefit of ripening. ‘It does not have great radiance’ means: it does not have great radiance with the radiance of ripening. ‘It does not have great extension’ means:

original: vipākavipphārassa amahantatāya na mahāvipphāro.
analyzed: vipāka vipphārassa a mahanta tāya na mahā vipphāraḥ
translated: Because of the smallness of the ripening, it is not of great extent.

original: Samaṇajātikāti samaṇāyeva. Paraṃ yojanasatanti yojanasataṃ atikkamitvā tato paraṃ.
analyzed: samaṇa jātikā iti samaṇāya iva param yojana satam ti yojana satam atikkamitvā tatas param
translated: ‘The kind of ascetics’: ascetics only. ‘Beyond a hundred leagues’: beyond a hundred leagues.

original: Tesu daṇḍaṃ nikkhipāhīti tesu yojanasatato parabhāgesu ṭhitesu sattesu daṇḍaṃ nikkhipa,🔽nikkhittadaṇḍo hohi. Nāhaṃ kvacani kassaci kiñcanatasminti ahaṃ katthaci kassaci
analyzed: tesu daṇḍam nikkhipāhi iti tesu yojana satataḥ parabhāgesu ṭhitesu sattesu daṇḍam nikkhipa  nikkhitta daṇḍaḥ hohi na aham kvacani kassaci kiñcana tasmin ti aham katthaci kassaci
translated: ‘Lay down your staff against them’: lay down your staff against those beings who are beyond a hundred leagues.

original: parassa kiñcanatasmiṃ na homi. Kiñcanaṃ vuccati palibodho, palibodho na homīti vuttaṃ
analyzed: parassa na homi kiñcanam vuccati palibodhaḥ palibodhaḥ na homi iti vuttam
translated: Be one who has laid down the staff. ‘I have nothing anywhere at all’: I have nothing anywhere at all belonging to another. ‘Anything’ is said to be an impediment. What is meant is: I am not an impediment.

original: hoti. Na ca mama kvacani katthaci kiñcanatatthīti mamāpi kvacani anto vā bahiddhā🔽vā katthaci ekaparikkhārepi kiñcanatā natthi, palibodho natthi, chinnapalibodhohamasmīti
analyzed: hoti na ca mama kvacani katthaci kiñcana tatthi iti mama api kvacani antaḥ vā bahiddhā  vā katthaci eka parikkhāre pi kiñcana tā natthi palibodhaḥ natthi chinna palibodhaḥ ham asmi iti
translated: ‘Nor do I have anything anywhere at all’: I do not have anything anywhere at all, either internally or externally,

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Bhogeti mañcapīṭhayāgubhattādayo. Adinnaṃyeva paribhuñjatīti punadivase
analyzed: vuttam bhoge iti mañca pīṭha yāgu bhatta ādayaḥ paribhuñjati iti puna divase
translated: in even one requisite. What is meant is: I am one who has cut off impediments. ‘Sir, you are using what has not been given’ means:

original: mañce nipajjantopi pīṭhe nisīdantopi yāguṃ pivantopi bhattaṃ bhuñjantopi te bhoge
analyzed: mañce nipajjantaḥ api pīṭhe nisīdantaḥ api yāgum pivantaḥ api bhattam bhuñjantaḥ api te bhoge
translated: When he lies down on a bed or sits on a seat or drinks rice gruel or eats alms food, he uses those riches even though they have not been given to him.

original: adinneyeva paribhuñjati. Na mahapphaloti nipphalo. Byañjanameva hi ettha sāvasesaṃ,🔽attho pana niravaseso. Evaṃ upavutthassa hi uposathassa appamattakampi vipākaphalaṃ
analyzed: paribhuñjati na nipphalaḥ byañjanam eva hi ettha sa avasesam  atthaḥ pana niravasesaḥ evam upavutthassa hi uposathassa appamattakam pi vipāka phalam
translated: It is not fruitful: it is fruitless. For only the letter is left here, not the meaning.

original: iṭṭhaṃ kantaṃ manāpaṃ nāma natthi. Tasmā nipphalotveva veditabbo. Sesapadesupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: iṭṭham kantam manāpam nāma natthi tasmā nipphalaḥ tu eva veditabbo sesa padesu pi esa iva nayo
translated: For there is no agreeable, desirable, or welcome result of the observance day that is kept in this way, even in the slightest degree. Therefore it should be understood as fruitless. The same method applies to the other terms.

original: Upakkiliṭṭhassa cittassāti idaṃ kasmā āha? Saṃkiliṭṭhena hi cittena upavuttho uposatho
analyzed: upakkiliṭṭhassa cittassa ati idam kasmai āha saṃkiliṭṭhena hi cittena upavutthaḥ uposathaḥ
translated: Why did he say “when the mind is defiled”? Because the observance day that is kept with a defiled mind

original: na mahapphalo hotīti dassitattā visuddhena cittena upavutthassa mahapphalatā anuññātā🔽hoti. Tasmā yena kammaṭṭhānena cittaṃ visujjhati, taṃ cittavisodhanakammaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: na mahapphalaḥ hoti iti dassita ttā visuddhena cittena upavutthassa mahapphala tā anuññātā  hoti tasmai yena kammaṭṭhānena cittam visujjhati tam citta visodhana kammaṭṭhānam
translated: is not fruitful. By showing this, he allows that the observance day that is kept with a purified mind is fruitful.🔽Therefore he said this in order to show the meditation subject that purifies the mind,

original: dassetuṃ idamāha. Tattha upakkamenāti paccattapurisakārena, upāyena vā. Tathāgataṃ
analyzed: dassetum idam āha tattha upakkamena ati paccatta purisakārena upāyena vā tathāgatam
translated: by means of which the mind is purified. Herein, by effort means by personal effort, or by means. The Tathāgata

analyzed: anussarati iti aṭṭhahi kāraṇehi tathāgata guṇe anussarati ettha hi iti pi saḥ bhagavā ati
translated: ‘Remembers’: he remembers the special qualities of the Enlightened One in eight ways. For here, ‘He is such a one, the Blessed One’

original: so bhagavā itipi sīlena, itipi samādhināti sabbe lokiyalokuttarā buddhaguṇā saṅgahitā.
analyzed: saḥ bhagavā itipi sīlena itipi samādhinā ati sabbe lokiya lokuttarāḥ buddha guṇāḥ saṅgahitāḥ

original: kiliṭṭhacittena uposathaṅgāni adhiṭṭhāya uposatho upavuttho na mahapphalo hoti, parisuddhena
analyzed: kiliṭṭha cittena uposathaṅgāni adhiṭṭhāya uposathaḥ upavutthaḥ na mahapphalaḥ hoti parisuddhena
translated: If you undertake the Observance with a defiled mind, the Observance is not entered upon well, it is not very fruitful or beneficial,🔽

analyzed: pana cittena uposathaṅgāni adhiṭṭhāya upavutthaḥ uposathaḥ mahapphalaḥ hoti iti adhippāyena
translated: If he observes the Uposatha with a defiled mind, then the Uposatha observance is not very fruitful. But if he observes the Uposatha with a pure mind, then the Uposatha observance is very fruitful. This is the meaning of the passage.

analyzed: evam āha brahma uposatham upavasati iti brahmā vuccati sammāsambuddhaḥ tassa guṇa anussaraṇa vasena
translated: He observes the Brahma-Uposatha: the Perfectly Enlightened One is called Brahma. By recollecting his special qualities,

analyzed: ayam uposathaḥ brahmuposathaḥ nāma tam upavasati brahmunā saddhim saṃvasati iti sammāsambuddhena

analyzed: saddhim saṃvasati brahman ca assa ārabbha ati sammāsambuddham ārabbha
translated: With Brahma as his starting point: with the Perfectly Enlightened One as his starting point.

original: Dhammaṃ anussaratīti sahatantikaṃ lokuttaradhammaṃ anussarati. Sottinti kuruvindakasottiṃ.
analyzed: dhammam anussarati iti sahatantikam lokuttara dhammam anussarati sottim ti kuruvindaka sottim
translated: He recollects the Dhamma: he recollects the supramundane Dhamma that is connected with the path. Thread: a Kuruvindaka thread.

original: Kuruvindakapāsāṇacuṇṇena hi saddhiṃ lākhaṃ yojetvā maṇike katvā vijjhitvā suttena
analyzed: kuruvindaka pāsāṇa cuṇṇena hi saddhim lākham yojetvā maṇike katvā vijjhitvā suttena
translated: For lac is mixed with Kuruvindaka stone-powder, made into a paste, and spun into thread.
