analyzed: cātumahārājikānam deva lokānam yasmai pana ekekasmin cakkavāḷe cattāraḥ cattāraḥ mahārājāno
translated: ‘In that thousandfold world’: in that thousandfold world-system. ‘A thousand of the Gods of the Four Kings’: a thousand of the heavenly worlds of the Gods of the Four Kings. But since there are four Great Kings in each world-system,

original: tasmā cattāri mahārājasahassānīti vuttaṃ. Iminā upāyena sabbattha attho veditabbo.🔽Cūḷanikāti khuddikā. Ayaṃ sāvakānaṃ visayo. Kasmā panesā ānītāti? Majjhimikāya lokadhātuyā
analyzed: tasmā cattāri mahā rāja sahassāni iti vuttam iminā upāyena sabbattha atthaḥ veditabbaḥ  cūḷanikā ati khuddikā ayam sāvakānam visayaḥ kasmā pana isā ānītā ati majjhimikāya lokadhātuyā
translated: therefore it is said ‘four thousand of the Great Kings.’ The meaning should be understood in this way in all instances.🔽‘The little one’: the small one. This is the province of disciples. But why is it brought in?

original: paricchedadassanatthaṃ.🔽Yāvatāti yattakā. Tāva sahassadhāti tāva sahassabhāgena. Dvisahassī majjhimikā lokadhātūti🔽ayaṃ sahassacakkavāḷāni sahassabhāgena gaṇetvā dasasatasahassacakkavāḷaparimāṇā dvisahassī
analyzed: pariccheda dassana attham  yāvatā ati yattakā tāva sahassadhā ati tāva sahassa bhāgena dvi sahassī majjhimikā lokadhātu uti  ayam sahassa cakkavāḷāni sahassa bhāgena gaṇetvā dasa sata sahassa cakkavāḷa parimāṇā dvi sahassī
translated: In order to show the delimitation of the medium world-system.🔽‘As far as’: as many as. ‘A thousandfold’: a thousandfold by the thousandfold world-systems. ‘The medium world-system is two thousand’:🔽this is a world-system called ‘medium’ which is two thousand in extent,

original: majjhimikā nāma lokadhātu. Ayaṃ sāvakānaṃ avisayo, buddhānameva visayo. Ettakepi
analyzed: majjhimikā nāma lokadhātu ayam sāvakānam avisayaḥ buddhānam eva visayaḥ ettake pi
translated: being measured by ten hundred thousand world-systems. This is not the province of disciples, but it is the province of Buddhas alone. Even in this

original: hi ṭhāne tathāgatā andhakāraṃ vidhametvā sarīrobhāsaṃ dassetvā sarena viññāpetuṃ
analyzed: hi ṭhāne tathāgatāḥ andhakāram vidhametvā sarīra ubhāsam dassetvā sarena viññāpetuṃ
translated: and the place where the Buddhas dispelled the darkness and showed the radiance of their bodies and were able to make themselves understood by their voices.

original: sakkontīti dīpeti. Ettakena buddhānaṃ jātikkhettaṃ nāma dassitaṃ. Bodhisattānañhi
analyzed: sakkonti iti dīpeti ettakena buddhānam jāti khettam nāma dassitam bodhisattānam hi
translated: This shows the extent of the Buddhas’ field of birth. For the extent of the field of birth of the Bodhisattas is as follows:

original: pacchimabhave devalokato cavitvā mātukucchiyaṃ paṭisandhiggahaṇadivase ca kucchito
analyzed: pacchima bhave deva lokataḥ cavitvā mātukucchiyam paṭisandhi ggahaṇa divase ca kucchitaḥ
translated: when they die in the Tusita heaven in their last existence and take rebirth-linking in their mothers’ womb,

original: nikkhamanadivase ca mahābhinikkhamanadivase ca sambodhidhammacakkappavattanaāyusaṅkhāravossajjanaparinibbānadivasesu
analyzed: nikkhamana divase ca mahābhinikkhamana divase ca sambodhi dhamma cakka ppavattana āyu saṅkhāra vossajjana parinibbāna divasesu
translated: and on the day they emerge from their mothers’ womb, and on the day of their Great Renunciation, and on the day of their enlightenment, and on the day of their setting in motion the Wheel of the Dhamma, and on the day of their relinquishment of their life-span, and on the day of their final attainment of Nibbāna,

original: ca ettakaṃ ṭhānaṃ kampati.🔽Tisahassī mahāsahassīti sahassito paṭṭhāya tatiyāti tisahassī, sahassaṃ sahassadhā
analyzed: ca ettakam ṭhānam kampati  ti sahassī mahā sahassī iti sahassitaḥ paṭṭhāya tatiyā ati ti sahassī sahassam sahassadhā
translated: this extent trembles.🔽A great three-thousandfold world: a great three-thousandfold world is a great three-thousandfold-thousandfold world.

original: katvā gaṇitaṃ majjhimikaṃ sahassadhā katvā gaṇitattā mahantehi sahassehi gaṇitāti
analyzed: katvā gaṇitam majjhimikam sahassadhā katvā gaṇita ttā mahantehi sahassehi gaṇitā ati
translated: It is a great three-thousandfold world because it is reckoned with a great many thousands, after being reckoned as a thousand times a thousand times a thousand.🔽This shows the world system consisting of a thousand million world-spheres.

original: mahāsahassī. Ettāvatā koṭisatasahassacakkavāḷaparimāṇo loko dassito hoti. Bhagavā
analyzed: mahā sahassī ettāvatā koṭi sata sahassa cakkavāḷa parimāṇaḥ lokaḥ dassitaḥ hoti bhagavā
translated: The Blessed One

original: ākaṅkhamāno ettake ṭhāne andhakāraṃ vidhametvā sarīrobhāsaṃ dassetvā sarena viññāpeyyāti.
analyzed: ākaṅkhamānaḥ ettake ṭhāne andhakāram vidhametvā sarīra ubhāsam dassetvā sarena viññāpeyya ati
translated: If he so wished, he could make darkness appear in a place of that size and show his body, and he could make his voice heard.

original: Gaṇakaputtatissatthero pana evamāha – “na tisahassimahāsahassilokadhātuyā evaṃ parimāṇaṃ.🔽Idañhi ācariyānaṃ sajjhāyamuḷhakaṃ vācāya parihīnaṭṭhānaṃ, dasakoṭisatasahassacakkavāḷaparimāṇaṃ
analyzed: gaṇakaputta tissa theraḥ pana evam āha na ti sahassi mahā sahassi lokadhātuyāḥ evam parimāṇam  idam hi ācariyānam sajjhāya muḷhakam vācāya parihīna ṭhānam dasa koṭi sata sahassa cakkavāḷa parimāṇam
translated: But the Elder Tissa, the son of a clan in the Gaṅgā, said this: “It is not of that size in the three-thousandfold world-system.🔽For this is a place that is beyond the range of the teachers’ verbal expression, a mere mnemonic for them. But the three-thousandfold world-system is of the size of a world-sphere consisting of a thousand million .

original: pana ṭhānaṃ tisahassimahāsahassilokadhātu nāmā”ti. Ettāvatā hi bhagavatā āṇākkhettaṃ
analyzed: pana ṭhānam ti sahassi mahā sahassi lokadhātu nāma ati ettāvatā hi bhagavatā āṇā kkhettam
translated: For it is in this extent that the Blessed One has shown the field of his power.

original: nāma dassitaṃ. Etasmiñhi antare āṭānāṭiyaparittaisigiliparittadhajaggaparittabojjhaṅgaparittakhandhaparitta-🔽moraparittamettaparittaratanaparittānaṃ āṇā pharati. Yāvatā pana ākaṅkheyyāti yattakaṃ
analyzed: nāma dassitam etasmin hi antare āṭā nāṭiya paritta esigili paritta dhajagga paritta bojjhaṅga paritta khandha paritta  mora paritta metta paritta ratana parittānam āṇā pharati yāvatā pana yattakam
translated: For the power of the Āṭānāṭiya, the Sigālaka, the Dhajagga, the Bojjhaṅga, the Khuddaka, the Mora, the Metta, and the Ratana Suttantas extends over this extent.

original: ṭhānaṃ iccheyya, iminā visayakkhettaṃ dasseti. Buddhānañhi visayakkhettassa pamāṇaparicchedo
analyzed: ṭhānam iccheyya iminā visaya kkhettam dasseti buddhānam hi visaya kkhettassa pamāṇa paricchedaḥ
translated: But as far as he wishes is the field of his knowledge. This shows the extent of the field of his knowledge. For the field of the knowledge of the Buddhas is unlimited.

original: nāma natthi, natthikabhāve cassa imaṃ opammaṃ āharanti – koṭisatasahassacakkavāḷamhi
analyzed: nāma natthi natthika bhāve cassa imam opammam āharanti koṭi sata sahassa cakkavāḷamhi
translated: “There is no such thing as ‘unseen’ by the Buddhas. In order to illustrate the fact that there is nothing that is not seen by the Buddhas, they relate the following parable:🔽Suppose the whole of the universe consisting of the four great continents,

original: yāva brahmalokā sāsapehi pūretvā sace koci puratthimāya disāya ekacakkavāḷe ekaṃ
analyzed: yāva brahma lokā pūretvā sace koci puratthimāya disāya eka cakkavāḷe ekaṃ
translated: the thousand world-spheres, and the Brahma-world were filled with mustard seeds,

original: sāsapaṃ pakkhipanto āgaccheyya, sabbepi te sāsapā parikkhayaṃ gaccheyyuṃ, na tveva
analyzed: sāsapam pakkhipantaḥ āgaccheyya sabbe pi te sāsapā parikkhayam gaccheyyum na tu eva
translated: and suppose that after the lapse of a very long time someone were to come every hundred years and take away one mustard seed.

original: puratthimāya disāya cakkavāḷāni. Dakkhiṇādīsupi eseva nayo. Tattha buddhānaṃ avisayo nāma natthi.🔽Evaṃ vutte thero cintesi – “satthā evamāha – ‘ākaṅkhamāno, ānanda, tathāgato tisahassimahāsahassilokadhātuṃ
analyzed: puratthimāya disāya cakkavāḷāni dakkhiṇa ādīsu pi esa iva nayaḥ tattha buddhānam avisayaḥ nāma natthi  evam vutte theraḥ cintesi satthā evam āha ākaṅkhamānaḥ ānanda tathāgato ti sahassi mahā sahassi lokadhātum
translated: Even so, the world-spheres would sooner be exhausted than the world-spheres of the eastern direction. The same would be true of the southern, western, and northern directions. There is nothing that is not known to the Buddhas.

original: sarena viññāpeyya, yāvatā pana ākaṅkheyyā’ti. Visamo kho panāyaṃ loko, anantāni cakkavāḷāni,
analyzed: sarena viññāpeyya yāvatā pana ākaṅkheyya ati visamaḥ kho pana ayam lokaḥ anantāni cakkavāḷāni
translated: When the Elder heard this, he thought to himself, “The Teacher says, ‘If the Tathāgata so desired, Ānanda, he could remain for an eon or for the remainder of an eon.’ But the world is uneven, the world-spheres are infinite in number,

original: ekasmiṃ ṭhāne sūriyo uggato hoti, ekasmiṃ ṭhāne majjhe ṭhito, ekasmiṃ ṭhāne atthaṅgato.
analyzed: ekasmin ṭhāne sūriyaḥ uggataḥ hoti ekasmin ṭhāne majjhe ṭhitaḥ ekasmin ṭhāne atthaṅgataḥ
translated: and the sun rises and sets in different places.

original: Ekasmiṃ ṭhāne paṭhamayāmo hoti, ekasmiṃ ṭhāne majjhimayāmo, ekasmiṃ ṭhāne pacchimayāmo.
analyzed: ekasmin ṭhāne paṭhama yāmaḥ hoti ekasmin ṭhāne majjhima yāmaḥ ekasmin ṭhāne pacchima yāmaḥ
translated: In one place it is the first watch of the night, in another the middle watch, and in yet another the last watch.

original: Sattāpi kammappasutā, khiḍḍāpasutā, āhārappasutāti evaṃ tehi tehi kāraṇehi vikkhittā
analyzed: sattā api kamma ppasutā khiḍḍa apasutā āhāra ppasutā ti evam tehi tehi kāraṇehi vikkhittā
translated: And they are scattered about in this way for various reasons, such as being devoted to work, being devoted to pleasure, and being devoted to food.

original: ca pamattā ca honti. Kathaṃ nu kho te satthā sarena viññāpeyyā”ti. So evaṃ cintetvā
analyzed: ca pamattā ca honti katham nu kho te satthā sarena viññāpeyya ati saḥ evam cintetvā
translated: And they are heedless. How can the Teacher make them understand by his voice?” Having thought thus,

original: vimaticchedanatthaṃ tathāgataṃ pucchanto yathā kathaṃ panātiādimāha.
analyzed: vimati chedana attham tathāgatam pucchantaḥ yathā katham pana ati ādim āha
translated: he asked the Tathāgata in order to remove his doubt.

original: Athassa satthā byākaronto idhānanda, tathāgatotiādimāha. Tattha obhāsena phareyyāti🔽sarīrobhāsena phareyya. Pharamāno panesa kiṃ kareyyāti? Yasmiṃ ṭhāne sūriyo paññāyati,
analyzed: atha assa satthā byākarontaḥ idha ānanda tathāgataḥ tiādim āha tattha obhāsena phareyya iti  sarīra ubhāsena phareyya pharamāno pana isa kim kareyya ati yasmin ṭhāne sūriyo paññāyati
translated: Then the Teacher, in explaining, said: “Here, Ānanda, the Tathāgata would illuminate with his beauty a whole world-element consisting of a thousand worlds.”🔽Herein, he would illuminate with his beauty means he would illuminate with the beauty of his body. But what would he do in illuminating?🔽In the place where the sun appears,

original: tattha naṃ attano ānubhāvena atthaṃ gameyya. Yattha pana na paññāyati, tattha naṃ
analyzed: tattha naṃ attanaḥ ānubhāvena attham gameyya yattha pana na paññāyati tattha naṃ
translated: he would go there by his own power. But where the sun does not appear,

original: uṭṭhāpetvā majjhe ṭhapeyya. Tato yattha sūriyo paññāyati, tattha manussā “adhunāva
analyzed: uṭṭhāpetvā majjhe ṭhapeyya tatas yattha sūriyo paññāyati tattha manussāḥ
translated: he would lift it up and place it in the middle. Then in the place where the sun appears, people would say: “Now the sun has risen in the east and is shining in the west.”

original: sūriyo paññāyittha, so idāneva atthaṅgamito, nāgāvaṭṭo nu kho ayaṃ, bhūtāvaṭṭayakkhāvaṭṭadevatāvaṭṭānaṃ🔽aññataro”ti vittakkaṃ uppādeyyuṃ. Yattha pana na paññāyati, tattha manussā “adhunāva
analyzed: sūriyaḥ paññāyittha saḥ idānā iva atthaṅgamitaḥ nāgāvaṭṭaḥ nu kho ayam bhūtāvaṭṭa yakkhāvaṭṭa devatāvaṭṭānam  aññataro ti vittakkam uppādeyyuṃ yattha pana na paññāyati tattha manussāḥ
translated: The sun has set, and it is only now that this has happened. Is this a nāga-whirl, a ghost-whirl, a goblin-whirl, or a deity-whirl?”

original: sūriyo atthaṅgamito, svāyaṃ idāneva uṭṭhito, kiṃ nu kho ayaṃ nāgāvaṭṭabhūtāvaṭṭayakkhāvaṭṭadevatāvaṭṭānaṃ🔽aññataro”ti vitakkaṃ uppādeyyuṃ. Tato tesu manussesu ālokañca andhakārañca āvajjitvā
analyzed: sūriyaḥ atthaṅgamitaḥ su ayam idānā iva uṭṭhitaḥ kim nu kho ayam nāgāvaṭṭa bhūtāvaṭṭa yakkhāvaṭṭa devatāvaṭṭānam  aññataro ti vitakkam uppādeyyuṃ tatas tesu manussesu ālokam ca andhakāram ca āvajjitvā
translated: But where it is not seen, people there will think, “The sun has just set, and it is only now that this has arisen. What is this, a nāga-whirl, a ghost-whirl, a goblin-whirl, or a deity-whirl?”

original: “kiṃ paccayā nu kho ida”nti pariyesamānesu satthā nīlakasiṇaṃ samāpajjitvā bahalandhakāraṃ
analyzed: kim paccayā nu kho idam ti pariyesamānesu satthā nīla kasiṇam samāpajjitvā bahala ndhakāram
translated: Then, as those people are reflecting thus, the Teacher, having attained the blue kasiṇa, will cause a great darkness to appear.

original: patthareyya. Kasmā? Tesaṃ kammādippasutānaṃ sattānaṃ santāsajananatthaṃ. Atha nesaṃ
analyzed: patthareyya kasmā tesam kamma ādi ppasutānam sattānam santāsa janana attham atha nesam
translated: Why? In order to frighten those beings who are addicted to sensual pleasures, etc. Then,

original: santāsaṃ āpannabhāvaṃ ñatvā odātakasiṇasamāpattiṃ samāpajjitvā paṇḍaraṃ ghanabuddharasmiṃ
analyzed: santāsam āpanna bhāvam ñatvā odāta kasiṇa samāpattim samāpajjitvā paṇḍaram
translated: knowing that they are frightened, he will attain the white kasiṇa and cause a bright, thick, Buddha-ray to appear.

original: vissajjento candasahassasūriyasahassauṭṭhānakālo viya ekappahāreneva sabbaṃ ekālokaṃ
analyzed: vissajjentaḥ canda sahassa sūriya sahassa oṭṭhāna kālaḥ viya eka ppahārena iva sabbam eka ālokam
translated: and when he were to emit light, he would do so all at once, as it were, with the simultaneous rising of a thousand moons and a thousand suns.

original: kareyya. Tañca kho tilabījamattena kāyappadesena obhāsaṃ muñcanto. Yo hi cakkavāḷapathaviṃ🔽dīpakapallakaṃ katvā mahāsamudde udakaṃ telaṃ katvā sineruṃ vaṭṭiṃ katvā aññasmiṃ
analyzed: kareyya tat ca kho tila bīja mattena kāya ppadesena obhāsam muñcantaḥ yaḥ hi cakkavāḷa pathavim  dīpaka pallakam katvā mahā samudde udakam telam katvā sinerum vaṭṭim katvā aññasmin
translated: And he would emit that light with just the part of his body measuring a mere seed of sesamum. For if anyone were to make the earth of the world system a wick,

original: sinerumuddhani ṭhapetvā jāleyya, so ekacakkavāḷeyeva ālokaṃ kareyya. Tato paraṃ vidatthimpi
analyzed: sinerum uddhani ṭhapetvā ālokam kareyya tato param
translated: and the water of the ocean the oil, and Mount Sineru the container, and were to light it, it would give light only in one world system. It would not be able to illuminate even the next world system beyond.

original: obhāsetuṃ na sakkuṇeyya. Tathāgato pana tilaphalappamāṇena sarīrappadesena obhāsaṃ
analyzed: obhāsetum na sakkuṇeyya tathāgato pana tila phala ppamāṇena sarīra ppadesena obhāsam
translated: But the Tathāgata, emitting light with a part of his body measuring a mere seed of sesamum,

original: muñcitvā tisahassimahāsahassilokadhātuṃ ekobhāsaṃ kareyya tato vā pana bhiyyo. Evaṃ
analyzed: muñcitvā ti sahassi mahā sahassi lokadhātum eka ubhāsam kareyya tatas vā pana bhiyyas evam
translated: would make the great system of a thousand worlds one bright flame. And he would do more than that.

original: mahantā hi buddhaguṇāti.
analyzed: mahantā hi
translated: For so great are the Buddha-qualities.

original: Taṃ ālokaṃ sañjāneyyunti taṃ ālokaṃ disvā “yena sūriyo atthañceva gamito uṭṭhāpito
analyzed: tam ālokam sañjāneyyunti tam ālokam disvā yena sūriyaḥ attham ca iva gamitaḥ uṭṭhāpito
translated: “They would recognize the light”: having seen the light, they would know, “The sun has been eclipsed and put down.

original: ca, bahalandhakārañca vissaṭṭhaṃ, esa so puriso idāni ālokaṃ katvā ṭhito, aho acchariyapuriso”ti
analyzed: ca bahala ndhakāram ca vissaṭṭham esa saḥ purisaḥ idāni ālokam katvā ṭhitaḥ aho acchariya puriso ti
translated: and it was dark and unfrequented, and now that man has stood up and made light, what a wonderful man!”

original: añjaliṃ paggayha namassamānā nisīdeyyuṃ. Saddamanussāveyyāti dhammakathāsaddamanussāveyya.
analyzed: añjalim paggayha namassamānāḥ nisīdeyyum saddam anussāveyya ati dhammakathā saddam anussāveyya
translated: and they would sit down making reverential salutation with their joined palms raised.

original: Yo hi ekaṃ cakkavāḷapabbataṃ bheriṃ katvā mahāpathaviṃ bhericammaṃ katvā sineruṃ🔽daṇḍaṃ katvā aññasmiṃ sinerumatthake ṭhapetvā ākoṭeyya, so ekacakkavāḷeyeva taṃ saddaṃ🔽sāveyya, parato vidatthimpi atikkāmetuṃ na sakkuṇeyya. Tathāgato pana pallaṅke vā
analyzed: yaḥ hi ekam cakkavāḷa pabbatam bherim katvā mahā pathavim bheri cammam katvā sinerum  daṇḍam katvā aññasmin sineru matthake ṭhapetvā ākoṭeyya saḥ tam saddam  sāveyya paratas vidatthim pi atikkāmetum na sakkuṇeyya tathāgataḥ pana pallaṅke vā
translated: He who, having made a world-sphere mountain into a drum, and the great earth into a drum-skin, and Sineru

original: pīṭhe vā nisīditvā tisahassimahāsahassilokadhātuṃ sarena viññāpeti, tato vā pana🔽bhiyyo, evaṃ mahānubhāvā tathāgatāti. Iti bhagavā iminā ettakena visayakkhettameva dasseti.
analyzed: pīṭhe vā nisīditvā ti sahassi mahā sahassi lokadhātum sarena viññāpeti tatas vā pana  bhiyyas evam mahā anubhāvā tathāgatā ati iti bhagavā iminā ettakena visaya khettam eva dasseti
translated: the king of mountains into a drumstick, were to beat it on another Sineru placed beyond, would make its sound reach only as far as that one world-sphere; it would not be able to go beyond even as far as the width of a plough pole. But the Tathāgata, sitting on his seat or on his couch,🔽makes his voice heard throughout the three-thousand great-thousand world system, and even beyond that. So great is the Tathāgata’s power.

original: Imañca pana buddhasīhanādaṃ sutvā therassa abbhantare balavapīti uppannā, so pītivasena
analyzed: imam ca pana buddha sīha nādam sutvā therassa abbhantare balava pīti uppannā so pīti vasena
translated: And when he heard this lion’s roar of the Exalted One, strong spiritual joy arose in the elder, and he was filled with joy and happiness.

original: udānaṃ udānento lābhā vata metiādimāha. Tattha yassa me satthā evaṃmahiddhikoti yassa
analyzed: udānam udānentaḥ lābhāḥ vata mā iti ādim āha tattha yassa me satthā evaṃmahiddhiko ti yassa
translated: “How great a gain and how well gained is it for me🔽that I have such a Master as this, who has such great psychic power.”🔽Or alternatively, his meaning is: “How great a gain and how well gained is it for me

original: pavedhamānaṃ purisaṃ ekamante ṭhito hitesī puriso “ito ehi ito ehī”ti punappunaṃ

analyzed: devesu ca manussesu ca atta bhāvam paṭilabhati tena assa gatim paricchindantaḥ evam āha  diṭṭhe iva dhamme iti imasmin yeva attabhāve ṭhatvā parinibbāyissati iti appaccaya parinibbānena

translated: But mundane consciousness of the sense sphere is called consciousness; that of the fine-material sphere based on that is called higher consciousness; that of the immaterial sphere based on that is called higher consciousness.

translated: In the fourth sutta, the Vajjian is a son of the royal family of the Vajjians. A hundred and fifty training precepts: more than fifty training precepts. This is said referring only to the training precepts laid down on that occasion. It seems that this bhikkhu was quick-witted, straightforward, guileless, and sincere. So he thought, “I wonder whether I could keep so many training precepts or not,” and he told the Master. I can: I am able. It seems that he said this thinking, “If I train in so many training precepts, I shall not be able to train in the three trainings.” Then the Blessed One, just as if a man unable to lift fifty bundles of hay were to be given a hundred bundles, so too, he gave him two more, thinking, “If he cannot train in one training precept, perhaps he can in two.”

original: tato catutthamaggañāṇato anantarā aññā uppajjati, arahattaphalaṃ uppajjatīti attho.
analyzed: tatas catuttha magga ñāṇataḥ anantarā aññā uppajjati arahatta phalam uppajjati iti attho
translated: “Then knowledge of other things next”: then next to the knowledge of the fourth path, knowledge of other things arises. The meaning is: the fruit of arahantship arises.

original: Aññāvimuttassāti arahattaphalavimuttiyā vimuttassa. Ñāṇaṃ ve hotīti paccavekkhaṇañāṇaṃ
analyzed: aññā vimuttassa ati arahatta phala vimuttiyā vimuttassa ñāṇam ve hoti iti paccavekkhaṇa ñāṇam
translated: “Liberated by the knowledge of destruction”: liberated by the knowledge of the fruit of arahantship.🔽“His knowledge is well developed”: the knowledge of reviewing.

original: hoti. Iti suttepi gāthāsupi satta sekhā kathitā. Avasāne pana khīṇāsavo dassitoti.
analyzed: hoti iti sutte pi gāthāsu pi satta sekhā kathitā avasāne pana khīṇāsavaḥ dassitoti
translated: So in the Sutta too and in the Verses seven kinds of Initiate are spoken of, but in the conclusion the Arahant is shown.

original: 6. Paṭhamasikkhāsuttavaṇṇanā🔽87. Chaṭṭhe attakāmāti attano hitakāmā. Yatthetaṃ sabbaṃ samodhānaṃ gacchatīti yāsu🔽sikkhāsu sabbametaṃ diyaḍḍhasikkhāpadasataṃ saṅgahaṃ gacchati. Paripūrakārī hotīti🔽samattakārī hoti. Mattaso kārīti pamāṇena kārako, sabbena sabbaṃ kātuṃ na sakkotīti
analyzed: paṭhama sikkhā sutta vaṇṇanā  chaṭṭhe atta kāmā ati attanaḥ hita kāmā yattha etam sabbam samodhānam gacchati iti yāsu  sikkhāsu sabbam etam diyaḍḍha sikkhāpada satam saṅgaham gacchati paripūra kārī hoti iti  sa matta kārī hoti mattaso kārī iti pamāṇena kārako sabbena sabbam kātum na sakkoti iti
translated: The first Sutta in the First Chapter

original: attho. Khuddānukhuddakānīti cattāri pārājikāni ṭhapetvā sesasikkhāpadāni. Tatrāpi
analyzed: attho khuddānukhuddakāni iti cattāri pārājikāni ṭhapetvā sesa sikkhāpadāni tatra api
translated: In the sixth , “those who are devoted to their own good” are those who want their own welfare. “So that all this is included” : in these Trainings all this hundred and fifty training precepts are included. “He is a fulfiller” : he is a completer. “He is a doer of what is enough” : he is a doer of what is measured. The meaning is that he is not able to do everything all round. “The minor and minor-than-minor” : the training precepts, leaving aside the four Offences involving Defeat, are called “minor” and the remaining training precepts are called “minor-than-minor”. Therein,

original: saṅghādisesaṃ khuddakaṃ, thullaccayaṃ anukhuddakaṃ nāma. Thullaccayañca khuddakaṃ,🔽pācittiyaṃ anukhuddakaṃ nāma, pācittiyañca khuddakaṃ, pāṭidesaniyadukkaṭadubbhāsitāni
analyzed: saṅgha ādisesam khuddakam thullaccayam anukhuddakam nāma thullaccayañca khuddakam  pācittiyam anukhuddakam nāma pācittiyam ca khuddakam pāṭidesaniya dukkaṭa dubbhāsitāni
translated: the Sanghasdisesa is called “minor” and the Thullaccaya is called “minor-than-minor”. The Thullaccaya is called “minor”

original: anukhuddakāni nāma. Ime pana aṅguttaramahānikāyavaḷañjanakaācariyā “cattāri pārājikāni
analyzed: anukhuddakāni nāma ime pana aṅguttara mahā nikāya vaḷañjanaka ācariyā cattāri pārājikāni
translated: and the Pacittiya is called “minor-than-minor”. The Pacittiya is called “minor” and the Patikamma, Dubbhasita, and Dukkaṭa are called “minor-than-minor”. But these teachers, the Anguttara-nikaya-mahavihara-Vajjiputtaka, say that the four Offences involving Defeat are called “minor-than-minor”🔽and the remaining training precepts are called “minor”.

original: ṭhapetvā sesāni sabbānipi khuddānukhuddakānī”ti vadanti. Tāni āpajjatipi vuṭṭhātipīti
analyzed: ṭhapetvā sesāni sabbāni api khuddānukhuddakāni iti vadanti tāni āpajjati pi vuṭṭhāti pi iti
translated: and all the other minor and very minor offenses.

original: ettha pana khīṇāsavo tāva lokavajjaṃ nāpajjati, paṇṇattivajjameva āpajjati. Āpajjanto
analyzed: ettha pana khīṇa āsavaḥ tāva loka vajjam na āpajjati paṇṇatti vajjam eva āpajjati āpajjanto
translated: Herein, one whose cankers are destroyed does not commit a natural offense, but he may commit a prescribed offense.🔽And in committing it he commits it by body, by speech, and by mind.

original: ca kāyenapi vācāyapi cittenapi āpajjati. Kāyena āpajjanto kuṭikārasahaseyyādīni āpajjati,
analyzed: ca kāyena api cittena api āpajjati kāyena āpajjantaḥ kuṭi kāra sahaseyya ādīni āpajjati
translated: In committing it by body he commits the offense of lying down on a high couch, etc.,🔽in committing it by speech he commits the offense of the act of osculation, etc.,

original: vācāya āpajjanto sañcarittapadasodhammādīni, cittena āpajjanto rūpiyapaṭiggahaṇaṃ
analyzed: vācāya āpajjanto cittena āpajjanto rūpiya paṭiggahaṇam
translated: in committing it by mind he commits the offense of receiving gold and silver.🔽The same method applies in the case of the trainee.

original: āpajjati. Sekkhesupi eseva nayo. Na hi mettha, bhikkhave, abhabbatā vuttāti, bhikkhave,
analyzed: āpajjati sekkhesu pi esa iva nayaḥ na hi mā ittha bhikkhave abhabba tā vuttā ati bhikkhave
translated: For here, bhikkhus, there is no prohibition for the noble person.

original: na hi mayā ettha evarūpaṃ āpattiṃ āpajjane ca vuṭṭhāne ca ariyapuggalassa abhabbatā🔽kathitā. Ādibrahmacariyakānīti maggabrahmacariyassa ādibhūtāni cattāri mahāsīlasikkhāpadāni.
analyzed: na hi mayā ettha evarūpam āpattim āpajjane ca vuṭṭhāne ca ariya puggalassa abhabba tā  kathitāḥ ādibrahmacariyakāni iti magga brahmacariyassa ādi bhūtāni cattāri mahā sīla sikkhāpadāni
translated: Bhikkhus, I have not declared that the noble person is incapable of committing such and such an offense and of emerging from it.🔽The first of the holy life: the four great training precepts of the great man.

original: Brahmacariyasāruppānīti tāniyeva catumaggabrahmacariyassa sāruppāni anucchavikāni.
analyzed: brahmacariya sāruppāni iti catu magga brahmacariyassa sāruppāni anucchavikāni
translated: Suitable to the holy life: those same four are suitable and proper for the four-path holy life.

original: Tatthāti tesu sikkhāpadesu. Dhuvasīloti nibaddhasīlo. Ṭhitasīloti patiṭṭhitasīlo.
analyzed: tattha ati tesu sikkhāpadesu dhuva sīlaḥ ati nibaddha sīlaḥ ṭhita sīlaḥ ati patiṭṭhita sīlo
translated: Herein, in these training precepts: Steadfast in virtue: his virtue is steady. Firm in virtue: his virtue is firm.

original: Sotāpannoti sotasaṅkhātena maggena phalaṃ āpanno. Avinipātadhammoti catūsu apāyesu
analyzed: sotāpannaḥ ti sota saṅkhātena maggena phalam āpannaḥ a vinipāta dhammaḥ ti catūsu apāyesu
translated: Stream-enterer: he has entered upon the fruit of stream-entry by means of the path called “stream-entry.” Not subject to loss: he is not of the nature to fall into the four states of loss,

original: apatanasabhāvo. Niyatoti sotāpattimagganiyāmena niyato. Sambodhiparāyaṇoti uparimaggattayasambodhiparāyaṇo.
analyzed: a patana sabhāvaḥ niyataḥ iti sotāpatti magga niyāmena niyataḥ sambodhi parāyaṇaḥ iti upari magga ttaya sambodhi parāyaṇaḥ
translated: Destined for enlightenment: he is destined for the enlightenment of the three higher paths.

original: Tanuttāti tanubhāvo. Sakadāgāmino hi rāgādayo abbhapaṭalaṃ viya macchikāpattaṃ viya
analyzed: tanuttā ati tanu bhāvaḥ sakadāgāminaḥ hi rāga ādayaḥ abbha paṭalam viya macchikā pattam viya
translated: Slight: he has slight greed, hate, and delusion, like a slight fleck of clay in a pot of oil, like a slight fleck of oil in a pot of clay.

original: ca tanukā honti, na bahalā. Orambhāgiyānanti heṭṭhābhāgiyānaṃ. Saṃyojanānanti bandhanānaṃ.🔽Parikkhayāti parikkhayena. Opapātiko hotīti uppannako hoti. Tattha parinibbāyīti
analyzed: ca tanukāḥ honti na bahalāḥ heṭṭhābhāgiyānam saṃyojanānam  parikkhayā ati parikkhayena opapātikaḥ hoti iti uppannakaḥ hoti tattha parinibbāyī iti
translated: The lower fetters: the fetters that are lower, that is, the five lower fetters.

original: heṭṭhā anotaritvā upariyeva parinibbānadhammo. Anāvattidhammoti yonigativasena anāgamanadhammo.
analyzed: heṭṭhā an otaritvā upariyā iva parinibbāna dhammo anāvatti dhammo ti yoni gati vasena anāgamana dhammo
translated: By their destruction: by their destruction. He is one who attains Nibbāna in the interval: he is one who attains Nibbāna in the intermediate state. He is one who attains Nibbāna without exertion: he is one who attains Nibbāna without exertion. He is a body-witness: he is a body-witness. He is one attained to view: he is one attained to view. He is one liberated by faith: he is one liberated by faith. He is a Dhamma-follower: he is a Dhamma-follower. He is a faith-follower: he is a faith-follower.

original: Padesaṃ padesakārītiādīsu padesakārī puggalo nāma sotāpanno ca sakadāgāmī ca anāgāmī
analyzed: padesam padesa kārī iti ādīsu padesa kārī puggalaḥ nāma sotāpannaḥ ca sakadāgāmī ca anāgāmī
translated: In the case of “one who does the amount for a stage” and so on, the person who does the amount for a stage is a stream-enterer, once-returner, and non-returner.

original: ca, so padesameva sampādeti. Paripūrakārī nāma arahā, so paripūrameva sampādeti.
analyzed: ca saḥ padesam eva sampādeti paripūrakārī nāma arahā saḥ paripūram eva sampādeti
translated: He accomplishes only a stage. One who does the amount in full is an Arahant. He accomplishes only the amount in full.

original: Avañjhānīti atucchāni saphalāni saudrayānīti attho. Idhāpi tisso sikkhā missakāva kathitā.
analyzed: avañjhāni iti a tucchāni sa phalāni saudrayāni iti attho idha api tissaḥ sikkhā missakā ava kathitā
translated: “Not barren” : not fruitless, not barren, not void, is the meaning. Here too the three trainings are called “mixed.”

original: 7. Dutiyasikkhāsuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dutiya sikkhā sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the second sutta of the Training Principles is finished.

original: 88. Sattame kolaṃkoloti kulā kulaṃ gamanako. Kulanti cettha bhavo adhippeto, tasmā
analyzed: sattame kolaṃkolā iti kulā kulam gamanako kulanti ca ittha bhavaḥ adhippeto tasmā
translated: In the seventh case, “going from family to family” : kulaṃ kulaṃ gacchati = kolaṃkolo. Herein,

original: “dve vā tīṇi vā kulānī”ti etthapi dve vā tayo vā bhaveti attho veditabbo. Ayañhi
analyzed: dve vā tīṇi vā kulāni iti ettha api dve vā tayaḥ vā bhava iti atthaḥ veditabbaḥ ayam hi
translated: “two or three families” should be understood to mean two or three existences. For this person

original: dve vā bhave sandhāvati tayo vā, uttamakoṭiyā cha vā. Tasmā dve vā tīṇi vā cattāri
analyzed: dve vā bhave sandhāvati tayaḥ vā uttama koṭiyā cha vā tasmai dve vā tīṇi vā cattāri
translated: goes to two or three existences, or at the most to six. Therefore the analysis should be understood thus: two, three, four,

original: vā pañca vā cha vāti evamettha vikappo daṭṭhabbo. Ekabījīti ekasseva bhavassa bījaṃ
analyzed: vā pañca vā cha vā ti evam ettha vikappaḥ daṭṭhabbo ekabījī iti ekassa iva bhavassa bījam
translated: five, or six. One who is a “single-seed” has a single existence as a human being as the seed for his rebirth.

original: etassa atthīti ekabījī. Uddhaṃsototiādīsu atthi uddhaṃsoto akaniṭṭhagāmī, atthi uddhaṃsoto
analyzed: etassa atthi iti ekabījī uddhaṃsoto tiādīsu atthi uddhaṃsoto akaniṭṭha gāmī atthi uddhaṃsoto
translated: One who has that is a single-seed. As regards the words “one who goes upstream,” etc., there is one who goes upstream and goes to the Akaniṭṭha realm,

original: na akaniṭṭhagāmī, atthi na uddhaṃsoto akaniṭṭhagāmī, atthi na uddhaṃsoto na akaniṭṭhagāmī.🔽Tattha yo idha anāgāmiphalaṃ patvā avihādīsu nibbatto tattha yāvatāyukaṃ ṭhatvā uparūpari🔽nibbattitvā akaniṭṭhaṃ pāpuṇāti, ayaṃ uddhaṃsoto akaniṭṭhagāmī nāma. Yo pana avihādīsu
analyzed: na akaniṭṭha gāmī atthi na uddhaṃsoto akaniṭṭha gāmī atthi na uddhaṃsoto na akaniṭṭha gāmī  tattha yaḥ idha anāgāmi phalam patvā aviha ādīsu nibbattaḥ tattha yāvatāyukam ṭhatvā uparūpari  nibbattitvā akaniṭṭham pāpuṇāti ayam akaniṭṭhagāmī nāma yaḥ pana a vihādīsu
translated: He who has this is called a single-seeded one. As regards the phrase “one who goes upstream,” etc., there is one who goes upstream and goes to the Akaniṭṭha realm, there is one who goes upstream and does not go to the Akaniṭṭha realm, there is one who does not go upstream and goes to the Akaniṭṭha realm, and there is one who does not go upstream and does not go to the Akaniṭṭha realm.

original: nibbatto tattheva aparinibbāyitvā akaniṭṭhampi appatvā uparimabrahmaloke parinibbāyati,
analyzed: nibbattaḥ tattha iva a parinibbāyitvā akaniṭṭham pi ap patvā uparima brahmaloke parinibbāyati
translated: Herein, one who, having attained the fruit of non-returner in this world, is reborn in the Aviha realm, etc., and remains there for the remainder of his life span, and then is reborn in the higher realms one after another, and finally reaches the Akaniṭṭha realm, is called one who goes upstream and goes to the Akaniṭṭha realm. But one who, being reborn in the Aviha realm, etc., does not attain final Nibbāna there but attains final Nibbāna in the higher Brahma-world realms without reaching the Akaniṭṭha realm,

original: ayaṃ uddhaṃsoto na akaniṭṭhagāmī nāma. Yo ito cavitvā akaniṭṭheyeva nibbattati, ayaṃ
analyzed: ayam uddhaṃsotaḥ na akaniṭṭhagāmī nāma yaḥ itas cavitvā akaniṭṭheya iva nibbattati ayam
translated: is called one who goes upstream and does not go to the Akaniṭṭha realm. One who passes away from here and is reborn only in the Akaniṭṭha realm is called

original: na uddhaṃsoto akaniṭṭhagāmī nāma. Yo pana avihādīsu catūsu aññatarasmiṃ nibbattitvā
analyzed: na akaniṭṭhagāmī nāma yaḥ pana a vihā ādīsu catūsu aññatarasmin nibbattitvā
translated: one who does not go upstream and goes to the Akaniṭṭha realm. But one who, being reborn in one of the four realms beginning with Aviha,

original: tattheva parinibbāyati, ayaṃ na uddhaṃsoto na akaniṭṭhagāmī nāma.
analyzed: tattha iva parinibbāyati ayam na uddhaṃsotaḥ na akaniṭṭhagāmī nāma
translated: attains final Nibbāna there, is called one who does not go upstream and does not go to the Akaniṭṭha realm.

original: Yattha katthaci uppanno pana sasaṅkhārena sappayogena arahattaṃ patto sasaṅkhāraparinibbāyī🔽nāma. Asaṅkhārena appayogena patto asaṅkhāraparinibbāyī nāma. Yo pana kappasahassāyukesu🔽avihesu nibbattitvā pañcamaṃ kappasataṃ atikkamitvā arahattaṃ patto, ayaṃ upahaccaparinibbāyī🔽nāma. Atappādīsupi eseva nayo. Antarāparinibbāyīti yo āyuvemajjhaṃ anatikkamitvā🔽parinibbāyati, so tividho hoti. Kappasahassāyukesu tāva avihesu nibbattitvā eko nibbattadivaseyeva
analyzed: yattha katthaci uppannaḥ pana sa saṅkhārena sa payogena arahattam patto sa saṅkhāra parinibbāyī  nāma asaṅkhārena appayogena patto asaṅkhāraparinibbāyī nāma yaḥ pana kappa sahassa āyukesu  avihesu nibbattitvā pañcamam kappa satam atikkamitvā arahattam pattaḥ ayam upahacca parinibbāyī  nāma a tappa ādīsu pi esa iva nayaḥ antarā parinibbāyī iti yaḥ āyu vemajjham an atikkamitvā  parinibbāyati saḥ tividhaḥ hoti kappa sahassa āyukesu tāva avihesu nibbattitvā ekaḥ nibbatta divaseya iva
translated: But one who attains Arahantship by means of prompting and by means of exertion is called one who attains extinction with prompting.🔽One who attains it without prompting and without exertion is called one who attains extinction without prompting.🔽But one who is reborn in the Aviha Brahmā-world, which lasts for a thousand of four-continent world-systems, and attains Arahantship after exceeding the fifth century, is called one who attains extinction with pressure.🔽The same method applies in the case of the Atappa, etc.🔽One who attains extinction in the interval is of three kinds. One who is reborn in the Aviha Brahmā-world, which lasts for a thousand of four-continent world-systems, and attains Arahantship on the very day of his rebirth, is called one who attains extinction in the interval.🔽

original: arahattaṃ pāpuṇāti. No ce nibbattadivase pāpuṇāti, paṭhamassa pana kappasatassa matthake🔽pāpuṇāti, ayaṃ paṭhamo antarāparinibbāyī. Aparo evaṃ asakkonto dvinnaṃ kappasatānaṃ
analyzed: arahattam pāpuṇāti no ce nibbatta divase pāpuṇāti paṭhamassa pana kappa satassa matthake 🔽pāpuṇāti ayam paṭhamaḥ antarā parinibbāyī aparaḥ evam a sakkontaḥ dvinnam kappa satānam
translated: But one who attains Arahantship by means of prompting and by means of exertion is called one who attains extinction with prompting. One who attains it without prompting and without exertion is called one who attains extinction without prompting. But one who is reborn in the Aviha Brahmā-world, which lasts for a thousand of four-continent world-systems, and attains Arahantship after exceeding the first five hundred of the thousand world-systems, is called one who attains extinction with pressure. And so too with the Atappa, etc., But one who attains extinction in the interval is of three kinds. One is reborn in the Aviha Brahmā-world, which lasts for a thousand of four-continent world-systems, and he attains Arahantship on the very day of his rebirth. If he does not attain it on the day of his rebirth, then he attains it at the end of the first five hundred world-systems. This is the first kind of one who attains extinction in the interval. Another, being unable to do this, attains it at the end of the second five hundred world-systems.

original: matthake pāpuṇāti, ayaṃ dutiyo. Aparo evampi asakkonto catunnaṃ kappasatānaṃ matthake
analyzed: matthake pāpuṇāti ayam dutiyaḥ aparaḥ evam pi a sakkonto catunnam kappa satānam matthake
translated: He reaches the end of the fourth aeon, this is the second. Another, unable to do even that,

original: pāpuṇāti, ayaṃ tatiyo antarāparinibbāyī. Sesaṃ vuttanayameva.
analyzed: pāpuṇāti ayam tatiyaḥ antarā parinibbāyī sesam vutta nayam eva
translated: reaches the end of the fourth aeon, this is the third inter- mediate one. The rest is as already stated.

original: Imasmiṃ pana ṭhāne ṭhatvā catuvīsati sotāpannā, dvādasa sakadāgāmino, aṭṭhacattālīsa🔽anāgāmino, dvādasa ca arahanto kathetabbā. Imasmiṃ hi sāsane saddhādhuraṃ paññādhuranti
analyzed: imasmin pana ṭhāne ṭhatvā catuvīsati sotāpannāḥ dvādasa sakadāgāmino aṭṭhacattālīsa  anāgāminaḥ dvādasa ca arahantaḥ kathetabbāḥ imasmin hi sāsane saddhā dhuram paññā dhuram
translated: But in this place twenty-four stream-enterers, twelve once-returners, forty-eight🔽non-returners, and twelve arahats should be mentioned. For in this Dispensation there are two kinds of persons, those who are devoted to faith and those who are devoted to wisdom,

original: dve dhurāni, dukkhapaṭipadādandhābhiññādayo catasso paṭipadā. Tattheko saddhādhurena
analyzed: dve dhurāni dukkha paṭipadāt andha abhiññā ādayo catasso paṭipadā tattha ekaḥ saddhā dhurena
translated: and there are four paths, namely, the painful path of slow progress, etc. Herein, one who is devoted to faith

original: abhinivisitvā sotāpattiphalaṃ patvā ekameva bhavaṃ nibbattitvā dukkhassantaṃ karoti,
analyzed: abhinivisitvā sotāpatti phalam patvā ekam eva bhavam nibbattitvā dukkhassantam karoti
translated: after entering upon the way to the first fruition, the fruit of stream-entry, produces only one becoming, and then he makes an end of suffering.

original: ayameko ekabījī. So paṭipadāvasena catubbidho hoti. Yathā cesa, evaṃ paññādhurena
analyzed: ayam ekaḥ eka bījī so paṭipadā vasena catubbidhaḥ hoti yathā ca isaḥ evam paññā dhurena
translated: This is the single-seeded one. He is of four kinds according to the path. As he is, so is the one devoted to wisdom

original: abhiniviṭṭhopīti aṭṭha ekabījino. Tathā kolaṃkolā sattakkhattuparamā cāti ime catuvīsati
analyzed: abhiniviṭṭhaḥ api iti aṭṭha ekabījino tathā kolaṃkolā sattakkhattuparamā ca ati ime catuvīsati
translated: after entering upon the way. So there are eight single-seeded ones. Likewise the clan-to-clan, and the seven-at-most. These twenty-four

original: sotāpannā nāma. Tīsu pana vimokkhesu suññatavimokkhena sakadāgāmibhūmiṃ pattā catunnaṃ
analyzed: sotāpannā nāma tīsu pana vimokkhesu suññata vimokkhena sakadāgāmi bhūmim pattā catunnam
translated: They are called Stream-Enterers. But in the case of the three liberations, those who have reached the fruit of Once-Returner by means of the void liberation are four kinds of Once-Returners according to the four paths,

original: paṭipadānaṃ vasena cattāro sakadāgāmino, tathā animittavimokkhena pattā cattāro,
analyzed: paṭipadānam vasena cattāro sakadāgāmino tathā animitta vimokkhena pattā cattāro
translated: and likewise those who have reached it by means of the desireless liberation are four kinds,

original: appaṇihitavimokkhena pattā cattāroti ime dvādasa sakadāgāmino. Avihesu pana tayo
analyzed: appaṇihita vimokkhena pattā cattāro ti ime dvādasa sakadāgāminaḥ avihesu pana tayo
translated: and those who have reached it by means of the signless liberation are four kinds. So these are twelve kinds of Once-Returners. But in the Aviha heaven there are three kinds of Non-Returners who attain Nibbāna in the interval,

original: antarāparinibbāyino, eko upahaccaparinibbāyī, eko uddhaṃsoto akaniṭṭhagāmīti pañca
analyzed: antarā parinibbāyinaḥ ekaḥ upahacca parinibbāyī ekaḥ uddhaṃsotaḥ akaniṭṭha gāmī iti pañca
translated: one who attains Nibbāna as soon as he is reborn, and one who goes upstream to the Akaniṭṭha heaven. So there are five kinds of Non-Returners.

original: anāgāmino, te asaṅkhāraparinibbāyino pañca, sasaṅkhāraparinibbāyino pañcāti dasa🔽honti, tathā atappādīsu. Akaniṭṭhesu pana uddhaṃsoto natthi, tasmā tattha cattāro
analyzed: anāgāminaḥ te asaṅkhāra parinibbāyino pañca sa saṅkhāra parinibbāyino pañca ati dasa  honti tathā atappa ādīsu akaniṭṭhesu pana uddhaṃsotaḥ natthi tasmā tattha cattāro
translated: Of these, five attain Nibbāna without exertion and five with exertion.

original: sasaṅkhāraparinibbāyī, cattāro asaṅkhāraparinibbāyīti aṭṭha, ime aṭṭhacattālīsa anāgāmino.
analyzed: sa saṅkhāra parinibbāyī cattāraḥ asaṅkhāra parinibbāyī iti aṭṭha ime aṭṭhacattālīsa anāgāmino
translated: So there are ten kinds in the Aviha heaven. Likewise in the Atappa heaven. But in the Akaniṭṭha heaven there is no one who goes upstream. So there are four kinds who attain Nibbāna with exertion and four kinds who attain Nibbāna without exertion, making eight. These are the forty-eight kinds of Non-Returners.

original: Yathā pana sakadāgāmino, tatheva arahantopi dvādasa veditabbā. Idhāpi tisso sikkhā missikāva kathitā.
analyzed: yathā pana sakadāgāminaḥ tathā iva arahantaḥ pi dvādasa veditabbā idha api tisso sikkhā missikā ava kathitā
translated: And as in the case of the Once-Returners, so in the case of the Arahants there are twelve kinds to be understood. Here too the three kinds of training are given as mixed.

original: 8. Tatiyasikkhāsuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: tatiya sikkhā sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: 8. The commentary on the third training precept

original: 89. Aṭṭhame taṃ vā pana anabhisambhavaṃ appaṭivijjhanti taṃ arahattaṃ apāpuṇanto
analyzed: aṭṭhame tam vā pana anabhisambhavam appaṭivijjhanti tam arahattam a pāpuṇanto
translated: . Or, not penetrating to that, not reaching Arahantship,

original: appaṭivijjhanto. Iminā nayena sabbaṭṭhānesu attho veditabbo. Idhāpi tisso sikkhā
analyzed: a paṭivijjhantaḥ iminā nayena sabba ṭṭhānesu atthaḥ veditabbaḥ idha api tissaḥ sikkhā
translated: not penetrating to that, not reaching Arahantship. The meaning should be understood in this way in all instances. Here too the three trainings🔽are spoken of as mixed. The ninth has a plain meaning. Here too the three trainings

original: missikāva kathitā. Navamaṃ uttānatthameva. Idhāpi tisso sikkhā missikāva kathitā.
analyzed: missikā ava kathitā navamam uttāna ttham eva idha api tisso sikkhā missikā ava kathitā
translated: are spoken of as mixed.

original: 10. Dutiyasikkhattayasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dutiya sikkhattaya sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . The commentary on the second training triad

original: 91. Dasame āsavānaṃ khayāti ettha arahattamaggo adhipaññāsikkhā nāma. Phalaṃ pana sikkhitasikkhassa uppajjanato sikkhāti na vattabbaṃ.
analyzed: dasame āsavānam khayā ti ettha arahatta maggo adhi paññā sikkhā nāma phalam pana sikkhita sikkhassa uppajjanato sikkhā ati na vattabbam
translated: . In the tenth, the destruction of cankers: here the Arahant path is called the training in higher understanding. But the fruition is not called training because it arises in one who has trained.

original: Yathā pure tathā pacchāti yathā paṭhamaṃ tīsu sikkhāsu sikkhati, pacchā tatheva sikkhatīti🔽attho. Dutiyapadepi eseva nayo. Yathā adho tathā uddhanti yathā heṭṭhimakāyaṃ asubhavasena
analyzed: yathā pure tathā pacchā ati yathā paṭhamam tīsu sikkhāsu sikkhati pacchā tathā iva sikkhati iti  atthaḥ dutiya pade pi esa iva nayaḥ yathā adhas tathā uddhanti yathā heṭṭhima kāyam asubha vasena
translated: As before, so after: the meaning is that as he trains in the three trainings at first, so he trains afterwards too.🔽The same method of explanation applies in the second case. As below, so above: as he sees the lower part of the body as foul, so he extends the sign to the upper part of the body.

original: passati, uparimakāyampi tatheva pharati. Dutiyapadepi eseva nayo. Yathā divā tathā
analyzed: passati uparima kāyam pi tathā iva pharati dutiya pade pi esā iva nayaḥ yathā divā tathā
translated: The same method of explanation applies in the second case. As by day, so by night:

original: rattinti yathā divā tisso sikkhā sikkhati, rattimpi tatheva sikkhatīti attho. Abhibhuyya
analyzed: rattim ti yathā divā tissaḥ sikkhā sikkhati rattim pi tathā iva sikkhati iti atthaḥ abhibhuyya
translated: ‘Night’: the meaning is that just as he trains in the three trainings by day, so he trains in them also by night.🔽‘Having overcome all directions’: having overcome all directions as objects.

original: disā sabbāti sabbā disā ārammaṇavasena abhibhavitvā. Appamāṇasamādhināti arahattamaggasamādhinā.
analyzed: disā sabbā ti sabbāḥ disāḥ ārammaṇa vasena abhibhavitvā appamāṇa samādhinā ati arahatta magga samādhinā
translated: ‘With measureless concentration’: with the concentration of the Arahant path.🔽‘The trainee’: the one still on the training, the one who still has to learn.

original: Sekkhanti sikkhamānaṃ sakaraṇīyaṃ. Paṭipadanti paṭipannakaṃ. Saṃsuddhacāriyanti saṃsuddhacaraṇaṃ
analyzed: sekkhanti sikkhamānam sakaraṇīyam paṭipadanti paṭipannakam saṃsuddha cāriyanti saṃsuddha caraṇam
translated: ‘The one on the way’: the one who has entered on the way.🔽‘The one of pure livelihood’: the one of pure conduct.

original: parisuddhasīlaṃ. Sambuddhanti catusaccabuddhaṃ. Dhīraṃ paṭipadantagunti khandhadhīraāyatanadhīravasena
analyzed: parisuddha sīlam sambuddhanti catu sacca buddham dhīram khandha dhīra āyatana dhīra vasena
translated: ‘The Enlightened One’: the one enlightened about the Four Truths.🔽‘The steadfast one who has reached the end of the path’: the steadfast one, the one endowed with steadfastness, who has reached the end of the path by means of steadfastness in the aggregates and steadfastness in the bases.

original: dhīraṃ dhitisampannaṃ paṭipattiyā antaṃ gataṃ. Viññāṇassāti carimakaviññāṇassa. Taṇhākkhayavimuttinoti
analyzed: dhīram dhiti sampannam paṭipattiyāḥ antam gatam viññāṇassa ati carimaka viññāṇassa taṇhā khaya vimuttino ti
translated: ‘Consciousness’: of the last consciousness.

original: taṇhākkhayavimuttisaṅkhātāya arahattaphalavimuttiyā samannāgatassa. Pajjotasseva
analyzed: taṇhā kkhaya vimutti saṅkhātāya arahatta phala vimuttiyā samannāgatassa pajjotassa iva
translated: ‘With freedom due to the destruction of craving’: possessed of the freedom called the fruit of Arahantship, which is freedom due to the destruction of craving.🔽‘Is released like a flame gone out’: like the flame of a lamp.

original: nibbānanti padīpanibbānaṃ viya. Vimokkho hoti cetasoti cittassa vimutti vimuccanā
analyzed: nibbānam ti padīpa nibbānam viya vimokkhaḥ hoti cetasaḥ ti cittassa vimutti vimuccanā
translated: ‘The mind is freed’: the mind’s freedom, the mind’s release,

original: appavattibhāvo hoti. Taṇhākkhayavimuttino hi khīṇāsavassa carimakaviññāṇanirodhena
analyzed: appavatti bhāvaḥ hoti taṇhā kkhaya vimuttinaḥ hi khīṇa āsavassa carimaka viññāṇa nirodhena
translated: there is no further occurrence. For just as the extinction of the cankers of one who is liberated by the destruction of craving is his final-knowledge-extinction with the cessation of the last consciousness,

original: parinibbānaṃ viya cetaso vimokkho hoti, na gataṭṭhānaṃ paññāyati, apaṇṇattikabhāvūpagamoyeva hotīti attho.
analyzed: parinibbānam viya cetasaḥ vimokkhaḥ hoti na gata ṭṭhānam paññāyati apaṇṇattika bhāva upagamaḥ yā iva hoti iti attho
translated: so too the liberation of the mind is his liberation; no place of going is discerned; the meaning is, it has reached the state of being unlocalised.

original: 11. Saṅkavāsuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The Explanation of the Eleven Terms in the Sutta on the Inhabited Place

original: 92. Ekādasame saṅkavā nāma kosalānaṃ nigamoti saṅkavāti evaṃnāmako kosalaraṭṭhe nigamo.🔽Āvāsikoti bhārahāro nave āvāse samuṭṭhāpeti, purāṇe paṭijaggati. Sikkhāpadapaṭisaṃyuttāyāti
analyzed: ekādasame saṅkavā nāma kosalānam nigamo ti saṅkavā ati evaṃnāmakaḥ kosala raṭṭhe nigamo  āvāsikaḥ iti bhārahāraḥ nave āvāse samuṭṭhāpeti purāṇe paṭijaggati sikkhāpada paṭisaṃyuttāya ati
translated: In the eleventh place, “The inhabited place called Saṅkassa” is a market town called Saṅkassa in the Kosalan country.

original: sikkhāsaṅkhātehi padehi paṭisaṃyuttāya, tīhi sikkhāhi samannāgatāyāti attho. Sandassetīti🔽sammukhe viya katvā dasseti. Samādapetīti gaṇhāpeti. Samuttejetīti samussāheti. Sampahaṃsetīti
analyzed: sikkhā saṅkhātehi padehi paṭisaṃyuttāya tīhi sikkhāhi samannāgatāya ati atthaḥ sandasseti iti  sammukhe viya katvā dasseti samādapeti iti gaṇhāpeti samuttejeti iti samussāheti sampahaṃseti iti
translated: A carrier of a burden: a porter who builds up a new inhabited place and looks after an old one. Connected with the training precepts: connected with the terms called “training,” the meaning is, endowed with the three trainings.🔽He shows: he shows as if face to face. He instigates: he makes them take it up. He inspires: he rouses them. He gladdens: he delights them by praising the qualities they have obtained.

original: paṭiladdhaguṇehi vaṇṇaṃ kathento vodāpeti. Adhisallikhateti ativiya sallikhati, ativiya
analyzed: paṭiladdha guṇehi vaṇṇam kathentaḥ vodāpa iti adhisallikhata iti ativiya sallikhati ativiya
translated: He presses them: he presses them very hard. He exhorts: he urges them on.

original: sallikhitaṃ katvā saṇhaṃ saṇhaṃ kathetīti attho.🔽Accayoti aparādho. Maṃ accagamāti maṃ atikkamma adhibhavitvā pavatto. Ahudeva akkhantīti
analyzed: sallikhitam katvā saṇham saṇham katheti iti attho  accayaḥ iti aparādhaḥ mam accagama ati mam atikkamma adhi bhavitvā pavattaḥ ahudeva akkhanti iti
translated: and having written it down, he spoke to me gently, gently.🔽“I have offended you”: I have transgressed against you, I have overcome you. “There was no patience”:

original: ahosiyeva anadhivāsanā. Ahu appaccayoti ahosi atuṭṭhākāro. Paṭiggaṇhātūti khamatu.🔽Āyatiṃ saṃvarāyāti anāgate saṃvaratthāya, puna evarūpassa aparādhassa dosassa khalitassa🔽vā akaraṇatthāyāti attho. Tagghāti ekaṃsena. Yathādhammaṃ paṭikarosīti yathā dhammo
analyzed: ahosiyā iva anadhivāsanā ahu appaccayo ti ahosi atuṭṭha ākāraḥ paṭiggaṇhātu uti khamatu  āyatim saṃvarāya ati anāgate saṃvara tthāya punar evarūpassa aparādhassa dosassa khalitassa  vā a karaṇa atthāya ati ekaṃsena yathādhammam paṭikarosi iti yathā dhammaḥ
translated: there was no endurance, no forgiveness. “There was no satisfaction”: there was no satisfaction. “Accept”: forgive.

original: ṭhito, tathā karosi, khamāpesīti vuttaṃ hoti. Taṃ te mayaṃ paṭiggaṇhāmāti taṃ tava🔽aparādhaṃ mayaṃ khamāma. Vuddhihesā, kassapa, ariyassa vinayeti esā kassapa buddhassa
analyzed: ṭhitaḥ tathā karosi khamāpesi iti vuttam hoti tam te mayam paṭiggaṇhāma ati tam tava  aparādham mayam khamāma vuddhi ha isā kassapa ariyassa vinaya iti esā kassapa buddhassa
translated: “For restraint in the future”: for the purpose of restraint in the future, for the purpose of not doing such a thing again. “Indeed”: certainly. “You have made amends according to the rule”: you have done according to the rule, you have made amends, you have asked for forgiveness, is what is said. “We accept it from you”: we forgive your offense.

original: bhagavato sāsane vuddhi nāma. Katamā? Yāyaṃ accayaṃ accayato disvā yathādhammaṃ paṭikaritvā
analyzed: bhagavato sāsane vuddhi nāma katamā yā ayam accayam accayataḥ disvā yathādhammam paṭikaritvā
translated: “This is growth, Kassapa, in the discipline of the noble ones”: this, Kassapa, is called growth in the Dispensation of the Buddha, the Blessed One. What is it? It is this: having seen an offense as an offense, having made amends according to the rule,🔽and having asked for forgiveness,

original: āyatiṃ saṃvarāpajjanā. Desanaṃ pana puggalādhiṭṭhānaṃ karonto “yo accayaṃ accayato🔽disvā yathādhammaṃ paṭikaroti, āyatiṃ saṃvaraṃ āpajjatī”ti āha. Na sikkhākāmoti tisso🔽sikkhā na kāmeti na pattheti na piheti. Sikkhāsamādānassāti sikkhāparipūraṇassa.
analyzed: āyatim saṃvara āpajjanāḥ desanam pana puggala adhiṭṭhānam karontaḥ yaḥ accayam accayataḥ  disvā yathādhammam paṭikaroti āyatim saṃvaram āpajjati iti āha na sikkhā kāmo ti tissaḥ  sikkhā na kāmeti na pattheti na piheti sikkhā samādānassa ati sikkhā paripūraṇassa
translated: and in the future he undertakes restraint. But when he makes the exposition of the person, he says: “One who sees an offence as an offence and makes amends for it in accordance with the Dhamma, undertakes restraint in the future.” “Not desirous of training”: he does not want, does not long for, does not strive for the three trainings. “In the undertaking of the training”: in the fulfilling of the training.

original: Na vaṇṇavādīti guṇaṃ na katheti. Kālenāti yuttappayuttakālena. Sesamettha uttānatthamevāti.
analyzed: na vaṇṇa vādī iti guṇam na kathā iti kālena ati yutta ppayutta kālena sesam ettha uttānattham eva ati
translated: and in the future he undertakes restraint. But when he makes the exposition based on persons, he says: “One who sees an offence as an offence and makes amends for it in accordance with the Dhamma, undertakes restraint in the future.” “Not desirous of training”: he does not want, does not long for, does not strive after the three trainings. “In the undertaking of the training”: in the fulfilling of the training. “Not a speaker on the virtues”: he does not proclaim the virtues. “In season”: at the right time, at the proper time. The rest is clear.

original: Samaṇavaggo catuttho.
analyzed: samaṇa vaggo catutthaḥ
translated: The fourth sub-chapter on recluses is finished.

original: (10) 5. Loṇakapallavaggo
analyzed: loṇaka palla vaggo
translated: 1. The sub-chapter on the lump of salt

original: 1. Accāyikasuttavaṇṇanā🔽93. Pañcamassa paṭhame accāyikānīti atipātikāni. Karaṇīyānīti avassakiccāni. Yañhi
analyzed: accāyika sutta vaṇṇanā  pañcamassa paṭhame accāyikāni iti atipātikāni karaṇīyāni iti avassa kiccāni yat hi
translated: 1. The discussion of the Sutta on the more and the less

original: na avassaṃ kātabbaṃ, taṃ kiccanti vuccati. Avassaṃ kātabbaṃ karaṇīyaṃ nāma. Sīghaṃ🔽sīghanti vegena vegena. Tassa kho tanti ettha tanti nipātamattaṃ. Natthi sā iddhi
analyzed: na avassam kātabbam tat kiccanti vuccati avassam kātabbam karaṇīyam nāma sīgham 🔽vegena vegena tassa kho tanti ettha tanti nipāta mattam natthi sā iddhi hi
translated: In the first sutta of the fifth chapter, “the more” means the excessive. “Things to be done”: duties. For what is not a duty is called a “thing to be done.” What is a duty is called “a thing to be done.” “Quickly, quickly”: quickly, quickly. “Tassa kho” is a mere particle here.

original: vā ānubhāvo vāti sā vā iddhi so vā ānubhāvo natthi. Uttarasveti tatiyadivase. Utupariṇāminīti
analyzed: vā ānubhāvaḥ vāti sā vai id hi saḥ vai ānubhāvaḥ na atthi tatiya divase utu pariṇāminī iti
translated: or the power of psychic potency, or the psychic potency, or the power, is not there. The next day: on the third day. Changing with the season:

original: laddhautupariṇāmāni hutvā. Jāyantipīti tatiyadivase nikkhantasetaṅkurāni honti, sattāhe
analyzed: laddha autu pariṇāmāni hutvā tatiya divase nikkhanta seta aṅkurāni honti satta ahe
translated: or the power of psychic potency, is not there. The next day: on the third day. Change with the season: having changed with the season obtained. They are born: on the third day the white shoots come out. After seven days

original: patte nīlaṅkurāni honti. Gabbhīnipi hontīti diyaḍḍhamāsaṃ patvā gahitagabbhāni honti.🔽Paccantipīti tayo māse patvā paccanti. Idāni yasmā buddhānaṃ gahapatikena vā sassehi
analyzed: patte nīlaṅkurāni honti gabbhīni pi honti iti diyaḍḍha māsam patvā gahita gabbhāni honti  tayaḥ māse patvā paccanti idāni yasmai buddhānam gahapatikena vā sassehi
translated: the shoots are blue. They are in the womb: after a month and a half they are in the womb.

original: vā attho natthi, sāsane pana tappaṭirūpakaṃ puggalaṃ vā atthaṃ vā dassetuṃ taṃ taṃ🔽opammaṃ āharanti. Tasmā yamatthaṃ dassetukāmena etaṃ ābhataṃ, taṃ dassento evameva
analyzed: vā atthaḥ natthi sāsane pana tad paṭirūpakam puggalam vā attham vā dassetum tam tam  opammam āharanti tasmai yam attham dassetu kāmena etam ābhatam tam dassentaḥ evam eva
translated: They are ripe: after three months they are ripe. Now, since the Buddhas have no need of crops either for themselves or for the Sangha, the simile is used to illustrate a person or a thing in the Dispensation that corresponds to it.

original: khotiādimāha. Taṃ atthato uttānameva. Sikkhā pana idhāpi missikā eva kathitā.
analyzed: kho ti ādim āha tam atthataḥ uttānam eva sikkhā pana idha api missikā eva kathitā
translated: Therefore, since it was brought in to illustrate a certain thing, the Master said “Just so” in order to show that thing. The meaning is obvious. But the training rule here is given as mixed as before.

original: 2. Pavivekasuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the Sutta on Seclusion is finished.

original: 94. Dutiye cīvarapavivekanti cīvaraṃ nissāya uppajjanakakilesehi vivittabhāvaṃ. Sesadvayepi🔽eseva nayo. Sāṇānīti sāṇavākacelāni. Masāṇānīti missakacelāni. Chavadussānīti matasarīrato🔽chaḍḍitavatthāni, erakatiṇādīni vā ganthetvā katanivāsanāni. Paṃsukūlānīti pathaviyaṃ🔽chaḍḍitanantakāni. Tirīṭānīti rukkhatacavatthāni. Ajinānīti ajinamigacammāni. Ajinakkhipanti
analyzed: dutiye cīvara pavivekam ti cīvaram nissāya uppajjanaka kilesehi vivitta bhāvam sesa dvaye pi  esa iva nayaḥ sāṇāni iti sāṇavāka celāni masāṇāni iti missaka celāni chava dussāni iti mata sarīrataḥ  chaḍḍita vatthāni eraka tiṇa ādīni vā ganthetvā kata nivāsanāni paṃsukūlāni iti pathaviyam  chaḍḍita nantakāni tirīṭāni iti rukkha taca vatthāni ajināni iti ajina miga cammāni ajina kkhipanti
translated: In the second, the seclusion of the robe is the state of being secluded from defilements that arise with reference to the robe. The same method applies in the case of the other two. Rags from a rag-heap: rags from a heap of rags. Rags from a dust-heap: rags from a dust-heap. Rags from a shop: rags from a shop. Rags from a street: rags from a street. Rags from a charnel ground: rags from a charnel ground. Rags from a river: rags from a river. Rags from a laundry: rags from a laundry. Rags from a prison: rags from a prison. Rags from a childbed: rags from a childbed. Rags from a shop: rags from a shop. Rags from a street: rags from a street. Rags from a charnel ground: rags from a charnel ground. Rags from a river: rags from a river. Rags from a laundry: rags from a laundry. Rags from a prison: rags from a prison. Rags from a childbed: rags from a childbed.

original: tadeva majjhe phālitaṃ, sahakhurakantipi vadanti. Kusacīranti kusatiṇāni ganthetvā🔽katacīraṃ. Vākacīraphalakacīresupi eseva nayo. Kesakambalanti manussakesehi katakambalaṃ.🔽Vālakambalanti assavālādīhi katakambalaṃ. Ulūkapakkhikanti ulūkapattāni ganthetvā katanivāsanaṃ.

translated: and the possession of the speed of knowledge by means of the three paths and fruits. In the seventh sutta, the fruit of arahatship is taught,
