translated: they say, “I will know after I have reviewed it, after I have thought it over, after I have gone through it.”

original: bhavaṅgasotasadisaṃ hoti, “asukaṃ suttaṃ vā jātakaṃ vā kathehī”ti vutte uddharitvā🔽tameva katheti. Taṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ “dhātā”ti. Vacasā paricitāti suttadasaka-vaggadasakapaṇṇāsadasakavasena
analyzed: bhavaṅga sota sadisam hoti asukam suttam vā jātakam vā kathehi iti vutte uddharitvā  tam eva kathā iti tam sandhāya vuttam dhātā ati vacasā paricitā iti sutta dasaka vagga dasaka paṇṇāsa dasaka vasena
translated: For others, the well-retained is like the stream of consciousness in the life-continuum. When they are asked, “Please tell a sutta or a Jātaka,” they take it out🔽and tell it. It is with reference to this that it is said, “retained.”🔽“Well-stored in mind” means that it has been reviewed by speech, by way of the ten suttas, the ten vaggas, the ten paṇṇāsas,

original: vācāya sajjhāyitā. Manasānupekkhitāti cittena anupekkhitā. Yassa vācāya sajjhāyitaṃ
analyzed: vācāya sajjhāyitā manasā anupekkhitā ati cittena anupekkhitā yassa vācāya sajjhāyitam
translated: and the ten dasakas. “Well-considered in mind” means that it has been reviewed by the mind.

original: buddhavacanaṃ manasā cintentassa tattha tattha pākaṭaṃ hoti, mahādīpaṃ jāletvā ṭhitassa
analyzed: buddha vacanam manasā cintentassa tattha tattha pākaṭam hoti mahā dīpam jāletvā ṭhitassa
translated: When he is mentally attending to the word of the Buddha, what is clear to him is as though it were a visible object when a great lamp is lit.

original: rūpagataṃ viya paññāyati, taṃ sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ. Diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhāti atthato🔽ca kāraṇato ca paññāya suppaṭividdhā.
analyzed: rūpa gatam viya paññāyati tam sandhāya itam vuttam diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā ti atthataḥ  ca kāraṇato ca paññāya suppaṭividdhā
translated: It is with reference to this that it is said: “Well penetrated by right view” .🔽“Well penetrated by right view” : well penetrated by understanding as to meaning and as to cause.

original: Ābhicetasikānanti abhicetoti abhikkantaṃ visuddhaṃ cittaṃ vuccati, adhicittaṃ vā,
analyzed: ābhicetasikānam ti abhiceto ti abhikkantam visuddham cittam vuccati adhicittam vā
translated: “The kinds of direct-knowledge” : the word abhi is a prefix meaning “excellent” or “superior” .🔽The kinds of direct-knowledge are “born of the excellent mind” , or “dependent on the excellent mind” .

original: abhicetasi jātāni ābhicetasikāni, abhicetosannissitānīti vā ābhicetasikāni. Diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārānanti
analyzed: abhicetasi jātāni ābhicetasikāni abhicetas sannissitāni iti vā ābhicetasikāni
translated: “The pleasant dwellings here and now” :🔽“Here and now” means in this very life.

original: diṭṭhadhamme sukhavihārānaṃ. Diṭṭhadhammoti paccakkho attabhāvo vuccati, tattha sukhavihārabhūtānanti🔽attho. Rūpāvacarajjhānānametaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Tāni hi appetvā nisinnā jhāyino imasmiṃyeva
analyzed: diṭṭhadhamme sukha vihārānam diṭṭhadhammo ti paccakkhaḥ atta bhāvo vuccati tattha sukha vihāra bhūtānam ti  atthaḥ rūpāvacara jhānānam etam adhivacanam tāni hi appetvā nisinnāḥ jhāyinaḥ imasmin yeva
translated: The word diṭṭha is used here in the sense of the visible individual existence. The meaning is: “The kinds of pleasant dwellings that are in this very life.”🔽This is a designation for the jhānas of the fine-material sphere.

original: attabhāve asaṃkiliṭṭhanekkhammasukhaṃ vindanti, tasmā “diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārānī”ti
analyzed: atta bhāve asaṃkiliṭṭha nekkhamma sukham vindanti tasmai diṭṭhadhamma sukha vihārāni iti
translated: For the meditator who sits down after having given up those jhānas finds the happiness of renunciation, which is unadulterated by the jhānas, in this very individual existence. Therefore it is said: “The pleasant dwellings here and now.”

original: vuccati. Nikāmalābhīti nikāmena lābhī, attano icchāvasena lābhī, icchiticchitakkhaṇe🔽samāpajjituṃ samatthoti vuttaṃ hoti. Akicchalābhīti sukheneva paccanīkadhamme vikkhambhetvā
analyzed: vuccati nikāma lābhī iti nikāmena lābhī attano icchā vasena lābhī icchiticchita khaṇe  samāpajjitum samatthaḥ ti vuttam hoti a kiccha lābhī iti sukhena iva paccanīka dhamme vikkhambhetvā
translated: is what is said. One who has attained to it at will: one who has attained to it at will, at his own wish, at the moment he desires it,🔽is what is said. One who has attained to it without difficulty: one who has attained to it without difficulty, after suppressing opposing qualities easily,

original: samāpajjituṃ samatthoti vuttaṃ hoti. Akasiralābhīti akasirānaṃ lābhī vipulānaṃ, yathāparicchedena
analyzed: samāpajjitum samatthaḥ ti vuttam hoti akasira lābhī iti akasirānam lābhī vipulānam yathā paricchedena
translated: is what is said. One who has attained to it without expending himself: one who has attained to it without expending himself, without expending himself in the way of a wide range,

original: vuṭṭhātuṃ samatthoti vuttaṃ hoti. Ekacco hi lābhīyeva hoti, na pana icchiticchitakkhaṇe🔽sakkoti samāpajjituṃ. Ekacco sakkoti tathāsamāpajjituṃ, pāripanthike ca pana kicchena
analyzed: vuṭṭhātum samatthaḥ ti vuttam hoti ekaccaḥ hi lābhīya iva hoti na pana icchiticchita khaṇe  sakkoti samāpajjitum ekaccaḥ sakkoti tathā a samāpajjitum pāripanthike ca pana kicchena
translated: is what is said. For one person has attained to it, but he is not able to attain it at the moment he desires it;🔽another is able to attain it in that way, but he suppresses opposing qualities with difficulty;

original: vikkhambheti. Ekacco tathā ca samāpajjati, pāripanthike ca akiccheneva vikkhambheti,
analyzed: vikkhambheti ekaccaḥ tathā ca samāpajjati pāripanthike ca a kicchena iva vikkhambheti
translated: another attains it in that way and suppresses opposing qualities without difficulty,

original: na sakkoti nāḷikayantaṃ viya yathāparicchedeyeva vuṭṭhātuṃ. Yassa pana ayaṃ tividhāpi
analyzed: na sakkoti nāḷikayantam viya yathā vuṭṭhātum yassa pana ayam tividhā api
translated: but he is not able to emerge from it at the time he has decided on, as if it were a tube fastened to his head. But when a man has attained to it in all three ways,

original: sampadā atthi, so “akicchalābhī akasiralābhī”ti vuccati. Āsavānaṃ khayātiādīni vuttatthāneva.
analyzed: sampadā atthi saḥ a kiccha lābhī a kasira lābhī iti vuccati āsavānam khaya ati ādīni vutta tthāni eva
translated: He is called “one who gains without trouble, without difficulty” . “With the destruction of the taints” and so on is in the same way as before.

original: Evamidha sīlampi bāhusaccampi khīṇāsavasseva sīlaṃ bāhusaccañca, jhānānipi khīṇāsavasseva
analyzed: evam idha sīlam pi bāhusaccam pi khīṇāsavassa iva sīlam bāhusaccam ca jhānāni pi khīṇāsavassa iva
translated: So here too the virtue and learning are the virtue and learning of one whose cankers are destroyed. The jhānas are the jhānas of one whose cankers are destroyed.

original: vaḷañjanakajjhānāni kathitāni. “Āsavānaṃ khayā”tiādīhi pana arahattaṃ kathitaṃ. Phalena
analyzed: vaḷañjana kajjhānāni kathitāni āsavānam khaya ati ādīhi pana arahattam kathitam phalena
translated: The jhānas are called “the plough” . “With the destruction of the taints” and so on refers to arahatship.

original: cettha maggakiccaṃ pakāsitanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: ca ittha magga kiccam pakāsitanti veditabbam
translated: The function of the path should be understood as being revealed by the fruit.

original: Uddhatenāti uddhaccasahagatena. Samphanti palāpakathaṃ. Asamāhitasaṅkappoti aṭṭhapitasaṅkappo.
analyzed: uddhatena ati uddhacca sahagatena asamāhita saṅkappo ti aṭṭhapita saṅkappo
translated: “With a mind that is high and haughty” : with a mind accompanied by agitation. “Chatter” : talk that is mere prattle. “Uncollected in his thoughts” : his thoughts are not steadied.

original: Magoti magasadiso. Ārāti dūre. Thāvareyyamhāti thāvarabhāvato. Pāpadiṭṭhīti lāmakadiṭṭhi.
analyzed: mago ti maga sadisaḥ dūre thāvareyyamhā ati thāvara bhāvataḥ pāpa diṭṭhī iti lāmaka diṭṭhi
translated: “A jungle” : like a jungle. “A wilderness” : far away. “A bog” : because of its firmness. “Evil view” : a crooked view.

original: Anādaroti ādararahito. Sutavāti sutena upagato. Paṭibhānavāti duvidhena paṭibhānena
analyzed: ādara rahitaḥ sutavāti sutena upagataḥ paṭibhānavāti duvidhena paṭibhānena
translated: “Disrespectful” : devoid of respect. “Learned” : approached by learning. “Eloquent” : endowed with the two kinds of eloquence.

original: samannāgato. Paññāyatthaṃ vipassatīti sahavipassanāya maggapaññāya catunnaṃ saccānaṃ
analyzed: samannāgataḥ paññāya attham vipassati iti saha vipassanāya magga paññāya catunnam saccānam
translated: “He sees with insight the meaning of what is said” : with the path insight, the meaning of the four truths

original: atthaṃ vinivijjhitvā passati. Pāragū sabbadhammānanti sabbesaṃ khandhādidhammānaṃ🔽pāraṃ gato, abhiññāpāragū, pariññāpāragū, pahānapāragū, bhāvanāpāragū, sacchikiriyāpāragū,
analyzed: attham vinivijjhitvā passati pāragū sabba dhammānam ti sabbesam khandha ādi dhammānam  pāram gataḥ abhiññā pāragū pariññā pāragū pahāna pāragū bhāvanā pāragū sacchikiriyā pāragū
translated: He has gone to the far shore of all things: he has gone to the far shore, the end, of all things classed as aggregates, etc.,

original: samāpattipāragūti evaṃ chabbidhena pāragamanena sabbadhammānaṃ pāraṃ pariyosānaṃ
analyzed: evam chabbidhena pāra gamanena sabba dhammānam pāram pariyosānam
translated: by the six kinds of “going to the far shore,” namely, by “going to the far shore” of direct knowledge, of full understanding, of abandoning, of development, of realization, and of attainment.🔽He is without blemish: he is devoid of the blemishes of lust, etc.

original: gato. Akhiloti rāgakhilādivirahito. Paṭibhānavāti duvidheneva paṭibhānena samannāgato.
analyzed: gataḥ akhilaḥ ti rāga khila ādi virahito paṭibhānavā ati duvidhena iva paṭibhānena samannāgato
translated: He is of penetrative wisdom: he is endowed with the two kinds of penetrative insight.

original: Brahmacariyassa kevalīti sakalabrahmacariyo. Sesamettha uttānamevāti.🔽3. Lokasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: brahmacariyassa kevalī iti sakala brahmacariyaḥ sesam ettha uttānam eva ati
translated: He is the supreme one in the life of purity: he is the one who has completed the whole life of purity.🔽The rest here is self-evident.🔽. The exposition of the third chapter called “The World” is ended.

original: 23. Tatiye lokoti dukkhasaccaṃ. Abhisambuddhoti ñāto paccakkho kato. Lokasmāti dukkhasaccato.
analyzed: tatiye loko ti dukkha saccam abhisambuddho ti ñāto paccakkho kataḥ lokasmā ati dukkha saccato
translated: In the third chapter called “The World” the word “world” is the truth of suffering.🔽“Fully awakened” : known, recognized.🔽“From the world”: from the truth of suffering.🔽“Abandoned”: abandoned by the knowledge of the path of arahantship at the Great Enlightenment.

original: Pahīnoti mahābodhimaṇḍe arahattamaggañāṇena pahīno. Tathāgatassa bhāvitāti tathāgatena bhāvitā.
analyzed: pahīno ti mahā bodhimaṇḍe arahatta magga ñāṇena pahīno tathāgatassa bhāvitā ati tathāgatena bhāvitā
translated: “The Tathāgata’s development”: the Tathāgata’s practice.

original: Evaṃ ettakena ṭhānena catūhi saccehi attano buddhabhāvaṃ kathetvā idāni tathāgatabhāvaṃ
analyzed: evam ettakena ṭhānena catūhi saccehi attanaḥ buddha bhāvam kathetvā idāni tathāgata bhāvam
translated: Having thus far spoken of his own Buddhahood in terms of the four Truths, he now speaks of his Tathāgatahood in terms of the four Noble Truths.

original: kathetuṃ yaṃ, bhikkhavetiādimāha. Tattha diṭṭhanti rūpāyatanaṃ. Sutanti saddāyatanaṃ.
analyzed: kathetum yam bhikkhave ti ādim āha tattha diṭṭham ti rūpa āyatanam sutam ti sadda āyatanam
translated: Herein, seen means the visible-form base. Heard means the sound base.

original: Mutanti patvā gahetabbato gandhāyatanaṃ rasāyatanaṃ phoṭṭhabbāyatanaṃ. Viññātanti
analyzed: mutanti patvā gahetabbataḥ gandha āyatanam rasa āyatanam phoṭṭhabba āyatanam viññātanti
translated: Sensed means the odour, flavour, and tangible-object bases, because they are sensed by being taken to oneself.🔽Cognized means cognized by the mind as the object of the happiness, grief, and equanimity ideas.🔽Attained means attained by searching for it or without searching for it.🔽Sought means either attained or unattained by searching for it.

original: sukhadukkhādi dhammārammaṇaṃ. Pattanti pariyesitvā vā apariyesitvā vā pattaṃ. Pariyesitanti
analyzed: sukha dukkha ādi dhamma ārammaṇam pattanti pariyesitvā vā a pariyesitvā vā pattam pariyesitanti
translated: Well investigated with understanding means well investigated by the understanding.🔽Well penetrated with wisdom means well penetrated by the wisdom.🔽Well seen means well seen by the eye.🔽Well heard means well heard by the ear.🔽Well sensed means well sensed by the mind.🔽Well cognized means well cognized by the mind.🔽Well cognized with over-all understanding means well cognized by the over-all understanding.

original: pattaṃ vā appattaṃ vā pariyesitaṃ. Anuvicaritaṃ manasāti cittena anusañcaritaṃ.
analyzed: pattam vā appattam vā pariyesitam anuvicaritam manasā ati cittena anusañcaritam
translated: Well penetrated with wisdom means well penetrated by the wisdom.🔽Well seen means well seen by the eye.🔽Well heard means well heard by the ear.🔽Well sensed means well sensed by the mind.🔽Well cognized means well cognized by the mind.

original: Tathāgatena abhisambuddhanti iminā etaṃ dasseti – yaṃ aparimāṇāsu lokadhātūsu imassa
analyzed: tathāgatena abhisambuddhanti iminā etam dasseti yam aparimāṇāsu lokadhātūsu imassa
translated: Well cognized with over-all understanding means well cognized by the over-all understanding.🔽Well penetrated with wisdom means well penetrated by the wisdom.🔽Well seen means well seen by the eye.🔽Well heard means well heard by the ear.🔽Well sensed means well sensed by the mind.🔽Well cognized means well cognized by the mind.🔽Well cognized with over-all understanding means well cognized by the over-all understanding.🔽Well penetrated with wisdom means well penetrated by the wisdom.🔽Well seen means well seen by the eye.

original: sadevakassa lokassa nīlaṃ pītakantiādi rūpārammaṇaṃ cakkhudvāre āpāthaṃ āgacchati,
analyzed: sa devakassa lokassa nīlam pīta kanti ādi rūpa ārammaṇam cakkhu dvāre āpātham āgacchati
translated: Well heard means well heard by the ear.🔽Well sensed means well sensed by the mind.🔽Well cognized means well cognized by the mind.🔽Well cognized with over-all understanding means well cognized by the over-all understanding.🔽Well penetrated with wisdom means well penetrated by the wisdom.🔽Well seen means well seen by the eye.🔽Well heard means well heard by the ear.🔽Well sensed means well sensed by the mind.🔽Well cognized means well cognized by the mind.

original: “ayaṃ satto imasmiṃ khaṇe imaṃ nāma rūpārammaṇaṃ disvā sumano vā dummano vā majjhatto
analyzed: ayam satto imasmin khaṇe imam nāma rūpa ārammaṇam disvā sumanaḥ vā dummanaḥ vā majjhattaḥ
translated: Well cognized with over-all understanding means well cognized by the over-all understanding.

original: vā jāto”ti sabbaṃ tathāgatassa evaṃ abhisambuddhaṃ. Tathā yaṃ aparimāṇāsu lokadhātūsu
analyzed: vā jātaḥ ti sabbam tathāgatassa evam abhisambuddham tathā yam aparimāṇāsu lokadhātūsu
translated: and so on, all this was fully awakened to by the Tathāgata. And so too with the infinite world systems.

original: imassa sadevakassa lokassa bherisaddo mudiṅgasaddotiādi saddārammaṇaṃ sotadvāre āpāthaṃ🔽āgacchati, mūlagandho tacagandhotiādi gandhārammaṇaṃ ghānadvāre āpāthaṃ āgacchati,
analyzed: imassa sa devakassa lokassa bheri saddaḥ mudiṅga saddaḥ ti ādi sadda ārammaṇam sota dvāre āpātham  āgacchati mūla gandho taca gandho iti ādi gandha ārammaṇam ghāna dvāre āpātham āgacchati
translated: and so on, all this the Tathāgata has discovered thus. And so too with the sound objects consisting of the sound of the drum, the sound of the tabor, and so on, in the countless world systems, which come within the avenue of the ear door,🔽with the odour objects consisting of root odour, heartwood odour, and so on, which come within the avenue of the nose door,

original: mūlaraso khandharasotiādi rasārammaṇaṃ jivhādvāre āpāthaṃ āgacchati, kakkhaḷaṃ mudukantiādi
analyzed: mūla rasaḥ khandha rasaḥ tiādi rasa ārammaṇam jivhā dvāre āpātham āgacchati kakkhaḷam mudukam tiādi
translated: with the flavour objects consisting of root flavour, heartwood flavour, and so on, which come within the avenue of the tongue door,

original: pathavīdhātutejodhātuvāyodhātubhedaṃ phoṭṭhabbārammaṇaṃ kāyadvāre āpāthaṃ āgacchati,🔽“ayaṃ satto imasmiṃ khaṇe imaṃ nāma phoṭṭhabbārammaṇaṃ phusitvā sumano vā dummano🔽vā majjhatto vā jāto”ti sabbaṃ tathāgatassa evaṃ abhisambuddhaṃ. Tathā yaṃ aparimāṇāsu
analyzed: pathavī dhātu tejaḥ dhātu vāyo dhātu bhedam phoṭṭhabba ārammaṇam kāya dvāre āpātham āgacchati  ayam satto imasmin khaṇe imam nāma phoṭṭhabba ārammaṇam phusitvā sumanaḥ vā dummanaḥ  vā majjhattaḥ vā jātaḥ ti sabbam tathāgatassa evam abhisambuddham tathā yam aparimāṇāsu
translated: with the tangible objects consisting of the earth element, the fire element, the air element, and so on, which come within the avenue of the body door,

original: lokadhātūsu imassa sadevakassa lokassa sukhadukkhādibhedaṃ dhammārammaṇaṃ manodvārassa
analyzed: lokadhātūsu imassa sa devakassa lokassa sukha dukkha ādi bhedam dhamma ārammaṇam manaḥ dvārassa
translated: and with the mental objects consisting of the consciousness element, the mental-data element, and so on, which come within the avenue of the mind door. And he knows that at the moment of touching a tangible object, a being is glad, or sad, or neither glad nor sad. All this the Tathāgata has discovered thus. And so too with the mental objects consisting of the happiness, grief, and equanimity of beings in the countless world systems, which come within the avenue of the mind door.

original: āpāthaṃ āgacchati, “ayaṃ satto imasmiṃ khaṇe imaṃ nāma dhammārammaṇaṃ vijānitvā sumano🔽vā dummano vā majjhatto vā jāto”ti sabbaṃ tathāgatassa evaṃ abhisambuddhaṃ. Yañhi,
analyzed: āpātham āgacchati ayam satto imasmin khaṇe imam nāma dhamma ārammaṇam vijānitvā su mano  vā dummanaḥ vā majjhattaḥ vā jātaḥ iti sabbam tathāgatassa evam abhisambuddham yat hi
translated: and it comes within the range of his knowledge, then the Tathāgata understands that at that moment this being was conscious of such and such an object and was glad or sorry or indifferent, and all this is known to the Tathāgata as it really is.

original: bhikkhave, imesaṃ sabbasattānaṃ diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ mutaṃ viññātaṃ, tattha tathāgatena
analyzed: bhikkhave imesam sabba sattānam diṭṭham sutam mutam viññātam tattha tathāgatena
translated: For, bhikkhus, whatever is seen, heard, sensed, or otherwise known by all beings,🔽there is nothing that is not known to the Tathāgata,

original: adiṭṭhaṃ vā asutaṃ vā amutaṃ vā aviññātaṃ vā natthi, imassa pana mahājanassa pariyesitvā🔽appattampi atthi, apariyesitvā appattampi atthi, pariyesitvā pattampi atthi, apariyesitvā
analyzed: a diṭṭham vā a sutam vā a mutam vā a viññātam vā na atthi imassa pana mahājanassa pariyesitvā  appattam pi atthi a pariyesitvā appattam pi atthi pariyesitvā pattam pi atthi a pariyesitvā
translated: and there is nothing that is not seen, nothing that is not heard, nothing that is not sensed, nothing that is not otherwise known.

original: pattampi atthi, sabbampi tathāgatassa appattaṃ nāma natthi ñāṇena asacchikataṃ.🔽Tasmā tathāgatoti vuccatīti yaṃ yathā lokena gataṃ, tassa tatheva gatattā tathāgatoti
analyzed: pattam pi atthi sabbam pi tathāgatassa appattam nāma natthi ñāṇena asacchikatam  tasmā tathāgataḥ iti vuccati iti yam yathā lokena gatam tassa tathā iva gata ttā tathāgataḥ ti
translated: There is nothing that is not seen by the Tathāgata, nothing that is not heard by him, nothing that is not sensed by him, nothing that is not otherwise known by him.🔽Therefore he is called the Tathāgata.

original: vuccati. Pāḷiyaṃ pana “abhisambuddha”nti vuttaṃ, taṃ gatasaddena ekatthaṃ. Iminā
analyzed: vuccati pāḷiyam pana abhisambuddhanti vuttam tam gata saddena ekattham iminā
translated: In the text it is said “he has awakened to” , but that is the same in meaning as “he has gone to” .

original: nayena sabbavāresu tathāgatoti nigamassa attho veditabbo. Tassa yutti ekapuggalavaṇṇanāyaṃ
analyzed: nayena sabba vāresu tathāgato ti nigamassa atthaḥ veditabbo tassa yutti eka puggala vaṇṇanā ayam
translated: and in all the other cases the meaning of the expression “Tathāgata” should be understood as stated in the method of explanation given above. The rationale for this method of explanation is given in the commentary on the section on the single person.

original: tathāgatasaddavitthāre vuttāyeva. Apicettha aññadatthūti ekaṃsatthe nipāto. Dakkhatīti
analyzed: tathāgata sadda vitthāre vuttāya iva apica ittha ekaṃsatthe nipātaḥ dakkhati iti
translated: The meaning of the name “Tathāgata” should be understood in all the passages in the same way. The explanation of the derivation of the name is given in the commentary on the verse of the single person.

original: daso. Vasaṃ vattetīti vasavattī.
analyzed: dasaḥ vasam vatta iti iti vasa vattī
translated: The word “also” is a particle in the sense of “another meaning.” “He will see” is “daso.” “He rules” is “vasavattī.”

original: Sabbaṃ lokaṃ abhiññāti tedhātukaṃ lokasannivāsaṃ jānitvā. Sabbaṃ loke yathātathanti🔽tasmiṃ tedhātukalokasannivāse yaṃkiñci neyyaṃ, sabbaṃ taṃ yathātathaṃ aviparītaṃ
analyzed: sabbam lokam abhiññāti tedhātukam loka sannivāsam jānitvā sabbam loke yathātathanti  tasmin tedhātuka loka sannivāse yaṃ kiñci neyyam sabbam tam yathātatham aviparītam
translated: “He knows the world” is “sabbaṃ lokaṃ abhiññā.” Having known the world as a place of habitation consisting of the three planes. “He knows the world as it really is” is

original: jānitvā. Visaṃyuttoti catunnaṃ yogānaṃ pahānena visaṃyutto. Anūpayoti taṇhādiṭṭhiupayehi
analyzed: jānitvā visaṃyuttaḥ ti catunnam yogānam pahānena visaṃyuttaḥ taṇhā diṭṭhi upayehi
translated: “sabbaṃ loke yathātathaṃ.” Having known whatever is to be known in the world consisting of the three planes as it really is, without perverting it. “He is detached” is “visaṃyutto.” Having abandoned the four bonds. “He is without attachment” is “anūpayo.”

original: virahito. Sabbābhibhūti rūpādīni sabbārammaṇāni abhibhavitvā ṭhito. Dhīroti dhitisampanno.
analyzed: virahitaḥ rūpa ādīni sabba ārammaṇāni abhibhavitvā ṭhitaḥ dhīro ti dhiti sampanno
translated: Being devoid of craving and views as means of attachment. “He has overcome all” is “sabbaṃ abhibhū.” Having overcome all objects such as visible forms, etc., he stands. “He is wise” is “dhī.” Being endowed with steadfastness.

original: Sabbaganthappamocanoti sabbe cattāropi ganthe mocetvā ṭhito. Phuṭṭhassāti phuṭṭhā
analyzed: sabba gantha ppamocanoti sabbe cattāro api ganthe mocetvā ṭhitaḥ phuṭṭhassa ati phuṭṭhā
translated: “He is the emancipator from all bonds” is “sabbaganthappamocano.” Having emancipated himself from all four bonds, he stands. “He has touched” is “phuṭṭhassa.”

original: assa. Idañca karaṇatthe sāmivacanaṃ. Paramā santīti nibbānaṃ. Tañhi tena ñāṇaphusanena
analyzed: assa idam ca karaṇa atthe sāmivacanam paramāḥ santi iti nibbānam tat hi tena ñāṇa phusanena
translated: and this is a genitive of relationship in the sense of instrument. The supreme peace is Nibbāna. For that is the supreme peace because it is the peace of the highest kind.

original: phuṭṭhaṃ. Tenevāha – nibbānaṃ akutobhayanti. Atha vā paramāsantīti uttamā santi.🔽Katarā sāti? Nibbānaṃ. Yasmā pana nibbāne kutoci bhayaṃ natthi, tasmā taṃ akutobhayanti
analyzed: phuṭṭham tena iva āha nibbānam akutobhayanti atha vā paramā asanti iti uttamā santi  katarā sā ati nibbānam yasmā pana nibbāne kutoci bhayam na atthi tasmā tam akutobhayanti
translated: and this is a genitive of relationship in the sense of instrument. ‘The supreme peace’: Nibbāna. For that is touched by the touch of that knowledge. Hence it is said: ‘Nibbāna, free from all fear’ . Or alternatively, ‘the supreme peace’ is the highest peace.

original: vuccati. Vimutto upadhisaṅkhayeti upadhisaṅkhayasaṅkhāte nibbāne tadārammaṇāya phalavimuttiyā
analyzed: vuccati vimuttaḥ upadhi saṅkhaye ti upadhi saṅkhaya saṅkhāte nibbāne tad ārammaṇāya phala vimuttiyā
translated: What is that? It is Nibbāna. But since there is no fear in Nibbāna from anywhere, it is said to be ‘free from all fear’ . ‘Liberated by the destruction of craving’: liberated in Nibbāna, called the destruction of craving, by the fruit-of-liberation that has that as its object.

original: vimutto. Sīho anuttaroti parissayānaṃ sahanaṭṭhena kilesānañca hiṃsanaṭṭhena tathāgato🔽anuttaro sīho nāma. Brahmanti seṭṭhaṃ. Itīti evaṃ tathāgatassa guṇe jānitvā. Saṅgammāti🔽samāgantvā. Taṃ namassantīti taṃ tathāgataṃ te saraṇaṃ gatā namassanti. Idāni yaṃ
analyzed: vimuttaḥ sīhaḥ anuttaro ti parissayānam sahana ṭhena kilesānam ca hiṃsana ṭhena tathāgato  anuttaraḥ sīhaḥ nāma brahmanti seṭṭham iti iti evam tathāgatassa guṇe jānitvā saṅgamma ati  samāgantvā tam namassanti iti tam tathāgatam te saraṇam gatāḥ namassanti idāni yam
translated: ‘The unsurpassed lion’: the Tathāgata is called the unsurpassed lion because of his ability to endure all troubles and to destroy all defilements.

original: vadantā te namassanti, taṃ dassetuṃ dantotiādi vuttaṃ. Taṃ uttānatthamevāti.
analyzed: vadantā te namassanti tam dassetum danta uti ādi vuttam tam uttāna attham eva ati
translated: ‘The Brahman’: the best. ‘Thus’: in this way. ‘Having known’: having known the Tathāgata’s special qualities. ‘Having come together’: having assembled. ‘They honour him’: those who have gone to him for refuge honour the Tathāgata. Now, in order to show what they honour by saying ‘we honour him’, it is said: ‘The tamed one …’ The meaning is evident.

analyzed: tatas acelakā mahā seṭṭhi kutas te evarūpā kālakaṇṇī laddhā kim sakala jambudīpe aññā  dārikā natthi iti seṭṭhim paribhāsiṃsu so ācariyā jānitvā vā katam hotu a jānitvā

translated: The Teacher preached the Law. The merchant Kāḷaka became a Stream-enterer and gave his own garden to the Teacher.

original: Acelakā “amhākaṃ paṭhamaṃ dinna”nti nikkhamituṃ na icchanti. “Gacchatha nīharitabbaniyāmena
analyzed: acelakāḥ amhākam paṭhamam dinnanti nikkhamitum na icchanti gacchatha nīharitabba niyāmena
translated: The naked ascetics said, “This was given to us first.” They refused to move out. “Go and have them removed by force.

original: te nīharathā”ti sabbe nīharāpetvā tattheva satthu vihāraṃ kāretvā brahmadeyyaṃ katvā
analyzed: te nīharatha ati sabbe nīharāpetvā tattha iva satthu vihāram kāretvā brahmadeyyam katvā
translated: They are to be removed.” So they removed them all, and there and then built a monastery for the Teacher, and made a gift of it to him.

original: udakaṃ pātesi. So kāḷakena kāritatāya kāḷakārāmo nāma jāto. Bhagavā tasmiṃ samaye
analyzed: udakam pātesi saḥ kāḷakena kārita tāya kāḷaka ārāmaḥ nāma jātaḥ bhagavā tasmin samaye
translated: and he poured water on it. Because it was made by Kāḷaka, it was called Kāḷakārāma. The Blessed One was

original: tattha viharati. Tena vuttaṃ – “sākete viharati kāḷakārāme”ti.
analyzed: tattha viharati tena vuttam sākete viharati kāḷakārāma iti
translated: residing there at that time. Therefore it is said: “He was staying at Sāketa in the Kāḷakārāma.”

original: Bhikkhū āmantesīti pañcasate bhikkhū āmantesi. Te kira sāketanagaravāsino kulaputtā
analyzed: bhikkhū āmantesi iti pañcasate bhikkhū āmantesi te kira sāketa nagara vāsinaḥ kula puttā
translated: He addressed the bhikkhus: he addressed the five hundred bhikkhus. It seems that these young men, residents of the city of Sāketa,

original: satthu dhammadesanaṃ sutvā satthu santike pabbajitvā upaṭṭhānasālāya nisinnā “aho
analyzed: satthu dhamma desanam sutvā satthu santike pabbajitvā upaṭṭhāna sālāya nisinnā aho
translated: having heard the Teacher preach the Dhamma, went forth into homelessness in the presence of the Teacher. Sitting in the attendance hall, they said,

original: buddhaguṇā nāma mahantā, evarūpaṃ nāma micchādiṭṭhikaṃ kāḷakaseṭṭhiṃ diṭṭhito mocetvā
analyzed: buddha guṇāḥ nāma mahantaḥ evarūpam nāma micchādiṭṭhikam kāḷakaseṭṭhim diṭṭhitaḥ mocetvā
translated: “Oh, the Buddha’s qualities are great! Having freed from wrong views the wealthy man Kāḷaka, who was such,

original: sotāpattiphalaṃ pāpetvā sakalanagaraṃ satthārā devalokasadisaṃ kata”nti dasabalassa
analyzed: sotāpatti phalam pāpetvā sakala nagaram satthārā deva loka sadisam dasabalassa
translated: and having caused him to attain the fruit of stream-entry, the Teacher has made the whole city like the world of the gods.” Thus they praised the qualities of the One of Ten Powers.

original: guṇaṃ kathenti. Satthā tesaṃ guṇaṃ kathentānaṃ cittaṃ upaparikkhitvā – “mayi gate
analyzed: guṇam kathenti satthā tesam guṇam kathentānam cittam upaparikkhitvā mayi gate
translated: The Teacher, investigating their minds as they praised his qualities, thought,

original: mahatī desanā samuṭṭhissati, desanāpariyosāne ca ime pañcasatā bhikkhū arahatte patiṭṭhahissanti,
analyzed: mahatī desanā samuṭṭhissati desanā pariyosāne ca ime pañcasatāḥ bhikkhū arahatte patiṭṭhahissanti
translated: “If I go there, a great discourse will arise, and at the conclusion of the discourse these five hundred bhikkhus will be established in arahatship.

original: mahāpathavī udakapariyantaṃ katvā kampissatī”ti dhammasabhaṃ gantvā paññattavarabuddhāsane
analyzed: mahā pathavī udaka pariyantam katvā kampissati iti dhammasabham gantvā paññatta vara buddha āsane
translated: and the great earth will quake down to the ocean’s shore.” Then he went to the Dhamma-hall, sat down on the prepared seat,

original: nisinno te bhikkhū ādiṃ katvā yaṃ, bhikkhave, sadevakassa lokassāti imaṃ desanaṃ
analyzed: nisinnaḥ te bhikkhū ādim katvā yam bhikkhave sa devakassa lokassa ati imam desanam
translated: and began the discourse with the words, “Monks, I know the world with its devas, its Mara, and its Brahma, this generation with its ascetics and brahmans, with its devas and hum an beings, and I know it to be void.

original: ārabhi. Evamidaṃ suttaṃ guṇakathāya nikkhittanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: ārabhi evam idam suttam guṇa kathāya nikkhittanti veditabbam
translated: ” Thus the discourse should be understood as given in praise of the qualities of the Buddha.

original: Tattha “tamahaṃ jānāmī”ti padapariyosāne mahāpathavī udakapariyantaṃ katvā akampittha.🔽Abbhaññāsinti abhiaññāsiṃ, jāninti attho. Viditanti pākaṭaṃ katvā ñātaṃ. Iminā etaṃ
analyzed: tattha tam aham jānāmi iti pada pariyosāne mahā pathavī udaka pariyantam katvā akampittha  abbhaññāsinti abhiaññāsim jāninti atthaḥ viditanti pākaṭam katvā ñātam iminā etam
translated: Herein, when he came to the words, “I know the world with its devas,” the great earth quaked down to the ocean’s shore.

original: dasseti – aññe jānantiyeva, mayā pana pākaṭaṃ katvā viditanti. Imehi tīhi padehi🔽sabbaññutabhūmi nāma kathitā. Taṃ tathāgato na upaṭṭhāsīti taṃ chadvārikaṃ ārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: dassā iti aññe jānantiyā iva mayā pana pākaṭam katvā viditam ti imehi tīhi padehi  sabbaññuta bhūmi nāma kathitā tam tathāgataḥ na upaṭṭhāsi iti tam cha dvārikam ārammaṇam
translated: I have directly known : I have known by direct knowledge. I have understood : I have known by understanding. With these three words

original: tathāgato taṇhāya vā diṭṭhiyā vā na upaṭṭhāsi na upagañchi. Ayañhi passati bhagavā
analyzed: tathāgato taṇhāya vā diṭṭhiyā vā na upaṭṭhāsi na upagañchi ayam hi passati bhagavā
translated: the plane of omniscience is stated. The Tathagata does not attend to it : the Tathagata does not attend to the sixfold base as object through craving or views. For the Blessed One sees

original: cakkhunā rūpaṃ, chandarāgo bhagavato natthi, suvimuttacitto so bhagavā. Suṇāti bhagavā🔽sotena saddaṃ. Ghāyati bhagavā ghānena gandhaṃ. Sāyati bhagavā jivhāya rasaṃ. Phusati🔽bhagavā kāyena phoṭṭhabbaṃ. Vijānāti bhagavā manasā dhammaṃ, chandarāgo bhagavato
analyzed: cakkhunā rūpam chanda rāgaḥ bhagavataḥ natthi su vimutta cittaḥ so bhagavā suṇāti bhagavā  sotena saddam ghāyati bhagavā ghānena gandham sāyati bhagavā jivhāya rasam phusati  bhagavā kāyena phoṭṭhabbam vijānāti bhagavā manasā dhammam chanda rāgaḥ bhagavataḥ
translated: with the eye and form, the Fortunate One has no desire and passion, the Fortunate One’s mind is well freed. The Fortunate One hears🔽with the ear and sound. The Fortunate One smells with the nose and smells. The Fortunate One tastes with the tongue and tastes. The Fortunate One touches🔽with the body and tangibles. The Fortunate One knows with the mind and thoughts, the Fortunate One has no desire and passion,

original: natthi, suvimuttacitto so bhagavā. Tena vuttaṃ – “taṃ tathāgato na upaṭṭhāsī”ti.
analyzed: natthi su vimutta cittaḥ saḥ bhagavā tena vuttam tam tathāgataḥ na upaṭṭhāsi iti
translated: The Blessed One has no desire-and-lust for visible forms cognizable by the eye, and his mind is well liberated. The Blessed One hears sounds cognizable by the ear … smells scents cognizable by the nose … tastes flavours cognizable by the tongue … touches tangible things cognizable by the body … cognizes mental objects cognizable by the mind, and his mind is well liberated. Therefore it was said: ‘The Tathāgata did not acquiesce in that’ .

original: Iminā padena khīṇāsavabhūmi kathitāti veditabbā.🔽Taṃ mamassa musāti taṃ me vacanaṃ musāvādo nāma bhaveyya. Taṃ passa tādisamevāti
analyzed: iminā padena khīṇāsava bhūmi kathitā iti veditabbā  tam mama assa musā ati tam me vacanam musāvādaḥ nāma bhaveyya tam passa tādisam eva ati
translated: This phrase should be understood as the plane of the exhaustion of taints.🔽That would be a lie for me: that statement of mine would be a lie. See that it is just the same for you: that would be a lie for you too.

original: tampi musāvādo bhaveyya. Taṃ mamassa kalīti taṃ vacanaṃ mayhaṃ doso bhaveyyāti attho.
analyzed: tam pi musāvādaḥ bhaveyya tam mamassa kalī iti tam vacanam mayham dosaḥ bhaveyya ati attho
translated: That would be a fault for me: the meaning is that that statement would be a fault for me.

original: Ettāvatā saccabhūmi nāma kathitāti veditabbā.
analyzed: ettāvatā saccabhūmi nāma kathitā ati veditabbā
translated: Up to this point the plane of truth should be understood as stated.

original: Daṭṭhā daṭṭhabbanti disvā daṭṭhabbaṃ. Diṭṭhaṃ na maññatīti taṃ diṭṭhaṃ rūpāyatanaṃ
analyzed: daṭṭhā daṭṭhabbanti disvā daṭṭhabbam diṭṭham na maññati iti tam diṭṭham rūpa āyatanam
translated: Having seen what is to be seen: having seen what is to be seen. He does not think ‘Seen’: he does not think ‘That visible-form base has been seen’

original: “ahaṃ mahājanena diṭṭhameva passāmī”ti taṇhāmānadiṭṭhīhi na maññati. Adiṭṭhaṃ na🔽maññatīti “ahaṃ mahājanena adiṭṭhameva etaṃ passāmī”ti evampi taṇhādīhi maññanāhi
analyzed: aham mahājanena diṭṭham eva passāmi iti taṇhā māna diṭṭhīhi na maññati adiṭṭham na  maññati iti aham mahājanena adiṭṭham eva etam passāmi iti evam pi taṇhā ādīhi maññanāhi
translated: “I see what the multitude sees,” he does not conceive in terms of craving, conceit, or views. He does not conceive what is not seen.🔽“I see what the multitude does not see,” he does not conceive in terms of craving, etc.

original: na maññati. Daṭṭhabbaṃ na maññatīti “mahājanena diṭṭhaṃ passāmī”ti evampi tāhi maññanāhi🔽na maññati. Daṭṭhabbañhi adiṭṭhampi hotiyeva. Evarūpāni hi vacanāni tīsupi kālesu🔽labbhanti, tenassa attho vutto. Daṭṭhāraṃ na maññatīti passitāraṃ ekasattaṃ nāma
analyzed: na maññati daṭṭhabbam na maññati iti mahājanena diṭṭham passāmi iti evam pi tāhi maññanāhi  na maññati daṭṭhabbam hi a diṭṭham pi evarūpāni hi vacanāni tīsu pi kālesu  labbhanti tena assa atthaḥ vuttaḥ daṭṭhāram na maññati iti passitāram ekasattam nāma
translated: He does not conceive what should be seen. “I see what the multitude sees,” he does not conceive in terms of craving, etc.🔽For what should be seen is seen even by the multitude. Such statements are possible in all three tenses, and that is why the meaning is stated in this way.🔽He does not conceive a seer. The meaning is that he does not conceive a single being who sees in terms of craving, etc.

original: tāhi maññanāhi na maññatīti attho. Sesaṭṭhānesupi imināva nayena attho veditabbo.
analyzed: tāhi maññanāhi na maññati iti attho sesa ṭṭhānesu pi iminā ava nayena atthaḥ veditabbo
translated: The meaning should be understood in the same way in the other instances.

original: Iminā ettakena ṭhānena suññatābhūmi nāma kathitā.
analyzed: iminā ettakena ṭhānena suññatābhūmi nāma kathitā
translated: Up to this point the plane of voidness has been expounded.🔽Thus, bhikkhus: in this way, bhikkhus.

original: Iti kho, bhikkhaveti evaṃ kho, bhikkhave. Tādīyeva tādīti tāditā nāma ekasadisatā.
analyzed: iti kho bhikkhave iti evam kho bhikkhave tādīyā iva tādī iti tādi tā nāma eka sadisa tā
translated: The same, the same: the same is the same.

original: Tathāgato ca yādiso lābhādīsu, tādisova alābhādīsu. Tena vuttaṃ – “lābhepi tādī,🔽alābhepi tādī. Yasepi tādī, ayasepi tādī. Nindāyapi tādī, pasaṃsāyapi tādī. Sukhepi🔽tādī, dukkhepi tādī”ti. Imāya tāditāya tādī. Tamhā ca pana tādimhāti tato tathāgatatādito
analyzed: tathāgataḥ ca yādisaḥ lābha ādīsu tādisaḥ uva alābha ādīsu tena vuttam  alābhepi tādī yasepi tādī a yasepi tādī nindāyapi tādī tādī sukhepi  tādī dukkhe pi tādī iti imāya tāditāya tādī tamhā ca pana tato tathāgata tādito
translated: And the Tathāgata is the same in regard to gain and so on as he is in regard to non-gain and so on. Hence it is said: “The same in regard to gain and in regard to non-gain, in regard to fame and to obscurity, in regard to honours and to want of them, in regard to happiness and to suffering” . He is the same in regard to these things. And he is the same in regard to that sameness.🔽

original: añño uttaritaro vā paṇītataro vā tādī natthīti ettāvatā tādibhūmi nāma kathitā. Imāhi
analyzed: aññaḥ uttaritaraḥ vā paṇītataraḥ vā tādī natthi iti ettāvatā tādibhūmi nāma kathitā
translated: The Tathāgata is the same in regard to gain and so on as he is in regard to non-gain and so on. Hence it is said: “The same in regard to gain and in regard to non-gain, in regard to fame and in regard to obscurity, in regard to honours and in regard to discourtesy, in regard to happiness and in regard to suffering” . This is the meaning of “the same.” And there is no one else who is the same as the Tathāgata in this way. This is the meaning of “no other is there equal to him.” Thus the plane of equality is stated.

original: pañcabhūmīhi desanaṃ niṭṭhāpentassa pañcasupi ṭhānesu mahāpathavī sakkhibhāvena akampittha.🔽Desanāpariyosāne te pañcasate adhunāpabbajite kulaputte ādiṃ katvā taṃ ṭhānaṃ pattānaṃ
analyzed: pañca bhūmīhi desanam niṭṭhāpentassa pañcasu pi ṭhānesu mahā pathavī sakkhi bhāvena akampittha  desanā pariyosāne te pañcasate adhunāpabbajite kula putte ādim katvā tam ṭhānam pattānam
translated: When he had finished his teaching with these five planes, the great earth shook in five ways in the five places.

original: devamanussānaṃ caturāsīti pāṇasahassāni amatapānaṃ piviṃsu.
analyzed: deva manussānam catur āsīti pāṇa sahassāni amata pānam piviṃsu
translated: At the conclusion of the teaching, eighty-four thousand breathing beings, beginning with the five hundred clansmen who had recently gone forth, drank the deathless draught by attaining it.

original: Bhagavāpi suttaṃ niṭṭhāpetvā gāthāhi kūṭaṃ gaṇhanto yaṃkiñcītiādimāha. Tattha ajjhositaṃ
analyzed: bhagavā api suttam niṭṭhāpetvā gāthāhi kūṭam gaṇhantaḥ yaṃkiñci iti ādim āha tattha ajjhositam
translated: And the Blessed One, having finished the sutta, took up the theme again in the verses beginning: “Whatever” . Here is the meaning in brief:

original: saccamutaṃ paresanti paresaṃ saddhāya parapattiyāyanāya saccamutanti maññitvā ajjhositaṃ
analyzed: saccamutam paresanti paresam saddhāya para pattiyā ayanāya saccamutam ti maññitvā ajjhositam
translated: “The truth of others” : what is clung to, thinking it to be the truth of others, by way of faith in others, by way of conviction in others.

original: gilitvā pariniṭṭhāpetvā gahitaṃ. Sayasaṃvutesūti sayameva saṃvaritvā piyāyitvā gahitagahaṇesu,
analyzed: gilitvā pariniṭṭhāpetvā gahitam saya saṃvutesu iti sayam eva saṃvaritvā piyāyitvā gahita gahaṇesu
translated: “Swallowed and digested” : in the case of those things that are clung to by being swallowed and digested, by being cherished and held dear.

original: diṭṭhigatikesūti attho. Diṭṭhigatikā hi sayaṃ saṃvutāti vuccanti. Saccaṃ musā vāpi🔽paraṃ daheyyāti tesu sayaṃ saṃvutasaṅkhātesu diṭṭhigatikesu tathāgato tādī tesaṃ🔽ekampi vacanaṃ “idameva saccaṃ moghamañña”nti evaṃ saccaṃ musā vāpi paraṃ uttamaṃ
analyzed: diṭṭhigatikesu iti atthaḥ diṭṭhigatikāḥ hi sayam saṃvutā iti vuccanti saccam musā vā api  param daheyya iti tesu sayam saṃvuta saṅkhātesu diṭṭhi gatikesu tathāgato tādī tesam  ekam pi vacanam idam eva saccam mogham aññanti evam saccam musā vā api param uttamam
translated: The meaning is: in the case of those who are opinionated. For those who are opinionated are called “self-controlled.”🔽“Whether it be true or false” :

original: katvā na odaheyya, na saddaheyya, na pattiyāyeyya. Etañca sallanti etaṃ diṭṭhisallaṃ.
analyzed: katvā na odaheyya na saddaheyya na pattiyāyeyya etam ca sallanti etam diṭṭhi sallam
translated: in the case of those who are opinionated and called “self-controlled,” the Tathāgata would not “burn” others, would not “believe” or “convict” them, by declaring “This alone is the truth, anything else is false.”🔽“This dart of views” : this dart of views.

original: Paṭikacca disvāti puretaraṃ bodhimūleyeva disvā. Visattāti laggā lagitā palibuddhā.
analyzed: disvā ati puretaram bodhi mūleya iva disvā visattā ati laggā lagitā palibuddhā
translated: “Having seen it” : having seen it earlier, at the foot of the Bodhi tree.🔽“I have gone beyond” : I have gone beyond, have transcended, have surmounted.

original: Jānāmi passāmi tatheva etanti yathāyaṃ pajā ajjhositā gilitvā pariniṭṭhāpetvā visattā
analyzed: jānāmi passāmi tathā iva etat ti yathā ayam pajā ajjhositā gilitvā pariniṭṭhāpetvā visattā
translated: “I know and see” : just as this generation is attached, has swallowed and digested, and is bound, hindered, and obstructed,

original: laggā lagitā, evaṃ ahampi jānāmi passāmi. Tathā evaṃ yathā etāya pajāya gahitanti
analyzed: laggā lagitā evam aham pi jānāmi passāmi tathā evam yathā etāya pajāya gahitanti
translated: I know and see just as this generation does. And so too, I know and see just as this generation does in regard to the way it has taken hold of things.

original: evaṃ ajjhositaṃ natthi tathāgatānanti attho.
analyzed: evam ajjhositam na atthi tathāgatānam ti attho
translated: The meaning is: there is no such clinging to the Tathāgata.

original: 5. Brahmacariyasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: brahmacariya sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the fifth sutta in the Brahmajāla is finished.

original: 25. Pañcame janakuhanatthanti tīhi kuhanavatthūhi janassa kuhanatthāya. Na janalapanatthanti
analyzed: pañcame jana kuhana tthanti tīhi kuhana vatthūhi janassa kuhana tthāya na jana lapana tthanti
translated: In the fifth sutta , “for the sake of deceiving people” means for the sake of deceiving people by means of the three bases of deception. “Not for the sake of pleasing people” means

original: na janassa upalāpanatthaṃ. Na lābhasakkārasilokānisaṃsatthanti na cīvarādithutivacanatthaṃ.🔽Na itivādappamokkhānisaṃsatthanti na tena tena kāraṇena katavādānisaṃsatthaṃ, na🔽vādassa pamokkhānisaṃsatthaṃ. Na iti maṃ jano jānātūti na “evaṃ kira esa bhikkhu,
analyzed: na janassa upalāpana ttham na na cīvara ādi thuti vacana ttham  na itivāda ppamokkha anisaṃsattham na tena tena kāraṇena kata vāda anisaṃsattham na  vādassa pamokkha anisaṃsa ttham naḥ iti mam janaḥ jānātu uti na evam kira esa bhikkhu
translated: not for the sake of pleasing people by means of flattery. “Not for the sake of gain, honour, and renown” means not for the sake of the words of praise of robes, etc.

original: evaṃ kira esa bhikkhū”ti janassa jānanatthāya. Saṃvaratthanti pañcahi saṃvarehi saṃvaraṇatthāya.
analyzed: evam kira esa bhikkhu iti janassa jānana tthāya saṃvara tthanti pañcahi saṃvarehi saṃvaraṇa tthāya
translated: “Not for the sake of reputation and freedom from annoyance” means not for the sake of the reputation that comes from the reasons given, not for the sake of freedom from annoyance by means of the reasons given. “Not thinking ‘May people know me’ ” means not for the sake of people’s knowing: “This bhikkhu is like this, this bhikkhu is like that.” “For the sake of restraint” means for the sake of restraint by means of the five kinds of restraint.

original: Pahānatthanti tīhi pahānehi pajahanatthāya. Virāgatthanti rāgādīnaṃ virajjanatthāya.
analyzed: pahāna atthanti tīhi pahānehi pajahana atthāya virāga atthanti rāga ādīnam virajjana atthāya
translated: “For the sake of abandoning” means for the sake of abandoning by means of the three kinds of abandoning. “For the sake of dispassion” means for the sake of the fading away of lust, etc.

original: Nirodhatthanti tesaṃyeva nirujjhanatthāya. Anītihanti itihaparivajjitaṃ, aparapattiyanti🔽attho. Nibbānogadhagāminanti nibbānassa antogāminaṃ. Maggabrahmacariyañhi nibbānaṃ

analyzed: cīvara khettanti saṅghataḥ vā gaṇataḥ vā ñātitaḥ vā mittataḥ vā attanaḥ vā dhanena paṃsukūlam

original: vā”ti evaṃ uppajjanato cha khettāni, aṭṭhannañca mātikānaṃ vasena aṭṭha khettāni jānitabbāni.
analyzed: vā ti evam uppajjanato cha khettāni aṭṭhannam ca mātikānam vasena aṭṭha khettāni jānitabbāni
translated: these are the six sources of robe-cloth. And there are eight sources according to the eight lists of rules.”

original: Paṃsukūlanti sosānikaṃ, pāpaṇikaṃ, rathiyaṃ, saṅkārakūṭakaṃ, sotthiyaṃ, sinānaṃ,🔽titthaṃ, gatapaccāgataṃ, aggidaḍḍhaṃ, gokhāyitaṃ, upacikakhāyitaṃ, undūrakhāyitaṃ,🔽antacchinnaṃ, dasacchinnaṃ, dhajāhaṭaṃ, thūpaṃ, samaṇacīvaraṃ, sāmuddiyaṃ, ābhisekiyaṃ,

original: Ettha ca sotthiyanti gabbhamalaharaṇaṃ. Gatapaccāgatanti matakasarīraṃ pārupitvā🔽susānaṃ netvā ānītacīvaraṃ. Dhajāhaṭanti dhajaṃ ussāpetvā tato ānītaṃ. Thūpanti vammike🔽pūjitacīvaraṃ. analyzed: ettha ca gabbha mala haraṇam mataka sarīram  susānam netvā ānīta cīvaram dhajāhaṭanti dhajam ussāpetvā tatas ānītam thūpanti vammike  pūjita cīvaram samudda vīcīhi thalam pāpitam panthikam ti  cora bhayena pāsāṇehi koṭṭetvā pāruta cīvaram iddhimayanti ehibhikkhu cīvaram sesam pākaṭam eva ati
translated: And here, “Sotthiya” is the cloth used for removing the placenta. “Gata-paccāgata” is the cloth used for wrapping up the corpse of a dead person and then brought back after it has been taken to the charnel ground. “Dhājāhaṭa” is the cloth brought from the place where a flag is hoisted. “Thūpa” is the cloth used for worshipping a tumulus. “Sāmuddiya” is the cloth brought up from the bottom of the ocean. “Panthika” is the cloth used for protection against the wind, which is beaten with stones on the road out of fear of robbers. “Iddhimaya” is the cloth of the “Come, bhikkhu” type. The rest is clear.
