original: parimāṇasantoso, suttasantoso, sibbanasantoso, rajanasantoso, kappasantoso, paribhogasantoso,
analyzed: parimāṇa santoso sutta santoso sibbana santoso rajana santoso kappa santoso paribhoga santoso
translated: Satisfaction in amount, satisfaction in kind of cloth, satisfaction in colour, satisfaction in quality, satisfaction in time, satisfaction in use,

original: sannidhiparivajjanasantoso, vissajjanasantosoti.
analyzed: sannidhi parivajjana santosaḥ vissajjana santosaḥ
translated: satisfaction in storing, satisfaction in giving away.

original: Tattha sādakabhikkhunā temāsaṃ nibaddhavāsaṃ vasitvā ekamāsamattaṃ vitakketuṃ vaṭṭati.
analyzed: tattha sādaka bhikkhunā temāsam nibaddha vāsam vasitvā eka māsa mattam vitakketum vaṭṭati
translated: Herein, a monk who is a wearer of rags may, after staying for three months on a regular basis, think for a month at a time.

original: So hi pavāretvā cīvaramāse cīvaraṃ karoti, paṃsukūliko aḍḍhamāseneva karoti. Idaṃ
analyzed: saḥ hi pavāretvā cīvara māse cīvaram karoti paṃsukūlikaḥ aḍḍha māsena iva karoti idam
translated: For he makes robe-cloth in the robe season after inviting for a month. One who wears rag-robes makes it in half a month. This

original: māsaḍḍhamāsamattaṃ vitakkanaṃ vitakkasantoso nāma. Vitakkasantosena pana santuṭṭhena
analyzed: māsa ḍḍha māsa mattam vitakkanam vitakka santosaḥ nāma vitakka santosena pana santuṭṭhena
translated: thinking for a month or half a month is called satisfaction in thinking. But a monk who is satisfied with what he has thought

original: bhikkhunā pācīnakhaṇḍarājivāsikapaṃsukūlikattherasadisena bhavitabbaṃ.
analyzed: bhikkhunā pācīnakhaṇḍa rājivāsika paṃsukūlika thera sadisena bhavitabbam
translated: should be like the Elder Paññā-Khandaka-Rājavāsi-Paṃsukūlika.

original: Thero kira “cetiyapabbatavihāre cetiyaṃ vandissāmī”ti āgato cetiyaṃ vanditvā cintesi
analyzed: thero kira cetiya pabbata vihāre cetiyam vandissāmi iti āgataḥ cetiyam vanditvā cintesi
translated: The elder, it seems, came to the Cetiya Monastery, thinking “I shall worship the shrine.” After worshipping the shrine he thought:

original: – “mayhaṃ cīvaraṃ jiṇṇaṃ, bahūnaṃ vasanaṭṭhāne labhissāmī”ti. So mahāvihāraṃ gantvā
analyzed: mayham cīvaram jiṇṇam bahūnam vasana ṭṭhāne labhissāmi iti saḥ mahāvihāram gantvā
translated: “My robe is worn. I shall get one in a place where they give robes to wear.” He went to the Great Monastery and

original: saṅghattheraṃ disvā vasanaṭṭhānaṃ pucchitvā tattha vuttho punadivase cīvaraṃ ādāya
analyzed: saṅghattheram disvā vasanaṭṭhānam pucchitvā tattha vutthaḥ puna divase cīvaram ādāya
translated: When he saw the senior monk, he asked him where he was staying. He stayed there and the next day he took his robe and

original: āgantvā theraṃ vandi. Thero “kiṃ, āvuso”ti āha. Gāmadvāraṃ, bhante, gamissāmīti.
analyzed: āgantvā theram vandi theraḥ kim āvuso ti āha gāma dvāram bhante gamissāmi iti
translated: came back. He saluted the senior monk. The senior monk said, “What is it, friend?” “I am going to the village gate, venerable sir.”

original: Ahampāvuso, gamissāmīti. Sādhu, bhanteti gacchanto mahābodhidvārakoṭṭhake ṭhatvā
analyzed: aham pāvuso gamissāmi iti sādhu bhante iti gacchantaḥ mahābodhidvāra koṭṭhake ṭhatvā
translated: “I too am going, friend.” “Very well, venerable sir.” As he was going, he stopped at the gate of the Great Bodhi Tree,

original: “puññavantānaṃ vasanaṭṭhāne manāpaṃ labhissāmī”ti cintetvā “aparisuddho me vitakko”ti
analyzed: puññavantānam vasana ṭṭhāne manāpam labhissāmi iti cintetvā aparisuddhaḥ me vitakkoti
translated: thinking, “I shall get something pleasant in a place where meritorious people live.” He thought, “My thought is not pure,”

original: tatova paṭinivatti. Punadivase ambaṅgaṇasamīpato, punadivase mahācetiyassa uttaradvārato🔽tattheva paṭinivattitvā catutthadivase therassa santikaṃ agamāsi. Thero “imassa bhikkhuno🔽vitakko na parisuddho bhavissatī”ti cīvaraṃ gahetvā tena saddhiṃyeva pañhaṃ pucchamāno
analyzed: tatas va paṭinivatti puna divase ambaṅgaṇa samīpataḥ puna divase mahā cetiyassa uttara dvārataḥ  tattha iva paṭinivattitvā catuttha divase therassa santikam agamāsi theraḥ imassa bhikkhuno  vitakkaḥ na parisuddhaḥ bhavissati iti cīvaram gahetvā tena saddhiṃyeva pañham pucchamāno
translated: and he turned back right there. The next day he went from the vicinity of the Mango Grove, the next day from the northern gate of the Great Shrine,🔽and the next day from the southern gate of the Great Shrine. He turned back right there. On the fourth day he came to the senior monk. The senior monk thought,🔽“This monk’s thought is not pure,” and taking his robe, he entered the village with him, asking questions. That night a man, having defecated,

original: gāmaṃ pāvisi. Tañca rattiṃ eko manusso uccārapalibuddho sāṭakeyeva vaccaṃ katvā taṃ
analyzed: gāmam pāvisi tat ca rattim ekaḥ manussaḥ uccāra palibuddhaḥ sāṭakeya iva vaccam katvā tam
translated: and having smeared his cloth, went to sleep.

original: saṅkāraṭṭhāne chaḍḍesi. Paṃsukūlikatthero taṃ nīlamakkhikāhi samparikiṇṇaṃ disvā
analyzed: saṅkāra ṭṭhāne chaḍḍesi paṃsukūlika thero tam nīla makkhikāhi samparikiṇṇam disvā
translated: and threw it on a rubbish heap. The Elder Pañcasukūla saw it covered with blue flies.

original: añjaliṃ paggahesi. Mahāthero “kiṃ, āvuso, saṅkāraṭṭhānassa añjaliṃ paggaṇhāsī”ti.
analyzed: añjalim paggahesi mahā thero kim āvuso saṅkāra ṭṭhānassa añjalim paggaṇhāsi iti
translated: He raised his hands in reverential salutation. The Elder Mahā Kassapa asked him, “Why do you raise your hands in reverential salutation to a rubbish heap?”

original: Nāhaṃ, bhante, saṅkāraṭṭhānassa añjaliṃ paggaṇhāmi, mayhaṃ pitu dasabalassa paggaṇhāmi,
analyzed: na aham bhante saṅkāra ṭṭhānassa añjalim paggaṇhāmi mayham pitu dasabalassa paggaṇhāmi
translated: “Venerable sir, I do not raise my hands in reverential salutation to a rubbish heap; I raise them in reverential salutation to my father, the One of Ten Powers,

original: puṇṇadāsiyā sarīraṃ pārupitvā chaḍḍitaṃ paṃsukūlaṃ tumbamatte pāṇake vidhunitvā susānato
analyzed: puṇṇa dāsiyā sarīram pārupitvā chaḍḍitam paṃsukūlam tumba matte pāṇake vidhunitvā su sānataḥ
translated: who, after covering the body of the slave girl Puṇṇā with his outer robe, threw it away on a rubbish heap. It is more difficult to take a rag from a charnel ground

original: gaṇhantena dukkarataraṃ kataṃ, bhanteti. Mahāthero “parisuddho vitakko paṃsukūlikassā”ti
analyzed: gaṇhantena dukkarataram katam bhante ti mahā thero parisuddho vitakko paṃsukūlikassa ati
translated: than to take a living creature from a heap of burning coals.” The Elder Mahā Kassapa thought, “The Elder Pañcasukūla’s reflection is pure.”

original: cintesi. Paṃsukūlikattheropi tasmiṃyeva ṭhāne ṭhito vipassanaṃ vaḍḍhetvā tīṇi phalāni
analyzed: cintesi paṃsukūlika theraḥ api tasmiṃ yeva ṭhāne ṭhitaḥ vipassanam vaḍḍhetvā tīṇi phalāni
translated: The Elder Pañcasukūla, standing in the same place, increased his insight and attained the three fruitions.

original: patto taṃ sāṭakaṃ gahetvā cīvaraṃ katvā pārupitvā pācīnakhaṇḍarājiṃ gantvā aggaphalaṃ arahattaṃ pāpuṇi.
analyzed: pattaḥ tam sāṭakam gahetvā cīvaram katvā pārupitvā pācīnakhaṇḍa rājim gantvā agga phalam arahattam pāpuṇi
translated: He took the cloth, made it into a robe, and put it on. Then he went to Pācīnakhaṇḍarājī, where he attained the supreme fruit, arahatship.

original: Cīvaratthāya gacchantassa pana “kattha labhissāmī”ti acintetvā kammaṭṭhānasīseneva🔽gamanaṃ gamanasantoso nāma. Pariyesantassa pana yena vā tena vā saddhiṃ apariyesitvā
analyzed: cīvara atthāya gacchantassa pana kattha labhissāmi iti a cintetvā kammaṭṭhāna sīsena iva  gamanam gamana santosaḥ nāma pariyesantassa pana yena vā tena vā saddhim a pariyesitvā
translated: When he goes to get it, he should not think, “Where shall I get a fine one?”🔽But he should go with his meditation subject as his only concern. This is called satisfaction with the attainment of requisites.

original: lajjiṃ pesalaṃ bhikkhuṃ gahetvā pariyesanaṃ pariyesanasantoso nāma. Evaṃ pariyesantassa
analyzed: lajjim pesalam bhikkhum gahetvā pariyesanam pariyesana santosaḥ nāma evam pariyesantassa
translated: When he is seeking it, he should not seek it with anyone at all, but he should seek it with a companion who is a discreet and competent bhikkhu. This is called satisfaction with the search for requisites.🔽When he is seeking it thus,

original: āhariyamānaṃ cīvaraṃ dūrato disvā “etaṃ manāpaṃ bhavissati, etaṃ amanāpa”nti evaṃ
analyzed: āhariyamānam cīvaram dūratas disvā etam manāpam bhavissati etam a manāpam ti evam
translated: he should not think, “This will be fine,” or “This will be coarse,” as soon as he sees the robe-cloth coming.

original: avitakketvā thūlasukhumādīsu yathāladdheneva santussanaṃ paṭilābhasantoso nāma. Evaṃ🔽laddhaṃ gaṇhantassāpi “ettakaṃ dupaṭṭassa bhavissati, ettakaṃ ekapaṭṭassā”ti attano🔽pahonakamatteneva santussanaṃ mattapaṭiggahaṇasantoso nāma. Cīvaraṃ pariyesantassa
analyzed: a vitakketvā thūla sukhuma ādīsu yathā laddhena iva santussanam paṭilābha santosaḥ nāma evam  laddham gaṇhantassa api ettakam du paṭṭassa bhavissati ettakam eka paṭṭassa ati attano  pahonaka mattena iva santussanam matta paṭiggahaṇa santosaḥ nāma cīvaram pariyesantassa
translated: But he should be satisfied with whatever he gets, whether fine or coarse, and so on. This is called satisfaction with what one gets.🔽When he receives it, he should be satisfied with just what suffices for the purpose of covering the parts of the body that need covering. This is called satisfaction with what is befitting.🔽When he is seeking robe-cloth, he should not think, “At such and such a house they will give me fine cloth,” and then go only to that house.

original: pana “asukassa gharadvāre manāpaṃ labhissāmī”ti acintetvā dvārapaṭipāṭiyā caraṇaṃ
analyzed: pana asukassa ghara dvāre manāpam labhissāmi iti a cintetvā dvāra paṭipāṭiyā caraṇam
translated: But he should go round in proper order from house to house. This is called satisfaction with what is acquired by proper means.

original: loluppavivajjanasantoso nāma.
analyzed: loluppa vivajjana santosaḥ nāma
translated: This is called contentment with what is got by way of alms.

original: Lūkhapaṇītesu yena kenaci yāpetuṃ sakkontassa yathāladdheneva yāpanaṃ yathālābhasantoso
analyzed: lūkha paṇītesu yena kenacid yāpetum sakkontassa yathāladdhena iva yāpanam yathā lābha santoso
translated: Contentment with what is got is when one is able to get by with anything at all, good or bad, and makes do with whatever he gets.

original: nāma. Attano thāmaṃ jānitvā yena yāpetuṃ sakkoti, tena yāpanaṃ yathābalasantoso nāma.
analyzed: nāma attanaḥ thāmam jānitvā yena yāpetum sakkoti tena yāpanam yathābala santosaḥ nāma
translated: Contentment with one’s strength is when one makes do with what one is able to get.

original: Manāpaṃ aññassa datvā attanā yena kenaci yāpanaṃ yathāsāruppasantoso nāma.
analyzed: manāpam aññassa da tvā attanā yena kenacid yāpanam yathā sāruppa santosaḥ nāma
translated: Contentment with what is proper is when one makes do with anything at all after giving the choice to another.

original: “Kattha udakaṃ manāpaṃ, kattha amanāpa”nti avicāretvā yena kenaci dhovanūpagena udakena🔽dhovanaṃ udakasantoso nāma. Paṇḍumattikagerukapūtipaṇṇarasakiliṭṭhāni pana udakāni🔽vajjetuṃ vaṭṭati. Dhovantassa pana muggarādīhi apaharitvā hatthehi madditvā dhovanaṃ
analyzed: kattha udakam manāpam kattha amanāpanti a vicāretvā yena kenacid dhovana upagena udakena  dhovanam udaka santosaḥ nāma paṇḍu mattika geruka pūti paṇṇa rasa kiliṭṭhāni pana udakāni  vajjetum vaṭṭati dhovantassa pana muggara ādīhi apaharitvā hatthehi madditvā dhovanam
translated: Contentment with water is when one washes with any water that is suitable for washing, without considering whether it is good or bad.🔽But one may reject water that is muddy, or has a bad smell, or is discolored by decayed leaves, etc.🔽Contentment with washing is when one washes without removing the dirt with a stick, etc., and then rubbing it off with the hands.

original: dhovanasantoso nāma. Tathā asujjhantaṃ paṇṇāni pakkhipitvā tāpitaudakenāpi dhovituṃ
analyzed: dhovana santosaḥ nāma tathā a sujjhantam paṇṇāni pakkhipitvā tāpita odakena api dhovitum
translated: Contentment with heating is when one heats the bowl by putting in it some dry leaves, etc., and then pouring in hot water.

original: vaṭṭati. Evaṃ dhovitvā karontassa “idaṃ thūlaṃ, idaṃ sukhuma”nti akopetvā pahonakanīhāreneva
analyzed: vaṭṭati evam dhovitvā karontassa idam thūlam idam sukhumanti a kopetvā pahonaka nīhārena iva
translated: If he makes it after washing it in this way, without spoiling it by saying, “This is thick, this is thin,” this is called “satisfaction in what is enough.”

original: karaṇaṃ karaṇasantoso nāma. Timaṇḍalapaticchādanamattasseva karaṇaṃ parimāṇasantoso🔽nāma. Cīvarakaraṇatthāya pana manāpaṃ suttaṃ pariyesissāmīti avicāretvā rathikādīsu
analyzed: karaṇam karaṇa santosaḥ nāma ti maṇḍala pati chādana mattassa iva karaṇam parimāṇa santoso  nāma cīvara karaṇa atthāya pana manāpam suttam pariyesissāmi iti a vicāretvā rathika ādīsu
translated: If he makes it just sufficient to cover the three circles, this is called “satisfaction in the measure.”

original: vā devaṭṭhāne vā āharitvā pādamūle vā ṭhapitaṃ yaṃkiñcideva suttaṃ gahetvā karaṇaṃ suttasantoso nāma.
analyzed: vā devaṭṭhāne vā āharitvā pāda mūle vā ṭhapitam yaṃ kiñcid eva suttam gahetvā karaṇam sutta santosaḥ nāma
translated: But if he does not consider thus “I shall get some nice thread for making the robe,” but instead gets whatever thread he can, from a shop or a guild house or from a shrine or a monastery storehouse, and makes the robe, this is called “satisfaction in the thread.”

original: Kusibandhanakāle pana aṅgulamatte satta vāre na vijjhitabbaṃ. Evaṃ karontassa hi🔽yo bhikkhu sahāyo na hoti, tassa vattabhedopi natthi. Tivaṅgulamatte pana satta vāre
analyzed: kusibandhana kāle pana aṅgula matte satta vāre na vijjhitabbam evam karontassa hi  yaḥ bhikkhu sahāyaḥ na hoti tassa vatta bhedaḥ api natthi ti vaṅgula matte pana satta vāre
translated: But at the time of sewing, he should not sew more than seven stitches of four fingers’ length.🔽For if he does so, he will not have to ask another bhikkhu for help, nor will there be any breach of his seclusion.

original: vijjhitabbaṃ. Evaṃ karontassa maggappaṭipannenāpi sahāyena bhavitabbaṃ. Yo na hoti,
analyzed: vijjhitabbam evam karontassa magga ppaṭipannena api sahāyena bhavitabbam yaḥ na hoti
translated: But if he sews seven stitches of four fingers’ length, he will have to get help from a companion bhikkhu who is going along the same path as himself. If there is no such bhikkhu,

original: tassa vattabhedo. Ayaṃ sibbanasantoso nāma. Rajantena pana kāḷakacchakādīni pariyesantena
analyzed: tassa vatta bhedaḥ ayam sibbana santosaḥ nāma rajantena pana kāḷa kacchaka ādīni pariyesantena
translated: This is called the satisfaction of the work.🔽But when he is dyeing, he should not search for black, brown, and so on.

original: na caritabbaṃ, somavakkalādīsu yaṃ labhati, tena rajitabbaṃ. Alabhantena pana manussehi
analyzed: na caritabbam soma vakkala ādīsu yam labhati tena rajitabbam a labhantena pana manussehi
translated: He should dye with whatever he gets, such as somavaṇṇa, etc.

original: araññe vākaṃ gahetvā chaḍḍitarajanaṃ vā bhikkhūhi pacitvā chaḍḍitakasaṭaṃ vā gahetvā
analyzed: araññe vākam gahetvā chaḍḍita rajanam vā bhikkhūhi pacitvā chaḍḍita kasaṭam vā gahetvā
translated: If he cannot get any, he should get grass from the wilderness, or he should get the dye-powder that people have thrown away after using it for dyeing cloth, or he should get the dye-powder that monks have cooked and thrown away.🔽This is called the satisfaction of the dyeing.

original: rajitabbaṃ. Ayaṃ rajanasantoso nāma. Nīlakaddamakāḷasāmesu yaṃkiñci gahetvā hatthipiṭṭhe🔽nisinnassa paññāyamānakappakaraṇaṃ kappasantoso nāma.
analyzed: rajitabbam ayam rajana santosaḥ nāma nīla kaddama kāḷa sāmesu yaṃ kiñci gahetvā hatthi piṭṭhe  nisinnassa paññāyamāna kappa karaṇam kappasantosaḥ nāma
translated: The satisfaction of the sewing is the sewing that is done by one who sits on the ground and uses any one of the three kinds of dye-powder that he has got.

original: Hirikopīnappaṭicchādanamattavasena paribhuñjanaṃ paribhogasantoso nāma. Dussaṃ pana🔽labhitvā suttaṃ vā sūciṃ vā kārakaṃ vā alabhantena ṭhapetuṃ vaṭṭati, labhantena na
analyzed: paribhuñjanam paribhoga santosaḥ nāma dussam pana  labhitvā suttam vā sūcim vā kārakam vā a labhantena ṭhapetum vaṭṭati labhantena na
translated: The satisfaction of the wearing is the wearing of the robe for the purpose of covering the parts of the body that ought to be covered, and for the purpose of warding off cold, flies, wind, burning insects, and snakes.🔽But if he gets cloth and he cannot get thread, a needle, or a worker, he can keep it. If he can get them, he should not keep it.

original: vaṭṭati. Katampi sace antevāsikādīnaṃ dātukāmo hoti, te ca asannihitā, yāva āgamanā
analyzed: vaṭṭati sace antevāsika ādīnam dātu kāmaḥ te ca asannihitāḥ āgamanā
translated: If he has made it and he wants to give it to his pupils, etc., but they are not present, he can keep it until they come.

original: ṭhapetuṃ vaṭṭati. Āgatamattesu dātabbaṃ. Dātuṃ asakkontena adhiṭṭhātabbaṃ. Aññasmiṃ
analyzed: ṭhapetum vaṭṭati āgata mattesu dātabbam dātum a sakkontena adhiṭṭhātabbam aññasmin
translated: He may keep it. He should give it to them as soon as they arrive. If he is unable to give it, he should determine it.🔽If he has another robe, he may determine even a floor cover.

original: cīvare sati paccattharaṇampi adhiṭṭhātuṃ vaṭṭati. Anadhiṭṭhitameva hi sannidhi hoti,
analyzed: cīvare sati paccattharaṇam pi adhiṭṭhātum vaṭṭati an adhiṭṭhitam eva hi sannidhi hoti
translated: For only what is not determined is a store,

original: adhiṭṭhitaṃ na hotīti mahāsīvatthero āha. Ayaṃ sannidhiparivajjanasantoso nāma. Vissajjentena
analyzed: adhiṭṭhitam na hoti iti mahāsīva theraḥ āha ayam sannidhi parivajjana santosaḥ nāma vissajjentena
translated: but what is determined is not a store, said the Elder Maha-Siva. This is called the satisfaction of avoiding a store.

original: pana na mukhaṃ oloketvā dātabbaṃ, sāraṇīyadhamme ṭhatvā vissajjetabbanti ayaṃ vissajjanasantoso nāma.
analyzed: pana na mukham oloketvā dātabbam sāraṇīya dhamme ṭhatvā vissajjetabbanti ayam vissajjana santosaḥ nāma
translated: But when he is giving it away, he should not give it after looking at the face of the recipient; he should give it after establishing himself in loving kindness. This is called the satisfaction of giving away.

original: Cīvarappaṭisaṃyuttāni dhutaṅgāni nāma paṃsukūlikaṅgañceva tecīvarikaṅgañca. Tesaṃ
analyzed: cīvara paṭisaṃyuttāni dhutaṅgāni nāma paṃsukūlikaṅgam ca iva tecīvarikaṅgam ca tesam
translated: The ascetic practices concerned with robes are the refuse-rag-wearer’s practice and the triple-robe-wearer’s practice.

original: vitthārakathā visuddhimagge veditabbā. Iti cīvarasantosamahāariyavaṃsaṃ pūrayamāno
analyzed: vitthāra kathā visuddhi magge veditabbā iti cīvara santosa mahāariya vaṃsam pūrayamānaḥ
translated: The detailed explanation of these should be understood according to the Visuddhimagga.🔽So when a bhikkhu fulfills the Great Man’s ideal of satisfaction with robes,

original: bhikkhu imāni dve dhutaṅgāni gopeti. Imāni gopento cīvarasantosamahāariyavaṃsavasena santuṭṭho hotīti.
analyzed: bhikkhu imāni dve dhutaṅgāni gopeti imāni gopento cīvara santosa mahāariya vaṃsa vasena santuṭṭhaḥ hoti iti
translated: he practices these two ascetic practices. And by practicing them he becomes satisfied with the Great Man’s ideal of satisfaction with robes.

original: Vaṇṇavādīti eko santuṭṭho hoti, santosassa vaṇṇaṃ na katheti. Eko na santuṭṭho hoti,
analyzed: vaṇṇa vādī iti ekaḥ santuṭṭhaḥ hoti santosassa vaṇṇam na katheti ekaḥ na santuṭṭhaḥ hoti
translated: One who speaks in praise of contentment is satisfied himself and does not speak in dispraise of contentment. One who does not speak in praise of contentment is not satisfied himself,

original: santosassa vaṇṇaṃ katheti. Eko neva santuṭṭho hoti, na santosassa vaṇṇaṃ katheti.🔽Eko santuṭṭho ceva hoti, santosassa ca vaṇṇaṃ katheti. Taṃ dassetuṃ “itarītaracīvarasantuṭṭhiyā
analyzed: santosassa vaṇṇam katheti ekaḥ na iva santuṭṭhaḥ hoti na santosassa vaṇṇam katheti  ekaḥ santuṭṭho ca iva hoti santosassa ca vaṇṇam katheti tam dassetum itarītara cīvara santuṭṭhiyā
translated: but he speaks in dispraise of contentment. One who neither speaks in praise of contentment nor speaks in dispraise of contentment is neither satisfied himself nor does he speak in dispraise of contentment.

original: ca vaṇṇavādī”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: ca vaṇṇa vādī iti vuttam
translated: One who both is satisfied himself and speaks in praise of contentment is satisfied himself and speaks in praise of contentment. In order to show this, it is said: “he is one who speaks in praise of contentment with the kind of robe that suits the country.”🔽“Without scheming”: without scheming of various kinds, such as going as an envoy, etc. “Without flattery”:

original: Anesananti dūteyyapahinagamanānuyogapabhedaṃ nānappakāraṃ anesanaṃ. Appatirūpanti🔽ayuttaṃ. Aladdhā cāti alabhitvā. Yathā ekacco “kathaṃ nu kho cīvaraṃ labhissāmī”ti🔽puññavantehi bhikkhūhi saddhiṃ ekato hutvā kohaññaṃ karonto uttasati paritassati,
analyzed: anesanam ti dūteyya pahina gamana anuyoga pabhedam nānappakāram anesanam appatirūpam ti  ayuttam a laddhā ca ati a labhitvā yathā ekacco katham nu kho cīvaram labhissāmi iti  puññavantehi bhikkhūhi saddhim ekatas hutvā kohaññam karontaḥ uttasati paritassati
translated: without what is unbecoming. “Without hinting”: without hinting. “Without belittling”: without belittling. “Without pursuing gain through a gain-made person”: without pursuing gain through another who has gained.

original: santuṭṭho bhikkhu evaṃ aladdhā cīvaraṃ na paritassati. Laddhā cāti dhammena samena
analyzed: santuṭṭhaḥ bhikkhu evam a laddhā cīvaram na paritassati laddhā ca ati dhammena samena
translated: “Without being intent on gain”: without being intent on gain. “Without being committed to gain”: without being committed to gain. “Without being devoted to gain”: without being devoted to gain. “Without being attached to gain”: without being attached to gain. “Without being tied to gain”: without being tied to gain. “Without being infatuated with gain”: without being infatuated with gain. “Without being intoxicated with gain”: without being intoxicated with gain. “Without being obsessed by gain”: without being obsessed by gain. “Without being greedy for gain”: without being greedy for gain. “Without coveting gain”: without coveting gain. “Without being covetous of gain”: without being covetous of gain. “Without being greedy for gain”: without being greedy for gain. “Without being covetous of gain”: without being covetous of gain. “Without being greedy for gain”: without being greedy for gain. “Without being covetous of gain”: without being covetous of gain. “Without being greedy for gain”: without being greedy for gain. “Without being covetous of gain”: without being covetous of gain. “Without being greedy for gain”: without being greedy for gain. “Without being covetous of gain”: without being covetous of gain. “Without being greedy for gain”: without being greedy for gain. “Without being covetous of gain”: without being covetous of gain. “Without being greedy for gain”: without being greedy for gain. “Without being covetous of gain”: without being covetous of gain. “

original: labhitvā. Agadhitoti vigatalobhagiddho. Amucchitoti adhimattataṇhāya mucchaṃ anāpanno.
analyzed: labhitvā agadhita uti vigata lobha giddhaḥ amucchita uti adhimatta taṇhāya muccham an āpannaḥ
translated: Having received it, he is not greedy for it, not greedy means not greedy for sensual desires. He is not infatuated with it, not infatuated means not infatuated with strong craving.

original: Anajjhopannoti taṇhāya anotthato apariyonaddho. Ādīnavadassāvīti anesanāpattiyañca🔽gedhitaparibhoge ca ādīnavaṃ passamāno. Nissaraṇapaññoti “yāvadeva sītassa paṭighātāyā”ti
analyzed: an ajjhopannaḥ ti taṇhāya an otthataḥ a pariyonaddhaḥ ādīnava dassāvī iti anesanāpattiyam ca  gedhita paribhoge ca ādīnavam passamānaḥ nissaraṇa pañño ti yāvat eva sītassa paṭighātāya ati
translated: He is not bound to it, not bound means not bound by craving, not fettered by it. He sees danger in it, seeing danger means seeing danger in the non-abandoning of the search for fine things and in the enjoyment of what has been searched for.

original: vuttaṃ nissaraṇameva pajānanto.🔽Itarītaracīvarasantuṭṭhiyāti yena kenaci cīvarena santuṭṭhiyā. Nevattānukkaṃsetīti
analyzed: vuttam nissaraṇam eva pajānantaḥ  itarītara cīvara santuṭṭhiyā ati yena kenacid cīvarena santuṭṭhiyā na ivattā anukkaṃseti iti
translated: He has the wisdom of escape, having the wisdom of escape means understanding the escape stated thus: “For the sake of warding off cold” .

original: “ahaṃ paṃsukūliko, mayā upasampadamāḷeyeva paṃsukūlikaṅgaṃ gahitaṃ, ko mayā sadiso
analyzed: aham paṃsukūlikaḥ mayā upasampadam āḷeya iva paṃsukūlika aṅgam gahitam kaḥ mayā sadisaḥ
translated: He is content with any kind of alms food, with any kind of alms food means with any kind of alms. He does not advertise himself, he does not advertise himself thus: “I am a refuse-rag wearer. The ascetic practice of the refuse-rag wearer was undertaken by me at the time of my ordination. Who is there like me?🔽Who is there better than me?”

original: atthī”ti attukkaṃsanaṃ na karoti. No paraṃ vambhetīti “ime panaññe bhikkhū na paṃsukūlikā”ti🔽vā, “paṃsukūlikaṅgamattampi etesaṃ natthī”ti vā evaṃ paraṃ na vambheti. Yo hi tattha
analyzed: atthi iti attukkaṃsanam na karoti no param vambheti iti ime pana aññe bhikkhū na paṃsukūlikā ati 🔽vā etesam natthi iti vai evam param na vambheti yaḥ hi tattha
translated: He does not despise others, he does not despise others thus: “These other bhikkhus are not refuse-rag wearers” or “They have not undertaken the ascetic practice of the refuse-rag wearer.”

original: dakkhoti yo tasmiṃ cīvarasantose vaṇṇavādādīsu vā dakkho cheko byatto. Analasoti🔽sātaccakiriyāya ālasiyavirahito. Sampajāno paṭissatoti sampajānapaññāya ceva satiyā
analyzed: dakkhaḥ ti yaḥ tasmim cīvara santose vaṇṇa vāda ādīsu vā dakkhaḥ chekaḥ byattaḥ analaso ti  sātacca kiriyāya ālasiya virahitaḥ sampajāno paṭissatoti sampajāna paññāya ca iva satiyā
translated: Skillful: he is skillful, clever, adept in the business of sewing robes, etc., or in the business of praising, etc. Not lazy:🔽he is not lazy, he is free from idleness in the performance of duties. Possessed of clear comprehension and mindfulness:

original: ca yutto. Ariyavaṃse ṭhitoti ariyavaṃse patiṭṭhito.
analyzed: ca yuttaḥ ariya vaṃse ṭhito ti ariya vaṃse patiṭṭhito
translated: he is endowed with the understanding that is called “clear comprehension” and with mindfulness. Abiding in the higher virtue: he is established in the higher virtue.

original: Itarītarena piṇḍapātenāti yena kenaci piṇḍapātena. Etthāpi piṇḍapāto jānitabbo, piṇḍapātakkhettaṃ
analyzed: itarītarena piṇḍapātena ati yena kenacid piṇḍapātena ettha api piṇḍapātaḥ jānitabbaḥ piṇḍapāta khettam
translated: With any kind of alms food: with whatever kind of alms food. Here too the alms food should be understood, the alms-resort,

original: jānitabbaṃ, piṇḍapātasantoso jānitabbo, piṇḍapātappaṭisaṃyuttaṃ dhutaṅgaṃ jānitabbaṃ.
analyzed: jānitabbam piṇḍapāta santosaḥ jānitabbaḥ piṇḍapāta paṭisaṃyuttam dhutaṅgam jānitabbam
translated: the satisfaction in alms food, and the ascetic practice dependent on alms food.

original: Tattha piṇḍapātoti odano kummāso sattu maccho maṃsaṃ khīraṃ dadhi sappi navanītaṃ🔽telaṃ madhu phāṇitaṃ yāgu khādanīyaṃ sāyanīyaṃ lehanīyanti soḷasa piṇḍapātā.
analyzed: tattha piṇḍapāto ti odanaḥ kummāsaḥ sattu macchaḥ maṃsam khīram dadhi sappi navanītam  telam madhu phāṇitam yāgu khādanīyam sāyanīyam lehanīyanti soḍasa piṇḍapātā
translated: Herein, the alms food is the sixteen alms foods, namely, cooked grain, porridge, flour products, fish, meat, milk, curd, ghee, oil, sugar, honey, vegetables, roots, fruits, human beings, and ghosts.

original: Piṇḍapātakkhettanti saṅghabhattaṃ uddesabhattaṃ nimantanaṃ salākabhattaṃ pakkhikaṃ
analyzed: piṇḍapāta khettanti saṅgha bhattam uddesa bhattam nimantanam salāka bhattam pakkhikam
translated: The alms-resort is a meal for the Sangha, a meal for a specific number of monks, a meal for named monks, a meal for monks coming in a certain gate, a meal for monks coming to a certain place, a meal for poor people, a meal for a specific class of poor people, a meal for the first-comers, a meal for those who have completed the rains, a meal for those who have entered for the rains, a meal for travelers, a meal for sick people, a meal for those who nurse the sick, a meal for those who are attending to the sick, a meal for those who are attending to the sick, a meal for those who are attending to the sick, a meal for those who are attending to the sick, a meal for those who are attending to the sick, a meal for those who are attending to the sick, a meal for those who are attending to the sick, a meal for those who are attending to the sick, a meal for those who are attending to the sick, a meal for those who are attending to the sick, a meal for those who are attending to the sick, a meal for those who are attending to the sick, a meal for those who are attending to the sick, a meal for those who are attending to the sick, a meal for those who are attending to the sick, a meal for those who are attending to the sick, a meal for those who are attending to the sick, a meal for those who are attending to the sick, a meal for those who are attending to the sick, a meal for those who

original: uposathikaṃ pāṭipadikabhattaṃ āgantukabhattaṃ gamikabhattaṃ gilānabhattaṃ gilānupaṭṭhākabhattaṃ
analyzed: uposathikam pāṭipadika bhattam āgantuka bhattam gamika bhattam gilāna bhattam gilāna upaṭṭhāka bhattam
translated: Food for the observance-day ceremony, food for one who is conducting the ceremony, food for one who has conducted the ceremony, food for one who has arrived, food for one who is going, food for the sick, food for one who is nursing the sick,

original: dhurabhattaṃ kuṭibhattaṃ vārabhattaṃ vihārabhattanti pannarasa piṇḍapātakkhettāni.
analyzed: dhurabhattam kuṭibhattam vārabhattam vihārabhattanti pannarasa piṇḍapāta kkhettāni
translated: food for the one in charge of the store-room, food for the one in charge of the building site, food for the one in charge of the monastery, food for the monastery. These are the fifteen kinds of alms-food fields.

original: Piṇḍapātasantosoti piṇḍapāte vitakkasantoso gamanasantoso pariyesanasantoso paṭilābhasantoso🔽paṭiggahaṇasantoso mattapaṭiggahaṇasantoso loluppavivajjanasantoso yathālābhasantoso
analyzed: piṇḍapāta santosaḥ ti piṇḍapāte vitakka santosaḥ gamana santosaḥ pariyesana santosaḥ paṭilābha santosaḥ  paṭiggahaṇa santosaḥ matta paṭiggahaṇa santosaḥ loluppa vivajjana santosaḥ yathā lābha santosaḥ
translated: Contentment with alms-food: contentment with the thought of alms-food, contentment with the going, contentment with the search, contentment with the acquisition,🔽contentment with the acceptance, contentment with the amount accepted, contentment with the avoidance of greed, contentment with what comes in,

original: yathābalasantoso yathāsāruppasantoso upakārasantoso parimāṇasantoso paribhogasantoso
analyzed: yathā bala santosaḥ yathā sāruppa santosaḥ upakāra santosaḥ parimāṇa santosaḥ paribhoga santosaḥ
translated: contentment with what is possible, contentment with what is suitable, contentment with the benefit, contentment with the measure, contentment with the use,

original: sannidhiparivajjanasantoso vissajjanasantosoti pannarasa santosā.
analyzed: sannidhi parivajjana santosaḥ vissajjana santosaḥ ti pannarasa santosā
translated: contentment with the avoidance of storing, contentment with the giving away. These are the fifteen kinds of contentment.🔽Herein, a monk who is a good hand at it washes his mouth and thinks:

original: Tattha sādako bhikkhu mukhaṃ dhovitvā vitakketi. Piṇḍapātikena pana gaṇena saddhiṃ
analyzed: tattha sādakaḥ bhikkhu mukham dhovitvā vitakketi piṇḍapātikena pana gaṇena saddhiṃ
translated: “I will go for alms with a group of monks.”

original: caratā sāyaṃ therūpaṭṭhānakāle “sve kattha piṇḍāya carissāmāti? Asukagāme, bhante”ti
analyzed: caratā sāyam thera upaṭṭhāna kāle sve kattha piṇḍāya carissāma ati asuka gāme bhante iti
translated: When it is time for the senior monks to be assigned dwellings, he says, “Venerables, tomorrow we will go for alms in such-and-such a village.”

original: ettakaṃ cintetvā tato paṭṭhāya na vitakketabbaṃ. Ekacārikena vitakkamāḷake ṭhatvā
analyzed: ettakam cintetvā tatas paṭṭhāya na vitakketabbam ekacārikena vitakkamāḷake ṭhatvā
translated: Having thought out this much, he should not think any more. He should stand in the doorway of thought.

original: vitakketabbaṃ. Tato paṭṭhāya vitakkento ariyavaṃsā cuto hoti paribāhiro. Ayaṃ vitakkasantoso nāma.
analyzed: vitakketabbam tatas paṭṭhāya vitakkento ariya vaṃsā cutaḥ hoti paribāhiraḥ ayam vitakka santosaḥ nāma
translated: If he thinks after that, he is outside the noble lineage and is excluded. This is called contentment with thought.

original: Piṇḍāya pavisantena “kuhiṃ labhissāmī”ti acintetvā kammaṭṭhānasīsena gantabbaṃ. Ayaṃ🔽gamanasantoso nāma. Pariyesantena yaṃ vā taṃ vā aggahetvā lajjiṃ pesalameva gahetvā🔽pariyesitabbaṃ. Ayaṃ pariyesanasantoso nāma. Dūratova āhariyamānaṃ disvā “etaṃ manāpaṃ,
analyzed: piṇḍāya pavisantena kuhim labhissāmi iti a cintetvā kammaṭṭhāna sīsena gantabbam ayam  gamana santosaḥ nāma pariyesantena yam vā tam vā aggahetvā lajjim pesalam eva gahetvā  pariyesitabbam ayam pariyesana santosaḥ nāma dūratas vas āhariyamānam disvā etam manāpam
translated: When he goes for alms, he should not think, “Where shall I get alms?” He should go with his head focused on his meditation subject. This is called🔽contentment with respect to going. While he is seeking alms, he should not pick and choose. He should take whatever is given, whether it is good or bad, and go away. This is called contentment with respect to seeking.

original: etaṃ amanāpa”nti cittaṃ na uppādetabbaṃ. Ayaṃ paṭilābhasantoso nāma. “Imaṃ manāpaṃ
analyzed: etam amanāpanti cittam na uppādetabbam ayam paṭilābha santosaḥ nāma imam manāpam
translated: When he sees food being brought to him from a distance, he should not arouse thoughts of satisfaction or dissatisfaction thus: “This is to my liking,” or “This is not to my liking.” This is called contentment with respect to obtaining.

original: gaṇhissāmi, imaṃ amanāpaṃ na gaṇhissāmī”ti acintetvā yaṃkiñci yāpanamattaṃ gahetabbameva.
analyzed: gaṇhissāmi imam amanāpam na gaṇhissāmi iti a cintetvā yaṃ kiñci yāpana mattam gahetabbam eva
translated: He should not think, “I shall take this which is to my liking, and I shall not take that which is not to my liking.” He should take whatever is given, just enough to sustain his life.

original: Ayaṃ paṭiggahaṇasantoso nāma.
analyzed: ayam paṭiggahaṇa santosaḥ nāma
translated: This is called contentment with respect to receiving.

original: Ettha pana deyyadhammo bahu, dāyako appaṃ dātukāmo, appaṃ gahetabbaṃ. Deyyadhammopi🔽bahu, dāyakopi bahuṃ dātukāmo, pamāṇeneva gahetabbaṃ. Deyyadhammo na bahu, dāyakopi🔽appaṃ dātukāmo, appaṃ gahetabbaṃ. Deyyadhammo na bahu, dāyako pana bahuṃ dātukāmo,
analyzed: ettha pana deyya dhammaḥ bahu dāyakaḥ appam dātu kāmaḥ appam gahetabbam deyya dhammaḥ api  bahu dāyakaḥ api bahum dātu kāmo pamāṇena iva gahetabbam deyya dhammaḥ na bahu dāyakaḥ api  appam dātu kāmaḥ appam gahetabbam deyya dhammo na bahu dāyakaḥ pana bahum dātu kāmo
translated: Herein, if the thing to be given is much and the giver wishes to give little, he should take little. If the thing to be given is much and the giver wishes to give much, he should take according to the measure. If the thing to be given is little and the giver wishes to give little, he should take little. If the thing to be given is little and the giver wishes to give much,🔽he should take according to the measure.

original: pamāṇena gahetabbaṃ. Paṭiggahaṇasmiñhi mattaṃ ajānanto manussānaṃ pasādaṃ makkheti,
analyzed: pamāṇena gahetabbam paṭiggahaṇasmin hi mattam a jānantaḥ manussānam pasādam makkheti
translated: Herein, if there is much to be given and the giver is willing to give little, then little should be accepted. If there is much to be given and the giver is willing to give much, then it should be accepted by measure. If there is little to be given and the giver is willing to give little, then little should be accepted. If there is little to be given and the giver is willing to give much, then it should be accepted by measure. For if he does not know the right amount in receiving, he spoils the confidence of the people,

original: saddhādeyyaṃ vinipāteti, sāsanaṃ na karoti, vijātamātuyāpi cittaṃ gahetuṃ na sakkoti.
analyzed: saddhā ādeyyam vinipāta iti sāsanam na karoti vijāta mātuyā api cittam gahetum na sakkoti
translated: he misappropriates what is given in faith, he does not honour the Dispensation, and he is unable to take the mind of a mother or a father or a maternal uncle or an aunt or a teacher or one who deserves respect, and lead it to the deathless.

original: Iti mattaṃ jānitvāva paṭiggahetabbanti ayaṃ mattapaṭiggahaṇasantoso nāma. Aḍḍhakulāniyeva
analyzed: iti mattam jānitvā ava paṭiggahetabbanti ayam matta paṭiggahaṇa santosaḥ nāma aḍḍha kulāniyā iva
translated: So it should be accepted knowing the right amount. This is called contentment with what is proper to accept.

original: agantvā dvārapaṭipāṭiyā gantabbaṃ. Ayaṃ loluppavivajjanasantoso nāma. Yathālābhasantosādayo
analyzed: a gantvā dvāra paṭipāṭiyā gantabbam ayam loluppa vivajjana santosaḥ nāma yathā lābha santosa ādayo
translated: He should go round by the door, not skipping from house to house. This is called contentment that discriminates between what is enough and what is not enough.

original: cīvare vuttanayā eva.
analyzed: cīvare eva
translated: Contentment with what is obtained, etc., are as already described in the case of robes .

original: Piṇḍapātaṃ paribhuñjitvā “samaṇadhammaṃ anupālessāmī”ti evaṃ upakāraṃ ñatvā paribhuñjanaṃ🔽upakārasantoso nāma. Pattaṃ pūretvā ānītaṃ na paṭiggahetabbaṃ. Anupasampanne sati
analyzed: piṇḍapātam paribhuñjitvā samaṇa dhammam anupālessāmi iti evam upakāram ñatvā paribhuñjanam  upakāra santosaḥ nāma pattam pūretvā ānītam na paṭiggahetabbam an upasampanne sati
translated: When he eats almsfood, knowing that it is a help, thinking, “I shall maintain the ascetic practice and I shall maintain the spiritual life,”🔽this is called satisfaction in the help.🔽When he has filled his bowl, he should not accept more. If there is anyone who is not fully admitted to the Order,

original: tena gāhāpetabbaṃ, asati harāpetvā paṭiggahaṇamattaṃ gahetabbaṃ. Ayaṃ parimāṇasantoso
analyzed: tena gāhāpetabbam asati harāpetvā paṭiggahaṇa mattam gahetabbam ayam parimāṇa santoso
translated: he should get him to take it. If there is no one, he should get it taken away and then take it himself. This is called satisfaction in moderation.

original: nāma. “Jighacchāya paṭivinodanaṃ idamettha nissaraṇa”nti evaṃ paribhuñjanaṃ paribhogasantoso🔽nāma. Nidahitvā na paribhuñjitabbanti ayaṃ sannidhiparivajjanasantoso nāma. Mukhaṃ
analyzed: nāma jighacchāya paṭivinodanam idam ettha nissaraṇa nti evam paribhuñjanam paribhoga santosaḥ  nāma nidahitvā na paribhuñjitabbanti ayam sannidhi parivajjana santosaḥ nāma mukham
translated: When he eats thinking, “This is for the purpose of warding off hunger and for the purpose of maintaining the spiritual life,” this is called satisfaction in using.🔽When he does not eat after storing, this is called satisfaction in avoiding storing.

original: anoloketvā sāraṇīyadhamme ṭhitena vissajjetabbaṃ. Ayaṃ vissajjanasantoso nāma.
analyzed: anoloketvā sāraṇīya dhamme ṭhitena vissajjetabbam ayam vissajjana santosaḥ nāma
translated: When he does not look at the face and he gives the food while standing in the Dhamma of helpfulness, this is called satisfaction in giving.

original: Piṇḍapātappaṭisaṃyuttāni pana pañca dhutaṅgāni piṇḍapātikaṅgaṃ sapadānacārikaṅgaṃ
analyzed: piṇḍapāta paṭisaṃyuttāni pana pañca dhutaṅgāni piṇḍapātikaṅgam sa padāna cārikaṅgam
translated: But the five ascetic practices connected with alms food are the alms-food-eater’s practice, the house-to-house seeker’s practice,

original: ekāsanikaṅgaṃ pattapiṇḍikaṅgaṃ khalupacchābhattikaṅganti. Tesaṃ vitthārakathā visuddhimagge
analyzed: eka āsanika patta piṇḍika aṅgam khalu pacchābhattika anti tesam vitthāra kathā visuddhi magge
translated: the one-sessioner’s practice, the bowl-food-eater’s practice, and the later-food-refuser’s practice. The detailed explanation of these is in the Path of Purity .

analyzed: vuttāḥ iti piṇḍapāta santosa mahāariya vaṃsam pūrayamānaḥ bhikkhu imāni pañca dhutaṅgāni
translated: The bhikkhu who keeps to these five ascetic practices

original: gopeti, imāni gopento piṇḍapātasantosamahāariyavaṃsena santuṭṭho hoti. Vaṇṇavādītiādīni
analyzed: gopa iti imāni gopentaḥ piṇḍapāta santosa mahāariya vaṃsena santuṭṭhaḥ hoti vaṇṇa vādī itiādīni
translated: is content with whatever alms food he gets. He is called “one who has the Great Man’s gait” because he goes about like a great thoroughbred elephant.

original: pīṭhaṃ bhisi bimbohanaṃ vihāro aḍḍhayogo pāsādo hammiyaṃ guhā leṇaṃ aṭṭo māḷo veḷugumbo
analyzed: pīṭham bhisi bimbohanam vihāraḥ aḍḍhayogaḥ pāsādaḥ hammiyam guhā leṇam aṭṭaḥ māḷaḥ veḷugumbaḥ
translated: A tree-trunk site is a site for a tree-trunk.

analyzed: rukkha mūlam yattha vā pana bhikkhū paṭikkamanti iti imāni pannarasa senāsanāni

original: Senāsanakkhettanti saṅghato vā gaṇato vā ñātito vā mittato vā attano vā dhanena paṃsukūlaṃ vāti cha khettāni.
analyzed: senāsana khettanti saṅghataḥ vā gaṇataḥ vā ñātitaḥ vā mittataḥ vā attanaḥ vā dhanena paṃsukūlam vā ati cha khettāni
translated: A tree-trunk site is a site for a

original: Senāsanasantosoti senāsane vitakkasantosādayo pannarasa santosā. Te piṇḍapāte vuttanayeneva
analyzed: senāsana santoso ti senāsane vitakka santosa ādayo santosā te piṇḍapāte vutta nayena iva
translated: Content with the resting place: there are fifteen kinds of contentment, beginning with contentment with the search for the resting place. They should be understood in the way already given under the alms food.

original: veditabbā. Senāsanappaṭisaṃyuttāni pana pañca dhutaṅgāni āraññikaṅgaṃ rukkhamūlikaṅgaṃ
analyzed: veditabbā senāsana paṭisaṃyuttāni pana pañca dhutaṅgāni āraññika aṅgam rukkhamūlika aṅgam
translated: The five ascetic practices connected with the resting place are: the open-air-dweller’s practice, the tree-root-dweller’s practice,

original: abbhokāsikaṅgaṃ sosānikaṅgaṃ yathāsanthatikaṅganti. Tesaṃ vitthārakathā visuddhimagge
analyzed: abbhokāsikaṅgam sosānikaṅgam yathā santhatikaṅganti tesam vitthāra kathā visuddhi magge
translated: the any-bed-user’s practice, the charnel-ground-dweller’s practice, and the any-house-dweller’s practice. The detailed explanation of these is given in the Path of Purity .

analyzed: vuttāḥ iti senāsana santosa mahāariya vaṃsam pūrayamānaḥ bhikkhu imāni pañca dhutaṅgāni
translated: So a bhikkhu who fulfils the Great Man’s ideal of contentment with the resting place maintains these five ascetic practices.

original: gopeti. Imāni gopento senāsanasantosamahāariyavaṃsena santuṭṭho hoti.
analyzed: gopa iti imāni gopentaḥ senāsana santosa mahāariya vaṃsena santuṭṭhaḥ hoti
translated: Maintaining them, he is content with the Great Man’s ideal of contentment with the resting place.🔽The requisite of medicine is included in the alms food. Herein, he should be content with whatever is obtained by way of the contentment consisting in what is proper and becoming in the search, the acceptance, and the use .

original: Gilānapaccayo pana piṇḍapāteyeva paviṭṭho. Tattha yathālābhayathābalayathāsāruppasantoseneva santussitabbaṃ. Nesajjikaṅgaṃ bhāvanārāmaariyavaṃsaṃ bhajati. Vuttampi cetaṃ –
analyzed: gilāna paccayo pana piṇḍapāteya iva paviṭṭhaḥ tattha yathā lābha yathā bala yathā sāruppa santosena iva santussitabbam nesajjika aṅgam bhāvanā ārāma ariya vaṃsam bhajati vuttam pi ca itam
translated: The practice of the sitter is included in the Great Man’s ideal of delight in development. And this is said:

original: “Pañca senāsane vuttā, pañca āhāranissitā;
analyzed: pañca senāsane vuttā pañca āhāra nissitā
translated: “Five in the case of the resting place, Five in the case of the food,

original: Eko vīriyasaṃyutto, dve ca cīvaranissitā”ti.
analyzed: ekaḥ vīriya saṃyuttaḥ dve ca cīvara nissitā ati
translated: One in the case of energy, And two in the case of the robe.”

original: Iti bhagavā pathaviṃ pattharamāno viya sāgarakucchiṃ pūrayamāno viya ākāsaṃ vitthārayamāno🔽viya ca paṭhamaṃ cīvarasantosaṃ ariyavaṃsaṃ kathetvā candaṃ uṭṭhāpento viya sūriyaṃ
analyzed: iti bhagavā pathavim pattharamānaḥ viya sāgara kucchim pūrayamānaḥ viya ākāsam vitthārayamānaḥ  viya ca paṭhamam cīvara santosam ariya vaṃsam kathetvā candam uṭṭhāpentaḥ viya sūriyam
translated: So the Blessed One, as if stretching out the earth, as if filling the ocean’s cavity, as if spreading out the sky,🔽having first told the noble line of contentment with robes, like one who raises the moon,

original: ullaṅghento viya ca dutiyaṃ piṇḍapātasantosaṃ kathetvā sineruṃ ukkhipanto viya tatiyaṃ
analyzed: ullaṅghentaḥ viya ca dutiyam piṇḍapāta santosam kathetvā sinerum ukkhipantaḥ viya tatiyam
translated: like one who overleaps the sun, having told the second noble line of contentment with alms food, like one who lifts up Sineru,

original: senāsanasantosaṃ ariyavaṃsaṃ kathetvā idāni sahassanayapaṭimaṇḍitaṃ catutthaṃ bhāvanārāmaṃ
analyzed: senāsana santosam ariya vaṃsam kathetvā idāni sahassa naya paṭimaṇḍitam catuttham bhāvanā ārāmam
translated: having told the third noble line of contentment with rest in any position, now, in order to tell the fourth noble line of delight in development, adorned with a thousand similes,

original: ariyavaṃsaṃ kathetuṃ puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu bhāvanārāmo hotīti desanaṃ ārabhi.🔽Tattha āramaṇaṃ ārāmo, abhiratīti attho. Bhāvanāya ārāmo assāti bhāvanārāmo. Bhāvanāya
analyzed: ariya vaṃsam kathetum puna ca param bhikkhave bhikkhu bhāvanā ārāmaḥ hoti iti desanam ārabhi  tattha āramaṇam ārāmaḥ abhirati iti atthaḥ bhāvanāya ārāmaḥ assa ati bhāvanā ārāmaḥ bhāvanāya
translated: he began the teaching with the words “Again, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu delights in development” .

original: ratoti bhāvanārato. Pañcavidhe pahāne ārāmo assāti pahānārāmo. Apica bhāvento ramatīti
analyzed: rato ti bhāvanā rato pañcavidhe pahāne ārāmaḥ assa ati pahāna ārāmaḥ apica bhāventaḥ ramati iti
translated: Herein, delighting is delight, enjoyment is the meaning. He is a delight in development, thus he is a delight in development. He is pleased with development, thus he is pleased with development. He is a delight in the five kinds of abandonment, thus he is a delight in the five kinds of abandonment. Furthermore, he delights in development, thus he is a delight in development.

original: bhāvanārāmo. Pajahanto ramatīti pahānārāmoti evamettha attho daṭṭhabbo. Ayañhi cattāro
analyzed: bhāvanā ārāmaḥ pajahantaḥ ramati iti pahānā ārāmaḥ ti evam ettha atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo ayam hi cattāro
translated: He delights in abandoning, thus he is one who delights in abandoning. This is how the meaning should be regarded here. For this meditator

original: satipaṭṭhāne bhāvento ramati, ratiṃ vindatīti attho. Tathā cattāro sammappadhāne.
analyzed: satipaṭṭhāne bhāvento ramati ratim vindati iti attho tathā cattāro sammappadhāne
translated: He delights in development. He delights in abandoning. This is how the meaning should be regarded here. For this bhikkhu delights in, finds satisfaction in, the four foundations of mindfulness. The meaning is that he finds satisfaction in them. Likewise in the four right kinds of striving,

original: Cattāro iddhipāde, pañcindriyāni, pañca balāni, satta bojjhaṅge, satta anupassanā,
analyzed: cattāraḥ iddhipāde pañca indriyāni pañca balāni satta bojjhaṅge satta anupassanā
translated: in the four bases for spiritual power, the five spiritual faculties, the five powers, the seven factors of enlightenment, the seven kinds of right view,

original: aṭṭhārasa mahāvipassanā, sattatiṃsa bodhipakkhiyadhamme, aṭṭhatiṃsa ārammaṇavibhattiyo
analyzed: aṭṭhārasa mahāvipassanā sattatiṃsa bodhi pakkhiya dhamme aṭṭhatiṃsa ārammaṇa vibhattiyo
translated: the eighteen principal insights, the thirty-seven states partaking of enlightenment, and the thirty-eight objects of insight.

original: bhāvento ramati, ratiṃ vindati. Kāmacchandādayo pana kilese pajahanto ramati, ratiṃ vindati.
analyzed: ramati ratim vindati kāmacchanda ādayaḥ pana kilese pajahantaḥ ramati ratim vindati
translated: He delights in, finds satisfaction in, the abandoning of the defilements beginning with lust.

original: Imesu pana catūsu ariyavaṃsesu purimehi tīhi terasannaṃ dhutaṅgānaṃ catupaccayasantosassa
analyzed: imesu pana catūsu ariya vaṃsesu purimehi tīhi dhutaṅgānam catu paccaya santosassa
translated: Now, in these four noble heritages, the first three are stated by way of the thirteen ascetic practices and the contentment with any alms bowl, etc.,

original: ca vasena sakalaṃ vinayapiṭakaṃ kathitaṃ hoti, bhāvanārāmena avasesaṃ piṭakadvayaṃ.
analyzed: ca vasena sakalam vinaya piṭakam kathitam bhāvanā ārāmena avasesam piṭaka dvayam
translated: and the last one is stated by way of the rest of the Vinaya Piṭaka and the rest of the two Piṭakas.

original: Imaṃ pana bhāvanārāmaṃ ariyavaṃsaṃ kathentena bhikkhunā paṭisambhidāmagge nekkhammapāḷiyā
analyzed: imam pana bhāvanā ārāmam ariya vaṃsam kathentena bhikkhunā paṭisambhidā magge nekkhamma pāḷiyā
translated: When this bhikkhu is expounding this noble heritage of delight in development, he should expound it by way of the section on renunciation in the Paṭisambhidā Magga .

original: kathetabbo, dīghanikāye dasuttarasuttantapariyāyena kathetabbo, majjhimanikāye satipaṭṭhānasuttantapariyāyena
analyzed: kathetabbaḥ dīgha nikāye dasuttara suttanta pariyāyena kathetabbaḥ majjhima nikāye sati paṭṭhāna suttanta pariyāyena
translated: It should be expounded by the Dasuttarasutta method in the Long Division,🔽by the Satipatthānasutta method in the Middle Length Division,

original: kathetabbo, abhidhamme niddesapariyāyena kathetabbo.
analyzed: kathetabbaḥ abhidhamme niddesa pariyāyena kathetabbaḥ
translated: and by the Niddesa method in the Abhidhamma Piṭaka.

original: Tattha paṭisambhidāmagge nekkhammapāḷiyāti –
analyzed: tattha paṭisambhidā magge nekkhamma pāḷiyā
translated: Herein, in the Path of Discrimination, in the section on renunciation,

original: “Nekkhammaṃ bhāvento ramati, kāmacchandaṃ pajahanto ramati. Abyāpādaṃ, byāpādaṃ…
analyzed: nekkhammam bhāventaḥ ramati kāmacchandam pajahantaḥ ramati a byāpādam byāpādam
translated: he delights in developing renunciation, he delights in abandoning sensual desire. He delights in developing non-ill will, in abandoning ill will.

original: ālokasaññaṃ… thinamiddhaṃ… avikkhepaṃ, uddhaccaṃ… dhammavavatthānaṃ… vicikicchaṃ…🔽ñāṇaṃ… avijjaṃ… pāmojjaṃ… aratiṃ… paṭhamajjhānaṃ, pañca nīvaraṇe… dutiyajjhānaṃ…
analyzed: āloka saññam thinam iddham avikkhepam uddhaccam dhamma vavatthānam vicikiccham  ñāṇam avijjam pāmojjam aratim paṭhama jhānam pañca nīvaraṇe dutiya jhānam
translated: He delights in developing perception of light, in abandoning torpor and drowsiness. He delights in developing concentration, in abandoning agitation and worry. He delights in defining mentality-materiality, in abandoning uncertainty.

original: vitakkavicāre… tatiyajjhānaṃ… pītiṃ… catutthajjhānaṃ… sukhadukkhe… ākāsānañcāyatanasamāpattiṃ
analyzed: vitakka vicāre tatiya jhānam pītim catuttha jhānam sukha dukkhe ākāsa anañca āyatana samāpattim
translated: He delights in developing the first jhāna, in abandoning the five hindrances. He delights in developing the second jhāna, in abandoning applied and sustained thought. He delights in developing the third jhāna, in abandoning rapture. He delights in developing the fourth jhāna, in abandoning pleasure and pain. He delights in developing the base consisting of boundless space,

original: bhāvento ramati, rūpasaññaṃ paṭighasaññaṃ nānattasaññaṃ pajahanto ramati. Viññāṇañcāyatanasamāpattiṃ…pe…
analyzed: bhāventaḥ ramati rūpa saññam paṭigha saññam nānatta saññam pajahantaḥ ramati viññāṇam ca āyatana samāpattim pe
translated: in abandoning perception of materiality, perception of impingement, and perception of variety. He delights in developing the base consisting of boundless consciousness …

original: nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasamāpattiṃ bhāvento ramati, ākiñcaññāyatanasaññaṃ pajahanto ramati.
analyzed: nevasaññānāsaññāyatana samāpattim bhāventaḥ ramati ākiñcaññāyatana saññam pajahantaḥ ramati
translated: He delights in developing the attainment of the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, in giving up the perception of the base of nothingness.

original: “Aniccānupassanaṃ bhāvento ramati, niccasaññaṃ pajahanto ramati. Dukkhānupassanaṃ…

original: Dīghanikāye dasuttarasuttantapariyāyenāti –🔽“Ekaṃ dhammaṃ bhāvento ramati, ekaṃ dhammaṃ pajahanto ramati…pe… dasa dhamme bhāvento🔽ramati, dasa dhamme pajahanto ramati. Katamaṃ ekaṃ dhammaṃ bhāvento ramati? Kāyagatāsatiṃ

translated: In the ten-&-one sutta method in the Long Division:🔽“One who develops one idea delights in one idea, and abandoning one idea he delights in abandoning one idea. … One who develops ten ideas delights in ten ideas, and abandoning ten ideas he delights in abandoning ten ideas. translated: This is how the exposition should be known here in brief in the Dīgha Nikāya by means of the tenfold method in the Dasuttara Sutta.🔽In the Majjhima Nikāya by means of the Satipaṭṭhāna Sutta:🔽“Monks, this is the direct path for the purification of beings, for the surmounting of sorrow and lamentation, for the disappearance of pain and grief, for the attainment of the true way, for the realisation of Nibbāna—namely, the four foundations of mindfulness.🔽He dwells contemplating (the nature of) the body in the body, ardent, clearly comprehending, and mindful, after removing avarice and sorrow regarding the world.🔽He dwells contemplating (the nature of) feelings in feelings, ardent, clearly comprehending, and mindful, after removing avarice and sorrow regarding the world.🔽He dwells contemplating (the nature of) the mind in the mind, ardent, clearly comprehending, and mindful, after removing avarice and sorrow regarding the world.🔽He dwells contemplating (the nature of) things in (various) things, ardent, clearly comprehending, and mindful, after removing avarice and sorrow regarding the world.🔽 Translation: dasa dhamme bhāvento ramati? dasa kasiṇāyatanāni, ime dasa dhamme bhāvento ramati.

original: susamāhitoti niyakajjhatte suṭṭhu ṭhapitacitto imasmiṃ suttepi gāthāyapi vaṭṭavivaṭṭaṃ kathitaṃ.

translated: Of these four lions, it is the maned lion that is intended here.

original: gocaratthāya, sambhavapīḷito vā assaddhammapaṭisevanatthāya. Idha pana gocaratthāya🔽nikkhamanto adhippeto.
analyzed: gocara tthāya sambhava pīḍitaḥ vā assaddhamma paṭisevana tthāya idha pana gocara tthāya  nikkhamantaḥ adhippetaḥ
translated: ‘King of beasts’: king of all the herd of beasts. ‘From his lair’: from his dwelling place, or from his golden cave, or from his silver, or crystal, or ruby cave, ‘he comes forth’: what is meant is that he comes out. But he comes out for four reasons: either because he is oppressed by darkness and he comes out for light, or because he is oppressed by urine and excrement and he comes out to void them, or because he is oppressed by hunger and he comes out to seek for food, or because he is oppressed by lust and he comes out to indulge in sexual intercourse. But here it is intended that he comes out to seek for food.

original: Vijambhatīti suvaṇṇatale vā rajatamaṇiphalikamanosilātalānaṃ vā aññatarasmiṃ dve
analyzed: vijambhati iti suvaṇṇa tale vā rajata maṇi phalika manosilā talānam vā aññatarasmim dve
translated: ‘He yawns’: on a golden surface or on a silver, or crystal, or ruby surface,

original: pacchimapāde samaṃ patiṭṭhāpetvā purimapāde purato pasāretvā sarīrassa pacchābhāgaṃ
analyzed: pacchima pāde samam patiṭṭhāpetvā purima pāde puratas pasāretvā sarīrassa pacchābhāgam
translated: He sets his hind legs evenly, stretches his forelegs in front,

original: ākaḍḍhitvā purimabhāgaṃ abhiharitvā piṭṭhiṃ nāmetvā gīvaṃ ukkhipitvā asanisaddaṃ🔽karonto viya nāsapuṭāni pothetvā sarīralaggaṃ rajaṃ vidhunanto vijambhati. Vijambhanabhūmiyañca
analyzed: ākaḍḍhitvā purima bhāgam abhiharitvā piṭṭhim nāmetvā gīvam ukkhipitvā asani saddam  karontaḥ viya nāsa puṭāni pothetvā sarīra laggam rajam vidhunantaḥ vijambhati vijambhana bhūmiyañca
translated: draws up his hind part, thrusts out his forepart, bends his back, raises his neck, and yawns as if making the sound of thunder.🔽He shakes the dust on his body, yawning. And on the yawning ground

original: pana taruṇavacchako viya aparāparaṃ javati, javato panassa sarīraṃ andhakāre paribbhamantaṃ
analyzed: pana taruṇa vacchakaḥ viya apara aparam javati javataḥ panassa sarīram andhakāre paribbhamantam
translated: he moves to and fro like a young calf. But as he moves, his body appears

original: alātaṃ viya khāyati.🔽Anuviloketīti kasmā anuviloketi? Parānuddayatāya. Tasmiṃ kira sīhanādaṃ nadante papātāvāṭādīsu
analyzed: alātam viya khāyati  anuvilokā iti iti kasmai anuvilokā iti tasmin kira sīha nādam nadante papāta āvāṭa ādīsu
translated: like a whirling firebrand.

original: visamaṭṭhānesu carantā hatthigokaṇṇamahiṃsādayo pāṇā papātepi āvāṭepi patanti, tesaṃ
analyzed: visama ṭṭhānesu carantā hatthi gokaṇṇa mahiṃsa ādayo pāṇā papāte pi āvāṭe pi patanti tesam
translated: As to “he looks around”: why does he look around? Out of compassion for others. For when he roars his lion’s roar, it seems that elephants, oxen, buffaloes, etc., that wander in uneven places such as ravines and pits fall into the ravines and pits.🔽He looks around out of compassion for them.

original: anuddayāya anuviloketi. Kiṃ panassa luddassa paramaṃsakhādino anuddayā nāma atthīti?
analyzed: anuddayāya anuvilokā iti kim panassa luddassa para maṃsa khādinaḥ anuddayā nāma atthi iti
translated: But has not the hunter, his closest companion, compassion for others?

original: Āma atthi. Tathā hi “kiṃ me bahūhi ghātitehī”ti attano gocaratthāyāpi khuddake pāṇe
analyzed: āma atthi tathā hi kim me bahūhi ghātitehi iti attanaḥ gocara tthāya api khuddake pāṇe
translated: Yes, he does. For he does not take even small creatures for his own food, thinking, “What have I to do with killing?”🔽Thus he is harmless. And this is said of him:

original: na gaṇhāti. Evaṃ anuddayaṃ karoti, vuttampi cetaṃ – “māhaṃ khuddake pāṇe visamagate
analyzed: na gaṇhāti evam anuddayam karoti vuttam pi ca itam mā aham khuddake pāṇe visama gate
translated: “I will not cause the death of small creatures

original: saṅghātaṃ āpādesi”nti.
analyzed: saṅghātam
translated: that come within my range of vision.”

original: Sīhanādaṃ nadatīti tikkhattuṃ tāva abhītanādaṃ nadati. Evañca panassa vijambhanabhūmiyaṃ
analyzed: sīha nādam nadati iti tikkhattum tāva abhīta nādam nadati evam ca panassa vijambhana bhūmiyam
translated: He roars his roar: first he roars his fearless roar three times. And when he roars, standing on the place of roaring,

original: ṭhatvā nadantassa saddo samantā tiyojanapadesaṃ ekaninnādaṃ karoti, tamassa ninnādaṃ
analyzed: ṭhatvā nadantassa saddo samantā eka ninnādam karoti tamassa ninnādam
translated: his roar makes a single sound all over the three leagues around him.

original: sutvā tiyojanabbhantaragatā dvipadacatuppadagaṇā yathāṭhāne ṭhātuṃ na sakkonti. Gocarāya🔽pakkamatīti āhāratthāya gacchati. Kathaṃ? So hi vijambhanabhūmiyaṃ ṭhatvā dakkhiṇato
analyzed: sutvā ti yojana abbhantara gatāḥ dvipada catuppada gaṇāḥ yathāṭhāne ṭhātum na sakkonti gocarāya  pakkamati iti āhāra atthāya gacchati katham saḥ hi vijambhana bhūmiyam ṭhatvā dakkhiṇatas
translated: When the multitude of bipeds and quadrupeds within the three leagues hear that roar, they are unable to stay where they are.

original: vā vāmato vā uppatanto usabhamattaṃ ṭhānaṃ gaṇhāti, uddhaṃ uppatanto cattāripi aṭṭhapi
analyzed: vā vāmatas vā uppatantaḥ usabha mattam ṭhānam gaṇhāti uddham uppatantaḥ cattāri pi aṭṭha pi
translated: He goes on his way: he goes for the purpose of seeking food. How? Standing on the place of roaring, he takes a spring to the right or to the left and reaches a place the size of a bull’s body. When he springs upwards, he reaches a height of four or eight times the height of a tāla tree.

original: usabhaṭṭhānāni uppatati, same ṭhāne ujukaṃ pakkhandanto soḷasausabhamattampi vīsatiusabhamattampi🔽ṭhānaṃ pakkhandati, thalā vā pabbatā vā pakkhandanto saṭṭhiusabhamattampi asītiusabhamattampi
analyzed: usabha ṭṭhānāni uppatati same ṭhāne ujukam pakkhandanto soḷasa usabha mattam pi vīsati usabha mattam pi  ṭhānam pakkhandati thalāḥ vā pabbatāḥ vā pakkhandantaḥ saṭṭhi usabha mattam pi asīti usabha mattam pi
translated: He springs over the places where bulls stand, and when he springs on level ground he springs sixteen or twenty times the length of a bull’s body.

original: ṭhānaṃ pakkhandati, antarāmagge rukkhaṃ vā pabbataṃ vā disvā taṃ pariharanto vāmato
analyzed: ṭhānam pakkhandati antara āmagge rukkham vā pabbatam vā disvā tam pariharantaḥ vāmatas
translated: When he springs over trees or rocks he springs sixty or eighty times the length of a bull’s body. When he sees a tree or a rock on the way, he avoids it by going to the left or right or above or below the length of a bull’s body.

original: vā dakkhiṇato vā uddhaṃ vā usabhamattaṃ apakkamati. Tatiyaṃ pana sīhanādaṃ naditvā🔽teneva saddhiṃ tiyojane ṭhāne paññāyati, tiyojanaṃ gantvā nivattitvā ṭhito attanova
analyzed: vā dakkhiṇatas vā uddham vā usabha mattam apakkamati tatiyam pana sīha nādam naditvā  tena iva saddhim ti yojane ṭhāne paññāyati ti yojanam gantvā nivattitvā ṭhitaḥ attanā uva
translated: But when he roars his third roar,

original: nādassa anunādaṃ suṇāti. Evaṃ sīghena javena pakkamati.
analyzed: nādassa anunādam suṇāti evam sīghena javena pakkamati
translated: it is heard within a distance of three leagues. When he has gone three leagues, he turns back and stands. He alone hears the echo of his own roar. He goes with such speed.

original: Yebhuyyenāti pāyena. Bhayaṃ santāsaṃ saṃveganti sabbaṃ cittutrāsasseva nāmaṃ. Sīhassa
analyzed: yebhuyyena ati pāyena bhayam santāsam saṃvegam ti sabbam cittutrāsassa iva nāmam sīhassa
translated: ‘For the most part’: for the most part, not entirely. ‘Fear, terror, and horror’: all these are names for fear in the mind.

original: hi saddaṃ sutvā bahū bhāyanti, appakā na bhāyanti. Ke pana teti? Samasīho hatthājānīyo
analyzed: hi saddam sutvā bahū bhāyanti appakāḥ na bhāyanti ke pana te iti samasīhaḥ hatthājānīyaḥ
translated: For when they hear the lion’s roar, many are afraid, but few are not afraid. But who are they that are not afraid? The lion, the elephant, the bull, the thoroughbred horse, the fighting cock, and the leopard.

original: assājānīyo usabhājānīyo purisājānīyo khīṇāsavoti. Kasmā panete na bhāyantīti? Samasīho
analyzed: assājānīyaḥ usabhājānīyaḥ purisājānīyaḥ khīṇa asavaḥ ti kasmā pana ete na bhāyanti iti samasīhaḥ
translated: and the horse, the bull, the human, and the one whose cankers are destroyed. But why are they not afraid?

original: tāva “jātigottakulasūrabhāvehi samānosmī”ti na bhāyati, hatthājānīyādayo attano sakkāyadiṭṭhibalavatāya
analyzed: tāva jāti gotta kula sūra bhāvehi samānaḥ asmi iti na bhāyati attano sakkāya diṭṭhi balavatāya
translated: The lion, first of all, is not afraid, thinking, “I am equal to anyone in the matter of species, family, clan, and strength.” The horse, the bull, and the human are not afraid because of the strength of their false view of self.

original: na bhāyanti, khīṇāsavo sakkāyadiṭṭhiyā pahīnattā na bhāyati.
analyzed: na bhāyanti khīṇa asavo sakkāya diṭṭhiyā pahīna ttā na bhāyati
translated: The one whose cankers are destroyed is not afraid because he has abandoned the false view of self.

original: Bilāsayāti bile sayantā bilavāsino ahinakulagodhādayo. Udakāsayāti udakavāsino macchakacchapādayo.🔽Vanāsayāti vanavāsino hatthiassagokaṇṇamigādayo. Pavisantīti “idāni āgantvā gaṇhissatī”ti
analyzed: bilāsayāti bile sayantāḥ bila vāsinaḥ ahi nakula godhā ādayaḥ udakāsayāti udaka vāsinaḥ maccha kacchapa ādayaḥ  vanāsayā ati vana vāsinaḥ hatthi assa gokaṇṇa miga ādayaḥ pavisanti iti idāni āgantvā gaṇhissati iti
translated: “Dwelling in holes”: snakes, mongooses, and so on, that live in holes. “Dwelling in water”: fish, turtles, and so on, that live in water.🔽“Dwelling in the forest”: elephants, horses, oxen, deer, and so on, that live in the forest. “They enter”: they enter the path, thinking, “Now he will come and catch me.”

original: maggaṃ oloketvā pavisanti. Daḷhehīti thirehi. Varattehīti cammarajjūhi. Mahiddhikotiādīsu
analyzed: maggam oloketvā pavisanti daḷhehi iti thirehi varattehi iti camma rajjūhi mahiddhika uti ādīsu
translated: “Tie up well”: with strong ropes. “Bind well”: with leather thongs. “He is powerful” and so on:

original: vijambhanabhūmiyaṃ ṭhatvā dakkhiṇapassādīhi usabhamattaṃ, ujuṃ vīsatiusabhamattādilaṅghanavasena
analyzed: vijambhana bhūmiyam ṭhatvā dakkhiṇa passa ādīhi usabha mattam ujum vīsati usabha matta ādi laṅghana vasena
translated: standing on the ground where he yawns, he can kick with his hind legs to the right and left to the extent of a bull’s breadth, and he can jump straight up to the extent of two bull’s breadths.

original: mahiddhikatā, sesamigānaṃ adhipatibhāvena mahesakkhatā, samantā tiyojanaṭṭhāne saddaṃ
analyzed: mahiddhika tā sesa migānam adhipati bhāvena mahesakkha tā samantā ti yojana ṭṭhāne saddam
translated: the great power, the great influence of the rest of the herd through the state of being the chief, the sound in a place all round three leagues,

original: sutvā palāyantānaṃ vasena mahānubhāvatā veditabbā.🔽Evameva khoti bhagavā tesu tesu suttantesu tathā tathā attānaṃ kathesi. “Sīhoti kho,🔽bhikkhave, tathāgatassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ arahato sammāsambuddhassā”ti imasmiṃ tāva🔽sutte sīhasadisaṃ attānaṃ kathesi. “Bhisakko sallakattoti kho, sunakkhatta, tathāgatassetaṃ🔽adhivacana”nti imasmiṃ vejjasadisaṃ, “brāhmaṇoti kho, bhikkhave, tathāgatassetaṃ
analyzed: sutvā palāyantānam vasena mahā anubhāva tā veditabbā  evam eva kho ti bhagavā tesu tesu suttantesu tathā tathā attānam kathesi sīhaḥ iti kho  bhikkhave tathāgatassa itam adhivacanam arahataḥ sammāsambuddhassa ati imasmin tāva  sutte sīha sadisam attānam kathesi bhisakkaḥ sallakatto ti kho sunakkhatta tathāgatassa etam  adhivacanam ti imasmin vejja sadisam brāhmaṇaḥ iti kho bhikkhave tathāgatassa etam
translated: The greatness of his psychic power is the greatness of his sovereignty over the other animals. His greatness of influence should be understood as the fleeing of the other animals on hearing his roar at a distance of three leagues.

original: adhivacana”nti imasmiṃ brāhmaṇasadisaṃ, “puriso maggakusaloti kho, tissa, tathāgatassetaṃ🔽adhivacana”nti imasmiṃ maggadesakapurisasadisaṃ, “rājāhamasmi, selā”ti imasmiṃ rājasadisaṃ.
analyzed: adhivacanam ti imasmin brāhmaṇa sadisam purisaḥ magga kusalaḥ ti kho tissa tathāgatassa etam 🔽adhivacanam ti imasmim magga desaka purisa sadisam rājā aham asmi imasmim rāja sadisam
translated: The Blessed One has spoken of himself in various ways in various suttas: “Bhikkhus, the Tathāgata, accomplished and fully enlightened, is said to be a lion, a tiger, a bull, an elephant, an admiral, a king, a brahman, a man, a doctor, a seer, a counsellor, a deva, a nāga, a supaṇṇa, a gandhabbha, an asura, a garuḍa, a kumbhaṇḍa, a rakkhasa, a piśāca, a bhikkhu, a deva-brahman, a wheel-turning monarch, a nāga-brahman, a nāga-king, a nāga-novice, a nāga-woman, a deva-novice, a deva-maiden, a human-brahman, a human-novice, a human-maiden, a deva-deva, a deva-nāga, a deva-supaṇṇa, a deva-gandhabbha, a deva-asura, a deva-garuḍa, a deva-kumbhaṇḍa, a deva-rakkhasa, a deva-piśāca, a deva-bhikkhu, a deva-deva-brahman, a deva-wheel-turning monarch, a deva-nāga-brahman, a deva-nāga-king, a deva-nāga-novice, a deva-nāga-woman, a deva-deva-novice, a deva-deva-maiden, a deva-human-brahman, a deva-human-novice, a deva-human-maiden, a deva-deva-deva, a deva-deva-nāga, a deva-deva-supaṇṇa, a deva-deva-gandhabbha, a deva-deva-asura, a deva-deva-garuḍa, a deva-deva-kumbhaṇḍa, a deva-deva-rakkhasa, a deva-deva-piśāca, a deva-deva-bhikkhu, a deva-deva-deva-brahman, a deva-deva-wheel-turning

original: Imasmiṃ pana sutte sīhasadisameva katvā attānaṃ kathento evamāha.
analyzed: imasmin pana sutte sīha sadisam eva katvā attānam kathentaḥ evam āha
translated: But in this sutta he describes himself as being like a lion.🔽Here is the parallel: just as the lion’s dwelling in the golden cave, etc.,

original: Tatrāyaṃ sadisatā – sīhassa kañcanaguhādīsu vasanakālo viya hi tathāgatassa dīpaṅkarapādamūle
analyzed: tatra ayam sadisa tā sīhassa kañcana guhā ādīsu vasana kālaḥ viya hi tathāgatassa dīpaṅkara pāda mūle
translated: so the Tathāgata’s performance of the Great Aspiration at the feet of Dīpaṅkara Buddha,

original: katābhinīhārassa aparimitakālaṃ pāramiyo pūretvā pacchimabhave paṭisandhiggahaṇena
analyzed: kata abhinīhārassa aparimita kālam pāramiyo pūretvā pacchima bhave paṭisandhi ggahaṇena
translated: his fulfilment of the pāramīs over an immeasurable period of time, his rebirth-linking in his last existence,

original: ceva mātukucchito nikkhamanena ca dasasahassilokadhātuṃ kampetvā vuddhimanvāya dibbasampattisadisaṃ
analyzed: ca iva mātukucchitaḥ nikkhamanena ca dasa sahassi lokadhātum kampetvā vuddhim anvāya dibba sampatti sadisam
translated: his causing the ten-thousand world-element to shake by his emerging from his mother’s womb, his growth, his enjoyment of the worldly perfections similar to the divine perfections,

original: sampattiṃ anubhavamānassa tīsu pāsādesu nivāsakālo daṭṭhabbo. Sīhassa kañcanaguhādito
analyzed: sampattim anubhavamānassa tīsu pāsādesu nivāsa kālaḥ daṭṭhabbo sīhassa kañcana guhā āditaḥ
translated: and his dwelling in the three palaces should be seen. Just as the lion’s emerging from the golden cave, etc.,

original: nikkhantakālo viya tathāgatassa ekūnatiṃsasaṃvacchare vivaṭena dvārena kaṇḍakaṃ āruyha
analyzed: nikkhanta kālaḥ viya tathāgatassa ekūnatiṃsa saṃvacchare vivaṭena dvārena kaṇḍakam āruyha
translated: so the Tathāgata’s departure from home after twenty-nine years, his going forth by the open door,

original: channasahāyassa nikkhamitvā tīṇi rajjāni atikkamitvā anomānadītīre brahmunā dinnāni
analyzed: channa sahāyassa nikkhamitvā tīṇi rajjāni atikkamitvā anomānadī tīre brahmunā dinnāni
translated: his crossing the three cords, his donning the ochre robes given to him by Brahmā on the bank of the Anomā River,

original: kāsāyāni paridahitvā pabbajitassa sattame divase rājagahaṃ gantvā tattha piṇḍāya
analyzed: kāsāyāni paridahitvā pabbajitassa sattame divase rājagaham gantvā tattha piṇḍāya
translated: and his going to Rājagaha on the seventh day and wandering for alms there.

original: caritvā paṇḍavagiripabbhāre katabhattakiccassa sammāsambodhiṃ patvā paṭhamameva magadharaṭṭhaṃ
analyzed: caritvā paṇḍavagiri pabbhāre kata bhatta kiccassa sammāsambodhim patvā paṭhamam eva magadha raṭṭham
translated: and after he had eaten his meal, he attained supreme enlightenment. Then, in order to come to the Magadha country,

original: āgamanatthāya yāva rañño paṭiññādānakālo.🔽Sīhassa vijambhanakālo viya tathāgatassa dinnapaṭiññassa āḷārakālāmaupasaṅkamanaṃ
analyzed: āgamana tthāya yāva rañño paṭiññā dāna kālo  sīhassa vijambhana kālaḥ viya tathāgatassa dinna paṭiññassa āḷāra kālāma upasaṅkamanam
translated: he waited until the king had given his promise.🔽The time from the time the Tathāgata accepted the promise,

original: ādiṃ katvā yāva sujātāya dinnapāyāsassa ekūnapaṇṇāsāya piṇḍehi paribhuttakālo veditabbo.
analyzed: ādim katvā yāva sujātāya dinnapāyāsassa ekūnapaṇṇāsāya piṇḍehi paribhutta kālaḥ veditabbaḥ
translated: beginning with his approach to Āḷāra Kālāma, until the time he had eaten the forty-nine lumps of food given by Sujātā, should be understood as the time of the lion’s yawning.

original: Sīhassa sarīravidhunanaṃ viya sāyanhasamaye sottiyena dinnā aṭṭha tiṇamuṭṭhiyo gahetvā🔽dasasahassacakkavāḷadevatāhi thomiyamānassa gandhādīhi pūjiyamānassa tikkhattuṃ bodhiṃ
analyzed: sīhassa sarīra vidhunanam viya sāyanha samaye sottiyena dinnāḥ aṭṭha tiṇa muṭṭhiyaḥ gahetvā  dasa sahassa cakkavāḷa devatāhi thomiyamānassa gandha ādīhi pūjiyamānassa tikkhattum bodhim
translated: The time from the time the eight handfuls of grass given by Suppiya were taken,

original: padakkhiṇaṃ katvā bodhimaṇḍaṃ āruyha cuddasahatthubbedhe ṭhāne tiṇasantharaṃ attharitvā
analyzed: padakkhiṇam katvā bodhimaṇḍam āruyha cuddasa hatthu bedhe ṭhāne tiṇa santharam attharitvā
translated: and the Bodhi Tree was circumambulated three times with the right side towards it, and the Bodhi Throne was ascended, and a bed of grass was spread on a place fourteen cubits wide,

original: caturaṅgavīriyaṃ adhiṭṭhāya nisinnassa taṃkhaṇaññeva mārabalaṃ vidhametvā tīsu yāmesu
analyzed: caturaṅga vīriyam adhiṭṭhāya nisinnassa taṃ khaṇañca eva māra balam vidhametvā tīsu yāmesu
translated: and he sat down with the four-limbed energy, and at that moment he destroyed the power of Māra, and in the three watches of the night,

original: tisso vijjā visodhetvā anulomappaṭilomaṃ paṭiccasamuppādamahāsamuddaṃ yamakañāṇamanthanena
analyzed: tissaḥ vijjāḥ visodhetvā anuloma ppaṭilomam paṭiccasamuppāda mahā samuddam yamaka ñāṇa manthanena
translated: Having purified the three knowledges, he churned the ocean of dependent origination, in forward and reverse order, with the churning-stick of the knowledge of the pairs.

original: manthentassa sabbaññutaññāṇe paṭividdhe tadanubhāvena dasasahassilokadhātukampanaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: manthentassa sabbaññu ta ññāṇe paṭividdhe tad anubhāvena dasa sahassi lokadhātu kampanam veditabbam
translated: And when he had penetrated the knowledge of omniscience, the ten-thousand world-spheres shook through the power of that knowledge.

original: Sīhassa catudisāvilokanaṃ viya paṭividdhasabbaññutaññāṇassa sattasattāhaṃ bodhimaṇḍe

translated: Then, after he had attained the knowledge of omniscience, he stayed in the vicinity of the Bodhi Tree for seven days, surveying the ten-thousand world-spheres in each of the four directions, like a lion looking out from his lair.

original: viharitvā paribhuttamadhupiṇḍikāhārassa ajapālanigrodhamūle mahābrahmuno dhammadesanāyācanaṃ

translated: After he had stayed there for seven days, he accepted the request of the Great Brahma to teach the Dhamma, which he did at the foot of the Ajapala Nigrodha tree.

original: paṭiggahetvā tattha viharantassa ekādasame divase “sve āsāḷhipuṇṇamā bhavissatī”ti🔽paccūsasamaye “kassa nu kho ahaṃ paṭhamaṃ dhammaṃ deseyya”nti āḷārudakānaṃ kālakatabhāvaṃ

translated: Then, after he had stayed there for eleven days and had eaten the honey-ball offered by Sujata, he thought: “Tomorrow is the full-moon day of the month of Asalha.🔽“Who should I teach the Dhamma first?” He then saw that Alara Kalama and Uddaka Ramaputta had died.

original: ñatvā dhammadesanatthāya pañcavaggiyānaṃ olokanaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Sīhassa gocaratthāya

original: tiyojanaṃ gamanakālo viya attano pattacīvaraṃ ādāya “pañcavaggiyānaṃ dhammacakkaṃ🔽pavattessāmī”ti pacchābhatte ajapālanigrodhato vuṭṭhitassa aṭṭhārasayojanamaggaṃ gamanakālo.

translated: The time when he took his own bowl and robe and set out on the way to the Deer Park in Riṣivadana at Bārāṇasī, thinking “I shall set the Dhamma Wheel rolling for the group-of-five monks” is like the time it takes to go three leagues.

original: Sīhassa sīhanādakālo viya tathāgatassa aṭṭhārasayojanamaggaṃ gantvā pañcavaggiye
analyzed: sīhassa sīha nāda kālaḥ viya tathāgatassa aṭṭhārasa yojana maggam gantvā pañcavaggiye
translated: The time when he left the Goatherd’s Banyan tree after his meal and went the eighteen leagues to the Deer Park in Riṣivadana is like the time it takes to go eighteen leagues.🔽The time when the Realised One, after going the eighteen leagues to the Deer Park in Riṣivadana,

original: saññāpetvā acalapallaṅke nisinnassa dasahi cakkavāḷasahassehi sannipatitena devagaṇena
analyzed: saññāpetvā acala pallaṅke nisinnassa dasahi cakkavāḷa sahassehi sannipatitena deva gaṇena
translated: and after instructing the group-of-five monks, sat down on the firm seat, and after being surrounded by a host of gods who had assembled from ten thousand world-systems,

analyzed: parivutassa dve me bhikkhave antāḥ pabbajitena na sevitabbā ati ādinā nayena dhamma cakka ppavattana kālo  veditabbaḥ imasmin ca pana pade desiyamāne tathāgata sīhassa dhammaghoso heṭṭhā avīcim
translated: and after saying: “Monks, there are these two extremes that are not to be followed by one who has gone forth,” and so on, set rolling the unsurpassed Dhamma Wheel is like the time of a lion’s roar.🔽And while this section was being spoken the lion’s roar of the Realised One’s Dhamma sound covered the ten thousand world-systems, from the Avīci hell

translated: up to the highest world. The small creatures who were in the ten thousand world-systems,

original: santāsāpajjanakālo viya tathāgatassa tīṇi lakkhaṇāni dīpetvā cattāri saccāni soḷasahākārehi🔽saṭṭhiyā ca nayasahassehi vibhajitvā dhammaṃ kathentassa dīghāyukānaṃ devānaṃ ñāṇasantāsassa
analyzed: santāsa āpajjana kālaḥ viya tathāgatassa tīṇi lakkhaṇāni dīpetvā cattāri saccāni soḷasahā ākārehi  saṭṭhiyā ca naya sahassehi vibhajitvā dhammam kathentassa dīgha āyukānam devānam ñāṇa santāsassa
translated: and having divided the Four Noble Truths by the sixteen aspects🔽and by the thousand and sixty methods,

original: uppattikālo veditabbo.
analyzed: uppatti kālaḥ veditabbaḥ
translated: preaches the Dhamma, is like the time when the light of knowledge of the long-lived gods arises.

original: Aparo nayo – sīho viya sabbaññutaṃ patto tathāgato, āsayabhūtāya kanakaguhāya nikkhamanaṃ
analyzed: aparaḥ nayaḥ sīhaḥ viya sabbaññu tam pattaḥ tathāgataḥ āsaya bhūtāya kanakaguhāya nikkhamanaṃ

analyzed: viya gandhakuṭitaḥ nikkhamana kālaḥ vijambhanam viya dhammasabham upasaṅkamana kālaḥ

analyzed: disā vilokanam viya veneyya satta vilokanam sīha nādaḥ viya sampatta parisāya dhamma desanā  gocarāya pakkamanam viya a sampattānam veneyya sattānam santikūpa saṅkamanam veditabbam

analyzed: yadā ati yasmin kāle tathāgataḥ ti heṭṭhā vuttehi aṭṭhahi kāraṇehi tathāgataḥ loke iti  satta loke uppajjati iti abhinīhārato paṭṭhāya yāva bodhi pallaṅkā vā arahatta magga ñāṇā
translated: When: at the time. The Tathāgata: the Tathāgata for the eight reasons stated above. In the world:

analyzed: dassitāḥ honti iti sakkāya samudayaḥ ti ayam sakkāyassa samudayaḥ nāma ettāvatā āhāra samudayā

analyzed: rūpa samudayaḥ tiādi sabbam dassitam hoti iti sakkāyassa atthaṅgamaḥ ti ayam sakkāyassa
