He has no need to turn back and take anything.

original: na hoti. Iti imassa bhikkhuno sallahukavuttitaṃ dassento bhagavā santuṭṭho hoti kāyaparihārikena cīvarenātiādimāha.
analyzed: na hoti iti imassa bhikkhuno sallahuka vutti tam dassentaḥ bhagavā santuṭṭhaḥ hoti kāya parihārikena cīvarena ati ādim āha
translated: So the Exalted One said, “He is content with robes to protect his body and almsfood to sustain his belly,” showing how this bhikkhu is easily supported.

original: Tattha kāyaparihārikenāti kāyapariharaṇamattakena. Kucchiparihārikenāti kucchipariharaṇamattakena.
analyzed: tattha kāya parihārikena ati kāya pariharaṇa mattakena kucchi parihārikena ati kucchi pariharaṇa mattakena
translated: Herein, with just enough to keep the body and life going: with just enough to keep the body and life going.🔽Taking only that: taking only that which consists of the eight requisites.

original: Samādāyeva pakkamatīti taṃ aṭṭhaparikkhāramattakaṃ sabbaṃ gahetvāva kāyappaṭibaddhaṃ
analyzed: samādāya iva pakkamati iti tam aṭṭha parikkhāra mattakam sabbam gahetvā ava kāya ppaṭibaddham
translated: He goes forth thus: he goes thus, making the requisites dependent on the body.

original: katvāva gacchati, “mama vihāro pariveṇaṃ upaṭṭhāko”tissa saṅgo vā bandho vā na hoti.🔽So jiyā mutto saro viya, yūthā apakkanto mattahatthī viya icchiticchitaṃ senāsanaṃ,
analyzed: katvā ava gacchati mama vihāraḥ pariveṇam upaṭṭhāka ūtissa saṅgaḥ vā bandho vā na hoti  saḥ jiyā muttaḥ saraḥ viya yūthāḥ apakkantaḥ matta hatthī viya icchiticchitam senāsanam
translated: There is no attachment or bondage in him such as “This is my dwelling, this my monastery, this my attendant, this my domain” .🔽Like a bird that leaves with a single flap the branch of a tree on which it has been living, like a tusker in rut that leaves the herd and goes off by itself, he makes use of a lodging, a forest grove, the foot of a tree, a new lodging, all by himself.

original: vanasaṇḍaṃ, rukkhamūlaṃ, navaṃ pabbhāraṃ paribhuñjanto eko tiṭṭhati, eko nisīdati,
analyzed: vana saṇḍam rukkha mūlam navam pabbhāram paribhuñjantaḥ ekaḥ tiṭṭhati ekaḥ nisīdati
translated: He stands alone, sits alone,

original: sabbiriyāpathesu eko adutiyo.
analyzed: sa biriyāpathesu ekaḥ a dutiyaḥ
translated: and in all postures he is alone, without a second.

original: “Cātuddiso appaṭigho ca hoti,🔽Santussamāno itarītarena;
analyzed: cātuddisaḥ appaṭighaḥ ca hoti  itarītarena
translated: “He is impartial, not grasping,🔽Content with anything at all,

original: Parissayānaṃ sahitā achambhī,
analyzed: parissayānam sahitāḥ a chambhī
translated: Not anxious, not depressed,

original: Eko care khaggavisāṇakappo”ti. –
analyzed: ekaḥ care khagga visāṇa kappo ti
translated: He goes alone like the horn of the rhinoceros” .

original: Evaṃ vaṇṇitaṃ khaggavisāṇakappataṃ āpajjati.
analyzed: evam vaṇṇitam khagga visāṇa kappa tam āpajjati
translated: He thus attains the state of the rhinoceros-horn sutta, which is thus described:

original: Idāni tamatthaṃ upamāya sādhento seyyathāpītiādimāha. Tattha pakkhī sakuṇoti pakkhayutto🔽sakuṇo. Ḍetīti uppatati. Ayaṃ panettha saṅkhepattho – sakuṇā nāma “asukasmiṃ padese🔽rukkho paripakkaphalo”ti ñatvā nānādisāhi āgantvā nakhapakkhatuṇḍādīhi tassa phalāni🔽vijjhantā vidhunantā khādanti, “idaṃ ajjatanāya, idaṃ svātanāya bhavissatī”ti nesaṃ
analyzed: idāni tam attham upamāya sādhentaḥ seyyathā api iti ādim āha tattha pakkhī sakuṇaḥ ti pakkha yuttaḥ  sakuṇaḥ ḍeti iti uppatati ayam pana ittha saṅkhepa atthaḥ sakuṇāḥ nāma asukasmin padese  rukkho paripakka phalo ti ñatvā nānā disāhi āgantvā nakha pakkha tuṇḍa ādīhi tassa phalāni  vijjhantā vidhunantā khādanti idam ajjatanāya idam svātanāya bhavissati iti na īsam
translated: Now, in order to establish that meaning by means of a simile, he said, “Just as a bird with wings” , etc. Herein, a bird with wings is a bird that has wings. Flies through the air: flies up into the air. But the meaning here in brief is this: Birds, having found out that “in such and such a place a tree has ripe fruit,” come from various directions, and pecking at the fruit with their claws, wings, beaks, etc., they break it open and eat it. “This is for today, this will be for tomorrow,” they think, and they do not take into account

original: na hoti. Phale pana khīṇe neva rukkhassa ārakkhaṃ ṭhapenti, na tattha pakkhaṃ vā🔽pattaṃ vā nakhaṃ vā tuṇḍaṃ vā ṭhapenti, atha kho tasmiṃ rukkhe anapekkhā hutvā yo🔽yaṃ disābhāgaṃ icchati, so tena sapattabhārova uppatitvā gacchati. Evameva ayaṃ bhikkhu🔽nissaṅgo nirapekkhoyeva pakkamati, samādāyeva pakkamati. Ariyenāti niddosena. Ajjhattanti
analyzed: na hoti phale pana khīṇe na iva rukkhassa ārakkham ṭhapenti na tattha pakkham vā 🔽pattam vā nakham vā tuṇḍam vā ṭhapenti atha kho tasmin rukkhe anapekkhā hutvā yaḥ 🔽yam disā bhāgam icchati saḥ tena sa patta bhāraḥ uva uppatitvā gacchati evam eva ayam bhikkhu 🔽nissaṅgaḥ nirapekkhaḥ yā iva pakkamati samādāya iva pakkamati ariyena ati niddosena ajjhattam ti
translated: Now, in order to establish that meaning by means of a simile, he said, “Just as a bird with wings” , etc. Herein, a bird with wings is a bird furnished with wings. Flies through the air: flies through space. But the meaning here in brief is this: Birds, having found out that “in such and such a place a tree has ripe fruit,” come from various directions, and pecking at the fruit with their beaks, wings, claws, etc., they eat it, and they do not think, “This is for today, that is for tomorrow.” But when the fruit is finished, they do not set a guard over the tree, nor do they leave a wing, a feather, a claw, or a beak there, but rather, they depart without any concern for the tree, and then, whichever direction they wish to go, they fly off in that very direction with their wings as their only concern. So too, this bhikkhu departs without any concern, departs with only his requisites. With the noble: with the stainless. Internally:

original: sake attabhāve. Anavajjasukhanti niddosasukhaṃ.
analyzed: sake atta bhāve niddosa sukham
translated: In his own person. Blameless happiness: happiness free from blame.

original: So cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvāti so iminā ariyena sīlakkhandhena samannāgato bhikkhu cakkhuviññāṇena
analyzed: so cakkhunā rūpam disvā ati saḥ iminā ariyena sīla kkhandhena samannāgataḥ bhikkhu cakkhu viññāṇena
translated: Having seen a visible object with the eye: having seen a visible object with eye-consciousness.

original: rūpaṃ passitvāti attho. Sesapadesupi yaṃ vattabbaṃ siyā, taṃ sabbaṃ visuddhimagge
analyzed: rūpam passitvā ti attho sesa padesu pi yat vattabbam siyā tat sabbam visuddhi magge
translated: The meaning is: having seen a visible object with the eye. And what should be said with reference to the other passages has all been said in the Visuddhimagga.

original: vuttaṃ. Abyāsekasukhanti kilesehi anāsittasukhaṃ, avikiṇṇasukhantipi vuttaṃ. Indriyasaṃvarasukhaṃ
analyzed: vuttam a byāseka sukham ti kilesehi an āsitta sukham avikiṇṇa sukham ti pi vuttam indriya saṃvara sukham
translated: Happiness of non-remorse: happiness not touched by defilements. Happiness of non-distraction: happiness not scattered.

original: hi diṭṭhādīsu diṭṭhamattādivasena pavattatāya avikiṇṇaṃ hoti.🔽So abhikkante paṭikkanteti so manacchaṭṭhānaṃ indriyānaṃ saṃvarena samannāgato bhikkhu
analyzed: hi diṭṭha ādīsu diṭṭha matta ādi vasena pavatta tāya avikiṇṇam hoti  saḥ abhikkante paṭikkante iti saḥ manaccha ṭṭhānam indriyānam saṃvarena samannāgataḥ bhikkhu
translated: For the happiness of restraint of the faculties is not scattered because it occurs by way of mere seeing, etc., of visible objects, etc.🔽Having directed his body: having directed his body, having made his body straight.🔽Having restrained his faculties: having restrained his faculties, having guarded the doors of his sense faculties.🔽In these seven instances: in these seven instances beginning with going forward and returning.

original: imesu abhikkantapaṭikkantādīsu sattasu ṭhānesu satisampajaññavasena sampajānakārī
analyzed: imesu abhikkanta paṭikkanta ādīsu sattasu ṭhānesu sati sampajañña vasena sampajāna kārī
translated: He acts with full awareness: he acts with full awareness by means of mindfulness and full awareness.

original: hoti. Tattha abhikkantanti purato gamanaṃ. Paṭikkantanti pacchāgamanaṃ.
analyzed: hoti tattha abhikkantanti puratas gamanam paṭikkantanti pacchāgamanam
translated: Therein, going forward is going in front. Returning is going behind.

original: Sampajānakārī hotīti sātthakasampajaññaṃ, sappāyasampajaññaṃ, gocarasampajaññaṃ,🔽asammohasampajaññanti imesaṃ catunnaṃ satisampayuttānaṃ sampajaññānaṃ vasena satiṃ
analyzed: sampajāna kārī hoti iti sātthaka sampajaññam sa pāya sampajaññam gocara sampajaññam  asammoha sampajaññanti imesam catunnam sati sampayuttānam sampajaññānam vasena satim
translated: He is one who acts with clear comprehension: he acts with the four kinds of clear comprehension that are associated with mindfulness, namely, clear comprehension of meaning, clear comprehension of norm, clear comprehension of the field, and clear comprehension of alertness.

original: upaṭṭhapetvā ñāṇena paricchinditvāyeva tāni abhikkantapaṭikkantāni karoti. Sesapadesupi
analyzed: upaṭṭhapetvā ñāṇena paricchinditvāya iva tāni abhikkanta paṭikkantāni karoti sesa padesu pi
translated: He acts with clear comprehension in the sense of defining with knowledge, having established mindfulness in these four kinds of clear comprehension. The rest is as stated in the Satipatthāna Sutta .

original: eseva nayo. Ayamettha saṅkhepo, vitthāro pana icchantena dīghanikāye sāmaññaphalavaṇṇanāto🔽vā majjhimanikāye satipaṭṭhānavaṇṇanāto vā gahetabbo.🔽So iminā cātiādinā kiṃ dasseti? Araññavāsassa paccayasampattiṃ dasseti. Yassa hi
analyzed: esa iva nayaḥ ayam ettha saṅkhepaḥ vitthāraḥ pana icchantena dīgha nikāye sāmañña phala vaṇṇanāto  vā majjhima nikāye sati paṭṭhāna vaṇṇanātaḥ vā gahetabbo  so iminā ca ati ādinā kim dasseti arañña vāsassa paccaya sampattim dasseti yassa hi
translated: This is the brief treatment here. The detailed treatment, however, should be sought in the Visuddhimagga .

original: ime cattāro paccayā natthi, tassa araññavāso na ijjhati, tiracchānagatehi vā vanacarakehi
analyzed: ime cattāro paccayā natthi tassa arañña vāso na ijjhati tiracchāna gatehi vā vana carakehi
translated: What does he show by the words “He is one who acts with clear comprehension in going forward and returning”? He shows the possession of requisites for dwelling in the forest. For one who does not have these four requisites cannot dwell in the forest. He would have to live together with animals or with foresters,

original: vā saddhiṃ vatthabbataṃ āpajjati. Araññe adhivatthā devatā “kiṃ evarūpassa pāpabhikkhuno
analyzed: vā saddhim vatthabbatam āpajjati araññe adhivatthā devatā kim evarūpassa pāpa bhikkhuno
translated: and the deities dwelling in the forest would think: “What is this sort of evil bhikkhu doing here?

original: araññavāsenā”ti bheravasaddaṃ sāventi, hatthehi sīsaṃ paharitvā palāyanākāraṃ karonti.
analyzed: arañña vāsena ati bherava saddam sāventi hatthehi sīsam paharitvā palāyana ākāram karonti
translated: “By living in the forest,” they make a great noise, and they beat their heads with their hands and make a show of running away.

original: “Asuko bhikkhu araññaṃ pavisitvā idañcidañca pāpakammamakāsī”ti ayaso pattharati.🔽Yassa panete cattāro paccayā atthi, tassa araññavāso ijjhati. So hi attano sīlaṃ
analyzed: asukaḥ bhikkhu araññam pavisitvā idam ca idam ca pāpa kammam akāsi iti ayasaḥ pattharati  yassa pana ete cattāro paccayāḥ atthi tassa arañña vāsaḥ ijjhati saḥ hi attanaḥ sīlaṃ
translated: And the bad report spreads: “So-and-so, it seems, has gone into the forest and done this and that evil deed.”

original: paccavekkhanto kiñci kāḷakaṃ vā tilakaṃ vā apassanto pītiṃ uppādetvā taṃ khayato
analyzed: paccavekkhanto kiñci kāḷakam vā tilakam vā a passanto pītim uppādetvā tam khayato
translated: But one who has these four requisites succeeds in his forest life. For when he reviews his own virtue and sees nothing to be ashamed of or despised, he arouses rapture.

original: vayato sammasanto ariyabhūmiṃ okkamati. Araññe adhivatthā devatā attamanā vaṇṇaṃ
analyzed: vayataḥ sammasantaḥ ariya bhūmiṃ okkamati araññe adhivatthā devatā atta manāḥ vaṇṇam
translated: And when he comprehends that rapture as liable to destruction and fall, he enters upon the plane of the noble ones. The deities who dwell in the forest are pleased and speak praise of him.

original: bhāsanti. Itissa udake pakkhittatelabindu viya yaso vitthāriko hoti.
analyzed: bhāsanti iti ssa udake pakkhitta tela bindu viya yasaḥ vitthārikaḥ hoti
translated: And so his fame spreads far and wide like a drop of oil in water.

original: Tattha vivittanti suññaṃ, appasaddaṃ, appanigghosanti attho. Etadeva hi sandhāya
analyzed: tattha vivittam ti suññam appa saddam appa nigghosam ti attho etat eva hi sandhāya
translated: Herein, secluded means empty, quiet, with little noise and little sound.

original: vibhaṅge “vivittanti santike cepi senāsanaṃ hoti, tañca anākiṇṇaṃ gahaṭṭhehi pabbajitehi,
analyzed: vibhaṅge vivittanti santike ce pi senāsanam hoti tat ca an ākiṇṇam gahaṭṭhehi pabbajitehi
translated: For this is said in the Vibhaṅga: “Secluded: a dwelling is near to a village or town, and yet it is not crowded with householders or with those gone forth;

original: tena taṃ vivitta”nti vuttaṃ. Seti ceva āsati ca etthāti senāsanaṃ. Mañcapīṭhānametaṃ
analyzed: tena tam vivittam ti vuttam seti ca iva āsati ca ettha ati senāsanam
translated: “It is secluded there” is said.🔽A dwelling place is what is meant by “dwelling place” . This is a term for a bed and chair.

original: adhivacanaṃ. Tenāha – “senāsananti mañcopi senāsanaṃ, pīṭhampi, bhisipi, bimbohanampi,
analyzed: adhivacanam tena āha senāsanam ti mañcaḥ pi senāsanam pīṭham pi bhisi pi bimbohanam pi
translated: Hence it is said: “‘Dwelling place’: a bed is a dwelling place, a chair, a mattress, a pillow,

original: vihāropi, aḍḍhayogopi, pāsādopi, hammiyampi, guhāpi, aṭṭopi, māḷopi, leṇampi, veḷugumbopi,
analyzed: vihāraḥ api aḍḍhayogaḥ api pāsādaḥ api hammiyampi guhā api aṭṭaḥ pi māḷaḥ pi leṇampi veḷugumbaḥ pi
translated: a dwelling, a multi-storied building, a gabled house, a cell, a cave, a shed, a forest,

original: rukkhamūlampi, maṇḍapopi senāsanaṃ, yattha vā pana bhikkhū paṭikkamanti, sabbametaṃ
analyzed: rukkha mūlam pi maṇḍapaḥ pi senāsanam yattha vā pana bhikkhū paṭikkamanti sabbam etam
translated: the foot of a tree, a pavilion—these are dwelling places. Or wherever bhikkhus go for shelter—all this

original: senāsana”nti. Apica vihāro, aḍḍhayogo, pāsādo, hammiyaṃ, guhāti idaṃ vihārasenāsanaṃ🔽nāma. Mañco, pīṭhaṃ, bhisi, bimbohananti idaṃ mañcapīṭhasenāsanaṃ nāma. Cimilikā,🔽cammakhaṇḍo, tiṇasanthāro, paṇṇasanthāroti idaṃ santhatasenāsanaṃ nāma. Yattha vā
analyzed: senāsananti apica vihāraḥ aḍḍhayogo pāsādaḥ hammiyam guhā idam vihāra senāsanam  nāma pīṭham idam mañca pīṭha senāsanam nāma cimilikā  cammakhaṇḍaḥ tiṇasanthāro paṇṇasanthāraḥ ti idam santhatasenāsanam nāma vā
translated: is a dwelling place” . Furthermore, a dwelling, a multi-storied building, a gabled house, a hut, a cave—this is called a dwelling place as a building.🔽A bed, a chair, a mattress, a pillow—this is called a dwelling place as a bed and chair. A mat of grass,

original: pana bhikkhū paṭikkamantīti etaṃ okāsasenāsanaṃ nāmāti evaṃ catubbidhaṃ senāsanaṃ
analyzed: pana bhikkhū paṭikkamanti iti etam okāsa senāsanam nāma ati evam catubbidham senāsanam
translated: a mat of leaves, a mat of bark, a mat of strips of wood, a mat of rope, a mat of animal hair, a mat of human hair, a spread of grass, a spread of leaves—this is called a dwelling place as a spread. Or wherever bhikkhus go for shelter—this is called a dwelling place as an opportunity. Thus a dwelling place is of four kinds.

original: hoti. Taṃ sabbampi senāsanaggahaṇena gahitameva.🔽Imassa pana sakuṇasadisassa cātuddisassa bhikkhuno anucchavikaṃ dassento araññaṃ
analyzed: hoti tam sabbam pi senāsana ggahaṇena gahitam eva  imassa pana sakuṇa sadisassa cātuddisassa bhikkhuno anucchavikam dassento araññam
translated: All these are included in the definition of a lodging.

original: rukkhamūlantiādimāha. Tattha araññanti “nikkhamitvā bahi indakhīlā sabbametaṃ arañña”nti
analyzed: rukkha mūlam ti ādim āha tattha araññanti nikkhamitvā bahi indakhīlā sabbam etam araññanti
translated: But the Blessed One, showing what is suitable for the bhikkhu who is like the bird, the all-around looker, said, “A forest,” etc. Herein, “forest” is any place outside the zone of cultivation a plough’s length from a tree, a fence, a landmark, or a path.

original: “idaṃ bhikkhunīnaṃ vasena āgataṃ araññaṃ. “Āraññakaṃ nāma senāsanaṃ pañcadhanusatikaṃ
analyzed: idam bhikkhunīnam vasena āgatam araññam āraññakam nāma senāsanam pañca dhanusatikam
translated: “A forest abode” is said with reference to bhikkhunīs. But this is suitable for this bhikkhu: “A forest abode is five hundred bow-lengths away” .

original: pacchima”nti idaṃ pana imassa bhikkhuno anurūpaṃ. Tassa lakkhaṇaṃ visuddhimagge dhutaṅganiddese
analyzed: pacchiman ti idam pana imassa bhikkhuno anurūpam tassa lakkhaṇam visuddhimagge dhutaṅga niddese
translated: Its characteristic, etc., are given in the Description of the Ascetic Practices .

original: vuttaṃ. Rukkhamūlanti yaṃkiñci sītacchāyaṃ vivittaṃ rukkhamūlaṃ. Pabbatanti selaṃ.🔽Tattha hi udakasoṇḍīsu udakakiccaṃ katvā sītāya rukkhacchāyāya nisinnassa nānādisāsu
analyzed: vuttam rukkha mūlam ti yaṃkiñci sīta chāyam vivittam rukkha mūlam pabbatam ti selam  tattha hi udaka soṇḍīsu udaka kiccam katvā sītāya rukkha chāyāya nisinnassa nānā disāsu
translated: “The foot of a tree” is any secluded root of a tree that has cool shade. “A mountain” is a rock.🔽For there, after doing the duties connected with drinking and washing, one can sit down in the cool shade of a tree and, as the various directions are fanned by the cool breeze, one’s mind becomes unified.

original: khāyamānāsu sītena vātena bījiyamānassa cittaṃ ekaggaṃ hoti. Kandaranti kaṃ vuccati
analyzed: khāyamānāsu sītena vātena bījiyamānassa cittam ekaggam hoti kandaranti kam vuccati
translated: “A cleft” is what is called a “cave” .

original: udakaṃ, tena dāritaṃ udakabhinnaṃ pabbatapadesaṃ, yaṃ nitambantipi nadīnikuñjantipi🔽vadanti. Tattha hi rajatapaṭṭasadisā vālikā hoti, matthake maṇivitānaṃ viya vanagahanaṃ,
analyzed: udakam tena dāritam udaka bhinnam pabbata padesam yam  vadanti tattha hi rajata paṭṭa sadisā vālikā hoti matthake maṇi vitānam viya vana gahanam
translated: The water that has broken through the rock there is called “the water of the cleft” and also “the water of the pool” and “the water of the hollow” .🔽For the sand there is like a silver plate, the trees on the top are like a jewelled awning,

original: maṇikkhandhasadisaṃ udakaṃ sandati. Evarūpaṃ kandaraṃ oruyha pānīyaṃ pivitvā gattāni
analyzed: maṇi khandha sadisam udakam sandati evarūpam kandaram oruyha pānīyam pivitvā gattāni
translated: and the water flowing there is like a mass of gems. After descending to the cleft and drinking the water there and cooling the limbs and body,

original: sītāni katvā vālikaṃ ussāpetvā paṃsukūlacīvaraṃ paññāpetvā nisinnassa samaṇadhammaṃ🔽karoto cittaṃ ekaggaṃ hoti. Giriguhanti dvinnaṃ pabbatānaṃ antaraṃ, ekasmiṃyeva vā
analyzed: sītāni katvā vālikam ussāpetvā paṃsukūla cīvaram paññāpetvā nisinnassa samaṇa dhammaṃ  karotaḥ cittam ekaggam hoti giri guhanti dvinnam pabbatānam antaram ekasmiṃyeva vā
translated: and after spreading the rag-robe on the sand and sitting down, he should make the mind calm by doing the ascetic’s duties.

original: umaṅgasadisaṃ mahāvivaraṃ. Susānalakkhaṇaṃ visuddhimagge vuttaṃ. Vanapatthanti gāmantaṃ
analyzed: umaṅga sadisam mahā vivaram su sāna lakkhaṇam visuddhi magge vuttam vana patthanti gāmantam
translated: A mountain cave is the space between two rocks or a large opening in one rock like a fireplace. The characteristics of a charnel ground are given in the Path of Purification .

original: atikkamitvā manussānaṃ anupacāraṭṭhānaṃ, yattha na kasanti na vapanti. Tenevāha –
analyzed: atikkamitvā manussānam an upacāra ṭhānam yattha na kasanti na vapanti tena iva āha
translated: A forest grove is a place beyond the village boundary where people do not go for such purposes as cultivation and sowing. That is why it is said:

original: “vanapatthanti dūrānametaṃ senāsanānaṃ adhivacana”ntiādi. Abbhokāsanti acchannaṃ.
analyzed: senāsanānam acchannam
translated: “A forest grove is a designation for a dwelling place that is far away” . The open air is an uncovered place.

original: Ākaṅkhamāno panettha cīvarakuṭiṃ katvā vasati. Palālapuñjanti palālarāsiṃ. Mahāpalālapuñjato🔽hi palālaṃ nikkaḍḍhitvā pabbhāraleṇasadise ālaye karonti, gacchagumbādīnampi upari
analyzed: ākaṅkhamānaḥ pana ittha cīvara kuṭim katvā vasati palāla puñjanti palāla rāsim mahā palāla puñjataḥ  hi palālam nikkaḍḍhitvā pabbhāraleṇa sadise ālaye karonti gaccha gumba ādīnam pi upari
translated: For they take the grass from a big heap of grass

original: palālaṃ pakkhipitvā heṭṭhā nisinnā samaṇadhammaṃ karonti. Taṃ sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ.
analyzed: palālam pakkhipitvā heṭṭhā nisinnā samaṇa dhammam karonti tam sandhāya itam vuttam
translated: and make a shelter like a cave in a cliff, and they sit underneath it and do their meditation. That is what is meant here.

original: Pacchābhattanti bhattassa pacchato. Piṇḍapātapaṭikkantoti piṇḍapātapariyesanato paṭikkanto.🔽Pallaṅkanti samantato ūrubaddhāsanaṃ. Ābhujitvāti bandhitvā. Ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāyāti
analyzed: pacchābhattanti bhattassa pacchatas piṇḍapāta paṭikkanto ti piṇḍapāta pariyesanataḥ paṭikkanto  samantataḥ ūru baddha āsanam ābhujitvā ati bandhitvā ujum kāyam paṇidhāya ati
translated: After the meal: after the meal is finished. Having returned from the alms round: having finished seeking alms food.🔽A cross-legged posture: a posture with the legs crossed, either with one foot placed upon the opposite thigh or with both feet placed upon the ground. Having arranged: having bound. Having straightened up the body:

original: uparimasarīraṃ ujukaṃ ṭhapetvā aṭṭhārasa piṭṭhikaṇṭake koṭiyā koṭiṃ paṭipādetvā.🔽Evañhi nisinnassa cammamaṃsanhārūni na paṇamanti. Athassa yā tesaṃ paṇamanapaccayā
analyzed: uparima sarīram ujukam ṭhapetvā aṭṭhārasa piṭṭhikaṇṭake koṭiyā koṭim paṭipādetvā  evam hi nisinnassa camma maṃsa nhārūni na paṇamanti athassa yā tesam paṇamana paccayā
translated: having straightened up the upper part of the body, having brought the tip of the spine into line with the tip of the nose,🔽for when he sits thus, his skin, flesh and sinews are not bent. Then any pains that might arise from their bending do not arise.

original: khaṇe khaṇe vedanā uppajjeyyuṃ, tā na uppajjanti. Tāsu na uppajjamānāsu cittaṃ ekaggaṃ
analyzed: khaṇe khaṇe vedanāḥ uppajjeyyum tāḥ na uppajjanti tāsu na uppajjamānāsu cittam ekaggam
translated: When they do not arise, the mind becomes concentrated

original: hoti, kammaṭṭhānaṃ na paripatati, vuddhiṃ phātiṃ upagacchati. Parimukhaṃ satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvāti🔽kammaṭṭhānābhimukhaṃ satiṃ ṭhapayitvā, mukhasamīpe vā katvāti attho. Teneva vibhaṅge
analyzed: hoti kammaṭṭhānam na paripatati vuddhim phātim upagacchati parimukham satim upaṭṭhapetvā ati  kammaṭṭhāna abhimukham satim ṭhapayitvā mukha samīpe vā katvā iti tena iva vibhaṅge
translated: Having established mindfulness in front:

original: vuttaṃ – “ayaṃ sati upaṭṭhitā hoti sūpaṭṭhitā nāsikagge vā mukhanimitte vā. Tena🔽vuccati parimukhaṃ satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvā”ti. Atha vā “parīti pariggahaṭṭho. Mukhanti🔽niyyānaṭṭho. Satīti upaṭṭhānaṭṭho. Tena vuccati – ‘parimukhaṃ sati”’nti evaṃ paṭisambhidāyaṃ
analyzed: vuttam ayam sati upaṭṭhitā hoti su upaṭṭhitā nāsikagge vā mukha nimitte vā tena  vuccati parimukham satim upaṭṭhapetvā ati atha vā pari iti pariggaha aṭṭhaḥ mukham ti  niyyāna ṭho satī iti upaṭṭhāna ṭho tena vuccati parimukham evam
translated: having placed mindfulness in the object of meditation, or having made it face in front, is the meaning. That is why it is said in the Vibhaṅga: “Mindfulness is established, well established, in the nose or in the sign at the tip of the nose.🔽That is why it is said, ‘Having established mindfulness in front’” .🔽Or alternatively, “pari” has the meaning of “embracing,” “mukha” has the meaning of “outlet,” and “sati” has the meaning of “establishment.” That is why it is said in the Paṭisambhidā: “Herein, what is ‘mindfulness in front’? ‘Pari’ has the meaning of ‘embracing.’ ‘Mukha’ has the meaning of ‘outlet.’ ‘Sati’ has the meaning of ‘establishment.’ That is why it is said, ‘mindfulness in front’” .

original: vuttanayena panettha attho daṭṭhabbo. Tatrāyaṃ saṅkhepo “pariggahitaniyyānaṃ satiṃ katvā”ti.
analyzed: vutta nayena pana ittha atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo tatra ayam saṅkhepaḥ pariggahita niyyānam satim katvā iti
translated: The meaning should be regarded here in the way stated in the Paṭisambhidā. The brief meaning is this: “having made mindfulness an embracing outlet.”

original: Abhijjhaṃ loketi ettha lujjana-palujjanaṭṭhena pañcupādānakkhandhā loko. Tasmā pañcasu
analyzed: abhijjham loka iti ettha lujjana palujjana ṭṭhena pañca upādānakkhandhāḥ tasmā pañcasu
translated: As to “having comprehended the world with understanding”: the world is the five aggregates as objects of clinging in the sense of their being crushed and wasted ;

original: upādānakkhandhesu rāgaṃ pahāya kāmacchandaṃ vikkhambhetvāti ayamettha attho. Vigatābhijjhenāti
analyzed: upādānakkhandhesu rāgam pahāya kāmacchandam vikkhambhetvā ati ayam ettha atthaḥ vigata abhijjhena ati
translated: and by “having abandoned greed for the five aggregates as objects of clinging” is meant that he has suppressed sense desire.🔽“Free from envy” :

original: vikkhambhanavasena pahīnattā vigatābhijjhena, na cakkhuviññāṇasadisenāti attho. Abhijjhāya
analyzed: vikkhambhana vasena pahīna ttā vigata abhijjhena na cakkhu viññāṇa sadisena ati atthaḥ abhijjhāya
translated: he is free from envy by suppression; the meaning is that he is not like eye-consciousness.

original: cittaṃ parisodhetīti abhijjhāto cittaṃ parimoceti, yathā naṃ sā muñcati ceva muñcitvā
analyzed: cittam parisodheti iti abhijjhātaḥ cittam parimoceti yathā nam sā muñcati ca iva muñcitvā
translated: “He purifies his mind from envy” : he liberates his mind from envy, he acts so that envy does not liberate him and then not seize him again.

original: ca na puna gaṇhāti, evaṃ karotīti attho. Byāpādapadosaṃ pahāyātiādīsupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: ca na puna gaṇhāti evam karoti iti atthaḥ byāpāda padosam pahāya ati ādīsu pi esa iva nayaḥ
translated: The same method of explanation applies to the phrases beginning “having abandoned ill will and worry.”

original: Byāpajjati iminā cittaṃ pūtikummāsādayo viya purimapakatiṃ pajahatīti byāpādo. Vikārappattiyā
analyzed: byāpajjati iminā cittam pūti kummāsa ādayaḥ viya purima pakatim pajahati iti byāpādaḥ vikāra ppattiyā
translated: Ill will is so called because it causes the mind to become ill , to abandon its natural condition like a rotten mango, etc.

original: padussati, paraṃ vā padūseti vināsetīti padoso. Ubhayampetaṃ kodhasseva adhivacanaṃ.
analyzed: padussati param vā padūseti vināseti iti padosaḥ ubhayam petam kodhassa iva adhivacanam
translated: Worry is so called because it causes the mind to become corrupted , or because it corrupts others, destroys them. Both are synonyms for anger.

original: Thinaṃ cittagelaññaṃ, middhaṃ cetasikagelaññaṃ. Thinañca middhañca thinamiddhaṃ.
analyzed: thinam citta gelaññam middham cetasika gelaññam thinam ca middham ca thina middham
translated: Dullness is sluggishness of the mind; drowsiness is sluggishness of consciousness. Dullness and drowsiness are a unity.

original: Ālokasaññīti rattimpi divāpi diṭṭhaālokasañjānanasamatthāya vigatanīvaraṇāya parisuddhāya
analyzed: āloka saññī iti rattimpi divā api diṭṭha āloka sañjānana samatthāya vigata nīvaraṇāya parisuddhāya
translated: Possessed of perception of light: he is possessed of perception that is purified, free from hindrances, and capable of perceiving light both by day and by night.

original: saññāya samannāgato. Sato sampajānoti satiyā ca ñāṇena ca samannāgato. Idaṃ ubhayaṃ
analyzed: saññāya samannāgato sataḥ sampajānoti satiyā ca ñāṇena ca samannāgataḥ idam ubhayam
translated: Mindful and clearly comprehending: he is possessed of mindfulness and knowledge. This pair is mentioned🔽because it assists perception of light.

original: ālokasaññāya upakārakattā vuttaṃ. Uddhaccañca kukkuccañca uddhaccakukkuccaṃ. Tiṇṇavicikicchoti
analyzed: āloka saññāyaḥ upakāraka ttā vuttam uddhaccam ca kukkuccam ca uddhacca kukkuccam tiṇṇa vicikiccho ti
translated: And restlessness and worry are restlessness and worry.

original: vicikicchaṃ taritvā atikkamitvā ṭhito. “Kathamidaṃ kathamida”nti evaṃ nappavattatīti🔽akathaṃkathī. Kusalesu dhammesūti anavajjesu dhammesu. “Ime nu kho kusalā, kathamime
analyzed: vicikiccham taritvā atikkamitvā ṭhitaḥ katham idam katham idam ti evam na ppavattati iti  akathaṃkathī kusalesu dhammesu iti anavajjesu dhammesu ime nu kho kusalā katham ime
translated: Crossed over doubt: having crossed over and gone beyond doubt, he stands. He does not proceed thus: “How is this? What is this?”🔽He is not a doubter.🔽In profitable ideas: in blameless ideas. He does not doubt or hesitate thus: “Are these profitable? How are these profitable?

original: kusalā”ti evaṃ na vicikicchati na kaṅkhatīti attho. Ayamettha saṅkhepo. Imesu pana
analyzed: evam na vicikicchati na kaṅkhati iti atthaḥ ayam ettha saṅkhepaḥ imesu pana
translated: What is this? How is this?” is the meaning. This is the brief treatment here.

original: nīvaraṇesu vacanatthalakkhaṇādibhedato yaṃ vattabbaṃ siyā, taṃ visuddhimagge vuttaṃ.
analyzed: nīvaraṇesu vacana ttha lakkhaṇa ādi bhedataḥ yat vattabbam siyā tat visuddhimagge vuttam
translated: But what should be said concerning the analysis of the meaning of the terms, their characteristics, etc., in these hindrances has been said in the Path of Purity .

original: Paññāya dubbalīkaraṇeti yasmā ime pañca nīvaraṇā uppajjamānā anuppannāya lokiyalokuttarāya
analyzed: paññāya dubbalīkaraṇa iti yasmai ime pañca nīvaraṇāḥ uppajjamānāḥ an uppannāya lokiya lokuttarāya
translated: They weaken understanding: for when these five hindrances arise, they prevent the occurrence of mundane and supramundane right view, which is understanding.

original: paññāya uppajjituṃ na denti, uppannāpi aṭṭha samāpattiyo pañca vā abhiññā ucchinditvā
analyzed: paññāya uppajjitum na denti uppannā api aṭṭha samāpattiyaḥ pañca vā abhiññāḥ ucchinditvā
translated: and do not give them the opportunity to arise, and having arisen, the eight attainments and the five super-knowledges are cut off,

original: pātenti. Tasmā paññāya dubbalīkaraṇāti vuccanti. Vivicceva kāmehītiādīni visuddhimagge vitthāritāni.
analyzed: tasmā paññāya dubbalīkaraṇā ti vuccanti vivicca iva kāmehi itiādīni visuddhi magge vitthāritāni
translated: They do not give the wisdom a chance to arise, and when it does arise, they cut off the eight meditative attainments and the five kinds of spiritual knowledge and drive them away. Therefore they are called “weaknesses of wisdom.” The passages beginning with “quite secluded from sense desires” are explained in detail in the Visuddhimagga.

original: Ime āsavātiādi aparenāpi pariyāyena catusaccappakāsanatthaṃ vuttaṃ. Nāparaṃ itthattāyāti🔽pajānātīti ettāvatā heṭṭhā tīhi aṅgehi bāhirasamayassa nipphalabhāvaṃ dassetvā catutthena
analyzed: ime āsavā ti ādi aparena api pariyāyena catu sacca pakāsana attham vuttam na aparam itthattāya ati  pajānāti iti ettāvatā heṭṭhā tīhi aṅgehi bāhira samayassa nipphala bhāvam dassetvā catutthena
translated: “These taints” and so on are stated by another method in order to reveal the four noble truths. “He understands: ‘There is no more of this state of being’ ”

original: aṅgena attano sāsanassa gambhīrabhāvaṃ pakāsetvā desanāya arahattena kūṭaṃ gaṇhi.
analyzed: aṅgena attano sāsanassa gambhīra bhāvam pakāsetvā desanāya arahattena kūṭam gaṇhi
translated: . So far, having shown by means of the first three factors the futility of the outsider’s path, he shows by means of the fourth factor the profundity of his own dispensation. Thus he concludes the teaching with arahatship.

original: Idāni desanaṃ appento evaṃ kho, bhikkhavetiādimāha.🔽9. Taṇhāsuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: idāni desanam appentaḥ evam kho bhikkhave ti ādim āha  taṇhā sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: Now, summing up the teaching, he says “Thus, bhikkhus,” and so on.🔽The exposition of the Thread dealing with craving.

original: 199. Navame jālininti jālasadisaṃ. Yathā hi jālaṃ samantato saṃsibbitaṃ ākulabyākulaṃ,
analyzed: navame jālininti jāla sadisam yathā hi jālam samantataḥ saṃsibbitam ākula byākulam
translated: In the ninth Thread, “the net” is like a net. Just as a net is spread all around, entangled,

original: evaṃ taṇhāpīti jālasadisattā jālinīti vuttā. Tayo vā bhave ajjhottharitvā ṭhitāya
analyzed: evam taṇhā api iti jāla sadisa ttā jālinī iti vuttā tayaḥ vā bhave ajjhottharitvā ṭhitāya
translated: so too craving is called “the net” because it is like a net. Or else, it is called “the net” because it is spread over the three kinds of becoming and stands there.

original: etissā tattha tattha attano koṭṭhāsabhūtaṃ jālaṃ atthītipi jālinī. Saritanti tattha🔽tattha saritvā saṃsaritvā ṭhitaṃ. Visaṭanti patthaṭaṃ vikkhittaṃ. Visattikanti tattha🔽tattha visattaṃ laggaṃ lagitaṃ. Apica “visamūlāti visattikā. Visaphalāti visattikā”tiādināpi🔽nayenettha attho daṭṭhabbo. Uddhastoti upari dhaṃsito. Pariyonaddhoti samantā veṭhito.
analyzed: etissā tattha tattha attano koṭṭhāsa bhūtam jālam atthi itipi jālinī tattha  tattha saritvā saṃsaritvā ṭhitam visaṭanti patthaṭam vikkhittam visattikam tattha  tattha visattam laggam lagitam apica visamūlā ati visattikā visaphalā ati visattikā iti ādinā api  nayena ittha attho daṭṭhabbo uddhastaḥ ti upari dhaṃsito pariyonaddhaḥ iti samantā veṭhito
translated: It is a net because it has a net of its own parts here and there. It is a stream because it is established by flowing and spreading here and there. It is a mass because it is a compact, scattered mass. It is a jungle because it is entangled, stuck, fastened here and there. Moreover, the meaning should be regarded here in the way beginning: “It has a poisoned root, thus it is a poison-rooted jungle; it has a poisoned fruit, thus it is a poison-rooted jungle” . It is upraised because it is raised up. It is covered because it is wrapped round.

Yathā nāma dunnikkhittaṃ mūsikacchinnaṃ🔽pesakārānaṃ tantaṃ tahiṃ tahiṃ ākulaṃ hoti, “idaṃ aggaṃ idaṃ mūla”nti aggena vā aggaṃ,🔽mūlena vā mūlaṃ samānetuṃ dukkaraṃ hoti, evaṃ sattā imāya taṇhāya pariyonaddhā ākulabyākulā🔽na sakkonti attano nissaraṇamaggaṃ ujuṃ kātuṃ. Gulāguṇṭhikajātoti gulāguṇṭhikaṃ vuccati

original: pesakārakañjiyasuttaṃ. Gulā nāma sakuṇikā, tassā kulāvakotipi eke. Yathā tadubhayampi
analyzed: pesakārakañjiya suttam gulā nāma sa kuṇikā tassā eke yathā tat ubhayam pi
translated: The Discussion of the Basket-Maker’s Son. The gulā is a kind of bird; some say it is a kind of quail.🔽

original: ākulaṃ aggena vā aggaṃ, mūlena vā mūlaṃ samānetuṃ dukkaranti purimanayeneva yojetabbaṃ.
analyzed: ākulam aggena vā aggam mūlena vā mūlam samānetum purima nayena iva yojetabbam
translated: The Sutta on the Weaver and the Cow-Herd. The gulā is a kind of bird, and its nest is called a kulāva by some. As to the two of them being “entangled” , it is hard to get the top to coincide with the top and the bottom to coincide with the bottom, as in the former case.

original: Muñjapabbajabhūtoti muñjatiṇaṃ viya pabbajatiṇaṃ viya ca bhūto, tādiso jāto. Yathā🔽tāni tiṇāni koṭṭetvā katarajjuṃ jiṇṇakāle katthaci patitaṃ gahetvā tesaṃ tiṇānaṃ
analyzed: muñja pabbaja bhūtaḥ iti muñja tiṇam viya pabbaja tiṇam viya ca bhūtaḥ tādisaḥ jātaḥ yathā  tāni tiṇāni koṭṭetvā kata rajjum jiṇṇa kāle katthaci patitam gahetvā tesam tiṇānam
translated: “He is born as a reed-bed” : he is born as a reed, as a reed-bed. As to the reeds

original: “idaṃ aggaṃ idaṃ mūla”nti aggena vā aggaṃ, mūlena vā mūlaṃ samānetuṃ dukkaraṃ. Tampi
analyzed: idam aggam idam mūlam ti aggena vā aggam mūlena vā mūlam samānetum dukkaram
translated: “It is hard to get the top to coincide with the top and the bottom to coincide with the bottom” , as in the former case.

original: ca paccattapurisakāre ṭhatvā sakkā bhaveyya ujuṃ kātuṃ, ṭhapetvā pana bodhisatte🔽añño satto attano dhammatāya taṇhājālaṃ padāletvā attano nissaraṇamaggaṃ ujuṃ kātuṃ
analyzed: ca paccatta purisakāre ṭhatvā sakkā bhaveyya ujum kātum ṭhapetvā pana bodhisatte  aññaḥ satto attanaḥ dhamma tāya taṇhā jālam padāletvā attanaḥ nissaraṇa maggam ujum kātum
translated: And that can be straightened by standing in personal effort, but apart from the Bodhisatta

original: samattho nāma natthi. Evamayaṃ loko taṇhājālena pariyonaddho apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ
analyzed: samatthaḥ nāma na atthi evam ayam loko taṇhā jālena pariyonaddhaḥ apāyam duggatim vinipātam
translated: no other being is able to break through the mesh of craving and to straighten his own way of escape by his own efforts. So this world is entangled in the mesh of craving, and it is hard to get it to coincide with the top and the bottom, as in the former case.

original: saṃsāraṃ nātivattati. Tattha apāyoti niraya-tiracchānayoni-pettivisaya-asurakāyā.🔽Sabbepi hi te vaḍḍhisaṅkhātassa āyassa abhāvato apāyāti vuccanti. Tathā dukkhassa
analyzed: saṃsāram na ativattati niraya tiracchāna yoni petti visaya asura kāyā  sabbe pi hi te vaḍḍhi saṅkhātassa āyassa abhāvataḥ apāyā ati vuccanti tathā dukkhassa
translated: he does not transcend saṃsāra. Herein, the ‘bad destinations’ are the hells, the animal realm, the realm of afflicted spirits, and the body of Asuras.🔽For all of them are called ‘bad destinations’ because of the absence of the ‘increase’ called ‘life’. Likewise, they are ‘bad bourns’ because of being the ‘going’ of suffering,

original: gatibhāvato duggati. Sukhasamussayato vinipatitattā vinipāto. Itaro pana –
analyzed: gati bhāvataḥ duggati sukha samussayataḥ vinipatita ttā vinipātaḥ itaraḥ pana
translated: and a ‘fall’ because of falling away from happiness. The other, however,

original: “Khandhānañca paṭipāṭi, dhātuāyatanāna ca;
analyzed: khandhānam ca paṭipāṭi dhātu āyatanāna ca
translated: “The succession of the aggregates, the elements, and the sense bases,

original: Abbocchinnaṃ vattamānā, saṃsāroti pavuccati.
analyzed: abbocchinnam vattamānā saṃsāro ti pavuccati
translated: Occurring without break, is called ‘saṃsāra’.

original: Taṃ sabbaṃ nātivattati nātikkamati, atha kho cutito paṭisandhiṃ paṭisandhito cutinti
analyzed: tat sabbam na ativattati na atikkamati atha kho cutitaḥ paṭisandhim paṭisandhitaḥ cutim ti
translated: He does not transcend all that, does not go beyond it, but rather, from death to rebirth-linking, from rebirth-linking to death,

original: evaṃ punappunaṃ cutipaṭisandhiyo gaṇhamāno tīsu bhavesu catūsu yonīsu pañcasu gatīsu
analyzed: evam punappunam cuti paṭisandhiyaḥ gaṇhamānaḥ tīsu bhavesu catūsu yonīsu pañcasu gatīsu
translated: thus taking up again and again the deaths and rebirths, he wanders in the three realms, in the four modes of origin, in the five destinations,

original: sattasu viññāṇaṭṭhitīsu navasu sattāvāsesu mahāsamudde vātakkhittanāvā viya yante
analyzed: sattasu viññāṇa ṭṭhitīsu navasu sattāvāsesu mahā samudde vāta khitta nāvāḥ viya yante
translated: in the seven stations of consciousness, and in the nine abodes of beings, like a ship on the ocean driven by the wind,

original: yuttagoṇo viya ca paribbhamatiyeva.
analyzed: ca
translated: or like a yoked ox going round and round in a water-wheel.

original: Ajjhattikassa upādāyāti ajjhattikaṃ khandhapañcakaṃ upādāya. Idañhi upayogatthe sāmivacanaṃ.
analyzed: ajjhattikassa upādāya ati ajjhattikam khandha pañcakam upādāya idam hi upayoga tthe sāmi vacanam
translated: “In dependence on the internal as object”: in dependence on the five aggregates as objects of clinging internally. For this is a genitive of dependence in the sense of object.

original: Bāhirassa upādāyāti bāhiraṃ khandhapañcakaṃ upādāya, idampi upayogatthe sāmivacanaṃ.🔽Asmīti, bhikkhave, satīti, bhikkhave, yadetaṃ ajjhattaṃ khandhapañcakaṃ upādāya taṇhāmānadiṭṭhivasena
analyzed: bāhirassa upādāya ati bāhiram khandha pañcakam upādāya idam pi upayoga tthe sāmi vacanam  asmi iti bhikkhave satī iti bhikkhave yat etam ajjhattam khandha pañcakam upādāya taṇhā māna diṭṭhi vasena
translated: “In dependence on the external as object”: in dependence on the five aggregates as objects of clinging externally. This too is a genitive of dependence in the sense of object.

original: samūhaggāhato asmīti hoti, tasmiṃ satīti attho. Itthasmīti hotītiādīsu pana evaṃ
analyzed: samūha ggāhataḥ asmi iti hoti tasmin sati iti attho itthasmi iti hoti itiādīsu pana evam
translated: “When there is ‘I am’”: when there is the “I am” that occurs through craving, conceit, and views in regard to the five aggregates as objects of clinging internally. The meaning is: when there is the perception of “I am.”

original: samūhato ahanti gahaṇe sati tato anupanidhāya ca upanidhāya cāti dvidhā gahaṇaṃ hoti.🔽Tattha anupanidhāyāti aññaṃ ākāraṃ anupagamma sakabhāvameva ārammaṇaṃ katvā itthasmīti
analyzed: samūhataḥ ahanti gahaṇe sati tatas an upanidhāya ca upanidhāya ca ati dvidhā gahaṇam  tattha an upanidhāya ati aññam ākāram an upagamma saka bhāvam eva ārammaṇam katvā itthasmi iti
translated: In the phrases “it thinks ‘I am of such a form’” and so forth, however, the perception of “I am” occurs in two ways: without making a distinction and by making a distinction.

original: hoti, khattiyādīsu idaṃpakāro ahanti evaṃ taṇhāmānadiṭṭhivasena hotīti attho. Idaṃ
analyzed: hoti khattiya ādīsu idaṃpakāraḥ aham ti evam taṇhā māna diṭṭhi vasena hoti iti atthaḥ idaṃ
translated: Herein, when there is the perception of “I am” without making a distinction, it occurs simply by taking one’s own being as object, without reference to any particular aspect. It occurs through craving, conceit, and views in the following manner: “I am a khattiya,” etc. This is the perception of “I am” without making a distinction.

original: tāva anupanidhāya gahaṇaṃ. Upanidhāya gahaṇaṃ pana duvidhaṃ hoti samato ca asamato
analyzed: tāva an upanidhāya gahaṇam upanidhāya gahaṇam pana duvidham hoti samataḥ ca asamataḥ
translated: The perception of “I am” by making a distinction is twofold: by way of equality and by way of inequality.

original: ca. Taṃ dassetuṃ evaṃsmīti aññathāsmīti ca vuttaṃ. Tattha evaṃsmīti idaṃ samato upanidhāya🔽gahaṇaṃ, yathāyaṃ khattiyo yathāyaṃ brāhmaṇo, evamahampīti attho. Aññathāsmīti idaṃ
analyzed: ca tam dassetum evam asmi iti aññathā asmi iti ca vuttam tattha evam asmi iti idam samatas upanidhāya  gahaṇam yathā ayam khattiyaḥ yathā ayam brāhmaṇaḥ evam aham pi iti atthaḥ aññathā asmi iti idam
translated: In order to show that, “I am” and “I am otherwise” are said. Herein, “I am” is the taking of a self by way of sameness,🔽in the sense that “Just as this Khattiya, just as this Brahmana, so am I.” “I am otherwise” is the taking of a self

original: pana asamato gahaṇaṃ, yathāyaṃ khattiyo yathāyaṃ brāhmaṇo, tato aññathā ahaṃ, hīno
analyzed: pana asamataḥ gahaṇam yathā ayam khattiyaḥ yathā ayam brāhmaṇaḥ tatas aññathā aham hīnaḥ
translated: by way of otherness, in the sense that “Just as this Khattiya, just as this Brahmana, so I am otherwise, inferior

original: vā adhiko vāti attho. Imāni tāva paccuppannavasena cattāri taṇhāvicaritāni.🔽Asasmīti satasmīti imāni pana dve yasmā atthīti asaṃ, niccassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Sīdatīti
analyzed: vā adhikaḥ vā ti attho imāni tāva paccuppanna vasena cattāri taṇhā vicaritāni  asasmi iti satasmi iti imāni pana dve yasmai atthi iti asam niccassa etam adhivacanam sīdati iti
translated: or superior.” These are the four kinds of craving for the present.🔽“I was” and “I am not” are the two kinds of craving for the past. But these two should be understood as stated by way of eternalism and annihilationism, respectively.

original: sataṃ, aniccassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Tasmā sassatucchedavasena vuttānīti veditabbāni.
analyzed: adhivacanam tasmā vuttāni iti veditabbāni
translated: “I will be” and “I will not be” and “I will be otherwise” are the three kinds of craving for the future.

original: Ito parāni santi evamādīni cattāri saṃsayaparivitakkavasena vuttāni. Santi hotīti🔽evamādīsu ahaṃ siyanti hotīti evamattho veditabbo. Adhippāyo panettha purimacatukke
analyzed: itas parāni santi evamādīni cattāri saṃsaya parivitakka vasena vuttāni santi hoti iti 🔽evamādīsu aham hoti iti evamatthaḥ veditabbaḥ adhippāyaḥ pana ittha purima catukke
translated: The remaining four, “I am,” etc., are stated by way of doubt and reflection.

original: vuttanayeneva gahetabbo. Apihaṃ santiādīni pana cattāri api nāma ahaṃ bhaveyyanti🔽evaṃ patthanākappanavasena vuttāni. Tānipi purimacatukke vuttanayeneva veditabbāni.
analyzed: vutta nayena iva gahetabbo api ham santi ādīni pana cattāri api nāma aham bhaveyyanti  evam patthanā kappana vasena vuttāni tāni api purima catukke vutta nayena iva veditabbāni
translated: and it should be taken in the way already stated. But the four beginning with “There may be” are spoken of in the way of a wish and a resolve, “I might be” .🔽These should also be understood in the way already stated in the previous tetrad.

original: Bhavissantiādīni pana cattāri anāgatavasena vuttāni. Tesampi purimacatukke vuttanayeneva
analyzed: bhavissanti ādīni pana cattāri anāgata vasena vuttāni tesam pi purima catukke vutta nayena iva
translated: But the four beginning with “There will be” are spoken of in the way of the future. Their meaning should be understood in the way already stated in the previous tetrad.

original: attho veditabbo. Evamete –
analyzed: atthaḥ veditabbaḥ evam ete
translated: So these are:

original: “Dve diṭṭhisīsā sīsaññe, cattāro sīsamūlakā;
analyzed: dve diṭṭhisīsā sīsaññe cattāro sīsamūlakā
translated: Two with views for their heads, four with heads alone,

original: Tayo tayoti etāni, aṭṭhārasa vibhāvaye.
analyzed: etāni aṭṭhārasa vibhāvaye
translated: Three with three, thus these eighteen He should discern.

original: Etesu hi asasmi, satasmīti ete dve diṭṭhisīsā nāma. Asmi, santi, apihaṃ santi, bhavissanti
analyzed: etesu hi asasmi satasmi iti ete dve diṭṭhisīsāḥ nāma asmi santi apiham santi bhavissanti
translated: For here “I am” and “I am not” are the two with views for their heads. “I am” and “There are” and “There may be” and “There will be”

original: ete cattāro suddhasīsā eva. Itthasmītiādayo tayo tayoti dvādasa sīsamūlakā nāmāti
analyzed: ete cattāro suddha sīsāḥ eva dvādasa sīsamūlakāḥ nāma ati
translated: are the four with heads alone. “Thus am I” and so on are the three with three. These twelve are called “with heads alone.”🔽So these are:🔽two with views for their heads, four with heads alone, twelve with heads alone,

original: evamete dve diṭṭhisīsā cattāro suddhasīsā dvādasa sīsamūlakāti aṭṭhārasa taṇhāvicaritadhammā
analyzed: evam ete dve diṭṭhi sīsā cattāro suddha sīsāḥ dvādasa sīsamūlakā ati aṭṭhārasa taṇhā vicarita dhammā
translated: eighteen ideas that are a footing for craving.

original: veditabbā. Imāni tāva ajjhattikassa upādāya aṭṭhārasa taṇhāvicaritāni. Bāhirassa
analyzed: veditabbā imāni tāva ajjhattikassa upādāya aṭṭhārasa taṇhā vicaritāni bāhirassa
translated: should be understood. These are the eighteen kinds of relishing of the internal.

original: upādāya taṇhāvicaritesupi eseva nayo. Imināti iminā rūpena vā…pe… viññāṇena vāti
analyzed: upādāya taṇhā vicaritesu pi esā iva nayaḥ iminā ati iminā rūpena vā āpe viññāṇena vā ati
translated: In the case of the external, the method is the same. “In this way”: in this way, with this kind of material form, etc.

original: esa viseso veditabbo. Sesaṃ tādisameva.🔽Iti evarūpāni atītāni chattiṃsāti ekamekassa puggalassa atīte addhani chattiṃsa.
analyzed: esa visesaḥ veditabbo sesam tādisam eva  iti evarūpāni atītāni chattiṃsa ati ekam ekassa puggalassa atīte addhani chattiṃsa
translated: This is the difference that should be understood. The rest is the same.🔽Thus there are thirty-six in the past for each individual person.

original: Anāgatāni chattiṃsāti ekamekasseva puggalassa ca anāgate addhani chattiṃsa. Paccuppannāni
analyzed: anāgatāni chattiṃsa ati ekam ekassa iva puggalassa ca anāgate addhani chattiṃsa paccuppannāni
translated: There are thirty-six in the future for each individual person. There are thirty-six in the present

original: chattiṃsāti ekassa vā puggalassa yathāsambhavato bahūnaṃ vā paccuppanne addhani chattiṃsāva.🔽Sabbasattānaṃ pana niyameneva atīte addhani chattiṃsa, anāgate chattiṃsa, paccuppanne
analyzed: chattiṃsā ati ekassa vā puggalassa yathāsambhavataḥ bahūnam vā paccuppanne addhani chattiṃsā ava  sabba sattānam pana niyamena iva atīte addhani chattiṃsa anāgate chattiṃsa paccuppanne
translated: for one person or for many people, according to circumstances.🔽But for all beings there are definitely thirty-six in the past, thirty-six in the future, and thirty-six in the present.

original: chattiṃsa. Anantā hi asadisataṇhāmānadiṭṭhibhedā sattā. Aṭṭhasataṃ taṇhāvicaritaṃ
analyzed: chattiṃsa anantā hi asadisa taṇhā māna diṭṭhi bhedā sattā aṭṭhasatam taṇhā vicaritam
translated: For beings are infinite in variety, with different kinds of craving, conceit, and views. The kinds of relishing of craving are one hundred and eight.

original: hontīti ettha pana aṭṭhasatasaṅkhātaṃ taṇhāvicaritaṃ hotīti evamattho daṭṭhabbo.🔽10. Pemasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: honti iti ettha pana aṭṭha sata saṅkhātam taṇhā vicaritam hoti iti evamatthaḥ daṭṭhabbo  pema sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Discussion of the Thread is ended.

original: 200. Dasame na ussenetīti diṭṭhivasena na ukkhipati. Na paṭisenetīti paṭiviruddho🔽hutvā kalahabhaṇḍanavasena na ukkhipati. Na dhūpāyatīti ajjhattikassa upādāya taṇhāvicaritavasena
analyzed: dasame na usseneti iti diṭṭhi vasena na ukkhipati na paṭiseneti iti paṭiviruddhaḥ  hutvā kalaha bhaṇḍana vasena na ukkhipati na dhūpāyati iti ajjhattikassa upādāya taṇhā vicarita vasena
translated: In the tenth, he does not stab with a knife: he does not stab with a view . He does not stab back: he does not stab back with a view .🔽He does not burn: he does not stab with a view to quarrelling and brawling. He does not smoke: he does not smoke with craving-search based on internal cleaving.

original: na dhūpāyati. Na pajjalatīti bāhirassa upādāya taṇhāvicaritavasena na pajjalati.
analyzed: na dhūpāyati na pajjalati iti bāhirassa upādāya taṇhā vicarita vasena na pajjalati
translated: He does not blaze: he does not blaze with craving-search based on external cleaving.

original: Na sampajjhāyatīti asmimānavasena na sampajjhāyati. Sesaṃ pāḷinayeneva veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: na sampajjhāyati iti asmimāna vasena na sampajjhāyati sesam pāḷi nayena iva veditabbam
translated: He does not glow: he does not glow with conceit based on the self. The rest is as in the text.

original: Imasmiṃ sutte vaṭṭavivaṭṭaṃ kathitanti.
analyzed: imasmin sutte vaṭṭa vivaṭṭam kathitanti
translated: In this Thread the Thread is stated.

original: Mahāvaggo pañcamo.
analyzed: mahā vaggo pañcamaḥ
translated: The Great Chapter is the fifth.

original: Catutthapaṇṇāsakaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ.
analyzed: catuttha paṇṇāsakam niṭṭhitam
translated: The fourth decade is finished.

original: 5. Pañcamapaṇṇāsakaṃ
analyzed: pañcama paṇṇāsakam
translated: The fifth decade

original: (21) 1. Sappurisavaggo
analyzed: sappurisa vaggo
translated: The Chapter of True Men

original: 1-6. Sikkhāpadasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: sikkhāpada sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Discussion of the Training Precepts

original: 201. Pañcamassa paṭhame asappurisanti lāmakapurisaṃ tucchapurisaṃ mūḷhapurisaṃ avijjāya
analyzed: pañcamassa paṭhame lāmaka purisam tuccha purisam mūḷha purisam avijjāya
translated: In the first of the fifth , a non-true man : a low man, a void man, a deluded man, a man of ignorance,

original: andhīkataṃ bālaṃ. Asappurisataranti atirekena asappurisaṃ. Itare dve vuttapaṭipakkhavasena
analyzed: andhīkatam bālam asappurisataranti atirekena asappurisam itare dve vutta paṭipakkha vasena
translated: A fool is one who is blind. A bad person is one who is worse than bad. The other two should be understood in the opposite sense to the above. The rest is clear.

original: veditabbā. Sesamettha uttānatthameva. Yathā cettha, evaṃ ito paresu pañcasu. Etesu
analyzed: veditabbā sesam ettha uttānattham eva yathā ca ittha evam itas paresu pañcasu etesu
translated: And as here, so also in the following five.

original: hi paṭhamaṃ pañcaveravasena desitaṃ, dutiyaṃ assaddhammavasena, tatiyaṃ kāyavacīdvāravasena,
analyzed: hi paṭhamam pañca vera vasena desitam dutiyam assaddhamma vasena tatiyam kāya vacī dvāra vasena
translated: For in the first of these the five lower fetters are taught, in the second the unprofitable state, in the third the bodily and verbal doors,

original: catutthaṃ manodvāravasena, pañcamaṃ aṭṭhamicchattavasena, chaṭṭhaṃ dasamicchattavasena.
analyzed: catuttham manaḥ dvāra vasena pañcamam chaṭṭham dasam icchatta vasena
translated: in the fourth the mental door, in the fifth the eight worldly ideas, and in the sixth the ten worldly ideas.

original: 7-10. Pāpadhammasuttacatukkavaṇṇanā
translated: The fourfold exposition of the unprofitable

original: 207-210. Sattame pāpanti lāmakaṃ saṃkiliṭṭhapuggalaṃ. Kalyāṇanti bhaddakaṃ anavajjapuggalaṃ.🔽Sesamettha uttānatthameva. Aṭṭhamepi eseva nayo. Navame pāpadhammanti lāmakadhammaṃ.
analyzed: sattame pāpanti lāmakam saṃkiliṭṭha puggalam kalyāṇanti bhaddakam anavajja puggalam  sesam ettha uttāna ttham eva aṭṭhame pi esā iva nayaḥ navame pāpa dhammanti lāmaka dhammaṃ
translated: In the seventh, bad is a low, defiled person. Good is an excellent, blameless person.🔽The rest is clear. The same method applies in the eighth. In the ninth, unprofitable ideas are low ideas.

original: Kalyāṇadhammanti anavajjadhammaṃ. Sesamettha uttānatthameva. Dasamepi eseva nayo.
analyzed: kalyāṇa dhammanti anavajja dhammam sesam ettha uttānattham eva dasame pi esā iva nayo
translated: Blameless ideas are excellent ideas. The rest is clear. The same method applies in the tenth.

original: Imasmiṃ vagge dasasupi suttesu agāriyappaṭipadā kathitā. Sacepi sotāpannasakadāgāmino
analyzed: imasmin vagge dasasu pi suttesu agāriya paṭipadā kathitā sace pi sotāpanna sakadāgāmino
translated: In this chapter, the way of life of the house- dweller is taught in the ten sutta-s. Even if they are stream-enterers and once-returners,

original: honti, vaṭṭatiyevāti.🔽Sappurisavaggo paṭhamo.🔽(22) 2. Parisāvaggo
analyzed: honti vaṭṭatiyā iva ati  sappurisa vaggo paṭhamaḥ  parisā vaggo
translated: it is still allowable.🔽The first chapter called “The Chapter of Good People” is concluded.

original: 1. Parisāsuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: parisā sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . The chapter on the assembly🔽. The commentary on the sutta on the assembly

original: 211. Dutiyassa paṭhame parisaṃ dūsentīti parisadūsanā. Parisaṃ sobhentīti parisasobhanā.
analyzed: dutiyassa paṭhame parisam dūsenti iti parisa dūsanā parisam sobhenti iti parisa sobhanā
translated: . They are corrupters of an assembly because they corrupt an assembly. They are ornaments of an assembly because they adorn an assembly.

original: 2. Diṭṭhisuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: diṭṭhi sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . The commentary on the sutta on views

original: 212. Dutiye manoduccarite pariyāpannāpi micchādiṭṭhi mahāsāvajjatāya visuṃ vuttā, tassā ca paṭipakkhavasena sammādiṭṭhi.
analyzed: dutiye manaḥ duccarite pariyāpannā api micchādiṭṭhi mahā sāvajja tāya visum vuttā tassā ca paṭipakkha vasena sammādiṭṭhi
translated: . In the second, wrong view, although included in mental misconduct, is mentioned separately because it is very blameworthy, and right view is its opposite.

original: 3. Akataññutāsuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: akataññutā sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . The commentary on the sutta on ingratitude

original: 213. Tatiye akataññutā akataveditāti akataññutāya akataveditāya. Ubhayampetaṃ atthato ekameva. Sukkapakkhepi eseva nayo.
analyzed: tatiye akataññu tā akata veditā ati akataññu tāya akata veditāya ubhayam petam atthataḥ ekam eva sukka pakkhe pi esa iva nayo
translated: . In the third, ingratitude and unthankfulness are ingratitude and unthankfulness. Both are the same in meaning. The same method applies to the bright side.

original: 4-7. Pāṇātipātīsuttādivaṇṇanā
translated: . The commentary on the sutta on killing living beings, etc.

original: 214-217. Catutthaṃ catunnaṃ kammakilesānaṃ tappaṭipakkhassa ca vasena vuttaṃ, pañcamaṃ
analyzed: catuttham catunnam kamma kilesānam tad paṭipakkhassa ca vasena vuttam pañcamam
translated: . The fourth is stated in terms of the four kinds of defilements of action and their opposites. The fifth is stated in terms of the four kinds of defilements of action and their opposites.

original: sukkapakkhānaṃ ādito catunnaṃ micchattānaṃ vasena, chaṭṭhaṃ avasesānaṃ catunnaṃ,
analyzed: sukkapakkhānam āditas catunnam micchattānam vasena chaṭṭham avasesānam catunnam
translated: The sixth is stated by way of the remaining four.🔽The seventh is stated by way of the unbeneficial and the beneficial.

original: sattamaṃ anariyavohāraariyavohārānaṃ. Tathā aṭṭhamanavamadasamāni sappaṭipakkhānaṃ
analyzed: sattamam anariya vohāra ariyavohārānam tathā aṭṭhama navama dasamāni sa paṭipakkhānam
translated: The eighth and ninth are stated by way of the unprofitable and the profitable.

original: assaddhammānaṃ vasena vuttāni. Sabbasuttesu pana sukkapakkhadhammā lokiyalokuttaramissakāva
translated: In all the Suttas, however, the profitable ideas are stated as a mixture of mundane and supramundane.

original: kathitā. Navasu suttesu kiñcāpi “sagge”ti vuttaṃ, tayo pana maggā tīṇi ca phalāni labbhantiyevāti.
analyzed: kathitā navasu suttesu kiñcā api saggā iti vuttam tayo pana maggā tīṇi ca phalāni
translated: And although in the nine Suttas it is said ‘in heaven’ , still the three paths and the three fruits are obtainable .

original: Parisāvaggo dutiyo.
analyzed: parisā vaggo dutiyaḥ
translated: The Second Division : On the Assembly

original: (23) 3. Duccaritavaggavaṇṇanā
translated: . The Third Division : On Misconduct

original: 221-231. Tatiyassa paṭhamādīni uttānatthāneva. Dasame yo cintetvā kabyaṃ karoti,🔽ayaṃ cintākavi nāma. Yo sutvā karoti, ayaṃ sutakavi nāma. Yo ekaṃ atthaṃ nissāya
analyzed: tatiyassa paṭhama ādīni uttāna tthānā iva dasame yaḥ cintetvā kabyam karoti  ayam cintā kavi nāma yaḥ sutvā karoti ayam suta kavi nāma yaḥ ekam attham nissāya
translated: The first, etc., of the third are evident in meaning. In the tenth, he who composes poetry after thinking it out is called a ‘thinking poet’ .🔽He who composes after hearing it is a ‘hearing poet’ . He who composes after depending on a single meaning is a ‘meaning poet’ .

original: karoti, ayaṃ atthakavi nāma. Yo taṅkhaṇaññeva vaṅgīsatthero viya attano paṭibhānena🔽karoti, ayaṃ paṭibhānakavi nāmāti.
analyzed: karoti ayam attha kavi nāma yaḥ vaṅgīsa theraḥ viya attanaḥ paṭibhānena  karoti ayam paṭibhāna kavi nāma ati
translated: He who composes on the spot like the Elder Vangisa is a ‘inspired poet’ .

original: Duccaritavaggo tatiyo.
analyzed: duccarita vaggaḥ tatiyaḥ
translated: The Third Division : On Misconduct

original: (24) 4. Kammavaggo
analyzed: kamma vaggaḥ
translated: 4. The Chapter about Action

original: 1. Saṃkhittasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: saṃkhitta sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Exposition of the Suttas in Brief

original: 232. Catutthassa paṭhame kaṇhanti kāḷakaṃ dasaakusalakammapathakammaṃ. Kaṇhavipākanti🔽apāye nibbattanato kāḷakavipākaṃ. Sukkanti paṇḍarakaṃ kusalakammapathakammaṃ. Sukkavipākanti
analyzed: catutthassa paṭhame kaṇhanti kāḷakam dasa akusala kammapatha kammam kaṇha vipākam ti  apāye nibbattanataḥ kāḷaka vipākam sukkam ti paṇḍarakam kusala kammapatha kammam sukka vipākam ti
translated: In the first of the fourth group, dark is the tenfold unprofitable action-process. Its ripening is dark:🔽its ripening is black because it leads to rebirth in the states of deprivation. Bright is the tenfold profitable action-process. Its ripening is bright:

original: sagge nibbattanato paṇḍarakavipākaṃ. Kaṇhasukkanti missakakammaṃ. Kaṇhasukkavipākanti
analyzed: sagge nibbattanataḥ paṇḍaraka vipākam kaṇha sukkam ti missaka kammam kaṇha sukka vipākam ti
translated: its ripening is white because it leads to rebirth in the happy destinies. Mixed is mixed action. Its ripening is mixed:

original: sukhadukkhavipākaṃ. Missakakammañhi katvā akusalena tiracchānayoniyaṃ maṅgalahatthiṭṭhānādīsu
analyzed: sukha dukkha vipākam missaka kammañhi katvā akusalena tiracchānayoniyam maṅgala hatthi ṭṭhāna ādīsu
translated: its ripening is mixed because it leads to rebirth in mixed destinies. Having done mixed action, one is reborn in the animal generation in the unprofitable part, as a lucky elephant, etc.,

original: uppanno kusalena pavatte sukhaṃ vediyati. Kusalena rājakulepi nibbatto akusalena
analyzed: uppannaḥ kusalena pavatte sukham vediyati kusalena rāja kule api nibbattaḥ akusalena
translated: and in the profitable part one experiences pleasure. Having done profitable action, one is reborn in a royal family in the unprofitable part,

original: pavatte dukkhaṃ vediyati. Akaṇhaṃ asukkanti kammakkhayakaraṃ catumaggañāṇaṃ adhippetaṃ.
analyzed: pavatte dukkham vediyati a kaṇham a sukkam ti kamma khaya karam catu magga ñāṇam adhippetam
translated: and in the profitable part one experiences pleasure. Neither dark nor bright is the fourfold path. That is intended here.

original: Tañhi yadi kaṇhaṃ bhaveyya, kaṇhavipākaṃ dadeyya. Yadi sukkaṃ bhaveyya, sukkavipākaṃ
analyzed: tat hi yadi kaṇham bhaveyya kaṇha vipākam dadeyya yadi sukkam bhaveyya sukka vipākam
translated: For if it were dark, it would give a dark ripening; if it were bright, it would give a bright ripening.

original: dadeyya. Ubhayavipākassa pana appadānato akaṇhaṃ asukkanti ayamettha attho.
analyzed: dadeyya ubhaya vipākassa pana appadānataḥ a kaṇham a sukkam ti ayam ettha atthaḥ
translated: and he would give. But since it does not give a ripening of both kinds, it is called neither-black-nor-white.

original: 2. Vitthārasuttavaṇṇanā🔽233. Dutiye sabyābajjhanti sadosaṃ. Kāyasaṅkhāranti kāyadvāracetanaṃ. Abhisaṅkharotīti🔽āyūhati sampiṇḍeti. Sesadvayepi eseva nayo. Sabyābajjhaṃ lokanti sadukkhaṃ lokaṃ.🔽Sabyābajjhā phassāti sadukkhā vipākaphassā. Sabyābajjhaṃ vedanaṃ vediyatīti sābādhaṃ🔽vipākavedanaṃ vediyati. Ekantadukkhanti ekanteneva dukkhaṃ, na sukhasammissaṃ. Seyyathāpi
analyzed: vitthāra sutta vaṇṇanā  dutiye sa byābajjhanti sa dosam kāya saṅkhāranti kāya dvāra cetanam abhisaṅkharoti iti  āyūhati sampiṇḍeti sesa dvaye pi esa iva nayaḥ sa byābajjham lokanti sa dukkham lokan  sa byābajjhā phassā ati sa dukkhā vipāka phassā sa byābajjham vedanam vediyati iti sa ābādham  vipāka vedanam vediyati ekanta dukkham ti ekantena iva dukkham na sukha sammissam seyyathā api
translated: The detailed explanation of the second sutta

original: sattā nerayikāti ettha seyyathāpīti nidassanatthe nipāto. Tena kevalaṃ nerayikasatte🔽dasseti, aññe pana taṃsarikkhakā nāma natthi. Iminā upāyena sabbattha attho veditabbo.
analyzed: sattā nerayikā ti ettha seyyathā api iti nidassana atthe nipāto tena kevalam nerayika satte  dasseti aññe pana taṃsarikkhakāḥ nāma natthi iminā upāyena sabbattha atthaḥ veditabbo
translated: In the second sutta, “with hate” is with hatefulness. “Formations of body” is volition in the door of the body. “He forms” is he generates, he combines. The same method applies in the other two cases. “The world with hate” is the world with suffering. “With hate” is with suffering as its result. “He feels a feeling with hate” is he feels a resultant feeling that is painful. “Entirely painful” is only painful, not mixed with pleasure. “Just as” is a demonstrative particle. By it he shows only beings in hell. But there are none like them. The meaning should be understood in this way in all the other cases too.

original: Seyyathāpi manussātiādīsu pana manussānaṃ tāva kālena sukhā vedanā uppajjati, kālena
analyzed: seyyathā api manussa ati ādīsu pana manussānam tāva kālena sukhā vedanā uppajjati kālena
translated: In the case of the words “Just as if, bhikkhus, men were to bring beings … from the human world and set them down in the animal world” , pleasure arises for human beings sometimes,

original: dukkhā vedanā. Ekacce ca devāti ettha pana kāmāvacaradevā daṭṭhabbā. Tesañhi mahesakkhatarā🔽devatā disvā nisinnāsanato vuṭṭhānaṃ, pārutauttarāsaṅgassa otāraṇaṃ, añjalipaggaṇhanantiādīnaṃ🔽vasena kālena dukkhaṃ uppajjati, dibbasampattiṃ anubhavantānaṃ kālena sukhaṃ. Ekacce
analyzed: dukkhāḥ vedanāḥ ekacce ca deva ti ettha pana kāmāvacara devā daṭṭhabbā tesam hi mahesakkhatarā  devatāḥ disvā nisinna āsanataḥ vuṭṭhānam pāruta uttarāsaṅgassa otāraṇam añjali paggaṇhana nti ādīnam  vasena kālena dukkham uppajjati dibba sampattim anubhavantānam kālena sukham ekacce
translated: and painful feeling. “Some gods” here should be understood as sense-sphere gods. For when they see a deity of high rank,🔽pain arises for them by way of the necessity of rising from their seats, of putting on their upper robes, of raising their joined palms, etc.,

original: ca vinipātikāti ettha vemānikapetā daṭṭhabbā. Te nirantarameva ekasmiṃ kāle sukhaṃ,
analyzed: ca vinipātikā ati ettha vemānika petā daṭṭhabbā te nirantaram eva ekasmin kāle sukham
translated: and pleasure arises for them by way of the experience of divine glory. “Some beings in the lower worlds” here should be understood as petas. They experience pleasure and pain continuously at one time,

original: ekasmiṃ kāle dukkhaṃ vediyanti. Nāgasupaṇṇahatthiassādayo pana manussā viya vokiṇṇasukhadukkhāva
analyzed: ekasmin kāle dukkham vediyanti nāga supaṇṇa hatthi assa ādayaḥ pana manussāḥ viya vokiṇṇa sukha dukkhā ava
translated: but not at another. Nāgas, supaṇṇas, elephants, horses, etc., are mixed in their pleasure and pain, like human beings.

original: honti. Pahānāya yā cetanāti ettha vivaṭṭagāminī maggacetanā veditabbā. Sā hi kammakkhayāya saṃvattatīti.🔽3. Soṇakāyanasuttavaṇṇanā🔽234. Tatiye sikhāmoggallānoti sīsamajjhe ṭhitāya mahatiyā sikhāya samannāgato moggallānagotto
analyzed: honti pahānāya yā cetanā ati ettha vivaṭṭa gāminī magga cetanā veditabbā sā hi kamma kkhayāya saṃvattati iti 🔽soṇakāyana sutta vaṇṇanā 🔽tatiye sikhā moggallānaḥ ti sīsa majjhe ṭhitāya mahatiyā sikhāya samannāgataḥ moggallāna gotto
translated: “The volition for abandoning” should be understood here as the volition of the path that leads to the turning away from kamma. It is this that leads to the exhaustion of kamma.

original: brāhmaṇo. Purimānīti atītānantaradivasato paṭṭhāya purimāni, dutiyādito paṭṭhāya
analyzed: brāhmaṇaḥ purimāni iti atīta anantara divasataḥ paṭṭhāya purimāni dutiya āditaḥ paṭṭhāya
translated: The earlier: the earlier days beginning with the second day next before the day of the question.

original: purimatarāni veditabbāni. Soṇakāyanoti tasseva antevāsiko. Kammasaccāyaṃ bho lokoti🔽bho ayaṃ loko kammasabhāvo. Kammasamārambhaṭṭhāyīti kammasamārambhena tiṭṭhati. Kammaṃ
analyzed: purimatarāni veditabbāni soṇakāyano ti tassa iva antevāsiko kamma saccā ayam bho loko ti  bho ayam lokaḥ kamma sabhāvaḥ kamma samārambha ṭṭhāyī iti kamma samārambhena tiṭṭhati kammam
translated: The brahmin’s pupil Soṇakāyana is called. The world is devoted to the deed, Master Gotama:

original: āyūhantova tiṭṭhati, anāyūhanto ucchijjatīti dīpeti. Sesaṃ heṭṭhā vuttanayameva.
analyzed: āyūhantaḥ iva tiṭṭhati an āyūhantaḥ ucchijjati iti dīpeti sesam heṭṭhā vutta nayam eva
translated: this world is of the nature of deeds. It stands by the performance of deeds: it stands by the performance of deeds, is what is meant. It is said that it stands by the accumulation of deeds, not by the non-accumulation of deeds. The rest is as already stated.

original: 4-9. Sikkhāpadasuttādivaṇṇanā🔽235. Catutthādīnipi uttānatthāneva. Maggaṅgesu pana yasmā satiyā upaṭṭhapetvā paññāya
analyzed: sikkhāpada sutta ādi vaṇṇanā  catuttha ādīni pi uttāna tthānā eva maggaṅgesu pana yasmā satiyā upaṭṭhapetvā paññāya
translated: The explanation of the Sikkhāpada Sutta, etc.,

original: paricchindati, tasmā ubhayameva kammaṃ. Sesā aṅgāneva honti, no kammanti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: paricchindati tasmai ubhayam eva kammam sesāḥ honti no kammanti vuttam
translated: The fourth and the rest are obvious in meaning. But as regards the path factors, since it is by means of mindfulness that one establishes and by means of understanding that one defines, therefore both are action. The remaining factors are only factors, not action, it is said.

original: Bojjhaṅgesupi eseva nayo. Abhidhamme pana sabbampetaṃ avisesena cetanāsampayuttakammanteva vaṇṇitaṃ.
analyzed: bojjhaṅgesu pi esa iva nayaḥ abhidhamme pana sabbam petam avisesena cetanā sampayutta kammantā iva vaṇṇitam
translated: The same method applies to the enlightenment factors. But in the Abhidhamma all this is described without distinction as action that is associated with volition.

original: 10. Samaṇasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: samaṇa sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the Samaṇa Sutta

original: 241. Dasame idhevāti imasmiṃyeva sāsane. Ayaṃ pana niyamo sesapadesupi veditabbo.
analyzed: dasame idha iva ati imasmin yeva sāsane ayam pana niyamaḥ sesa padesu pi veditabbo
translated: In the tenth, here: in this dispensation. But this restriction should be understood to apply to the other terms too.🔽For the second and the rest are ascetics here, not elsewhere.

original: Dutiyādayopi hi samaṇā idheva, na aññattha. Suññāti rittā tucchā. Parappavādāti cattāro🔽sassatavādā, cattāro ekaccasassatikā, cattāro antānantikā, cattāro amarāvikkhepikā,
analyzed: dutiya ādayaḥ api hi samaṇāḥ idha iva na aññattha suññā ati rittā tucchā parappavādā ati cattāro  sassatavādā cattāraḥ ekaccasassatikā cattāraḥ antānantikā cattāraḥ amarāvikkhepikā
translated: Empty: void, hollow. Other doctrines:

original: dve adhiccasamuppannikā, soḷasa saññivādā, aṭṭha asaññivādā, aṭṭha nevasaññināsaññivādā,
analyzed: dve adhiccasamuppannikā soḷasa saññi vādāḥ aṭṭha asaññi vādāḥ aṭṭha nevasaññi nāsaññi vādāḥ
translated: the four eternalist doctrines, the four doctrines of partial eternalism, the four doctrines of endless equivocation, the four doctrines of non-causality, the two doctrines of fortuitous origination, the sixteen doctrines of the theorists of consciousness, the eight doctrines of the theorists of non-percipient eternalism, the eight doctrines of the theorists of neither-percipient-nor-non-percipient eternalism,

original: satta ucchedavādā, pañca diṭṭhadhammanibbānavādāti ime sabbepi brahmajāle āgatadvāsaṭṭhidiṭṭhiyo
analyzed: satta uccheda vādā pañca diṭṭhadhamma nibbāna vādā ti ime sabbe pi brahmajāle āgata dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhiyaḥ
translated: the seven doctrines of annihilationism, and the five doctrines of the self-mortifiers who are Nibbuan here and now. All these sixty-two views given in the Brahmajāla Sutta

original: ito bāhirānaṃ paresaṃ pavādā parappavādā nāma. Te sabbepi imehi catūhi phalaṭṭhakasamaṇehi
analyzed: itas bāhirānam paresam pavādāḥ parappavādāḥ nāma te sabbe pi imehi catūhi phalaṭṭhaka samaṇehi
translated: are the doctrines of others, of outsiders. They are all empty of these four kinds of fruit-attainer ascetics.

original: suññā. Na hi te ettha santi. Na kevalañca eteheva suññā, catūhi pana maggaṭṭhakasamaṇehipi,
analyzed: suññāḥ na hi te ettha santi na kevalam ca etehi iva suññā catūhi pana maggaṭṭhaka samaṇehi pi
translated: For they are not found there. And not only are they empty of these, but also of the four kinds of path-attainer ascetics.

original: catunnaṃ maggānaṃ atthāya āraddhavipassakehipīti dvādasahipi samaṇehi suññā eva.
analyzed: catunnam maggānaṃ atthāya āraddha vipassakehi pi iti dvādasahi api samaṇehi suññā eva
translated: and for the four paths, and for those who have begun insight for the sake of the four paths, that is, for twelve kinds of men, it is empty of them.

original: Idameva atthaṃ sandhāya bhagavatā mahāparinibbāne vuttaṃ –
analyzed: idam eva attham sandhāya bhagavatā mahāparinibbāne vuttam
translated: With this meaning the Blessed One said in the Great Passing:

original: “Ekūnatiṃso vayasā subhadda,
analyzed: ekūnatiṃsaḥ vayasā su bhadda
translated: “Subhadda, when I was nineteen,

original: Yaṃ pabbajiṃ kiṃkusalānuesī;
analyzed: yam pabbajim kiṃkusala anuesī
translated: Seeking what is skillful I went forth.

original: Vassāni paññāsa samādhikāni,
analyzed: vassāni paññāsa samādhikāni
translated: Fifty-one years have passed

original: Yato ahaṃ pabbajito subhadda;
analyzed: yatas aham pabbajitaḥ su bhadda
translated: Since I went forth, Subhadda,

original: Ñāyassa dhammassa padesavattī,
analyzed: ñāyassa dhammassa padesavattī
translated: And I have been a wanderer in the doctrine of what is right,

original: Ito bahiddhā samaṇopi natthi”.
analyzed: itas bahiddhā samaṇaḥ api natthi
translated: Outside of this there is no other wanderer” .

original: “Dutiyopi samaṇo natthi, tatiyopi samaṇo natthi, catutthopi samaṇo natthi, suññā
analyzed: dutiyaḥ api samaṇaḥ natthi tatiyaḥ api samaṇaḥ natthi catutthaḥ api samaṇaḥ natthi suññā
translated: “There is no second wanderer, there is no third wanderer, there is no fourth wanderer,

original: parappavādā samaṇehi aññehī”ti. Ettha hi padesavattīti āraddhavipassako adhippeto.🔽Tasmā sotāpattimaggassa āraddhavipassakaṃ maggaṭṭhaṃ phalaṭṭhanti tayopi ekato katvā
analyzed: parappavādā samaṇehi aññehi iti ettha hi padesa vattī iti āraddha vipassakaḥ adhippeto  tasmā sotāpatti maggassa āraddha vipassakam maggaṭṭham phalaṭṭhanti tayo pi ekatas katvā
translated: other sects are empty of wanderers” . Herein, “a wanderer in the doctrine of what is right” is one who has begun insight.🔽So he said “there is no wanderer” with reference to the stream-enterer, taking the one who has begun insight for the path and the one who has reached the path and the one who has reached the fruition as three.

original: “samaṇopi natthī”ti āha, sakadāgāmimaggassa āraddhavipassakaṃ maggaṭṭhaṃ phalaṭṭhanti
analyzed: samaṇaḥ api na atthi iti āha sakadāgāmi maggassa āraddha vipassakam maggaṭṭham phala ṭṭham
translated: And with reference to the once-returner, taking the one who has begun insight for the path and the one who has reached the path and the one who has reached the fruition as three,

original: tayopi ekato katvā “dutiyopi samaṇo natthī”ti āha. Itaresupi dvīsu eseva nayo. Ekādasamaṃ uttānatthamevāti.
analyzed: tayo api ekatas katvā dutiyaḥ pi samaṇaḥ natthi iti āha itaresu pi dvīsu esa iva nayo ekādasamam uttānattham eva ati
translated: and he said, “There is no second recluse.” The same method applies in the case of the other two. The meaning of the eleventh is plain.

original: Kammavaggo catuttho.
analyzed: kamma vaggaḥ catutthaḥ
translated: The fourth chapter on legal issues is finished.

original: (25) 5. Āpattibhayavaggo
analyzed: āpatti bhaya vaggaḥ
translated: The chapter on the danger of offenses

original: 1. Saṅghabhedakasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: saṅghabhedaka sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The sutta on schism in the Sangha

original: 243. Pañcamassa paṭhame api nu taṃ, ānanda, adhikaraṇanti vivādādhikaraṇādīsu aññataraṃ🔽adhikaraṇaṃ bhikkhusaṅghassa uppajji, satthā tassa vūpasantabhāvaṃ pucchanto evamāha.
analyzed: pañcamassa paṭhame api nu tam ānanda adhikaraṇan ti vivāda adhikaraṇa ādīsu aññataram  adhikaraṇam bhikkhu saṅghassa uppajji satthā tassa vūpasanta bhāvam pucchantaḥ evam āha
translated: In the first of the fifth chapter, “Was there any legal issue for the Sangha of monks?” refers to any of the four kinds of legal issues.🔽The Buddha is asking whether the issue has been resolved.

original: Kuto taṃ, bhanteti, bhante, kuto kinti kena kāraṇena taṃ adhikaraṇaṃ vūpasamissatīti
analyzed: kutas tam bhante iti bhante kutas kinti kena kāraṇena tam adhikaraṇam vūpasamissati iti
translated: “Where, Sir, will that legal issue be settled?” He is asking, “For what reason will that legal issue be settled?”🔽“In the whole of the territory”: in the whole area.

original: vadati. Kevalakappanti sakalaṃ samantato. Saṅghabhedāya ṭhitoti saṅghena saddhiṃ🔽vādatthāya kathitaṃ paṭikathentova ṭhito. Tatrāyasmāti tasmiṃ evaṃ ṭhite āyasmā anuruddho.
analyzed: vadati sakalam samantataḥ saṅgha bhedāya ṭhitaḥ iti saṅghena saddhim  vādatthāya kathitam tatra ayasmā iti tasmin evam ṭhite anuruddhaḥ
translated: “He stands in schism in the Sangha”: he stands in opposition to the Sangha,🔽arguing against what the Sangha has said.

original: Na ekavācikampi bhaṇitabbaṃ maññatīti “mā, āvuso, saṅghena saddhiṃ evaṃ avacā”ti
analyzed: na eka vācikam pi bhaṇitabbam maññati iti mā āvuso saṅghena saddhim evam avacāti
translated: “The Venerable Anuruddha thought that not a word should be spoken”: “Friends, don’t argue with the Sangha.”

original: ekavacanampi vattabbaṃ na maññati. Voyuñjatīti anuyuñjati anuyogaṃ āpajjati. Atthavaseti
analyzed: ekavacanam pi vattabbam na maññati voyuñjati iti anuyuñjati anuyogam āpajjati attha vasā iti
translated: He does not think that even a single word should be spoken. He presses: he presses for an investigation, he brings about an investigation. On the grounds of:

original: kāraṇavase. Nāsessantīti uposathappavāraṇaṃ upagantuṃ adatvā nikkaḍḍhissanti. Sesaṃ

But since the elder is desirous of entering the forest and practicing the life of a recluse only when he is old, the Exalted One is said to “extol” the elder by this statement: “What shall we say of the young? This son of ours, Malunkyaputta, is desirous of entering the forest and practicing the life of a recluse even when he is old. But you, though young, do not exert yourselves.”
